The Complete Collection of Ancient and Modern Books: Volume 111

On the Art of Metaphysics

Huangdi's Basic Questions

The Great Discussion on the Five Movements

Huangdi sat in the Ming Hall, beginning to establish the celestial principles, observing the eight directions, and considering the establishment of the five constants. He asked the heavenly teacher: "Speaking of the movements and stillness of Heaven and Earth, the wise spirits are the recorders of these. The ascent and descent of Yin and Yang, cold and heat reveal their signs." I have heard about the numbers of the five movements from my teacher, who spoke of how each of the five energies governs the respective years. The first cycle establishes the movements: Earth governs the first and sixth, Metal governs the second and seventh, Water governs the third and eighth, Wood governs the fourth and ninth, and Fire governs the fifth and tenth.[1p]
At the time of Zi and Wu, the Lesser Yin governs; at the time of Chou and Wei, the Greater Yin governs; at the time of Yin and Shen, the Lesser Yang governs; at the time of Mao and You, the Yangming governs; at the time of Chen and Xu, the Greater Yang governs; at the time of Si and Hai, the Jueyin governs. What is the reason for the disharmony of Yin and Yang?

(Note: I have heard about the numbers of the Five Movements from the Master, who said that the Qi of the Five Movements has already been discussed in the theory of the Six Seasonal Organs; thus, I will explain it. Guiyuqu again discusses the Five Movements and Six Qis in relation to the years, which is known as the Grand Treatise on the Celestial Origin. The disharmony of Yin and Yang arises when the Yin-Yang of the Five Movements and Six Qis do not align.)

Qibo said: This is the clarified way. This is the Yin and Yang of Heaven and Earth. As for the quantifiable numbers, they represent the Yin and Yang within humans. Thus, the harmonious numbers can be obtained. Yin and Yang are quantifiable to ten, extrapolated to a hundred, quantifiable to a thousand, extrapolated to ten thousand.[2p]
The yin and yang of heaven and earth cannot be quantified; they are understood through symbols. The discussion in the text refers to the five movements and six atmospheres that interact and govern, illustrating the principles of yin and yang in the universe. The quantifiable yin and yang are those within humans. This human yin and yang give rise to the five elements and three vital energies. Three relates to heaven, three relates to earth, and three relates to humanity. When threes combine, they form nine. Nine divides into nine regions, which correspond to the nine organs, aligning with the six divisions of heaven. This represents the harmony between human yin and yang and the cosmos, where the quantities can indeed be counted. However, the yin and yang of heaven and earth are vast—countable in tens and hundreds, and extrapolated into the thousands and tens of thousands—making them beyond mere quantification, understood only through symbolic representation.[3p]
The symbol of the celestial phenomena refers to the red, black, blue, white, and original celestial phenomena discussed in the following text, which represent the southern and northern diagrams. The Emperor said, "I wish to know their origins." Qi Bo replied, "Your question is indeed profound! I have reviewed the text of the 'Records of the Original Celestial Elements': The red celestial energy travels through the Ox, the Maiden, and the Wu division; the black celestial energy travels through the Heart, the Tail, and the Ji division; the blue celestial energy travels through the Danger, the Room, the Willow, and the Ghost; the white celestial energy travels through the Ascendant, the Earth, the Spirits, and the End; the original celestial energy travels through the Zhang, the Ji, the Lou, and the Stomach. The so-called Wu and Ji division refers to the Well, the Jade, the Horn, and the Chariot, which are the gates of Heaven and Earth. The origin of these signs and the generation of the Way must not be overlooked. This discusses the transformation of the five elements, which begins from the celestial signs of the five directions. Red represents fire energy. The Ox and the Maiden are at the point of Gui, traveling through the Ox and Maiden Wu division; the combination of Wu and Gui transforms into fire. Black represents earth energy.[4p]
The heart and tail are at the position of Jia, linked to the heart and tail; when they are separated, Jia and Ji unite to transform into earth. Cang, the color blue, is the essence of wood. Wei and Shi are at the position of Ren, while Liu and Gui are at the position of Ding; Ding and Ren unite to transform into wood. Su, the color white, is the essence of metal. Kang and Di are at the position of Yi, while Mao and Bi are at the position of Geng; Yi and Geng unite to transform into metal. Yuan, the color black, is the essence of water. Zhang and Ji are at the position of Bing, while Lou and Wei are at the position of Xin; Bing and Xin unite to transform into water. Wu and Ji occupy the central palace, serving as the gateways of heaven and earth. The "Dun Jia Jing" states: six Wu form the heavenly gate, six Ji form the earthly door, located in the divisions of Kui, Bi, Jiao, and Zhen. Kui and Bi are in the Kan direction, while Jiao and Zhen are in the Xun direction; these five essences transform to initiate the five elements, being the origin of the yin and yang of heaven and earth, which must not be disregarded. The Emperor said: Excellent.[5p]
The discussion of heaven and earth refers to the upper and lower aspects of all things and their left and right, which are the pathways of yin and yang. One does not yet understand what this means.

[Note: This also discusses the upper and lower aspects of the six qi. Heaven is above, at the spring it is below, and all things are generated in between, hence heaven and earth are the upper and lower of all things. The left and right refer to the interstitial qi; the interstitial qi is the marker of movement, thus it is called the pathway of yin and yang.]

Qibo said: What is referred to as upper and lower is seen throughout the year, indicating where yin and yang exist.

[Note: This reflects on the positioning of the heavenly controls in relation to the springs. For example, in the year of Zi-Wu, Shaoyin is above, while Yangming is below; in the year of Chou-Wei, Taiyin is above, while Taiyang is below; in the year of Yin-Shen, Shaoyang is above, while Jueyin is below; in the year of Yin-Yin, Yangming is above, while Shaoyin is below; in the year of Chen-Xu, Taiyang is above, while Taiyin is below; in the year of Si-Hai, Jueyin is above, while Shaoyang is below.][6p]
The text discusses the positions of various energies or elements based on orientation. When facing north, the arrangement is as follows:

  • When Xuéyīn is on top, Shǎoyīn is to the left, and Tàiyáng is to the right.
  • When Shǎoyīn is on top, Tàiyīn is to the left, and Xuéyīn is to the right.
  • When Tàiyīn is on top, Shǎoyáng is to the left, and Shǎoyīn is to the right.
  • When Shǎoyáng is on top, Yángmíng is to the left, and Tàiyīn is to the right.
  • When Yángmíng is on top, Tàiyáng is to the left, and Shǎoyáng is to the right.
  • When Tàiyáng is on top, Xuéyīn is to the left, and Yángmíng is to the right.

This indicates how the positions relate depending on the direction one faces, with the east representing left and the west representing right.[7p]
The text describes the orientation of images according to cardinal directions. When facing south, one's face is to the north to observe the representations, indicating their positions in relation to top, bottom, left, and right. The Emperor asks, "What is considered 'down'?" Qi Bo explains: when Jue Yin is above, Shao Yang is below, with Yang Ming on the left and Tai Yin on the right; when Shao Yin is above, Yang Ming is below, with Tai Yang on the left and Shao Yang on the right; when Tai Yin is above, Tai Yang is below, with Jue Yin on the left and Yang Ming on the right; when Shao Yang is above, Jue Yin is below, with Shao Yin on the left and Tai Yang on the right; when Yang Ming is above, Shao Yin is below, with Tai Yin on the left and Jue Yin on the right; when Tai Yang is above, Tai Yin is below, with Shao Yang on the left and Shao Yin on the right. This describes the positions by facing south and indicating what is observed. The note clarifies the relative positions of left and right below: for instance, in the year of Si and Hai, Jue Yin is above, hence Shao Yang is below, with Yang Ming to the left of Shao Yang and Tai Yin to the right.[8p]
In the Year of the Rat and the Horse, when Lesser Yin is above, then Greater Yang is below; and Greater Yang is to the left of Greater Yin, while Lesser Yang is to the right. In the Year of the Ox and the Sheep, when Greater Yin is above, then Greater Yang is below; and Lesser Yin is to the left of Greater Yang, while Greater Yang is to the right. In the Year of the Tiger and the Monkey, when Lesser Yang is above, then Lesser Yin is below; and Lesser Yin is to the left of Lesser Yin, while Greater Yang is to the right. In the Year of the Rabbit and the Rooster, when Greater Yang is above, then Lesser Yin is below; and Greater Yin is to the left of Lesser Yin, while Lesser Yin is to the right. In the Year of the Dragon and the Dog, when Greater Yang is above, then Greater Yin is below; and Lesser Yang is to the left of Greater Yin, while Lesser Yin is to the right. This is because the diagram faces north, and people face south to observe it.[9p]
Based on what is seen above and below, left and right, their positions are determined; hence it is said to articulate what is seen.

When the upper and lower elements encounter each other, and the cold and heat come together, the energy harmonizes if they are compatible, but if they are not, illness arises.

The reference to "coming together" refers to the six atmospheric energies. It indicates that when the energies from the heavens meet with those of the springs, the upper and lower energies encounter each other, and the energies between left and right also interact, then the four seasons come together. For example, when the energy of the sun and the cold water interacts in the first half of the year, the energies of lesser yin and lesser yang related to warmth and heat also come forth in the second half of the year. Conversely, if the energy of warmth prevails in the first half of the year, then the cold water energy emerges in the second half.

By considering the elements of cold and heat, the six energies are sequenced, primarily focusing on the upper and lower elements of the year, while the six energies on the left and right mark the passage of time. When they align with the season, harmony occurs; when they are opposed, illness arises.

The emperor asked: "What does it mean when incompatible energies cause illness?" Qibo replied: "When the lower influences extend upwards, it is not in proper position."[10p]
The note states that there is a connection and a disconnection between the six qi influenced by the incoming energy and the six qi of the governing time. When the qi are in harmony, it is like the qi of the Lesser Yin's fire associating with the qi of the Lesser Yang's fire, representing the relationship between sovereign and minister. The sovereign's position is above, while the minister's position is below; when the sovereign fire influences the minister fire above it, this is in accordance with the order. Conversely, when the minister fire influences the sovereign fire above it, this is an improper inversion of their positions. The "Essence of the Six Subtleties" states: a sovereign above is in accordance, while a minister above is in opposition. Opposition brings immediate illness and swift harm; accordance brings distant illness and subtle harm. This refers to the two types of fire.

The Emperor then asked: "What about movement and stillness?" Qibo replied: "The one above moves right, while the one below moves left. When they move around the celestial sphere, they eventually converge again."

The note states that movement and stillness are the principles of heaven and earth. The overarching entity governs the heavens, while the lower entity governs the earth.[11p]
If you are young and yin is above, then yangming must be below. The 365 days of the celestial cycle: those above move right in accordance with the moon; those below move left in accordance with the sun. The cycles of heaven move in six-year intervals, still accounting for the six years of noon, mid-afternoon, evening, dusk, night, and midnight, which then turn back to meet once more.

The Emperor said: I have heard that in the area of the ghost’s division, what responds to the earth is stillness. Now you say that those below move to the left; I do not understand what you mean. I wish to hear how this comes to be.

(Note: Stillness is the essence of the earth. Birth refers to what arises from movement.)

Qibo said: The movement and stillness of heaven and earth, and the changes of the five elements—although the ghostly division above observes these, it still cannot fully illuminate them.

(Note: The movement and stillness of heaven and earth refer to the qi of the springs surrounding and rotating the earth. The changes of the five elements refer to the cyclical and repeated transitions of the five phases.)[12p]
The above mentions that in a brief moment up to ten generations, one can only predict the movements of the heavens and the still forms of the earth; yet, one cannot fully comprehend the operations of heaven and earth, yin and yang. The function of transformation manifests in the heavens as signs and in the earth as forms; the seven luminaries weave through the void, and the five elements flourish on the earth. The earth is that which bears all living forms. The void is that which aligns with the essence and energy of heaven. The movement of form and essence is akin to the roots and branches of a tree. By gazing up at their signs, even distant knowledge can be attained.

(Note: The use of transformation refers to the movement of heaven and earth’s yin and yang. In heaven, it is formless and manifests as signs; in earth, it has form and becomes established. The seven luminaries refer to the sun, moon, and five planets. The void is the space that is woven between the great void, also rotating around the earth. The five elements are the forms that arise from the five directions and their corresponding energies. The earth is that which bears all living things.)[13p]
The essence is the refined water born of the One in Heaven. The essence and energy responding to Heaven are, above, the energy, and below, the water. Water responds to Heaven, and thus Heaven connects to water. The form is called the body of the Earth, tranquil and unmoving. The movement of the essence within the form refers to the swirling of the subterranean energy at springs, as the roots remain still while the branches and leaves sway, yet the root energy is interconnected with the branches and leaves. Looking up to observe the celestial phenomena, one sees the sun, moon, and five stars revolving around the Earth in a clockwise motion; though the path is deep and distant, it is knowable.

The Emperor said: Is the Earth indeed below? Qibo replied: The Earth is below for mankind; it exists within the great void. The Emperor asked: What supports it? Qibo replied: It is upheld by the great energy.

(Note: The statement about the Earth being below refers to Heaven being above and the Earth below. The great void refers to the essence of emptiness, indicating that the Earth exists within this void, upheld by great energy, without any support.)[14p]
According to the "Theory of the Universe," it is said: The shape of heaven resembles a bird's egg, with the earth contained within; heaven wraps around the earth like the egg white surrounding the yolk, round like a pellet, hence it is called the "Harmonious Sky." This indicates that its form is holistic; its principle suggests that heaven covers half of the earth above, and half is below. Above ground, heaven is observed at an angle of one hundred eighty-two and a half degrees, and the same is true underground. The North Pole rises thirty-six degrees above ground, while the South Pole descends thirty-six degrees below ground, with Mount Song situated exactly at the zenith of heaven.

Drought dries it, heat steams it, wind moves it, moisture moistens it, cold hardens it, and fire warms it. Thus, wind and cold are below, dryness and heat are above, humidity is in the middle, and fire moves among them; cold and heat both enter the mix, leading to the vacuity that fosters transformation.

(Note: Wind, cold, heat, humidity, dryness, and fire are formless qi in heaven. Dryness, steaming, movement, moistening, hardening, and warming are the tangible signs of earth.)[15p]
Heaven envelops the earth, which is why it exists above the sky, below the springs, and among the land, beyond the eight extremes, and within the six directions, reaching everywhere. This refers to the vastness of the void, which not only encompasses the outside of the earth but also penetrates through its depths. Cold water lies below, while wind arises from the interaction of earth and water, thus cold winds reside beneath. Dryness corresponds to the energy of the dry metal, while heat corresponds to the fire of the sun, hence dry heat is above. Soil occupies the center, so moisture resides within. Fire is the primal Yang of the supreme ultimate, that is, the vital energy of heaven, thus it moves between above and below. The Book of Changes states: "The sun and moon move in cycles, one cold and one hot." As cold and heat alternate, the energies of the six elements all enter the earth, allowing the tangible earth to receive the intangible void energy, and thus engender all things. Therefore, when dryness prevails, the land becomes dry; when heat prevails, the land becomes hot; when wind prevails, the land moves; when moisture prevails, the land turns muddy; when cold prevails, the land cracks; when fire prevails, the land solidifies.

(Note: This also relates back to the previous mention of the six entries.)[16p]
The Emperor said: How can one assess the qi of Heaven and Earth? Qi Bo replied: The qi of Heaven and Earth is the product of triumph and renewal, and it cannot be captured in diagnosis. The method of pulse diagnosis states: The changes of Heaven and Earth cannot be diagnosed through the pulse. This is what it means.

[Note: The qi of Heaven and Earth refers to the five movements and six qi. The creator of triumph and renewal refers to excessive victory and stagnation. It is said that the changes in qi and movements that cause the people's ailments cannot be known through diagnosis. Each year has the six qi governed by the celestial officials, the five movements governed by the annual patron, the added influences of intermediate qi, and the main qi of the four seasons. When individuals are caught in the interplay of the qi of Heaven and Earth, if one qi is disharmonious, it leads to ailments among the people. Thus, the qi of the four seasonal atmospheres causes the people's ailments, which cannot be diagnosed through pulses but rather indicates the disharmony of specific qi.][17p]
The text states: "Regarding diseases caused by hidden pathogens, they are assessed through intention. If there is a hidden pathogen within the month, assuming there was already a latent condition, pulse examination must be conducted. The energies of heaven and earth, when excessive, will suppress opposing energies, leading to latent conditions. The people affected will experience illness from this suppressed state, which does not manifest during diagnosis. Therefore, to understand diseases caused by hidden pathogens, one must intuitively assess them, observing any disharmonies of energy within the month, thus recognizing the presence of latent illness among the people. When the suppressed energy flares up and illness begins, it will then become recognizable in the pulse. Hence, it is stated: if there was already a hidden pathogen, pulse examination must be conducted. This is different from sudden issues caused by external forces like wind, cold, heat, or dampness, which can immediately show up during pulse diagnosis. Therefore, it is said: the energies of heaven and earth cannot be diagnosed through pulse examination. It is with this understanding." The emperor then asked: "What about intermittent energy?"[18p]
Note: The term "intermediary qi" refers to the six qi added to the existing conditions. The qi applies both above and below, and the combination forms six qi, which is why it is termed "intermediary qi." Each qi pertains to one of the four seasons and governs a period of sixty days, thus the term "intermediary qi" is related to the measurement of time. It is based on the understanding that sixty days plus eighty-seven and a half ke constitutes a single step.

Qi Bo said: The location of the qi is to be considered on the left and right sides.

Note: The "Six Subtle Principles" states: above the heavenly axis, the heavenly qi governs; below the heavenly axis, the earthly qi governs. It also states: "addition" refers to earthly qi, while "middle" pertains to heavenly qi. The qi below turns left, while the qi above rotates right, each governing sixty days to complete a year. Thus, it is said to observe the position of qi and consider the left and right rotations. For instance, in the year of the Rat, if the Lesser Yin is above, then the Yangming is below. If the Lesser Yin is above, then the Jueyin is on the left and the Taiyin is on the right. With Yangming below, the Taiyang is on the left and the Shaoyang is on the right.[19p]
The essence of the earth turns to the left, governing the initial qi, which is why the sun presides over the first day of the first month, with the first moment in the sub-chamber of the tiger representing the beginning. Next is Jueyin, followed by Shaoyin, in charge of the heavenly qi, completing the three qi and overseeing the year above half. Following that is Taiyin, then Shaoyang, and finally Yangming, which governs the qi of the springs, completing the six qi and overseeing the year below half. Each is supplemented by an additional sixty days to finalize a year. The six qi circulate in the same manner.

The Emperor asked: How is the period determined? Qibo replied: Following its qi brings harmony; opposing it leads to disease.

Note: The interstitial qi is the guest qi that accompanies the main. During a year, there are also the six qi that govern the times. If the main follows its guests, harmony prevails; if it goes against them, illness arises. For instance, in the Year of the Rat and Horse, the initial qi, associated with the cold water of the sun, governs the qi related to Jueyin, which is connected to wind and wood. If cold dominates wind, it aligns; if wind overcomes cold, it is contrary. Hence, it is stated in the lower scriptures: the main overcomes the contrary, and the guest overcomes the aligned. This applies to all six qi. Disease arises when one is not in their proper position.[20p]
Those who do not occupy their proper place will be influenced by those below them, as mentioned above. Transitioning positions leads to illness.

As for the initial energy, when the cold water of the Sun is present, it turns warm. In the case of the third energy, when the True Yin's fire arrives, it becomes cold. When the energies of their original positions interchange, this reversal of energy causes suffering among the people. This applies to all six energies.

Failing to maintain one's proper position brings danger.

By "failing to maintain one's position," it refers to losing control of one's foundational responsibilities. For instance, in the Year of the Rat or the Year of the Goat, when the Great Yin is in charge of the heavens, the initial guest energy and the primary energy are both governing the Wood of the True Yin Wind, while the cleansing and refreshing energy, unable to withstand this, gets insulted; thus, the Metal has lost its proper position. In the case of the fifth energy, the dryness of the Yangming Metal leads to a deficiency in its original position. When the child energy of Wind and Wood seeks revenge, and the fire's heat presses down on Metal, this results in severe illness and great danger, referred to as being insulted and consequently suffering from adversity.

A reversal in proportions can lead to death.[21p]
"During the years of southern and northern governance, there is a distinction between the responses of inches and feet. If there is a response or no response, but there is still a reaction, this is referred to as the contradiction of dimensions. When yin and yang interact, there is death.

In the years of governance, there is an imbalance in left and right dimensions. The left represents yang and the right represents yin; inches represent yang and feet represent yin. If yin and yang react correspondingly, there is death.

First, establish the year to understand its essence; observe the left and right responses, and only then can one discuss the reversals and alignments of life and death.

This summarizes the forces of the six qi. First, determine the year of the main qi to understand its celestial influence at the spring, and then observe the responses of the intervening qi on the left and right, either aligning or opposing, thus enabling a discussion on the reversals and alignments of life and death.

The Emperor asked: How do cold, heat, dryness, humidity, wind, and fire interact with humanity? How do they transform and give rise to all things?

Qibo replied: The east generates wind, wind generates wood, wood generates sourness, sourness generates the liver, the liver generates tendons, and tendons generate the heart.

This discusses the qi of heaven and earth and its connection to the people and all things."[22p]
Human beings embody the essence of the five elements and flavors of heaven and earth. In heaven, it is the primal source; in humanity, it is the Way; on earth, it is transformation, which gives rise to the five flavors. The Way gives birth to wisdom, the primal source produces divinity, and transformation generates vitality. The divine manifests as wind in the heavens, as wood on earth, as tendons in the body, as softness in the qi, and as the liver in the organs.

This describes the unpredictable changes of yin and yang, operating between heaven, earth, and humanity. The primal source, the Way, the transformation, and the tangible five phases, five bodies, and five organs are all manifestations of the miraculous and formless action of the divine. Softness refers to the gentle quality of the wind and wood.

Its nature is warm, its virtue is harmony, its function is movement, its color is green, and its transformation is flourishing. Its insects are like fine hair. Its governance is dispersive, its commands are disseminated, its changes can be destructive, its calamities are falling, its flavor is sour, and its ambition is anger. Anger harms the liver, while sadness overcomes anger. Wind harms the liver, while dryness overcomes wind. Sourness harms the tendons, while pungency overcomes sourness.

The nature refers to the essence of the five elements. Transformation of virtue signifies the auspiciousness of qi. Governance and commands represent the order of qi. Changes and calamities reflect the mutability of qi.[23p]
The user is the movement of the body. The caterpillar embodies the dense energy of the forest. Heaven has five elements, which control five positions to create cold, heat, dryness, humidity, and wind. Humans have five viscera, which transform five energies to produce joy, anger, worry, contemplation, and fear. Thus, humans are nurtured by these five energies and five flavors, yet can also be harmed by them in their five sentiments. It is like water, which can carry a boat but can also capsize it. Therefore, the people of ancient times practiced moderation in diet and had regular routines, flowing with the transformations of heaven and earth to harmonize their yin and yang, thus avoiding severe illness and consistently preserving their fate. In today’s era, those who understand the shifts of the seasons can avoid disasters and misfortunes—this not only allows for the governance of people but also for the nurturing of life. Extending this further can save the populace for generations to come.

The south generates heat; heat produces fire; fire yields bitterness; bitterness creates the heart; the heart generates blood; blood nurtures the spleen. In the heavens, this translates to heat; on earth, it manifests as fire; within the body, it is the pulse; in the atmosphere, it is the breath; within the organs, it is the heart. Its nature embodies summer heat, its virtue is prominence, its function is restlessness, its color is red, and its transformation is flourishing.[24p]
The insect's wings, its governance is bright, its commands are dense and steamy, its transformations are fiery and flickering, its afflictions are scorched and burned, its flavor is bitter, its will is joy. Joy harms the heart, fear prevails over joy. Heat harms the qi, cold prevails over heat. Bitterness harms the qi, saltiness prevails over bitterness.

[Note: The essence here reflects the fervent energy of fire and the dynamic nature of restless fire. The insect's wings signify the fiery essence moving in the void both above and below. The extremes of burning and scorching denote the peak of heat. At extremes, transformations occur, leading to disasters and afflictions.]

In the center, dampness is born; dampness gives rise to earth; earth gives rise to sweetness; sweetness produces the spleen; the spleen produces meat; meat generates the lungs. In the heavens, it is damp; on earth, it is soil; in the body, it is meat; in the atmosphere, it is fullness; in the organs, it is the spleen. Its nature is tranquil and inclusive; its virtue is moistening; its function is transformation; its color is yellow; its transformation is abundance. The insect is sluggish, its governance is serene, its commands are clouds and rain, its transformations are movements of precipitation, its afflictions are indulgent and overwhelming, its flavor is sweet, its will is contemplation. Contemplation harms the spleen, anger prevails over contemplation. Dampness harms meat, wind prevails over dampness. Sweetness harms the spleen, sourness prevails over sweetness.

[Note: Fullness refers to the earth's energy being pervasive in all directions.][25p]
The nature of stillness is that of the earth, which encompasses the four seasons and includes the four atmospheric qualities of cold, heat, warmth, and coolness. It is the medium through which all things are transformed and created. Worms, the creatures of flesh, are born from the earth. Clouds and rain are the rising of moisture. Movement leads to indulgence and collapse, which is the extreme of dampness.

In the west, dryness arises, leading to the production of metal; metal generates bitterness, which gives rise to the lungs; the lungs produce skin and fur; and skin and fur produce the kidneys. In the heavens, it is dry; on earth, it is metal; in the body, it is skin and fur; in the atmosphere, it is maturation; in the organs, it is the lungs. Its nature is cool, its virtue is purity, its function is solidification, its color is white, and its transformation is contraction. Its insect is the armor, its governance is strength, its command is mist and dew, its change is severity and killing, its affliction is pallor, its taste is bitter, and its intention is sorrow.

Sorrow injures the lungs, while joy overcomes sorrow. Heat damages skin and fur, while cold surpasses heat. Bitterness harms skin and fur, while sourness prevails over bitterness.

(Note: "Maturation" refers to the completion of all things in response to autumn's atmosphere. "Solidification" pertains to the function of hard metal. "Armor insect" symbolizes the exterior covered in armoring metal.)[26p]
The force of strictness is that when things are overly abundant, there will be a need for extermination; at that time, it is represented by metal and military symbols. The fallen are those that succumb to overwhelming strictness and perish.

In the north, cold is born; from cold comes water, from water arises saltiness, from saltiness comes the kidneys, from the kidneys the bone marrow, and from the marrow the liver. In the heavens, it represents cold; on earth, it signifies water; in the body, it pertains to bones; in the spirit, it is hardiness; in the organs, it relates to the kidneys. Its nature is severe, and its virtue is cold. Its function is [lacking]. Its color is black, its transformation is strictness, and it produces scales and insects. Its governance is tranquility, and its command is [lacking]. Its transformation is freezing and biting; its misfortunes are hail; its flavor is salty; its intention is fear. Fear injures the kidneys, while thought overcomes fear. Cold injures the blood, dryness surpasses cold. Salty injures the blood, sweetness surpasses saltiness.

[Note: Hardiness is a transformation of cold energy. Tranquility pertains to the governance of water. Scales and insects arise from water. Freezing is the extreme of cold. Hail is a transformation of water.]

The five energies are established in succession, each having its precedence. If not in its proper position, it becomes aberrant; if in its proper position, it is correct.

[Note: The five energies correspond to the energies of the five directions. The succession reflects the interchange of the four seasons.][27p]
Each has its own lead, like the spring breeze, summer heat, autumn coolness, and winter cold, all arriving in proper order and corresponding to their designated positions — the right energy of the four seasons. If in winter it becomes hot instead of cold, or in summer it becomes cold instead of hot, it is out of its rightful place and thus harmful. Such harm is a thief of all things. The Emperor asked: How about the changes that cause illness? Qi Bo replied: When the energies are harmonious, illnesses are mild; when they are not harmonious, they become severe.

This discusses how the energies of the four seasons relate to the illnesses of the people. When the five energies are in their rightful positions, illnesses remain mild. If they are not harmonious and deviating from their proper positions, then the illnesses will be severe.

The Emperor asked: What governs the year? Qi Bo replied: When the energy is abundant, it controls what it overcomes and bullies what it cannot. If the energy is deficient, then what it cannot overcome becomes the bully, while it becomes light against what it can overcome.

This further discusses the governing of the five movements throughout the year, indicating the consequences of excess or insufficiency. For instance, if the wood element is excessive in the year, it controls the earth energy it overcomes, while bullying the metal energy it cannot overcome.[28p]
If one is insufficient, then the metal energy that they cannot overcome will insult and dominate them; the earth energy that they can overcome will come to belittle and insult them. The five movements are all the same, revolving and restarting.

Insults turn into backlash. To insult and then receive backlash is due to a lack of fear. The emperor said: "Well said."

[Note: This speaks of the cycle of insult and backlash. If the wood of the year is insufficient, then the metal energy that one cannot overcome will insult and dominate, causing the metal to undercut its own position. In the time of autumn, when the metal energy is weak and receives the child energy of wood in return, it is hot fire that melts metal; this is what is meant by the insult leading to backlash. The insult arises because the wood energy is insufficient, yet the metal energy can restrain the wood, making it less fearful. This passage discusses the energies of the five movements, focusing on the year and the time, while also addressing the dynamics of the six energies in relation to one another. The union of the five and six is what forms the year.]

The energies of the five movements and six energies govern the year's cycles, addressing both excess and insufficiency and the influences of interstitial energies.

[Note: The sections on years and movements are summarized through this diagram; the five movements, six energies, heavenly officials, interstitial energies, and the governing of time and years are all encompassed here. By correlating weather, public health, and various conditions, everything becomes clear without needing excessive elaboration.][29p]
The Great Discussion of the Six Subtleties

The Yellow Emperor asked: Alas! So distant. The Way of Heaven is like welcoming floating clouds, like gazing into a deep abyss. The deep abyss can still be measured, but welcoming floating clouds knows no limits.

[Note: The Way of Heaven refers to the way of yin and yang. It speaks of the way of yin and yang, which is high and deep. That which has form can still be measured, but what exists in Heaven as qi is beyond knowing its limits.]

The Master often spoke of diligently upholding the Way of Heaven. I have heard and cherished it, in my heart I have my doubts, and do not understand its meaning. I wish the Master could expand on this, fully explaining the matter so it never fades away and endures through time. Can the Way of Heaven be made known?

Qibo bowed deeply and replied: Your inquiry is indeed profound, the Way of Heaven is such. This is due to the order of Heaven, the times of prosperity and decline.

[Note: The Way of Heaven refers to the yin and yang of Heaven. The order of Heaven is based on six as the measure, revolving around the six types of qi.]

The Emperor said: I wish to hear of the Way of Heaven, the six-fold measure, and the reasons for prosperity and decline? Qibo replied: There are positions above and below, rules to the left and right. Therefore, to the right of Shaoyang is Yangming; to the right of Yangming is Taiyang; to the right of Taiyang is Jueyin; to the right of Jueyin is Shaoyin; to the right of Shaoyin is Taiyin; to the right of Taiyin is Shaoyang. This is what is known as the markers of qi, it rests in the southern direction to await it.[30p]
Therefore, it is said: according to the order of heaven, during times of flourishing and decline, one should adjust the light and position properly, standing upright and waiting for it. This is what it means.

[Note: The "six six" refers to the three yin and three yang that govern the heavens, corresponding to the six vital energies in heaven. When there are positions above and below, it is stated that if the lesser yin is above, then the bright yang is below; if the greater yin is above, then the sun is below; if the lesser yang is above, then the decisive yin is below; if the decisive yin is above, then the lesser yin is below; if the sun is above, then the greater yin is below; if the decisive yin is above, then the lesser yang is below. The six phases rotate, each with their defined positions above and below. As for the left and right, for instance, if the lesser yin is above, then the decisive yin is on the left, and the greater yin is on the right; if the greater yin is above, then the lesser yin is on the left, and the lesser yang is on the right; if the lesser yang is above, then the sun is on the left, and the bright yang is on the right; if the bright yang is above, then the lesser yang is on the left, and the sun is on the right; if the sun is above, then the bright yang is on the left, and the decisive yin is on the right; if the decisive yin is above, then the sun is on the left, and the lesser yin is on the right. Each follows the presence of qi above, establishing a left and right distinction. Thus, the right side of the lesser yang is governed by the bright yang; the right side of the bright yang is governed by the sun. This is due to the placement of yin and yang on the right side, transitioning above and presiding over the years. The marker of qi is evident above. The celestial qi rotates clockwise, thus facing south and awaiting its orderly rotation. Moving light refers to the running of the sun and moon, determining the position of vital energy by the sun completing a full cycle around the heavens. Standing upright means standing facing south.]

The six energies govern the illustration of the years, both excessive and deficient.[31p]

The energy of the second phase corresponds to the Lesser Yin Monarch. Fire governs this energy.

The energy of the third phase corresponds to the Lesser Yang, with fire also governing it. The energy of the Taiyin, associated with damp earth, prevails above these three energies, governing the period prior to the mid-year.

The Lesser Yin Monarch’s fire increases; the Taiyin's damp earth increases; the Lesser Yang’s fire increases. The energy of the fourth phase corresponds to the Taiyin, related to damp earth.

The energy of the fifth phase corresponds to the Yangming, related to dry metal. The final energy corresponds to the Sun, related to cold water.

In the Lesser Yang, the fire energy is managed, and we see the influence of the Jue Yin. In the Yangming, the dry energy is managed, and we see the influence of the Taiyin. In the Sun, the cold energy is managed, and we see the influence of the Lesser Yin. In the Jue Yin, the wind energy is managed, and we see the influence of the Lesser Yang. In the Lesser Yin, the heat energy is managed, and we see the influence of the Sun. In the Taiyin, the damp energy is managed, and we see the influence of the Yangming.

What is termed "original" refers to the foundation, from which we see what lies within; beneath that, we have the standard of energy.

[Note: This describes the three Yin and three Yang energies, the six transformations of energy, the foundational and standard relationships, and the insights gained. Wind, cold, heat, dampness, dryness, and fire represent the celestial Yin and Yang. The three Yin and three Yang energies are revered, leading us to see the atmospheric conditions as foundational above, with the energies symbolically manifesting below.]

The foundational symbols differ, leading to variances in energy manifestations.[36p]
The passage discusses the six energies of the Three Yin and Three Yang, which, although responding to one another, differ individually. Shaoyin represents Yin but is inherently warm, while Taiyang represents Yang but is inherently cold; this distinction pertains to their fundamental attributes. Shaoyin and Taiyang follow their inherent nature and representation. Taiyin and Shaoyang stem from their fundamentals. Yangming and Jueyin do not follow the representation or fundamentals but arise from the middle. Thus, there are those that are derived from fundamentals, those that are derived from representations, those that derive from both representations and fundamentals, and those that are derived from observations of the middle. This illustrates the varying manifestations of the energies.

The Emperor inquired: "What accounts for some energies being present while others are absent, some being excessively present?" Qibo responded: "Those that are present and complete represent harmony; those that are present but not complete indicate that the incoming energy does not reach sufficiently; those that are incomplete yet reach signify an excess of the incoming energy."

This discourse addresses the main energies of the Three Yin and Three Yang throughout the year, and the occurrences of excess or deficiency. When energies are present and complete, it signifies a year of balanced energies, with no excess or deficiency, where the seasonal energies arrive timely, reflecting harmony in energies. For example, if spring is supposed to be warm yet remains cold, or if summer is expected to be hot yet remains warm, this indicates presence without completeness, due to inadequate incoming energy. Conversely, if warmth arrives before spring or heat before summer, this signifies an arrival of energy that is premature and excessive, indicating an abundance of incoming energy.[37p]
According to the Great Discussion of the Heavenly Origins, it is stated: Generally, the Yangming, Taiyin, and Jueyin govern the affairs of heaven, whereby the qi transforms and operates according to the later heaven; the Taiyang, Shaoyang, and Shaoyin govern the affairs of heaven according to the earlier heaven. In years of deficiency, the heavenly qi arrives at the later heaven; in years of surplus, the heavenly qi arrives at the earlier heaven. Moreover, the Yang years are associated with substance, while the Yin years are associated with emptiness. The years in which the celestial symbols gather are considered to have balanced qi, with neither excess nor deficiency.

The Emperor asked: What about when it is expected yet does not arrive, or when it arrives before expected? Qibo replied: If it responds, it aligns; otherwise, it is contrary. When it is contrary, changes arise; when changes arise, illness occurs.

(Note: The years of deficiency respond yet do not arrive; the years of surplus respond before they should arrive, which is considered alignment.)[38p]
If the year of deficiency is not reached, it arrives nonetheless; if the year of abundance is reached, it does not arrive, this is what is called contrary. When the contrary occurs, change is born, and when change is born, it becomes a disaster for the people. The Emperor said: Good! Please speak of its response! Qi Bo said: The response of things is born from their nature; the response of qi and channels is determined by their flow.

[Note: To speak of its response means to discuss the excessive or insufficient qi. The response of things is such that, for example, when the Spring of the Liver governs the heavens, silkworms remain still, and butterflies are nurtured; when the Shao Yang governs the heavens, grass and trees flourish early; when the Tai Yin governs the heavens, all things thrive. All these living things respond to the heavenly phenomena. The response of qi and channels indicates that when the Tai Yang governs the heavens, cold descends into the vast void, and yang qi is not permitted; when the Yang Ming governs the heavens, yang rules its command, and summer heat prevails; when the Tai Yin governs the heavens, yin rules its authority, and yang qi retreats.][39p]
When it reaches Jueyin, its pulse is string-like; when it reaches Shaoyin, its pulse is hooked; when it reaches Taiyin, its pulse is deep; when it reaches Shaoyang, it is large and floating; when it reaches Yangming, it is short and thin; when it reaches Taiyang, it is large and long. All these correspond to the energies and pulses.

The emperor said: Good! I wish to hear about the geographical correspondences of the six solar terms. Qibo replied: To the right of Xiangming is the position of Jun fire. To the right of Jun fire, step back one position, and the position of Xiang fire governs it: move back one more step, and the Earth energy governs it; move back one more step, and the Metal energy governs it; move back one more step, and the Water energy governs it; move back one more step, and the Wood energy governs it; move back one more step, and Jun fire governs it.

[Note: This discussion relates to the six solar terms and their seasonal dominances. Energy positions refer to the steps governed by the six energies. Xiangming refers to the beginning of spring, which indicates the initial energy. The right of Xiangming is the position of Shaoyin Jun fire, governing the second energy. Stepping back one position means moving one step rightward. The right of Jun fire is the position of Shaoyang Xiang fire, governing the third energy. Stepping back one more position brings us to Taiyin damp Earth, governing the fourth energy; stepping back one more brings us to Yangming dry Metal, governing the fifth energy; stepping back one more brings us to Taiyang cold Water, governing the sixth energy; stepping back one more brings us to Jueyin wind Wood, governing the initial energy; and stepping back one more brings us back to the position of Shaoyin Jun fire, representing the cyclical nature.][40p]
Under the influence of fire, water regulates it; beneath water's level, earth supports it; below earth's level, wind sustains it; under wind's level, metal supports it; beneath metal's level, fire sustains it; under the influence of the sovereign fire, the essence of yin supports it. The Emperor asked: Why is this so? Qibo replied: Excess leads to harm; support leads to control, and control leads to transformation. Externally, the cycles of prosperity and decline indicate harm leads to chaos, and transformation can lead to great illness.

(Note: This passage discusses the interrelationships of the six qi and how they influence each other, emphasizing the principles of generation, control, and the importance of proper regulation to avoid excess and imbalance in natural phenomena.)[41p]
If the water rises without soil to contain it, then the water overflows and extinguishes the fire; without soil to regulate the water, the water rises even more. Thus, excess leads to harm among the five elements, causing chaos in the processes of growth and transformation, resulting in significant afflictions. The external manifestations of prosperity and decline refer to the energy of the year, which can have both abundance and scarcity. If the energy of the year and the energy of the time both become excessively strong, the harm becomes even greater. Therefore, it is said that harm leads to chaos and significant afflictions.

The Emperor asked: What are prosperity and decline? Qibo replied: When it is out of place, it is evil; when it is in place, it is correct. When evil prevails, changes are extreme; when correct, changes are subtle.

(Note: This refers to the years of excess and deficiency in energy. When it is out of place, it means that the energy is excessive and subdues what it should conquer while taking offense against what it can’t conquer – this is the prosperity of the year. When the energy is insufficient, it means that what it can't conquer is offensive, and what it should conquer is slighted – this is the decline of the year. In both cases, they fail to maintain their proper positions, and thus there arises internal evil. When it is in place, it is a year of balanced energy, with no excessive or insufficient oppression, and each maintains its proper position; this is the correct energy. When there is evil, changes are extreme; when there is correctness, changes are subtle.)

The Emperor asked: What is meant by being in place? Qibo replied: Wood operates in the East, fire operates in the South, earth operates across the four seasons, metal operates in the West, and water operates in the North. This is what is meant by the meeting of the year; it signifies balanced energy.[42p]
The Emperor said: What if it is not the right time? Qibo replied: It is a year that does not align! [Note: This refers to a year of balanced qi, without extremes. The Wood cycle corresponds to the Year of Dingmao; the Fire cycle corresponds to the Year of Wuwu; the Earth cycle corresponds to the Years of Jiachen, Jiaxu, Jichou, and Jiwwei; the Metal cycle corresponds to the Year of Yiyou; the Water cycle corresponds to the Year of Bingzi. As the transformations of the heavenly stems align with the ruling years of the earthly branches, this year is considered aligned, thus a year of balanced qi. If it is not a year of alignment, then there will be extremes in excess and deficiency, which is considered not the right time.] The Emperor said: In the year of the Earth cycle, the Taiyin is seen above; in the year of the Fire cycle, Shaoyang and Shaoyin are seen above; in the year of the Metal cycle, Yangming is seen above; in the year of the Wood cycle, Jueyin is seen above; in the year of the Water cycle, Taiyang is seen above. How is this? Qibo replied: It aligns with the Heaven. Therefore, the "Heavenly Origin Register" states: Heavenly symbols. [Note: The phenomena seen above refer to the qi of the heavens, manifested in the yearly cycles. In the year of the Earth cycle, the Taiyin is seen above, corresponding to the years Jichou and Jiwwei. In the year of the Fire cycle, Shaoyang is seen in the years Wuyin and Wushen; Shaoyin is seen in the years Wuzi and Wuwu. In the year of the Metal cycle, Yangming is seen in the years Yimao and Yiyou. In the year of the Wood cycle, Jueyin is seen in the years Dingsi and Dinghai. In the year of the Water cycle, Taiyang is seen in the years Bingchen and Bingxu.][43p]
The Qi of the heavens, when it merges with the Qi of the Five Movements, is called the Heavenly Sign. The Emperor asked, "What is the significance of the Heavenly Sign in relation to the year?" Qi Bo replied, "It is the meeting of the Great Yiy Heavenly Sign."

(Note: When the Heavenly Sign coincides with the annual meeting, it is called Great Yiy. The Heavenly Sign corresponds to the years of Wu Wu, Ji Chou, Ji Wei, and Yi You, representing the merger of the Qi of the heavens, the Qi of the Five Movements, and the annual Qi, hence it is also referred to as the Three Mergers.)

The Emperor then asked, "What about its nobility and baseness?" Qi Bo replied, "The Heavenly Sign represents the enforcement of law, the annual meeting signifies the implementation of commands, and the Great Yiy Heavenly Sign represents nobility."

(Note: Wang Bing states that "enforcement of law" relates to mutual assistance, "implementation of commands" is like a local noble, and "nobility" refers to a sovereign.)

The Emperor inquired, "What about the relevance of evil within?" Qi Bo explained, "In those who are within the enforcement of law, their afflictions are swift and perilous; in those within the implementation of commands, their afflictions are gradual and enduring; in those within nobility, their afflictions are abrupt and fatal."

(Note: Wang Bing adds that the enforcement of law is the standard for officials, so if it becomes corrupt, the consequences are swift and dangerous. The local noble does not have the power of enforcement, therefore harm comes slowly and is manageable. The noble's authority is inviolable, hence if afflicted, the outcome is abrupt and lethal.)

The Emperor asked, "How about the ease of positions?" Qi Bo replied, "When a ruler is in place, ministers are compliant; when a minister occupies the position of a ruler, there is rebellion. Rebellion brings ailments closer and harms swiftly; compliance distances ailments and minimizes harm. This is referred to as the Two Fires."[44p]
【Note: The correspondence of geography to the six phases corresponds to the six qi of the main time, which are unchanging positions. However, there are also the additional six qi that arise in conjunction with the heavenly affairs, which revolve in six cycles, hence it is said to involve change in position. For instance, when the lesser yin lord fire is in conjunction with the lesser yang minister fire, it is a position of lord and minister in harmony; conversely, when the lesser yang minister fire is in conjunction with the lesser yin lord fire, it is a position of minister and lord in opposition. This describes the harmony and discord of the two fires.】 The Emperor said: Excellent! I wish to hear about its steps. Qi Bo said: The so-called steps involve sixty degrees and a discrepancy. Therefore, there are twenty-four steps, accumulating to a hundred divisions to complete a day. 【Note: This discusses the additional six qi in conjunction. Each qi presides over sixty days and eighty-seven and a half divisions, hence is sixty degrees with a discrepancy. Within four years, there are a total of twenty-four steps, with each step accumulating eighty-seven and a half divisions, totaling two thousand one hundred divisions. From two thousand divisions, divided across four years, the accumulation is five days, with an additional one hundred divisions, thus completing an extra day.】 The Emperor asked: How do the six qi correspond to the transformations of the five elements? Qi Bo said: Positions have beginnings and ends, and qi has initial, middle, and upper and lower aspects that differ; thus, the inquiries differ as well. 【Note: This discusses how the additional six qi correspond with the qi dominating the time, and how each is distinct. The five elements refer to the jueyin wind wood which governs the initial qi, the two fires of the lord and minister which govern the second and third qi, the taiyin damp earth which governs the fourth qi, the yangming dry metal which governs the fifth qi, and the taiyang cold water which governs the sixth qi. This refers to the five elements of the main time that maintain their positions without change.】[45p]
If the six qi are added based on their positions, they will correspond to the five elements of the time, thus bringing about different changes. Positions have beginnings and ends, referring to the six positions of the principal time, which start at Jueyin and end at Taiyang, having a certain foundational position. Qi has an initial and a central aspect, meaning that the six qi added begin from the initial qi of the earth and end at the central qi of the sky. The differences above and below indicate that the guest qi is added from above, while the main qi resides below, and they differ accordingly; therefore, seeking them will also be different.

The Emperor said: How shall we seek this? Qibo replied: The heavenly qi begins with Jia, and the earthly qi begins with Zi. When Zi and Jia combine, it is called the establishment of the year. Be diligent in observing the time, and the qi can be anticipated.

(Note: The heavenly stems' qi begins with Jia, and the earthly branches' qi begins with Zi; when Zi and Jia combine, the year is established. First establish the year to observe the time, so that the six qi added can be anticipated and determined accordingly.)

The Emperor said: I wish to know how the six qi of the year start and end, and what are the early and late timings?

(Note: The "year" refers to the six qi appearing within the year. The beginning and end are from one moment to eighty-seven and a half moments. Early and late refer to cases like the year of the Rabbit, Rat, and Dragon, where the heavenly qi begins at one moment, indicating an early qi; whereas in the year of the Tiger, Goat, and Pig, the heavenly qi begins at seventy-six moments, indicating a late qi.)[46p]
Qi Bo said: "Do you understand? It is a question! In the Year of the Jiazi, the first Qi begins at the moment below water at the start of the day, starting at 87 units and ending at 75 units; the second Qi begins at 76 units and ends at 62.5 units; the third Qi begins at 62.6 units and ends at 50 units; the fourth Qi begins at 51 units and ends at 37.5 units; the fifth Qi begins at 37.6 units and ends at 25 units. The so-called 'Initial Six' corresponds to the celestial numbers.

[Note: The celestial numbers are derived from the count of days in a year, corresponding to a complete cycle of 365.25 days. The first Qi begins on the New Moon of the Yin month, with the moment below water starting at 87.5 units, ending at 60 days with 87.5 units. The total of the six Qis amounts to 360 days and 525 units, which equates to 365 days and 25 units. Thus, the Initial Six Qi corresponds to the celestial numbers.]

In the Year of Yichou, the first Qi starts at 26 units and ends at 12.5 units; the second Qi starts at 12.6 units and ends at a hundred units below water; the third Qi begins at 1 unit and ends at 87.5 units; the fourth Qi starts at 87.6 units and ends at 75 units; the fifth Qi begins at 76 units and ends at 62.5 units; the sixth Qi starts at 62.6 units and ends at 50 units. The so-called 'Six Two' corresponds to the celestial numbers."[47p]
In the year of Bingyin, the initial qi began at the fifty-first ke and ended at thirty-seven and a half ke; the second qi began at thirty-seven and six minutes and ended at twenty-five ke; the third qi began at twenty-six ke and ended at twelve and a half ke; the fourth qi began at twelve and six minutes and ended at the hundredth ke below the water; the fifth qi began at one ke and ended at eighty-seven and a half ke; the sixth qi began at eighty-seven and six minutes and ended at seventy-five ke. The so-called six and three corresponds to the numbers of heaven. In this year of Bingyin, the initial qi started in the previous two years, at seven hundred and thirty-one days and fifty-one ke; it finished at one thousand and ninety-six days and seventy-five ke, totaling three hundred sixty-five days and twenty-five ke. This is known as the six qis of the three years.[48p]
In the year of Ding Mao, during the initial qi, the heavenly cycles begin at seventy-six divisions and end at sixty-two and a half divisions; during the second qi, it begins at sixty-two and six tenths and ends at fifty divisions; during the third qi, it starts at fifty-one divisions and ends at thirty-seven and a half divisions; during the fourth qi, it begins at thirty-seven and six tenths and ends at twenty-five divisions; during the fifth qi, it starts at twenty-six divisions and ends at twelve and a half divisions; during the sixth qi, it begins at twelve and six tenths and ends at below one hundred divisions of water. The so-called six four is the calculation of heaven. In the subsequent year of Wu Chen, the initial qi begins again at one division. This cycle continues endlessly, revolving and repeating.

(Note: The annotation specifies that in the year of Ding Mao, the initial qi starts at seventy-five divisions of the one thousand ninety-sixth day and ends at below one hundred divisions of water on the one thousand four hundred sixty-first day.)[49p]
Each year consists of three hundred sixty-five days and twenty-five moments. Over four years, it totals one thousand four hundred sixty days, accumulating an extra hundred moments to form an additional day. Each year records a new moon and the empty period by six days, while the weather accumulates five days and twenty-five moments. Among twenty years, the total excess from the weather and new moon counts to two hundred twenty-five days. Thus, there are three years in one cycle, five years in another, and in the ninth decade, there are seven cycles, excluding the three odd days.

The Emperor said: "I wish to understand how the years and seasons behave!" Qi Bo replied: "Indeed, a keen inquiry! The sun travels a complete cycle and the weather begins at one moment; as the sun travels two cycles, the weather begins at twenty-six moments; after three cycles, it starts at fifty-one moments; after four cycles, it begins at seventy-six moments; and after five cycles, the weather resets to one moment. This is what is called a 'cycle of years.'"

[Note: The previous section discussed the periodicity of the six energies, while this section discusses the energies of a year in relation to the cycles of the heavens.][50p]
In a year, the heavens cycle through three hundred sixty-five degrees and a quarter degree within a day, completing one full turn around the Earth in one day while progressing one degree. Each year comprises three hundred sixty-five days and an additional twenty-five quarts. Thus, in one year, it completes one full turn around the heavens, returning to two cycles. Over four years, this accumulates to a full hundred quarts, forming one record.

Therefore, the years associated with the tiger, horse, and dog share a common energy, as do the years of the rabbit, goat, and pig; the years of the dragon, monkey, and rat; and the years of the snake, rooster, and ox, concluding and beginning anew.

The emperor said, "I wish to understand its application!" Qi Bo replied: "Speaking of heaven is in seeking the origin; speaking of earth is in seeking the position; speaking of humanity is in seeking the interaction of energies."

Application refers to the movement of yin and yang as they ascend and descend. The origin is based on the six energies of wind, cold, heat, dampness, drought, and fire. The position pertains to the steps of the three yin and three yang. The interaction of energies refers to the convergence of the energies of heaven and earth, the yin and yang, entering and exiting from above and below.[51p]
The Emperor asked: What is meant by the exchange of qi? Qi Bo replied: The positions of above and below are where the exchange of qi occurs, which is where humanity resides. Therefore it is said that above the celestial pivot, the heavenly qi governs; below the celestial pivot, the earthly qi governs. The distribution of qi is such that human qi follows it, and all things arise from it. This is what is meant.

The Emperor asked: What is the initial middle? Qi Bo replied: The initial state is generally thirty degrees and has its peculiarities; the central qi follows the same principles. The Emperor asked: What constitutes the initial middle? Qi Bo replied: It is what divides heaven and earth. The Emperor expressed desire to hear this completely! Qi Bo said: The initial refers to earthly qi, while the middle refers to heavenly qi.

This clarifies the exchange of yin and yang of heaven and earth. Before the half year, heavenly qi governs, and the initial qi of the heavenly is derived from the left of the earth. After the half year, earthly qi governs, and the initial qi of the earthly begins from the right of the heavens. This describes the intersection of above and below. Within one qi, there is also the distinction of initial and middle, including the peculiar. Each governs for thirty days, four hours, seven minutes, and five tenths. The initial qi of the earth, the central qi of the heavens, is within one qi, and thus there is the convergence of the yin and yang of heaven and earth. Hence it is said that within yin there is yang, and within yang there is yin.[52p]
The Emperor said: How do the rise and fall occur? Qibo replied: The rise and fall of qi is the transformation of heaven and earth. The Emperor said: I wish to know how this transformation works. Qibo replied: When it rises, it then falls; the falling is called heaven; when it falls, it then rises; the rising is called earth. The qi of heaven descends, flowing to the earth; the qi of the earth ascends, rising to the heavens. Thus, the high and the low summon each other, the rise and fall are interconnected, and transformation occurs.

The Emperor said: Excellent! When cold and damp encounter, when dryness and heat bear upon one another, is there any interval between them? Qibo replied: Qi has phases of dominance and recovery; this phase of dominance and recovery involves virtue and transformation, utility and change; when change occurs, then evil qi resides within it.

This discusses the six qi governing heaven and earth; they have differences in domination, virtue, transformation, and calamity. People also undergo beginnings and endings due to the transformations of yin and yang. Encountering refers to the coming together of the six qi; arriving refers to the six qi's presence; aligning refers to the direct influence of the six qi through the seasons. Dominance refers to the overwhelming presence, virtue refers to the auspiciousness of qi, utility refers to the movement of essence, change refers to the order of recovery, and evil refers to the changing qi.[53p]
The Emperor said: What does that mean? Qi Bo replied: The birth of things arises from transformation, and the extremes of things are due to change. The interaction of change and transformation is where success and failure stem from.

[Note: The Great Treatise on the Five Constants states: Qi begins and gives rise to transformations; Qi ends and manifests change. Therefore, nurturing and collecting are the completion of things, while disasters and alterations are the cause of their downfall. Thus, humans and all things grow within the transformations of yin and yang, and their success and failure depend on these changes.]

Hence, qi has cycles of return, and action has speeds of delay and quickness. These four elements result in transformation and change, leading to the coming of the wind.

[Note: The cycles of return in qi refer to the qi of heaven and earth, having both ascension and descension. The speeds of action refer to the entry and exit of yin and yang, which can be slow or fast. Wind is the movement of qi in heaven and earth, capable of nurturing all things, yet also able to harm them.]

The Emperor said: The slow and fast return is how the wind is born. Therefore, the reason for transformation and change is due to the fluctuations between prosperity and decline! Why do success and failure fluctuate within?

Qi Bo replied: Success and failure arise from movement; if movement does not cease, transformation occurs.

[Note: Movement refers to the unceasing rise and fall, entry and exit. The success and failure of all things depend on the changes of yin and yang, thus the mechanisms of success and failure lie within these transformations.]

The Emperor asked: Is there a fixed period? Qi Bo replied: Not being born and not transforming is the period of stillness.

[Note: This is like being not born and not transformed, leading to stillness in the end. It refers to the qi of heaven and earth, which is in constant movement.]

The Emperor said: Is there no birth or transformation?[54p]
Is there a time when there is no birth and transformation?

Qibo said: When in and out is wasted, the divine mechanisms wither away; when rising and falling cease, the vital energy becomes isolated and precarious. This reiterates that the opening and pioneering of heaven and earth involve motion and transformation. "In and out" refers to closing and opening. "Mechanism" is the pivot, and "divine mechanism" refers to the unpredictable changes of Yin and Yang. Just as closing and opening are like doors and shutters, and the pivot is the turning point, without the pivot, there can be no closing or opening; without closing and opening, there is no turning. Thus, when in and out is wasted, the divine mechanisms wither.

Rising and falling refer to the transitions of cold and heat. The rising and falling of Yin and Yang emanate from the earth, while heaven encompasses the earth. Therefore, when rising and falling cease, the external vital energy becomes isolated and precarious; isolation means there is no birth. The "Lower Classic" states: Those rooted in the external are termed vital energy; when energy halts, transformation ceases. Those rooted within are termed divine mechanisms; when the divine departs, the mechanism ceases.[55p]
Therefore, without entrance and exit, there can be no growth, maturity, aging, and passing; without rising and falling, there can be no growth, transformation, storage, and collection. Thus, rising and falling, entering and exiting, are present in all things.

(Note: "Passing" refers to death. "Growth, maturity, aging, and passing" pertains to animals; "growth, transformation, storage, and collection" pertains to plants. All tangible things are called vessels. The relationship between humans and all things arises from the interaction of the energies of heaven and earth. The processes of growth, maturity, aging, and passing depend on the rising and falling and entering and exiting of energies, which is why there is no vessel devoid of these movements.)

Thus, vessels are the universe of transformation. When vessels disperse, the essence of transformation ceases. Therefore, nothing lacks entrance and exit, and nothing lacks rising and falling.

(Note: All tangible things are influenced by the energies of heaven, earth, and the four directions to grow and transform. Thus, vessels represent the universe of transformation. When vessels disperse, the yang returns to heaven and the yin returns to earth, causing transformation to cease. Therefore, all things possess these movements of rising and falling and entering and exiting, which are determined by success and failure.)

Transformation has size, and timing has proximity and distance.[56p]
The text discusses the transformation and balance of the forces between heaven and earth, noting distinctions in size and distance. For instance, small creatures like the morning mushroom are unaware of the cycles of day and night, while larger beings like the great mulberry tree experience the seasons over centuries. The forces of heaven (yang) are active, and those of earth (yin) are still; daytime is active while nighttime is still, representing the nearer cyclical changes. The cosmos began at the beginning of the day (zi) and the earth was established in the early hours (chou). The continuous movement of heaven and earth ultimately returns to a state of unity (xu-hai), a more distant transformation, where everything is still and unmoving.

Therefore, maintaining constant principles is of utmost importance; deviation from these will lead to disasters. Thus, it is said that being formless leads to no afflictions; this is a principle to uphold.

As humans exist amidst these forces, it is important to maintain a consistent state; an awareness of potential troubles is crucial, and going against the natural order can invite disasters. Hence, the idea that to transcend earthly forms allows for freedom from worries.

The Emperor asked whether there is a state of existence beyond birth and transformation. Qi Bo replied affirmatively, stating that such a state exists for those who are in harmony with the Dao—these are true individuals. The Emperor acknowledged this as good.

This implies that those who exist between heaven and earth without being constrained by transformation are indeed true individuals. True individuals are those who hold the balance of heaven and earth, mastering the interplay of yin and yang, enduring beyond the decay of the cosmos, and experiencing neither movement nor stillness in unison with heaven and earth.[57p]
The Gate of Qi

Huangdi on the Simple Questions

The Grand Theory of Qi Transformation

The Huangdi asked: “The five phases undergo their changes, in alignment with heavenly cycles. Yin and Yang alternate, and the four seasons follow one another. The true and the false influence each other, while the internal and external separate. The six channels fluctuate, and the five energies shift. Excess and deficiency, specialization and amalgamation. I wish to speak of their beginnings, which have constant names. Can this be elucidated?”

[Note: The five phases undergoing change refers to the succession of the five phases in their cyclical influences. Alignment with heavenly cycles means each phase governs three hundred sixty-five days, corresponding to the heavenly measure. The alternation of Yin and Yang indicates their excess leading to departure or deficiency following. The true and false influencing one another suggest auspicious transformations and changing energies. The six channels refer to the three Yin and three Yang channels, and the five energies pertain to the Qi of the five organs. Specialization and amalgamation refer to those years of excess and deficiency; the energy that is overcome is specialized, and excess is then amalgamated.][58p]
The beginning, the heavenly qi starts with Jia, the earthly qi starts with Zi, the conjunction of Zi and Jia gives rise to the operation of the year. Qi Bo bowed his head in reverence and replied: "Indeed, it is clear, I ask! This is the luminous Dao. This is what the Supreme Deity values, transmitted by the ancient masters. Though I am not talented, I have heard its purpose."

The emperor said: "I have heard that if one obtains a person but does not teach them, it is called losing the Dao; if one transmits to an unworthy person, it is a slow leaking of heavenly treasures. I am indeed lacking in virtue, insufficient to receive the ultimate Dao. However, the multitude grieves for its incompleteness, wishing that you may preserve it infinitely and flow into the boundless. If I were to manage this matter, what should I do?"

Qi Bo said: "Please allow me to continue my explanation."[59p]
The "Upper Canon" states: The Way is such that it knows the celestial phenomena above, understands the geography of the earth below, and comprehends human affairs in the middle; it can be eternal and enduring. This is what is meant.

The Emperor asked: What does this mean? Qi Bo replied: The root is the position of Qi. The position of heaven pertains to celestial phenomena. The position of earth pertains to geography. Understanding the changes in human Qi relates to human affairs. Therefore, the excessive pertains to the former heaven, while the insufficient pertains to the latter heaven. What is meant by governing and transforming is that people respond to it.

Note: The position of Qi refers to the Five Movements and Six Qi, each governing the positioning of heaven and the marking of earth, determining the seasons and timing. The position of heaven is the manifestation of the heavens. The position of earth corresponds to the six seasonal phases. Humans dwell in the intersection of the Qi of heaven and earth, adapting to the changes of yin and yang across the four seasons, which pertains to human affairs.[60p]
Therefore, when the forces of fate are excessive, the atmospheric influences of the four seasons arrive ahead of their natural time; conversely, when the forces of fate are insufficient, the atmospheric influences of the four seasons arrive later than their natural time. This describes the changes brought about by the influences of the year, to which people must respond.

The Emperor asked, "What happens when the transformation of the five influences is excessive?" Qi Bo replied, "When the Wood of the year is excessive, the winds are rampant, and the Earth of the Spleen suffers from evil influences. The people experience symptoms like loose stools, reduced appetite, a heavy and discomforted body, rumbling intestines, and abdominal distension. This corresponds to the Year Star."

(Note: When the Wood of the year is excessive, it overcomes the Earth influences, causing illnesses related to the Spleen. Loose stools, reduced appetite, rumbling intestines, and abdominal fullness are all disorders of the Spleen. The Spleen governs the muscles and limbs, hence the feeling of heaviness and discomfort arises, as Earth is damaged and cannot control Water, allowing Water's influences to rise and affect the Heart. This corresponds to the Year Star, which is greatly luminous. The Year Star refers to Jupiter. Thus, too much Wood influence corresponds to certain years.)

In severe cases, one may feel sudden anger, and could experience dizziness, headache, or a sense of imbalance.[61p]
The excess of indulgence leads to self-harm. A good anger is a disease of the liver and will. The Jueyin and Du meridians meet at the top of the head, hence the dizziness and headaches. If the transformation of qi does not regulate, the vital energy acts alone, causing the clouds and objects to fly, and the plants and trees to be unsettled; excessively, they may even shake and fall, leading to side pain and severe vomiting. If the Chongyang is cut off, there is no hope of recovery. It also corresponds to the planet Tai Bai.
