The transformation of qi refers to the energy of the earth. Excessive wind and wood cause the transformation of qi to fail in establishing its governance. The vital energy refers to the wood's energy. When the wind is dominant, it moves; hence the clouds and objects above are flying, and the plants and trees below are unsettled. The side pain and severe vomiting happen when indulgence reaches its peak, leading to injury. When the nourishing energy of food enters the stomach, it spreads its essence to the liver. When the liver qi is weak and reverses, it results in severe vomiting. The Chongyang refers to the stomach meridian.[62p]
The wood has thrived and the earth's energy has been depleted; thus it serves as evidence of a death that cannot be treated. It corresponds to the Venus star, which is the bright star of Venus. When the year’s energies are excessive and the star loses its brightness, it affects its mother as well. If wood is too abundant in the year, then the stabilizing star loses its brightness, and even the fiery planet Mars becomes dim. When Mars loses its brilliance, the Venus shines and thus overcomes the wood. This mutual interaction and regulation is the way of nature.

In a year where fire is excessive, scorching heat prevails, leading to pathogenic influences on the metallic lungs. The people suffer from fevers, reduced vitality, coughing and wheezing, bleeding, severe diarrhea, dry throats, deafness, internal heat, and discomfort in the shoulders and back. This corresponds to the planetary influence of Mars.

Note: Fire dominates and thus overcomes metal, which is why the metallic lungs are affected. Malaria and fevers are heat-related illnesses. Intense fire consumes energy, hence the low vitality. The lungs suffer from excessive heat, resulting in coughing and wheezing.[63p]
The lungs govern the hundred vessels; when the yang vessels are harmed, blood overflows above; when the yin vessels are harmed, blood leaks below. The lungs are the source of water. If the throat is dry, it is due to fire's scorching. The kidneys open to the ears; when the source of water is exhausted, the kidneys become deficient, leading to deafness. Internal heat indicates excessive heat within. The shoulders and back correspond to the lungs. The Blazing Star is the planet associated with fire. When fire energy is dominant, it corresponds above to the Blazing Star, its light becoming much greater. When fire is overactive, it affects all the Wus.

If this condition becomes severe, it can lead to chest pain, fullness in the ribs, rib pain, pain between the chest and shoulder blades, inner arm pain, body heat, and bone pain, resulting in accumulation.

(Note: This extreme condition harms the heart's fire. The chest is the palace of the heart. The back is yang, while the heart is the sun among the yang, hence the pain in the chest, back, and between the shoulder blades.)[64p]
The Hand Shaoyin Heart Meridian emerges beneath the ribcage, following the inner arm down to the elbow, then along the inner back of the arm. Thus, one experiences fullness and pain in the sides, pain in both inner arms, and symptoms of body heat and bone pain, indicating excess fire and damage to water. Soaking and immersion lead to fiery heat sores. The path of the organ's energy states that heart disease causes pain in the chest, fullness in the sides, pain beneath the ribs, pain between the eagle's back and shoulder blades, and pain in both inner arms. The "Jinkui Yaolue" states that sores from immersion that flow from the mouth to the limbs can be treated; those that flow from the limbs back to the mouth cannot be treated.

If energy is not circulating, and yang energy is solely bright, it brings rain, water, and frost chill. This corresponds to the Zen Star.

[Note: Here, the golden energy is stagnant while the water energy is replenished. Gathering energy represents golden energy. Lengthening energy represents fiery energy. Rain, water, and frost chill represent the resurgence of cold water energy. The correspondence to the Zen Star indicates brightness, with the Zen Star being Mercury.][65p]
When the upper forces are influenced by the Lesser Yin and Lesser Yang, the fire burns fiercely, the water springs dry up, and all things become scorched and withered.

(Note: The 'upper forces' refer to the celestial energy governing the year's fortunes, known as the 'heavenly sign of the year.' In the years of Wuzi and Wuwu, the Lesser Yin prevails; in the years of Wuyin and Wushen, the Lesser Yang prevails. When the celestial influences align with the year's fortunes, the fire energy intensifies, causing the water springs to dry and nature to wither. It is noted that among the years governed by Yang, only Wuzi, Wuwu, Wuyin, Wushen, Bingchen, and Bingxu have this celestial influence aligning with the year's fortunes; other years associated with wood, metal, and earth do not have this alignment.)

In cases of reversal, there are delirium and madness, dry cough, wheezing, and continuous severe bleeding and diarrhea. If the Taiyuan pulse is absent, it is an indication of death without treatment. This corresponds to the influence of the comet.[66p]
In the text, it discusses various conditions and their symptoms. It explains that a severe fire condition can lead to self-harm, resulting in madness or delirium, showcasing extreme heat symptoms. Coughing and wheezing indicate an upward blaze that affects the metal element. The heart governs blood vessels, and excessive downward flow causes continuous blood loss. Taiyuan is the acupoint associated with lung metal. When fire is too intense and metal energy is depleted, it signifies an incurable death sign. This corresponds to the appearance of the comet, whose luminosity is magnified and represents the fire star.

When the year's earth is excessive, causing dampness and disease spread, the kidney water is affected, leading to symptoms like abdominal pain, illness, a lack of joy, and oppressive heaviness. This aligns with the star associated with weather stability.

The notes clarify that earth pertains to the ground while moisture pertains to the sky; thus, excessive earth leads to damp rain. The "Six Elements and Proper Timing" states that the location of the moon results in clouds and rain, indicating the rise of humid earth energy as it transforms into clouds and rain.[67p]
Abdominal pain refers to pain in the lower and upper abdomen, indicating a kidney-related illness, where dominance and water cause harm. The method of assessing internal energy states states: when suffering from kidney disease, the body feels heavy; when the kidneys are deficient, there is pain in the upper and lower abdomen. The kidneys are the source of life energy; when kidney energy is affected by pathogens, it leads to coldness in the hands and feet. If the will is not settled, it results in a lack of joy. Human actions rely on energy and blood circulation. The kidneys are the source of blood and energy; when the body feels heavy and burdened, water cannot support fire. If the earth element is excessive, its influence will increase in brightness. The star of influence refers to Saturn. An excess of earth energy affects all yearly cycles.

In severe cases, muscles may atrophy, feet may weaken and retract, movement becomes difficult, there is pain in the feet, shallow breathing, fullness in the stomach, decreased appetite, limbs become immobile, and transformations in position occur.

(Note: Muscles and limbs are under the dominion of the spleen, which is associated with the earth element.)[68p]
Drinking leads to an inability to transform the qi, resulting in phlegm and water retention. When there is fullness and reduced food intake, the individual becomes weak and cannot handle transformations. If this excess becomes too extreme, it will overturn the original state and cause self-harm. Therefore, on the eighteenth day of the fourth month of the season, when the earth qi is at its proper place, this illness arises.

Storing energy suppresses water qi, while transforming qi uniquely treats it. Springs gush and rivers flow, drying up marshes produces fish. When strong winds and heavy rains occur, the earth collapses, and scales appear on land. Symptoms of bloated abdomen, diarrhea, and intestinal sounds indicate severe descent and exhaustion of the Tai Xi, leading to untreatable death. This corresponds to the year star.

Note: Storing energy refers to water qi. Transforming qi refers to earth qi. When earth is strong, it controls water, hence the storage of energy is suppressed. The gushing springs and flowing rivers indicate excessive humidity. Strong winds and heavy rains signify the return of wood qi. The collapse of the earth and the appearance of scales on land show the failure of earth and overflow of water.[69p]
Bloating, diarrhea, and intestinal rumbling indicate a deficiency in the spleen's earth element. Tai Xi corresponds to the kidney meridian. If one excessively purges and the Tai Xi pulse disappears, the earth fails and the water fluxes downward excessively. When there is a serious overflow of water, the kidney qi is depleted. This corresponds to the brilliance of the year star (Jupiter), indicating the dominance of wood.

When there is an excess of metal this year, dry energy circulates, affecting the liver wood. The people suffer from pain in the lower ribs and lower abdomen, red eyes, eye sores, and hearing loss. When the suppression is severe, the body feels heavy and troubled, the chest is painful and radiates to the back, and there is fullness and pain in the lower ribs that radiates to the lower abdomen. This corresponds to the Tai Bai star (Venus).

Note: When there is an excess of metal this year and dry energy flows, the liver wood is affected. Pain in the lower ribs and lower abdomen indicates liver disease. The liver opens to the eyes, hence the eye pain and sores; if the liver is deficient, there is hearing loss.[70p]
Those who are heavy in weight experience a deadly chill, lacking any vibrant life force. Those troubled by grievances have their liver qi counterflowing and unable to relax. The Classic text states: Kidney deficiency, spleen deficiency, and liver deficiency all lead to a heavy and troubled body. The Treatise on the True Organs of the Jade Mechanism states: If the liver meridian is deficient, it causes pain in the chest that radiates to the back, and fullness in the sides. Tai Bai refers to the planet Venus. When the metal energy prevails, it corresponds upwards to the brightness of Tai Bai. When the metal influence is excessive, it leads to years categorized by the metal element. When it becomes extreme, it results in wheezing, coughing, counterflowing qi, shoulder and back pain, and illness in the lower body including the thighs, knees, and feet. This corresponds to the star of the comet.

Note: An excessive chill can lead to a deficiency in metal energy and a resurgence of fire energy. Wheezing and coughing indicate lung disease. The lung shu points are located on the shoulders and back, hence the shoulder and back pain. Illness in the lower body occurs when metal energy is deficient, affecting the water organs derived from it.[71p]
The excessive indulgence of metal leads to a depletion of its foundational essence; when metal is depleted, it cannot generate water, which allows fire to gain strength and flourish. Thus, there is an astrological correspondence with the brightening of the comet.

When energy is gathered and heightened, vitality descends; plants and trees wither, turning yellow and falling. Illness returns with violent pain, and the sides are restricted, making it impossible to turn. Severe cough leads to significant bleeding. When the Great Surge is obstructed, death is inevitable and cannot be treated. This corresponds above to the star Venus.

(Note: The explanation clarifies that "gathering energy" refers to the energy of metal, while "vitality" refers to the energy of wood. The gathering of metal energy and the suppression of wood vitality cause plants to wither. Violent pain and restriction of the sides indicate liver and gallbladder ailments, as the liver meridian passes through the lungs, resulting in severe cough; the liver's function of storing blood explains the bleeding as well. The Great Surge is the meridian of the liver, and strong metal energy corresponds above to the brightness of Venus.)[72p]
In this year, excessive water has led to a prevalence of cold air. The邪 (pathogenic factors) affects the heart fire, causing the people to suffer from symptoms such as fever, irritability, restlessness, cold limbs, general coldness, delirium, and heart pain, indicating the arrival of cold air early. This is reflected in the celestial bodies, specifically the star Chen.

(Note: The explanation describes how excessive water leads to flowing cold air, thereby harming the heart’s fire. The cold air overpowers the fire, resulting in symptoms like fever and irritability. Heart palpitations are caused by water vapor affecting the heart. Restlessness arises when fire energy does not harmonize with yin energy. The extreme cold causes cold limbs, and a decline in the fire of the Triple Burners leads to general coldness and mental unrest, manifesting as delirium. Cold is associated with winter, hence the early arrival of cold air in this year's climate, which correlates with the star Chen, representing water. The excessive water causes the star Chen to shine more brightly. When water is overly excessive, it relates to the years particularly abundant in fire.)

In severe cases, symptoms can include abdominal distension, swollen limbs, wheezing cough, night sweats, aversion to wind, heavy rain, and a thick haze.[73p]
The above corresponds with the Zheng Star. [Note: This water is excessively indulgent and harmful to oneself. The theory of the viscera states that a kidney disease results in a large abdomen, swollen legs, coughing, sweating at night, and aversion to wind. This is because the water evil overflows, and when the earth cannot control it, there is a large abdomen and swollen legs; when the water qi rises, there is coughing. The sun's qi is birthed in the water and rules the surface; if the water overflows, the source dries up, and the sun's qi has no means of sustenance. The exterior yang is deficient, hence sweating and aversion to wind. When heavy rain arrives, dust and mist become thick, indicating that the water is indulgent yet the earth’s qi recovers. The Six Elements Discussion states: where the Taiyin reaches, dampness arises, ultimately leading to rainfall. The thick mist indicates that the earthy damp qi is rising. With the earth's qi restored, the Zheng Star shines even brighter.] When the sun is above, rain, ice, snow, and frost fall irregularly, causing humidity to transform things. This results in reverse symptoms of abdominal fullness, intestinal sounds, diarrhea, undigested food, and thirst leading to bizarre behavior. If the Shenmen is extinguished, there is no cure for death. Above it also corresponds with the Yinghuo and Chen Stars. [Note: The one above the sun indicates that the cold water governs the atmospheric qi, adding to its presence above, namely in the years of Bingchen and Bingxu, which are the years of the heavenly sign. The mingling of cold water is why rain, ice, snow, and frost fall irregularly. Ice represents the variability of cold water. When rain descends, the earth becomes damp and things transform. The ailments of abdominal fullness, intestinal sounds, diarrhea, and undigested food are all proofs of the water overflowing and the earth succumbing. The spleen cannot transport its fluids, hence the thirst. The humidity appears prominently, hence the strange behavior. Shenmen refers to the heart channel. The water qi is exceedingly strong, leading to a dimming of the Yinghuo and a brighter Chen Star.][74p]
The emperor said: "Good! What if it does not suffice?" Qi Bo replied: "It is important to inquire! When the year's wood fails, the dry air prevails, the vital energy loses its response, and grass and trees flourish late. When the chill and killing energy is excessive, even the sturdy wood suffers damage, while the soft and wilted become pale and dry. This corresponds to the appearance of the Tai Bai star."

[Note: When the year's energy is insufficient, what one cannot overcome is insulted and exploited. Thus, the main influence of the year's wood is inadequate, and the dry energy of metal prevails, causing the vital energy of wood to lose its timing and response, resulting in late flourishing of grass and trees. The excessive chill and killing atmosphere affect even the hard and strong wood, which suffers harm; the soft and wilted become pale and dry. The metal energy dominates, leading to the appearance of the brighter Tai Bai star. The wood influence is insufficient, resulting in the Year of the Six Ding.] The people suffer from internal heat, experiencing pain in the ribs and sides, lower abdominal pain, rumbling intestines, and diarrhea, with cool rain arriving timely. This also corresponds to the appearance of the Tai Bai star. Its grains are pale.[75p]
Note: The "Middle Clear" refers to the coolness of the air residing within, resulting in a cool internal energy. Pain in the sides and lower abdomen is associated with liver wood disorders. The food energy enters the stomach, dispersing essence in the liver and circulating energy in the tendons. When the liver energy is deficient and rebellious, combined with the Middle Clear, it leads to rumbling in the intestines and diarrhea. The metal energy is cool, hence the arrival of cool rain; metal can generate water. When the metal energy prevails, it corresponds above to Venus, whose brilliance is magnified. The five grains receive the energies of the five elements from the earth, growing, transforming, and storing nutrients. Wood is controlled by metal, thus the grains appear bluish-green.

When Yangming rises, the vital energy loses its regulation; grasses and trees flourish once more, and the transformation of energy becomes urgent. It also corresponds above to Venus, the stabilizing star. Its influence is early and flourishing.

Note: Yangming, being dry metal, rises above in the control of the heavens, represented by the years of Ding Yin and Ding You, known as the years of heavenly punishment. The wood of the year is insufficient, combined with the presence of metal energy above, thus leading to the loss of the wood's vital energy regulation.[76p]
The grass and trees receive the punishment of metal and thus flourish again. If the wood is insufficient, it cannot control the earth; hence, the transformation of energy becomes urgent. The energy of metal and earth prevails, corresponding to Venus, the bright star. The wood succumbs to the control of metal, hence it governs the azure hue appearing early, and when it is controlled, it embodies the principle of transformation and vitality.

In all the yin years, the influence is not sufficient; thus, there are only the years of Ding Mao, Ding You, Ji Si, Ji Hai, Xin Chou, and Xin Wei. In those years of Gui and Yi, there is no superior conjunction of heaven.

As for the revival, it is the mother of the bulging offspring. The flowing fire refers to the great fire descending. At the turn of summer and autumn, the great fire flows westward, scorching the metal with heat. The long summer, where the wet earth dominates energy, results in damp conditions turning dry due to the summer heat, causing all things to become soft and brittle, leading to withered grass and trees. The lower body regenerates, and blossoms and fruits transform simultaneously. Diseases of cold and heat—sores, rashes, abscesses—occur. This corresponds to the wandering star (Mars) and Venus above, while the grains are firm and white.

(Note: Revival refers to the mother’s accumulated energy. Flowing fire indicates the great fire pouring downward. At the transition between summer and autumn, the great fire flows westward, scorching the metal. The long summer, ruled by damp earth, becomes hot and dry, making all things brittle and leading to withered vegetation. Fire governs the long energy, thus the lower body regenerates. Summer is the season of blossoms, while autumn signifies maturity; therefore, fire controls metal, allowing blossoms and fruits to transform together. Cold and heat afflictions are all illnesses caused by summer heat. This corresponds to Mars shining brightly above and Venus dimming its brightness. The grains are white and firm, reflecting the autumn's harvest, thus they mature early.)

With the early arrival of White Dew, the harvest killing energy manifests. Cold rain harms the crops, and insects feast on the sweet, yellow plants. The spleen earth suffers from evil influences, the red aura transforms afterwards, and heart energy treats late. The influence above overcomes the lung metal, resulting in the white energy being subdued, and thus the grains do not mature. Coughing and sneezing occur. This corresponds to Venus and the bright star above.[77p]
This discussion occurs in the year influenced by Yangming, where the metal energy is prominent, resulting in an early arrival of White Dew at the transition from summer to autumn, and the lethal energy is activated while fire remains subdued. In years lacking this influence, the prevailing energies act recklessly, causing self-weakening in their positions, allowing the rebalancing energies to prevail. Now, under Yangming’s influence, the metal energy is indeed strong. When metal energy is strong, its offspring energy can also prevail; thus, the offspring of fire and wood wish to regain their influence, but the offspring of metal can counter them, leading to subsequent transformations in red energy. Cold rain, the essence of cold water, is the energy of metal’s offspring. Following the prolonged energies, the command to store early acts, therefore causing harm to all things, which disrupts the growth of grains. Insects respond to the humid air of rain and thrive, yet at the transition from summer to autumn, the earth energy is in action but overpowered by the cold rain, resulting in insects consuming sweet and ripe crops. The spleen’s earth element is affected by this malevolent force, leading to symptoms in the lungs and nasal passages, hence causing coughs and clear nasal discharge.[78p]
When the comet appears, it revives its brilliance, while Venus dims its light. In years when fire is not sufficient, cold prevails, and long governance is ineffective. The things below flourish but are repressed; when cold is severe, the vital energy does not transform, and thus beauty withers. This corresponds with the appearance of the constellations.

(Note: The lines explain that in a year where fire is weak, water dominates, leading to pervasive cold and ineffective governance. All beings require vital energy to flourish, but when the cold prevails, this energy is suppressed, hindering growth and vitality.)[79p]
The people suffer from internal pain in the chest, fullness in the sides, pain in both flanks, and discomfort between the shoulder blades and in both inner arms. There is vexation and obscurity, and sudden heart pain causing muteness. The chest and abdomen are distended, with pain radiating from the flanks to the lower back, making it difficult to bend or extend, as if the hips and thighs are separated. This corresponds to the stars of Mercury and the celestial dragon.

[Note: When the fire element is insufficient, cold prevails, preventing yang energy from transforming, resulting in various pains. The phrase 'cold prevailing leads to painful obstruction' reflects this. Vexation and obscurity represent the invasion of cold and dampness. The chill from the water affects the heart, hence the heart pain. The heart's association with speech leads to sudden muteness. The Taiyang (Sun) governs all yang energies that arise amidst cold water; excessive cold leads to a deficiency of yang. The inability to bend or extend indicates that the problem resides in the tendons, as Taiyang governs the tendons, and the deficiency of yang energy cannot nourish them.][80p]
The illness caused by solar energy manifests as a sensation of the waist being broken, the thigh unable to bend, a knotting in the back of the knee, and a feeling of cracking in the ankle, which is known as ankle deficiency. This corresponds with the dimming of the Red Planet and the increased brightness of the star of the morning. Fire is constrained, hence the grain and dye are affected.

If it recurs, dust and gloom will accumulate, heavy rain is imminent, and black air will desecrate. Symptoms include excessive drooling, a bloated abdomen, inability to eat or drink, cold sensations, rumbling in the intestines, diarrhea, abdominal pain, violent cramps, weakness, and the feet unable to support the body. This corresponds with the restraint of the stars. The original grain cannot be formed.

(Note: The text refers to excessive water and the recovery of earth energy, where the accumulated dust steams upward, leading to imminent heavy rain. The energy of the earth rises and manifests as clouds and rain. According to the Six Elements’ Key Concepts, the moisture associated with the moon ultimately leads to rain. The black air represents the water energy, while the term "desecrate" indicates the lower position of earth energy recovering and water energy being subdued.)[81p]
The ducks are full but unable to move, indicating signs of cold and dampness. It is due to excessive cold water, compounded by wet soil, that these ailments arise. This corresponds to the brightening of the northern star and the dimming of the dawn star. The cold and dampness oppose each other, and without the transformation of dryness and heat, the essence of life cannot come to fruition.

If the earth is insufficient, the wind will then greatly circulate, and the vital energy will not direct its course. The grass and trees flourish abundantly, swaying excessively, becoming lush but lacking substance. This aligns with the position of the annual star.

Note: When the earth's energy is lacking, wood prevails, hence the strong winds arise, while the transforming energy of the earth cannot establish its governance. Wind nurtures growth, while the earth solidifies existence, thus the grass and trees may be lush but often do not yield fruit. This reflects the increased radiance of the annual star in a year when the earth's energy falls short, specifically during the sixth year of the cycle.[82p]
When the people suffer from food poisoning, cholera, weight issues, abdominal pain, throbbing in the muscles and bones, they become irritable, maintaining pent-up energy and taking action. Insects that hibernate appear early, and they are generally sick from the cold within. This corresponds to the year star and the town star. Their grains are infested.

[Note: Food poisoning, cholera, weight issues, abdominal pain, and muscle throbbing are all illnesses caused by the excess of wind and wood injuring the earth. The movement of the muscles and bones indicates diseases of the Jueyin and Shaoyang. Excess wind and wood cause the muscles and bones to tremble and irritability to arise. If the earth's energy is inadequate, wood has no restraint, hence the pent-up energy leads to action, and hibernating insects attach early. Those sick from cold within are affected by cold water, while fire and earth are weakened. This corresponds to the increased brightness of the year star and the diminished color of the town star. The earth is subjected, hence the infestation of their grains.]

When recovery occurs, governance becomes strict. The wood is dark and sculpted, causing pain in the chest and flanks, radiating down to the lower abdomen, leading to deep sighing. Insects consume sweetness, and yellow energy settles in the spleen, resulting in a reduction of infested grains, leading to less flavorful food and a decline in the quality of grain.[83p]
The above corresponds to the White Star and the Year Star.

[Note: The earth is weak and the wood is excessive; therefore, metal restores it, leading to strict governance, and is named 'the dark wood carving.' Symptoms include pain in the chest and sides that radiates down to the lower abdomen, which is due to liver wood illness. The "Neijing" states: Those with gallbladder issues sigh frequently. This is because wood stagnates, causing the gallbladder energy to be unrelaxed, hence the sighing as a means to release it. Insects are affected by cold and dampness, feeding on the sweet yellow energy trapped in the spleen, which in turn causes water to invade the earth. Thus, when the earth fails to circulate properly, the stored energy is mobilized, and although metal restores it, the offspring also follow this. When metal energy is restored, the dark valley is damaged. When water energy prevails, the dark valley diminishes, leading the people to have less and less flavorful food. The above corresponds to the White Star increasing its brightness.]

Looking up to the Jue Yin, the flowing waters do not freeze, and the hibernating insects come forth. If the stored energy is not utilized, the white does not restore. Looking up to the Year Star, the people will prosper.[84p]
Note: In the upper realm is the element of Jueyin, corresponding to the years of Ji-Si and Ji-Hai. When Jueyin is above, Shaoyang is below; hence, flowing water does not freeze, and hibernating insects do not hide. When the qi is stored but not used, it is said to be below the midpoint of the year, gaining the fire of Shaoyang, resulting in a winter that is not cold. Even if the wood of the year does not seek its virtue, it still overcomes and uses the earth. However, when Jueyin governs the heavens, the wood qi is not empty, hence the white (referring to frost) does not return. In the upper realm corresponds with the year star increasing its brightness. It is noted that the winning qi is predominant before the midpoint of the year, while the recovering qi prevails after. During autumn and winter, the wood qi has equalized, and the gold qi does not return; therefore, the people can attain health. One must understand that the winning qi acting recklessly damages its original position, leaving both child and mother devoid; thus, the recovering qi is able to restore. If the original qi is not empty, then the child qi is also substantial, and the recovering qi fears its child and does not dare to restore.[85p]
The year of metal does not prevail; the fiery energies arise. Vital forces are in use, with long-lasting energies dominating. All things flourish, and the dryness shines forth. It corresponds to the planet Mars.

Note: When the metal influence is weak, the fire energies prevail. Metal cannot control wood, hence the life force of wood is utilized. The dominance of the long-lasting fire energies leads to vigorous growth, hence all things flourish. The fiery energies prevail, causing dryness to shine forth. It corresponds to Mars, whose brightness is significantly enhanced. The year of metal does not prevail; it is the Year of the Six Yi.

People suffer from shoulder and back pain, and nasal congestion; blood flows downwards, the vital forces are collected afterwards. It corresponds to the planet Venus, for its grains are hard and sharp.

Note: The lungs are associated with the shoulders and back, hence people suffer from these pains. The low pressure at the head is referred to as nasal congestion. The meridian texts say: the lungs cause movement, leading to pain in the lower abdomen, and in severe cases, it could lead one to grasp at their hands in distress.[86p]
Sneezing indicates lung diseases. Blood in stool indicates that fire is forcing blood downwards. When metal is restrained, it collects energy until autumn is deep, and only then does it move. This corresponds to the pale appearance of Venus. When energy gathers, grains afterwards become coarse and substantial.

Then suddenly, cold rain arrives, leading to sleet, hail, frost, and snow, which kills living things. Yin grows constricted, and yang reverses and ascends, causing pain in the head and temples, extending to heat at the crown. This corresponds to the star Chen.

When the red valley does not form, people suffer from mouth ulcers, and severe cases lead to heart pain.

(Note: When metal is weak and fire is excessive, water then returns, thus the sudden cold rain. The subsequent sleet kills living things, representing the transformation of cold water. In autumn and winter, yang energy should be stored in the yin organs. The constricting cold air reverses and presses against yang outside, causing it to ascend, resulting in pain in the head and warmth at the crown, which corresponds to the brighter star Chen. Water exceeds its long energy, thus the red valley does not form. The cold energy of water ascends, forcing the heart's fire to flare outward, hence people suffer from mouth ulcers, and in severe cases, heart pain.)

In years when water is insufficient, humidity prevails, the long energy is counterproductive, and transformations occur rapidly, with frequent summer rains. This corresponds to the star Zhen.

(Note: When the water flow is insufficient, earth prevails, hence the great spread of humidity. The weakness of water cannot restrain fire, resulting in the long energy being counterproductive. When fire and earth combine, the transformation of earth's energy is rapid, thus summer rains occur frequently. The records of the six elements state that wherever the Taiyin reaches, it causes transformation into clouds and rain. This corresponds to the brighter star Zhen. When water flow is insufficient, it is a year of the six Xins.)[87p]
The people suffer from symptoms such as abdominal fullness, a heavy body, diarrhea, cold sores, excessive fluid, pain in the lower back and thighs, difficulty in the knees and legs, restlessness, foot weakness, coldness in the feet, and severe cases leading to swelling in the ankles. The stored energy is in disarray, and the kidney energy is unbalanced. This corresponds to the planet of the morning star. The grain is glutinous millet.

(Note: Excessive damp earth injures the kidney yin, resulting in these ailments. The "Classic of Suwen" states that excess yang energy can lead to insufficient nourishment, resulting in boils. When yin and yang do not communicate and the two heats clash, it leads to pus formation. Additionally, it states that when cold evil invades the meridians and cannot be expelled, it results in boils. This indicates cold poison without heat transformation, hence the occurrence of cold sores, with fluid but no pus. The cold energy rising causes restlessness. The water's stored energy cannot manifest its directives, and the kidney energy, related to the water organ, cannot be balanced. This also corresponds to the morning star losing its brightness. Glutinous millet, being black millet, gains its moisture from the earth, leading to the formation of glutinous grain.)[88p]
When the upper celestial body aligns with the Moon, there are frequent occurrences of extreme cold, and hibernating insects have already hidden away. The ground accumulates solid ice, and sunlight fails to provide warmth. As a result, the people suffer from cold diseases below; in severe cases, they experience abdominal distension and swelling. This corresponds with the Zhuan star, presiding over the valley grains.

(Note: The commentary explains that the heavenly energy, when aligned with the Moon, indicates the years of Xin Chou and Xin Wei. The Moon, representing damp earth in the heavens, leads to the cold water of the Sun in the springs, which causes the extreme cold to occur frequently, and hibernating insects to hide away. Due to the persistent cold, sunlight fails to warm above, and the cold water in the springs causes the people below to suffer from diseases; in severe cases, abdominal swelling and distension occur due to excessive dampness injuring the earth element of the spleen. The celestial alignment corresponds with the Zhuan star shining brightly above and indicates the successful harvest in the valley below.)[89p]
When strong winds arise, the grass bends and trees fall, growth becomes lacking in vitality, and the complexion changes frequently. The muscles and bones are affected, causing shivers and trembling, with vision unclear. Things become sparse and break, and the flesh develops rashes. The energy is trapped in the diaphragm, causing pain in the heart and abdomen, and the yellow energy diminishes, leading to poor harvests. This corresponds to the year star.

The notes explain that water is weak and earth prevails, so the intense winds arise, causing the grass to droop and trees to drop, hence the lack of vibrant growth. The Yangming element, associated with earth, controls the face, resulting in the complexion changing frequently. Yangming regulates the muscles and tendons, which are all connected to the bones; thus, when the earth energy is harmed, the muscles and bones are affected too. The shivers and trembles refer to sudden movements. When vision is unclear, it indicates that the eyes are impaired due to the winds damaging the blood. When things break due to wind, it is described as splitting. Rashes occur when wind enters the diaphragm; it causes pain above in the heart and below in the abdomen. Earth governs the formation of things, and its energy being harmed results in poor harvests. The phenomenon corresponds to the year star, which shines more brightly.

The emperor said: "Good! I wish to hear about the timing!"[90p]
The notes explain that the four seasons correspond to the victory and recovery of the five movements. The "True Discussion" states: at the beginning of the qi, with the arrival of the three qi, the heavenly qi governs it, exemplifying its victory; at the end of the four qi, the earthly qi governs it, exemplifying its recovery. The five movements govern the years, with the victorious qi before the midpoint of the year and the recovering qi after it. In the case of the victories and recoveries of the four seasons, they follow the governing times for victory and also follow the governing times for recovery, which is different from the yearly movement.

Qibo then says: Indeed, what a question! If wood does not flourish, then metal should overcome it; just as in spring, if there are harmonious transformations, then in autumn there will be clear and cool mists and dews. If in spring there is a severe and destructive victory, then in summer there will be the scorching heat of recovery. The afflictions arise from the east, and affect the liver internally, with illness manifesting externally in the joints.

The notes clarify that if wood does not flourish, then metal should overcome it; just as when spring has the harmony of transformation, autumn will have the governance of cool mists and dews. These each fulfill their rightful place in the four seasons, without victory or recovery, exemplifying the harmony of qi. If spring has a severe and destructive victory, then summer will have the intense heat of recovery.[91p]
The disasters and misfortune are governed by the East, with the liver as the organ involved. The illnesses manifest in internal places such as the ribs, which are related to the liver. Externally, issues arise in the joints, as the liver governs the tendons. The same applies to the other four seasons.

When fire is insufficient, summer shows bright and apparent transformations, while winter has a serious and frigid governance. Summer may face grim and chilling victories, leading to seasonal disturbances with fog and heavy rains. The disasters occur in the South, with the heart as the governing organ. The diseases affect the internal spaces of the chest and ribs, while externally, they affect the meridians, as the heart governs the blood vessels.

When earth is insufficient, the four directions bring forth cloudy and moist transformations, thus spring has policies that stimulate the growth of plants. The four directions also vibrate and sway, leading to autumn's harsh kill and heavy rains. The disasters loom over the four directions, with the spleen as the organ affected. The sicknesses concern the internal areas of the abdomen, while externally, they affect the muscles and limbs.[92p]
The notes explain that the moistening of the earth is the virtue of soil transformation, and the sounding of drums represents the regulations of wood. The peace of this atmosphere means there is no overpowering force. The resonance and the floating movement indicate that wood dominates over soil. The cooling and heavy rains signify the return of autumn’s golden qualities. The earth governs the four seasons, hence it's referred to as the four dimensions and as out of season.

The heart is related to the stomach, while the abdomen pertains to the spleen and soil.

When metal is lacking, summer’s radiant and oppressive regulations lead to winter’s severe and orderly responses; summer’s fiery transformations result in autumn’s return of hail, frost, and snow. The afflictions are in the west; the lung is affected, with ailments residing in the chest, sides, shoulders, and back, manifesting externally in the skin and hair.

The notes clarify that the radiant and oppressive nature is the transformation of fire. The Six Elements’ Correct Record states that the lesser yang corresponds to fire, generating steam and humidity. This reflects the constant virtue of transformation. The chest contains the lungs; within the sides are the cloud gate and the heavenly treasury, where the lung meridian emerges. The shoulders and back pertain to the lung reserve, with the skin and hair being under the governance of the lungs.[93p]
When water is insufficient, the four dimensions will be enhanced by the torrential transformation of dust and clouds, leading to gentle winds occasionally arising in response; when dust overwhelms and suddenly pours down, there will also be times of drifting and shaking in restoration. The affliction is to the north, affecting the kidneys, with ailments manifesting internally in the lower back and spine marrow, and externally in the hollow valleys and knees.

As for the governance of the five movements, it is akin to a balance. The high is suppressed, the low is raised, transformations respond, and changes are restored. This is the principle of growth, transformation, fixation, and storage, the natural order of qi. When it deviates from its norm, the universe becomes completely obstructed.

The governance and regulations of the five movements of yin and yang are like the balance of scales. What is elevated and excessive must be suppressed, as it is too much; what is low and lacking must be raised, as it is insufficient. The virtuous transformations respond with the four seasons. Changes follow the times to restore; this is the principle of life, growth, transformation, and storage, the constant qi of the four seasons. When it deviates from its norm, the qi of the universe and the four seasons will all become sealed off.[94p]
Thus it is said: The movement and stillness of Heaven and Earth are recorded by the divine; the alternation of Yin and Yang reveals the signs of cold and heat. This is the meaning of it.

[Note: The energetic movements of Heaven are dynamic and incessant, while the energies of Earth are still and maintain their positions. The divine refers to the nine stars hanging brightly and the seven luminaries revolving. This relates to the previous discussion of rise and fall. Triumph and recovery correspond to the movement and stillness of Heaven and Earth, and growth, transformation, and storage correspond to the alternation of Yin and Yang. Movement and stillness are not visible, yet there are divine records to observe; Yin and Yang are not measurable, but the signs of cold and heat can be known. This is the way of Heaven and Earth concerning Yin and Yang.]

The Emperor said: Your words about the changes of the five energies and the corresponding four seasons can be considered comprehensive! However, the disorder of energies arises from encounters and circumstances, resulting in sudden disasters; how can one anticipate such events? Qi Bo said: The movements and changes of Heaven and Earth are inherently not constant, yet the effects of virtuous governance and decrees regarding disasters are different in their manifestations. The Emperor asked: What does this mean? Qi Bo replied: The east generates wind, and the wind arises from wood.[95p]
Its virtue spreads harmony, its transformation brings prosperity, its governance is expansive, its commands are influential, its changes are dynamic, and its disasters are dispersed. The south generates heat, and heat produces fire. Its virtue is manifest, its transformation flourishes, its governance is reflective, its command is warm, its changes are vibrant, and its disasters scorch. The center generates moisture, and moisture produces earth. Its virtue is humid, its transformation is abundant, its governance is tranquil, its command is moist, its changes are sudden, and its disasters are torrential. The west generates dryness, and dryness produces metal. Its virtue is pure, its transformation is restrained, its governance is incisive, its command is dry, its changes are severe, and its disasters are devastating. The north generates cold, and cold produces water. Its virtue is desolate, its transformation is serene, its governance is solemn, its command is cold, its changes are frigid, and its disasters are hail and snow. Thus, one should observe its movements. There are virtue, transformation, governance, commands, changes, and disasters; things arise from these, and people respond accordingly. This discusses the energies of the five movements and four seasons, highlighting the distinctions of virtue, transformation, governance, commands, and disasters, which must be observed to be understood. In years of excess, there is indulgence; in years of deficiency, there is recovery. This is the regularity of seasonal movements, which can be correlated accordingly.[96p]
The energies of the Five Movements arise from the Five Directions; the energies of the Five Directions converge in the Four Seasons. Although there are changes in the yearly cycles, such as excess and stagnation, there are also harmonies from virtue, transformation, policies, and commands in the Four Seasons, which differ from the annual cycles. Therefore, one must observe the movements of these energies, noting whether they are virtuous, transformative, political, or commanding, as well as whether they indicate disaster or change. All things are affected by these forces, leading to success or failure, and people respond accordingly—either suffering from illness or enjoying health. This relationship of the energies is influenced by the year, the season, the constant, and the variable, and it cannot be predetermined. The Emperor asked: "Your words about the yearly cycles say that there must be balance, corresponding with the Five Stars. Now, virtues, transformations, policies, disasters, and changes are not constant but can arise unexpectedly; do these also lead to changes in the Five Stars?" Qi Bo replied: "We act in accordance with Heaven, hence there should be no reckless actions, and everything will respond appropriately."[97p]
In the end, those actions that occur abruptly are due to the sudden changes in the prevailing energy, which do not respond accordingly. Therefore, it is said: responses are constant, but abrupt actions do not receive a response; this is what it means.

These words imply that the five celestial bodies signify the cycles of the years, yet they do not respond to the abrupt changes of the seasonal energies. To "bear the heaven" means to accept the energies of the five cycles, which align with the transformations of the heavenly stems. By following the heavenly order and acting accordingly, there should be no unprovoked actions, and one will always respond to the five celestial bodies. Abrupt actions arise from the exchanges of the seasonal energies, which do not align with the five celestial bodies; hence, it is again said: responses are constant, but abrupt actions do not receive a response.

"Constant" refers to the five cycles governing the year, which may have excessive or deficient energies and display equilibrium in their interactions. "Abrupt" refers to the energies of the five directions and four seasons, which may suddenly bring about transformations, decrees, disasters, or changes.

The Emperor asked: How is this to be responded to? Qibo replied: Each follows its own energy transformations.

"Energy transformations" refer to the transformations of the five cycles’ energies. The energy of the Jia and Ji cycles transforms into earth, the energy of the Yi and Geng cycles transforms into metal, the energy of the Bing and Xin cycles transforms into water, the energy of the Ding and Ren cycles transforms into wood, and the energy of the Wu and Ji cycles transforms into fire. The years governed by the five yang energies are excessive, while those governed by the five yin energies are deficient, and each corresponds to the five elements in heaven.

The Emperor asked: How do these actions proceed, regarding their speed, and whether they are in harmony or opposition?[98p]
Qibo said: To retain the path for a long time, to guard against retreat while remaining small, is called observing the lower realms.

Notes: The path refers to the route of the five stars. To retain long means to delay and prolong. Guarding against retreat means to go against the advance and maintain its measure. Being small means that light does not manifest. Observing the lower realms refers to observing the distinctions below, in relation to the virtues and faults of rulers and subjects.

To leave by the path and return swiftly, meandering and passing it by, is called inspecting the overlooked faults.

Notes: This means to leave and quickly return, navigating through delays while exceeding the measure. Inspecting overlooked faults refers to examining areas that have not been fully addressed, then revisiting the faults that were neglected.

Staying for a long time and revolving, either departing or adhering, is called deliberating on calamity and its virtues.

Notes: To stay for a long time means to maintain one's position and not depart. Revolving means to rotate and circulate. Either departing or adhering indicates a desire to leave but not leaving. Deliberating on calamity and virtue means discussing the faults of rulers and subjects that might result in calamities versus discussing the virtuous that might result in blessings.

Responding to the near is small, responding to the far is great.[99p]
The notes clarify that misfortunes and blessings correspond to the distance between realms. The brightness is much greater than normal; a doubling of the normal leads to calamities. A slight normality reduces the brightness; another slight normality is referred to as "close observation." Shortcomings are compared to virtue. Virtue brings blessings, whereas shortcomings bring retribution.

The brightness refers to the light of the five stars. Transformation indicates the overwhelming and restorative energy. When the restorative energy is abundant, the celestial light shines greatly beyond the norm; when the restorative energy diminishes, the celestial light appears smaller than usual. If the brightness is twice that of the normal, calamities will ensue.[100p]
If it is less than twice the usual, this is called "observational vision," meaning to look from above downwards, scrutinizing the virtues of the ruler and the people, granting blessings to the virtuous, and punishing the transgressors with disasters. Therefore, the visibility of the stars is such that those high and distant appear small, while those low and near appear large. Thus, when great, joy and anger are close; when small, blessings and disasters are distant.

[Note: Stars high and distant appear small; stars low and near appear large. Joy and anger represent the emotional states of the stars. When the ruler and the people are virtuous, the star imagery expresses joy; when they are at fault, the star imagery expresses anger. When the radiance is greatly magnified, the errors become evident. When the vigilance is small, it seeks to lessen the faults of the ruler and the people. The first speaks to the size of the star imagery corresponding to the distance; the second speaks to the size of the star imagery in relation to the degree of victory and loss; the last addresses the size of the star imagery in relation to the swiftness or delay of blessings and disasters.]

If the annual cycle is excessively overreaching, then the operational stars will move northward.[101p]
【Note: The运星 (Yunxing), or the Star of Fortune, refers to the annual cosmic alignment in the twelfth year known as the Year of the Heavenly Symbol, where cosmic energies are particularly strong. 运星 governs the year's star. 北越 (Beiyue) means going beyond its original measure, becoming closer to the North. The North is the residence of Taiyi, and the conjunction of 北越 with 天枢 (Tianshu) gives it the additional name of 太乙天符 (Taiyi Heavenly Symbol).】 When the energies of fortune and cosmic influences align, they each follow their own path.

【Note: When the energies align, it means the Wood influence meets the Rabbit, the Fire influence meets the Horse, the Earth influence meets the four seasons, the Metal influence meets the Rooster, and the Water influence meets the Rat. This alignment of cosmic energies with the annual energies results in a harmonious year where the stars operate within their proper measures without overwhelming dominance.】 Thus, if the yearly influence is excessive, the ruling star will lose its brilliance and be compromised by its mother influence. If it is insufficient, its appearance will be affected by what it cannot withstand. 【Note: This continues the previous discussion; for example, if the yearly Wood influence is excessive, the ruling star will overreach into territories it cannot dominate, thus losing luminosity. If the yearly Earth influence is excessive, the ruling star will invade territories of Water it cannot overcome, resulting in the losing star losing luminosity.】[102p]
Those who share in the essence of their mother are said to share in the essence of the Mother of the Stars of Fear, which also loses its color. The Mother of the Stars of Fear is the same as the Child of the Winning Star, suggesting that when it becomes excessive, it causes harm, and cannot nurture its child’s essence. In a year when the influences are insufficient, the stars that are not conquered also simultaneously appear in color. For example, if wood is insufficient in the year, the influencing star, the Bright White Star, increases in brightness, while the energy of the earth that is not conquered is fearless; thus, its stable star also simultaneously reveals its color. The five movements are the same.

The resemblance is obscure, and none can grasp its subtleties. Those who are mournful—who sets the good standard?

(Note: The term "resemblance" refers to following a principle or model; "obscure" indicates a perplexing demeanor. This suggests that when taking guidance from star patterns—good or ill—none can fully understand their subtle intricacies. The sentiment of being mournful indicates an anxiety in observing the star’s consistency of change in emotions and conditions, questioning which law should be preferred, highlighting the difficulty in divining star patterns.)

Irresponsible actions lack basis, indicating fear toward the ruler.[103p]
Annotations: If one does not seek good methods but makes reckless statements about omens, then whatever is said about fortune and misfortune lacks evidence. This only serves to instill fear in lords and kings, indicating a lack of learning and skill in diviners.

The Emperor asked: What are the indications of calamity? Qi Bo replied: Each calamity comes from its own transformation. Therefore, there are times of prosperity and decline, violations of proper order, varying numbers of protective forces, visible signs of good and evil, conditions of victory and defeat, and manifestations of fortune and misfortune.

Annotations: The indications of calamity refer to changes in the five planets, which result in disasters affecting the populace. Each follows the energies of the five elements. The changes in the five planets occur in due time, bringing both prosperity and decline, with mutual violations and proper sequences; on certain days of protection, there are many or few; the visible signs may indicate joy and abundance or worry and anger; the five constellations may reflect victories or losses; they correspond to the ruler and the people, yielding blessings of virtue or disasters and illness.

The Emperor asked: What do you mean by good and evil? Qi Bo replied: There is joy and anger, worry and mourning, abundance and drought. These are the constants of signs, and they must be carefully observed.[104p]
[Note: Wang Bing said: The appearance of the Five Stars occurs when seen in the deep of night. When people see it, they feel joy; this is the joy of the stars. If they see it with fear, this is the anger of the stars. When the light is dim and flickering, appearing sometimes bright and sometimes dark, this reflects the worry of the stars. When the light is completely distinct, neither bright nor dull, and does not resemble others, this signifies the loss of the stars. When the light is round and clear, neither growing nor shrinking, appearing serene and radiant, this is the joy of the stars. When the light comes forth with intensity, overflowing with brilliance, and its appearance is awe-inspiring, this indicates the anger of the stars.] The Emperor asked: Are the six phenomena different in height and depth? Qi Bo answered: The manifestations vary in height and depth, yet their responses are unified; hence, people respond correspondingly. [Note: This refers to the manifestations of joy, anger, worry, loss, grace, and dryness. Despite being high or small, near or far, their responses are unified, allowing people to respond and determine auspiciousness or misfortune without distinction.] The Emperor said: Good! What about the effects of virtue and governance on movement and stillness, loss and gain? Qi Bo replied: Virtue and governance cannot increase through calamities and changes. [Note: Wang Bing said: The movements and stillness of heaven and earth, the cyclical changes of yin and yang, repay virtue with virtue and transformation with transformation. The effects of governance and disasters are the same; hence, they cannot increase.] Prosperity and decline cannot be multiplied.[105p]
【Note: Wang Bing said: "Victory overshadows abundance, and victory diminishes abundance. Therefore, it is said that they cannot exceed each other." The interactions of the small and large also cannot surpass one another.】

【Note: Excess leads to a great year, insufficiency leads to a small year. When there is surplus, it goes forth,but when there is a lack, it follows behind; hence, it is said that they cannot surpass one another.】 The use of ascending and descending also cannot exist without each other.

【Note: 'Use' refers to the operation of yin and yang energies. The qi of heaven and earth, when it ascends, then descends; when it descends, then ascends. Cold follows warmth, and warmth follows cold. Therefore, it is said that they cannot exist without each other.】 Each acts according to its movement and returns accordingly.[106p]
Note: The interactions of winning and losing, the ascension and descension of yin and yang, all follow the movements of their respective energies. The Treatise on the Six Subtle Points states: Success and failure depend on movement. If there is unceasing movement, then transformation occurs!

The Emperor asked: How does illness arise? Qi Bo replied: The transformation of qi is an omen of virtue; political decrees represent the manifestation of qi; changes indicate the pattern of return; disasters and misfortunes mark the beginning of harm.

Note: This refers to illness arising from changes. The quality and transformation of seasonal qi is the harmony of qi; having governance and decrees signifies the elucidation of qi. Changes are indicative of retribution, while disasters and misfortunes originate from the harm experienced by the people.

When qi overcomes one another, there is harmony; when it does not, there is illness. Severe affliction from the pathogenic influence leads to serious conditions.

Note: Qi refers to the transformative energy. According to the Treatise on the Six Organs and Their Correspondences, illness arises upon change; what is overcome is subtle, while what is not is illness, leading to severe affliction from the pathogenic influence resulting in death. Thus, if conditions are not right, it remains subtle; when conditions are right, it becomes severe. This refers to the transition of qi: spring transforms into the energy of late summer, late summer into winter qi, winter transitions to the heat of summer, summer shifts to autumn qi, and autumn reverts back to spring qi. The concept of achieving the victories of the five elements in their appropriate times leads to the mutual victory and transformation of seasonal qi, resulting in harmony. If the wood element does not flourish in spring, and if the metal element becomes excessive, then spring can turn into a season of harshness.[107p]
If the fire of the year is insufficient and the water of the year is excessive, during summer it should be hot, yet cold air prevails; at this time, the seasonal energies do not overcome the transformed energies, leading to illness. Therefore, when the time is not suitable for overcoming, it is mild; when the time is suitable for overcoming, it is severe. Those who are heavily affected by evils refer to the evils of the four seasons being out of order.

The Emperor said: "Good! The discussion of the essence of light, the great sage's undertaking, clarifies the great way and connects to the infinite, reaching the boundless. I have heard that a good expression of heavenly concepts must resonate with humanity; a good expression of antiquity must validate in the present; a good expression of qi must manifest in things; a good expression of response harmonizes with the transformations of heaven and earth. Those who speak well of transformation and change convey the principles of the divine. Who but the Master can articulate the ultimate way?"

[Note: The discussion of the essence of light refers to the principles of the divine. The great sage's undertaking reaches the infinite, governing the people above and cultivating oneself below, with virtue and grace flowing downwards, bestowed upon future generations, with no end in sight. The Book of Changes states: “Those who understand the way of transformation know what the divine accomplishes.”]

He then chose a good omen and stored it in the spiritual chamber, reading it every morning, calling it the interplay of qi and change. He did not dare to speak it without fasting and performing self-discipline, exercising caution in its transmission.

[Note: The spiritual chamber refers to the secret space of the spiritual orchid. It represents the way of yin and yang of heaven and earth, which the supreme deity values. Not daring to speak it without fasting demonstrates utmost respect and caution, fearing to pass it on to the wrong person and carelessly disclose the heavenly treasures.][108p]
The Great Discussion on the Five Constants of Governance [Part 1]

The Yellow Emperor asked: "The vastness of the great void is expansive, the five movements rotate irregularly, prosperity and decline differ, and losses and gains follow each other. I wish to know how to define ‘balanced qi’ and what it signifies in terms of regulation."

Qi Bo replied: "What an excellent question! The Wood element represents harmony, Fire signifies brightness and elevation, Earth embodies nurturing transformation, Metal symbolizes refinement and balance, and Water signifies tranquility and acquiescence."

The Emperor said: "What happens when it is inadequate?" Qi Bo replied: "Wood represents waning harmony, Fire indicates concealed brightness, Earth stands for lowered supervision, Metal means following change, and Water signifies diminished flow."

This describes the inadequacy of the five movements, each having its own designation. When the Wood element is lacking, it cannot spread the warm and harmonizing qi and therefore weakens.[109p]
If the fire energy is insufficient, then the brightness of its decree will not rise but will be subdued. If the earth energy is insufficient, then the lowly will guard but cannot provide for the four directions. The nature of metal is inherently rigid; if it is insufficient, it will change due to the influence of fire. If the water energy is insufficient, then the source and flow will dry up.

The Emperor asked, "What is excessive?" Qibo replied: "Wood signifies growth, fire signifies brilliance, earth signifies stability, metal signifies solidity, and water signifies overflowing."

(Note: The five energies being excessive each have corresponding names. The excess of wood energy is growth at its peak. Brilliance symbolizes abundant light. Stability signifies height and substance. The essence of metal is solid and firm, useful for creation. Overflowing means being full and spilling over.)

The Emperor said, "I wish to hear about the indicators of the three energies." Qibo replied, "What a thorough question! In the season of harmony, the virtue of wood circulates broadly, yang expands while yin disperses, the five transformations are manifested and balanced; their energy is upright, their nature follows, their applications vary, their transformations produce prosperity, they correspond to plants and trees, their governance is expansive, their indicators are warm and harmonious, their decree is wind, and their organ is the liver. The liver fears clarity, governs the eyes, corresponds to hemp grains, fruits that are plums, is solid in form, responds in springtime, corresponds to insect fur, is related to dogs, its color is green, it nourishes tendons, its ailments are urgent fullness in the interior, its flavor is sour, its tone is the horn, its substance is firm in the middle, and its number is eight."[110p]
The Three Energies refer to the balanced energy and the extremes of excess and deficiency. The balanced motion of wood represents harmony. When the virtue of wood circulates freely, the yang energy expands and the yin energy diffuses, encompassing the five energies of growth, transformation, storage, and their emergence. When the growth energy is harmonious, all five energies are balanced. "Duan" signifies uprightness, while "Sui" embodies softness and obedience. The straight and curved represent the characteristics and utility of wood. "Sheng Rong" refers to the vitality of wood’s growth and transformation. "Lei" pertains to the classification of things. The emergence and scattering signify the governance by wood. "Wen He" indicates the warmth and harmony of spring. The wind in the sky represents the commands of wood. Within the organs, it corresponds to the liver, which fears the clarity that wood resists against metal. It relates to the eyes among the sensory organs. In the grains, it corresponds to hemp, which resembles wood in form and has a green hue. In fruits, it represents the season, appearing green and tasting sour. The core contains the kernel, which is split into two parts, representing the origin of wood’s vitality. Caterpillars, like the dense forests of grass and trees, are born from vegetation. Dogs exhibit a courageous disposition, responding to the rising energy of spring with anger. The liver governs the tendons, therefore its nourishment is in the sinews. Abdominal urgency and fullness are symptoms of liver illness. "Jiao" is the sound of wood, which thrives in water, making it strong and resilient. The number eight is the manifestation of wood. In the era of rising brightness, governance is based on rectified yang, where virtues are widely applied and the five transformations are balanced.[111p]
Its energy is high, its nature is swift, its function is to burn and scorch, its transformation is abundant, its kind is fire, its governance is bright and radiant, its climate is hot and sultry, its command is heat, and its organ is the heart. The heart fears cold, it governs the tongue, its grains are wheat, its fruit is apricot, its essence is connected, it responds to summer, its insects fly, its livestock is horses, its color is red, it nourishes blood, its sickness is twitching and convulsions, its taste is bitter, its sound is a signal, its substance is veins, and its number is seven.

(Note: Fire is positioned in the south, hence it governs the Yang. Fire represents Yang energy, whereby virtues are distributed widely. The warmth of Yang energy is extensively disseminated, and all transformations are balanced, all influenced by the transformation of fire. The energy of fire rises high, hence its energy is elevated; its nature is active and urgent, thus it is swift. Burning and scorching is its function. The flourishing of all things is the transformation of summer. All terrestrial fire shares a kindred nature. Brightness and radiance are the governance of fire. Hot and sultry is the climate of summer. In the heavens, it manifests as heat, which is commanded by fire. In the organs, it is the heart; the heart fears cold because fire fears water. The heart opens to the tongue. Wheat is the grain that matures in summer. The color of apricot is red, and its taste is bitter. Connection refers to the veins of the fruit. Insects that can fly are inspired by the energy of fire. Horses belong to the noon, the livestock of fire. The heart governs blood vessels, thus its nourishment is found in blood. Twitching and convulsions occur when the meridians respond to the energy of fire with contraction. Signal is the sound of fire. Bitter is the taste of fire. Veins refer to the networks of substances. Seven is the number representing the essence of fire.)[112p]
In the era of preparation for transformation, the air is in harmony with heavenly rest. Virtue flows through the four forms of governance, and the five transformations are cultivated together. Its essence is balanced, its nature is compliant, its applications are high and low, its transformations are abundant, its category is earth, its governance is tranquil, its climate is humid and warm, its laws are moist, and its organ is the spleen. The spleen fears the wind, governs the mouth, relates to grains such as millet, fruits such as jujubes, and the substance of meat, responding to the long summer, to parasitic insects, to livestock such as cattle, exhibiting a yellow color, nourishing meat, and dealing with sickness. Its flavor is sweet, its tone is royal, its material is skin, and its number is five.

[Note: Heavenly dominion brings forth life, while earthly dominion nurtures growth. The air of the earth is harmonious and combines with the beauty of heavenly rest, thereby leading to the emergence of all things. The virtues of the earth flow in all directions, allowing the five transformations to develop together. Balance is the essence of earth; gentleness is its inherent nature; high and low represents its body. Both elevation and depression encompass its transformations, demonstrating the utility of the earth. Abundance and richness signify the humidity associated with the earth's transformation. The five directions correspond to the five types of earth, being of the same category. Tranquility and transformation signify the governance of the earth. Warmth and humidity denote the weather of the long summer. Humidity in the heavens represents the laws of earth, while the spleen governs the organ. The fear of wind corresponds to wood, which overcomes earth. The spleen opens to the mouth. Millet is a type of fine grain. Jujubes are yellow in color and sweet in taste. Meat refers to the flesh of fruits. Parasitic worms are afflictions of the physical body. Cattle are livestock pertaining to the earth. The spleen governs muscles, thus its nourishment is in meat.][113p]
Otherwise, the disease of the spleen resides within, and the energies above and below do not interact. The sound of the palace is the sound of the central land. The skin refers to the flesh of the body. The five correspond to the generative numbers of earth. The "Lun" on the six correct registers states: Earth always generates.

Examining the equilibrium of the registers, it accumulates without contention, kills without offense, and the five transformations are clear and distinct. Its energy is pure, its nature is strong, its function is to disperse, its transformation is to consolidate, it resembles metal, its governance is vigorous and austere, its season is clear-cut, its command is dry, and its organ is the lung. The lung fears heat, governs the nose, corresponds to grains and rice, fruits like peaches, has a hard shell, responds to autumn, relates to insects like pests, is associated with chickens, is white in color, nourishes skin and fur, and has coughing as its ailment, its taste is spicy, its tone is that of "shang," its material is externally firm, and its number is nine.

(Note: Gold symbolizes weaponry, and the energy of metal is balanced, hence it accumulates and does not contend. The energies of heaven and earth bring forth life in spring and kill in autumn; killing without offense means not harming anything. The energy of metal is pure and clear, thus the five transformations obtain clarity. Brightness is the energy of gold. Strength and firmness are the nature of metal. All things disperse in the influence of metal. Its energy consolidates, representing the transformation of autumn. The five kinds of metal belong to this category. Firmness, strength, and clarity signify the governance of metal. Clarity relates to the season of autumn. In heaven, it represents dryness, as per the command of metal. The organ is the lung, which fears heat, hence metal fears fire. The lung opens at the nose.)[114p]
Rice is the grain that matures in autumn. Peaches are pink and white, and have fuzz; they are the fruits of the lungs. The hard-shelled fruit and the armored insects are all born from the strong and firm energy. Chickens are naturally combative, influenced by the chilling and lethal energy. The lungs govern the skin and fur, so their nourishment lies in the skin and fur. Coughing is an illness of the lungs. The Shang relates to the sound of the west. Sin represents the flavor of metal. All things share a solid essence, just like the hard shells and armored insects. Nine is the number associated with metal.

The tranquility and compliance of the discipline entails concealment without harm, governing in a way that promotes good descent; thus, the five transformations align harmoniously. Its energy is clear, its nature descends, its function is nourishing and expansive, its transformation is concrete and firm, it is akin to water, its regulations flow and evolve, its conditions are still and austere, its enforcement is cold, and its organ is the kidneys. The kidneys fear moisture and govern the two yin, their grains and beans, their fruit and chestnuts, their essence is moist, responding to winter. They contain insects and scales, domesticate pigs, their color is black, they nourish the bones and marrow, their illness is fatigue, their flavor is salty, their sound is like feathers, their substance is moist, and their number is six.

(Note: The commentary mentions that the smooth functioning of water is known as tranquility and compliance. All things prosper by receiving the vital energy for growth, and with the smooth flow of water, it supports concealment without harming anything. With good governance and descent, the five energies respond, hence they are in harmony. Heaven produces water, therefore its energy is lofty and bright. The essence of water seeks to lower, hence its nature descends. The solidity and firmness of all things is derived from the transformation of concealed energy.)[115p]
The waters of the great earth, like kindred spirits, flow and never cease; this is the governance of water. Condensed and solemn is the season of winter. In the heavens, it manifests as the decree of cold water. In the organs, it corresponds to the kidneys, which are sensitive to dampness; water fears earth. The kidneys open to the two yin passages, thus they govern them. The bean is the valley of water. Its dark brown color and salty flavor are the essence of the kidneys. Moisture refers to that which contains liquid within. Scaled creatures arise from water. The kidneys govern bone marrow, hence their nourishment is found in marrow. The kidneys are the source of vitality; thus when one is ill, the hands and feet become cold. The sound of feathers is associated with water. Six represents the number characterized by water.

Therefore, to allow life and not to kill, to nurture and not to punish, to transform and not to constrain, to gather and not to harm, to store and not to repress—this is called harmonious Qi.

Thus, in the years governed by wood, life energy is obtained without the harshness of metal. In the years governed by fire, the nurturing energy flows without the constraints of water. In the years of earth, transformative energy flourishes without the governance of wood. In the years of metal, gathering energy is achieved without the harm of fire. In the years of water, storing energy is possible without the repression of earth. This is called the year of harmonious Qi.

The principles of harmony are said to conquer life. When life energy does not govern, transforming energy is then exalted. Nurturing energy is naturally balanced, and the decree of gathering comes early. Cool rain descends timely, and wind and clouds rise together. Plants and trees flourish late, their leaves withering and falling. Things bloom and bear fruit, with flesh and skin richly filled within.[116p]
Its energy is condensed, its function is gathered, its movement is soft, restrained, and slow; it emerges with shock and fear. Its organs are the liver, its fruits are jujubes and plums, its solids are kernels and shells, its grains are millet and rice, its taste is sour and bitter, its color is white and grey, its domesticated animals are dogs and chickens, its insects are hairy and shell-like. Its master is fog and dew, sorrowful and desolate; its sound is the musical notes of Jiao and Shang. Its ailments include shaking, edema, and sores. Sweet insects are harmful to the liver. The upper official corresponds to the central palace. When the winds blow fiercely, there is turmoil, and malignancies occur. The so-called revival is masterful over flying and tunneling insects, resembling thunder. If the Wood element is insufficient, it is said to be harmonious, thus the victorious energy conquers its vitality. If the Metal energy is strong, the life force of Wood cannot establish its governance. If the Wood governance is not established, then the Earth energy has no fear, and the transformative energy rises. When Wood declines, the Fire energy does not flourish, thus the breath stabilizes.
