Since the Metal energy is abundant, the collection and commands happen early. Coolness represents Metal transformation, wind corresponds to Wood transformation, and clouds and rain represent Earth transformation; this occurs because the Wood operation is insufficient, hence there are aspects of Metal and Earth transformation. When the vital energy does not govern, the grasses and trees flourish late. The collection and commands arrive early; thus, the crust is dry and the fruits fall. The transformative energy, aligned with the autumnal energies, makes it possible for things to flourish and be substantial, nourishing the inner reaches.[117p]
Convergence is the essence of metal. Gathering is the function of wood. Movement indicates the internal onset of illness; emergence indicates the external manifestation of symptoms. Binding indicates contraction; obstruction indicates thoroughness; restraint indicates urgency; relaxation indicates non-convergence; these are all ailments of the tendons. The Golden Chamber's true words state: In the east, the liver is wood, and its illness manifests as fright. The organ is the liver. Its fruits are jujubes and plums, its shells are pits, its grains are millet and rice, its flavors are sour and pungent, its colors are pale, its animals are dogs and chickens, its insects are hairy and shelled, its sounds are those of horns and merchants. Due to the inadequacy of wood's growth, it is thus transformed by metal and earth. It governs fog and dew, evoking melancholy, overpowering wood; its illness involves agitation and dread, a liver condition, as it stems from metal's transformation. Judgment means half. The lesser horn and judgment merchant are collectively referred to as the year of the six ding, a year when wood's growth is insufficient. The horn indicates the sound of wood, so when wood's growth is insufficient, it governs the lesser horn. Metal is also engaged; thus half aligns with the merchant's metal transformation. The upper horn and correct horn are the same as the years of ding-si and ding-hai. In those years, it encounters the Jueyin celestial official, and since wood's growth is inadequate, it receives celestial assistance, thus resembling the harmonious correct horn. The upper merchant and correct merchant are identical in the years ding-mao and ding-you. In those years, it meets the Yangming celestial official, hence referred to as the upper merchant. With insufficient wood growth, half of the merchant transforms, while also coinciding with the Yangming celestial official's time, so metal is fully engaged, aligning with the authentic merchant of balanced assessment.[118p]
Therefore, ailments manifesting as limb atrophy, sores, and abscesses, along with sweet pests, all arise from a surfeit of metal energy harming the liver. The upper palace shares qualities with the main palace, corresponding to the years of Ding Chou and Ding Wei, when the Tai Yin governs the heavens. Hence, it is called the upper palace. During this time, wood does not flourish; its transformative energy is thus weakened, but it also receives assistance from the heavenly governance. This allows the earth to dominate and aligns with the cycle of transformation, thus making the upper palace akin to the main palace. The autumn winds are harsh and the metal energy is excessive. The heat blazes and boils—this indicates the return of fire. Disasters and misfortunes are associated with the eastern position of Zhen. The term "return" refers to decay arising from wood, and the fire element is represented by flying, indicating the fire generated within wood itself. Maggots are the offspring of flies; when maggots enter ash, they transform into flies. Flies prefer warmth and despise cold, flying by day and hiding at night. The pheasant, as a kind of bird, embodies the transformative energy of fire. The rapidity of thunder is called ting; when wood experiences extreme accumulation, fire wraps around it, producing the energy known as thunder. Thus, the I Ching states that Zhen represents thunder.

The record of hidden brightness is called "victorious growth." When the vital energy is not expressed, it becomes repressed. Collecting energy through regulation leads to balance. The effect of cold clarity is repeated, while heat leads to lightness. Following transformation, life emerges; it grows but does not extend. It becomes substantial yet remains immature, encountering transformation while already aged. The yang energy is restrained, causing hibernating insects to conceal themselves early.[119p]
Its essence is repressed, its use is violent, its movement is evident in change, its release causes pain, its organ is the heart, its fruit is the chestnut and peach, its substance is intertwined and moist, its crops are beans and rice, its taste is bitter and salty, its color is the original cinnabar, its livestock are horses and pigs, its insects have feathers and scales, its master is ice, snow, frost, and cold, its sound is the call of feathers, its illnesses are confusion, sorrow, and forgetfulness, arising from the influence of water. The minor signs are the same as the minor feathers; the upper commerce is the same as the correct commerce. Evil harms the heart. Gathering cold and somber, it brings heavy rain and deluge, afflicting the nine realms. Its master causes sudden downpours, thunder and lightning disturb, and persistent rain falls.

(Note: Fire's absence leads to water prevailing over its growth; thus, the long essence of fire remains unexpressed, while the concealed essence of water becomes manifest. When the essence of fire is subdued, metal has nothing to fear, allowing it to gather its essence and govern independently. Without sufficient fire, the essence of the earth it produces does not thrive, hence balance in transformation is initiated.)[120p]
The cold is persistently clear, and the heat is gradually diminishing; water prevails over fire. As the transformative energy of the earth achieves balance, living things are able to grow. If the energy is not expressed, growth will stall, and thus even the young that have become real will age when they encounter the transformative energy of long summer. The cold and clarity cause the yang energy to retreat. The hidden energy is utilized, causing hibernating insects to come out early. When the energy is stagnant, water restrains its fire. When it is harshly utilized, the nature of fire desires to manifest. The manifesting is the governance of fire. When the manifest becomes concealed, it transforms and becomes cold, producing pain, as the victory of cold leads to pain. The organ associated with the heart is represented by fruits such as chestnuts and peaches, real items like mulberries, grains like beans and rice, flavors like bitterness and saltiness, colors like cinnabar, livestock like horses and pigs, creatures like insects with feathers and scales, and sounds like musical notes from feathers—all experience inadequate movement of fire and thus are influenced by the transformations of metal and water. Ice, snow, and frost are changes brought by water.[121p]
Confusion and sorrow cloud the mind, leaving it insufficient; thus, influenced by water, the heart's fire is diminished. The concept of "lesser fortune" and "lesser wings" both refer to the six Gui years. "Lesser fortune" represents a fire tone, which lacks vigor; hence it is called lesser fortune. Minor engagements occur, therefore lesser fortune and lesser wings transform similarly. The Upper Shang and the True Shang share the same characteristics; they correspond to the Gui-Mao and Gui-You years, where the heavens favor the sun's brightness, hence named Upper Shang. Metal fears nothing but gains the aid of the heavens, marking the cycle of fire's movement and enforcing fair governance; thus, the years of Upper Shang share the same atmosphere as those of True Shang. The combination of metal and water is victorious, yet causes harm to the heart. The atmosphere is heavy and cold, and the intense cold prevails. Relentless rain brings about the return of earth. Disasters and misfortunes are expected from the south of the Li position. Dull clouds obscure the sun. Sudden downpours and excessive rain signify changes in the earth. Thunder shakes the ground, causing fire to surge forth.

The chronicle of the low overseers is called diminished transformation. The energy of transformation does not command, and governance becomes pronounced. When the energy is harmonized, rain becomes misaligned. When energy is contained and balanced, cold winds arise. Vegetation flourishes and appears beautiful, yet lacks substance; it matures only to produce emptiness.[122p]
Its qi is dispersed, its function is calm and stable. Its motion causes sores to burst and swelling to fester. Its manifestations are damp and stagnant. Its organ is the spleen. Its fruits are plums and chestnuts, and its seeds are damp and hard. Its grains are beans and hemp. Its flavor is sour and sweet, and its color is dim yellow. Its livestock includes cattle and dogs. Its insects are hairy and worms. Its primary qualities are drifting, anger, and shaking hair. Its sound is like the palace bell and horn. Its afflictions cause fullness or blockage due to the influence of wood. The lesser palace corresponds with the lesser horn; the upper palace aligns with the true palace; the upper horn matches the true horn. Its illness involves diarrhea and leakage, harmed by evil affecting the spleen. When it shakes and sways, it becomes sparse and falls apart, with its flaws spanning in four directions. Its nature yields to tigers and wolves, and clear qi then is useful, whereas life governance brings disgrace.

(Note: If the earth element is not thriving, then its transformative qi is diminished, and wood overpowers it, thus the transformative qi cannot exercise its command, while the governance of life notably manifests. Wood generates fire, hence the growth of qi is orderly. When the transformative qi does not command, rain becomes overdue.)[123p]
The earth's energy is insufficient, thus it self-regulates. The dominance of wood and water causes both wind and cold to arise. The vital energy is pronounced and well-organized, allowing plants to flourish beautifully. When transformative energy is lacking, even when they grow, they may be unproductive and withered. Divergence represents the energy of wood. Tranquility is the function of earth. Conditions like sores and abscesses arise in opposition to the flesh, leading to swelling and inflammation. Humidity and stagnation indicate water's influence over earth-related illnesses. The related organ is the spleen; its fruit includes plums and chestnuts, its essence is moist, its grains include beans and sesame, its flavor is sour and sweet, its color is bluish-yellow, its livestock are cattle and dogs, its parasites are lice and fur, its sound is akin to the gong and the horn. Because earth's energy is insufficient, it also derives from the transformations of water and wood. Fluctuation and anger reflect the dominance of wood's energy. Retention and obstruction indicate damage to the spleen's energy. The lesser palace and lesser horn are both termed the six personal years. The palace represents the sound of earth, and when earth's energy is insufficient, it is called the lesser palace. Wood also plays a role, thus the lesser palace and lesser horn share a transformation.[124p]

The upper corner, being the same as the central corner, pertains to the years of Ji Si and Ji Hai. It lies above the Great Yin and the ruler of heaven, thus it is called the upper corner. The passage explains the influence of the summer season and the characteristics of fire energy. It describes how excessive fire leads to a vibrant growth of plants and how heat causes the inward transformation of yin energy. The outward manifestation of yang energy is evident through the bright warmth of summer, which is a time of flourishing and growth.

During this season, the vitality is strong, resulting in high and dynamic energy. The brightness of fire represents clarity in leadership. However, the intensity of heat can also lead to agitation and discomfort. The warmth and humidity contribute to a harmonious atmosphere, while excessive heat can lead to changes and transformations.

Various crops and animals thrive during this time, indicating a rich interplay of elements, including flavors and colors. This reflects the summer's essence and its connection to various meridians associated with the heart and other organs.

The heart is considered the organ of fire, and its health is crucial, correlating with the lungs, as both are connected in the creation of life according to various ancient texts. It is noted that if heart energy is strong, joy and laughter will follow. Conversely, summer's heat can lead to fevers and illnesses in the fall, suggesting that imbalances may manifest later.

Thus, the focus is on the balance of fire energy, its seasonal effects, and its implications for health.[132p]

Thus it is said: If one does not maintain virtue consistently, what is conquered will return; if governance adheres to principles regularly, what is conquered will integrate harmoniously. This is the essence of it.[137p]
The text summarizes the five elemental energies, stating that if one relies on strength without maintaining virtue, the energies one has overcome will return, which is referred to as "being insulted in retaliation," leading to a diminished sense of fear. However, if governance is peaceful and each adheres to their principles, the energies one has overcome will be assimilated. This assimilation is akin to the transformation in spring when the melodies of nature resonate, resulting in the clear and cool governance of autumn.

The Emperor asks: The heavens are insufficient in the northwest, where it is cold on the left and cool on the right; the earth is insufficient in the southeast, where it is hot on the right and warm on the left. What is the reason for this?

It is noted that as there are yin and yang in heaven, there are also yin and yang on the earth, thus discussing the five movements of heaven and the four directions of the earth. The left being cold and the right cool, as well as the right being hot and the left warm, stem from the hexagrams of the later heaven. The hexagrams of the later heaven are positioned with Li (fire) in the south and Kan (water) in the north, with Zhen (thunder) in the east and Dui (lake) in the west. Because of this arrangement of heaven and earth, the four directions emerge.

Qibo replies: The energies of yin and yang, and the principles of high and low, are merely distinctions of more and less.

The energies of yin and yang refer to the cold and hot energies present in the four directions. The shapes of high and low refer to the earth having elevations and depressions. The terms "more" and "less" refer to the four symbols, which differ according to the energies of the four directions.

The southeast is yang. Yang denotes that its essence descends below, thus it is hot on the right and warm on the left. The northwest is yin. Yin denotes that its essence is revered above, thus it is cold on the left and cool on the right. Consequently, the earth has elevations and depressions, while the energies exhibit warmth and coolness; the higher areas experience cold energies, while the lower areas experience hot energies.

The essence referred to is the refined water born from the unity of heaven.[138p]
The weather is influenced by changes, and the essence flows between heaven and earth. Therefore, the theory of the correspondence between yin and yang states that heaven has essence, and earth has form. Heaven represents yang while essence represents yin; the cycle of yin and yang revolves up and down. When essence descends below, yang energy rises above, thus it is hot on the right and warm on the left. When the yin essence is sustained above, yang energy is stored below, hence it is cold on the left and cool on the right. The northwest is high, and the southeast is low; therefore, the high places have cold energy, while the lower places have hot energy.

Thus, those exposed to cold and coolness suffer from swelling, while those in warmth and heat suffer from sores. When one drains excess, swelling subsides; when one sweats, sores heal. This reflects the common principles of the opening and closing of the pores, differing in their nature of abundance and scarcity.

This discussion concerns the rise and fall of essence and energy. In cold and cool environments, the yin energy ascends while yang energy is stored below, leading to much swelling, referred to as "disease due to internal cold." In contrast, when in warm and hot places, yin energy descends while yang energy ascends, resulting in many sores, known to be related to fire, such as painful and itchy sores. Therefore, when one drains, yin energy descends, and yang energy rises, thus resolving swelling. Sweating, being a yin fluid, causes yin fluid to rise and yang energy to descend, leading to the healing of sores. This interplay of essence and energy within the body, their rise and fall, opening and closing, is the natural principle.[139p]
In life, one exists amidst the interplay of the energies of heaven and earth, subject to the differences of cold and heat from the four corners. One should follow these energies and adjust accordingly, and naturally, severe ailments will not arise. The Emperor asked: How is it with longevity and short life? Qibo replied: Yin essence sustains a person's longevity, while Yang essence leads to a person's early death.

[Note: Where the Yin essence is preserved, the original energy is firmly stored, thus promoting longevity; where the Yang essence is dispelled, the original Yang is lost outwardly, resulting in many premature deaths. The terms Yin essence and Yang essence suggest that there is essence in the earth and essence in the heavens; in the earth, it is Yin, and in the heavens, it is Yang.]

The Emperor said: Good! What about diseases; how should they be treated? Qibo replied: The energy from the northwest is dispersive and cold; the energy from the southeast is gathering and warm. This is what is meant by treating the same disease in different ways.

[Note: The western and northern energy is cold, and when it is firmly established externally, heat builds up internally, hence it is appropriate to disperse the external cold and cool the internal heat. The southeastern energy is warm, and the Yang energy leaks outward, causing internal energy to be weak and cold; therefore, it is suitable to gather the original Yang and warm the cold within. Although the diseases are the same, the treatment methods differ.]

Hence it is said: For cold and cool energies, treat with cold and cool methods, using water to moisten. For warm and hot energies, treat with warm and hot methods, strengthening internal retention. One must align with the energy to achieve balance. The opposite is true for uninvited conditions.

[Note: The cold and cool energies of the northwest cause the Yang heat within a person to become obstructed, thus it should be treated with cold and cool interventions. The process of using water to moisten means to use hot liquid to soak, inducing sweat, opening pores to allow Yang energy to flow freely.][140p]
In the southeastern regions, the climate is warm and hot, which causes people's pores to open and the yang energy to disperse outward. Therefore, one should treat these conditions with warmth, strengthening the primordial yang to ensure it remains within. What is closed should be opened, and what is opened should be closed. The rising and expanding qi should be collected and stored; the qi that is stored should rise and disperse. It is essential to achieve harmony in qi to achieve balance. For people in the northwest suffering from cold pathogens but feeling warmth, they should also be treated with warmth; conversely, for those in the southeast suffering from heat pathogens but feeling cold, they should be treated with coolness. What is termed "false" is indeed the opposite.

The Emperor asked: Good! If the energy of a region gives rise to different life spans, what is the reason for this? Qi Bo replied: It is due to the principles of elevation and depression, caused by the topography. High places are governed by yin energy, while low and wet places are governed by yang energy. The strong yang is associated with pre-natal factors, while the strong yin is associated with post-natal factors. This is the consistent rule of geography and the way of transformation and generation.

This further discusses the qi of a specific region, recognizing the differences of yin and yang, cold and hot. In high and lofty mountainous areas, there tends to be more cold and yin; in low and damp areas, there tends to be more heat and yang. The strong yang corresponds to the seasonal qi that arrives at the first instance; the strong yin corresponds to the seasonal qi that arrives later. The coming and going of cold and heat all derive from the earth. This differentiation in geography regarding elevation, density, and the regularity of yin and yang entering and exiting is inherent. The way of transformation and generation refers to the qi of growth, transformation, storage, and collection.[141p]
When treated with Yang energy, it promotes growth; when treated with Yin energy, it promotes storage. The Emperor asked: Is there a difference between longevity and early death? Qi Bo replied: Those with abundant energy live long, while those with deficient energy do not. This is due to the differences in the Earth’s characteristics. The smaller ones have minor differences, while the larger ones have significant differences.

Thus, those who heal must understand the heavenly principles and geographical distinctions, the changes of Yin and Yang, the order of energy, as well as the longevity and early death of people and the cycles of life and transformation, in order to comprehend the physical and energetic conditions of individuals. The Emperor said: Excellent!

The heavenly principles refer to the transformative patterns of Heaven. Geographical distinctions refer to the four directions of the Earth. The changes of Yin and Yang concern the excesses and deficiencies of the five movements and six energies, and the balance and imbalance they create. The order of energy refers to the notion that excess indicates pre-Heaven qualities, while deficiency indicates post-Heaven qualities. Those with lower and weaker qualities are pre-Heaven, while those with high and robust qualities are post-Heaven. To understand people's longevity based on heavenly influences and the dynamics of energy, is to know their physical conditions.

As mentioned in the "Lingshu Classic": When form and energy are in harmony, there is longevity; when they are not, there is early death. When skin and flesh are connected, there is longevity; when they are not, there is early death. When blood and energy prevail in the channels over form, there is longevity; when they do not, there is early death. When the form is full and the skin is loose, there is longevity; when the form is full and the skin is tense, there is early death. When the energy prevails over the form in a balanced person, there is longevity; when the form and flesh weaken and energy prevails, there is death. When the form prevails over energy, it is perilous.[142p]
Integration of Ancient and Modern Texts: Complete Records of the Medical Section, Volume One Hundred Thirteen

On the Regulation of Qi

Huangdi's Suwen

Discussion on the Five Constants of Governance [Part Two]

The Emperor said: In years when there is no illness, why do the bodily energies not respond as they should? Qi Bo replied: It is governed by the celestial weather; there are sources of Qi. [Note: The following three sections discuss the five movements of heaven and the five directions of earth, as well as the six energies of the heavenly overseer governed by springs, which interrelate. Years without illness are not determined by the five movements of heaven and the five directions of earth. Bodily energies are those of the five organs, in accordance with the five movements and five elements. "Not responding and not being used" refers to not being utilized according to the five movements; this is due to the influence of the energies administered by the heavenly overseer, from which the bodily energies derive.]

The Emperor said: I wish to hear the conclusion! Qi Bo replied: In the lesser yang, the heavenly overseer, the fire energy descends, the lung energy ascends; the white represents the metal element which is utilized when weeds are afflicted. Fire appears scorched, metal is worn and drained; during the great heat period, there are coughs, sneezes, nasal congestion, oral ulcers, and swelling from cold and heat. [Note: According to the record of Jin Ping, its organ is the lung, its color is white, and it corresponds to metal, all of which reflect the use of the five movements and five elements. The ascent refers to the descent of the heavenly overseer's energy, fearing its overpowering nature and yielding to it. The energies of the five movements are rooted within and circulated externally; the energies administered by the heavenly overseer are positioned above and descend below. The lung energy ascends, the white corresponds to metal, both aligning with the energy of the heavenly overseer, while not being used by the five movements.][143p]
When metal is used in the upper regions, then the grass and trees will suffer in the lower regions. When metal transforms from fire, it undergoes change and depletion. Symptoms such as coughing, sneezing, nasal congestion are all indications of lung disease; oral ulcers, chills, fever, and swelling are signs of heat. This is the movement and energy of metal, which reacts with transformation from fire. This discussion of movement and energy is, above, aligned with the transformation of heaven and, with regard to the yearly cycles of heaven, there are only minor distinctions.

The wind moves across the ground, dust and sand are lifted and fly; this leads to symptoms like heart pain, stomach pain, and reversal of qi, causing obstruction. Its main cause is rapidity.

(Note: In the section where lesser yang governs heaven, the greater yin is at the spring; that is why the wind moves across the ground. When the wind prevails, movement occurs, hence dust and sand are lifted. The "Spiritual Pivot Sutra" states that the diseases stemming from the heart's pericardium which relate to the greater yin include heart pain, worry, and stomach discomfort, indicating that wood is overcoming upwards. The center is earth, when the middle of the stomach is obstructed, it causes upward rebounds. Wind energy is swift, thus its main focus is rapidity.)

When the greater yang governs heaven, the drying energy descends, while the liver energy ascends. The trees flourish and stand tall, then earth suffers; the storms approach, trees are cut down, grasses wither, causing side pain, red eyes, instability, trembling, and weakness in the muscles, making prolonged standing difficult.

(Note: Standing refers to the body of wood; it generally means that the essence of the five elements is on earth, while its function ascends towards heaven. When wood is transformed from heaven, earth suffers. The energy of metal descends, causing trees to be cut and grasses to wither. Symptoms like side pain, red eyes, trembling, and muscle atrophy all indicate diseases related to liver wood.)[144p]
When extreme heat arrives, the earth becomes hot, the yang energy surges, urine changes, chills and fevers resemble intermittent malaria, and if severe, there is heart pain. Fire acts upon the withered, flowing water does not freeze, and hibernating insects emerge.

Note: When the yang ming rules the heavens, then the shaoyin lord’s fire resides in the spring, thus when extreme heat comes, the earth becomes hot. With excessive yang heat, urine changes, and chills and fevers resemble intermittent malaria, hence it is said that summer injuries from heat will lead to autumn fevers. Heart pain arises from fire being rampant within. The term "withered" refers to the time when fire acts upon withered plants, hence flowing water does not freeze, and hibernating insects do not hide.

When the sun rules the heavens, cold energy descends, and heart energy rises, the fire begins to ignite. The metal suffers, and during the cold and clear time, if excessive, water freezes. The fire energy becomes high and bright, the heart is hot and restless, the throat feels dry and thirsty, sneezing produces joy or sadness, and there are frequent yawns, with the heat energy running rampant. Cold then returns, frost does not fall at the proper time, one becomes forgetful, and if severe, there is heart pain.

Note: Brightness refers to the function of fire. When cold energy descends and heart energy rises, fire naturally flares upwards, while water naturally sinks down, hence fire appears high and bright, while the water becomes cold and solid at the bottom. Water in the earth corresponds to cold in the heavens; the fire's energy runs rampant upwards, hence frost and cold are restored.[145p]
When the heart is heated and troubled, the throat feels dry and thirsty, as the fire rises above. The lungs are the cover of the heart. Sneezing and sadness indicate the heat of fire burning the metal. Fire is yang, and water is yin; when the balance is lacking, yang rises while yin descends. Those who forget easily are harmed by cold, leading to injuries to the spirit and energy.

Earth is nurturing, and water is abundant; when cold guests arrive, hidden yin transforms, and dampness alters matter. Drinking water causes fullness but not hunger, the skin and flesh are strained, and the meridians are obstructed, leading to swelling and sores on the back.

Note: When the sun governs the heavens, the yin moisture from the earth is found in springs, hence the earth is nurturing. Water being abundant means that it can be controlled by the earth. In the years of the Earth Dog, when the sun governs, the cold water brings its guest energy influencing the three vital energies, and the main energy associated with wet earth governs the four vital energies; thus it is said cold guests have arrived. The transformation of hidden yin refers to the time when summer transitions, with water and moisture combining but without the nurturing of fire and earth, leading to alterations due to dampness. Drinking water to the point of fullness and suffering from strained skin and flesh are both the result of water and dampness illness. The swelling on the back arises from sores appearing there. The classic text states that all swellings and boils arise from the transformation of cold energy. The sun's cold water governs while the meridians circulate along the back, causing swelling there.

When the jueyin influences the heavens, the wind energy descends, and the spleen energy rises, leading the earth to flourish and emerge yellow. Water then becomes hazardous; the earth undergoes change, the body feels heavy, the muscles weaken, appetite decreases, and the mouth feels strange. Winds traverse the vast void, clouds and objects sway, eyes shift, and ears ring.[146p]
Note: The record of the earth is related to the earth element itself; its organ is the spleen, and its color is yellow. The earth is also elevated as the body of the earth is rich and thick below. The appearance of yellow indicates that the earth draws nourishment from above, from heaven. When the earth is transformed by wood, it receives the overpowering influence, thus the earth undergoes changes, resulting in the heavy body and reduced spleen illnesses. The turning of the eyes and ringing in the ears is due to wind invading from above.

Fire unleashes its ferocity, and the earth experiences heat; the excessive heat causes fiery vapors to consume, the red earth generates below, hibernating insects are often seen, and flowing water does not freeze, indicating a rapid onset of phase.

Note: The wind and wood of the Jueyin control the heavens, while the Shaoyang fire exists in the springs; wood and fire mutually generate, hence fire unleashing its ferocity. The statement about the heat of the earth implies that the Taiyin damp earth is also hot and humid. The description of "red earth below" indicates that the leaves of the trees, though lush, also wither and fall. During the severe winter storage time, hibernating insects are not visible, and flowing water does not freeze; the nature of fire is rapid, and the Shaoyang governs the pivot, hence its quick onset.

The Shaoyin governs the heavens, with heat descending, lung energy circulating upward, the white aspect pertains to gold use; plants suffer ailments, coughs, and manifestations of cold and heat, sneezing, and nasal blockage; extreme heat flows throughout, leading to sores and burns, and gold melts with flowing stone.

Note: The ailments of plants arise from extreme heat flowing, which is worse than in spring and summer. The melting gold and flowing stone indicate excessive heat invading from autumn and winter.[147p]
The essence of heavenly influence is governed, though it presides over half a year prior, yet it also commands the entirety of the year. The essence of springs governs after half a year. Therefore, it is said that when the wind moves over the earth, it denotes heat emanating from the ground; as moist air transforms substances, all arise from the long summer.

The earth becomes dry; cold and sorrowful conditions emerge, causing lateral pain and heavy sighing. The process of gradual cooling occurs, causing changes in grass and trees.

[Note: When the lesser yin governs the heavens, the active yang metal becomes dry at the springs, hence the earth is dry, with cold and sorrowful conditions arising, a manifestation of clear and cool energy. Lateral pain causing heavy sighing reflects diseases of the liver and gallbladder. The process of gradual cooling results in changes in grass and trees.]

When the greater yin governs the heavens, moist air descends while the energy of the kidneys ascends, resulting in the emergence of dark waters, clouds, and rain. There is obstruction in the chest, impotence, great depletion of energy, leading to difficulty in rising or moving; at this time, there can be lower back pain, stiffness in movement, and counterflow.

[Note: Dark waters manifest from movement, leading to bodily changes. Clouds and rain result from the transformation of moist earth. Obstruction in the chest indicates upward water energy. Impotence arises from depletion in the kidneys. Yang energy is generated from the yin of the kidneys and moves to the surface; thus, with great depletion of kidney energy, yang energy fails to rise or function, leading to counterflow in the limbs. During the winter season, the kidneys govern energy, causing lower back pain, difficulty in movement due to energy rising and significant depletion below.][148p]
The earth conceals its yin, the great cold approaches, insects awake early from hibernation. There is pain beneath the heart, the ground cracks and the ice becomes hard, there is pain in the lower abdomen, and food is harmful at this time. When metal is involved, it ceases. Water increases its taste and becomes salty; when water flows, it diminishes.

(Note: The "heart below" refers to the imbalance between the water and fire energies, as they do not interact. The cracking ground and hard ice indicate the variability of cold water. Pain in the lower abdomen suggests issues with the kidneys. Food being harmful means that water dominates the earth. The kidneys are fundamental, while the lungs are secondary, both accumulating water. When metal is involved, water energy rises to the lungs and ceases activity there. The heart's energy connects to the tongue, and harmony within the heart allows for understanding the five flavors. When water increases its flavor and becomes salty, it is an indication that excess water is rising to affect the heart. This condition indicates excess water energy leads to disease; thus, with water flowing, the illness decreases.

The discussion above pertains to the energies of the five movements, influenced by the weather; the energies of the five organs and five elements respond to this and transform in accordance with nature.)

The emperor asked: "In years where there is fetal energy but no growth, what energies are responsible for this?" Qi Bo replied: "The six energies have five categories, with mutual overcoming and restraining at play. Similar energies increase, while different energies diminish. This is the way of heaven and earth, the constant pattern of life and transformation."[149p]
This text discusses the relationship between the Six Qi (energies) and the Five Movements (elements) in the context of birth and growth of various insects, emphasizing how these energies influence the vitality or decline of different species based on their compatibility.

Thus, the Taiyin governs the heavens: the hairy caterpillar grows, the feathered insect develops, but the armored insect does not mature.

When the Taiyin governs the heavens, the Shaoyang is at the spring, thus the hairy caterpillar remains still while the feathered insect develops. "Still" refers to the state of being tranquil, allowing for growth; the "armored insect does not mature" indicates that in the years Gui Si and Gui Hai, the victory of fire overpowers and hinders the development of metal insects.

In the spring, the hairy caterpillar grows, the naked insect diminishes, and the feathered insect does not develop.

Here, the Taiyin is in spring, allowing the hairy caterpillar to thrive. Wood overcomes earth, leading to the decline of the naked insect. The text notes that the earth's energy suppresses itself. The non-development of the feathered insect refers to the years Bing Yin and Bing Shen, which experience the overpowering of water, hence, fire insects do not develop.

The Shaoyin governs the heavens: the feathered insect remains still, the armored insect develops, and the hairy caterpillar does not mature.

When the Shaoyin governs the heavens, the Yangming appears at the spring, hence the feathered insect remains still while the armored insect develops. The non-maturing of the hairy caterpillar means that in the years Geng Zi and Geng Wu, the dominance of metal restricts the growth of wood insects.

In the spring, the feathered insect develops, while the armored insect diminishes and does not grow.[150p]
Notes: When the Lesser Yin is at the spring, it governs the breeding of winged insects. The earth's energy overcomes itself, thus it governs the depletion of armored insects. The Lesser Yin is at the spring, signifying the years governed by Yangming, such as in the years of Gui Mao and Gui You, where the fire's vigor prevails, leading to the depletion of armored insects and hence the statement about the depletion of armored insects not breeding. This implies that when depletion occurs, the defeated are weak, but if they do not breed, the overcoming is significant.

Text: When the Great Yin governs the heavens, the wingless insects remain still, the scaled insects breed, and the winged insects do not thrive.

Notes: When the Great Yin governs the heavens, then the Greater Yang is at the spring, thus it leads to the stillness of wingless insects and the breeding of scaled insects. In years such as Xin Chou and Xin Wei, where the power of water prevails, the fire-related insects do not thrive.

At the spring, wingless insects breed, and scaled insects do not thrive.[151p]
Note: The moon governs the growth of serpentine insects, while those that it can control should be dominated by scaly insects. In the years of Jiachen and Jiashen, when the earth's energy prevails, scaly insects will not thrive.

When the lesser yang governs the heavens, winged insects are quiet, hairy insects grow, and serpentine insects do not thrive. Note: When the lesser yang governs the heavens, the extreme yin is in the spring, hence the winged insects are quiet and the hairy insects grow. The failure of serpentine insects refers to the years of Renyin and Renshen, when the wood energy prevails, and therefore soil-type insects do not thrive.

In spring, winged insects grow, shelled insects diminish, and hairy insects do not thrive. Note: When the lesser yang is in spring, it therefore governs the growth of winged insects; controlling what it can dominate, it governs the diminishing of shelled insects. For the years of Yisi and Yihai, when the metal energy prevails, wood-type insects will not thrive.

When the greater yang governs the heavens, shelled insects are quiet, winged insects grow, and shelled insects do not thrive. Note: When the greater yang governs the heavens, the lesser yin is in spring, hence shelled insects are quiet, and winged insects grow. In the years of Guimao and Guiyou, when the fire energy prevails, metal-type insects do not thrive.

In spring, shelled insects grow, hairy insects diminish, and winged insects do not thrive. Note: When the greater yang is in spring, it therefore governs the growth of shelled insects; controlling what it can dominate, it governs the diminishing of hairy insects. In the years of Bingzi and Bingshen, when the water energy prevails, fire-type insects do not thrive.

When the greater yang governs the heavens, scaly insects are quiet, and serpentine insects grow.[152p]
【Note: When the Sun governs the heavens, the Moon dwells in the springs, hence it represents stillness of scaled insects and the nurturing of bare insects.】 In the springs, scaled insects diminish, and bare insects fail to grow.
【Note: When the solar cold water resides in the springs, and the lunar damp earth governs the heavens, the combination of water and moisture results in the earth being unable to contain the water. The diminishing of scaled insects means that the earth collapses and scales are visible on land. In the years of Ding Chou and Ding Wei, when wood dominion prevails, the insects of the earth types do not thrive.】 The influences that cannot be achieved by all vehicles are indeed considerable.[153p]
The essence of this summary discusses that the forces of luck which do not conform to the various schools are exceedingly dominant. Thus, the governing energy is subject to control, and the annual cycles give birth to phenomena.

The governing energy refers to the Five Movements being the masters of the Five Energies. The annual cycle, half of the year prior is led by atmospheric conditions; half of the year afterwards is governed by terrestrial conditions. The heavens regulate the six energies to establish the annual cycle, each energy has its generative qualities, and thus the Five Movements have their limits, leading to cases of infertility and incompletion.

The earth's energy controls what it can overcome, while the heavens regulate over itself. Heaven governs color, and earth governs form. Each of the five types of decline and growth corresponds with its appropriate energy. Therefore, there are cases of pregnancy without result, and treatments that are incomplete; this is the norm of energy.

As for the earth's energy controlling what it can overcome, this is exemplified by the Liver and its connection to certain worms; likewise, the Kidney corresponds with other insects. The control that the earth has over its form is why it is called earth governing form.

The theory states that when the atmosphere is insufficient, the earth's energy follows; when the earth's energy is insufficient, the atmosphere follows. The movement lies in between, and remains constant. Thus, the energy of the Five Movements transforms within the realms of heaven and earth, remaining constant and overpowering the energies that govern the heavens. It states that when the Lesser Yang governs the heavens, the fire energy descends, bringing forward the Metal energy. When the Yangming governs the heavens, the dry energy descends, introducing the White energy.[154p]
It is the qi of the heavens, which can also control and overcome one's own fortune, thereby allowing for the rise of Baiqi, Danqi, Cangqi, and Huangqi. Hence, it is said that heaven controls the colors. All of this pertains to the various victories and generation of the five movements and six qi, each with its own success and failure, and the five categories of flourishing and declining, which follow the appropriate qi. Therefore, there are issues with pregnancy and childbirth when treatment is incomplete; such is the nature of victory and control.

The so-called "root in the center" refers to the roots being five externally, thus distinguishing between the transformations of life. There are five qi, five flavors, five colors, five categories, and five appropriateness.

This indicates that the qi of the five movements is rooted in the center, while the transformations related to qi, flavor, color, and category are external. The qi of Cang, Jiao, Dan, Su, and Yuan corresponds to the divisions of the five directions and gives rise to the five elements, aligning with the growth, transformation, and storage of the five qi. Therefore, what is termed "root in the center" is akin to the root of a plant in relation to its branches and leaves: rooted in the center while sprouting outward.

The external roots refer to the qi of heaven and earth, yin and yang, which give rise to the growth of plants and insects, each possessing the qi, flavors, colors, and categories of the five. Thus it is said: the distinction of transformation involves five qi and five flavors. The five categories and five appropriateness refer to the various types of insects, each associated with the five elements and the qi that corresponds to it.[155p]
The Emperor said: What does this mean? Qi Bo replied: What is rooted within is called the divine mechanism; when the divine leaves, the mechanism ceases. What is rooted without is called the establishment of qi; when the qi stops, transformation is severed. Thus, each has its own restraint, each has its own triumph, each has its own generation, each has its own completion. Therefore, it is said that without understanding the addition of years and the similarities and differences of qi, one cannot adequately discuss creation and transformation. This is what it means.

[Note: This also clarifies the qi of the five movements, transforming within heaven and earth, with the celestial influencing the springs of qi, circulating beyond heaven and earth; each has its own restraint and triumph, mutually supporting one another. The divine refers to the unmeasurable aspects of yin and yang; the mechanism refers to the rotation of the five movements. The divine manifests in heaven as wind and in earth as wood; in heaven as heat and in earth as fire; in heaven as humidity and in earth as earth; in heaven as dryness and in earth as metal; in heaven as cold and in earth as water. It moves in and out between heaven and earth, causing the birth, growth, aging, and death of all living things. Thus, it is said what is rooted within is called the divine mechanism; when the divine departs, the mechanism ceases. The establishment of qi refers to the rise and fall of the yin and yang qi of heaven and earth, leading to the growth, transformation, and storage of all things. Therefore, it is said what is rooted without is called the establishment of qi; when the qi stops, transformation is severed.][156p]
In this world, the five elemental energies rise and fall, entering and exiting, moving continuously without rest. Each has its own mastery and generation, giving rise to all things, and human vitality follows suit. Thus, one cannot fully understand the influences of the five movements and six energies, nor the differences and similarities of excess and deficiency, which are insufficient to describe the processes of life and transformation.

The Emperor said: Energy begins and brings forth transformation; when energy disperses, forms arise; when energy spreads, nurturing occurs; and when energy concludes, forms change—its essence is the same. However, the experiences of the five tastes differ in abundance and maturity, leading to variations in their beginning and ending. What is the reason for this?

Qi Bo replied: It is governed by the energies of the earth; without the heavens, there would be no birth, and without the earth, there would be no growth.

[Note: This discussion revolves around the energies of the five movements, which primarily govern the transformation of all things, influenced by the energies of springs; it is not due to the absence of growth from heaven and earth. The term "energy" refers to the transformative energies of the five movements: energy begins and brings forth life, meaning it obtains vital energy; energy disperses and forms arise, meaning it obtains growth energy; energy spreads and nurtures, meaning it obtains transformative energy; and energy concludes and forms change, meaning it senses the energy of storage, where things reach their extreme and transform. These five energies predominantly govern growth, transformation, and storage. From beginning to end, their essence is unified. The transformation through the five tastes is facilitated by the tastes that arise from the transformations of the five movements, which in turn support the earth's energies.][157p]
The energy of the five phases governs transformation and growth, regulated by the energy of the earth, which is why transformation can be rich or thin, and ripening can vary in amount. The Emperor asked: “I wish to understand this principle!” Qibo replied: “The variations of cold, heat, dryness, and humidity lead to different forms of transformation. Therefore, in the case of Shaoyang, where the spring is cold, no toxic elements arise; its flavor is pungent, its remedy is bitter and sour, and its grains are of a blue hue. The cold and heat, dryness and humidity, are the six energies of heaven in springs, different from the transformations governed by the five phases. Thus, the growth and breeding governed by the five phases get regulated by the earth's energy, resulting in variations in richness and quantity. Toxicity refers to singularity, indicating that when extremes of cold or heat appear, they generate poisonous energies that are excessive. In the case of Shaoyang fire residing in spring, no cold toxicity arises, exemplifying the differing transformations of cold and heat. For instance, in the years of Xin Si and Xin Hai, when the cold water phase is in effect, and Shaoyang is in springtime, the energy of the earth governs, preventing cold toxicity from manifesting, thereby showing the superiority of earth energy over the transformation of phases. The five colors and five flavors are under the governance of the five phases. When Shaoyang governs heaven, the color white corresponds to metal; this color is regulated by heaven, known as 'heaven-regulated color.'”[158p]
In Lesser Yang at the spring, its flavor is pungent, which is a flavor derived from the earth, known as the form regulated by the earth. This is the color and flavor of transformation and movement, adhering to the superior regulation of the heavenly. Therefore, it is said that the five flavors are nourished, referring to the five flavors of transformation and movement, which in turn support the earth's qi. When Lesser Yang is at the spring, then the utmost Yin governs the heavens, thus it primarily oversees bitterness and acidity, with its grains characterized by "azure" and "cinnabar" being mature, drawing from the qi of heaven and earth, rather than from transformation and movement.

In following the guidelines of balance, its color is white, and its flavor is pungent. For example, when Lesser Yang governs the heavens, the white color reflects heavenly transformation. When Lesser Yang is at the spring, then the pungent flavor draws upon the earth's qi, a manifestation of the qi of heaven and earth, dominating its transformative energy. As for the utmost Yin overseeing the heavens, if the larvae do not complete, and if the utmost Yin is at the spring, then the feathered insects do not thrive. This is the qi of the five movements, dominating its regulation at the spring. Therefore, it is said that each has its regulation, each has its dominance, each has its birth, and each has its completion, referring to the five movements and six qi, each having its generation; if one encounters dominance, then there is no birth or completion.

When Greater Yang is at the spring, damp toxins do not arise; its flavor is sour, its qi is damp, its treatment is pungent, bitter, and sweet, and its grains are cinnabar and white.

(Note: Greater Yang, being associated with dry metal at the spring, is why damp and toxic substances do not arise. Sour is the flavor of wood.)[159p]
In the year of Fuhuo, its color is dark green, and its flavor is sour. When it aligns with the years of Renzi and Renwu, the Yangming is at the spring, and the earth's qi controls it, thus the flavor that comes from the wood's movement is transformed by the earth, leading to its sour taste. Yangming does not derive from the external signs but reflects the influences of the Taiyin's moist earth from within, hence its dominant quality is moist, with flavors that are spicy, bitter, and sweet, also deriving from earth's transformation. The grains that are red and white mature when the Heavenly Controller is at the spring, as mentioned in the lower section regarding annual grains.

When the Sun is at the spring, heat toxins do not arise; its flavor is bitter and its treatment is plain salty, with the grains being dark and hulled.

The Sun's cold water at the spring prevents the emergence of heat toxins, as cold and heat undergo different transformations. In the years of Guichou and Guwei, the fire governs the movements; fire fears being controlled by water, thus its flavor is bitter and plain, accompanied by sweetness, forming flavors that are plain salty, and its mature grains are predominantly yellow.

When the Jueyin is at the spring, clean toxins do not manifest, its flavor is sweet, its treatment is sour and bitter, with grains being dark red, its qi is focused, and its flavor is pure.

When the Jueyin is at the spring, clean toxins do not arise. The earth fears the control of wood, thus its flavor is sweet.[160p]
The flavors it governs are sour and bitter, and its grains that are primarily blue and red are ripe. The Jueyin does not follow the principles, but instead observes the transformation of Shaoyang's fire from within, and in the essence of springs, it sees the bitterness and heat it governs; thus, its energy is singular, and its flavor is precise.

In the Shaoyin there is a spring, and cold toxins do not arise; its flavor is pungent, and its treatment is of pungent, bitter, and sweet nature, while its grain is white millet.

(Note: The fire of Shaoyin is at the spring, hence cold toxins do not arise. Metal fears fire's restraint, thus its flavor is pungent. When Shaoyin is below, Yangming is above. Above Yangming, the drying energy treats it; within, it sees the transformation of Taiyin and Yangming, hence its governed flavors are pungent, bitter, sweet, and also show the flavor of earth. Its grain, mainly white millet, is ripe.)

In the Taiyin there is a spring, and dry toxins do not arise; its flavor is salty, its essence is hot, its treatment is sweet and salty, and its grain is barnyard millet.

(Note: The wet earth of Taiyin in the spring does not produce dry toxins. Water fears the restraint of earth, thus its flavor is salty. When Taiyin is below, the Sun is above, hence its essence is hot; it refers to the Sun following the principles, with flavors derived from earth and essence from heaven. The flavors it governs are sweet and salty, and its grains, primarily barnyard millet, are ripe.)

Through transformation, salt is preserved, energy is singular, thus pungency transforms and both treatments align.[161p]
The explanation here states that the five flavors are related to their respective transformative energies, adhering to the principles of dominance and control. The term "pure transformation" refers to the Yangming being transformed by the moist earth it encounters, where dryness and moisture combine, leading to harmony in transformation. Metal transforms from earth, hence its salty flavor, which should be preserved and not allowed to overflow due to the fear of the Taiyin's regulation. The concentrated energy of the Jueyin sees the governing energy of the Shaoyang, thus the spicy flavor appears alongside the flavors of sweetness, sourness, and bitterness. Spiciness is influenced by the control of fire, as transformation follows the regulation of fire. Cold, heat, dryness, and moisture are among the six energies found in springs. Sour, bitter, sweet, spicy, and salty are the five flavors related to the five movements. The combination of dryness and moisture's pure transformation preserves saltiness, while the concentrated energy of fire transforms spiciness, all governed by the energy of the earth, leading flavors to return to energy transformation.

Therefore, it is said: To supplement the upper and lower aspects, one follows, and to treat them, one goes against their nature, adjusting based on the variations of cold and heat. Thus, the upper and lower are treated accordingly, and the internal and external are addressed in search of imbalances. For those who can be poisoned, a strong remedy is applied, while for those who cannot withstand poison, a mild remedy is used. This is the meaning.[162p]
The text discusses the regulation of vitality (qi) in relation to seasonal changes and environmental influences. It explains that the celestial energy associated with water (represented as the spring energy) can be complemented by sour and bitter flavors to balance its upward and downward movements. It outlines how to address imbalances caused by external winds or internal heat, suggesting that when cold dominates internally, one should treat it with warmth, and when internal heat prevails, it should be countered with coldness.

The process of healing involves assessing the prevailing conditions—whether they are too cold or too hot—and adjusting treatment accordingly. If the energy is strong, it should be moderated; if it is weak, it should be supplemented. The five elemental energies (wuyun) must be harmonized according to their movements, ensuring that any excesses are appropriately managed.

The text also mentions how ailments can manifest based on the relationship between upper and lower energies, or external and internal forces. When illness arises from a discord between these energies, treatments should be tailored to address such oppositions.[163p]
Thus, when the upper side prevails and the lower side reacts, the patient should take from below; when the upper side is defeated and the lower side reacts, the patient should take from above; when the external side prevails and the internal side reacts, the patient should take from the outside. To treat heat with cold, one should use warmth in application. To treat cold with heat, one should apply coolness. To treat warmth with clarity, one should apply coldness. To treat clarity with warmth, one should apply heat. Therefore, one can either dispel or reduce, induce vomiting or purging, tonify or deplete, following the same method for a long time.

[Note: To treat heat with cold and apply warmth in treatment implies that cold nature is incompatible with heat; hence, warmth should be used. The methods of treating heat with cold and treating cold with heat start similarly but end differently. It can break down accumulations, dissolve hardness, harmonize qi, and resolve blockages, which is the method of opposition. To treat warmth with clarity and apply cold, and to treat clarity with warmth and apply heat—this is the proper method. One uses clarity and coolness to treat warmth and heat, and warmth and heat to treat clarity and coolness—this is what is termed the inverse approach, while the proper treatment is as stated.][164p]
Eliminate and reduce it; this refers to taking from both the inside and the outside. Spit it out and drain it; this indicates taking from above and below. Supplement and drain; supplement above and below, treating both the upper and lower parts. Chronic conditions refer to diseases of repressed Qi; new conditions arise suddenly from an infectious cause.

The Emperor asked: If the disease is internal but not solid or firm, and it gathers and disperses, what should be done? Qi Bo replied: Your question is thorough! For those without accumulation, seek the organ; if it is deficient, supplement it. Use medicine to dispel it, food to nourish it, perform water therapy to induce sweating, and harmonize the inside and outside, so that it can be resolved.

[Note: This discusses the Qi of the five movements as a disease and the methods of treating it. When the disease is internal, it is rooted within. If it is not solid or firm, and it both gathers and disperses, it is related to the movement of the mind between the internal and external. For example, during the transitional phase, the liver is the organ involved with symptoms of urgency and fullness; during another phase concerning transformation, the spleen is the organ related to the condition of no. The Qi of the five movements corresponds to the five organs; therefore, for those without accumulation, one should seek the relevant organ. When the organ's Qi is deficient, supplement it first with medicine to dispel the evils and follow with food to nourish the upright Qi, conduct water therapy to induce sweating, and harmonize the inside and outside to expel the evils, thus resolving the issue.][165p]
The Emperor said: Is there a distinction between poisonous and non-poisonous, and is there a measure for their consumption? Qibo replied: Illness can be old or new, and prescriptions can vary in strength. Whether poisonous or not, there should always be regulation. For severe poison treating illness, six out of ten symptoms are alleviated; for moderate poison, seven out of ten; for mild poison, eight out of ten; and for non-poisonous treatment, nine out of ten symptoms are alleviated. When consuming grains, meats, fruits, and vegetables, one should fully utilize them but avoid excess that harms the body’s balance. If not used entirely, one must proceed according to the proper method.

(Note: The distinction of old and new illness refers to the poison’s ability to harm, and whether it can be overcome. The mention of varying strengths indicates that some prescriptions may require heavier doses while others may only need lighter ones. Poison can be severe or mild, often manifesting as dampness or dryness, thus care is needed in treating illness; stopping treatment at the right moment is essential to avoid harming the body further. Hence, for severe poisons, treatment ceases when six symptoms are alleviated; for moderate poisons at seven; for mild poisons at eight; and even non-poisonous medicines should not be overused, as prolonged use can weaken the body’s energy, which is a natural principle.)[166p]
When the vital energy increases over a long period, it leads to premature death. The principles of internal energy state that poison attacks the evil, grains are for nourishment, fruits are for assistance, livestock are for benefit, and vegetables are for sustenance. When the flavors and essences are harmonized and consumed together, they help to replenish essence and enhance energy. Therefore, using medicine and stones to treat illness, while grains and meat provide nourishment, can ensure that diseases are completely eradicated without excess that harms the body's integrity. If the illness does not fully go away, continue to treat and nourish as before.

One must first understand the seasonal energy, without disrupting the harmony of the heavens. Avoid excesses and deficiencies that lead to misfortune for people; do not cause evil nor lose the proper balance, as this would shorten lifespans.

One must recognize the fluctuations of seasonal energy: when it is weak, one should nourish, and when it is strong, one should drain. Nourish by following the natural flow and drain against it, without disrupting the celestial harmony. Avoid excesses and deficiencies that lead to misfortune; repel evil and nurture the proper balance, ensuring no one loses a long life.

The Emperor asked about those who have long-standing illnesses. When their energy continuously declines, and disease remains while they grow weak, what should be done? Qi Bo replied: "Indeed, a profound question from a sage! Transformation cannot be replaced, and timing must not be violated."[167p]
The channels exist to facilitate flow, and the blood and energy follow suit. To restore what is lacking, one must align with the collective. Nurture and harmonize it; remain still and wait for the right moment. Carefully guard your energy, preventing it from shifting; only then will its form manifest, and vital energy will flourish, leading to the designation of a sage king. Therefore, the great principle states: do not forsake transformation, do not disregard the timing; you must nurture and harmonize, and await the returns; this is what is meant by it. The Emperor said: Good!

[Note: This discusses the human body, which is sustained by the movement of energy. When the spirit departs, mechanisms cease, when energy stops, transformation ends; thus, the spirit and energy must be nurtured. However, the spirit and energy are like the master, while the body is like a vessel. Only when the form and spirit exist together can one complete their natural lifespan, hence the body must be nurtured. The followers of energy refer to the spirit and energy being harmonized. "Unwell and emaciated" indicates that the body is unwell while the form appears thin. "Transformation" refers to the transformative energy of the five movements, while "timing" refers to the dominant seasons of the six qi.][168p]
In the spring season, it nourishes the tendons; in summer, it nourishes the blood; in late summer, it nourishes the muscles; in autumn, it nourishes the skin and hair; in winter, it nourishes the bone marrow. The flesh, tendons, and bones of the body are all sustained by the transformations and movements of these seasons, which cannot be replaced. Just as spring air nourishes the tendons, summer air nourishes the blood vessels, late summer air nourishes the muscles, autumn air nourishes the skin and hair, and winter air nourishes the bone marrow. The body’s flesh, tendons, and bones are all nourished by the seasonal airs, which should not be contradicted.

The meridians and vessels are what circulate qi and blood and nourish yin and yang. Blood is the essence of spirit; just as the meridians connect the flow of blood and qi to restore what is deficient in spirit, bringing it back in line with those who have no illness. However, if the spirit is restored but the body is still unwell and remains thin and emaciated, one should focus on nurturing the spirit, harmonizing the qi, and waiting patiently for the right time, carefully guarding the qi and preventing any disruption. When the body receives the seasonal nourishment, it will gradually thrive. This is the fundamental principle of qi and nourishment for the body.

The aspects of nurturing and harmonizing are language for governance, intended for people to align with the harmony of heaven and earth, following the appropriateness of the four seasons to nourish the spirit, qi, and body. This naturally leads to longevity, without an end in sight.[169p]
Heavenly Origins Discussion

The Yellow Emperor asked: The heavens have five elements governing five positions, which produce cold, heat, dryness, moisture, and wind.

[Note: The five elements of heaven refer to the five energies of red, black, blue, and white. The five positions are the five directions, corresponding to the five elements of the earth. Cold, heat, dryness, moisture, and wind are the six energies of heaven. This means that the five energies of heaven interact through the ten stems; the energies of the ten stems transform the five elements of the earth; and the five elements of the earth produce the six energies of heaven.]

Human beings have five organs that transform into five energies, which generate joy, anger, worry, thought, and fear.

[Note: The five organs arise from the five elements. The five energies are the energies of the five elements: wind, heat, dryness, moisture, and cold. Joy, anger, worry, thought, and fear are the spiritual states of the five organs. In the heavens, they are energies; on the earth, they take shape. Energies and forms interact, giving rise to all things.][170p]
Human beings originate from the five elements of the earth, taking on this form, with the five banners of physical manifestation, transforming the five energies, giving rise to the five aspirations, and reconnecting with the celestial phenomena.

Discussion states that the five movements follow one another and are all governed, with the conclusion of the cycle recurring endlessly, which I already understand. I wish to inquire how this relates to the cycles of the three yin and three yang.

[The commentary refers to the six seasonal organs as discussed in various texts. The five movements are as follows: the year of Jia and Ji is the earth movement; the year of Yi and Geng is the metal movement; the year of Bing and Xin is the water movement; the year of Ding and Ren is the wood movement; the year of Wu and Gui is the fire movement. The three yin and three yang are associated with the years: the zi and wu years are governed by Shaoyin; the chou and wei years are governed by Taiyin; the yin and shen years are governed by Shaoyang; the mao and you years are governed by Yangming; the chen and xu years are governed by Taiyang; the si and hai years are governed by Jueyin. The Emperor states that the energies of the five movements succeed one another and that each year is ruled by them.][171p]
On the 365th day of the final period, everything follows a cyclical pattern. How does it align with the masters of the three yin and three yang of the year? Ghostly spirits, bowing twice, replied: What a profound question! The five movements of yin and yang are the way of heaven and earth, the framework of all things, the parents of transformation, the origin of life and death, and the abode of the divine. Can one not understand this?

(Note: The ten heavenly stems transform the five earthly elements; the five earthly elements manifest the six qi of the three yin and three yang. Hence, the five movements of yin and yang are deemed the way of heaven and earth. Wang Bing explained: The Way refers to the method of transformation and generation. Framework refers to the principles of growth, transformation, and storage. Parents refer to the origin of the shapes of all things. Origin refers to the fact that life and death all arise from it.)[172p]
There are beings with physical forms that are not subjected to the influences of the five movements of yin and yang; such a state is unheard of. Why is it that creation does not reach its limit and becomes the origin of all things’ generation and transformation? It is because it is the abode of the divine. However, the gathering and dispersing are unpredictable, and the processes of generation and transformation are infinite; it is not that the divine is incapable of operating! Therefore, the emergence of things is called transformation, and the culmination of things is called change. The unpredictable nature of yin and yang is referred to as the divine, and the application of the divine without limitation is called sagehood.

The "Six Subtleties" states: the emergence of things arises from transformation, while the culmination of things stems from change. The interaction between change and consistency is what leads to success or failure. The "Great Treatise on the Five Constants" states: when qi begins, generation and transformation occur; when qi disperses, forms arise; when qi spreads, growth happens; when qi ends, forms transform. Yin and yang are the principles of heaven and earth. Within yin resides yang, and within yang resides yin; neither can be fully measured. Their influence operates through the four seasons, transforming all things, and cannot be subjected to quantification. Therefore, the function of transformation is:[173p]
The changes of yin and yang, which are unpredictable, generate all things between heaven and earth, having the greatest function. In heaven, it is the origin; the origin is distant and profound. The way of heaven is distant and profound, with endless transformations. In humans, it is the path; the path is akin to a road. In all daily dealings among things, there is none that does not follow the natural way of heaven and earth. On earth, it is transformation; transformation means life-giving. The nurturing of all things comes from the generation of the earth. Transformations give rise to the five flavors. The five flavors arise from the five elements. Everything with feelings and nature possesses the essence and flavors of the five elements. The way gives birth to wisdom.[174p]
The mind's clarity is called wisdom; when it can follow the natural principles of heaven, it can distinguish right from wrong naturally, and nothing is left unfulfilled.

The spirit, in its completeness, interacts with the original flow, transforming through encounters with things, and responds to all. In heaven, it manifests as wind; on earth, as wood. In heaven, it manifests as heat; on earth, as fire. In heaven, it manifests as moisture; on earth, as earth. In heaven, it manifests as dryness; on earth, as metal. In heaven, it manifests as cold; on earth, as water. Thus, in heaven, it is qi (vital energy); on earth, it takes shape. The interaction of form and qi brings forth all things.

Wind, cold, heat, dryness, and moisture are the yin and yang of heaven. Wood, fire, earth, metal, and water are the yin and yang of earth. Therefore, in heaven, it is qi; on earth, it takes shape, and through their interaction, all things manifest.

Heaven and earth are the upper and lower realms of all things.

Heaven supports and earth carries, allowing myriad creatures to arise in between.

The left and right are the pathways of yin and yang.

The qi of yin and yang rotates continuously; thus, the left and right refer to the interstitial qi.

Water and fire are the signs of yin and yang.

Heaven generates water, and earth generates fire. Fire is yang, and water is yin. Though yin and yang are not visible, water and fire serve as tangible symbols of their presence.

Metal and wood represent the beginning and end of generation.[175p]
The Wood element governs spring, bringing forth life and giving rise to all things. The Metal element governs autumn, drawing in and completing all things; thus, it represents the beginning and end of creation.

Qi varies in abundance, and forms experience growth and decline. The interplay between above and below creates a cycle of gain and loss. In Heaven, there is qi, which varies in quantity; on Earth, forms manifest which experience growth and decline. The interactions between above and below reveal the extremes and deficiencies of qi clearly.

The Emperor asked: "I wish to understand the timing governed by the five phases. How does it work?"

Gui Yu Qu replied: "The five qi operate with designated periods; they are not limited to just one time frame."

This means that the qi of the five phases each complete their cycle within three hundred sixty-five days. With each cycle ending and beginning anew, the governing of time is not solely theirs. The five phases govern seasons, reflecting the cold, heat, warmth, and coolness of the four seasons, while the governance of the years pertains to the excess or deficiency of the five elements.

The Emperor said: "Please explain this further!" Gui Yu Qu responded: "I have compiled from the 'Taishi Tianyuan Ce', which states: 'The great void is vast, establishing the foundation of transformation and origin.'

The 'Tianyuan Ce' is an ancient text that records the running of the primordialqi of heaven. The great void refers to the realm of formlessness, fully occupying the atmosphere, the palace of spirit and clarity. Vast and boundless describes the immeasurable expanse. Transformation's origin is the root of creation.

All things originate, and the five phases culminate in the heavens.[176p]
The Five Movements are Wood, Fire, Earth, Metal, and Water. The end of the heavens refers to the daily movement of one degree, where each of the Five Movements rules over a year, corresponding to one three hundred sixty-fifth and four-part degree of the entire heavenly cycle. All things begin to grow through the transformative origin, constantly tied to the movements of the heavens.

The true essence of Qi is the connection between humanity and all things, where the earth resides in the center of heaven, and heaven envelops the earth.

The Nine Stars shine brightly, and the Seven Luminaries revolve around them. The Nine Stars are Tienpeng, Tienrui, Tienchong, Tienfu, Tienqin, Tienxin, Tienren, Tienzhhu, and Tienying, positioned in the heavens and corresponding to the divisions of the nine provinces. The Seven Luminaries are the Sun, Moon, and the Five Planets. "Revolving" refers to the degrees of the heavenly dome, while "moving in a circle" means rotating to follow the heavenly path.

There are Yin and Yang, Softness and Rigidity.[177p]
The Book of Changes states: "Establishing the way of Heaven is called Yin and Yang. Establishing the way of Earth is called softness and hardness."

When the hidden and the manifest are positioned, cold and heat are relaxed and tightened.

The sun governs the day, while the moon governs the night. The positioning of the hidden and the manifest refers to the establishment of Yin and Yang. The relaxation and tightening of cold and heat signify the ebb and flow of the seasons.

Life nurtures and transforms, and all things are expressed harmoniously.

The Book of Changes says: "Heaven and Earth are intertwined, and all things are refined and pure; this is why life continues unceasingly, transformations are endless, and all things express themselves harmoniously."

I serve over ten generations, this is what it refers to.

"Ten generations" means from ancestral teachings to the present, it has been ten generations. This is what is meant by accumulating study of the records of the Great Initiation of the Celestial Origins.

The Emperor said: "Good! What do you mean by the amount of qi and the waxing and waning of forms?"

Gui Yu Qu replied: "The qi of Yin and Yang each has its own quantity, which is why we say there are three Yin and three Yang. The waxing and waning of forms refers to the governance of the five elements, each having its excesses and deficiencies."

This refers to Tai Yang, Shao Yang, and Shao Yin, which operate in alignment with the pre-heaven and govern abundance; while Yang Ming, Tai Yin, and Jue Yin operate in accordance with the post-heaven and govern deficiency. This is the quantity of the three Yin and three Yang. The term form refers to the tangible aspect of the five elements.[178p]
