The governance of the five forms has its excesses and deficiencies. It is said that each of the five movements governs specific years; for instance, in the years dominated by Ren, the wood movement is excessive, while in the years of Ding, the wood movement is deficient. Similarly, in the years of Wu, the fire movement is excessive, while in the years of Gui, the fire movement is deficient. In the years of Jia, the earth movement is excessive, while in the years of Ji, the earth movement is deficient. In the years of Geng, the metal movement is excessive, while in the years of Yi, the metal movement is deficient. In the years of Bing, the water movement is excessive, while in the years of Xin, the water movement is deficient. Therefore, at the beginning, when there is excess, it proceeds; when there is deficiency, it follows after. When there is deficiency, it proceeds, and the excess follows.

Understanding how to respond and follow, one can make predictions regarding qi. The term "beginning" refers to the initiation of the heavenly stems from Jia and the earthly branches from Zi. For example, when the earth movement is excessive in a Jia year, the metal movement in the following Yi year will be deficient; when the lesser Yin is excessive in the Zi year, the greater Yin will be deficient in the Chou year. This is what is meant by "excess leads forward, deficiency follows." Similarly, when the metal movement is deficient in the Yi year, the water movement in the following Bing year will be excessive; when the greater Yin is deficient in the Chou year, the lesser Yang will be excessive in the Yin year. This illustrates the principle of "deficiency leads forward, excess follows."

By comprehending the cycles of annual movements, one can establish timing regarding excesses and deficiencies in qi. Responding to Heaven is like the heavenly symbols, adhering to each year is akin to the yearly principles, and the three harmonies lead to governance.[179p]
This text discusses the concept of a "neutral year" where, within a cycle of sixty years, there are years harmonized by celestial symbols. The so-called "celestial symbols" refer to the energies associated with the five elements: in the year of Earth, the Moon is visible; in the year of Fire, both the lesser Yang and lesser Yin are seen; in the year of Metal, the Yangming appears; in the year of Wood, the Jueyin is present; and in the year of Water, the Taiyang is observed. These energies represent the combination of the five elements with the energies of celestial governance, known as heavenly symbols.

The Wood element corresponds to the Rabbit, Fire to the Horse, Earth to the four seasons, Metal to the West, and Water to the Rat. These correspondences align the earthly branches, governing years, and the energies of the five elements; hence, they are termed "combined years." The "three harmonies" refer to the synergies among the celestial energies, the energies of the five elements, and the governing year's energies, collectively known as the Grand Unity Celestial Symbol. These are all balanced years, without excess or deficiency.[180p]
The Emperor said: How do the upper and lower realms call upon each other? Gui You Qu replied: The cold, heat, dryness, humidity, wind, and fire are the yin and yang of heaven, which are upheld by the three yin and three yang. The wood, fire, earth, metal, and water are the yin and yang of the earth, which correspond to growth, transformation, and storage below.

[Note: The cold, heat, dryness, humidity, wind, and fire are the six energies of heaven. Above the sun, cold energy presides; above the lesser yin, hot energy presides; above the yang brightness, dry energy presides; above the greater yin, humid energy presides; above the lesser yang, wind energy presides; and above the lesser yin, fire energy presides. Thus, the three yin and three yang uphold the six energies of heaven. The wood, fire, earth, metal, and water are the five elements of the earth. In spring, wood governs growth; in summer, fire governs maturity; during the long summer, earth governs transformation; in autumn, metal governs harvest; and in winter, water governs storage. Therefore, growth, transformation, and storage respond below to these principles. The five energies of heaven operate on the five elements of the earth; the five elements of the earth present the six energies of heaven. Thus, the mutual calling between upper and lower realms is established, and the energies of the three yin and three yang belong to both heaven and earth. Therefore, it is said later: Heaven has yin and yang; the earth also has yin and yang.]

Heaven uses yang to engender, and yin to nourish; the earth uses yang to eliminate and yin to store.[181p]
The heavens possess yin and yang, and so does the earth. The five elements of wood, fire, earth, metal, and water represent the yin and yang of the earth. They give rise to life, promote growth, transform, and store; thus, within yang, there is yin, and within yin, there is yang. This reflects that the earth also has the three types of yin and three types of yang. Wind, cold, heat, moisture, dryness, and fire represent the three types of yin and yang from above, illustrating that the heavens embody yin and yang. The five elements of wood, fire, earth, metal, and water reflect the yin and yang of the earth, corresponding to growth, transformation, and storage. Heaven is yang, yet it contains the three types of yin and yang, meaning there is yin within yang; the earth is yin, yet it also possesses the three types of yin and yang, meaning there is yang within yin.[182p]
To understand the yin and yang of heaven and earth, one should recognize that the qi of heaven moves without ceasing, hence it shifts to the right every five years; the qi of earth remains still and maintains its position, therefore it circles back every six periods.

The qi of heaven refers to the essence of various colors and elements, which moves without end. The shift to the right every five years pertains to the transition from Jia to Yi, Yi to Bing, Bing to Ding, and Ding to Wu, marking the completion of the qi of the Five Movements, after which it restarts. The qi of earth refers to the essences of wood, fire, earth, metal, and water. Its stillness and preservation of position lead to the cyclical returns every six years, starting from the Rat to the Ox, then to the Tiger, completing six years, and at the year of the Horse, it begins anew with the lesser yin.

Movement and stillness summon each other, the upper and lower realms harmonize, and yin and yang intertwine, thus transformation arises from life.

The interaction of movement and stillness refers to the mutual influence of the qi of heaven and earth. The upper and lower realms align as the five qi of heaven control the five elements of earth; the wood, fire, earth, metal, and water of earth are regulated by the six qi of heaven.[183p]
Thus, heaven is marked by six and earth by five; heaven with six and earth with five, where yin and yang interweave, giving rise to the cycles of thirty years as one era and sixty years as one complete cycle. The Emperor asked: "Is there a numerical system for the upper and lower cycles?" Guiyu Qu replied: "Heaven is divided into six for its seasons, and earth into five for its forms. The cycle of the heavens consists of six periods as one complete set; the completion of the earthly cycle consists of five years as one rotation. The lord fire brings brightness, and the mutual fire takes its position."

(Note: The annotations explain that the upper and lower cycles refer to the heavenly stems and earthly branches, where five and six come together. Each thirty years constitutes an era, and each sixty years constitutes a cycle. Heaven is marked by six in accordance with the three yin and three yang seasons. Earth is marked by five according to the positions of the five elements. The heavenly cycle consists of the twelve zodiac signs, with each associated with yin or yang and ruling elements.)[184p]
The ultimate record of the earth is governed by the cycles of the Five Elements: Jia controls the earth's movement, Yi governs metal's movement, Bing oversees water's movement, Ding manages wood's movement, and Wu presides over fire's movement. The five years represent one cycle of the Five Elements. Thus, the ruler of fire shines brightly in the heavens, while the fire below holds its position. This indicates that the earth is shaped by one fire into the Five Elements, and the heavens are formed by two fires into the Six Energies.

When the Five and Six come together, the 720 energies form one cycle. In total, after thirty years, there are 1,440 energies, and after sixty years, one complete cycle is achieved. The phenomena of excess and deficiency can all be observed herein.

It is noted that each fifteenth day corresponds to one energy. The combination of the Five Elements and Six Energies governs the years. In one year, there are 24 energies, summing to 720 energies for one cycle. A cycle signifies a small reunion. Indeed, by combining five and six to form thirty, and six and five also equating to thirty, we define thirty years as one reunion. From Jia Zi to Gui Hai, the total of sixty years constitutes one complete cycle. The energies of excess and deficiency can also be observed here.

The Emperor said: The teachings of the master concerning the end of heavenly phenomena and the completion of earthly records can be said to be thorough indeed.[185p]
I wish to hear and preserve this. Above to govern the people, below to cultivate oneself, so that the citizens are enlightened, and there is harmony between those above and below, with virtue and grace flowing downwards, ensuring that descendants have no worries, and passing this on to future generations, unending. Can I hear this?

[Note: The following further clarifies the principles of the Five Movements and Six Qi, which have their governing years, cycling endlessly, ensuring that all under heaven for generations, both descendants and common folk, are as the numbers of heaven and earth's yin and yang, free from calamities. This reflects the sage's concern for the people, with virtue and grace flowing without end.]

Gui Yuqu said: The mechanism of the ultimate numbers is subtle and intricate. Its arrival can be seen, its departure can be traced. Those who respect it will prosper, those who disregard it will perish. To act unlawfully for personal gain will surely bring heavenly calamity. Diligently follow the way of heaven; I will speak the true essentials!

[Note: The ultimate numbers refer to the fixed numbers that neither exceed nor fall short. The mechanism denotes taking action ahead of time. The movements of qi are very subtle; if one can reflect on the past qi, then the incoming can be known.][186p]
If one shows reverence and fear, then calamities can be avoided; if one is careless and indifferent, one will surely suffer heavenly disasters. The term "unrighteous" refers to the failure to cultivate the way of life. "Acting privately" signifies indulging in desires. The "true intent" refers to the essential path of ultimate truth.

The Emperor said: Good. It is said that one who begins must understand the end, and one who speaks of the near must know the distant. Therefore, when the utmost principles are reached, the way remains clear and unconfused; this is what is meant by clarity. I hope the Master will elaborate on this, making it orderly, simple yet comprehensive, enduring yet unbroken, easy to apply yet hard to forget, forming a guiding principle. Regarding the essential principles, I wish to hear everything about them!

[Note: This refers to the way of yin and yang, from beginning to end, from near to far, simple and clear, easy yet difficult, orderly and reasoned, with structure and guidelines.]

Gui Yu Qu said: Your questioning is truly illuminating! The way is indeed clear! Just as the drum responds to the striking, so too does the echo respond to the sound.

[Note: This expresses the clarity of the yin and yang way, which can be understood like the resonance of a drum; there is no instance where they do not correspond.][187p]
I have heard: In the years of Ji and Geng, the influence of the scholar's fortune is dominant; in the years of Bing and Xin, the influence of metal is dominant; in the years of Ding and Ren, the influence of wood is dominant; in the years of Wu and Gui, the influence of fire is dominant. The "influence" refers to the five energies succeeding one another and all being governed. The Emperor asked: Regarding the three Yin and three Yang, how do they combine? Gui Yu Qu replied: In the years of Zi and Wu, the presence of Shao Yin is seen above; in the years of Chou and Wei, the presence of Tai Yin is seen above; in the years of Yin and Shen, the presence of Shao Yang is seen above; in the years of Mao and You, the presence of Yang Ming is seen above; in the years of Chen and Xu, the presence of Tai Yang is seen above; in the years of Si and Hai, the presence of Jue Yin is seen above. Shao Yin is referred to as the "mark"; Jue Yin is referred to as the "end." This combination involves the five influences merging with the six energies, as well as the heavenly stems merging with the earthly branches. Zi and Wu represent the lord of Shao Yin fire.[188p]
The ruler is supreme, therefore the Lesser Yin is regarded as the beginning and is marked above. The Jue Yin represents the limit of Yin, which is why it is seen as the end; when Yin is at its peak, the offspring of one Yang re-emerges. Above Jue Yin, the Qi of wind presides; above Lesser Yin, the Qi of heat presides; above Greater Yin, the Qi of dampness presides; above Lesser Yang, the Qi of mutual fire presides; above Yang Ming, the Qi of dryness presides; above Tai Yang, the Qi of cold presides. This is called the foundation and is referred to as the Six Origins.

In explanation, the Six Origins refer to the six Qi of three Yin and three Yang in heaven, and likewise in the earth. Heaven and earth are in a harmonious state, mutually responding to each other, which is why the six Qi govern heaven, and the six Qi are present in springs.

The Emperor said: "The Dao is so illuminating! The discussion is so clear! Please inscribe this on a jade tablet, store it in a golden chest, and title it 'Chronicles of the Heavenly Origins'."

In explanation, inscribing on a jade tablet and storing it in a golden chest serves as a sign of permanence and value.[189p]
The Gate of Luck

Yellow Emperor’s Questions

Great Discussion on the Six Origins and Their Principles [Part One]

The Yellow Emperor asked: "The six transformations and the six changes, how do they relate to the predominance and subjugation of excess and order? I understand the sequences of sweet, bitter, pungent, salty, sour, and bland. What else should I know?"

[Note: The six transformations refer to the six climatic influences presided over by the heavens. The six changes refer to the changes brought about by the predominance and subjugation of the five energies of the seasons, which do not fully govern each year. The sweet, bitter, pungent, salty, sour, and bland refer to the five flavors that aid in the prevailing generation and subjugation.]

The five energies can either follow the influences of the heavens or resist them, arise from the heavens and counter the energies of the earth, or arise from the energies of the earth and counter the influences of the heavens. Sometimes they harmonize, and sometimes they do not. I have yet to understand this matter fully. I wish to comprehend the principles from the heavens and the regulations of the earth, harmonize their influences, and adjust their transformations so that the upper and lower realms align in virtue, with no rivalry in order. The rise and fall of the heavens and the earth must not deviate from appropriateness. When the five energies circulate, their governance must not be disrupted. How do we adjust their true flavors when faced with opposition?

[Note: The five energies refer to the transformative influences of the five elements.][190p]
There are situations influenced by the five qi, which involve harmony, clarity, and the preparation for transformation, as discussed in the "Suwen" under the theory of qi exchanges and changes. It is important to consider the balance and tranquility of the seasons, where the five movements are harmonious, and there is no conflict with the six qi. In certain years, such as the Year of Bingzi and the Year of Bingwu, the fire movement governs the heavens while the water movement prevails; in the Years of Jiachen and Jiaxu, the water movement governs the heavens while the earth movement prevails.

Qi can either be influenced by the heavens or by the earth, with three cases where it is excessive and matches heavenly transformations, and three cases where it is insufficient yet matches. Similarly, there are three cases where it is excessive and matches earthly transformations, and three cases where it is insufficient and matches. All of these twenty-four years align with the heavenly influences and correspond with the earthly qi. If there is a reversal of the earthly qi or the heavenly qi, excluding the years designated by the heavenly symbols, it does not align with the qi that governs in the springs.

Whether qi is harmonious or not corresponds with the seasonal influences, such as the warming winds of spring, the heat of summer, the clear dew of autumn, the rainy periods of late summer, and the ice and snow of winter—these represent the guest qi matching the seasonal qi. If the governing qi is deficient and the guest qi prevails, this indicates a mismatch between the guest qi and seasonal qi.

The heavenly cycles conform to the earthly principles, facilitating harmony between upper and lower realms, without disruption of order, ensuring that the qi governing the heavens is consistently aligned. The rise and fall of heaven and earth maintain their appropriateness, with a rise followed by a fall and a fall followed by a rise; thus, the changes in heaven and earth proceed without losing their suitability.[191p]
Harmonizing its movement, adjusting its transformations, ensuring that the five movements operate smoothly, and not deviating from their governance: harmonize the energies of the five movements, manifest moral cultivation, and do not stray from orders of governance. The five movements and six energies, when harmonized with moral orders and authoritative regulations, must inevitably undergo transformations of excess and resurgence. Now, if one wishes for the energies to be peaceful, one must support and restrain them by means of the five flavors, hence it is said to adjust with the proper flavors. In heaven, it is called energy; on earth, it is called flavor; flavors are used to adjust energies. Those who go along with what is beneficial should take the supportive path, while those who restrain should take the opposite path.

Qi Bo bowed deeply and replied: What a profound question! This is the fundamental principle of heaven and earth, the source of transformations. Who among the sages can exhaust its ultimate principles? Although I am dull, I respectfully present my understanding, so that it may endure and remain unchanged over time.

The five movements and yin-yang represent the way of heaven and earth, the framework of all things, the parents of transformations, the origin of life and death, and the abode of the divine. If a person can adjust their energies and movements, they will secure everlasting fulfillment without the fear of extinction, allowing for permanence without the disaster of change.

The Emperor said: I wish for you to expound further, to categorize and order them, to divide their main elements, to distinguish their essential authorities, to reveal their energetic patterns, and to clarify their governance and transformation.[192p]
Can it be heard? Qibo said: First establish the year to clarify its nature. Metal, wood, water, fire, and earth, the numbers of their movements; cold, heat, dryness, humidity, wind, and fire, the transformations they govern. Then the way of heaven can be seen, and the spirit of the people can be adjusted. The fluctuations of yin and yang are clear, and there is no confusion nearby. What can be counted, please allow me to continue speaking about it.

[Note: "Classes" refers to the Heavenly Stems and Earthly Branches. The Heavenly Stems begin with Jia, and the Earthly Branches begin with Zi, each having its own order; establishing the year first is what this refers to. The "Chiefs" of the divisions refer to the influence of the wind on the upper Yin, and the heat on the upper Lesser Yin. The six atmospheric influences correspond to the six divisions, each governing the year and the seasons. The "lineage" refers to the five movements and five phases as the rulers of the vital energies. The "proper transformations" refer to transformations of heat, cold, rain, and wind, which illustrate the nature being clarified. The "numbers of movements" indicate how the five movements succeed each other, all of which are managed, returning to their cycle in the end. The "transformation they govern" means that the six energies oversee those above, govern those below the spring, take charge of the seasonal energies, and additionally oversee guest energies. By clarifying the numbers of their nature, the way of heaven can be seen, the spirit of the people can be adjusted, the fluctuations of yin and yang can be clarified, and confusion dissipated.]

The Emperor said: What about the governance of the sun? Qibo replied: It pertains to the record of Chen and Xu.

[Note: The years of Chen and Xu are governed by the sun, overseeing the heavens.][193p]
Sun [Director of Heaven], Great Horn [Transformation and Movement], Great Yin [At the Spring]. Ren-Chen and Ren-Xu: Its movement is wind; its transformation is to vibrate, disperse, and split; its change is to shake, pull, and lift; its affliction is dizziness, loss of sight, and fainting. [Note: This section discusses the transformation and movement of Great Horn. The next section begins to discuss the Director of Heaven at the Spring and the six Qi during the intervening atmosphere. Ren signifies the yang year; the year of excessive wood thus points to Great Horn. The sounds and vibrations, as well as the proliferation, are signs of flourishing. Splitting occurs when wood sprouts and opens. The excessive wind wood thus causes shaking, pulling, and lifting. Dizziness and loss of sight are all illnesses caused by wind wood. Ni Zhongxuan states: The five movements correspond internally to the five organs, and the illness is in the liver, which is why symptoms appear in the eyes. The following five movements follow this pattern.]

Great Horn [Initial Correctness], Minor Adjustments, Great Palace, Minor Commerce, Great Feather [Ultimate]. [Note: The "Lingshu" says: Between heaven and earth, within the six harmonies, one does not depart from the five. It also states: The five represent sound. Sound indicates the differentiation between winter and summer, divided by the zi and wu. Yin and yang are distinguished, while cold and heat contest. Thus, the five sounds govern the two solstices related to zi and wu, and the two divisions related to mao and you, with the central position being the soil, ruling over the four seasons. Therefore, the five sounds align with the transformations and movements of the five elements.]

Sun, Great Adjustments, Great Yin: Wu-Chen, Wu-Xu, both are in Correctness and Adjustments. Its movement is heat; its transformation is warm, sultry, and humid; its change is intense, fiery, and boiling; its affliction is heat and stagnation.[194p]
Notes: The excessive manifestation of the fire element (戊癸化火) indicates an overly powerful year of fire, hence the term "Tai Zheng" (太征). When the fire element is too strong, and cold water rises above it, fire is able to maintain its control, thus its brilliance is balanced, avoiding the harmful effects of excessive heat. This aligns with the year of "Zheng Zheng" (正征), in which the fire element is present in the noon position, leading to a harmonious gathering of energies. The heat represents the fire element's nature, characterized by warmth and oppressive heat, reflecting its transformation. Due to the excessive fire energy, its changes become fierce and turbulent. An excess of heat further translates into the affliction of heat-related illnesses.

Tai Zheng: Wu (戊) - Young Palace, Ji (己) - Tai Shang, Geng (庚) - Young Feather, Xin (辛) - Lesser Horn, Ding (丁) - Initial Notes: Wu symbolizes the overpowering fire element, hence named Tai Zheng. As Tai Zheng is elevated, it signifies the honoring of the energy of the year.[195p]
The energies of the four seasons begin with the horn beam, hence from the minor corner of Ding arises the Wu fire. Fire gives rise to the Ji earth, earth gives rise to the Geng metal, and metal gives rise to the Xin water. This cycle moves from minor to major, and from major back to minor; it flows from above to below, and then rises again. I operate in a similar manner.

The sun corresponds with the Tai Palace, while the moon corresponds with the Tai Yin. In the year of Jia Chen, there is an assembly, and in the year of Jia Xu, there is also an assembly. Its operation is represented by dampness; its transformation is soft and moist, like heavy rain. Its change is sudden and tumultuous, while its affliction is heaviness from dampness.

(Note: Jia belongs to Yang Earth, thus it is associated with the Tai Palace. The operation of Earth corresponds to the four seasons, which are the years of Chen, Xu, Chou, and Wei. The mention of cloudy rain and dimness refers to the dampness of the earth, thus it operates with dampness. It later states that its operation is gentle and moist, representing the transformation of the earth. When earth energy is excessive, it leads to sudden changes and disturbances. The heaviness from dampness corresponds to spleen disorders.)[196p]

Its movement is cool, its transformation is mist and dew, its change embodies severity and death, its illness involves dryness and fullness of the chest.

[Note: Geng governs excessive metal movement, hence it is labeled as Great Business. Business governs the autumn metal, therefore the movement is cool. Its transformation is misty and dew, as the metal energy is too abundant, hence the change embodies severity and death. Dryness and fullness of the chest are ailments pertaining to the lungs.][197p]
The Lung Shu is located in the shoulder and back, essentially being the palace of the lungs. The passage on channels states: the lungs are associated with movement-related illnesses; in severe cases, one may feel dizzy and experience issues in both hands. This happens when the lungs are excessively active, leading to self-harm.

Tai Shang [Geng]

(Note: Ding follows the end of the previous section marked by Bing, and Xin starts the next section with Ren. The ten stems of the Five Movements are continuous and unbroken.)

Tai Yang, Tai Ming, Tai Yin, Bing Chen Tian Fu, Bing Xu Tian Fu.
Its movement is cold, its transformation is icy and harsh, its changes bring frost, snow, and hail, and its illness leaves profound cold in the valleys.
(Note: Chen and Xu, governed by the Tai Yang, represent the cold water in heaven; Bing pertains to the water movement, aligning with the heavenly energy, hence it is identified as a heavenly symbol. The cold movement signifies the energy of water.)[198p]
The atmosphere is chilling and severe, transforming due to water. When water overflows, it changes into ice, snow, frost, and hail, shifting from abundance to variability. The kidneys govern the bones, and the valleys are associated with the bones. The extreme cold that lingers in the valleys occurs when the qi of the environment combines with the qi of the organs, resulting in illness. 【Tai Yu】【Bing Zhong】 【Tai Jiao】【Ren Chu】 【Shao Zheng】【Gui】 【Tai Gong】【Jia】 【Shao Shang】【Yi】

【Note: The dominant seasonal qi, when excessive, begins with Ren for three years, following the sequence Ren, Gui, Jia, Yi, Bing; if insufficient, it begins with Ding for three years, following Ding, Wu, Ji, Geng, Xin. Observing them horizontally, the cycle recurs every six years. The seasonal qi for the time: in Yang years, it begins with Ren and finishes with Bing; in Yin years, it begins with Ding and finishes with Xin. Observing them vertically.】[199p]
One is great, and one is small, and they continuously succeed each other, thus governing the annual qi. This is expressed in the upper regions, hence stopping at the beginning of the horn and concluding at the end of the feather. It is understood that each year corresponds to the following: the horn wood governs spring, the fire governs summer, the metal governs autumn, and the water governs winter. If one establishes a separate diagram of the time, it is all based on the horn. Scholars comprehend this conceptually, and it is easily grasped, without the need for elaborate illustrations.

In all matters, the sun administers heaven's affairs and the transformation of qi operates according to the primal order. When the heavenly qi is solemn and the earthly qi is tranquil, cold arrives in the vast void. Yang qi does not compel; water and earth combine in virtue, responding to the stars of the zodiac and the fixed stars. Its grains are heavy and its governance is solemn, issuing orders gradually. The cold regime takes great action; the marsh lacks solar flame, thus fire waits for the right moment. In the lesser yang, when governance is in order, rain comes timely. Once the rain is extreme and disperses, it returns to the great yin. Clouds face the North Pole, moisture spreads, and the marsh nourishes all things. Cold settles above, and thunder moves below.[200p]
The cold and damp energy lingers in the atmosphere. When the people suffer from cold dampness, their muscles wither, their legs weaken and cannot retract, and they experience moist diarrhea and excessive bleeding.

(Note: This section discusses the overarching principles of the six energies related to seasonal and temporal changes. The yearly energy relates to the heavenly authority at the springs, while the seasonal energy pertains to the interplay of guest and host energies. Although the six energies each have their divisions, the heavenly energy is regarded as the main energy of the year; hence this is referred to as the administration of the sun in controlling heavenly matters and energies moving in accordance with nature. The years governed by the celestial branches of the rat, horse, tiger, and earth are associated with excessive energy, while those of the ox, goat, rabbit, rooster, snake, and pig are linked to insufficient energy. Energies that dominate in years characterized as excessive arrive earlier in the natural order, while those in insufficient years arrive later. Thus, it is said that "excessive movement" arrives early, while "insufficient movement" arrives late. The sun's cold water governs the heavens, thus the atmosphere is restrained; the moon's damp earth is at the springs, thus the land's energy is tranquil. Cold in the vast void prevents the yang energy from manifesting its governance; the combination of water and earth reflects the alignment with the stars of the hours and the stabilizing stars. The grains governed by the original mellow energy ripen, responding to the energy at the heavenly springs, which is referred to as the seasonal grains. Restraint is the governance of the heavens, while gradual emergence is the command of the earth. The marsh without the sun’s flame indicates the emergence of yang within the yin, subdued by cold water; these two energies signify the lesser yin and its ruling energy. Due to the strong governance of cold, it must wait for the appropriate time before emerging. The concept of "waiting for the times" indicates the arrival through the five energies, as the lesser yin's intermediate energy commands before it emerges. This describes the governing energies of the four seasons, which are ultimately superseded by those of the heavens.)[201p]
In the treatment of the Shao Yang, the Shao Yang's fire governs the energy of the three phases, while also being influenced by the cold water. Thus, timely rain becomes the edge. This refers to the governing energies of the four seasons, which are overcome by the guest energies that join them. Before the midpoint of the year, it is the celestial energies that govern; after the midpoint, it is the energies of the earth that govern. The three energies that join are dominated by cold water. The primary energy of the four seasons is associated with Tai Yin, which is why the energy of cold water ceases at the three energies, converging at the Tai Yin of the four energies. Where Tai Yin reaches, there are clouds and rain. The clouds that move towards the North Pole represent the energy of springs, transforming above. The moist earth that nourishes all things represents the energy in the lower regions. The cold settles above, belonging to the solar cold water. The thunder’s movement below represents the fire energy of Shao Yin on the right side of Tai Yin, beginning to manifest with the five energies. The energy of cold and moisture holds at the points where energies intersect, interacting up and down.[202p]
The ailments of the people, such as muscle atrophy and various types of diarrhea, are all caused by the onset of cold and dampness. This section discusses the overarching principles of the Taiyang governing the heavens and the Taiyin residing in the springs, along with the dominant and guest Qi of the four seasons. By applying the diagrams of the five constants to our reasoning, the sequence of the six Qis becomes clear.

In the initial Qi, the Earth's Qi shifts; the air becomes greatly warm, the grasses thrive early, and the people suffer. Warm illnesses arise, resulting in fever, headaches, vomiting, and skin sores and abscesses.

(Note: This part addresses the Qi of the period between the seasons. The transitional Qi is like a marker, while the initial Qi begins with the Shaoyang. The shift of the Earth’s Qi refers to the concluding Qi of the previous year residing in the springs, which intersects with the initial Qi of the current year governed by the heavens. The concluding Qi of last year is the fire of the Shaoyin, while the initial Qi of this year is the fire of the Shaoyang. The interaction of these two fires causes the air to be greatly warm. The thriving of the grasses signifies robust Qi.)[203p]
As spring begins and warmth increases, the people suffer from severe illnesses. Heat-related ailments emerge, causing fever, headaches, vomiting, and sores.

In the second phase, a great chill returns, leading to despair among the people. The grasses encounter cold, the fire element is consequently suppressed, and the people become afflicted by stagnant internal energy filled with heat. The cold now begins.

(Note: The "second phase" refers to when the yangming metal energy arrives, causing the return of great chill and transforming the excessive heat into coolness before mid-year; hence, it is termed a return. The despair of the people is due to the cold energy present during this transitional phase. Grasses suffering from cold indicate that the chill lies below. With cold prevailing below, the fire energy from above begins to be suppressed. It is said that the atmospheric energy from heaven all arises from below. The stagnation of internal energy implies that the yang energy is constrained within. The cold now beginning refers to the cold energy from heaven, which starts with the second phase. This heavenly energy is further overcome by the intervening energies.)

In the third phase, the heavenly order is established, allowing cold energy to circulate, bringing rain, which results in the people suffering from cold and retroverted heat internally. The presence of boils and abscesses occurs, leading to heart heat and confusion; those untreated may die.

(Note: The chilling water energy from heaven arrives during the third phase, hence the establishment of heavenly order while cold energy flows and rain falls. In summer, when heat should prevail, the arrival of cold energy leads to the people suffering from internal heat that is instead cold. The presence of boils and confusion is indicative of fire stagnation; if untreated, it may lead to self-destruction.)

In the fourth phase, wind and moisture clash, causing the wind to transform into rain, which nurtures growth and results in maturation. The people suffer from great heat and diminished vitality, experiencing muscle atrophy, leg weakness, and loss of bodily fluids, manifesting as red and white discharges.[204p]
The note describes the addition of the Qi of Wind and Wood from the Yin aspect, where the dominant Qi of the Earth is the Moist Earth of the Taiyin, leading to a struggle between Wind and Moisture. When Wind transforms into Rain, it is due to the added Qi that changes with the time. At the transition from summer to autumn, the Moist Earth is the dominant Qi, which fosters growth and transformation—summer promotes growth and autumn promotes completion, while the long summer facilitates transformation. The ailments arising from excessive heat and lack of Qi are attributed to Wind and Heat disorders. Conditions of flesh weakness and limb atrophy are due to the Qi of Moist Earth. Blood appearing below, whether red or white, signifies the interaction of Moisture and Heat.

As for the Fifth Qi, when the Yang recovers and transforms, grass grows, evolves, and flourishes, allowing the people to feel at ease.

Another note indicates that the lesser Yin, represented by the Lord Fire, is augmented by cold and coolness. When the Five Qis are treated, the Yang Qi recovers and transforms, thus the so-called "swamp without Yang flame," where Fire awaits its time to ignite, and Thunder activates below.[205p]
The fire energy transforms again, thus the grass grows. The moisture of the soil governs the seasons less than half a year, therefore it transforms. The primary energy of the five elements is linked to the dryness of metal, so it comes to fruition. The fire that is trapped releases it, enabling the people to relax.

The energy at the end is correct for the earth, and moisture allows for movement; the yin condenses in the vast emptiness, dust darkens the countryside, and the people are in sorrow and despair as the cold wind arrives. When the reversing force gives birth, it leads to death.

The energy of the spring, pertaining to the terminal energy, makes the earth's energy correct and moisture allows for action. The yin condensing in the vast emptiness refers to the movement of the great yin energy above. The dust darkening the countryside is the transformation of the moist soil spread below. The sorrowful condition of the people is due to the moisture and yin energy acting within them. The earth is responsible for nurturing earthworms, while humanity is linked to the abundance of these earthworms. Thus, when the cold wind arrives, it signifies that the earth has been overcome by the wind and wood, resulting in unsuccessful conception.

Therefore, the seasons should appropriately suffer, in order to dry and warm.[206p]
[Note: Bitter flavors are associated with fire, which can warm the cold, while bitterness can counteract dampness. In years when the sun governs the heavens, dampness prevails, hence it is appropriate to dry out to overcome dampness and warm up to conquer cold, achieving balance in flavors, so that harmony exists between above and below. The same principle applies to food consumption.]

It is essential to dispel stagnant energy and first support its source of transformation.
[Note: The source of transformation refers to the five movements that generate the six energies. To dispel stagnant energy means to alleviate the energies causing stagnation. For example, in the year governed by Tai Zheng, when the sun rules the heavens, the fire movement becomes stagnant; in the year of Tai Yu, when the yin is at its peak, the water movement becomes stagnant. Therefore, it is necessary to dry out to counteract the earth energy of Tai Yin and warm up to mitigate the cold evil of Tai Yang. The six energies are equivalent.]

Regulate the movements and energies, support those that cannot withstand, and prevent excesses that could lead to illness.
[Note: In years when the sun governs the heavens, if the movement and energy become excessively dominant, it is necessary to suppress the excessive energies and support the weaker ones. For instance, in the year of Tai Jiao, if the wind wood is overwhelmingly strong, the earth will be controlled by it. Thus, one should suppress the strength of wind wood and support the weakness of earth. Similarly, in the year of Tai Zheng, if the fire movement is too strong, the metal energy will be controlled. Therefore, one should moderate the excess of fire and support the weakness of metal. This is what is meant by harmonizing the movement, adjusting its transformation, and preventing excesses that could lead to illness among the people.][207p]
After the lesser yang and lesser yin years are the same. By consuming the year's grains to nurture their essence, and avoiding the false evils to stabilize their true nature.

(The note explains that the year's grains refer to the original grains cultivated in harmony with the heavenly energies, and consuming them allows one to absorb the essence of heaven and earth. False evils refer to the negative influences that overpower the vital energies in their midst. For instance, in the year governed by the sun, the initial energy is the lesser yang fire, but if cold overcomes it, that is the cold evil overpowering its initial energy; the second energy is the dry metal of yang brightness, but if heat overcomes it, that is the heat evil overpowering its second energy; the fourth energy is the wind wood of the exhaustive yin, but if dryness overcomes it, that is the drying evil overpowering its fourth energy; the fifth energy is the lesser yin fire lord, but if cold overcomes it, that is the heat evil overpowering its fifth energy. This is referred to as the four fears, which must be carefully observed. Thus, it is said to consume the grains in between to avoid false evils; when the evils are eliminated, the true nature will stabilize.)

In terms of atmosphere, similarities and differences govern it. When cold and damp are similar, they transform into dryness and heat; when they are different, they transform into dampness and dryness. Therefore, the similar are in abundance while the different are in scarcity.[208p]
This text discusses the theory of the five types of qi (vital energy) and their relation to the celestial phenomena and natural water sources, highlighting the similarities and differences in their qualities. The quantity and nature of qi must be adjusted according to these peculiarities.

When dealing with similar cold and damp conditions, represented by Taiyu and Taigong, which correspond with the cold dampness of the celestial phenomena, one should use more drying and warming flavors to counteract them. This is because dryness will control dampness, and heat will transform coldness.

In contrast, when addressing the conditions governed by Taizheng, Taijiao, and Taishang, which possess distinct properties from cold dampness, one should use fewer drying and damp contents for correction. This is due to the necessity of using dampness to nourish the drying and warming energies while using dryness to regulate the harmful aspects of wood and wind.

In instances of similarity, the energy is abundant, thus it is advisable to increase it; in cases of difference, the energy is isolated, thus it should be reduced.

One should use cold to counteract extreme cold, cool to ease excessive coolness, warm to mitigate extreme warmth, and hot to neutralize excessive heat. Dietary practices should align with these principles. If one deviates from these norms, it will lead to illness, which is referred to as "timely action."

Additionally, this text reiterates the considerations of the celestial phenomena concerning water sources and the influences of the six energies, each having their suitable states of cold, heat, warmth, and coolness, which should not be neglected.[209p]
Just as the sun governs the heavens, it is necessary to use heat to warm. When the spring energy is characterized by lesser yang fire, one should avoid this heat of lesser yang before applying warmth. When lesser yin is at the spring, cold should be used to cleanse it, while the seasonal energy reflects the cold water of the greater yang. In such cases, one must avoid this cold of greater yang before using cold. Warmth and coolness share the same meaning, and herbs and food follow the same method; this is what is meant by timing and the six positions. If there is something false, it contradicts the norm, which is to say that harmful energy overcomes, and it is not necessary to avoid cold while avoiding heat. When the greater yang cold water governs the heavens, and the spring energy reflects lesser yang fire, if the weather is cold, it is necessary to use heat, and there is no need to avoid heat. When lesser yin fire is at the spring, and the seasonal energy reflects the greater yang cold water, if the weather is warm, it is necessary to use cold, and there is no need to avoid cold. This is what is meant by the weather contradicting the season, and one can rely on the timing. Those who go against this cause ailments among the people, which is the so-called seasonal affliction. The Emperor said, "Good! What about the governance of the greater yang?" Qi Bo replied, "It corresponds to the cycle of the rabbit and rooster."

(Note: The cycle of the rabbit and rooster refers to the governing principles of the greater yang.)[210p]
Yangming, Lesser Horn, Lesser Yin, Cold Rain Overcomes Recovery Together, Same as Zheng Shang, Year of Gui Yin, Year of Gui You, Its Influence is Hot and Cold Rain

[Note: "Cold Rain Overcomes Recovery Together" means that cold refers to the energy of cold water, and rain refers to the energy of damp earth. The cold overcomes Lesser Horn, and the earth comes to recover from it.]

Yangming, Lesser Zheng, Lesser Yin, Cold Rain Overcomes Recovery Together, Same as Zheng Shang, Year of Gui Yin, Year of Gui You, Its Influence is Hot and Cold Rain

[Note: The year follows Wood as the chief element, hence it starts with the initial Zheng, beginning with Ding, which gives birth to Wu Fire, fire gives birth to Ji Earth, earth gives birth to Geng Metal, and metal gives birth to Xin Water, culminating in this way.][211p]
The Right Merchants are aligned with the records of Fuxi; the Upper Merchants and the Right Merchants are the same. The Gui (癸) controls the Lesser Zheng (少征) and the Yao (卯) and You (酉) control the Yangming, while the Shaoyin is found in the spring. The movements of heat, cold, and rain correspond to the qi of warmth, the qi of cold, and the qi of rain.

Lesser Zheng, Grand Palace, Lesser Merchants, Grand Feather—End. Grand Horn—Beginning.

Note: Starting from Ren (壬) to Grand Horn, it produces the Lesser Zheng's Gui fire; fire gives birth to Jia (甲) earth, earth gives birth to Yi (乙) metal, metal gives birth to Bing (丙) water, and concludes.

Yangming, Lesser Palace, Lesser Yin, cool wind, victory, and recovery coincide with Ji (己) in Yao and You. The movements are rain, wind, and coolness.

Note: The phrase "cool wind, victory, and recovery coinciding" indicates the earth's movements are inadequate. The wind's counteracting victory brings a pure and cool metal energy that recovers. Ji in Yao and You, and Ji and Jia transform earth; Jia indicates excessive movements of earth while Ji indicates insufficient movements. The movements of rain and cool wind refer to the Moon's arrival, resulting in clouds and rain. Rain is the qi of earth's movements, wind is victory's qi, and coolness is recovery's qi. Therefore, when the movements are inadequate, the victorious and recovering qi correspond to their transformation.

Lesser Palace, Grand Merchants, Lesser Feather—End. Lesser Horn—Beginning. Grand Zheng.

Note: From Ding (丁), Lesser Horn arises; Ding gives rise to Wu (戊) fire, fire generates Ji (己) earth, earth produces Geng (庚) metal, and metal leads to Xin (辛) water, concluding the cycle.[212p]
The text describes various concepts related to Chinese cosmology and astrology, detailing interactions between elements and energies. Here is the translation:

Yangming, Minor Metal, Minor Yin, Heat and Cold Victory Returning Together. Together, the Proper Metal. The Heavenly Symbol of Yi (Wood) in the Year of Yi (Metal) at the Time of Yiyou. The Great Heavenly Symbol is its movement of Cooling Heat and Cold.

(Note: "Heat and Cold Victory Returning Together" means that heat overcomes Minor Metal, and cold energy returns. "Together the Proper Metal" correlates with the times of change, where Upper Metal and Proper Metal are the same. Yi represents Metal movement, and the conjunction of the energies of Yin and You with Bright Yang creates the Heavenly Symbol. The presence of Metal in You constitutes the Year Meeting. The year featuring Bright Yang signifies the Heavenly Symbol. When the Year Meeting coincides with the Heavenly Symbol, it is called the Great Heavenly Symbol, also named the Triple Conjunction. The Triple Conjunction denotes the harmony of the Heaven, Energies, and Year. The movement of Cooling Heat and Cold indicates that the energy is cool, the victorious energy is hot, and the returning energy is cold.)

(Note: "Rain and Wind Victory Returning Together" indicates that rain is the victorious energy, and wind is the returning energy.)

In the year of Xinmao, the Palace corresponds to the element of water, which is insufficient, allowing the earth to take advantage of it. Therefore, the tone of the Palace resonates partially with its transformation. The energy of wood is also insufficient, represented by the Yinming years of Xinmao and Xinyou, the Taiyin years of Xinchou and Xinwei, and the Jueyin years of Xinsi and Xinhai. In the year governed by the Taiyin, the sun is in the spring, and water is enhanced and flourishing. In the year governed by Jueyin, the energy of wood rises, and earth is restrained by wood. The year of Xinyou is one where metal and water nourish each other; thus, it is primarily noted in the Xinmao year.

All five tones have their insufficiencies, yet only the Palace tone is mentioned because it is situated centrally among the elements and is influenced by the four seasons. Therefore, it is said that the energy of the five movements is rooted in the center and operates outward. Rooted in the center denotes the earth of the Central Palace, transforming and influencing in all directions. Cold represents energy in motion, rain signifies winning energy, and wind indicates recuperative energy; hence, the movement encompasses cold, rain, and wind.

Regarding the "Minor Feather" and "Minor Horn," they represent the energy of the year's ruling. The "Minor" during the year begins with the Horn and concludes with the Feather. The Horn represents the beginning, and the Feather denotes the end, concerning the energies of time. Minor and Major both commence with the Horn and finish with the Feather, with the latter four seasons conforming to this.

All of this represents the administration of the Yangming in the realm of heaven, with energy transformations occurring in the latter days. The year governed by Mao and You indicates that the annual energy is insufficient, as all celestial governance in spring references temporal energies that arrive later. The heavenly energy is urgent, and the earthly energy is clear.[214p]
The Yangming governs the heavens, thus the Shaoyin is at the springs. The metal command is above, hence the weather is vigorous; the ruling fire is below, hence the earth's energy is bright. When Yang exclusively exerts its command, the heat of summer prevails, and things become dry and firm.

With Yangming above and ruling fire below, Yang’s heat is intense, causing things to dry and harden. The pure wind then governs, and the dry winds circulate. This flow of energy is characterized by more Yang and less Yin. Clouds approach the rain office, and moisture spreads. When dryness is extreme, there are marshes.

At the beginning of the season, the energy is that of the Jueyin wind and wood. In years of excess, the guest energy is strong and often dominates; in years of deficiency, the guest energy is weak but still responds to the ruling energy. Therefore, the pure wind governs, reflecting the transformation of the initial energy of wind and wood. Yangming, representative of dry metal, governs the heavens, while Jueyin, associated with wind and wood, symbolizes the ruling energy. Hence, dry winds circulate and flow through the interchange of energies.

The interaction of ruling and guest energies refers to their intertwining dynamics. The intersection of energies occurs before the midpoint of the year, and their interaction is completed thereafter. The dual energies of ruling and guest are the two ruling fires, while the principal energies of the three are Yangming and Shaoyang, thus resulting in more Yang and less Yin. The clouds approaching the rain office signify the moisture of the earth, which, when vaporized, becomes clouds, and when the weather cools, it falls as rain. The energy of the four is under the influence of the Taiyin representing moist earth, while the Taiyang embodies cold water, leading to the phrase "clouds approach the rain office, and moisture spreads." The governing dry metal fulfills its role in the triple energies, interacting with the cold water and moist earth of the four energies, thereby leading to dryness becoming extreme and marshes forming.

Its grain is white and stony.[215p]
The notes indicate that the "yearly harvest" refers to the energy of the heavens felt in springs, which leads to maturity. The concept of "intermediary harvest" suggests that there is an interaction of energies between the left and right sides leading to maturation. The energy of the heavens resides in springs, interacting with the four energies from the left and right. When the Yangming is at the top, the left side is represented by Taiyang, and the right side by Shaoyang; Yangming oversees Shao while Taiyang and Shaoyang govern Tai, hence the term "intermediary harvest governs Tai." This refers to the energy above, while the energies below are less emphasized. The description suggests that the numbering begins from above and concludes below, thereby highlighting the energies above. Observing the cyclical nature of the five constant principles reveals the clear distinctions between the greater and lesser energies. The final phrase mentions the consumption of the white armor and feathered goods.[216p]
This text discusses five types of insects that are influenced by the celestial atmosphere and have limited reproduction. The terms "white," "armor," and "variety" refer to insects that respond to the celestial essence, which are merely decorative in nature and have little capacity for reproduction, unlike those that thrive during abundant times. In a year influenced by metal, all types of protective insects, described as the 360 kinds of protective insects, are born from the metal influence. However, only the white and armored ones reproduce under the celestial metal influence, while others do not.

When metal and fire combine harmoniously, it corresponds to the bright star and the wandering star. The governance is strict and the orders severe. Hibernating insects come to light and flowing water does not freeze. The people suffer from coughs, blockages in the throat, chills and fevers, shivering, and urinary retention.

The harmony of metal and fire above relates to the governance of brightness and clarity (represented by metal) and urgency and severity (represented by fire). When the force of fire is present in the spring, hibernating insects do not hide, and flowing water remains unfrozen. The ailments suffered by the people, such as throat blockages and shivering, arise from the influence of dry heat.

When clarity precedes vigor, woolly insects die. When heat follows and becomes severe, armored insects face disaster. This means that when the celestial energy is strong before the mid-year, it affects the outcome, while heat that intensifies later causes issues, with the insects succumbing to the dominance of the celestial influence in the spring and ultimately perishing.[217p]
Therefore, it is said: each has its strengths, each has its controls, each has its birth, each has its completion; this refers to the five movements and six qi, each having its generation and dominance. The victory of the five movements can restrain the six qi, and the victory of the six qi can also restrain the five movements. If restraining occurs, there will be no birth or nurturing, or there may be turmoil and death.

As for the disturbance of the excessive victory, it creates chaos and great disorder, clearing the heat qi held in the qi interchange.

(Note: The qi of Yangming and Shaoyin both governs disturbance; thus, its disturbance is like fire overcoming metal. Before the midway point of the year, water overcomes fire, while after the midway point, victory and recovery arise, leading to great disorder in the seasonal qi. The qi interchange refers to the heavenly qi merging with the earthly qi, affecting the interactions above and below.)

In the initial qi, the earthly qi migrates, the yin begins to condense, the qi begins to become solemn, water then freezes, and cold rain transforms.[218p]

The energy of the second phase brings forth yang, allowing the people to relax and the things to grow and flourish; however, when severe conditions arise, it can lead to sudden deaths among the populace.[219p]
The text discusses the interactions of various elements in relation to health and societal conditions. It explains that when the two flames representing the sovereign and minister harmonize, the yang energy can spread, resulting in the people thriving. Conversely, when the harsh conditions intensify, it can lead to violent deaths, indicating a disbalance between the roles of power.

In a scenario where the three energies represent the heavenly governance, coolness prevails, and there is a convergence of dryness and heat, resulting in illness among the populace characterized by cold and heat disturbances. This is attributed to the influence of metal energy from the heavens, which causes the governance to distribute while cooling occurs.

As conditions further transition into a fourth phase, cold rain falls, leading to ailments such as sudden collapse, shivering, hallucinations, shortness of breath, dry throats requiring thirst, heart pain, abscesses, ulcers, and feverish illnesses, along with issues like bone weakness and bloody stools.

The presence of the fourth phase relates to the interaction of cold water and the governing energy from the damp earth, which brings about cold rain. As the season progresses, lesser yin energy invokes further cold and dampness, exacerbating health issues. Symptoms manifest due to cold external conditions and internal heat stagnation. The text notes that various ailments such as cold-related shivering and heart pain arise when external cold interplays with internal fire, resulting in complications. It references traditional beliefs connecting these symptoms to underlying cold energy affecting health.[220p]
The energy of spring, when it returns, causes grass to flourish and the people's spirits to be harmonious.

(Note: The vigorous energy of the wood element influences the qi of spring, allowing grass to thrive, which leads to this flourishing. The subtle energy of the yin, aligned with the wood energy, allows for a harmonious spirit among the people.)

As the energy of the end of the season emerges, the yang energy spreads, allowing for a warm return; the hibernating insects reappear, and flowing water does not freeze. Thus, the people enjoy health and peace, while illnesses are mild.

(Note: The energy of the subtle yin fire influences the end of the season's energy, so the yang energy of springs results in warmth during winter. This warmth prevents hibernating insects from remaining dormant and keeps water flowing. The earth's energy is comfortable, resulting in the people's health and peace. If disasters arise, they are associated with mild illnesses, termed "winter warmth diseases.")[221p]
Thus, consuming the annual grain stabilizes one's qi, while consuming intermediate grains dispels its evils. The "annual grain" refers to the white dan grain, which absorbs the energies of heaven and earth. Qi refers to the original true qi. The "intermediate grain" absorbs intermediate energies. In the case of the initial energy, one should eat white glutinous rice; for the second energy, one should eat white dan; for the fourth energy, one should eat dan yuan; and for the fifth energy, one should eat dan cang grain. The "evil" refers to the adverse influence that counters the intermediate energy.

The seasonal requirements include salty, bitter, and pungent flavors, which help in sweating, cleansing, and dispersing. Salty flavors help to clear the heat of the ruling fire, pungent flavors moisten the dryness of yangming, and bitter flavors help to release inner congested fire. Sweating helps to resolve external cold, cleansing helps to eliminate internal evils, and dispersing helps to relieve the warming energy of winter.

When the sage encounters this period, they harmonize the cold and heat, preventing external and internal conflicts from arising. If external and internal forces clash, it leads to maladies of cold and heat, such as diarrhea, deafness, dizziness, and vomiting, where the energy of wind and heat prevails within. Swellings and color changes signify that cold and dampness dominate from without.

In the initial phase, the energy of the earth moves, the wind prevails and shakes, the cold departs, and the season turns warm. Vegetation flourishes early; the cold does not kill, and thus warmth-related illnesses arise. Symptoms of illness include upward blockage, blood overflowing leading to red eyes, coughing with reverse flow, headaches, blood loss, fullness in the sides, and skin sores.

In this initial period, the energy aligns with the Lesser Yin's fire, while the governing energy corresponds with the Severe Yin's wind and wood; hence the wind stirs and the temperature rises, allowing plants to absorb the life-giving energy early. The Lesser Yang governs the heavens, paired with the fire of the ruler, which means that despite the arrival of seasonal cold, it does not kill, due to the warmth of both fires. Symptoms like blood overflow, red eyes, coughing, and skin sores showcase the afflictions caused by wind and fire.

In the second phase, fire reacts with pent-up energy, white dust rises everywhere, clouds gather, and rain is anticipated. If the wind cannot overcome the moisture, the rain falls, and the people find relief.[229p]
The illness manifests as heat accumulating in the upper body, with symptoms of cough, nausea, and sores arising in the middle; there is discomfort in the chest and sides, headaches, fever, confusion, and pus-filled sores.

[Note: The guest qi of the second phase is the damp earth of the Taiyin, thus the fire energy in charge of heaven becomes repressed. When wind and fire energies are strong and harmonized by Yin dampness, the people are well. The essence of the Earth, when it is upright, reveals the transformation of Shaoyang from within. All things encounter the vital energy and begin to thrive; the Earth’s energy then rises up. During times of frost and mist, it acts and conceals, thus commanding the process of emergence. Therefore, those who suffer from blockages and heart pain have kidney energy ascending to the heart. The lungs govern Qi, while the kidneys are the source of vitality; thus, the kidneys are foundational, and the lungs are secondary. Yang energy, in winter, returns to the kidneys, but if it instead ascends to the lungs, it leads to cough.

In cases of excessive energy, one must suppress it. It is essential to break the stagnation and first address the source of transformation. Intense excess does not bring forth life, and harsh illnesses do not arise.

When the energy is too much, it must be suppressed. What cannot withstand it, like during the Ren year when the wood energy is excessive, leads to the Earth energy being overwhelmed; in the Wu year, when the fire energy is excessive, the metal energy becomes overwhelmed. Therefore, it is appropriate to suppress the overabundance and support what cannot be overwhelmed. Breaking the stagnant energy occurs, for example, in the Geng Yin and Geng Shen years, when Shaoyang governs the heavens, thus the commerce energy suffers stagnation; in the Jia Yin and Jia Shen years, where Jueyin resides in the spring, the palace energy suffers stagnation.[232p]
To address the excess of stagnant energy, one should first draw from the source of the Five Movements, moderating its extremes and supporting its insufficiency. Hence, excessive conditions do not arise, and harsh ailments do not emerge. The term "excessive" refers to the energy of the Tai Gong and Tai Shang, which governs excess and in turn experiences stagnation, resulting in its severity. Extreme excess is called "harsh".

Therefore, in a year, one should favor salty,辛, and sour elements to mitigate the detrimental effects of the environment.

Salty is appropriate to control the fire of the lesser yang, and辛 helps to overcome the evil of the wind and wood. The Jue Yin follows the transformation of the lesser yang fire, thus it drains the mother’s energy, making the use of sour necessary for replenishment. The term "soak" refers to the ancient practice of using liquids to extract sweat. "Seep" refers to draining in order to clear the internal heat; "soak" is for dispersing external wind evils.

Observe the cold and warm air to adjust the excess. Similar winds with heat tend to undergo more cold transformation, while dissimilar wind heats experience less cold transformation.

The cold and warm refer to the temperatures of the Five Movements. In years of Tai Jiao or Tai Zheng, when the atmospheric conditions resonate with the wind and heat at the springs, one often uses cooler elements for cleansing. In the years of Tai Gong, Tai Shang, and Tai Yu, when the energies differ from those at the springs, less cooling is needed.[233p]
Food and medicine follow the same principles. Use hot to counteract heat, use warm to counteract warmth, use cold to counteract cold, use cool to counteract cool. Food should adhere to the same principles. This is the way of it. Those who deviate from this are in a state of illness.

The movement of wind and clear heat signifies that wind is the moving energy, clear is the overcoming energy, and heat is the recovering energy; all three energies are in harmony in their movement.

It is noted that one speaks of illness in terms of excessive movement, but does not speak of illness regarding insufficient movement, for excessive movement is abrupt, while insufficient movement is gradual.[234p]

Tai Zheng, Shao Gong, Tai Shang
Overall, the Tai Yin governs the affairs of Heaven, and the transformation of qi operates in the later heaven. The Yin exclusively governs the affairs, the Yang qi retreats and hides, the great wind occasionally rises, the weather descends, the earth qi ascends, the fields are dim and hazy, the white dust rises everywhere, the clouds race toward the southern pole, cold rain arrives frequently, and things mature in varying summer conditions. The people suffer from cold and dampness, bloating, bodily irritations, swelling, stagnation, and cold-induced urgency.[236p]
Moist cold combines with virtue, yellow and black dust darkens, the circulating qi interacts, responding upwards to the Zheng and Chen stars. The governance is solemn, the decrees quiet, suitable for the valley grain.

(Note: The moon governs the heavens; cold water is at the spring, hence the yin predominates in governance. The yang retreats, and the soil's command does not reach, while the wind overcomes it. The cold and wet qi of heaven and earth interact, thus the fields are shrouded in mist; cold rains arrive frequently. This differs from summer; it is the time of late summer, the beginning of autumn. The people suffer from abdominal fullness and other symptoms, all caused by the cold and wet qi. The combination of cold and wet yields yellow and black dust in darkness, and the circulating qi interacts, responding upwards to the bright Zheng and Chen stars. "Solemn" pertains to the governance of the earth. "Quiet" refers to the decrees of water. The valley grain arises from the influence of the qi governed by the heavens in the spring.)

Thus, the yin condenses above, while cold accumulates below. When cold water overcomes fire, it becomes hail. If the sunlight does not regulate, the killing qi will manifest.

(Note: The moist qi of the moon condenses above, while the cold qi of the sun accumulates below; when cold water overcomes fire, it results in hail.)[237p]
The fire’s emergence is akin to the flourishing of vegetation; mountains and rivers covered in ice and snow represent this. When the yang energy is positioned above and is overcome by the yin, the chilling and killing energy arises. This illustrates the interplay of the upper and lower forces of yin and yang.

Thus, when there is an abundance, it is appropriate to rise; when there is deficiency, it is suitable to descend. The benefit of the earth lies in the transformation of its energy, which the populace adapts to, thereby influencing their fate.

This refers to the varying elevations and thickness of the soils in the five regions. Therefore, when seasonal energy is abundant, the soil should be high and thick; when the seasonal energy is lacking, the soil should be low and thin. An excess of energy should be moderated, while a deficiency should be prioritized. High and thick soil allows energy to be more gradual in emergence; lower soil permits easier ascension of energy. When energy is abundant, it should arrive more slowly; when deficient, it should arrive more quickly. This reflects the geographical advantages of high and low lands, the timing of energy arrivals, and the corresponding behavior of the populace, which is governed by this dynamic.[238p]
In the beginning of the season, the earth's qi shifts, the chill departs, the spring qi is established, the wind arrives, nurturing all things to thrive, and the people feel at ease. The interaction of wind and dampness leads to rain arriving later. The people suffer from symptoms of blood overflow, stiff muscles, tense tendons, obstructed joints, heaviness in the body, and muscle atrophy.

(Note: The initial influence of the qi for both rulers and subjects is controlled by wind qi; hence, the earth's qi shifts before the year starts, and the winter chill departs. When the spring qi is proper, the winds come, fostering the growth of all things, and the people's spirits are at ease. The interplay of the ruling and subject qi with the atmospheric qi delays the arrival of rain. The illnesses such as blood overflow and muscle atrophy are all due to the influence of wind and damp qi.)

In the second season, the great fire is proper, and things transform; thus, the people are harmonious. The illnesses arise from severe warmth and spread across the land. With dampness steaming and mingling, rain falls at the appropriate times.

(Note: The influences of the rulers and subjects here are represented by the two fires; hence, the great fire is strong. The combination of fire and earth brings forth transformation, leading to harmony among the people.)[239p]
The prevalence of damp heat leads to the harshness of warmth. The earth's energy is abundant in all directions, thus both near and far experience it uniformly. In the third atmospheric phase, heavenly governance distributes, dampness descends, earth's energy rises, and rain falls timely, followed by cold. When affected by cold dampness, the people suffer from heavy bodies, swelling, and fullness in the chest and abdomen.

Note: The air from the heavens influences the three energies; the cold dampness is active in the interplay of energies.

In the fourth phase, there is a fear of fire's arrival, steam transforms, the earth's energy rises, and the heavenly energy is separated. The cold wind morning and evening, steam and heat suppress one another; plants and trees are shrouded in mist, dampness condenses without flowing, resulting in white dew and signaling the arrival of autumn. People suffer from heat in the pores, overflowing blood, fevers, and fullness and heat in the heart and abdomen, leading to severe swelling.

Note: The guest energy of the fourth phase aligns with the lesser yang fire. Cold water in springs thus fears the encroachment of fire.[240p]
The energy of the fourth phase is governed by the Great Yin, which represents moist and loamy earth. When dampness and heat combine, it creates a steamy vapor that rises from the earth. The damp and cold energy does not integrate well with fire energy, causing a blockage in the weather's flow. As a result, dampness does not descend; instead, the white dew appears, signaling the arrival of autumn. The cold wind represents the frigid energy of the sun and water. The people suffer from fullness and other related ailments, which arise from the mingling of cold, damp, and heat energies, manifesting as illness.

The energy of the fifth phase is now surging. The cold dew has descended, and frost falls early. The vegetation turns yellow and withers, while the cold energy affects the body. A gentleman must be meticulous; the people suffer from skin conditions.

(Note: The energies of the fifth phase, whether master or servant, are all the clear and cooling energies of Yangming. Thus, the signs of cold and the command to store up energy arise early, prompting the gentleman to exercise caution. The Yangming energy governs the muscles, which explains the sickness affecting the skin.)

In the final phase, the cold becomes prominent, dampness intensifies, frost accumulates, and Yin becomes solidified. Water hardens into ice, and sunlight fails to correct this.[241p]
When affected by the cold, a person experiences joint stiffness and lumbar pain; the cold and dampness invade the interaction of the qi, leading to illness. The root cause is the coldness of the water, which is why the cold is severe. The interaction between the cold and damp qi, both above and below, causes great transformation of dampness. Frost accumulates and solidifies, transforming the dampness; ice grows rigid and suppresses the yang, enforcing the cold. The kidneys store during winter and govern the bones; hence, the joints become stiff and the movements of the bones are restricted. The lumbar region pertains to the kidneys. The cold and damp hold the qi in intersection, which refers to the balance of the qi between heaven and earth; people become ill within this interaction of qi.

One must break through the accumulated qi to find the source of transformation, enhancing the seasonal qi to prevent the evil from prevailing. The seasonal energies are insufficient, hence the need for enhancement. The evil qi refers to the qi that one cannot overcome.

Consume grains of the season to maintain one's essence, and eat intermediate grains to preserve one's vital energy. The essence refers to the true origin born from the Unity of Heaven, which encompasses both essence and qi.[242p]
Therefore, it is said that the true essence is refined. Thus, the seasons should be adjusted with bitter and dry warmth; in extreme cases, these should be released. If not released, dampness overflows, leading to flesh decay and skin splitting, causing the mingling of water and blood. One must support the yang fire to resist severe cold. From the harmonies of qi, distinctions in quantity are made. Those with similar cold are transformed by heat; those with similar dampness are transformed by dryness. The differing should be reduced, while the similar should be increased. Use coolness to counter coolness, cold to counter cold, warmth to counter warmth, and heat to counter heat. Eating should follow the same principles. Conversely, if one applies oppositely, that leads to sickness.
