If one does not induce nor attack yet violates both cold and heat, then the internal cold and heat can invade each other, worsening the condition. Thus, what is absent generates, what is present worsens. Therefore, if one does not induce heat, heat will arrive; if one does not induce cold, cold will arrive. When cold arrives, diseases such as hardness, abdominal pain, and diarrhea will emerge. When heat arrives, there will be symptoms like body heat, nausea, chaotic diarrhea, boils, ulcers, confusion, excessive lethargy, shivering, swelling, vomiting blood, nosebleeds, headaches, and pains in the joints, along with conditions of excess blood leaking, obstructed urination, and so forth. Wang also commented: If one has eaten and yet feels not hungry, vomits foul matter, this is also a symptom of cold illness. Sudden muteness and confusion, inability to recognize others, restlessness and mania, incoherent speech and curses, fright and convulsions, these are symptoms of heat illness. Therefore, as the classics say, there should be no loss of harmony with the heavens, no opposing qi, no reliance on victory, and no reinforcement of recovery; this is called the ultimate principle.[412p]
If one does not understand this, internal cold and heat can invade, losing the proper balance of qi, leading to ignorance of the four seasons and five elements. This results in mutual overcoming, dispelling evil and attacking the righteous, shortening human life. The art that does not align with the classics becomes a warning against rudimentary practitioners. Therefore, the six qi oversee the nine palaces, which in turn oversee the nine sources, and the nine appropriations below. The three numbers are clear, each discerning the main from the guest, managing excess, and conquering diseases. The thickness and thinness of seasonal qi and flavors, as the classics state, have both weight and lightness, activity and stillness, and the quantity of treatment and preservation varies in depth. Thus, when the lesser yang is at the spring point, cold toxins do not arise; when the greater yang is at spring, heat toxins do not arise. Hence, its qi is concentrated, and its flavor is correct. When the lesser yin is at spring, cold toxins do not arise; when the greater yin is at spring, dry toxins do not arise. This is called the transformation of heaven and earth, thus when the qi of heaven and earth converges, the six seasons subdivide and myriad things are transformed and born. The classics convey that one should carefully observe the appropriate qi to avoid missing the opportunity for treatment. The disease mechanisms are cold, heat, dryness, dampness, wind, and the five elements: metal, wood, water, fire, and earth; from this, all diseases arise. Therefore, by carefully examining the root of disease mechanisms, and understanding the essence of treatment, one can cure ailments. However, it is rare for one to clearly understand the appropriate conditions of the six qi and five elements, the thickness and thinness of flavors, and the use of these in relation to the body as the source of illness, while still achieving results.[413p]
The Confucian Duty to Parents (By Zhang Congzheng in the Yuan Dynasty)

The nine qi (vital energies) affect ailments and are treated accordingly.

Heaven uses qi to illuminate, and the earth uses qi to sustain. All things flourish between heaven and earth and are born through qi. When they are ill, they are all afflicted by qi. The qi of wind is gentle and opens the pores; the qi of heat is warm and promotes growth; the qi of fire is fiery and drives activities; the qi of moisture is heavy and burdensome; the qi of dryness is clear and harsh; the qi of cold is chilling and retreats to conceal. These six types of qi are the natural transformations of the seasons.

When they change, the wind qi can become furious and revert to cold; the heat qi can swell and revert to chill; the fire qi can whip through and revert to frost; the moisture qi can pour down like thunder and revert to fierce winds; the dry qi can scatter and revert to dampness; the cold qi can produce snow, frost, and hail, reverting to white dust. These are the variations of the six qi.

Thus, if it is cold for a long time, it should be treated with warmth; if it is cool for a long time, it should be treated with heat; if it is dim for a long time, it should be treated with brightness; if it is clear for a long time, it should be treated with rain. The qi of heaven and earth is stable when constant, and it becomes ill when it changes. Moreover, humans inherit the qi of heaven and earth; the five transformations invade from outside, while the seven emotions conflict within. This is why sages treasure qi as if it were a precious jewel, while the common people utilize it and harm the harmony of nature. Hence, Xuan and Qi discuss that all pains arise from qi, that all illnesses are born from qi, and so arises the concept of the nine different qi. Qi itself is one, yet it manifests as nine due to interactions. The so-called nine refers to anger, joy, sorrow, fear, cold, heat, shock, thought, and labor.[414p]
It is said: When angry, the qi reverses; when severe, it can lead to vomiting blood and diarrhea, hence the qi rises. The Grand Master Wang noted: Anger causes the yang qi to rise and the liver wood to overpower the spleen, which leads to vomiting blood and diarrhea when severe. When joyous, the qi is harmonious and the spirit is free, thus the qi becomes gentle. When sad, the heart is constricted, the lung's leaves are raised, and the upper burner becomes obstructed, causing the essence and defense to not disperse, leading to trapped warmth within, hence the qi dwindles. When frightened, the essence retreats, which leads to the closure of the upper burner; if closed, the qi reverses, and if it reverses, the lower burner becomes distended, thus the qi does not flow. It is also said: Fear harms the essence, causing it to rise and not descend, the yin qi of the lower burner also circulates and does not disperse, leading to accumulation and distension. Therefore, if the upper burner is constrained, and the qi of the lower burner reverses, the qi does not flow. The new revision states: "not flowing" should be read as "flowing downward"; cold causes the pores to close, and the qi descends, thus the qi is collected. Grand Master Wang further remarked: When the body is cool, the defense qi sinks, causing the skin's pores and places of excretion to close tightly, and the qi does not circulate, hence the defense qi contracts inward and does not disperse. When heated, the pores open, allowing the defense to flow, resulting in significant sweating, thus the qi is released. Additionally, it is said: When a person is in the yang state, they are relaxed; when in the yin state, they are despondent, hence when hot, the skin's pores open, allowing the defense to circulate significantly, leading to fluid drainage and considerable sweating. When startled, the heart has no foundation, the spirit has no resting place, and thoughts lack resolution, causing the qi to become chaotic. When exhausted, there is wheezing and sweating, and both inside and outside are overwhelmed, thus the qi is consumed. Moreover, excessive labor causes the qi to rush quickly, leading to wheezing. When the qi rushes quickly, the yang projects outward, resulting in sweating. Both internally and externally exceed the usual limits, hence the qi is depleted.[415p]
When one thinks, the mind has something to hold onto, and the spirit has a place to return; if the righteous energy remains but does not act, then the energy becomes stagnant. Furthermore, when the heart is tied and does not scatter, the energy also stays. This discussion of the nine energies in the "Su Wen" is quite detailed, and its principles are very clear. However, it briefly addresses the diseases caused by the nine energies, only discussing vomiting blood and diarrhea, while leaving the rest unmentioned. The "Ling Shu" on the other hand discusses the illnesses caused by thoughts and emotions such as sadness, joy, anger, fear, and worry. It states: Those who understand how to nurture life must align with the four seasons, adapt to cold and heat, harmonize joy and anger, and ensure a peaceful living situation. They should balance yin and yang, harmonize rigidity and flexibility; by doing so, evils will not approach, leading to long life and lasting vision. Therefore, excessive anxiety and worry harm the spirit; when the spirit is harmed, fear arises, leading to unending desires. Sadness drains one’s life force and results in loss; joy and happiness scatter the spirit, preventing it from being contained; worries cause energy to become blocked and stagnant; intense anger confuses the spirit and prevents healing; fear causes the spirit to become scattered and unsettled.[416p]
Fear and constant worry harm the spirit; if the spirit is harmed, it leads to fear and loss, causing decay in bodily flesh and hair, pallor, and death in winter. Spleen sorrow that remains unresolved harms the will; if the will is harmed, it causes disarray, leaving the limbs unable to move, leading to hair loss, pallor, and death in spring. Grief affecting the liver harms the soul; if the soul is harmed, it results in madness and forgetfulness, lacking precision and correctness, causing the body to shrink and the muscles to cramp, with hair loss, pallor, and death in autumn. Unrestrained joy of the lungs harms the ghost within; if the ghost is harmed, it leads to madness where one loses awareness of oneself, with the skin scorched, hair loss, pallor, and death in summer. Anger overwhelming the kidneys harms the will; if the will is harmed, joy is lost and past intentions are forgotten, leading to an inability to bend or stretch the back, hair loss, pallor, and death in late summer. Constant fear and not resolving it harms essence; if essence is harmed, it causes bone pain and weakness, leading to loss of vitality. Thus, the five organs are responsible for storing essence, and should not be harmed. If harmed, one loses balance, leading to a deficiency of yin; without sufficient yin, there can be no energy, and ultimately, death ensues.[417p]
The "Lingshu" discusses the diseases arising from emotions, spirit, soul, and essence, but if there are no cold, heat, shock, or labor as evidence, I therefore expand on it:

When anger prevails, it leads to vomiting blood, diarrhea, convulsions, fainting, yang collapse, chest fullness and side pain, belching with reversed qi that does not descend, shortness of breath and thirst, restlessness, consumption, accumulated phlegm, sudden blindness, sudden deafness, muscle spasms manifesting externally, and abscesses.

When joy prevails, it leads to uncontrollable laughter, burning hair, internal diseases, failure to contain yang energy, and in severe cases, mania.

When sorrow prevails, it results in yin contraction, muscle cramps, paralysis of the flesh, weak pulse, bloody urine in men, uterine bleeding in women, sour nasal discharge, blurred vision, insufficient breath for inhalation, and numbness in the arms when weeping.

When fear prevails, it can cause fractures, muscle atrophy, sudden greenish diarrhea, heated face with urgent skin, impotence, and collapsing from fright.

When shock prevails, it results in drooling, blurred vision, disordered speech, seizures, loss of consciousness, stiff paralysis, and prolonged pain and numbness.[418p]
When anger is directed inward, it can lead to various ailments: difficulty swallowing, shortness of breath, coughing up blood, back pain, weakness of the bones, lung noise, bone decay, impotence, coughing up blood, dim vision, ear blockage, low sperm production in men, irregular menstrual cycles in women. If it becomes severe, it may lead to a breakdown and uncontrollable flow.

When thoughts are distressed, it results in insomnia, excessive sleepiness, confusion, abdominal discomfort, blockage in the triple warmer, difficulty in swallowing, bitter vomiting, muscle weakness, excessive sexual desire, and a sense of debilitation that feels like exhaustion, leading to a lack of appetite.

When coldness affects the body, it can cause water discharge from the upper and lower parts, clear and cold liquid, diarrhea that is clear and white, foul vomiting, loss of appetite after eating, a hard sensation in the abdomen with urgent pain, lumps or hernias, difficulty in movement, and a firm retention of qi.[419p]
When the qi is obstructed, it leads to symptoms such as wheezing, vomiting of sour substances, sudden spasms, cloudy urination, abdominal distension that sounds like a drum when tapped, sores and ulcers, lumps and nodules, vomiting and diarrhea, cholera, mental confusion, swelling, nasal blockage, nosebleeds, excessive bleeding, urinary retention, fever, and aversion to cold. In severe cases, it can result in convulsions, blurred vision, tinnitus or deafness, agitation, madness, curses, and fright. One may feel as if possessed, with qi reversing and surging upwards, spitting out foul substances, inability to eat, abdominal swelling and pain, sudden hoarseness and collapse, and sudden illness leading to death. All these nine symptoms have treatment methods in the "Inner Canon", typically addressed through the principle of the Five Elements overcoming one another. For instance, anger harms the liver, which belongs to wood; when angry, qi becomes stuck in the liver, thereby allowing pathogens to affect the spleen. When wood is excessive, the liver itself also becomes ill.[420p]
Joy injures the heart; the heart belongs to fire. When joyful, the spirit unites with the heart, while the lungs, representing metal, are harmed. Excessive fire causes the heart to be ill as well. Grief injures the lungs; the lungs belong to metal. When grieving, the spirit unites with the lungs, while the liver, representing wood, is harmed. Excessive metal causes the lungs to be ill as well. Fear injures the kidneys; the kidneys belong to water. When fearful, the spirit unites with the kidneys, while the heart's fire is harmed. Excessive water causes the kidneys to be ill as well. Thoughtfulness injures the spleen; the spleen belongs to earth. When overly thoughtful, the spirit unites with the spleen, while the kidneys' water is harmed. Excessive earth causes the spleen to be ill as well. Cold injures the body; the body belongs to yin. When cold overcomes heat, the yang becomes ill. Excessive cold also harms yin. Heat injures the qi; qi belongs to yang. When heat overcomes cold, the yin becomes ill. Excessive heat also harms yang. All of these seven conditions influence each other. Thus, sorrow can remedy anger; one can touch others with words of compassion and suffering. Joy can also remedy sorrow.[421p]
To amuse others with playful and teasing words; fear can be managed with sudden and frightening words related to death; anger can be treated by touching thoughts with insults and deception; thought can be managed by addressing fears with considerations of others' intentions; these five methods must be deceitful and strange, without limits, in order to truly affect people’s ears and eyes, and easily manipulate their perceptions. If one lacks inner resources, they cannot employ these five methods. Heat can treat cold; external cold can be relieved with heated needles (that is, using fire) to warm and induce sweating; internal cold can be treated with warm food and balms to stabilize it. Cold can also remedy heat; external heat can be alleviated with cool environments, thin clothing, and cooling solutions to induce sweating; internal heat should be addressed with cold drinks and remedies for balance. Only rest can remedy labor; the scriptures state that labor requires warmth, meaning to conserve and nurture.

Today’s doctors regard warmth as a gentle remedy, but they have strayed from this principle for too long. Qi Bo stated that rest is essential; it also refers to relaxation. Only practice can remedy shock; the texts mention that shock must be calmed, referring to the ordinary. Shock occurs suddenly and unexpectedly; familiarity through repeated exposure helps one become desensitized to shock. These nine aspects are defined in the "Inner Canon" and are disregarded by mediocre practitioners. In our time, Liu Hejian addressed the five emotions, deriving insights beyond words, suggesting that these emotions originate from the heart. Thus, in observing signs of joy, anger, sadness, fear, and thought, they all fundamentally rely on a balanced heart's energy. As for labor, which results from movement and is categorized as yang, shock arises from the heart which corresponds to fire, and both are likewise dependent on the balanced heart.[422p]
The physicians of today do not understand this principle, which has led to slander about cold and heat, creating a ruckus among the people, and the scholars and officials are misled by it. When will public opinion settle? In the past, I treated a scholar who was overworked, with severe constipation, cough, and reverse qi, producing a hoarse sound in his throat, and spitting up fresh blood. I administered a bitter decoction to detoxify, adding Huanglian and Muscone, taken gradually. I also used a concoction of Muscone and Areca nut to alleviate his reverse qi, and within a little over a month, he recovered.

I have once treated a person plagued by deep sorrow using a mixture of methods, where I would accompany acupuncture with sounds from bamboo flutes and drums to address worries and heart pain. I have also knocked on doors and windows, ensuring the sound did not cease, to help those frightened by sudden noises—restoring their spirit. Additionally, I treated a woman who could not sleep due to prolonged thoughts; I acted drunk and did not inquire, and she, in her anger, fell asleep that very night.[423p]
I have also used sour jujube seed pills to treat people with excessive worry; I have employed Bai Hu Decoction without regard to the seasons to regulate individuals during the heat. I further used Wuyou Powder to treat those who suffered from cold obstruction in winter due to dampness, and then administered a modified Ma Huang Decoction twice as one dose, simmered with jujubes and ginger, to induce sweating for recovery; if not healed, I would use Gua Di Powder to promote sweating, assisted by heat. The same method applies to treating cold and contraction. I once treated a patient with a severe heat illness; when all medicines proved ineffective, I pricked several points on their head, leading to immediate recovery upon bloodletting. The treatments I provided felt as if I were reaching into a pouch. Only those who are exhausted or fearful are difficult to heal. Those who are happy have fewer ailments, as all their channels are relaxed and harmonious. In the past, I heard that Mr. Yang from Shandong treated a provincial leader suffering from continuous leakage without response. Initially, Mr. Yang did not address the patient directly, talking instead with others about the movements of the sun, moon, and stars.[424p]
In times of wind, clouds, thunder, and rain, from the time of the Dragon to the time of the Sheep, the sick would listen and forget their ailments. Yang once said: For those suffering from chronic ailments, one must first inquire about their interests. For those who love chess, play chess with them; for those who enjoy music, do not cease playing the flute and sheng. I also heard of Master Zhuang, who treated a patient with the utmost joy and music, but when he felt the patient's pulse, he lost his voice and pretended to leave for medicine. Days passed without him returning, and the patient, in despair, bid farewell to their family and friends, saying, "I won't be here for long." Zhuang knew the patient would recover and comforted them. When questioned about this, Zhuang referred to the "Plain Questions" saying, "Fear outweighs joy." These two men could be said to have grasped the essence of healing. However, Hua Yuan was nearly killed out of anger towards the county magistrate, while Wen Zhi was ultimately killed due to his anger toward the King of Qi. Among thousands of people, only one or two may find such misfortune. If the arts of medicine are so exquisitely delicate that they cannot ensure one’s safety, then they are indeed a cheap skill. Alas![425p]
The Four Influences of Internal and External Factors

Externally, there are wind, cold, heat, and dampness, which are the four seasonal influences from heaven, and they are formless; internally, there are hunger, fullness, exertion, and rest, which are also the four seasonal influences from heaven, and they are tangible.

  1. The first refers to illnesses that arise from the movement of qi resulting in internal conditions, such as the accumulation of conditions, nodules, and the onset of tumors, thyroid issues, abscesses, and mental disturbances.
    Explanation: 'Zheng' refers to hardness and accumulation. 'Jia' refers to qi and blood.

  2. The second refers to illnesses caused by the movement of qi resulting in external conditions, such as sores, ulcers, scabies, varicose veins, swellings, reddened eyes, pain, and itching.

  3. The third refers to illnesses arising internally that are not due to the movement of qi, such as the accumulation of fluids, food habits, hunger, fullness, fatigue, and emotional disturbances like sorrow, fear, joy, and anger.

  4. The fourth refers to illnesses arising externally that are not due to the movement of qi, such as miasma, toxic entities, bites or stings from insects or snakes, influences from the dead, as well as exposure to wind, cold, heat, and dampness, and injuries from knives or sharp objects.[426p]
    Diseases of Wind and Wood Stagnation

The populace suffers from pain in the stomach and heart, with afflictions on both sides of the torso; the throat is blocked, and food and drink cannot be swallowed. In severe cases, there are tinnitus and dizziness, loss of visual recognition, tendency to faint, and stiffened muscles and bones, leading to collapse with no awareness.

Diseases of Heat and Summer Stagnation

The populace suffers from weakness, sores and ulcers, swollen stiff areas in the sides, chest, back, head, and limbs, with abdominal distension, vomiting, and reverse flow. There may be spasms, bone pain, joint discomfort, and conditions such as diarrhea. Additionally, there may be heat stroke, sudden violent abdominal pain, and profuse bleeding; the essence can diminish, eyes may redden, and there may be heart pain. In severe cases, there is confusion and distress, leading to sudden death.[427p]

Illness of Damp Accumulation

The people suffer from a bloated sensation in the heart and abdomen, with rumbling intestines leading to many occurrences; in severe cases, chest pain and side pain occur, along with vomiting and diarrhea, resulting in swelling and heaviness due to heat in the spleen.

Illness of Dry Metal Accumulation

The people suffer from reverse coughing, a full heart and abdomen, and sharp pain in the lower abdomen that prevents turning side to side. There is dryness in the throat, a dusty appearance, and a sickly complexion, as metal prevails over wood.

Illness of Cold Water Accumulation

The people suffer from cold-induced heart pain, waist and lumbar pain, restricted joint movement that makes bending difficult, along with sudden faintness, hard distension, and abdominal fullness, as the yin overwhelms the yang.

Initial Qi

From the coldest winter until the spring equinox, in the position of the wind-wood of jueyin, yang energy engages while qi is weak, thus it is called shaoyang. It follows the principle of the first day of the heavenly stem of jiazi, always aligning with the initial qi of great cold, responding to the six qi with their respective heavenly stems, each ruling over two months. The first and second months belong to shaoyang, and likewise for the three yin and three yang.

Second Qi

From the spring equinox to the minor fullness, it is the position of the shao-yin fire lord; the yang qi is clear and bright, also in the position of yangming.

Third Qi

From minor fullness to major heat, it is the position of the shao-yang fire minister; the yang qi emerges, all things reach maturity, hence it is also referred to as the flourishing taiyang. Its pulse is vast and long. The heavenly weather and all things echo one another, flourishing and waning in nature.[428p]

The Four Energies

When the Great Heat arrives until the Autumn Equinox, the position of the Great Yin is in wet earth; the weather is auspicious, and the summer's post-Yin has already engaged, thus it is said that the Great Yin is flourishing. This is different from the three Yin and three Yang symbolizing the weather. The pulse is slow, large, and long. The Dry Metal is flourishing, tight, fine, short, and muddy, manifesting that all things are dry and visibly clear.

The Five Energies

From the Autumn Equinox to the Minor Snow, the position of the Yang Brightness is in Dry Metal; the energy is declining while Yin is flourishing, thus it is said that Metal energy is robust, and the pulse is fine and subtle.

The Final Energy

From the Minor Cold to the Major Cold, the position of the Sun is in Cold Water; Yin reaches its extremity and concludes, thus it is said that the Rebellious Yin is flourishing. "Rebellious" means to exhaust.

Wind Wood Liver Sour (Achieving Acupuncture)

It is paired with the Gallbladder, corresponds to the East Wood, has a blue color, corresponds to the eyes, and governs blood. Peony has a slightly sour and cold flavor, Alisma is salty and neutral, and Black Plum is sour and warm. All winds causing vertigo belong to the Liver Wood and are proactive. The treatment method is called "achieving," meaning to expel; the high ones should be surpassed. One can puncture Da Dun (Great Surge) or apply moxibustion similarly.

Summer Fire Heart Bitter (Inducing Sweat)

It is paired with the Small Intestine. The fire color of the South corresponds to the tongue and governs the blood circulation through the meridians. Rhubarb is bitter and cold, Wood Fragrance is bitter and warm, Coptis is bitter and cool, and Myrrh is bitter and warm. All pains, itching, sores, and ulcers belong to Heart Fire. The treatment method is to induce sweat for those who are hot, allowing dispersal. One can puncture Shao Chong (Lesser Surge) or apply moxibustion similarly.[429p]
Moist Earth Spleen Sweet (Seizing Needle)

This is related to the stomach. It is the central earth, yellow in color, corresponds with the lips, governs the muscles, and corresponds to the four seasons. Honey is sweet and cool; licorice is sweet and neutral. All swellings due to moisture belong to the spleen earth. The treatment method states that "seizing" means to purge, dividing Yin and Yang to facilitate water pathways. You may puncture the Hidden White point, and moxibustion is also effective.

Dry Metal Lung Spicy (Clearing Needle)

This is related to the large intestine. It corresponds to the west, is metal, white in color, affects the skin and hair, and the nose also aids in Qi flow. Dried ginger is spicy and hot, fresh ginger is spicy and warm, mint is spicy and cool. All stagnant Qi belongs to the lung metal. The treatment method states that "clearing" means to clear the diaphragm, promote urination, and resolve exterior conditions. You may puncture the Lesser Merchant point, and moxibustion is also effective.

Cold Water Kidney Salty (Bending Needle)

This is related to the bladder. It corresponds to the north, is water, black in color, affects the ears, and governs the bone marrow. Oyster is salty and cold; leech is salty and cold. All cold contractions belong to the kidney water. The treatment method states that "bending" refers to suppressing and controlling its rebellious nature. You may puncture the Springing Point, and moxibustion is also effective.

Great Cold, Initial Qi

The initial Qi is often associated with illnesses such as frequent cough, wind phlegm, wind stroke, excessive saliva, blockages, crooked mouth, hemiplegia, loss of voice, wind mania, and being in the wind. For women, there may be fluid retention in the chest, slight pain in the abdomen around the umbilicus, nausea and vomiting, rapid movements leading to anxiety and mania, and heart wind spasms. For illnesses related to initial Qi, it is advisable to disperse by using gourd stem powder and promote downward discharge.[430p]
Spring Equinox: The Second Vital Qi

The second vital qi leads to diseases that frequently manifest as wind-heat and wind-warmth. The classics state: wind injures the yang, while dampness injures the yin. Therefore, symptoms such as headache and body heat arise from wind-warmth, as wind harms the defensive qi and dampness harms the spleen qi. Hence, with wind-warmth as the illness, both yin and yang are floating. There may be sweating, a heavy body, excessive sleepiness, and difficulty in breathing or speaking. For these above symptoms, it is inappropriate to induce purging. If large doses of poisonous medicinal pills, such as bitter almonds, are administered, and heat symptoms arise concurrently, the patient is likely to face death. For diseases caused by the second vital qi, one should use the Gui Zhi Ma Huang Decoction to induce sweating only.

Grain Full: The Third Vital Qi

The third vital qi causes diseases that commonly present as fevers, particularly in the channels of the lower limbs. The three yang—Taiyang, Yangming, and Shaoyang—and the three yin—Taiyin, Shaoyin, and Jueyin—are involved. Taiyang presents with fever and aversion to cold, headache and neck pain, and stiff lower back; Yangming shows body heat, eye discomfort, and dry nose with inability to lie down; Shaoyang reveals chest and side pain, deafness, bitter taste in the mouth, with alternating chills and fever accompanied by vomiting. These three yang conditions are associated with heat. Taiyin shows abdominal fullness, dry throat, warm hands and feet, normal bowel movements without thirst, or abdominal pain when full. Shaoyin presents with dryness of the mouth and tongue with thirst, and Jueyin manifests as abdominal distension, constricted feeling, breathlessness, heavy sensation in the chest, cold extremities, and bluish nails. For diseases caused by the third vital qi, one should apply cooling measures, warm the upper body, and nourish the lower body, but it is inappropriate to use purging with medicinal pills like bitter almonds.[431p]
Heat of Great Summer before the Ascendance of the Four Qi

The Four Qi are associated with illnesses that frequently arise from heat, causing headaches, body fever, thirst, and are unsuitable for treatment as hot diseases. It is advisable to use Bai Hu Decoction, as this illness is non-contagious. Subsequently, symptoms may include spleen-dampness, gastric distress, large intestinal problems, small intestinal issues, severe abdominal pain, cholera symptoms such as vomiting and diarrhea, dysentery with mixed red and white, inability to differentiate between food and drink, diabetes, intestinal rumbling with cutting pain, facial swelling and foot edema, jaundice, dryness of the mouth, abdominal distension, and weakness in hands and feet. Children can also present these symptoms. For illnesses of the Four Qi, it is best to promote drainage, using remedies like Wu Ling San.

Autumn Equinox and the Ascendance of the Five Qi

The Five Qi are linked to illnesses that commonly manifest as wheezing, vomiting, coughing, and women experiencing alternating chills and fever, along with intermittent fevers, abscesses, and skin rashes in children. For illnesses associated with the Five Qi, it is advisable to use Xiao and Da Chai Hu Decoction, focusing on treatments for both the exterior and interior.[432p]
Small Snow - The Qi of Conclusion

The Qi of Conclusion leads to frequent illnesses caused by wind phlegm, wind-cold, and damp obstruction, resulting in the limbs being unresponsive. As winter water increases, the water and dampness clash, leading to a decline in lung qi. The harsh winter cold intensifies the issue, causing an inability to recover and leading to weakness with impaired function, while the water and fluids remain clear and cold. In cases of severe cold illnesses, there are accumulations and masses, cold hernias, and blood stagnation. For any qi-related ailment, the diseases of the Qi of Conclusion should be treated by breaking accumulations and inducing sweat.

From the Eastern Garden Ten Writings [Yuan Dynasty, Li Gao]

Southern Politics and Northern Politics

In Southern politics, the year is determined by the sky at the spring, observing if the ruler's fire is above or below; if above, it does not respond, if below, it does not respond. In Northern politics, if the ruler's fire is above it does not respond, if below, it does not respond, if on the left, it does not respond on the right, if on the right, it does not respond on the left. What should sink rises; what should rise sinks. In Southern politics, the previous is left and the latter is right, representing the ruler. In Northern politics, the previous is right and the latter is left, representing the ministers.[435p]

Discussion on the Fluctuation of Qi

This is a discussion of the four theories regarding the mutual existence of body and function in heaven and earth, examining the divine mechanisms of diagnosing illness. Conditions such as dampness affecting the stomach, heat in the small intestine, and wind in the gallbladder all indicate deficiency due to falling below the norm. To remedy this, one should first supplement with herbs like astragalus, ginseng, licorice, angelica, bupleurum, and cisplenus, which are warm and sweet, aiding in growth during spring and summer.

The spleen represents earth, the heart represents fire, and the liver represents wood, all reflecting the flourishing energy of strong fire. When there is an excess, one should drain with sweet and cold herbs like licorice and gardenia to alleviate heat, which can harm the lungs and cause reverse flow in the chest. The bitter and cold herb, huangqin, helps to reduce chest heat and alleviates breathlessness. Safflower is used to break up stagnant blood, while huangqin may greatly nourish kidney water and enhance lung energy, cooling excessive heat in the blood.

In conditions of cold affecting the bladder and dryness affecting the large intestine, there is often a significant excess. Here, one should drain using warm and sweet herbs like astragalus to stop spontaneous sweating, making the exterior strong against cold pathogens. The warming effects of angelica can moisten dryness, while the addition of peach kernel helps to open blocked pathways and relieve constipation.

The essence of kidney water and the qi of lung metal both reflect deficiency. To address this, one should initially supplement using bitter and cold herbs like berberine to eliminate damp heat associated with atrophy. This can manifest in weakened knees, and helps to alleviate symptoms of yin deficiency, sweats, and sexual dysfunction while enhancing essence. Licorice, gardenia, and huangqin can support lung qi and balance downward flow of yin fire. When the lung experiences distress from upward movement of qi, consuming bitter herbs for drainage is essential.

This describes the common method of treatment for heat in early summer, which is not a rigid rule. A flexible approach, based on the specific nature of the illness, is what is truly necessary.[436p]
On Excess and Harm in Reception

I read the "Inner Canon," regarding the subtle principles and reached the point about excess causing harm in reception. I sighed and said: "Indeed, this is the pivot of creation!" Wang Taifu expounded on this earlier, and Liu Hejian later elucidated it; the sages’ essence is nearly all encompassed. However, scholars still cannot fully comprehend it; isn't there still an understanding lacking?

Carefully, I note in the "Inner Canon," the emperor said, "I wish to understand the correspondence of the geography to the six seasons, how is the Qi positioned?" Qibo replied, "To the right of clarity is the position of sovereign fire. To the right of sovereign fire, take a step back, and the minister fire will govern; take another step back, the earth Qi will govern; another step back, the metal Qi will govern; another step back, the water Qi will govern; another step back, the wood Qi will govern; and another step back, the sovereign fire will govern again."[437p]
Under the influence of fire, water rises; beneath the water level, earth rises; beneath the earth level, wind rises; beneath the wind level, metal rises; beneath the metal level, fire rises: under the influence of the sovereign fire, yin essence rises. The emperor asked, "Why is this?" Qi Bo replied, "Excess leads to harm; to support is to regulate; regulating leads to transformation. The external manifestations of prosperity and decline indicate that harm leads to disorder, and transformation leads to great illness.

Consider how yin and yang and the five elements interact in the universe: the high are restrained, the low are elevated; the strong are bent, the weak are supported. This occurs inevitably and cannot be otherwise. If not, the high would become higher, the low lower, the strong stronger, and the weak weaker, leading to extreme chaos in governance. Can heaven and earth maintain their positions like this? Yet, whether high or low, weak or strong, this is still an inevitable occurrence.

Hence, change is the essence of transformation. Because it cannot be constant, divine transformation cannot be measured; what cannot be measured is continuous; if it could be constant, it would cease."[438p]
When excessive, it harms the following, hence the control. Can one really act against this, and yet be unable to avoid it? As for the Grand Marshal and the Hejian, they have already elaborated, so I will not elaborate further here. For what has not yet been fully understood, please allow me to present it.

From the clearly manifest to the fifteen sentences of governance by the sovereign fire, this refers to the positions governed by the six sections. From below the mutual fire to the twelve sentences of the hidden essence of yin, this pertains to the correspondence of geography with seasonal energy. The two sentences on excessive harm and control indicate the need to restrain excess. Control leads to transformation. The four sentences regarding major transformations discuss the constants of control and the variables of lack of control.

"Receiving" is akin to "following." Yet, they use the term "receiving" instead of "following" because it signifies receiving from above, hence it is called "receiving." Although it is called a symbol, it contains the meaning of prevention. Excess refers to extreme overreach. Harm indicates the damage to things. Control signifies overcoming. However, what is received, if not excessive, simply follows. Thus, even though it receives without visibility, once it is excessive, it must overcome to bring balance, and in that balance, it becomes visible.[439p]
However, when one welcomes it, they do not know where it comes from; when one tracks it, they do not know where it stops. It is certain there are things that cannot be definitively known. Yet, what can be certain always exists in the obscurity and haze, and cannot be deceived by anyone. Hejian states: When the rising reaches its peak, it seems to reverse into a transformation of itself. The "seeming" can certainly be sought through form and substance. Therefore, in the later chapters, the organ of the yin relates to the wind's emergence, ultimately leading to austerity; the organ of the lesser yin relates to the emergence of heat, ultimately leading to categories of cold. The emergence as wind or heat corresponds to the peak (or height), while the austerity and cold correspond to control. Additionally, when water manifests as hail and snow, and earth manifests as rapid winds, the manifestation of water and earth corresponds to the peak, while hail, snow, and rapid winds correspond to control. Such occurrences are the constants of creation; they cannot exist without peaks, nor can they exist without control. Although the themes of the preceding and following chapters may differ in seasonal influences and atmospheric conditions, the peak can harm the method of control, and this applies to all matters without exception. Because this applies universally, when seeking from humanity, the five viscera mutually balance each other.[440p]
If one organ is imbalanced, it cannot maintain balance; when the five organs balance each other, is it not the case that one must guard against excess? If one organ is imbalanced, does that mean it cannot overcome balance? Speaking of heart fire, if it is not in excess, then even if kidney water fears heart fire, it merely guards against it; but if there is excess, it will rise and overcome it. The same applies to all other organs. Regulation allows transformation; one must work to regulate so that transformation occurs. This may be a misunderstanding in transmission and writing, and those who read it may unknowingly seek understanding in vain, thus omitting these four lines entirely. Little do they know that the first two lines only speak of excess causing harm and harm leading to regulation. These four lines convey meanings beyond harm and regulation. If one were to omit them, the full intent of the text would not be understood. Regulation and transformation directly contrast with the following discussion of harm leading to disorder, and both ideas are coherent. There is no need for convoluted explanation; they naturally align.[441p]
The principles of creation and transformation state that when there are regulations, the six energies are kept from becoming excessive, resulting in balance. In this balance, all things are born, giving rise to endless transformations. The abundance of transformation is such that birth precedes transformation. Externally, the phenomena of prosperity and decline indicate that the distribution of the six energies governs these cycles of rise and fall, which are distinctly observable, hence it is referred to as external manifestation. When harm leads to chaos, and the great illnesses of creation and transformation arise, it indicates that when excess harms without any regulation, it results in the disintegration and disorder of governance. When governance disintegrates and becomes chaotic, transformations reach their extremes, leading to severe calamities; can there be any beings that are not afflicted? The concept of creation and transformation pertains to everything born and transformed, wherein extreme changes lead to severe disasters, hence it is called great illness. Above, creation relates to the principles of transformation, while below, it pertains to all things. Speaking in terms of humanity, regulation leads to creation and transformation, like the original energy circulating and nourishing the entire body, with all five organs, six intestines, limbs, bones, and nine orifices relying upon it. This is regarded as the governing principle of movement and stillness.[442p]
Severe illness arises when evil spirits run rampant, depleting the righteous energy. All the five organs, six visceras, four limbs, hundreds of bones, and nine orifices can no longer function as they normally would. Some harm themselves out of self-harm, others inherit pain, or one comes into being through the absence of being, transforming what is inherently present into absence. Some regard the dual transformations as a single intent, while others use great illness as a metaphor for the essence of creation. All these notions are incorrect. Moreover, the essence of a person certainly has both exuberance and self-restraint; if it is exuberant but lacks self-control, then methods involving herbs, fluids, needles, stones, and guiding practices serve as assistance. For the energies of heaven and earth, those that are exuberant yet self-restrained return to equilibrium, while those that are exuberant without restraint—who will assist them? Nevertheless, the way of creation and transformation, when changed to the extreme, must eventually revert and restore its normal state. If scholars can comprehend the principles from those like Tai Pu and He Jian and then relate them to this discourse, it may elucidate the intricacies of the nexus of creation and transformation. Yet, Zhang Dai Ren in "Essentials of Treatment" states: Suppose water is the mother, and wood is the child.[443p]
When spring is in full bloom, winter's command still lingers, indicating the excess of water. When water is excessive, the wood cannot thrive. Wood is the successor to winter and draws strength from water. When water is already excessive, it harms what it supports, thus wood has no power. Without the power of wood, there can be no control over earth; when earth is strong, it dominates water. Earth is the successor to the mandate of late summer. When water is controlled by earth, heat overcomes cold. This transformation becomes humidity, which is its power.

Similarly, when fire is the mother and earth is the child, during late summer, warmth still prevails, indicating an excess of fire. When fire is excessively strong, humidity cannot emerge. Humidity is the successor to summer and is created by fire; if fire is excessive, it harms what it supports, and thus humidity has no power. Without the power of humidity, it cannot control water; when water is strong, fire becomes constrained. Water is the command of severe winter. When fire is controlled by water, cold conquers heat. This transforms into earth, and wet earth thus regains its power.

This statement, when elaborated further, strays increasingly from the classic texts. Some say that the essence of the heart is what others have achieved, and it is likely derived from misconceptions in what one has heard.[444p]
On the Longevity and Shortness of Life Related to Yin and Yang

The Great Discussion of the Five Constants states: The essence of Yin supports the longevity of a person, while the essence of Yang leads to their early demise. The essence of Yin that supports refers to the energy of spring and summer, which is associated with growth. The essence of Yang that descends pertains to the energy of autumn and winter, which is related to storage.

In nature, when the hidden Yin of the heavens encounters spring, it stirs and rises above, and this is referred to as the energy of life. When it reaches its peak and floats, it is known as the energy of flourishing. These six energies migrate rightwards to the heavens, representing the clear Yang of the sky. Yang is associated with life and, therefore, longevity.

The primal Yang of heaven, when encountering autumn, retreats and descends, leading to the energy of collection and demise. When it sinks to its limits and becomes heavy, it is the energy of closure and preservation. This energy migrates leftwards into the earth, thus representing the turbid Yin of the ground. The act of release leads to death.

Outward roots are referred to as the establishment of energy; when energy ceases, transformation halts. Inward roots are called the workings of the spirit; when the spirit departs, the workings stop. Both do not rise but rather fall.

The energy of the earth corresponds to the human spleen and stomach. The spleen governs the energy of the five organs, while the kidneys govern their essence, both of which are offered upwards to the heavens. These two collectively govern the processes of creation, rising and floating, which indicates that spring brings forth life and summer nurtures growth, all stemming from the stomach.

Thus, when activities, rest, and nourishment are well-ordered, and when they are clear and pure, it is imperative not to harm the original energy of the stomach. If one descends to the consumption of the kidneys and liver, or enacts the commands of autumn and winter that lead to demise, they will align with the natural order of heaven.[445p]
The Gate of Qi

The Heart Method of Danxi
(Yuan Dynasty - Zhu Zhenheng)

When excessive, it harms; when carried, it controls.

As Qi comes, if it reaches extremes and causes disaster, then to ride on this Qi, balance must be restored by reverting it. Things that reach their extremes must revert, for this is the nature of principles. Generally, the influences of cold, heat, dryness, humidity, wind, and fire, as well as the forms of wood, fire, earth, metal, and water, all can harm their objects when they become excessive; thus, carrying and controlling them is necessary. Therefore, when extremes lead to disasters, balance can be achieved by reverting, revealing the subtlety of the movement of Qi.

This is the meaning of "when excessive, it harms; when carried, it controls."

The interplay of heaven and earth, yin and yang, ensures that extreme cold generates heat. Extreme heat generates cold, and spirits are unpredictable, having their roles in the control and modulation in between. Thus, when wood is at its peak, it resembles metal; when fire reaches its peak, it resembles water; when earth is at its peak, it resembles wood; when metal is at its peak, it resembles fire; and when water is at its peak, it resembles earth. The excessive nature of Qi leads its carrying to triumph over itself. Only by carrying the excessive and controlling its harm can the achievements of creation be realized.

Now, beneath the fire of the heart, the water energy carries it but does not transform the fire energy; beneath the water level, the earth energy carries it while the water energy does not alter (the growth of wood); beneath the earth level, wood carries it and earth follows; beneath the wind level, metal carries it and calms the wind. The heat of fire carries the dry metal, naturally causing the ailments among metal families; the essence of yin carries its sovereign fire, naturally leading to an outcome among fire families.[446p]
The so-called excess causing harm, and the receiving that leads to restraint, is just thus. I have examined the Great Treatise on the Six Origins, which states that when the Lesser Yang reaches, it is fire that generates, ultimately leading to moisture; this reflects the idea of water transforming to receive the fire of the opposite. When the Greater Yang reaches, it brings cold snow and hail, white dust, which signifies the earth transforming to receive cold water. Then comes the Great Yin, which manifests as thunder and sudden violent winds; the Absolute Yin brings forth life-creating winds, ultimately leading to desolation; the Bright Yang results in diffusion and warmth; the Lesser Yin gives rise to heat, balanced by cold. Is it not true that excess causes harm and that receiving leads to restraint? In the past, the Yellow Emperor and Qi Bo explored the celestial records and the extremes of geography, gathering distant elements and observing their own bodies, questioning each other to compose the "Inner Canon." This culminated in the profound discussions of the Great Treatise, which articulates the interdependence of the six vital energies, indicating that restraint leads to transformation; externally, there is flourishing and decline, harm causes chaos, and transformation can lead to great ailments. All energies that dominate and come from below are diminished in their manifest power. Otherwise, when changes arise from water, hail and snow occur; from earth, sudden gusts arise; from wood, destruction emerges; from metal, clarity is revealed; from fire, obscurity sets in. These are all manifestations of extremity responding to the reception of excess. Alas! To understand the cosmic principles as a Confucianist includes the medical practitioners; it is not merely about treating illnesses. One must consider their ignorance of the principles of heaven and earth, which is insufficient for the language of a physician.[447p]
Examine the disease mechanisms without failing to consider the appropriate energies.

Evil energies each have their own affiliations, which must be thoroughly examined at the outset; treatment methods each have their own principles, which must be carefully observed afterwards. The essence of treating illness lies in identifying these affiliations first; if one is unaware of where the principles lead, it is easy to make mistakes. The emergence of illness is overwhelmingly numerous, but its affiliations are confined to the five phases and six energies. If one can accurately investigate this and discern the critical points, treatment can be conducted accordingly, ensuring that each method aligns with the appropriateness of the phases and energies, avoiding any minute errors. In this way, the approach to treating illness and seeking affiliations shall be without regret. The True Essentials treatise states: “Examine the disease mechanisms, without losing sight of the appropriate energies,” encapsulating this idea. It has been said that within the practice of medicine, if one word could encompass its essence, it would be "energies."[448p]
Heaven is the Yang, and Earth is the Yin. The dual energies of Yin and Yang are divided into three categories, referred to as the three Yin and three Yang. However, Heaven is not purely Yang; it also contains three Yin. Likewise, Earth is not purely Yin; it also contains three Yang. Thus, above and below, Heaven and Earth each have the six elements of wind, heat, fire, moisture, dryness, and cold that circulate and move between them, along with the five movements of Wood, Fire, Earth, Metal, and Water.

Human life is intertwined with these elements, as the organs, vital energy, and blood flow in correspondence with Heaven and Earth. This reveals the cause of many illnesses and the mechanisms involved, all of which arise from these principles. Therefore, how should a physician approach treatment? They should carefully observe this and ensure that nothing is neglected in accordance with the proper conditions before proceeding.

As for various illnesses: disturbances from wind dizziness are associated with the Liver Wood; all types of pain, itching, and ulcers relate to Heart Fire; swelling and fullness due to moisture pertain to Spleen Earth; emotional distress and stagnation correspond to Lung Metal; and cold that contracts and pulls relates to Kidney Water. These illnesses are attributed to the five movements.[449p]
All violent rigidity belongs to wind; all vomiting of sourness belongs to heat; all agitation and madness belong to fire; all spasms and rigidity belong to dampness; all dry and desiccated conditions belong to dryness; all diseases with clear and cool bodily fluids belong to cold. This pathology relates to the six qi. Indeed, understanding the nature of a disease is crucial; although it may seem thorough, the treatment applied must be specific. Therefore, one must clearly differentiate between yin and yang in cases of doubt, and distinguish between root and branch in subtle matters. For the differences between whether there is or isn't, one should seek the reasons for these differences; for the distinctions between fullness and emptiness, one should consider the reasons for these distinctions. Induce sweating, vomiting, or purging as warranted; use warm, cold, or cool treatments as appropriate. One may go against it to control the mild, or follow it to direct the severe.[450p]
In the higher aspects, one governs the disturbances of the vital energy from afar; in the middle aspects, one discerns the transformations of the seasonal movements; in the lower aspects, one examines the appropriateness of the north and south, ensuring that the small and great are balanced, and the order of events aligns properly, thereby achieving governance. Could there be any mistakes that are grossly different or chaotic? Furthermore, the "Inner Canon" states: to treat an illness, one must seek its root. The "Materia Medica" says: to heal an illness, one must first observe the mechanism of the disease. This is the essence of examining the disease mechanism. The "Great Treatise on the Six Yuan" states: do not lose the trust of Heaven, and do not go against the appropriate energies. The "Great Treatise on the Five Constants" states: one must prioritize the seasonal energies and not disrupt the harmony of Heaven. All of this conveys the importance of maintaining proper energies. Thus, the texts of the "Simple Questions" and the "Spirit Pivot" consistently emphasize the discourse on the movements of energy. It has been said that one must first establish the year to clarify its energies, and it further advises that those who treat diseases must be clear about the laws of Heaven and the geography of the earth, as well as the interchange of Yin and Yang. It has been said that if one does not understand the seasonal changes of the years, the fluctuations of energies, and the origins of vacuity and solidity, one cannot be proficient in their craft. This is stated with repeated emphasis as if there is an inability to refrain from such a notion; could this be the private worries of the sages overemphasized? The essence of the medical path is entirely contingent upon this. By observing the "Basic Patterns of Illness," one compares various physical forms and gains a profound understanding of the subtlety of the movements of energies and transformations, leaving no room for additions regarding the principles of disease mechanism and energy appropriateness.[451p]
Medical Canon of the Right Transmission

By Yu Tuan of the Ming Dynasty

On Excess and Its Harm

Someone asked about the meaning of "excess harms and restraint pertains." It was said that Wang Andao has elaborated on this thoroughly. Yet, there are still points that need clarification, so I will briefly present them as follows. The Yellow Emperor said: “I wish to know how geography corresponds to the six seasonal phases.” Qi Bo replied: “To the right of the obvious is the position of the Fire of the Ruler. To the right of the Fire of the Ruler, one step back, is governed by the Fire of the Minister; another step back, is governed by the Earth Qi; another step back, is governed by the Metal Qi; another step back, is governed by the Water Qi; another step back, is governed by the Wood Qi; and another step back, returns to the governance of the Fire of the Ruler. Below the Fire of the Minister, the Water Qi supports it; beneath the Water position, the Earth’s Yang supports it; beneath the Earth position, the Wind Qi supports it; beneath the Wind position, the Metal Qi supports it; beneath the Metal position, the Fire Qi supports it; and beneath the Fire of the Ruler, the Yin Essence supports it. Excess causes harm; restraint pertains to governance, and governance leads to transformation. Externally, the cycles of flourishing and decline can lead to harm, chaos, and the manifestation of serious illnesses.[452p]
The Five Elements consist of Wood, Earth, Metal, Water, each represented once, while Fire has two forms: the Ruler Fire and the Minister Fire. Geographically, they are distributed across the six directions, and seasonally, they correspond to the six Qi.

The first Qi goes from the Chou (Ox) to the Mao (Rabbit), starting from the Major Cold and ending at the Spring Equinox, governed by the Jueyin Wind Wood. The second Qi extends from the Mao to the Si (Snake), beginning at the Spring Equinox and concluding at the Lesser Fullness, overseen by the Shaoyin Ruler Fire. The third Qi spans from the Si to the Wei (Goat), commencing at the Lesser Fullness and finishing at the Major Heat, controlled by the Shaoyang Minister Fire. The fourth Qi covers the period from the Wei to the You (Rooster), starting at the Major Heat and ending at the Autumn Equinox, presided over by the Taiyin Moist Earth. The fifth Qi goes from the You to the Hai (Pig), beginning at the Autumn Equinox and concluding at the Lesser Snow, managed by the Yangming Dry Metal. The final Qi runs from the Hai to the Chou, starting from the Lesser Snow and ending at the Major Cold, ruled by the Taiyang Cold Water.

What is referred to as "manifest" pertains to direction, with the sun rising in the direction of Mao. The Shaoyin Ruler Fire begins here and moves to the right, hence it is said to be "manifest to the right."[453p]
The heavens and the earth rotate to the left, while the six energies rotate to the right. Thus, it is said to retreat. Below the six positions, each has something it cannot overcome, which it supports from below. The Wang family says: "To support is like to follow, but it also has the meaning of hindrance." Therefore, what is offered below is called support. As for the Way of the five elements, if there is no excess, it merely follows; if there is any excess, it rises to overcome. Some say: "What does the regulator regulate?" "What does the harmful one harm?" It is said: "The regulator regulates the excessive energy; the harmful one harms the original energy of the supporter." What is called original energy, in general, is referred to as the One; when divided, it is called the six. The One is that from the One Heaven comes Water, Water produces Wood, Wood produces Fire, Fire produces Earth, Earth produces Metal, and Metal again produces Water, circulating without end, generating endlessly.[454p]
The six elements are as follows: water is the source of the transformation of wood, wood is the source of the transformation of fire, fire is the source of the transformation of earth, earth is the source of the transformation of metal, and metal is the source of the transformation of water. This cycle of transformation is boundless. If fire is not excessive, then the accompanying water simply follows. When there is excessive heat, the water rises to balance it, as it fears harming the essence of metal. This principle applies to all six energies.

The concept of the Five Elements’ cycles of dominance and recovery emerges organically and unexpectedly. When there is regulation, there is transformation. The principle states that when there is regulation, it is like heat being managed, leading to continuous transformation—what harm can there be? The external manifestations of prosperity and decline indicate that what is supported is weak, while what is excessive is at its peak, yet the regulation does not cease. In the heavens and earth, these are the six harms; in the human body, they manifest as six ailments. Harm arises from disorder, meaning there is transformation without regulation. What is supported becomes extremely weak and devoid of energy, thus what is excessive becomes rampant and uncontainable. In the heavens and earth, this leads to great destruction; in the human body, it results in serious illness and potentially death.

This is a general overview, not exhaustive in detail. Scholars should refer to the discussions of An Dao for a complete understanding of these concepts.[455p]
The Evils of the Six Excesses

Someone asked about the evils of the six excesses, and it should be understood as the extremes of the six energies from the "Inner Canon." In the past, the physician He responded to Duke Ping of Jin, not mentioning wind, cold, heat, dampness, dryness, and fire, but referred instead to yin and yang, wind and rain, clarity and obscurity. Why is this? He replied: Although the terms differ, the underlying principles are the same. What is meant by yin excess leading to cold diseases is that the excessive command of the taiyang (greater yang) and cold water leads to cold diseases; yin excess leading to heat diseases refers to the excessive command of the shaoyang (lesser yang) with its fire resulting in heat diseases; wind excess leading to endpoint diseases means an excess in the jueyin (terminal yin) and windy wood results in endpoint diseases; rain excess leading to abdominal diseases is due to the excessive command of the taiyin (greater yin) and damp earth resulting in abdominal diseases; obscurity excess leading to confusion diseases comes from the excessive command of the yangming (brightness) and dry metal leading to epidemic diseases; and clarity excess leading to heart diseases is caused by the excessive command of the shaoyin (lesser yin) and ministerial fire resulting in heart diseases. Someone said: Yin and yang, wind and rain, can be equated with the ailments of cold, heat, wind, and dampness; they clearly correspond with each other. However, the conditions of obscurity excess leading to confusion diseases and clarity excess leading to heart diseases seem not to correspond; please clarify this for me.[456p]
It is said: When gold is excessive in a year, dryness causes great upheaval; long periods of clear skies without rain result in yellow dust obscuring the heavens, and the sun and moon lose their brightness. This should be regarded as a pestilential disease, the miasma of mountains and hills. The confusion appears to indicate a pestilence, understood as a transmission error. When the fire of the sovereign is excessive, heat advances prematurely; fire symbolizes brightness, thus it is said to be "lewd brightness," as stated in the "Inner Canon" that when the sky is bright, the sun and moon do not shine clearly. The lesser yin sovereign fire governs, hence it is called heart disease. The spring equinox arrives and great heat occurs at the beginning of summer. Some interpret brightness as daylight and darkness as night, while confusion is seen as misleading the heart and will, which is incorrect. Daylight and darkness are merely the natural laws of heaven; how can there be lewdness in that? What is called misleading the heart and will is also not the lewdness or evil of heaven and earth. Scholars ought to reflect further on this. In ancient times, sages looked up to examine celestial phenomena and looked down to observe geographical features, correlating the ten stems to create the five movements, and associating the twelve branches to form the six qi. Heaven embodies the six directions, and the year is marked by the six qi across the five elements. By adding the six qi of heaven to the six divisions of the year's five movements, one can discern the principles of gain and loss, which are universally valid. As the tradition states, the height of heaven and the distance of the stars, if one seeks their meanings, one could thus attain understanding even after a thousand years.[457p]
Medical Outline
(Ming Dynasty – Lou Ying)

Exegesis on the Great Treatise of Temporal Origins and the Principle of Qi

According to the Great Treatise on Temporal Origins, the heavens have five elements and regularities, which pertain to the beginnings of the discussion on the five movements and six qi, marking the start of the changes between abundance and deficiency. The five movements refer to the wood, fire, earth, metal, and water of the earth, governing the internal aspects of governance. The three yin and three yang refer to the wind, heat, humidity, dryness, and cold of the heavens, governing the external aspects of governance. When the Emperor asked about the interaction of the five movements in governance and how it corresponds with the external treatment of the three yin and three yang, Gui Yu responded that the governance of the five movements and the yin-yang is the way of heaven and earth, the guiding principle of all things, the parents of change, and the source of life and death, the abode of the divine. Thus, in governance, what is born is called transformation, what is extreme is called change, the unknowable nature of yin and yang is referred to as the divine, and the use of the divine without boundaries is called sage-like. Their transformations, divine and sacred, are called function; in the heavens, this corresponds to the qi of wind, heat, humidity, dryness, and cold (the three yin and three yang); on the earth, the qi of wind corresponds to wood, heat corresponds to fire, humidity corresponds to earth, dryness corresponds to metal, and cold corresponds to water, thus forming the shapes of the five movements. Therefore, the forms in heaven resonate with those on earth, allowing all things to thrive—this is the transformation of life. Yet, heaven and earth are the up and down of all things, the left and right of yin and yang, represented by the external qi of the three yin and three yang, rotating to the right to influence the earth. Water and fire signify the manifestations of yin and yang, while metal and wood represent the beginning and end of generation; this is the shape of the five movements in the earth, turning left to align with the heavens.[458p]
The amount of energy in the heavens corresponds to the rise and fall of forms on the earth. Thus, the quantity of energy in the heavens interacts with the rising and falling forms on the earth, leading to the changes manifested in all things. When the energy is abundant and coincides with the flourishing forms, it brings increase, resulting in thriving changes; when the energy is scarce and coincides with the declining forms, it leads to decrease, resulting in diminished changes.

The transformation of living things arises from the constant energy of heaven and earth, known as "normal energy" in the five phases and "consistent transformation" in the six energies. The extreme changes of things refer to the changing energies of heaven and earth, termed "excess and deficiency" in the five phases and "excessive dominance and reversals" in the six energies. The predominance of changes is characterized by excessive conditions in the five phases and excessive dominance in the six energies, while the diminishment of changes arises from deficiencies in the five phases and reversals in the six energies.

All discussions about the five phases and six energies relate to their transformations of abundance and scarcity. This topic, explored thoroughly in the latter part of the classic texts, encompasses countless words aiming to thoroughly elucidate these four concepts, which scholars should study diligently.

The movements of the five phases each have their designated periods and are not limited to just the main seasonal times, referring to wood, fire, earth, metal, and water. The governance of each phase concludes its yearly cycle and is not confined merely to the seasonal timing within a year. Previous sections discuss the five phases without addressing the six energies, focusing on the main seasonal times without considering the yearly governance. This section begins the discussion of how the five phases and six energies interact and govern together, extending beyond only the five phases; it subsequently explores how each phase governs its respective year, extending beyond just the main seasonal times.[459p]
On the Great Discussion of the Five Movements and the Transformations of Qi

According to the Great Discussion of the Five Movements, the Yellow Emperor sat in the Hall of Brightness to express his desire to understand their origins. He then discussed the meanings of Yin and Yang derived from the previous text on the Five Movements and Six Qi. This discussion encompasses the symbols of the Five Heavens, wherein the constellations traversed represent the transformations of Qi, corresponding to the same categories of the Ten Heavenly Stems and Twelve Earthly Branches, along with those that are linked in position, resulting in harmonious transformations.

The Earth governs the first (Jia) and sixth (Ji) stems and corresponds to the Ox (Chou) and Goat (Wei) branches. The Moon governs these as the energy of the dark heavens, traversing the symbol of the heart and the tail represented by Ji (the sixth stem) and the middle palace. Therefore, Jia and Chou share a position, while Ji and Wei belong to the same category, leading to the transformation of moist Earth.

Metal governs the second (Yi) and seventh (Geng) stems and relates to the Rabbit (Yin) and Rooster (You) branches. The Yangming governs these as the energy of the pure heavens, traversing the symbols of the stars Kang (Kang), Zhi (Zhi), Ma (Mao), and Bi (Bi). Thus, Yi and Yin correspond to the same category, while Geng and You do as well, leading to the transformation of dry Metal.[460p]
Water governs the substances of Bing and Xin, as well as those of Chen and Xu. The Sun is its master; the primordial energy of Heaven flows through the symbols of Zhang Yi and Lou Wei. Zhang Yi corresponds to the substance of Bing and Lou Wei to Xin, hence Bing and Chen are linked, and Xin and Xu are connected, harmonizing to transform into cold water.

Wood governs the substances of Ding and Ren, as well as those of Si and Hai. The Jue Yin is its master; the celestial energy flows through the symbols of Wei Shi and Liu Gui. Wei Shi corresponds to the substance of Ren, and Liu Gui to Ding, thus Ren and Hai belong together, and Ding and Si belong together, harmonizing to transform into the winds of wood.

Fire controls the substances of Wu and Gui, as well as those of Zi and Wu. The Shao Yin is its master, and above Chen and Shen, the Shao Yang dominates; the energy of Dan Tian flows through the symbols of Niu Nu and Wu Fen. Niu Nu corresponds to the substance of Gui, and Wu Fen to the center, thus Gui and Zi are linked, and Wu and Wu are connected, harmonizing to transform into heat and fire.

The stems Ji and Yi belong to wood, positioned in the East; Bing and Ding belong to fire, positioned in the South; Geng and Xin belong to metal, positioned in the West; Ren and Gui belong to water, positioned in the North; Xu and Ji belong to earth, positioned in the central palace. The branches Ying and Mao match with Ji and Yi, Si and Wu match with Bing and Ding, Shen and You match with Geng and Xin, and Hai and Zi align with Ren and Gui.[461p]
The eastern position is in the direction of the dragon, the southwestern position is in the direction of the goat, the northwestern position is in the direction of the dog, and the northeastern position is in the direction of the ox, which makes up the four directions. In combination with the earth (Wu and Ji), the wood (Jia and Yi in Yin and Mao) comes together, the fire (Bing and Ding in Si and Wu) comes together, the earth (Wu and Ji in Chen, Xu, Chou, and Wei) comes together, the metal (Geng and Xin in Shen and You) comes together, and the water (Ren and Gui in Hai and Zi) comes together as well. The Jia in Yin is at the head of the east, while Gui in Chou is at the tail of the north, and Jia and Chou are connected, as are Gui and Yin. Bing is at the head of the south, and Chen is at the tail of the east, thus Bing and Chen are connected. Wu and Ji are located in the middle of wood, fire, metal, and water, serving as gateways between heaven and earth, and marking the long summer in the four seasons; they connect with Wu to the south and Shen to the west, thereby Wu and Ji are not assigned a specific direction. However, the texts distinctly mention Wu divided from Ji to represent their distinction. Xin and Xu are both at the tail of the west, and Xin and Xu are connected. Only Wu fire connects with Shen.[462p]
The unrefined earth is nestled within, with Gui water connected to Yin. The earth in the center of Chou is moist, indicating that wet earth is present, with water and fire circulating in between. In the heavens, it resides before the earth, while in the ground, it resides behind the earth, leading to a constant mixture of earth and fire. Thus, earth thrives during the hot summer. Danxi deeply understood this principle and elucidated that the combination of dampness and heat often leads to illness, with eight or nine out of ten cases involving dampness generating heat, and prolonged heat giving rise to dampness. According to the celestial patterns, the stars traversing their territories primarily belong to the positions of the five movements, not extending to the positions of the six energies. This is because the stem relates to the roots of wood, while the branches and leaves correspond to the supports; therefore, when mentioning stems, the supports are included. Thus, transformations are of the same nature as both stems and supports, signifying a blend of roots and branches. Some say in recent times that only the transformations from the five movements should be considered for the celestial patterns, neglecting the transformations of the six energies. Instead, they assert the standing transformations: earth transforms properly at Wei, counter-transforms at Chou; metal properly at You, counter at Mao; water properly at Xu, counter at Chen; wood properly at Hai, counter at Si; true fire properly at Wu, counter at Zi; and mutual fire properly at Yin, counter at Shen.[463p]
The essence of the transformation of the five movements lies in the authentic and true nature of the principles of the universe, which cannot be surpassed or replicated; while the transformations represented by the opposing forces are illusory and can be outdone. The scriptures you interpret relate solely to the changes of these transformations. They are derived from the energies of the five celestial bodies. How then does this differ from what was previously stated? The response is: the meaning of the scripture is as clear as the sun and stars; those who seek understanding should excavate the meanings of the authentic and opposing transformations. Upon careful examination of the texts, the Emperor clearly outlines the celestial stems of the five movements and the branches of the six energies, posing questions collectively—not solely inquiring about the five movements without regard to the six energies. The answer given by Qibo also encompasses the representations of the five celestial bodies and their bearing on celestial stars, thus addressing both the five movements and the six energies together, not just focusing on the five movements alone and excluding the six branches. Why then, is there a failure to delve into the essential meanings of the scripture, leading to an arbitrary division of the movements and energies into two separate concepts? This results in confusion in understanding the sacred texts and misleads subsequent learners, committing the grave error of creating discord and deviation.[464p]
As for the theory of victory and defeat, the classics only discuss the six years of Zi, Wu, Yin, Shen, Chen, and Xu. The great transformation of Qi emphasizes that there is no victory or defeat in the primordial state. It is not heard that the lesser transformations of Qi in Wei, You, Hai are real; without victory or defeat, in the cycles of Chou, Wei, Mao, You, Si, and Hai, the transformations of Qi are less, yet there is victory and defeat. It has not been heard that there are great transformations of Qi during Zi, Chen, and Shen that are false, yet there is victory and defeat.

Now, the heavens and the earth represent the upper and lower aspects of all things, and the left and right denote the pathways of Yin and Yang. As for the year, what is the season? It discusses the rightward rotation of heaven outside, with the cold and heat entering six times to elevate the earth. The earth receives the six entries from heaven to facilitate the leftward rotation of the five elements, which give rise to people and things in the midst of heaven. The upper and lower aspects of all things, as well as the left and right pathways of Yin and Yang, correspond to the rightward rotational positions of the six seasons.
