The upper and lower refer to what is above, which is the position governed by heaven, and what is below, which is the position by the spring. The left and right refer to what is beside the upper; they are the left and right aspects of heaven, and what is beside the lower; these are the left leisure and right positions by the spring. Thus, the three Yin and three Yang of heaven rotate rightward in their six positions, as seen during the years of Si and Hai, where Jue Yin appears above, while Shao Yin is to the left, and Tai Yang is to the right.[465p]
As for the positions of the Yin and Yang at the time of the Child and Noon years, when the Jueyin descends in a rightward spiral, above it is the Shaoyin, while to the left is the Taiyin and to the right is the Jueyin; this is how it constantly spirals downwards to the right each year. Facing north, its position is determined; what it observes, refers to the position of the heavenly authority, which is in the south while facing north. Its left and right are designated as follows: southwest is the left position, southeast is the right position, referring to the Yin and Yang that are seen. When Jueyin is above, Shaoyang is below, with the left position being Yangming and the right position being Taiyin. When Jueyin spirals downwards to the right and Shaoyin is above, Yangming is below, with the left position being Taiyang and the right position being Shaoyang. This rotation aligns with the heavenly authority. Facing south, its position is determined; what it observes, refers to the position of the earth, which is in the north while facing south. Its left and right are designated as follows: northeast is the left position, northwest is the right position, referring to the Yin and Yang that are seen. From the heights and depths of all things in heaven and earth, this discussion focuses solely on the heavenly rightward-spiraling energy.[466p]
The upper and lower realms encounter each other, and cold and heat come close together; when the qi interacts harmoniously, there is balance, but when it does not, there is illness. This refers to the celestial forces circling the geographical locations, where the qi of the heavens and the qi of the earth encounter each other. When similar types of qi meet, they promote harmony; when different types meet, they lead to illness. Even when the qi is of the same type, if they meet improperly—for example, when the ministerial fire confronts the sovereign fire—there is also illness due to improper positioning.

The text later states that when the minister is in the position of the sovereign, it is harmony; when the sovereign is in the position of the minister, it is discord. Discord brings about illnesses that strike swiftly and closely. What is the relationship between movement and stillness? The Emperor states that heaven moves and can approach the earth, while the earth is still and cannot approach heaven, creating difficulties in the interplay of cold and heat.

Qi Bo replies that the rightward movement is the upper, while the leftward movement is the lower, indicating that heaven is always above, descending from the southeast, and circling back to approach the earth. The earth, remaining below, rises from the northeast and follows the positions of wood, earth, metal, and water in their clear logic, cycling to approach heaven while all things move downward. Thus, the left and right movements interact, each encompassing the cycle of heaven, and when patterns exceed, they reciprocally converge.

However, the rightward movement of heaven corresponds to the rightward movements attributed to calendars and realities, yet all function similarly to the leftward movements of the earth which rise in the east and descend in the west. The earth responds through stillness, and this indicates the challenges relating to the leftward perspective that the Emperor addresses.[467p]
Qibo replied regarding the nature of heaven and earth. Although movement and stillness are different, their utility and transformation manifest: on earth, the five elements flourish and generate forms that operate internally; in the heavens, the seven celestial bodies weave through the void and align with the vital energies of heaven, moving externally. The forms and vital energies follow each other in motion, akin to the relationship between roots and branches, unified in essence and not distinct. Therefore, by merely observing the appearance of the seven celestial bodies, even from afar, their movements can be understood.

From the mutual interactions of above and below, this discourse pertains to the clockwise motion of heaven and the counterclockwise motion of earth. As for whether earth is below, the Emperor states that the celestial phenomena revolve while turning below the earth, and since earth occupies the upper position, the current view of 'below' is affirmed. If the leftward motion is regarded as the downward movement of earth, can it not also be considered as below? Qibo clarifies that earth is beneath humans, situated within the vast emptiness, thus revealing the meaning of up and down.

In terms of their respective domains, the director of heaven, associated with the vital energy of springs, is considered above, while the five elements associated with earth are deemed below.[468p]
According to its position, the one who governs heaven is above, while the one at the spring is below, and the five elements of the earth are in the middle. Qi Bo speaks according to his association, hence he says that the lower one moves to the left. The emperor speaks according to the position, so it is difficult to say that the left movement of the earth is not downward. The term "Feng" means to attach. The earth is situated in the great void; where does it attach and not fall? It is supported by the great atmosphere. This refers to the six seasons of wind, cold, heat, dampness, dryness, and fire, as the great atmosphere rotates externally, allowing the earth to hold and influence its dry, moist, and solid states to interpenetrate its body. Thus, as it enters, cold and wind are below, with wind in the east and cold in the north; dryness and heat are above, with dryness in the west and heat in the south; humidity is in the middle, centered. Before fire enters, it is above the humidity; after it enters, it is below the humidity, moving up and down between them. The essence of the earth as lower continues from this point, originating from the heavens. "Hao" refers to the examination and observation. It discusses the atmospheric energies of heaven and earth, as well as the process of victory and recovery, which coordinates six positions, making it challenging to diagnose. We can only inquire about the energy favoring one position, thus allowing us to follow its location and expect it in the range of inches left and right.[469p]
In terms of the laws of periods, where yang is located, its pulse responds; where yin is located, its pulse does not respond. Therefore, in the year of northern governance, the people's energy faces north, with the inch to the north and the foot to the south. The energy on the left side of the earth is on the right inch, and the energy on the right side is on the left inch. The energy on the left side of heaven is on the left foot, and the energy on the right side is on the right foot. Thus, when Shao Yin is at the spring, the left is Tai Yin and the right is Jue Yin, and both inches do not respond. When Jue Yin is at the spring, the left is Shao Yin, and the right inch does not respond. When Tai Yin is at the spring, the right is Shao Yin, and the left inch does not respond. When Shao Yin governs the heavens, the left is Tai Yin, the right is Jue Yin, and both feet do not respond. When Jue Yin governs the heavens, the left is Shao Yin, and the left foot does not respond. When Tai Yin governs the heavens, the right is Shao Yin, and the right foot does not respond either. In the year of southern governance, the people's energy faces south, with the inch to the south and the foot to the north. The energy on the left side of heaven is on the right inch, and the energy on the right side is on the left inch. The energy on the left side of the earth is on the left foot, and the energy on the right side is on the right foot. Therefore, when Shao Yin governs the heavens, the left is Tai Yin, the right is Jue Yin, and both inches do not respond.[470p]
When Jueyin governs the heavens, then Shaoyin is to the left and does not correspond on the right. When Taiyin governs the heavens, then Shaoyin is to the right and does not correspond on the left. When Shaoyin is at the spring, then Taiyin is on the left, Jueyin is on the right, and neither corresponds at both feet. When Jueyin is at the spring, then Shaoyin is on the left, and the left foot does not correspond. When Taiyin is at the spring, then Shaoyin is on the right, and the right foot does not correspond. Following its energy, those in harmony find yin and yang correspond to their respective foot positions. Against its energy, there are illnesses, wherein yin and yang may not correspond to their positions, or may alternate positions, or may lose their positions, or have feet reversed, or yin and yang may intersect. Not corresponding to their positions means that yin and yang do not align correctly with their requisite foot positions. Alternating positions means that both yin and yang have shifted one position. For example, if in the southern governance, Shaoyin governs the heavens, then yin is all at the foot, and yang is all at the position. If all shift left, yin moves left and does not correspond on the left, and yang moves right and corresponds on the right. If all shift right, yin moves right and does not correspond on the right, and yang moves left and corresponds on the left, and so forth. Losing their positions means that both the original and alternate positions have lost their correspondence and are not apparent.[471p]
If the yin is lost in governance, then both the inch and the foot lose their yin; if the yang is lost in governance, then both the inch and the foot lose their yang. It is not like moving in succession to be opposite and intersecting in other positions. The reversal of the inch and the foot refers to a situation where, under the governance of slight yin in the north, yang is at the inch and yin is at the foot, yet yang is perceived at the foot while yin is perceived at the inch. The intersection of yin and yang describes a situation where, under the governance of slight yin in the north, yang is on the left and yin is on the right, but yang is perceived on the right while yin is perceived on the left.

As for cold, heat, dryness, dampness, wind, and fire, how do they interact with humans? In relation to all things, how does life and transformation occur? This pertains to the great rotating atmosphere outside of heaven, which enters the earth, giving life and transformation to beings. How does this affect the human organs and form, and how does it relate to the life and transformation of all things?

The wind that arises in the east is the wind from the great atmosphere, residing in the eastern part of the earth, and is the beginning of generation. From the wind, trees, sourness, liver, tendons, and heart are generated. All things relating to the nature, use, virtue, transformation, and governance of the east are fundamentally based on the wind, which corresponds to the liver energy within humans.[472p]
Therefore, the liver resides on the left, symbolizing the emergence of wind from the east, with tendons representing its bending and stretching, resembling the movement of the wind. The southern region generates heat, being the source of the six seasonal heats from heaven located in the south, at the center of the earth, indicative of the beginning of growth. From this heat arises bitterness in the heart, blood, and spleen. All things in the southern nature, such as virtue, transformative governance, and edicts, derive from heat, resonating with the human spirit and emotions. Therefore, the heart is situated at the front, symbolizing the heat that arises in the south, while blood represents the spirit of humanity, likening to the brilliance of fire.

The central region produces earth; the six seasonal dampness from heaven is present in the center of the earth, marking the commencement of transformation. From this dampness arises sweetness in the spleen, flesh, and lungs. All things in the central nature, such as virtue, transformative governance, and edicts, stem from dampness, resonating with the human spleen energy. Therefore, the spleen is located in the abdomen, symbolizing the dampness that arises from the center, while flesh fills the body, likening to the fullness of the vast earth.

The western region generates dryness; the six seasonal dryness from heaven resides in the west, central to the earth, marking the start of harvest. From this dryness arises metal, bitterness, lungs, skin, and kidneys. All things in the western nature, such as virtue, transformative governance, and edicts, emerge from dryness, resonating with the human lung energy.[473p]
Therefore, the lungs are located on the right, and dryness originates in the west. The skin and hair are dry on the body, reflecting the dryness of the superficial qi. The cold that arises from the north has six entrances; cold resides within the northern earth, marking the beginning of concealed growth, producing ice and affecting the kidneys, bones, and liver. All aspects of northern nature, including virtues and governance, are based on cold, which internally aligns with the essence of the kidneys in people. Thus, the kidneys are positioned at the back, symbolizing the cold that arises in the north. Bones represent the hundred body parts and symbolize the hardness of cold. The five qi stand separately, each with its precedence; if not positioned rightly, they become disruptive, while if in their rightful place, they are right. This refers to the qi of the five directions, each governing a specific set of regulations. The five qi are established, and their regulations have their own priorities. What prevails is that the rise of wind is not the spring regulation, heat is not the summer regulation, dampness is not the long summer regulation, dryness is not the autumn regulation, and cold is not the winter regulation; all of these are considerations that become disruptive when not in their rightful position.[474p]
Wind arises in spring, heat arises in summer, humidity arises in the late summer, dryness arises in autumn, and cold arises in winter; these are the rightful expressions of seasonal energy. When the elements are in harmony, disturbances are minor; when they are not in harmony, disturbances are severe. This means that when disturbances arise that are not in accordance with the proper seasonal alignments, their negative effects are exacerbated. The primary energies also refer to the atmospheres of the five directions, each governing the affairs of the year. When the energy of the year is abundant, it overcomes that which it can control and dominates that which it cannot. For example, if the energy of wood governing the year is excessive, it will check the energy of earth, reducing humidity, while it will dominate the energy of metal, resulting in strong winds. Conversely, if the energy is insufficient, it will be dominated and overwhelmed by that which it cannot control, while lightly dominating what it can. If the wood energy is insufficient, the metal energy will take control and dominate, leading to dryness, while the earth energy remains weak and is overwhelmed, resulting in an increase in humidity. Those who are dominated are affected by disturbances; if one is subdued and subjected to disturbances, the weak will not fear. If metal subdues wood and is then overwhelmed, wood's offspring, fire, will retaliate against its oppressor, and metal will then also be overwhelmed. If metal is overwhelmed by disturbances, the insufficient wood will be weak and will not resist, while the energy will rebound. How does the energy from heaven and earth reach this point? The essence of human energy originates from heaven.[475p]
The Great Treatise on the Principles of the Six Subtleties and the Changes of Luck

According to the Great Treatise on the Principles of the Six Subtleties, the Way of Heaven is like welcoming floating clouds; when one gazes into the deep abyss, the abyss can still be measured, but the limits of floating clouds remain unknown. Therefore, I will speak of its responsiveness to the seasons, discussing the yin and yang of Heaven, following the regularities of the celestial way. What is called "above" refers to those who move to the right. The rhythms of the heavenly way are divided into six sectors, with the cycles of prosperity and decline—three yin and three yang of Heaven—as they spiral outward. Each year experiences a cycle of prosperity and decline, and after six years, the complete cycle of six sectors is attained.

There are positions above and below, and there are records left and right, which indicate the positions of the flourishing and declining yin and yang each year. The "above and below" refer to the positions of the celestial overseer in the two springs. The "left and right" refer to the left and right realms of the celestial overseer, as well as the left and right realms of the springs, forming the four records. In general, for the yin and yang that spiral rightward in the heavens, those who preside over the positions of the celestial overseer witness the prosperity of heavenly governance when the three energies begin to manifest. Those positioned in the springs see the prosperity of the earthly energies when the final energies begin to manifest. Thus, within the upper and lower two positions, there are two sections of the flourishing and declining yin and yang.[476p]
The left side of the Heavenly Scribe is characterized by a strong presence of the Four Energies. The right side, however, is marked by a strong presence of the Two Energies. The left side of the Fountain, on the other hand, has a strong presence of the Initial Energy, while the right side also has a strong presence of the Two Energies. Thus, throughout the left and right sides, there are four cycles of Yin and Yang that demonstrate their rise and decline. Therefore, these six seasonal changes of Yin and Yang each experience a rise and fall annually, leading to a total of six.

In the Year of Geng Shen, the Lesser Yang comes to oversee the heavens, initiating the first cycle; on the right side of the Lesser Yang, in the Years of Mao and You, the Greater Yang comes to oversee the heavens, initiating the sixth cycle; on the right side of the Greater Yang, in the Years of Chen and Xu, the Sun comes to oversee the heavens, initiating the seventh cycle; on the right side of the Sun, in the Years of Si and Hai, the Absolute Yin comes to oversee the heavens, initiating the eighth cycle; on the right side of the Absolute Yin, in the Years of Zi and Wu, the Lesser Yin comes to oversee the heavens, initiating the ninth cycle; on the right side of the Lesser Yin, in the Years of Chou and Wei, the Greater Yin comes to oversee the heavens, initiating the tenth cycle.

The cycle is continuous, returning to the Lesser Yang. Thus, it is said that the sixth cycle of rise and decline of the energies exists. All these three Yin and three Yang energies are what we refer to as the markers of the Six Energies.[477p]
Those who face south and wait for it, as indicated by the right of the lesser yang before the bright, all stand facing south and await, thereby residing to the right in the west, passing through the east in a circular manner. Above the lesser yang, the fire energy governs; in the middle appears the jueyin. Above the yangming, the dry energy governs; in the middle appears the taiyin. Above the taiyang, the cold energy governs; in the middle appears the shaoyin. Above the jueyin, the wind energy governs; in the middle appears the lesser yang. Above the lesser yin, the heat energy governs; in the middle appears the taiyang. Above the taiyin, the moisture energy governs; in the middle appears the yangming. The fire, dryness, wind, cold, heat, and moisture are the governing energies—these are what is referred to as the essence of the six energies. The energies seen in the middle refer to the central energies of the six. If we speak of the prior six energies in terms of their signs, the essence is at the top, the signs are at the bottom, and the central energies are in between the essence and the signs. Thus it is said to be beneath the essence, with manifestations beneath that and the signs of energies following. The central energy, consisting of three yin and three yang, corresponds to the harmonious coupling of couples, and the organs, bowels, and meridians of a person all respond to this.[478p]
Therefore, in the concept of Shao Yang, within it is found Jue Yin, and in the concept of Jue Yin, within it is found Shao Yang. They mutually safeguard each other as the central qi. Thus, in humans, the Gallbladder and San Jiao channels of Shao Yang also connect with the Liver and Pericardium, while the Liver and Pericardium channels of Jue Yin also connect with the Gallbladder and San Jiao, creating mutual interactions.

In the concept of Yang Ming, within it is found Tai Yin, and in the concept of Tai Yin, within it is found Yang Ming. They mutually safeguard each other as the central qi. Thus, in humans, the Stomach and Large Intestine channels of Yang Ming also connect with the Spleen and Lungs, while the Spleen and Lung channels of Tai Yin also connect with the Stomach and Large Intestine, creating mutual interactions.

In the concept of Tai Yang, within it is found Shao Yin, and in the concept of Shao Yin, within it is found Tai Yang. They mutually safeguard each other as the central qi. Thus, in humans, the Bladder and Small Intestine channels of Tai Yang also connect with the Kidney and Heart, while the Kidney and Heart channels of Shao Yin also connect with the Bladder and Small Intestine, creating mutual interactions.

For different manifestations of distinct qi, this refers to the two energies of Tai Yang and Shao Yin. Above Tai Yang, cold qi is controlled, leading to the manifestation of Yang being primarily cold. In this way, the condition of Tai Yang becomes cold while the internal state is warm, resulting in cold and warm differing manifestations. Above Shao Yin, hot qi is controlled, leading to the manifestation of Yin being primarily hot. In this manner, the condition of Shao Yin becomes hot while the internal state is cold, resulting in hot and cold differing manifestations.[479p]
As for the pulse responding to illness, it is like a sweet melon with a bitter stem, green onion with white leaves, ginseng nourishing while reed purges, and ephedra inducing sweat while its root stops sweat—these are all differing manifestations of the essence of the Taiyang and Shaoyin. There are occurrences of arrival, occurrences that do not arrive, and occurrences that arrive excessively. This refers to the cyclical arrival of yin and yang, responding to the seasons; when the essence transforms accordingly, it is termed arrival, and such arrival is harmonious. If the essence transforms but does not arrive, it is termed arrival but not arriving, indicating that the cyclical essence is insufficient. If the season has not arrived but the essence transforms beforehand, it is termed not arrived yet arriving. Therefore, the transformation of the essence that responds to the season is regarded as harmonious, while what arrives without having reached the season is considered contrary; the contrary leads to the emergence of changes, and with changes, illness arises. Things arise in accordance with their nature, and the essence and pulse respond—this reflects the principle of being harmonious. The classic text mentions that what the Jueyin reaches gives rise to wind-like phenomena, which is the response of things to their nature. When the Jueyin arrives, its pulse is string-like, which is the response of the essence and pulse.[480p]
According to the emperor's inquiry about the geographical correspondence of the six solar terms, it pertains to the essence of the seasonal phases. Thus, it is discussed in relation to the yin and yang of the earth, the usual practices of geography, with the term "down" referring to the movement to the left. The geographical response to the six solar terms is divided into six steps, which regulate the seasons in accordance with the six solar positions outside of heaven.

On the right of bright clarity, the position of the royal fire is located at the point of sunrise, to the right of the earth at the eastern-southeastern direction and aligning with spring equinox. After the point associated with the hare, there lies the position of royal fire. Moving right again by one step, the position of associated fire is governed by the southern air, where the fire rules and regulates the energies around the summer solstice. This corresponds with the governance from heaven, presiding over the years of the earth element.

Stepping forward once more, the position of earth governs the energies coming from the southwestern air, with earth ruling and regulating the four energies prior to the autumn equinox. This aligns with the plentiful atmosphere in the left quarters, presiding over the years of the wood element.

Again moving a step further, the position of metal governs the energies from the northwestern air, with metal ruling and regulating the five energies after the autumn equinox. This corresponds to the energies that surround the right of the spring, presiding over the years of the wood element as well.[481p]
After taking another step, the water energy is governed by the earthly energy reaching the northern direction. The water level issues commands, regulating the energy before and after the winter solstice to correspond with the energy dispersed in the spring. Its operation is subordinate to the years of Bing and Xin, corresponding to the political years of the celestial authority.

After taking another step, the wood energy is governed by the earthly energy reaching the northeast. The wood level issues commands, regulating the energy at the beginning of the spring equinox to correspond with the flourishing energy on the left side of the spring. Its operation is subordinate to the years of Ding and Ren, corresponding to the political years of the celestial authority.

After taking another step, the sovereign fire is governed by the earthly energy reaching the southeast. The sovereign fire level issues commands, regulating the energy after the spring equinox to correspond with the flourishing energy on the right side of the celestial authority. Its operation lasts throughout the year without a predominant year.

In all these six steps and regulations, each energy of its respective direction enters China. Thus, when the wood energy in the east issues commands, the spring energy moves westward, while all of China experiences the warmth of the east, coinciding with the energy found on the left side of the spring. When the sovereign energy in the southern direction issues commands, the summer energy moves northward, while all of China experiences the heat of the south, corresponding to the energy found on the right side of the celestial authority.[482p]
When the metal in the west governs, the autumn qi travels east, and all of China receives the cool qi of the west, associated with the atmosphere in the left quadrant of the celestial governance. When the water in the north governs, the winter qi travels south, and all of China receives the cold qi of the north, associated with the atmosphere in the right quadrant of the spring.

Below the six qi, each type is supported by the qi it governs, based on the five elements. Each pole gives rise to one phase, and they cycle through interdependently without any interruption.

Under the influence of fire, the water qi supports it. When the summer fire reaches its peak, it leads to the emergence of water, gradually transforming until it arrives at winter.

Under the level of water, the earth qi supports it. When winter's water reaches its peak, it gives rise to the earth, gradually transforming until it arrives at late summer.

Under the level of earth, the wood qi supports it. When the long summer earth reaches its peak, it gives rise to the wood, gradually transforming until it arrives at spring.

Under the level of wood, the metal qi supports it. When spring's wood reaches its peak, it gives rise to the metal, gradually transforming until it arrives at autumn.

Under the level of metal, the fire qi supports it. When autumn's metal reaches its peak, it leads to the emergence of fire, gradually transforming until it arrives at summer.

Under the influence of the sovereign fire, the yin essence supports it. When the summer sovereign fire reaches its peak, the yin essence supports it, gradually transforming until it arrives at winter.[483p]
Its meaning, akin to the views of the Yin-Yang school regarding water originating from noon and metal from the rabbit, is largely similar, as they all circulate and are inherited to form the foundation. "Kang" represents excess. Excess leads to harm; accepting (or bearing) leads to control, and control promotes transformation. Externally, this expresses prosperity and decline. Harm leads to chaos, and significant disorders in transformation indicate that the energy of six and five has reached extremes and will certainly cause harm. Accepting energy generates from below and controls it to prevent excess. Thus, control comes from subtle transformation, while acceptance externally presents prosperity. Extremes lead to decline from the outside. The cycle of transformation indicates that harm produces chaos and significant illness arises. Prosperity and decline, when not in their proper places, become evil; in their proper places, they become righteous. This connects back to the previous discussion that control leads to transformation, which externally reflects prosperity and decline. Control resists excess and allows transformation of prosperity. Only when the year's energy is harmonious can its transformations proceed gradually and in sequence.[484p]
From the subtle to the manifest, all must align correctly within the six positions. If the seasonal energies are excessive or deficient, their transformations will be disordered, sometimes causing equality to be surmounted or the precarious to triumph. Hence, transformations might blend and yield a partial state, not by virtue of their position. Alternatively, transformations might restore supremacy leading to completeness, also not due to their position.

When wood influences the Rabbit, fire influences the Horse, earth corresponds to the four seasons, metal governs the West, and water influences the Rat, this is referred to as the balance of yearly seasonal energies. It indicates that in these eight years, the seasonal energies harmonize with the five movements, creating a balance where their flourish and decline follow a proper sequence aligned with the six positions. Conversely, if other years do not align with the movements, the energies will be excessive or deficient, resulting in disorder in their flourish and decline, also not by virtue of their position.

Some say that Wang's commentary explains that water represents the acceptance of fire below; when it is excessively hot, it overflows like water. When earth accepts water below, extreme cold makes ice solid like earth. Wind accepting earth below signifies rain driven by strong winds. Metal accepting wind below shows that the wind stirs the air, drying all things. Fire accepting metal below represents fire refining metal. Lin's rectifications further illustrate that wood can sprout and break. Additionally, he verifies this with phrases like "the arrival of the extreme Yin brings tumultuous rage and great coolness."[485p]
In Hejian, it is stated that harm comes from excessively rising, leading to the establishment of the principles of the six characters. Treatises and arguments from both schools refer to the six positions below and their corresponding energies, which create phenomena both in day and night. Now, you uniquely argue that this pertains to the cyclical changes of the four seasons, asserting that there must be a coherent explanation that can validate the gains and losses, right and wrong.

It is said: The classics indicate that through regulation below, generation and transformation occur, and external manifestations of prosperity and decline are listed. When prosperity and decline align with their positions, it is correct; when not, it is erroneous. By discussing the meaning of below, one can tender details adequately, sufficient to verify gains and losses, right and wrong.

Now, the classics say: To the right of the ruler's fire, retreat one step, the fire of the official governs it, while the water energy supports it; retreating another step, the earth energy governs it, while the wood energy supports it; retreating yet another step, the metal energy governs it, while the fire energy supports it; retreating once more, the water energy governs it, while the earth energy supports it; retreat one more step, the wood energy governs it, while the metal energy supports it; retreating yet again, the ruler's fire governs it, while the yin essence supports it. This passage pertains to the prosperity and decline in the transformation of energies below, signifying that when they are in their proper positions, it is aligned with the correct principles.[486p]
The rise and fall of things follow a sequence without chaos. During prosperity, one should take the correct position in governance; during decline, one should inherit the proper position. Each should adhere to the correct principle of its own phase: warmth belongs to spring, heat to summer, coolness to autumn, and cold to winter. When the climate is balanced, it allows for growth and storage. This is the fundamental principle of the classics, discussing the cyclical nature of the four seasons and the proper alignment of transformations.

Wang's commentary explains the idea of inheriting the underlying principles, while Lin mentions the destruction and bending of wood, representing the violent coolness brought on by the influence of the Extreme Yin. This reflects the fluctuations of growth and decline; when out of place, it leads to disorder. The decline does not follow a sequence, resulting in the violent destruction of wood and extreme anger, which combines and acts in harmony with the destructive qualities of metal, thus disrupting the natural order of growth and decline.

The effects of Extreme Yin, causing violent anger and great coolness, arise from the extreme wood, which leads to chaos and violence. The metal, associated with coolness, retaliates, causing growth and decline to stray far from their rightful positions. Consequently, warmth does not represent spring, heat does not represent summer, coolness does not represent autumn, and cold does not represent winter, leading to various ailments in humans.

This highlights the mistakes of Wang and Lin, who misused the chaotic nature of dawn and dusk as signs of disorder instead of adhering to the proper alignment prescribed in the classics. However, the disruption of proper alignment and the resulting chaos also possess unique characteristics of excessive or insufficient states. Currently, the arguments presented by Hejian, referencing Wang and Lin, emphasize how extremes can harm the natural balance, clarifying the significance of changing energies.[487p]
It is said that wood resembles metal at its extreme; metal resembles fire at its extreme; fire resembles water at its extreme; water resembles earth at its extreme; and earth resembles wood at its extreme. All these transformations are a result of the excess leading to a resemblance to the overcoming of its own nature. It is also said that when regulated too much, these transformations become mere illusions. It is stated that the regulation of these transformations should focus on mitigating the excess energy, which is the root of the disorder, and one should not mistakenly treat the accompanying transformation.

Scholars speak of the transformations of the five energies as they become abundant, while those that are insufficient have not yet manifested. According to the Great Treatise on Governance of the Five Constants, if wood is insufficient, it is termed "degenerated harmony"; the nature of this is soft and restrained; its taste is sour and pungent; its color is pale white; its sound is the horn and the shang. If fire is insufficient, it is termed "repressed illumination"; its nature is marked by evident changes and transformations; its taste is bitter and salty; its color is bright red; its sound is the zheng and the feather. If earth is insufficient, it is termed "low surveillance"; its nature results in sores and pus, and the splitting of abscesses; its taste is sour and sweet; its color is yellowish-green; its sound is the gong and the horn. If metal is insufficient, it is termed "subsequent transformation"; its nature results in intense sounds and confusion; its taste is bitter and pungent; its color is white and red; its sound is the shang and zheng. If water is insufficient, it is termed "dried flow"; its nature is characterized by hardness and stillness; its taste is sweet and salty; its color is dark; its sound is the feather and the low harmony.[488p]
What is referred to as soft, oblique, and restrained? Softness, according to Wang, means to shorten. When the branches of wood extend but do not reach their utmost, they are then shortened by metal, which transforms and compensates for them, achieving mastery despite being out of position. Oblique refers to the bending and twisting of the limbs. Restraint denotes the strength of tendons and vessels. Wood is bent and restrained as it is influenced by the shortening of metal. Slowness indicates the relaxation of tendons and vessels. When metal overcomes wood, earth diminishes in fear; thus, earth transforms and relaxes into its gaps, while those who are restrained restrain themselves, and those who are slow are slow themselves. Sour, bitter, white, and blue pungents are all instances of wood failing to reach its utmost; metal compensates for them despite being out of position. Fuxing, what is called the manifestation of change? Manifestation refers to the clarity and brightness of fire. Concealment refers to the hidden depths of water. Change indicates that fire does not reach water but partially manifests or conceals; change is not constant. The bitter and salty elements, as well as the original essence, are cases where fire fails to reach its utmost, with water compensating despite being out of position. The principle of dips and heights refers to the emergence and rupture of sores and swellings. Sores and swellings are caused by earth’s obstruction. Emergence and rupture pertain to the opening and splitting of wood.[489p]
The earth becomes obstructed and develops ulcers and swelling; when wood simultaneously transforms and emerges, it causes surging and bursting through the obstruction. The sour, sweet, and pale colors indicate that the earth is inadequate, leading to premature demise, while wood takes on a role it shouldn't and transforms into something else. From the change, the so-called "clang, obstruct, dizzy, and faint" arises. The "clang" refers to the sound of metal transforming, leading to coughing. "Obstruct" means to hold back breath and suppress coughs. When metal in the lungs is excessive, the desire for air expands, causing wheezing; when metal is deficient, there is a desire to retain breath and suppress it. The "clang" is coughing. "Dizzy" refers to confusion. "Faint" means to be opposite or in reverse. When metal transforms into clang without deficiency, fire takes over. The dizzying, faint, and reverse energy rises from the emptiness of suppression. The bitter, spicy, white, and red components indicate that metal is deficient, leading to premature demise, while fire assumes a role it shouldn't and transforms. The term "dried-up flow," known as "stubborn stoppage," describes rigidity and stillness. When water is scarce, it becomes firm and dry, and earth enforces this stillness. The sweet and salty elements, pale and primordial, indicate that water is insufficient, leading to premature demise, while earth takes on a role it shouldn't and transforms. All of this represents transformations resulting from depleted energy; thus, the treatment should focus on replenishing this deficiency, rather than using purging methods appropriate for abundant energy transformations.[490p]
In contemporary Hejian, it is said that governing involves both treatment and transformation. However, should one not alleviate the extreme excesses of the root energy? The transformations that are included stem from a deficiency of the root energy, which can be overcome by what is received. Without intervention, the root energy will further decline, and the received energy will become overpowering. Thus, when one speaks of transformation as similar to an empty appearance, can one not say it should not be addressed? This is where Hejian misinterprets, believing that both excessive and insufficient transformations are overly excessive.

It is said that the Wang, Lin, and Hejian clans have lost the true intent of the classics and have already received mandates in this regard. Nevertheless, the six levels of the received energy, which maintain the proper transformation, those that indicate the changes of overcoming variation, and those that elaborate on harmony and discord, are still worthy of exploration, and can be verified through the classic principles.

It is said that true sincerity without end is the essence of the Dao. Yin, Yang, and the Five Elements flow through heaven and earth, with one extreme giving rise to another and endlessly supporting each other, in a cycle that is boundless; this is the essence of the Dao. Therefore, with regard to their mutual support, when spoken of in terms of Yin and Yang, during the winter solstice, the extreme of Yin leads to the emergence of Yang, and during the summer solstice, the extreme of Yang leads to the emergence of Yin. When discussed in terms of the Five Elements, the Five Elements themselves correspond to the mutual support of Yin and Yang, each having its own distinction between fullness and youth. Thus, fire is the fullness of Yang, water the fullness of Yin, wood the youth of Yang, metal the youth of Yin, and earth bears Yin while embracing Yang as the energizing force.[491p]
In the relationship of yin and yang, during the winter solstice, yin reaches its extreme and yang begins to emerge; this starts in the long summer, where the energy of the earth is at its peak. In spring, the young wood gives rise to yang, then in autumn, the young metal reaches its extreme yin. In turn, the flourishing fire brings forth yang, culminating in winter. The abundance of water signifies extreme yin, with the earth's energy nurturing it.

During the summer solstice, yang reaches its peak and yin is generated, starting in spring, where the young wood is at its extreme yang. Then, in summer, the young metal reaches its extreme yin, and in the thriving summer, the flourishing fire symbolizes the peak of yang. Yin essence begins to emerge, culminating in summer, where the intense fire's peak leads to the emergence of yin, completing a yearly cycle.

In the context of the Five Elements, interactions occur as follows: yang fire is engaged with the essence of yin water beneath it; beneath the water is the earth's energy, marking the first year. Below the earth is the energy of wood, signifying the second year. Below the wood is the energy of metal, and beneath the metal is the energy of fire, completing a cycle of three years and then repeating.[492p]
Thus, the blending of yin and yang, the division into the five elements, and their constant interdependence and endless cycles arise from the essence of mutual support, which is sincere and ceaseless. The sage observes the river and states, "Those who flow like this do not cease day or night," which rightly refers to this essence of sincere continuity. However, when discussing mutual support as a structure, it is indeed this sincere and ceaseless nature that attaches itself without change or deviation. When speaking of its flow in application, it manifests at the extremes of balance; those who properly assume their positions correspond to the constant of right transformation and harmony, while those who do not assume their proper positions correspond to the chaotic transformations resulting from excess or deficiency. The constant is a gradual progression, reflecting the cyclical changes of the four seasons; the transformations may either unleash overwhelming might, reaching extremes in improper positions or fall short of required strength, leading to deficiencies in those positions. Thus, what is supported follows the maximum limitset below, while transgressing ranks to change its fundamental energy, causing abrupt transformations at dawn and dusk. Hence, a partial change occurs when fundamental energy is partially diminished, descending to a half-strong state and resulting in a moderate transformation relative to improper positioning. A complete change occurs when fundamental energy is entirely depleted, descending to a fully thriving state leading to an overwhelming return to improper positioning.[493p]
Harmony and change signify virtue and the governance of decrees, while discord and change lead to disaster and injury. In what is known as the occurrence of phenomena, such changes that resonate, shake, and uproot, are excessive transformations. When timber cannot withstand virtue, it leads to retraction and restoration, which represents an excessive recovery. In the context of harmony, behaviors that are soft, restrained, and slow reflect inadequate transformations. Conditions of strictness, scorching heat, and boiling over represent the triumph of virtue over governance. When water yields hail and snow, and wood results in destruction and breakage, these signify disasters and injuries caused by dual transformations. The birth of the Yin results in fierce winds and great chills, while the arrival of the Shao Yin leads to severe warmth and cold; these too indicate the victory of disasters and injuries. Thus, the essence is of utmost sincerity and perpetual motion, yet the extremes and inheritances of change and discord are not consistent. As a result, the responses observed will vary, showing correct transformations, dual transformations, triumphs, and the different aspects of minor and major disasters and auspices. The Wang and Lin families fail to differentiate changes, interpreting transformation as merely altering the atmosphere; the Hejian school does not distinguish between emptiness and reality, interpreting dual transformations as mere abundance; both are errors in understanding.[494p]
The Emperor asked about the paths and the use of seasons. Thus, it is said that the yin and yang of heaven and earth alternate and transform, as movement and stillness invoke one another, and the upper and lower realms correspond with each other; this is the essence of the intermingling of yin and yang.

The "paths" refer to the six steps of the earth mentioned in the previous text. Sixty degrees have odd characteristics; the six steps of the earth revolve around the heavens in a complete circle of three hundred sixty-five degrees, which is the number of days in a year. Each step is made up of sixty degrees with odd peculiarities. Thus, one day corresponds to one degree, with sixty days equating to eighty-seven and a half divisions, signifying one step. In a year, without exceeding a day, twenty-four steps accumulate, and every four years, the remaining oddities sum up to a hundred divisions, resulting in an additional day to conclude the year, termed a cycle.

The six airs responding to the changes of the five elements indicate a correlation with the previous text regarding the celestial cycles and the geographical positions of the six solar terms. Therefore, the Emperor inquired further. The six airs of heaven—wind, heat, moisture, fire, dryness, and cold—correspond to the five elements of the earth, namely wood, fire, earth, metal, and water, enforcing their regulation throughout the year. How do we seek the transformation of their intermingling energies? "Position," here, refers to the path or step. Each position has its beginning and end, determining the potency of the six airs of heaven in accordance with the regulatory influences of the five elements on earth—all occurring within the same step, while their timing exhibits its own commencement and conclusion.[495p]
There are initial and middle stages of Qi. Each step marks the fullness of the beginning and ending of Qi, divided into front and back. The first half of a step represents the initial Qi, associated with the rising of terrestrial Qi, while the second half represents the final Qi, which relates to the descending of celestial Qi. The Qi of heaven and earth interacts at the terminal points, and the initial and middle Qis differ; thus, the methods of seeking them are also different. The heavenly Qi starts at Jia, and the earthly Qi starts at Zi, with methods of seeking positions linked to their beginnings and endings. The Qi of heaven and earth should be sought from the start of the Jia-Zi year. By carefully observing the time of their beginnings and endings, one can anticipate the arrival of the climatic conditions. If the six Qis begin and end early or late within a year, this indicates the distinction in the beginnings and endings of the two Qis of heaven and earth, governed by step intervals. Within these intervals, there are six steps each year, and for each step, the beginning and ending of the Qi of heaven and earth each govern for sixty days and eighty-seven and a half kè. Annually, each beginning and ending of Qi governing lasts for three hundred sixty-five days and twenty-five kè. Now the Emperor first inquires about the Qi of the annual six steps, concerning the timing of their beginnings and endings and whether they are early or late.[496p]
In the year of Jiazhi, the beginning occurs at a moment past the water, concluding at seven and a half eighty-sevenths. The year of Jiazhi has six phases. The heavenly qi is under the control of Shaoyin, with Taiyin on the left and Jueyin on the right; Yangming is at the spring, with Taiyang on the left and Shaoyang on the right, each flourishing in its respective phase, responding to one another. The earthly qi corresponds to its decree. Now, at the beginning qi, the cold qi of Taiyang is strong in the left spring, corresponding to the northeastern wood qi’s decree, and shares the mastery of the sixty days before the vernal equinox at seven and a half eighty-sevenths, characterized by the early and late climates.

The second qi begins at six minutes past eighty-seven, concluding at seventy-five. The control of the heavens has Jueyin’s wind qi strong on the right, corresponding to the southeastern fire qi’s decree, sharing the mastery of the sixty days after the vernal equinox at seven and a half eighty-sevenths, characterized by the early and late climates.

The third qi begins at seventy-six and concludes at sixty-two and a half. The control of the heavens is under Shaoyin, where the warm administration is spread out, corresponding to the southern fire qi’s decree, sharing the mastery of the sixty days before and after the summer solstice at seven and a half eighty-sevenths, characterized by the early and late climates.[497p]
The energy of the Four begins at 62 divisions and 6 minutes and ends at 50 divisions; this corresponds to a strong moisture in the left space of heaven, aligned with the dominant earthy energy of the southwest, and is equally governed by the 60 days before the autumn equinox, spanning 87 and a half divisions, marking the early and late phases. The energy of the Five starts at 51 divisions and ends at 37 and a half divisions, prevalent in the right space of the spring where fire energy is abundant. This corresponds to the dominant metal energy of the northwest and similarly governs the 60 days after the autumn equinox, also spanning 87 and a half divisions, marking the early and late phases. The energy of the End begins at 37 divisions and 6 minutes and ends at 25 divisions, filled with dry energy in the sunlight of the spring. This corresponds to the dominant water energy of the northern direction and similarly governs the 60 days around the winter solstice, also spanning 87 and a half divisions, marking the early and late phases. The energy of heaven and earth operates through six phases within the year of Jiazi, marking the early and late phases, with similar applications in subsequent years. The seasonal markers are questions posed by the emperor regarding the seasonal indicators. The governance of heaven and earth within a single year, with the weather overseen by the heavens above, collectively governs the year. The energy of the earth operates in the center, forming a pair with it, combining the two energies’ indicators to begin and end within a single year. The sun travels through a year while also completing a full cycle of the heavens.[498p]
The Qi begins from a moment: in the year of Jiazi, the celestial aspect is governed by the Lesser Yin's warm Qi, within the seasonal cycle of the Yangming dryness, and during the middle of the Earth, the Qi of the Great Palace is present, marking the beginning of management for that year. When the sun travels through the twenty-six markers, in the year of Yichou, the celestial aspect is governed by the Taiyin's damp Qi, within the seasonal cycle of the Yangming dryness, and during the middle of the Earth, the Qi of the Lesser Shang is present, marking the beginning of management for that year. When the sun travels through the fifty-one markers, in the year of Bingyin, the celestial aspect is governed by the Lesser Yang's fire Qi, within the seasonal cycle of the Jueyin's wind Qi, and during the middle of the Earth, the Qi of the Great Feather water is present, marking the beginning of management for that year. When the sun travels through the seventy-six markers, in the year of Dingmao, the celestial aspect is governed by the Yangming dryness, within the seasonal cycle of the Lesser Yin's warm Qi, and during the middle of the Earth, the Qi of the Lesser Horn wood is present, marking the beginning of management for that year. This is the essence of the Qi of Heaven and Earth; in the initial period of four years, the beginning and end conditions can be similarly extended to the remaining periods. The user looks to the previous year's beginnings and endings to seek the Qi of Heaven and Earth. To speak of Heaven seeks its foundation, to speak of Earth seeks its application, to speak of humans looks for the transition of years, speaking to the usage of the previous year's beginnings and endings. When seeking the weather of Heaven, one seeks the fundamental Qi of wind, cold, heat, dampness, dryness, and fire; the standards and the central Qi need not be sought.[499p]
To seek the energy of the earth is to seek the positions of wood, fire, earth, metal, and water; the energy below that does not need to be sought. To seek the energy of humanity is to seek the energy that should be seen in the interactions of qi; if it is not seen, it does not need to be sought. When discussing the energy at the start of the year of Jiazi, seeking the energy of heaven refers to the heat governed by the heavenly officials, the dryness of springs, and the cold adjacent to the springs. To seek the energy of the earth is to seek the earth of the central movement and the wood of the main division. To seek the energy of humanity is to seek the energy that should be seen in the interactions of qi. Whether it is hot, dry, cold, earthy, or watery, these five energies are constant; anything other than these five is a corrupt transformation of imbalance. The interactions of qi occur at the junction of the two energies of heaven and earth, with the human body serving as the boundary at the midpoint. Above this midpoint, the domain of the heavenly officials governs the energy of heaven, while below it, the domain of springs governs the energy of the earth.[500p]
The interplay of the two energies of heaven and earth occurs at the boundary of the celestial pivot, which is where human energy originates and where all things derive from. Hence, it is called the convergence of energies. This encompasses the cyclical phenomena of heaven and earth, an unchanging essence through the ages.

Initially, there are thirty degrees with anomalies; the central energy aligns with established principles, seeking energy that has initial and central methods. It is stated that each cycle lasts sixty days and consists of eighty-seven and a half divisions. The first thirty days with anomalies are regarded as initial energy, belonging to the yang of the month, where all energies below the celestial pivot rise. The latter thirty days with anomalies are considered central energy, belonging to the yin, where all energies above the celestial pivot descend.

Regarding the initial energies of the year of Jiazi, energies below the celestial pivot pertain to the dry energy of springs, cold energy in the left channel of the springs, earthy energy within the central realm, and wood energy in the main region, all of which rise. The energies above the celestial pivot relate to the descending hot energy of heaven.

Rising leads to descending, and descending signifies the flow on earth; conversely, descending leads to rising where the energies soar into heaven. Therefore, the high and the low summon each other, and rising and falling follow one another. From this intricate interplay and mingling of energies, the balance and transformation arise, creating shifts and recoveries in the convergence of energies.[501p]
The essence of heaven and earth is balanced and equal; therefore, between rising and falling, each maintains its boundary and responds to the constant transformations of the seasons. When there is abundance or scarcity, those that are abundant and similar in nature prevail; when they prevail, they exceed the established order of the seasons. Conversely, those that are scarce and similar in nature are disregarded; when they are disregarded, they become part of the energies outside the established seasonal order. The energies that come and prevail continually change, thus maintaining transformations and resurgence.

All of this reflects the rising and falling energies of heaven and earth, which fluctuate with time. Some say: in the phases of heaven’s yin and yang across the six seasons, the two phases presided over by heaven are specifically the springs, which govern the entire year. Why is it that the other four phases flourish only in their respective steps? It is because the two phases presided over by heaven occupy the center of heaven and earth. Their rising and falling are always balanced in the central region, thus governing the entire year. The other four phases are located in the four directions, with their rising and falling not centered; they merely govern the energies of the regions they occupy. The energy corresponding to spring moves westward, summer northward, autumn eastward, and winter southward, eventually returning to the central region to flourish. Hence, these four phases each flourish independently in their seasonal governance.

As for transformations and changes that occur beyond the established order, even without the influence of seasonal governance, they also circulate back into the central region.[502p]
It is said that the heavenly phenomena are ordered by the sequences of warm, humid, fiery, dry, and cold, with humidity preceding fire; the earthly phenomena are ordered by the elements of wood, fire, earth, metal, and water, with earth following fire. The presence of humidity and earth is one essence, yet their positional differences exist—why is this? It is because in the heavens, it is a matter of qi, thus they are ordered by the amount of the three yin and three yang energies; on the earth, it is a matter of forms, thus they are ordered by the generative sequences of the five elements. The ordering by the amount of qi starts with the lesser and gradually increases, beginning with the first yin, which is called Jue Yin (厥阴); the next is Shao Yin (少阴), which is the second yin; the last is Tai Yin (太阴), which is the third yin. The ordering of yang begins with Shao Yang (少阳), which is the first yang; the next is Yang Ming (阳明), which is the second yang, and then Tai Yang (太阳), which is the third yang. Thus, heavenly phenomena are ordered by the amounts of yin and yang, with humidity preceding fire. The ordering of forms generating each other begins and continues endlessly, thus the qi starts with wood, the initial qi; wood generates fire, hence the fire of the lord is the second qi, and the fire of the companion is the third qi; fire generates earth, hence earth is the fourth qi; earth generates metal, hence metal is the fifth qi; metal generates water, hence water is the final qi, which then regenerates wood. Thus, earthly phenomena are ordered by the generative relationships of the five elements, with earth following fire. Wang Tai Pu ordered Shao Yang after Tai Yang, while Chen Wu Ze ordered humid earth to generate companion fire, which can be said to not delve into the essence of the classics.[503p]
According to the correspondence of cold and heat, dryness and moisture, and the confrontation of wind and fire, if there are intervals, there should be no storage or transformation at the seasonal divisions. Here, it discusses the changes of yin and yang in heaven and earth. When cold and moisture correspond, and dryness and heat confront, is there any interval at the junction of these interactions?

The Emperor, following the previous discussion on the principles of the ascent and descent of heaven and earth, inquires about the interplay of cold, moisture, dryness, heat, wind, and fire, specifically whether there are gaps in their interactions of ascent and descent. Qi Bo responds, stating that qi has the ability to dominate and recover. He explains that when heaven and earth correspond, confront, or interact, the five elements experience fluctuations in abundance and scarcity. At the junction of ascent and descent, there is a constant struggle between strength and weakness, with no gaps in their interactions.[504p]
Therefore, the creation of its victories and reversals occurs at the intersections of ascent and descent, where there are virtues of harmony, clarity, warmth, cleanliness, and melancholy. There are transformations of life, flourishing, abundance, restraint, and tranquility. There are utilities of curvature and straightness, burning and melting, heights and depths, dispersion and nurturing. There are changes of destruction, heat, indulgence, desolation, and chilling. It is only through change that evil energy resides, leading to sickness and death in humans.

The Emperor asked what is meant by evil and why change is called evil. Qi Bo replied that the life of things derives from transformation, and the extremes of things come from change. The transformation of the two energies is like the oppositions of yin and yang, night and day; thus, the life of things comes from transformation while extremes derive from change. As such, transformation corresponds with the correct energy, while change is the source of evil energy, hence change is considered evil.

Qi has periods of circulation, and its uses vary in speed. The energies of change have cycles of return; the uses derived from these cycles also differ in pace. For instance, as the "Classic" states, spring has the harmonious emergence of chirping while autumn brings the refreshing governance of mist and dew, exemplifying the cyclical nature of transformative energy. Winter, with its harsh and desolate extremes, contrasts with summer's scorching heat and consuming changes, demonstrating the cyclic return of transformation. Furthermore, the reactions prompted by lesser yin leading to significant warmth or cold, and by greater yang leading to dispersive warmth, reveal instances where the cyclical uses occur with differing velocities.[505p]
All changes must involve the four aspects of slow and rapid, coming and going; these are foundational. Then, regarding proper winds and aberrant winds, they initially affect the weak. Success and failure depend on the conditions that fluctuate in the middle. In winter, one suffers from cold; in spring, one is bound to be ill from warmth; in spring, one is injured by wind; in summer, one is susceptible to diarrhea. This is akin to what Zhongjing referred to as latent energy and latent cold. The emperor asked about the slow and rapid, the coming and going, the wind's origination and transformation, hence the natural occurrence of winds due to the ebb and flow of qi. People perceive these winds as determinants of success and failure; hence, they fluctuate in their conditions, but do not align with the feelings they experience in that moment. Why is this? Qibo replied that success and failure, the states of being present or absent, arise from movement. When movement does not cease, then the meaning of dependency and fluctuation starts to clarify. Danxi's view that cold injury pertains to internal harm is a notion that holds considerable truth. Those who are present or absent are all influenced by human movements. When a person moves in accordance with rhythm and self-nourishment, their qi harmonizes, and what they sense, too, harmonizes to become the vital energy nourishing their being, hence they fluctuate in the middle.[506p]
When a person moves without regulation and is weary, their vital energy becomes disordered, and what they sense also transforms into disordered energy, settling within as the root of bodily disease, lurking within. If movement does not cease, weariness is endless, and heavy sensations disturb the energy, then what was once lurking begins to emerge and transform. "Period" refers to the time of transformation, indicating movement that does not act on itself. If there is no birth or transformation, and the period is one of stillness, then it is akin to death. Thus, it is said that without birth or transformation, the period is one of stillness. Therefore, for animals, when still, the breath entering and exiting through the mouth and nose is exhausted, and the spirit’s mechanisms are extinguished as a period; for plants, stillness means the rising and falling of roots and branches ceases, leading to a period of solitary danger in the vital energy. Thus, without the breath of animals, there is no growth, aging, or vitality; without the transformation of plants, there is no growth or accumulation. Therefore, rising, falling, entering, and exiting are omnipresent. Thus, the mechanisms of animals and plants are the dwellings of transformation and life. When energy disperses, entering and exiting, rising and falling, separate and give rise to transformation and breath. Hence, there is nothing that does not enter and exit, nothing that does not rise and fall. Transformation has both large and small aspects, from the slightest movements to the vastness of heaven and earth; periods have both proximity and distance, from the mayfly, born in the morning and perishing by evening, to the longevity of the tortoise and the crane, living for thousands of years. All these four aspects of size and distance are precious in maintaining constancy; deviating from this leads to disasters and abrupt ends to periods of stillness.[507p]
On the Fundamentals of the Six Elements and the Great Discussion of the Qi Dynamics

According to the Great Discussion of the Six Elements, the proper function of the six transformations and the regular patterns of change leads to the understanding of how the energies of heaven and earth fluctuate. This includes the discussion of the five movements and six qi's convergence in different conditions. The proper function of the six transformations refers to the consistent energies, while the regular patterns of the six changes refer to the variable energies. The six conditions encompass transformation, change, dominance, return, utility, and illness: the condition of transformation aligns with the proper function of the six transformations; the conditions of change, dominance, return, utility, and illness correspond to the regular patterns of the six changes.

The arrival of the utmost yin signifies a balanced flow, regulating the twelve solar terms and discussing the three conditions of transformation, change, and illness. There are the constancy of seasonal transformations, the constancy of administrative orders, and the general rules of operations influencing the conditions of transformation; the constancy of qi variations pertains to the conditions of change; and the constancy of illness concerns the conditions of illness. In all, these twelve variations describe one aspect of change, related to the two conditions of dominance and return. The application of the six qi relates to the seasonal aspects, corresponding to one condition of utility. The constancy of seasonal transformation relates to the regular transformation of the six departments. The constancy of similarity relates to the administration of heaven in the springs. The constancy of energy transformation refers to the regular transformations of the five movements.[508p]
The arrival of Jueyin results in the generation of wind, ultimately leading to dryness; Shaoyin leads to the generation of heat, and culminates in cold; Taiyin initiates humidity, ultimately resulting in rain; Shaoyang gives rise to fire, ending in vapor; Yangming brings about dryness, finishing in coolness; Taiyang results in cold, with warmth in between. These six phenomena of wind, heat, humidity, fire, dryness, and cold are the primary qi; while the final states of dryness, rain, vapor, and coolness are the derived qi; the middle states of cold and warmth represent the central qi. The essence of each begins with the primary qi and concludes with the derived qi, while the final qi consistently resides within the relationship of primary and derived. Thus, when discussing primary and derived, the central qi is embedded within. The reason Shaoyin and Taiyang mention the middle without concluding is that the central qi of Shaoyin and Taiyang is identical to the derived qi; therefore, when mentioning the middle, the derived qi is considered to also be included.[509p]
The constancy of virtue transformation refers to the regularization of the growth of plants through virtue. Following this, the constancy of virtue transformation also pertains to the regularization of the development of animals through virtue. All these twelve transformations imply the variations that occur due to previous virtue transformations, administrative decrees, and changing conditions in response to the twelve indicators. If the timing of the seasonal progression does not align properly with the rightful positions of subject and guest, then it results in atmospheric changes leading to a victorious recovery.

As for the signs of recovery, when the victorious energy transforms the virtue, it rewards with virtue; when change occurs, it rewards with transformation; and when policies shift, it rewards with administration. However, the circulation of energy cannot be moved from its original path. If the transformed energy is high, the response will also be high; if it is low, the response will be low; if it is behind, the response will be behind; if it is ahead, the response will be ahead; if it is in the middle, the response will be in the middle; if it is outside, the response will be outside. The positioning of high and low cannot be altered either.

From this perspective, the changes of wind, cold, heat, humidity, dryness, and fire in the world cannot be uniform. The south experiences dryness and drought, while the north has rain and humidity; the central plains endure ice and cold, while the sides are damp and hot.[510p]
Moreover, geography has heights and depths, and terrain has sizes. The high places have cold air and are often clear and dry, while the low places have hot air and are often rainy and humid. Smaller differences are minor, while larger differences are significant, all mixed up in the ever-changing ways of nature. The Wang family explains the heights and depths, as well as the fore and aft in human experiences of illness, without considering the divisions of geography. This reflects Chengzi's view that the droughts and floods of the world are consistently different, which is not merely dictated by the cycles of fortune in a given year.

When wind is dominant, movement occurs; when heat is dominant, swelling arises; when dryness is dominant, things become parched; when cold is dominant, they become buoyant; when humidity is dominant, they become wet and leak. In severe cases, water can cause blockages leading to swelling, which varies according to where the air resides, indicating the changing conditions where illness occurs.

For instance, if the wind is dominant in high places, then a person will feel a heavy head and dizziness when at a height; if the wind is dominant in low places, then that person will feel tremors and movement in their legs. Similarly, if heat is dominant in high places, swelling and heat will manifest around the waist; if heat is dominant in low places, the same will happen below the waist. All of these variations in illness correspond to where the six qi (vital energies) dominate, in terms of height, depth, fore, aft, and in-and-out positions.

The application of the six qi returns to the principle of non-dominance, manifested as transformation, meaning they each revert to areas where they are non-dominant at monthly intervals. The monthly cycle, for example, is when the jueyin governs the celestial year; at that time, the yangming position lies on the left near the spring, in the northeast, corresponding to the initial qi; the taiyang position is on the right near the spring, in the southeast, corresponding to the second qi. The jueyin position governs above, facing directly south, corresponding to the third qi; and the shaoyin position is on the left near the heavens, in the southwest, corresponding to the fourth qi.[511p]
The position of the Moon is between the right of the spring, facing the northwest, associated with the energy of the number five; the position of the Lesser Yang is at the spring, facing directly north, associated with the energy of completion. Therefore, in the annual application, the Moon's rain transformation is administered in the southeast, corresponding to the energy of two and the position of the Sun; the Sun's cold transformation is administered in the southwest, corresponding to the energy of four and the position of the Lesser Yin; the Lesser Yin's heat transformation is administered in the northeast, corresponding to the initial energy and the position of the Yang Ming; the Yang Ming's dryness transformation is administered directly south, corresponding to the energy of three and the position of the Absolute Yin; the Absolute Yin's wind transformation is administered in the northwest, corresponding to the energy of five and the position of the Moon. Each transformation is determined by its location to validate its application according to the annual method. When one gains their position, transformation is administered in the direction of their original position.[512p]
In a year of the Jueyin, the Taiyin is positioned in the northwest, where its five energies embody the transformation of rain; the Yang is in the southeast, where its two energies embody the transformation of cold; the Shaoyin is in the southwest, where its four energies embody the transformation of heat; the Shaoyang is in the due north, where its overall energy embodies the transformation of fire; the Yangming is in the northeast, where its initial energy embodies the transformation of dryness; and the Jueyin is in the due south, where its three energies embody the transformation of wind. This can be applied uniformly across the years.

For those of great constitution, there is a gradual and constant accumulation of qi, which corresponds to illness; thus, their condition appears to wane slowly and subtly, necessitating treatment in opposition to it. For those of lesser constitution, there is a violent and sudden depletion of qi, which corresponds to illness; therefore, their condition appears suddenly and severely, and treatment should conform to this. When one observes their qi as violent and intense, and hastily employs strong remedies against it, then the heat illness remains unresolved, and the cold illness may re-emerge. One fails to realize that the qi of those with a strong constitution appears to wane, while the qi of those with a weak constitution appears to intensify.[513p]
The True Principles of Treating Illnesses According to Qi

This text discusses the use of the five flavors and the principles of yin and yang, as well as the methods of curing diseases caused by imbalances in internal qi. It is understood that illnesses arise from the disharmony of internal qi, and thus the treatment should target the subtle energies of the affliction. If the condition is severe and treatment is applied incorrectly, it can lead to a confrontation between the rightful and the evil, making it difficult to overcome the illness, and life may be at risk. Therefore, one must be mindful to address the external symptoms of cold or heat while administering the appropriate remedy internally, allowing the rightful energies to counter the evil.

For instance, recommendations by Dongyuan include using ginger with a warming drink for cold symptoms, while Zhang Zhongjing proposed adding gallbladder extract to Baitong decoction to treat conditions of the lesser yin that involve cold. Similarly, Danxi advised that stir-fried mixtures in Qinhong decoction can treat women suffering from cold due to color and sight issues.

When the qi is balanced, treatment methods can be applied when illnesses stem from external evils, regardless of their degree of cold or heat. Whether the approach is counteractive or supportive is acceptable, and there is no need to fear confrontation between rightful and evil, as a strong rightful energy will cause the evil to recede on its own.[514p]
The Complete Collection of Ancient and Modern Books, Volume 119: The Gate of Fate

The Divination of Five Movements

The Emperor said: I have heard about the concept of the Five Movements from the Master; it does not align with Yin and Yang. What is the reason for this? Qibo replied: This is the clarification of the Dao. It pertains to the Yin and Yang of Heaven and Earth. The numbers that can be counted are those of Yin and Yang among people.
