The external display of prosperity and decline is governed by the distribution of the six energies, which alternate between abundance and scarcity. If there is harm without governance, it will result in the collapse and disorder of governance, causing disaster and transformation, leading to the great calamity of all things. This great calamity refers to disasters and changes. When all things are afflicted, can heaven and earth still maintain their positions? This excessive harm stems from control, which is unavoidable and inevitable. Taking the timing of heaven into account, if spring does not yield to the winter's decree, then water becomes excessively dominant, harming the wood it supports. However, fire, being the child of wood, then utilizes earth to control water, allowing wood to receive the mandate of transformation and display its beauty and splendor outwardly.[566p]
However, plants and insects have their own cycles of growth and decline each year. If there is no regulation and the trees suffer harm, then winter will enter spring prematurely, causing life to wither and resulting in disasters between heaven and earth. Could this not be the utmost chaos of governance? Speaking in terms of the human body, when the heart fire is excessive, the mouth becomes dry and parched, and the body overheats. Consequently, the spleen loses nourishment, the lung suffers damage from the metal element, and from this, water rises to counter the fire of the heart. Sweating releases moisture, cooling the mouth and body, bringing balance. If the kidney water is too weak to ascend and regulate, and the heart fire is too strong to descend, then spirit departs, qi becomes solitary, and disasters ensue.

Furthermore, it is said: When there is surplus, it should not be squandered; when there is deficiency, one should remain steady. Knowing when to welcome and when to follow, qi can be anticipated.

This expresses that when there is surplus, there will subsequently be deficiency; when there is deficiency, there will subsequently be surplus. If surplus follows surplus and scarcity follows scarcity, then the principles of heaven and earth are altered.

Again, it is said: When the entering and exiting are neglected, the spirit’s mechanisms are extinguished; when ascension and descent cease, the qi becomes isolated and precarious.[567p]
Therefore, without entrance and exit, there would be no growth, aging, and death; without rising and falling, there would be no development, transformation, and storage. Thus, rising and falling, entrance and exit, are present in all things. If these four are not maintained, disaster will come.

Entrance and exit are the breathing of heaven and earth. Rising and falling are the transformative energies of heaven and earth. Beasts with fur and feathers, and creatures that fly or crawl, all derive their life force from within, with the spirit acting as the master of movement and stillness—hence it is called the spirit mechanism. Gold, jade, earth, stones, plants, and trees all derive their life force from the external, depending on atmosphere to establish themselves—thus it is called the establishment of atmosphere. Those that originate within are rooted in the heavens, and all their movements are driven by the spirit energy as the master of mechanism. What they do is unknown to all beings; therefore, when the spirit departs, the mechanism rests.[568p]
Those that are rooted in the external world are dependent on the earth for their birth and growth. Thus, their processes of growth, transformation, and storage all arise from the vital essence of nature. Therefore, what emerges from them is unknown to all beings. When the vital essence ceases, the path of creation is cut off. The nine orifices that are horizontal all possess the air of entry and exit. The vertical orifices have the air of yin and yang, rising and falling. The interactions within, along with walls, windows, and openings, all receive the incoming air that strikes us. When yang rises, the well is cold; when yin rises, the well is warm. When objects are thrown into the well and leaves fall from above, tumbling without haste, this is all due to the condensation of yin energy.

The hollow tube holds water completely; if earth is suspended, the water cannot flow out because there is no rising air to facilitate descent. A small-mouthed empty bottle, when poured into suddenly, does not allow liquid in, because the air cannot escape—so it cannot enter. From this, we observe that rise contains no limit to descent, and descent contains no limit to rise. Without exiting, there is no entering; without entering, there is no exiting. The birth of all things involves the cycles of rising, falling, entering, and exiting—this is the constant principle of vital energy.[569p]
If there is exit without entry, entry without exit, ascent without descent, and descent without ascent, then it contradicts the constant way of transformation, and the spirit departs while the energy is solitary—what could this be but disaster? However, both reversals and smoothness, all are manifestations of celestial energy. The earth is below man, upheld by the great atmosphere. Heaven moves six times and does not rest, while the earth is stable in its five positions.

Heaven uses six energies to influence the earth, and the earth, with its five positions, receives heaven. Yet, if the heavenly fire does not augment the lord’s fire, adding six to five results in one excess energy after five years; hence the lord’s fire is not suitable for seasonal energy but is merely a designation following heaven. Therefore, it is said that the lord's fire is based on name, while the fiery energy is based on position; this means that the fiery energy replaces the lord's fire in function, leading to its migration after five years. If the earth supports six with five, then after six years the celestial source energy is fully prepared, thus completing six cycles, repeating and renewing continuously.[570p]
At five years, the energies of the five elements circulate; at six years, the positions of the six energies complete their cycle. The combination of five and six means that at thirty years, a cycle begins, resulting in sixty years. By examining the calendar days and the transformation of seasons, each year is governed by a dominant energy, referred to as the earth energy. If the heavenly officer is positioned between the springs on either side, moving and residing above the dominant energy, it is called the heavenly energy, which is secondary. The secondary energy follows the heavenly decree throughout the year, while the dominant energy merely serves the secondary energy. If the secondary energy prevails, one follows; if the dominant energy prevails, one resists. There can be a victory of one over the other, but no return.

When the dominant prevails, it diminishes the dominant energy and replenishes the secondary; when the secondary prevails, it diminishes the secondary and replenishes the dominant. The classics state: First, establish the year to clarify its energy. Each year, establish the movement of energies, examine their excesses and deficiencies, then use the dominant energy of the earth as the foundation, while the incoming heavenly energy serves as the marker, in pursuit of the six transformations. As the energies fluctuate, the subtle follows, and the intense is constrained.[571p]
The restoration of qi involves harmonizing what is passive and grasping what is aggressive. Each follows the victorious qi to find its balance, aiming for equilibrium. Moreover, examining the teachings of the Zhu family, it is said that the Great Disturbance generates the Jiazi, and the initiated heads operate by numerical principles, marking the distance of time and seasons. Therefore, the current year is identified as the Jiazi year, the Winter Solstice is the Jiazi month, the New Moon is the Jiazi day, and midnight marks the Jiazi hour. Accumulating ten, a hundred, a thousand, and so forth, all is orderly and coherent, representing human effort. Humans are born into different qi, and their ailments are difficult to predict; I have yet to witness it as true. Alas! This is a biased viewpoint. One does not understand that the timing of heaven is not something an ordinary person can measure; the human body is endowed with tremendous transformation and life.

The Ming Tang poem states: "Jia generates the gallbladder, Yi generates the liver, Bing generates the small intestine, Ding generates the heart, Wu generates the stomach, Ji generates the spleen, Geng belongs to the large intestine, Xin belongs to the lungs, Ren belongs to the bladder, and Gui belongs to the kidneys." The San Jiao also returns to the palace of Ren, and the channels converge in the area of Gui. [The poem indicates that humans embody the heavenly qi of Ren to give birth to the bladder at the gateway of life, embody the qi of Gui to produce the kidneys, embody the qi of Jia to produce the gallbladder, embody the qi of Yi to produce the liver, embody the qi of Bing to generate the small intestine, embody the qi of Ding to produce the heart, embody the qi of Wu to generate the stomach, embody the qi of Ji to produce the spleen, embody the qi of Geng to produce the large intestine, and embody the qi of Xin to produce the lungs. This applies to the heavenly stems as well as the earthly branches.]

Furthermore: "Lungs correspond to Yin, Stomach to Chen, Spleen to Si, Heart to Wu, Small Intestine to Wei. Shen corresponds to the bladder, You to the kidneys, and Xun to the heart and channels of Xu, while Hai corresponds to the three Zi, Gallbladder to Chou, Liver to Tong." Observing these two poems, it becomes evident that the interaction among heaven, earth, and the human body is ceaseless.[572p]
The scripture states: "Heavenly energy connects with the lungs, earthly energy connects with the throat, windy energy connects with the liver, thunderous energy connects with the heart, grain energy connects with the spleen, and rainy energy connects with the kidneys. The six channels form rivers, and the intestines and stomach form the sea; the nine orifices are water, infusing energy." Therefore, if even one energy is not in harmony, creation and transformation cannot occur. Heaven has six energies, and humans respond to them with three yin and three yang.

Speaking in terms of the six channels, there are three yin and three yang. When divided into twelve branches, there are six yin and six yang. Yin descends from above, is born in the afternoon, and reaches its peak at the midnight, termed as six yin. Yang arises from below, is born at the rat hour, and peaks at the snake hour, termed as six yang.

The earth has five elements, and humans respond to them with the five viscera and bowels. The viscera are yin, while their numbers are odd, corresponding to the five movements. The qualities of the five elements exist in the earth, while their energies move in the heavens.[573p]
The organs are yang, and their numbers are even, corresponding to the six energies. Though the six climatic pathogens descend from the heavens, they must inevitably fill the earth. Zi and Wu represent the center and uprightness of heaven and earth, with fire occupying its position. The Hand Shaoyin Heart resides at Wu, and the Foot Shaoyin Kidney is at Zi. Chen and Xu lead the seven governing powers, with cold water in their place.

【The cold water of Taiyang, having Zi's position at Chen and Xu, signifies that water lies hidden beneath the earth, thus Xu serves as the Six Wu heavenly gate, while Chen is the Six Ji earthly door.】 The Hand Taiyang Small Intestine is positioned at Xu, and the Foot Taiyang Bladder is at Chen. Hence, fire is transformed from water, and water follows the kidney; thus, Shaoyin occupies the organ position, integrating with Taiyang through the interaction of qi to form the fu (hollow organs).

Chou and Wei represent the prototype of storage, with damp earth in their place. The Foot Taiyin Spleen is at Wei, and the Hand Taiyin Lung is at Chou. Mao and You are the pathways of the sun and moon, with dry metal in their place. The Foot Yangming Stomach is at You, and the Hand Yangming Large Intestine is at Mao. Therefore, Zi follows its mother; with strong earth and flourishing metal, Taiyin occupies the organ position, integrating with Yangming through the interaction of qi to form the fu.[574p]
The Si-Wei (Snake-Pig) is the gateway of Heaven and Earth, where the Wood of the Wind is positioned. Although the Yin-Mao (Rabbit) is the proper division of Wood and is inhabited by the Yangming Dry Metal, Wood is generated in the Pig, hence it resides in the Pig and transforms in correspondence with the Si.

The Foot Jueyin (Liver) is located in the Pig, while the Hand Jueyin (Heart) resides in the Si. The Yin-Yang (Tiger-Monkey) holds the beginning and end of transformation, where the Fire of the Yin-Yang is situated. Although there is a position in the Wu (Horse) for the Yang Fire, this Fire ultimately resides in the Yin, for Fire is generated in the Yin.

The Foot Shaoyang (Gallbladder) is located in the Yin, and the Hand Shaoyang (San Jiao) resides in the Monkey. However, the Fire of transformation is hosted in the Liver and Kidney. The Gallbladder is the organ of the Liver, while the Heart's network corresponds with the Kidney, thus the Jueyin denotes the position of the organs, and the Shaoyang is separate but harmonizes with the Qi to form the bodily cavities.

The three Yin and three Yang, while named differently, are fundamentally one in essence.[575p]
When the yin and yang energies are weak, it is called "less"; when they are strong, it is called "greater." Yin represents less yang, while the different phases are: Yin (寅) for less yang, Mao (卯) for pure yang, Chen (辰) for great yang, Wu (午) for less yin, Wei (未) for great yin, and Hai (亥) for extreme yin.

In the Southern governance, when the three yin dominate the sky, nothing responds at the inch level; when the three yin are in the spring, nothing responds at the foot level. In the Northern governance, when the three yin dominate the sky, nothing responds at the foot level; when the three yin are in the spring, nothing responds at the inch level. The lack of response is identified as a sinking pulse.

This indicates that among the six energies, the ruler is represented by fire, and among the five movements, damp earth is considered significant. Thus, the Earth movement of Jia and Ji is associated with the Southern governance, as earth constitutes the foundation, integrating the movements of metal, wood, water, and fire. Earth occupies the center, ruling from the south and issuing commands, while the other four movements serve as ministers from the north in a manner that delineates their difference. However, this pertains to the regular case. If there are seasonal illnesses from celestial movements, then not everything must strictly conform.[576p]
The classics say: "The vital energy of heaven and earth is the source of all transformations, but it does not manifest in diagnosis. Heaven and earth operate through energy, not through positions; thus, one should not diagnose according to meridians, but rather observe through physical symptoms." From this perspective, the channels and organs, pulse diseases, and medicinal treatments all stem from the movement of vital energy. It is not confined to just one year; even in a fleeting moment, the energies of the Five Elements are ever-present. It is not limited to a single object; even in the tiniest detail, the transformations of the Five Elements are contained. When observed in the heavens, there are responses corresponding to the five stars’ patterns; when observed on the earth, there are evidences in the growth of plants and insects. How unfortunate it is that common physicians, unaware of the source of medicine, do not recognize what vital energy truly is; they lack understanding of the changes in medicine and cling to rigid prescriptions that harm people. In summary: There is the celestial vital energy, and there is the vital energy within humanity.[577p]
When the heavenly timing prevails, one abandons the afflictions of humanity and follows the way of heaven; when human ailments dominate, one relinquishes the heavenly timing to attend to human sickness. Zhang Zi said: If an illness does not align with the seasonal influences of that year, why consider it in relation to any other year's influences? Only by seeking the method of survival in a certain year can one truly understand the essence of truth. Bian Que said: Cold ailments arise from the excess of yin energies; warm ailments result from the excess of yang fire; ailments from wind are due to excess of wood influences; damp ailments stem from excess moisture; ailments from obscurity and confusion arise from excess dryness; prolonged clear weather without rain may lead to epidemics; heart ailments are caused by an excessive initial activation of the ruling fire. The classics state: One must first consider the yearly influences; do not disturb the harmony of heaven. It also says: Not understanding the impact of the year and the fluctuations of seasonal energies, one cannot pursue mastery. Scholars should combine their observations, refine their understanding of pulse diagnoses, and thus attain their own insights. Ah! The path of Confucianism is broad and succinct, while the path of medicine is rooted in the dynamics of energy. Can scholars not enter through this door and seek its profound essence?[578p]
The Complete Collection of Books from Ancient and Modern Times, Volume 120: On the Mechanisms of Qi

On the Mechanisms of Qi for Easy Reference [Ming Dynasty, Wang Ji]

The Outline of the Five Movements and Six Qis

Someone asked: The Five Movements and Six Qis are discussed in the "Neijing," but various schools gloss over them. The principles are profound and not easily comprehensible; I wish for them to be elucidated. Danxi said: When beginning to study medicine, one must first understand the variations in disease mechanisms, discuss the human body, and assess treatments. If one hastily focuses on Qi movements, they might end up like the followers of Ma Zongsu, speaking of people born in certain years, becoming ill on certain days, and treating them with specific medicines. Someone further inquired: The five organs and six viscera in humans correspond to the heavens and the earth, governing Qi and movements, reacting to the changes of the eight winds. Isn't this quite relevant? If one does not understand this, how can they practice medicine without grasping the principles of regulation? The answer is that Yang Taishou also mentioned this.[579p]
The five movements and six energies must be observed daily, noting their wind, rain, clarity, and obscurity. Some may fall ill due to seasonal afflictions, others may fall sick due to latent energy after time has passed, and some may be affected by chronic conditions activated by external forces. With prolonged understanding, one will naturally reach the utmost skill.

【Written by Ding Yuanji, "Outline of Movements and Energies": The purpose of this outline is based on the "Inner Canon" and Liu Wenshu’s discussions of profound theories and significant concepts, complemented by annotations below. If the main annotations are insufficient, easily noticeable side annotations shall be provided. However, deep side annotations should be listed as figures for reference, blotted with ink.】

The classics state that where Yin is located, the pulse does not respond, and when discussing the three Yins, it does not refer solely to the Shao Yin. Wang Taifu notes that under the Tai Yin and Jue Yin, the Shao Yin is close in position, yet it neglects the fundamental Qi on either side. It does not take position into account based on personal inclinations, thus aligning with the essence. Therefore, all writings of Ma Zongsu reference this according to the position of the governing fire. This is what Danxi refers to as losing the fundamental principles. It is not followed today.

Five Elements diagram of life and death, as seen in the diagram.

【Verse: Wood, fire, earth, metal, water—the five elements, cyclic and mutually generating. Water, fire, metal, wood, earth—the five thieves, cyclic and mutually overcoming.】

Diagram of the Heavenly Stems and Earthly Branches associated with the five elements, as seen in the diagram.

【Verse: Jia and Yi, the East holds wood, Bing and Ding, the South holds fire.】

【Geng and Xin, the West holds metal, Ren and Gui, the North holds water. Wu and Ji, the Earth of Chen, Xu, Chou, and Wei is centered among the seasons.】[580p]
The Concept of Qi and Luck

The discussion of the five movements and six atmospheres is not found in the classics of Confucian scholars, but is present in the medical text "Suwen." "Suwen" is an ancient text predating the Qin dynasty; although not all its content may originate from the words of the Yellow Emperor and Qi Bo, during the time before the Qin, particularly in the Spring and Autumn and Warring States periods, those such as the He and Yue people were indeed very proficient in medicine, yet their understanding of the applications of the five elements of heaven and earth was not as precise. Therefore, although these words may not fully belong to the Yellow Emperor and Qi Bo, their essence must have come from some teachings.

Furthermore, the cold, heat, damp, dryness, wind, and fire are the yin and yang of heaven, with the three yins and three yangs upheld above; while the wood, fire, earth, metal, and water are the yin and yang of the earth, with growth and transformation responding below. The five movements occur within these, representing the transformative qi of the five elements. The heavenly sequence ends with five, while the earthly ends with six, leading to seven. The earth of Wu and Ji must channel qi through the five, hence Jia and Ji transform into earth and take precedence; earth generates metal, thus Yi and Geng follow; metal generates water, hence Bing and Xin succeed; water generates wood, thus Ding and Ren follow; wood generates fire, hence Wu and Gui follow. This is the order of transformative qi. The three yins and three yangs of the earth are indeed the five elements, yet fire uniquely has two, showcasing the profound principles of the five elements. It is said that wood flourishes in the east, fire in the south, metal in the west, water in the north, and earth is prosperous in all directions.[581p]
The fifth branch is attached to the tenth and is in the dry element; the sixth branch is attached to the fifth and is in the southeast; the position of the sixth is opposed in the second, hence the fifth and tenth branches with the second and fourth branches are in auspicious positions. The fifth branch is in the southwest, its hexagram is Kun, and its season is late summer. Because it is located in the middle of the four seasons, "The Monthly Regulations of Lü" refers to it as the center. If the transformation of the great horn of Ren wood is to open and separate, and it changes to collapse and pull, the great sign of Wu fire transforms to warmth, and changes to be fiery and intense; this is how transformation becomes change. The lesser horn of Ding wood, with insufficient wood energy, leads to clarity overcoming warmth, and warmth returning; the lesser sign of Gui fire, with insufficient fire energy, leads to cold overcoming and rain returning; thus, the transformation into return occurs. When cold is severe, it becomes the flame of yang, which represents fire; when mugginess and heat are severe, it becomes starkly clear, representing metal; this is how congestion becomes stifled and unextending. When water is congested and emerges, it becomes hail; when earth is congested and emerges, it becomes a sudden shower; this is how congestion arises in fury. When the wind overcomes, it defeats the great yin; when heat overcomes, it defeats the yangming; this is how it overwhelms what it defeats. Under the influence of fire, water energy is borne; under the pressure of damp earth, wind energy carries; thus extremes give rise to reversals. If the transformation into collapse and pull does not respond, then great winds will sweep across the sky; if the transformation into fiery intensity does not respond, the thin sea will be entirely scorched; if clarity overcomes does not respond, then the universe will be unmistakably bright and clear; if rain energy returning does not respond, then all mountains and marshes will be in steam and humidity.[582p]
The principles are rooted in prosperity, development, indulgence, and acceptance. All of these reflect a truth. When responding, there may not necessarily be a moment for it, leading to responses that occur unexpectedly. When the time has truly come, there can be sudden occurrences. Therefore, even at a distance of a thousand miles, there may be similar transformations; at a close distance of a hundred miles, the transformations may also differ. If one reads the signs in accordance with the time and place, it becomes possible to predict fortune and misfortune. Moreover, the "Suwen," which discusses the transformation of the energies of heaven and earth, aims to observe these changes to alleviate the suffering of the people. The vastness of heaven and earth parallels the smallness of the human body, where the energies of the five elements reside. When the energies of heaven and earth remain constant, people will be at peace and free from disasters. However, when the energies of heaven and earth change and lose their constancy, ailments will arise. Therefore, when wood energy prevails, the liver experiences real illness, and the spleen suffers from deficiency. When fire energy prevails, the heart faces real illness, while the lungs deal with deficiency. This is something that doctors can discern, while scholars may not grasp the details. Furthermore, governing the heavens and earth, managing yin and yang, and aligning with the five elements ensures that winter does not bring unseasonable warmth, summer does not have lurking cold, autumn is free from bitter rain, and spring is devoid of sorrowful winds. When the harmonious energy flows between these seasons, the nation will not suffer from floods or droughts, and the people will be free from malevolent diseases; this is what scholars should observe, something doctors may not necessarily know. The "Suwen" also briefly touches upon this.[583p]
The essence of the Five Elements constitutes the Five Coordinates, corresponding with the cycle of fortune. There are the Year Star and the Morning Star; through these, one observes the reversals and smoothness of their paths, and divines fortune and misfortune. Yet it must be said, those with virtue will gain blessings, while those who err will incur punishment. This reflects the harmony of fortune and destiny leading to auspiciousness, summoned by the virtuous. In contrast, discord in fortune leads to afflictions, brought upon by the errant.

Nevertheless, this explanation is brief and lacks detail; the texts of our scholars provide thorough elaboration. The "Hong Fan" begins with the Five Elements, centers on the Supreme Ultimate, and concludes with the Five Blessings and Six Extremes. The sage establishes the Ultimate above to align with the application of the Five Elements, such that the people of the world possess the Five Blessings and lack the Six Extremes. With the Five Blessings, they can attain peace and well-being; devoid of the Six Extremes, they can evade illnesses. This principle naturally aligns with forces beyond mere fortune, which is why during the reign of Great Shun, it was observed.

Through the poem of Geng, yin and yang followed their paths; through the poem of Huashu, the Four Seasons maintained their harmony; through the poem of Yi, all things found their appropriateness. This establishes the Supreme Ultimate, aligns with the Five Elements, and demonstrates to the people the presence of the Five Blessings while lacking the Six Extremes. Therefore, the "Su Wen" is a manual of methods, while the "Hong Fan" is the grand doctrine of the sages in governing the world. To know the "Su Wen" but not the "Hong Fan" is to belong to the realm of prescriptions; to know the "Hong Fan" but not the "Su Wen" is not to be considered a accomplished scholar.

The Chart of the Twenty-Four Seasonal Points.[584p]
See the diagram.

On the Climate of the Four Seasons

The six qi begin and end at different times, and the five movements exhibit variations in fullness and emptiness. By examining the fundamental principles and analyzing the numerical patterns, we find that there has been no discrepancy throughout the ages. The classics say: every five days corresponds to a候 (hou), which aligns with the five elements. Therefore, three candidates form one qi, which spans fifteen days. Three qi together create one节 (jie), referring to the significant points: the beginning of spring, the spring equinox, the beginning of summer, the summer solstice, the beginning of autumn, the autumn equinox, the beginning of winter, and the winter solstice; these are the eight节. The four directions account for the twenty-four qi, governing the four seasons, thus completing the year.

In the discussions of spring and autumn, the term "division" refers to the monthly qi: by the end of the first half of the second month, one qi transitions to another, while by the end of the first half of the eighth month, the fourth qi concludes and transitions to the fifth. When discussing the qi of the four seasons, it is the yin-yang, cold-warm qi that can be categorized at this stage. Day and night are divided into fifty segments, which also represents a division of yin and yang. Therefore, the classics state: "Division leads to differing qi."[585p]
In terms of the six atmospheric influences, when we speak of the arrival of winter and summer, the energy of May, under the control of Heaven, reaches its highest point; in November, the energy of the springs reaches its own place. When we reference the four seasons, the energies of yin and yang arrive at their extremes. At the summer solstice, the day does not exceed sixty double-hours, representing the peak of yang; at the winter solstice, the day does not fall below forty double-hours, representing the peak of yin, both of which indicate that the heavens have yet to change. Thus, it is said in classic texts: when the arrival occurs, the energies are the same. The heavens turn from west to east, with the sun, moon, and five planets following this celestial movement from east to west; therefore, it is stated in "The White Tiger Compendium": the heavens turn left, while the sun, moon, and starry constellations move to the right. Furthermore, it is said: the sun represents yang, the moon represents yin, and their movements have divisions and principles. The sun travels one degree across the heavens, with each degree consisting of a hundred double-hours, totaling a day; the moon, however, traverses the heavens with thirteen degrees, where an odd number recurs—completing one degree while generating fractions, resulting in nineteen fractions yielding seven. [One degree consists of a hundred double-hours, yielding nineteen fractions equating to seven, with each fraction corresponding closely to five double-hours. Therefore, five times seven equals thirty-five double-hours, implying that the moon travels in the heavens thirteen degrees and an additional ten and a half double-hours].[586p]
The moon generally travels swiftly, completing its orbit in twenty-seven days. This corresponds to thirteen degrees and seven-sevenths of nineteen minutes. In total, it is twenty-nine days, measuring a movement of three hundred eighty-seven degrees and some extra. If we calculate the speed of the moon compared to the sun, in twenty-nine days, the sun travels twenty-nine degrees, while the moon has already completed a full orbit of three hundred sixty-five degrees, plus an additional twenty-two degrees, thus falling short by seven degrees compared to the sun. The followers of Yin and Yang say that the movements of the sun and moon are inconsistent, with the sun having variations in speed and timing, leading to differences in the sizes of the lunar months. The base of three hundred sixty-five days and a quarter corresponds to one full year, specifically twenty-five segments; thus, it may indeed be considered a year.[587p]
From the remainder outside the year, there are three hundred sixty days. Subtracting six days for the short months, we have three hundred fifty-four days making one year, which totals eleven days and twenty-five periods beyond, thus establishing the intercalary month system to create twelve months. This corresponds to the energy of the solstices, which reflects the arrival of the three seasons. The half-month signifies the orientation of the Big Dipper, which aligns with the twelve earthly branches.

In the records of the intercalary month, there are no established energies, and the orientations correspond to other energies, dependent on the calendar to reveal the eight seasonal festivals. The remainder after this determines the intercalary month, completing the celestial calculation. Thus, the texts state: “Establishing the beginning in the beginning, representing the middle accurately, and deriving the remainder at the end, completes the celestial calculations.” This refers to celestial observations that are so obscure that they lack a measure; rather, the movement of the sun and moon each day corresponds to the twenty-eight lunar lodges as evidence, hence noted as measure.

Therefore, it says in the texts: “The stars are the means for regulating the movements of the sun and moon.” To regulate means to have a system. The heavens themselves do not have signs; they manifest through wind, rain, frost, dew, and vegetation, which can be verified by seasonal occurrences, indicating a sign. Referring to a single sign corresponds to the five movements interacting harmoniously, spanning five days.

As in an endless cycle, it is continuous and returns. The texts state: “Expect three hundred sixty weeks plus six days, using the intercalary month to establish the four seasons and complete the year; this is its meaning.” The practitioners of medicine should certainly know this. It is stated: “Not knowing the increments of the year, the rise and fall of energies, or the origins of emptiness and fullness, cannot be considered skilled work.”[588p]
Sixty Years of Qi Division

The Qi begins in the year of the Jiazi at the moment of Yinjun, and according to this, Qi extends from Zi to Xu as the second Qi, from Hai to You as the third Qi, from You to Wei as the fourth Qi, from Shen to Wu as the fifth Qi, and from Wu to Chen as the sixth Qi. Starting from Si to Mao, the first Qi of the Yichou year commences. The subsequent years are calculated similarly, demonstrating that the Qi emerges at the same moment, and within three years it aligns harmoniously, the principle is evident.

However, there are a hundred marks of daytime and nighttime, which should be divided according to the twelve hours, with each hour encompassing eight marks and three minutes.

[Note: It is believed that each Qi governs sixty days and eighty-seven and a half marks. For instance, in the year of Shenzi, the initial Qi begins on the day of Dahan at the beginning of Yinjun, extending to the spring equinox at the middle of Zi, thus the initial Qi just completes sixty days and eighty-seven and a half marks. The second Qi starts on that day at the time of Zi, at eighty-seven marks and six minutes, extending until the minor full moon at the time of Xu, marking the second Qi which also completes sixty days and eighty-seven and a half marks. Subsequent Qis follow this pattern based on visual representation. The mentioned eighty-seven and a half marks derive from the total of a hundred marks within the twelve hours. In the Jiazi year, the day of Dahan at the beginning of Yinjun brings forth the initial Qi, extending until the middle of the second month at the time of Zi, just filling sixty days and eighty-seven and a half marks, precisely at the five marks of Zi. Remaining from the hundred marks after deducting eighty-seven and a half is twelve and a half marks, included in the second Qi, still amounting to seventy-five marks to total eighty-seven and a half marks.][589p]
From the previous time period, at the sixth and a quarter, the energy of the second Qi began, extending to seventy-five quarters, reaching the fourth quarter of the dog hour. After subtracting seventy-five from a hundred quarters, there remained twenty-five quarters. This is included within the third Qi, which still requires an addition of sixty-two and a half quarters, totaling eighty-seven and a half quarters. From the previous dog hour and five quarters, the energy of the third Qi began, extending to sixty-two and a half quarters, thus reaching the fifth quarter of the rooster hour. After subtracting sixty-two and a half from a hundred quarters, there remained thirty-seven and a half quarters. This is included within the fourth Qi, which still requires an addition of fifty quarters, totaling eighty-seven and a half quarters. From the previous rooster hour and six quarters, the energy of the fourth Qi began, extending to fifty quarters, thus reaching the fourth quarter of the fifth day. After subtracting fifty from a hundred quarters, there remained fifty quarters. This is included within the fifth Qi, which still requires an addition of thirty-seven and a half quarters, totaling eighty-seven and a half quarters. From the previous fifth day and five quarters, the energy of the fifth Qi began, extending to thirty-seven and a half quarters, thus reaching the fifth quarter of the afternoon hour. After subtracting thirty-seven and a half from a hundred quarters, there remained sixty-two and a half quarters. This is included within the sixth Qi, which still requires an addition of twenty-five quarters, totaling eighty-seven and a half quarters. From the previous afternoon hour and six quarters, the energy of the sixth Qi began, extending to twenty-five quarters, thus reaching the fourth quarter of the dragon day. After subtracting twenty-five from a hundred quarters, there remained seventy-five quarters, included within the initial energy of the Year of the Wood Ox.[590p]
Song: If you wish to know the intersection of qi at the early and late times, it drops a moment at the beginning of the first cycle. Finally, at eighty-seven and a half moments, two qi continue to rise from this. By seventy-five moments is complete; consider the half of six moments where three qi reside. At sixty-two moments and six parts, it begins, and fifty moments four qi reside. Five qi at thirty-seven and a half moments; six qi take away twenty-five moments. This continues to the start of wuchens, again dropping a moment like the beginning. The initial moments of shen, zi, and chen coincide, also the initial moments of si, you, and chou share the same time. The initial qi for yin, wu, and xu is not different; the initial moments of hai, mau, and wei ought to be stored together. Every four years is a small cycle tripled, six jia pass through without fail.

Fifteen small cycles constitute one large cycle, which totals sixty years.[591p]
On the Sixty-Day Intervals of Solar Terms

The day consists of one day and one night, divided into twelve equal parts; hence, a bronze vessel is set up to hold water, with a drip mechanism that allows it to flow and mark the divisions, creating a hundred increments for measure. Regardless of the clarity or obscurity of day and night, it cannot escape this measurement. Thus, within a single day, there are a hundred increments to observe.

The six energy cycles govern an entire year, therefore, one cycle corresponds to sixty days and eighty-seven and a half increments, from which we understand that the timing of these energy exchanges varies between early and late. Hence, this chart is established for clarity. The differences in daylight between winter and summer result in continual shifts between day and night, leading to different timings for sunrise and sunset; yet, they ultimately equal a hundred increments. However, the timings for the energy exchanges cannot be altered.

In a year of the Jiazi cycle, the first energy phase begins at the last minute of the water-dripping method in the early hour of Yin, and concludes at eighty-seven and a half increments in the middle of the hour of Zi. The second energy phase starts again at eighty-seven increments and six minutes, concluding at seventy-five increments in the hour of Xu, four increments into that hour.[592p]
The energy of the Three begins at the seventy-sixth moment and ends at the sixty-second and a half moment in the middle of the You hour. The energy of the Four begins at the sixty-second and six minutes and ends at the fifty moments before the fourth quarter of the hour. The energy of the Five begins at the fifty-first moment and ends at the thirty-seventh and a half moment in the middle of the Wu hour. The energy of the Six begins at the thirty-seventh and six minutes and ends at the twenty-fifth moment, which is four moments into the Chen hour. This is called the sensation and measurement of one complete celestial cycle, with the remaining moments entering the beginning energy of the Yi Chou year. In this way, by the time it reaches the Wu Chen year, the initial energy restarts one moment after the dripping water, thus constituting four years as one small cycle. Therefore, the convergence of the energies of Shen, Zi, and Chen happens here. The initial energies of Si, You, and Chou all arise at the twenty-sixth moment, with energies all starting from the fifty-first moment. The energies of Hai, Mao, and Wei also arise at the seventy-sixth moment, all starting from the same moment; thus, this is the meaning of being called the Three Convergences.[593p]
Theory of Generating Numbers

The sage establishes laws to advance cyclically, for one cannot escape their numbers. Observing the reasons for establishing these numbers, they all emerge from nature. The first is water, the second is fire, the third is wood, the fourth is metal, and the fifth is earth: Water is in the northern position of the Rat, which is the beginning of yang birth, therefore water is called one; Fire is in the southern position of the Horse, which is the beginning of yin birth, therefore fire is called two; Wood resides in the east, which is yang, thus three is an odd number and also yang, so wood is called three; Metal resides in the west, which is yin, so four is an even number and also yin, thus metal is called four; Earth corresponds to the southwest long summer. The fifth is an odd number and also yang, hence earth is called five. From this, it is argued that numbers are paired with yin and yang. Water generates at one, in the beginning when heaven and earth were not yet separated and all things were not yet formed, water is always the first seen; if we examine it now, the seeds of plants and the embryos of animals are all in water, is it not logical to regard water as one? When the water gathers and forms its qualities, the vital energies of yin and yang are present within, and then it becomes complete. Therefore, the small things that taste bitter signal the presence of fire.[594p]
When things are ripe, they are sweet; this is the flavor of the earth. When sweetness reaches its peak, it turns bland; blandness is the original flavor. However, people inherit the transformations of yin and yang from their parents, thus they have two kidneys: the left kidney belongs to water, and the right kidney belongs to fire. Fire is manifest only after water, hence fire is secondary.

Plants and trees, despite their varying sizes, all contain dualities within themselves, harmonizing in ways similar to the kidneys in humans, also bearing the signs of yin and yang. Therefore, if all things do not embody the union of yin and yang, they cannot undergo transformation and generation.

Once yin and yang are united, then spring gives rise to life and autumn brings completion. Thus, wood is ranked third and metal is ranked fourth. Water has its own domain, fire has its own reserves, wood has its own growth, and metal has its own distinctions; all these are ultimately realized through the earth.

Hence, the numerical generation of the five elements—metal, wood, water, fire, and earth—must also include the number of the earth, which is five. Water is six, fire is seven, wood is eight, and metal is nine; the earth always maintains the generative number of five and cannot reach ten. The earth does not need to reach ten to fulfill its nature, for the numbers of generation are all based on combinations. Thus, how can all things escape their numerical destiny?

There are three yin and three yang; true transformations arise from the original generative numbers, while opposing transformations derive from the established numbers.

In the records of the five movements, those that exceed their numbers are completed, while those that fall short generate; each takes the extent of generative numbers to assess political decrees and the transformations of Qi. This clarifies the practical applications of these principles.[595p]
Here is the English translation of the Classical Chinese text:

"See the illustration.

The song says: 'One and six represent water, two and seven represent fire; three and eight have always been aided by wood. Four and nine denote the countryside of metal, while five is the realm of the impoverished, as the infinite does not lead to completion, and ten is difficult to settle. The five movements cannot be used to predict life; if one encounters excessive conditions, this will inevitably follow. The six energies produce verification and transformation; when completed, mutual transformation is beyond doubt.'

Discussion on the intersection of the six energies and the days.

The classic states: 'On the right side of the bright sun lies the position of the wood, the position of the fire. To the right of the fire lies the position of the earth; step back one space (which equals sixty days and eighty-seven and a half divisions); the fire of mutuality regulates it; stepping back again, the earth energy regulates it; stepping back again, the metal energy regulates it; stepping back again, the water energy regulates it; and once more, the wood energy regulates it. This is the main position of the six energies. Starting from the day of great cold in the twelfth month, we meet the initial energy of wood; then, arriving at the day of the spring equinox in the second month, we meet the second energy of fire; next, at the day of minor fullness in the fourth month, we encounter the third energy of mutual fire; following this, at the day of great heat in the sixth month, we meet the fourth energy of earth; next, at the day of autumn equinox in the eighth month, we encounter the fifth energy of metal; and next, at the day of minor snow in the tenth month, we meet the sixth energy of water. Each energy governs for sixty days, with each day having eighty-seven and a half divisions, totaling three hundred sixty-five days and twenty-five divisions, completing the cycle of one year.'[596p]
If we consider "if" as "except," it seems to imply the following. The surplus of the year outside [the regular days]—the surplus being those days left after subtracting five days from the total of three hundred sixty-five—along with the days of the small months [which have six days each, also subtracted], does not suffice. After excluding the extra four to five days and the small month days, a total of eleven days is removed, leaving only three hundred fifty-four days, which falls short of the three hundred sixty-five.

However, when calculating the calendar days, according to the seasonal transitions and the changes in qi, there are usually the main vital energies of dryness, moisture, cold, heat, wind, and fire for each year, which correspond to the regular cycles of the six energies. This is referred to as the yin and yang of the earth that are stable and maintain their positions.

The varying responses to this include the celestial officials residing within the water springs surrounding the four directions who bring forth guest qi. These guest qi also manifest as cold, heat, dryness, moisture, wind, and fire, thus executing the heavenly mandate throughout the year, positioned above the main qi. The main qi should duly honor the mandate of the guest qi, which is always in motion.

In summary, the celestial officials preside over the first half of the year, while the water springs oversee the second half. When divided, each qi occupies its own peculiar six-day cycle, with each extraordinary period comprising eighty-seven and a half moments.

When the guest qi prevails over the main qi, it follows; when the main qi prevails over the guest qi, it resists. There is victory for one but not for both. Each year has the celestial official positioned in the third place as the water spring, and the fourth position as the initial qi. For instance, if Zi corresponds to the Lesser Yin of Fire as the celestial official, then the third place in front of Zi, which is Mao, represents the Yangming Qi of Dry Metal, while the fourth place in the water spring is Chen, representing the initial qi. Chen and Xu are opposites, both belonging to the solar cold waters, marking the period from Great Cold to the Spring Equinox, lasting a peculiar sixty days. Chen is situated to the left of Mao.[597p]
In the second position is the energy of the Earth, where the Si (巳) stands opposite to the Hai (亥), both belonging to the category of Jue Yin Wood. This governs from the Spring Equinox to the time of the Lesser Grain, spanning sixty days with some variation; Si is the right interval of Wu (午).

In the third position is the energy of the Fire, where the Wu stands opposite to the Zi (子), both belonging to the category of Shao Yin Fire. This governs from the Lesser Grain to the Greater Heat, also spanning sixty days with some variation; it is the custodian of the seasonal weather.

In the fourth position is the energy of the Earth again, where the Wei (未) stands opposite to the Chou (丑), both belonging to the category of Tai Yin Earth. This governs from the Greater Heat to the Autumn Equinox, again spanning sixty days with some variation; Wei is the left interval of Wu.

In the fifth position is the energy of Fire, where the Shen (申) stands opposite to the Yin (寅), both belonging to the category of Shao Yang Fire. This governs from the Autumn Equinox to the Lesser Snow, also spanning sixty days with some variation; Shen is the right interval of You (酉).

In the final position is the energy of Metal, where the You stands opposite to the Mao (卯), both belonging to the category of Yang Ming Dry Metal. This governs from the Lesser Snow to the Greater Cold, again spanning sixty days with some variation; it resides in the water spring energy.

Note that the six energies preside over the heavenly year and are positioned to the south, thus addressing left and right while facing north; the spring energy is located to the north, thus addressing left and right while facing south. For instance, in the year of Chou and Wei, Earth presides over the heavens, facing north. In this case, the left interval of Chou corresponds to the Shao Fire of Yin, while the right interval corresponds to the Jun Fire of Zi; in the year of Chen and Xu, Water is in the springs, facing south; thus the left interval of Chen corresponds to the Jue Yin Wood of Si, and the right interval corresponds to the Yang Ming Metal of Mao. Therefore, we conclude that left represents Jue Yin and right represents Yang Ming.[598p]
In this year, the guest qi is the initial qi of the Yin, represented by the Wood of the Hai (亥) sign; the second qi is the Shaoyin, which is represented by the Fire of the Zi (子) sign; the third qi is the Tearth of the Chou (丑) sign, controlled by the heavens; the fourth qi is the Shaoyang, represented by the Fire of the Yin (寅) sign; the fifth qi is the Yangming, represented by the Metal of the Mao (卯) sign; the final qi is in the Water of the Chen (辰) sign. This is how the heavenly control is positioned between the springs in four phases, with the guest qi adding to the host qi. The rest follows this model.

Wu Cheng of the thatched cottage states: The movement of Yin and Yang in Heaven and Earth circulates back and forth, continuing the cycle of Wood, Fire, Earth, Metal, and Water, marking beginnings and ends, like a circular path, in order of the six qis generating each other. The annual qi begins and ends in the Zi; hence it is called the winter solstice. At the midpoint of Zi, the heart does not change; from Zi to Wu (午), the year begins with thirty days of dry Metal after the winter solstice, then it transitions into the cold Water until reaching the Fire of the Succeeding. There are five days of sixty each, and after the Minor Snow, its days return to thirty, ending once more with the dry Metal. For the years of Chou and Wei (未), it starts with thirty days of cold Water after the winter solstice, transitioning into Wood and Wind until reaching dry Metal, with five days of sixty each. Similarly, for days after the Minor Snow, its days return to thirty, once again ending with the cold Water.

This follows for Yin and Shen (申) and beyond. Thus, throughout sixty years to thousands of years, the order of qi generates without interruption. There are no teachings at the end of Minor Cold, nor acceptance at the beginning of Major Cold; if a qi is isolated, it does not continue intermixed. The cutoff from Major Cold marks the beginning of the next year’s initial qi. This is the marvel of creation, secretly recorded in the “Inner Canon,” yet not yet revealed— the original source is obscured in its discussion. In modern times, Yang Zijiang has explored and derived it, presenting interpretations that may not align perfectly with the texts but are deeply logical. I submit this here to enlighten scholars.

The Diagram of the Six Transformations.[599p]
Seeing the Diagram
[The Song says: Water is cold, wood transforms into wind. They counter the heat of summer together, while damp earth shares the work with rain.]
On the Six Transformations

The five elements take shape on earth—metal, wood, water, fire, and earth—and become the energies in the heavens, known as the six energies, which are the primordial energies of heaven, then three yin and three yang serve them. [Lesser yin governs fire, greater yin governs damp earth, jueyin governs wind and wood, lesser yang governs fire, greater yang governs cold water, and yangming governs dry metal.] These are called the six energies, each responsible for a transformation. The transformation of wood into wind governs spring. The transformation of lord fire into heat governs the end of spring and the beginning of summer, serving the warm and gentle mandate in accordance with the virtue of the lord. The transformation of fire into heat governs summer, where the heat prevails. The transformation of metal into clarity and dryness governs autumn, where coolness prevails. [The white dew represents clear energy. Metal represents the elements gēng and xīn; xīn is linked to fire, hence it is dry. After a long rain, when the western wind blows and becomes clear, it is a sign of dryness. When the western wind brings rain, dryness and dampness contend, yet it eventually clears.] The transformation of water into cold governs winter, where stern cold prevails. The transformation of earth into dampness and rain governs the long summer [June], as earth is nourished by fire and grows during summer; once it has matured and rules, it moistens and transforms in the heat of the summer season.[600p]
The text states: "The classics say: The earth's energy rises as clouds, while the sky's energy falls as rain. Rain emerges from the earth's energy, and clouds arise from the sky's energy, thus the transformation of earth and rain is revealed."

In spring, there is warmth; in summer, heat; in autumn, coolness; and in winter, coldness—all are the genuine energies of heaven and earth. The six energies govern transformations; when the guest follows the host's movement, there will inevitably be differences in reversal, harmony, triumph, and defeat, resulting in varied climates. How can one make definitive statements about them?

The interplay of yin and yang across the four seasons begins in the middle of each month and peaks in the final month, which is why the classics say: "A difference of thirty degrees leads to the strange." It further discusses the influence of these energies during their rise and decline across the four dimensions, which are the four seasonal months: the second month for spring, the fifth month for summer, the eighth month for autumn, and the eleventh month for winter. Spring commences in the second month, peaks in warmth in the third; summer starts in the fifth, peaks in heat in the sixth; autumn begins in the eighth, peaks in coolness in the ninth; and winter starts in the eleventh, peaking in coldness in the twelfth, thus the differences in energy are evident.

However, in the month of the summer solstice in May, when the yin energy begins to rise, extreme heat occurs; in November, at the winter solstice, when the yang energy starts to emerge, extreme cold follows. This is due to the energy's origin from below, pushing upwards. Therefore, when yin arises, yang increases and it gets hotter; when yang arises, yin increases and it gets colder. The coolness of summer wells and the warmth of winter wells can serve as evidence of this.[601p]
On the Principal Qi

The qi of the earth is calm and maintains its position; thus, spring is warm, summer is hot, autumn is cool, and winter is cold, which are the regular orders of the years. The four seasons are born from the six qis. The wood of the Jueyin represents the initial qi, corresponding to the beginning of spring. Wood generates fire; therefore, the Shaoyin represents the lord fire, and the Shaoyang corresponds to the fire following it. Fire generates earth, thus the Taiyin represents the earth that follows; earth generates metal, making the Yangming correspond to the metal that follows; metal generates water, hence the Taiyang corresponds to the water that follows. All of these are mutually generated and spread their orders, each having its connections.

Wood, as the initial qi, governs the sixty days before the spring equinox, spanning from the start of the Doushu to the midpoint of the Yin zodiac, during which the wind qi begins to circulate. The lord fire represents the second qi, governing the sixty days after the spring equinox, from the start of Doushu to the midpoint of the Si zodiac, during which the warm and mild qi circulates. The xiang fire represents the third qi, governing thirty days before and after the summer solstice, from the start of Doushu to the midpoint of the Wei zodiac, during which the heat circulates.[602p]
The earth is associated with the Four Energies, governing the sixty days before the autumn equinox, where unusual phenomena occur. From the beginning of the Dipper, as it moves from Weizheng to the middle of You, when heaven reaches this point, clouds and rain will be present, and moist vapor will emerge. Metal corresponds to the Five Energies, governing the sixty days after the autumn equinox, where unusual phenomena also arise. From the beginning of the Dipper, as it moves from Youzheng to the middle of Hai, when heaven reaches this point, the clear energies will circulate, and all things will be dry. Water represents the Six Energies, governing the thirty days before and after the winter solstice, where unusual phenomena manifest. From the beginning of the Dipper, as it moves from Haizheng to the middle of Chou, when heaven reaches this point, the cold energy will circulate. The Six Energies rotate in a cycle to form the governing energy of the year. The six energies from heaven interact with this, transferring each year as they enact the celestial commands. Thus, acting at the right time leads to change that is constant; acting inappropriately brings disaster. For instance, if spring acts in the commands of summer, autumn, and winter, or winter acts in the commands of spring, summer, and autumn, this represents the distortion due to the interactions of the guest and the main energies. Therefore, there are regularities in effective governance and laws, as well as variations in violent winds, sudden rain, and lightning. In winter, there is heat like that of scorched stones, and in summer, a chilling wind. This is simply due to the energies of heaven and earth, thriving and flourishing together. This illustrates the five energies, reflecting the extremes of excess and deficiency.[603p]
On Politeness

The six energies divide into upper, lower, left, and right, overseeing the heavenly commands; the twelve branches divide into seasonal periods, governing the transformation of the earth's forces. The interactions between upper and lower phenomena, along with the changes of cold, heat, dryness, wind, and fire, differ from those of the four seasons due to their simultaneous presence and lack of unity. The six energies correspond with the twelve branches, finding their appropriate transformations. The Jue Yin corresponds to the Si and Hai branches, relating to Jue Yin wood, as wood originates in Hai, thereby its proper transformation occurs in Hai and corresponds to Si. Although Yin (Yin) represents the primary wood division, it also correlates with the Yang Ming metal transformation. The term "sheng" refers to drawing from and adhering to Si. The Shao Yin corresponds to Zi and Wu, where Shao Yin is considered the noble fire, aligning with the southern Li position, thus its proper transformation occurs in Wu, corresponding to Zi. The Tai Yin governs the Chou and Wei branches, with Tai Yin representing earth, associated with the center palace, residing in the Kun position to the southwest, thus its proper transformation occurs in Wei, corresponding to Chou. The Shao Yang is associated with the Yin and Shen branches, regarded as the lesser Yang fire, lower in rank than the noble fire; although it has the Wu position of noble fire, fire originates in Yin, hence its proper transformation occurs in Yin, corresponding to Shen. The Yang Ming corresponds with the Mao and You branches, where Yang Ming represents metal, and You refers to the West, thus its proper transformation occurs in You, corresponding to Mao. The Tai Yang corresponds with the Chen and Xu branches, with Tai Yang symbolizing water; despite its alignment with the Zi position as the noble fire's counterpart, it resides in the depths of the earth, specifically the six Wu at the heavenly gate Xu and the six Ji at the earthly door Chen.[604p]
Thus, although water is used for the earth, its true transformation occurs in the Dog (戌), and its counter-transformation in the Dragon (辰). This is the interaction of heaven's yin and yang with the twelve earthly branches, which move without ceasing. When the annual cycle begins, it is ordained by heaven; the corresponding qi is present in the springs, while the residual qi operates left and right. The qi succeeding the springs is the initial qi, governing the sixty days with anomalies, leading to the qi of the third for the heavenly overseer, which governs the first half of the year [starting after the winter solstice, extending to the first half of the year]. By the time it reaches the springs, it embodies the six qi, governing the second half of the year [starting after the summer solstice, extending to the second half of the year]. The classics state: Before mid-year, the heavenly qi governs; after mid-year, the earthly qi governs. The six qi of heaven are considered guest qi. When this guest qi is distributed over the six qi of the earth, there are distinctive transformations. The classics state: There are positions above and below, and rules left and right; the master of heaven is referred to as the upper position, facing north when standing in the south, with left being west and right being east. The springs are designated as the lower position, facing south when standing in the north, with left being east and right being west. Thus, above and below differ, as do left and right. The classics state: To the right of Shaoyang, Yangming governs, thus standing facing south to observe. This does not merely pertain to the positions above, below, left, and right; it aligns with the clear right, indicating the position governed by fire when facing south. The six qi diagram marks the basis of this.[605p]
See the diagram.
[The roots of the six qi are: Shao Yin (午), Tai Yin (未), Shao Yang (寅), Yang Ming (酉), Tai Yang (戌), Jue Yin (亥).]
[The song says: Zi leads Chen, and Chou is the earth; Mao is the metal, and Chen is the water that harmonizes with Si's wood. Shen is also included in this count, and the rest align with the fundamental transformations.]
The essential diagram of the Five Movements and Six Qi.[606p]
Discussion on Standard and Origin

Three Yin and Three Yang represent the Six Qi of Heaven, which serves as the standard. Metal, Wood, Water, Fire, and Earth are the Five Elements of Earth, which represent the origin. The Greater Yin’s damp Earth and the Lesser Yang’s fire are the same in standard and origin. However, the Lesser Yin’s True Fire and the Greater Yang’s Cold Water are mutually distinct in Yin and Yang, cold and hot. Why is this? It is because True Fire governs the hours of the Rat and Horse; the Horse is the position where the first Yin begins to emerge. Fire is originally hot, but its energy coincides with the beginning of Yin's birth, thus True Fire belongs to Lesser Yin. Water resides in the North, the position of the Rat; the Rat is where the first Yang begins to emerge. Water is inherently cold, and its energy aligns with the beginning of Yang's birth, therefore Cold Water belongs to Greater Yang. This distinction between the standard and origin of Water and Fire is as such. Earth occupies the position of the Southwestern Wei, corresponding to the month of Long Summer. Wei follows the Horse, making it Yin; hence Earth is called Greater Yin. The Fire of Harmony governs the Tiger, which follows the Ox, making it Yang, hence Harmony Fire is called Lesser Yang. Wood is positioned in the Eastern Zhen, associated with the Liver in humans. Although Yang is situated below the diaphragm, it occupies a Yin position, thus it belongs to Jue Yin. Metal, located in the Western Dui, is associated with the Lungs in humans. Even though the Yin organ resides above the diaphragm, it occupies a Yang position, thus it belongs to Yang Ming. The classic states: Lesser Yang and Greater Yin are treated according to origin, while Lesser Yin and Greater Yang are treated according to standard. Yang Ming and Jue Yin do not derive from standard and origin, but are governed from the center. In the center of Yang Ming, there is Greater Yin [Greater Yin and Yang Ming are complementary and unite]. In the center of Jue Yin, there is Lesser Yang [Jue Yin and Lesser Yang are complementary and unite].[607p]
Qi's Heavenly Control and Hospitality

In the positions of the solar terms, the lesser yin corresponds to the noon and midnight, while the taiyin is associated with the vale of the ox and the sheep. The lesser yang belongs to the tiger and monkey. The yangming is linked to the hare and the rooster. The dragon and dog are paired with the greater yang, while the jueyin resides with the snake and boar. The center governs the heavenly positions, counted in this orderly fashion.

When encountering the year of the rat or horse, the lesser yin governs the heavenly control. Excluding the original positions, the third yangming indicates the spring at the source, while the fourth greater yang signifies the initiation of hospitality. Next comes the jueyin, then once again the lesser yin. From the winter solstice onward, the superior six months are under the greater yin, followed by the lesser yang, culminating in yangming. From the summer solstice onward, the inferior six months are governed. Each atmospheric phase lasts sixty days and eighty-seven and a half moments, distributed upon the dynamic vitality. The rest corresponds to the mapping of host and guest.[608p]
On the Five Heavenly Energies and the Five Movements

The heavens are divided into five energies, and the earth is categorized into five elements. The five energies flow and disperse above. They align with the constellations and correspond to the cardinal directions, thus being named the five movements.

The red heavenly energy aligns with the constellations of the Ox, Girl, and the Four Walls, descending to the positions of Wu and Gui, establishing the fire movement.

The black heavenly energy aligns with the constellations of the Heart, Tail, Corner, and Chariot, descending to the positions of Jia and Ji, establishing the earth movement.

The white heavenly energy aligns with the constellations of the Kang, Di, and the Four Stars, descending to the positions of Yi and Geng, establishing the metal movement.

The original heavenly energy aligns with the constellations of the Zhang, Wing, Lou, and Stomach, descending to the positions of Bing and Xin, establishing the water movement.

The green heavenly energy aligns with the constellations of the Danger, Chamber, Willow, and Ghost, descending to the positions of Ding and Ren, establishing the wood movement.

The five energies traverse the twenty-eight constellations, which correspond with the twelve divisions of the fields, clearly observable. Xu corresponds to the heavenly gate and is aligned with the position of Gan; Si corresponds to the earthly door and is aligned with the position of Xun.

From the Room to the Four Stars encompasses fourteen constellations of the Yang, representing the day; from the Four Stars to the Heart encompasses fourteen constellations of the Yin, representing the night, completing one day.

If one were to analyze this based on the lunar calendar, the reasons for establishing the movements become apparent. The character Bing represents the Yang of fire and is established at the beginning of the Jia and Ji year, with the first month marking Bing Yin. Bing fire generates earth, hence Jia and Ji represent the earth movement. The character Wu represents the Yang of earth and is established at the beginning of the Yi and Geng year, with the first month marking Wu Yin. Wu earth generates metal, hence Yi and Geng represent the metal movement.[609p]
The Geng element is the yang of metal, established at the beginning of the Bingshen year, with Geng Yin formed in the first month. Geng metal generates water; hence Bingshen corresponds to the water cycle. The Jia element is the yang of wood, established at the beginning of the Wugui year, with Jia Yin formed in the first month. Jia wood generates fire; therefore Wugui corresponds to the fire cycle. The Ren element is the yang of water, established at the beginning of the Dingren year, with Ren Yin formed in the first month. Ren water generates wood; thus Dingren corresponds to the wood cycle. All five cycles originate from the establishment of the celestial stems in the first month. Is it not true that the sun, moon, and seasonal times influence and determine their uses? Since the beginning of creation, the five energies have been transmitted and received, and the original cycles have operated in the world with their own ordained nature, which neither heaven nor earth can escape. In recent times, it should be the earth cycle, hence people are not ill but rather damp, in contrast to the era of heat during the fire cycle.[610p]
The text refers to a phenomenon commonly known as "Yang Mei Chuang," which travels from the south to the north, where people and the earth are alike, and moisture creates mold, hence it is called mold sores. The cycles of the five elements and the six energies, as well as the governance of the north and south, are not limited to just one year or one season, are they?

The transformations of the ten stems and the five elements occur as each of the five energies takes its respective position and generates transformation. Some say that among the twelve zodiac animals, the dragon, which corresponds to Chen, is the most changeable, and each position establishes its own Yin-Yang combinations, leading to different transformations with the occurrence of Chen.

For example, when Jia Yin transforms into Bing Chen, it becomes fire; when Bing Yin transforms into Wu Chen, it becomes earth.

Moreover, some say that Jia, representing rigid wood, overcomes soft earth to create a couple, resulting in earth; while Yi, representing soft wood, marries Geng, which embodies rigid metal, resulting in metal. Ding, representing yin fire, pairs with Ren, representing yang water, leading to wood; and Bing, representing yang fire, marries Xin, representing soft metal, resulting in water. Wu, representing yang earth, marries Gui, representing yin water, generating fire. While these interpretations are similar in intent, the reasoning is not entirely natural.

This refers to a diagram illustrating the emergence of the five energies and five cycles.[611p]
The image shows a chart of the Five Energies establishing their influence.

The Five Elements' energies spread across the five directions of heaven, categorized into the Five Heavens, hence they are named as such.

A verse says: "Metal [Jin] is associated with Xu [the constellation], and the [star] Wei [the tail star] is at the forefront; Water [Shui] corresponds to Zhang [the wings] and the extravagance of the constellation; Wood [Mu] is linked to Cang [the azure dragon] and the ghost of Liuli; Fire [Huo] aligns with Dan [the cowherd] and the [constellation] Que by the wall; Earth [Tu] is connected to Du [the tail] and the angle position, descending to the operational positions in the heavens."

The monthly chart is depicted.

A verse says: "Jia and Ji correspond to Yin; the remaining years are to be measured. Yi and Geng are to rise with Wu; Bing and Xin are to seek Geng. Wu and Gui are straightforward toward Jia, Ding and Ren again establish Ren."

In Jia and Ji years, the first month establishes Bing, with Bing fire giving rise to Jia and Ji soil. By extending this concept, the principle of establishing influence is all correlated, and each year's monthly celestial virtues can be derived according to this example.[612p]
On the Establishment of the Lunar Months

The twelve branches correspond to the twelve months: thus, the first month is Yin and the second is Chen. In the years of Jia and Ji, the first month is established in Bing Yin; in the years of Yi and Geng, it is established in Wu Yin; in the years of Bing and Xin, it is established in Geng Yin; in the years of Ding and Ren, it is established in Ren Yin; and in the years of Wu and Gui, it is established in Jia Yin. The ten stems are thus established upon Yin. Observing this method, the year of Jia Zi becomes the first, as it is the first in the sixty Jia Zi cycle. Consequently, the initial establishment corresponds to Bing Yin, and the subsequent one corresponds to Wu Yin—this order reveals a clear sequence that can be followed in rotation. In the previous sixty Jia Zi classification of sounds, once the positioning is completed, it again rotates to finalize the record. This is evident.

When establishing the time, the same principle applies to the day stem. If the five periods of Yin years do not reach that year, when the Day of Major Cold intersects with the Initial Qi, the day and time stems that correspond with the year stem are called De Fu, which indicates the balance of Qi, neither excessive nor deficient. This is briefly presented to clarify its application. The diagram is provided later.

Diagram of the Five Tones Establishing the Quantum of Energy

[Illustration]

Song of the Ten Stems and the Transformation of Energy: Jia and Ji are associated with the Earthly Energy of the Soil, Yi and Geng are the Golden Energies. In the years of Ding and Ren, Wood predominates, and in the years of Bing and Xin, Water is sustained. Wu and Gui must seek the Fire Energy.

Song of the Five Tones Establishing the Quantum of Energy: The sound of feathered water reflects the sound of fire; the earth resonates with the horns of wood and the metal of merchants. The year stem defines the quantum of Yin and Yang; the abundant energy is Yang, whereas the lesser is Yin.[613p]
On the Five Tones and Their Operations

The five tones are the sounds of the five elements. The Earth is called "Gong," which corresponds to the years of Jia and Ji. "Gong" represents the Earth. The way of balance and harmony permeates all aspects and is collectively referred to as "Gong," encompassing various formations. It is understood that the Earth connects with Metal, Wood, Water, and Fire, governing the four seasons and nourishing the five organs, all embodying a unified concept. Thus, the five operations begin from the ten Heavenly Stems, with Jia representing the Earth. The Earth generates Metal, hence Yi follows; Metal generates Water, thus Bing follows. In this way, the five elements generate and transform each other, with Jia as Yang and Yi as Yin, alternating in sequence like an endless loop. In Yang years, it is called "Tai," and in Yin years, it is called "Shao." An excessive Yang year is restrained by the Celestial Authorities, while an insufficient Yin year is joined with the Year Branch, both being termed "Ping Qi."

Metal is represented as "Shang," corresponding to the years of Yi and Geng. "Shang" signifies strength, referring to the resilient nature of Metal.

Water is referred to as "Yu," corresponding to the years of Bing and Xin. "Yu" signifies comfort; as Yang energy begins to recover, all things grow and flourish.

Wood is called "Jiao," corresponding to the years of Ding and Ren. "Jiao" signifies contact, symbolizing the emergence of Yang energy in a vigorous manner.

Fire is referred to as "Zheng," corresponding to the years of Wu and Gui. "Zheng" signifies cessation, indicating that when things are abundant, they come to a halt.[614p]
The image of excessive and insufficient balance in energy
See the chart
【Song says: The occurrence is harmoniously arranged. Bright light rises to bring peace and order. Abundance is nurtured to transform the palace. Flowing streams recede, tranquility follows. Firmness transforms through careful examination of commerce. Too much and too little balance the energy’s record.】 【Each line has three parts: first is excessive, next is insufficient, and the last is balanced energy.】[615p]
Discussion on the Seasons and Cycles

Among the ten heavenly stems, there are five yin and five yang. These establish the five movements, which can become excessive or deficient, and mutually interact. In years of deficiency, the overcoming force comes to conquer, due to the emptiness of the cycle. Accordingly, there are certain years that align, and also certain years that correspond in mutual energy, as well as combinations of years and specific days, whereby they merge with the heavenly stems, which can provide assistance and are referred to as harmonious energy, achieving equilibrium in seasonal energy.
