The growth and response of all things must harmonize without precedence or delay, and sages have established names to commemorate this. For example, in the year of Xin-Hai, when the water movement is at play, why is it said to be harmonious energy? Because Xin represents the water movement, and in the yin year, Hai corresponds to the northern water, thus the water energy becomes harmonious.

Similarly, in the year of Gui-Si, when the fire movement is present, it is also referred to as harmonious energy. Why? Because Gui represents the fire movement in the yin, and the year Si corresponds to the southern fire, thus the fire energy aligns harmoniously.

Each year initiates with the onset at the major cold day prior to the year. For instance, in the year of Ding-Hai, when the season's transition occurs, if it coincides with the day of the new moon and resonates with Ren, it is called the Heavenly Virtue Sign; 'sign' means unity, thus establishing harmonious energy. If during the transition the encounter with Ren also represents the Heavenly Virtue Sign, after this initial point of energy overlap, there are no other mutual assistances.

The same pattern applies to the combinations; the so-called unions include Jia and Ji, Yi and Geng, Bing and Xin, Ding and Ren, and Wu and Gui. Further, in an yin year, if the month stem aligns, they complement and assist each other.[616p]
If one encounters the favorable elements without an association with the heavenly stems, it is still a balanced year. If one succeeds the previous winner and again encounters a combination of the heavenly stems, one achieves the rightful position. Therefore, a year of balance cannot be predetermined. The ten heavenly stems are arranged with yin and yang years to facilitate understanding. The balance of the year must be calculated according to the specific day and time of that year. Hence, the year of the Great Horn is termed "Emergence" (Excess), the year of the Lesser Horn is termed "Harmonization" (Insufficient), and the year of the Right Horn is termed "Abundant Harmony" (Balanced). The Great Zheng year is called "Brilliant Radiance" (Excess), the Lesser Zheng year is "Hiding Brightness" (Insufficient), and the Right Zheng year is "Ascending Peace" (Balanced). The Great Palace year is termed "Rich and Abundant" (Excess), the Lesser Palace year is "Low Monitoring" (Insufficient), and the Right Palace year is "Prepared Transformation" (Balanced). The Great Merchants year is called "Strong Completion" (Excess), the Lesser Merchants year is "Following Change" (Insufficient), and the Right Merchants year is "Carefully Balanced" (Balanced). The Great Feather year is termed "Flowing and Spreading" (Excess), the Lesser Feather year is "Dried Flow" (Insufficient), and the Right Feather year is "Calm and Orderly" (Balanced). Each of these years reflects the balanced energy, correlating with the right transformations, without excess or insufficiency. Additionally, during the era of excess, if the energy is suppressed by celestial forces, it still counts as balanced; thus, the record of Radiance includes the years when the cold water governs the sky (Wu Chen, Wu Xu) and the years when the two fires govern the sky (Geng Zi, Geng Wu, Geng Yin, Geng Shen); all are years of balanced energy.[617p]
On the Influence of Tai and Sha Qi

The influence and energy, whether Tai (Great) or Sha (Lesser), are governed by the cycles of time and seasons, which wax and wane. When they reach the heavens, there is a corresponding effect of the five stars diminishing; when they descend to the earth, there is the evidence of the five pests consuming life. The transformations of the five grains, five fruits, five flavors, and five colors vary; is there not one year that lacks any of these? It is merely about the abundance of maturity and the richness or thinness of color and taste. The Five Elements—Metal, Wood, Water, Fire, and Earth—coexist, with their transformations experiencing different states of prosperity and decline. In a Yang year, the energy is strong and excessive; in a Yin year, the energy is weak and insufficient. In times of excess, one who is strong seeks to harmonize with what is stronger; in times of deficiency, one who is weak is overtaken by the stronger energy.

In years of excess, Wood (Ren) aligns with Metal transformation; Metal (Geng) aligns with Fire transformation; Fire (Wu) aligns with Water transformation; Water (Bing) aligns with Earth transformation; and Earth (Jia) aligns with Wood transformation. In years of deficiency, Wood (Ding) harmonizes with Metal; Metal (Yi) harmonizes with Fire; Fire (Gui) harmonizes with Water; Water (Xin) harmonizes with Earth; and Earth (Ji) harmonizes with Wood.[618p]
When the Director of Heaven meets with the Celestial Mechanics, there are circumstances of contradiction and harmony, mutual constraints and assistance. The Director of Heaven maintains its proper order, while the Celestial Mechanics suppresses its natural balance. Thus, when the five energies are balanced and correct, there is no mutual infringement among them.

In years of great excess, each of the five movements governs six years, leading to thirty Yang years comprised of five and six. The Great Horn refers to the year of the Six Ren, encountering the second fire at Zihou and Zishen; thus, the Wood movement is the reverse, with fire occupying the higher position (the child occupies the father's place), which constitutes a reversal.

The Great Zheng refers to the year of the Six Wu, occurring with Cold Water in control. Here, the fire is properly suppressed, making it a year of balanced energies, where the upper feather and proper Zheng are the same. (Wu Chen, Wu Xu represent proper Zheng, along with Wu Wu patterns).

The Great Palace refers to the year of the Six Jia, while the Great Commerce refers to the year of the Six Geng. Occurring with the second fire at Zihou and Zishen, this suppresses Metal, again resulting in a year of balanced energies, where the upper Zheng and proper Commerce match each other (Geng Zi, Geng Wu, Geng Yin, Geng Shen represent proper Commerce, just as Yi You does).

Encountering Water at Chen and Xu serves as a reverse (Geng Chen, Geng Xu), as Water is the offspring of Metal and holds the upper position, thus being reversed. The Great Feather refers to the year of the Six Bing and does not exceed the years where each of the five movements governs six years, resulting in thirty Yin years comprised of five and six. The Lesser Horn refers to the year of the Six Ding, encountering Wood at Si and Hai serves to assist the flow, thus the upper Horn matches the proper Horn (Ding Si, Ding Hai represent proper Horn, similar to Ding Mao).[619p]
In the year of the Ding-Mao and Ding-Yin, when the metal presides over heaven, it aligns with the movement and transforms; thus, the Shang is in accordance with the Zheng Shang.

In the year of the Ding-Chou and Ding-Wei, when the earth presides over heaven, as wood cannot surpass metal in transformation, the earth receives its governance. The upper palace aligns with the Zheng Palace.

In the year of the Jiu-Qi, when the internal enters the Mao and You, the metal presiding over heaven allows water not to prevail against fire in transformation; therefore, metal receives its governance. The upper Shang aligns with the Zheng Shang.

In the year of Ji-Chou and Ji-Wei, when the internal enters the Chou and Wei, the earth presiding over heaven supports the movement; thus, the upper palace aligns with the Zheng Palace.

In the year of Ji-Si and Ji-Hai, when the wood presides over heaven, it aligns with the movement and transforms; thus, the upper jiao aligns with the Zheng jiao.

In the year of Yi-Mao and Yi-You, when the internal enters the Mao and You, with metal presiding over heaven, it receives support in the movement; thus, the upper Shang aligns with the Zheng Shang.

In the year of Yi-Si and Yi-Hai, when the wood presides over heaven, and since metal does not surpass fire in transformation, wood receives its governance; thus, the upper jiao aligns with the Zheng jiao.

In the year of Xin-Chou and Xin-Wei, when the earth presides over heaven, it aligns with the movement and transforms; thus, the upper palace aligns with the Zheng Palace.

What is said about the upper refers to the command of heaven.[620p]
The five elements, with their respective heavenly stems and earthly branches, vary from year to year based on fortunate or unfortunate encounters. For instance, when fire encounters fire or cold water, it generally corresponds to a yang year governing the heavens, while moist earth and dry metal, along with windy wood, typically align with an yin year in celestial governance.

Within a cycle of sixty years, there are various upper and lower influences at play; sometimes the heavens prevail over fortune, other times fortune outweighs the heavens. Occasionally, fortune may exceed what is appropriate, leading to excessive indulgence in areas where one ought to exercise restraint, or the fortune may fall short, avoiding areas where one prevails, failing to integrate its transformation.

As for the celestial symbols of the Great Unity, the annual associations with the heavenly symbols and their respective meetings have been detailed in other texts, so I will refrain from elaborating further.

According to the classics: when energies are in harmony, they synchronize. This includes the combinations of wood and fire, metal and water, water and wood, fire and earth, and earth and metal, all of which promote the generation of lower energies from the upper ones, allowing the heavens to influence fortune. Therefore, they are compatible. When they are incompatible, illness occurs, as seen in combinations where wood and earth meet, earth and water meet, water and fire meet, and fire and metal meet; in these cases, the upper elements suppress the lower, leading to disharmony and illness.

Furthermore, when earth encounters fire, fire encounters wood, wood encounters water, and metal encounters earth, this results in fortune nurturing the upper realm, with lower energies opposing the upper, hence causing minor ailments. Similarly, if wood occupies positions of metal and earth, and fire occupies positions of metal and water, with earth in the positions of water and wood, and metal in positions of fire and wood, it indicates that fortune represses the heavenly influences, or vice-versa; such situations lead to disharmony, consequently resulting in significant illness.

The diagram of the five energies and the great minimalities harmonizing together.[621p]
Five Transformations and Harmonization Song

When the five elements are excessive, it is called harmonization; it can be predicted in any Yang year. If I prevail, and it meets my peak, even if it overpowers me, I shall harmonize it.
【Harmonize refers to wood wanting to harmonize with metal.】

Five Transformations and Compounding Song

When the five elements are insufficient, it is called compounding; it occurs in any Yin year when divination is used. My energy has declined, and the order is right; among them, those that prevail must come to compound.
【Compounding means the strong assimilate the weak, as water assimilates fire.】[622p]
Annual Balance Song

Balance is carefully adjusted over the years, not merely lacking timeliness. In yang years, the heavens suppress movement, while in yin years, movements align with the year's branches. If in a yang year of Wu Chen fire is excessive, and water governs the heavens, suppression leads to balance. In a yin year of Gui Si, fire is insufficient, yet Si belongs to fire; with its assistance, balance is also achieved.

Excessive Five Movements Song

The upper feather correctly corresponds, as Wu fire encounters water energy. The upper Zheng corresponds correctly, as Geng metal's fire movement is. The designation of upper Zheng refers to the years encountering excess or insufficiency, based on the original movement being less; the Heavenly governance energy is above, which might surpass its proper form, thus transforming and aligning perfectly, not merely superior. Therefore, when the self is excessive, the upper part suppresses for balance, hence the upper energy resonates in harmony with the proper energy.

Inadequate Five Movements Combined with Heavenly Support Song

The upper Jiao coincides with the proper Jiao, as Ding movement wood governs the heavens. The upper Gong coincides with the proper Gong, as Ji movement earth energy is suspended. The upper Shang coincides with the proper Shang, as Yi movement metal energy flows.

Inadequate Sound Movement Overpowers with Heavenly Support and Transformation Song

Wood energy movement encounters self, the upper Jiao appropriately aligned. Earth energy movement encounters Xin, the upper Gong appropriately overlaps. Metal energy movement encounters Ding, the upper Shang properly corresponds. When the superior self is dominant, transforming aligns thus, hence the proper sound follows the heavenly governance.[623p]
The dynamics of sound do not surpass the governance of Heaven in securing the rhythm of song.

Why does the upper angle coincide with the correct angle? Fire, along with the transformation of wood, governs the season. The upper palace aligns with the correction of the center palace, where metal accompanied by the transformation of earth governs the energy. The upper commerce naturally aligns with the correct commerce, with water combined with the transformation of metal governing it.

[The self does not return to its origin, as it is dominated by what's superior. When it encounters something that can overpower it, it finds governance above, while itself is entirely weak, hence the center palace also aligns with the governance of Heaven.]

Discussion on the dominance and reversal of the Five Elements.

Someone has said: In the fourth year of Yuanfeng, during the year of Xin You, the Yang Ming governs the heavens for the upper commerce, while the Shao Yin resides in the spring for the lower military. The weather is dry and the energy of the earth is hot. The operation benefits from the lesser wings, but the water of the year does not reach its potential, which is called the record of drained streams, yet the river reverses and floods arise; what is the reason? It is said: The operation of the lesser angle is that the annual wood does not reach its potential, and the one that insults and rides upon it is metal. Metal does not pursue virtue, hence dryness overcomes wind. At that time, the white dew descends early, the energy is harvested early, its transformation leads to desolation, and its disaster causes sudden collapse, named the lesser angle, yet it truly aligns with the year of Tai Shang.

The operation of the lesser military is that the annual fire does not reach its potential, and the one that insults and rides upon it is water. Water does not pursue virtue, hence cold overcomes heat. At that time, cold tears fall, the earth accumulates hard ice, its transformation leads to chilling, and its disaster brings frost and hail, named the lesser military, yet it truly aligns with the year of Tai Yu.

The operation of the lesser palace is that the annual earth does not reach its potential, and the one that regrets and rides upon it is wood.[624p]
When wood does not cultivate virtue, it allows the wind to overpower the dampness. Thus, there are times when strong winds blow violently, causing grass to bend and sand to rise. This transformation leads to stirring upheaval, and the disaster results in scattering, known as the Lesser Palace, yet it is the same as the year of the Great Horn.

In the operation of Lesser Commerce, when the year of metal is insufficient, those who insult and dominate are the fires. When fire does not cultivate virtue, it allows heat to overpower dryness. Thus, flames scorch and char, heated and boiling, leading to melting and destruction, known as Lesser Commerce, yet it is the same as the year of the Great Conquest.

In the operation of Lesser Feather, when the year of water is insufficient, those who insult and dominate are the earth. When earth does not cultivate virtue, it allows dampness to overpower cold. Thus, springs surge and rivers overflow, drying lakes give birth to fish; this transformation leads to sudden deluges, and the disaster results in torrential rains, known as Lesser Feather, yet it is the same as the year of the Great Palace.

By understanding this, one can know when the year is marked by drought in the currents, and when the river breaks its banks, one can draw parallels. It is not just this alone.[625p]
Between heaven and earth, some are born from the cosmic force, while others perish due to discordant energies; none can escape the five elements. The so-called cosmic force merely does not conflict with itself. The so-called discordant energy, on the other hand, causes conflict and recurring strife. When the discord breeds contention, ferocity takes shape, and anger begins to sprout; to seek victory over the other while in this state is futile. Even with strong and valiant spirit, how can one always triumph? Therefore, those who have been defeated await their chance. Thus, when wood overcomes, metal counters to save the earth, and wood fails to thrive; when fire overcomes, water counters to save metal, and hail falls as a result; when earth overcomes, wood counters to save water, and pests do not reproduce; when metal overcomes, fire counters to save wood, and rivers do not freeze; when water overcomes, earth counters to save fire, and grain does not prosper. Those who are violent and lack virtue bring disaster upon themselves; those who insult and ride roughshod over others shall also face retribution. What comes from you returns to you; there has never been a victory devoid of consequence. The subtle victories beget subtle consequences.[626p]
Those who excel excessively will also face excessive challenges, akin to echoes in an empty valley. Therefore, it is said that the energies of the five phases are like scales. The high are suppressed, the low are raised, the transformative respond, the victorious revert, and the balance of energies reflects the mutual gains of the five phases. The victorious reverting signifies imbalance in energies and the mutual detriment among the five phases. When energies are balanced and mutually supportive, it reflects the constancy of the way; when they are unbalanced and mutually detrimental, it prompts observation of change. Those in ancient times who understood this well and adeptly nurtured life never failed to align with the fluctuating fullness and emptiness, managing the divine with the path! They did not lose celestial trust, nor act against suitable energies; they restrained excess without hoping for victory and helped the defeated without encouraging a return. Thus, emotions of joy, anger, sadness, worry, and fear have their boundaries and cannot be disturbed; the spirit, soul, and thoughts have their nourishment and cannot be harmed. Spring winds and autumn rains, winter coolness and summer heat, though the heavenly way often changes, such as during famine or pestilence, how could they result in suffering?[627p]
Seeing the Diagram

Victory and Defeat Are the Same Song

The victory and defeat do not match the years; when the fate declines, victory over oneself will surely add to the mistakes. The mother’s rivalry and the child’s prosperity must return; the child transforms with time and can again achieve victory. Just as in the case of the Ding year, wood does not surpass gold; when pure transformation arrives, fire becomes the return, reversing the heat to win over gold. I follow this pattern.

Discussion on Victory and Defeat

Fate has its ups and downs, and energy has its fullness and emptiness, thus responding to each other according to the years. Therefore, the classics say: "What is surplus should not go forth; what is insufficient thus follows after." Hence, the changes of too much and too little in the alternation of victory and defeat arise. When the excess is too great, the primordial celestial changes occur, with energy winning over reality, leading to the vanquished being afflicted. When the deficiency is too great, the post-celestial changes arise, and diminishing energy leads to those who win becoming conquerors. After being vanquished, one must wait for the right time to return. When returning to what has been conquered, one cannot advance, so one must wait until the right moment arrives for the child to flourish, then the child becomes the mother’s rival again. For instance, in a year of wood with few horns, when the pure metal transforms and wins, the child fire becomes the return; also, the return won is fire winning over gold, thus it is stated that victory and defeat are the same. Reversing heat wins over gold as well. When the fire is scarce in its transformation, and in a year where cold water wins due to the chill, the child earth becomes the return, reversing humidity to win over water. When the earth is scarce in its palace, and wood transforms with the wind winning in a year, the child metal becomes the return, reversing purity to win over wood. When metal is scarce in its commerce, in a year where hot fire wins due to heat, the child water becomes the return, reversing cold to win over fire. When water is scarce in its feathers, and in a year where damp earth wins due to humidity, the child wood becomes the return, reversing wind to win over earth.[628p]
Thus, the statement about victory and recurrence being the same refers to this. The "Yuan Zhu" discusses the six energies, which have the authority of positive transformation and counter-transformation. If the authority of the positive transformation is substantial, victory occurs without recurrence; if the authority of the counter-transformation is insubstantial, victory may occur but recurs slightly. If victory is great, recurrence is also great; if victory is slight, recurrence is likewise slight, hence the saying about the transformation of evil energies.

It is said that the great energies have varying degrees of victory and recurrence. When these energies do not align, it leads to evil energies entering people and illness. However, the energies of heaven and earth also operate in victory and recurrence; thus, the classics state that the initial energy reaching the three energies is governed by heaven, representing the constant of victory. When the four energies conclude, it is governed by earth, representing the constant of recurrence. Indeed, victory arrives, then recurrence follows; if recurrence occurs, then victory arises, thus there is no permanence. When the energies cease to recurrently overpower, it signifies that the life force has been exhausted, hence the phrase about harming life.

Furthermore, if seasonal energies are excessive, those unable to achieve victory suffer from evil. Should they seize the essence and deceive those they cannot overcome, while the energies do not reach those they should overcome, they will be attacked by those unable to be defeated, leading ultimately to the reception of evil, thus misfortunes arise from not having energies superior to their own. Therefore, the classics say that what one humiliates will return as evil; this is what is meant. If this does not happen uniformly, it depends on the climate to differentiate.[629p]

Song of the Transformation of Pre-Heaven and Post-Heaven

When the Qi is excessive, the transformation of Pre-Heaven occurs. When the Qi is insufficient, the transformation of Post-Heaven takes place. The operations and transformations should be refined and distinctive, allowing the Qi to flow according to the appropriate order of before and after. Post-Heaven is influenced by what cannot be reached, while the excessive belongs primarily to Pre-Heaven.

Discussion on the Sixty-Year Guest Qi

When the celestial bodies are in the Spring, the various seasonal Qi marks move in cycles, each governing sixty days and eighty-seven and a half units of time. The guest Qi follows the heavenly decree above the main Qi, hence there arise different transformations: warmth and coolness, cold and heat, twilight and bright days, wind, rain, frost, snow, lightning, hail, and thunder. The warmth of spring and the heat of summer, the coolness of autumn and the cold of winter—these seasonal commands cannot entirely be due to luck and Qi alone; therefore, there must be significant variations appropriate to the time. By laying out these sixty guest Qis beneath the main positions, one recognizes the great principles governing Qi’s location. The celestial symbols of the yearly cycle harmonize and balance the Qi’s branches and stems, where reverse and normal Qi spawn and overcome one another; guests can surpass the host, and calamities can vary in nature. Changes of fortune might either flourish or be stifled, and auspicious omens contrast with disasters, each differing uniquely. When Qi is at its peak, it may become excessive, leading to calamity. Thus, when Qi reaches its utmost, it reverses. This is why the inherited Qi resides below to ride upon it, as referenced in the teachings regarding the mutual fire beneath, where water Qi holds it up. There is also the Qi perceived from above, corresponding to the lesser Yang, where fire Qi governs it, as indicated by the lesser Yin. The principle is that when Yang is at its extreme, Yin emerges, and when Yin is at its extreme, Yang emerges; this is the marvel of mutual assistance. The Qi perceived in this way involves the transformations of the six organs of the body working together. Among Heaven and Earth, Qi accordingly responds.[630p]
On the Six Energies of Heaven and Earth

The energies of the Five Elements and Yin-Yang spread to the eight directions. Indeed, the energy of heaven descends while the energy of earth ascends. The energy of the earth is calm and constant, while the energy of the heavens is dynamic and ever-changing. The source of the six energies is the same, but their manifestations differ. Why is this? It is because the energies of heaven and earth begin with Shaoyin and end with Jueyin. The classic states that Shaoyin is the beginning, while Jueyin is the end. The energy of the earth starts with Jueyin Wood and concludes with Taiyang Water. The classic states, "On the side of clarity, this is the position of the ruling Fire." Therefore, the six energies of heaven, along with the twelve earthly branches, correspond to the Five Elements and transform accordingly. Thus, Shaoyin governs the Zi and Wu hours, Taiyin governs the Chou and Wei hours, Shaoyang governs the Yin and Shen hours, and Yangming governs the Mao and You hours. And so it is.[631p]
The six energies of the Earth combined with the four seasons of Heaven are correlated to wind, heat, summer, moisture, dryness, and cold. The Jueyin (Liver) represents spring, the Shaoyin (Heart) signifies late spring and early summer, the Shaoyang (Triple Burner) governs summer, the Taiyin (Spleen) oversees late summer, the Yangming (Large Intestine) takes charge of autumn, and the Taiyang (Kidney) rules winter. The causes for the start and end of the Earth’s energies are thus.

The texts say: Heaven has Yin and Yang; the Earth also has Yin and Yang, from their mutual presence above and below. The energy of Heaven is dynamic and never still, thus it migrates every five years to the right; the energy of the Earth is calm and maintains its position. If the energy of Heaven does not increase the fire of the ruler, then every five years one energy remains, migrating above the fire of the ruler, because the fire of the ruler does not establish a year.

The cycles of the Earth are complete every five years, while the cycles of Heaven are fulfilled every six periods. When five years pass, the energies of the five elements are widespread; through the six periods, the positions of the six energies are complete, somewhat similar to the interactions of the heavenly stems and earthly branches. Yin and Yang intertwine. The mutual enhancement of above and below conveys the intent of fulfilling their cycles. With the combination of five and six, a cycle is completed every thirty years, leading to a total of sixty years.

This corresponds to the diagram of the interaction of the six energies over time.[632p]
The text describes a diagram related to the movement and changes of the six vital energies. The song mentions the following associations:

  • Wu (Fire position) with Yin (Fire generates) and You (Metal),
  • Wei (Earth resides) with Xu (Water hidden in the heavenly gate) and Hai (Wood generates) as the primary directions.

It further states that the twelve Earthly Branches are divided in half, with the remaining ones seeking corresponding changes.

The transformations are outlined as follows:

  • Shaoyin directly transforms in Wu, corresponding to Zi;
  • Taiyin directly transforms in Wei, corresponding to Chou;
  • Shaoyang directly transforms in Yin, corresponding to Shen;
  • Yangming directly transforms in You, corresponding to Mao;
  • Taiyang directly transforms in Xu, corresponding to Chen;
  • Jueyin directly transforms in Hai, corresponding to Si.

This is the diagram of the migration and addition of the six energies.[633p]

On the left of the spring water Qi is the initial Qi, and on the right is the Five Qis.] [The poem says: If you push for the Four Qis, where do they reside? The dominant should be honored and revered by the ancestors.

Both measure victory by how much each prevails;
It is unlike the usual victory.

The energy manifests in the natural order,
Fortune influenced by energy leads to much celestial punishment.
When minor reversals are witnessed, energy is born anew,
When energy and fortune align, the heavenly signs transcend.

The Rat occupies the Father’s position, leading to reversal.
In sixty years, the main and guest stars oversee the celestial conditions.

Diagram of the Heavenly Signs.[635p]
On the Heavenly Sigil

The one who governs the heavens is the one who directs, commanding the decrees of heaven from a high position; the cyclical years refer to the movement that governs the transformative energies of all beings between heaven and earth, positioned in the middle; while the one in the springs governs the transformations of the earth, positioned below. Within a year, these three energies—upper, middle, and lower—each enact their transformative decrees. When the energies resonate and converge, they align in their transformations. Even without any significant changes, there can be distinct variations in ailments, whether subtle or severe. This is known as the celestial sigil of the year: when the heavenly energy and the middle energy of the year are in harmony, it is called the Heavenly Sigil, symbolizing unity.

Within the twelve years, there are also those that coincide with the five elements of the twelve pitches of that year, indicated as the Great Yin Heavenly Sigil. The term "Great Yin" is a title of reverence. It refers to three connections: the heavenly connection, the yearly connection, and the cosmic connection. During the four years, regardless of whether they are yin or yang years, all are termed under the heavenly sigil as enforcement of law, with the yearly connection enacting the decrees, and the Great Yin Heavenly Sigil representing the noble ones. For those in between, the enforcers of the law may face rapid and severe ailments, while those following the decrees may experience gradual and enduring sickness. For the noble ones, their ailments may come abruptly and lead to death, for the energy decrees are profound among the intermediary ones.

When the yearly connection aligns with the pitches but not with heavenly decrees, it refers to the enforcement of decrees—representing one who does not possess the authority of law enforcement, thereby suffering no rapid danger from illness, but merely enduring it.[636p]
The Diagram of the Yearly Meeting

Discussion on the Yearly Meeting

In a given year, the interaction of the ten heavenly stems with the twelve earthly branches and the five elements is referred to as the Yearly Meeting, which signifies the balance of energies. Therefore, it does not distinguish between yin years and yang years but rather takes the middle of the four seasons—specifically, the first month of the year—as the foundation for the four clear months of the cycle. The positions of Zi (Rat), Wu (Horse), Chen (Dragon), and Xu (Dog) represent this. The earth has no fixed position; instead, it contributes to the flourishing of the four seasons towards the end of each. If there are significant occurrences every eighteen days, then it is said that the discussion of the cycle embraces the zodiac signs of Chen, Xu, Chou, and Wei.

Externally, there are four years: Ren Yin (Water and Wood) signifies yang years, while Geng Shen (Metal) also signifies yang years, making them two yang years. Gui Si (Water and Fire) and Xin Hai (Metal and Water) signify yin years, resulting in two yin years. Hence, the movement aligns with the yearly zodiac signs, which is not considered a Yearly Meeting because it does not conform to the principal decree of the four years.

Excluding the two yang years, the two yin years, Gui Si and Xin Hai, while not designated as Yearly Meetings, also align in their five elements and collectively represent a balanced energy year. The emergence of all things corresponds to a unified cycle; thus, there are no precedents or sequences in timing. Within the eight years of the Yearly Meeting, the four years that align with the deity of weather have already entered the great Taiyi celestial symbol.[637p]
On the Same Heavenly Talismans and Same Year Assemblies

The movements of fate align with the springs; this transformation in the Yang year is called the same heavenly talismans, while in the Yin year, it is called the same year assemblies. In sixty years, there are four years of the Great Yin Heavenly Talismans, twelve years of heavenly talismans, eight years of year assemblies, six years of the same heavenly talismans, and six years of the same year assemblies. If articulated separately, they total thirty-six years; if combined, there are only twenty-seven years. The classic mentions twenty-four years but does not refer to year assemblies. There are variations in actions, degrees of illness, and timings of life and death. By consulting the texts, one can discern these patterns. A "talisman" means a convergence. "Great Yin" is a term of reverence. Only the signs of Chen, Xu, Chou, and Wei preside over the true central positions of Zi, Wu, Mao, and You, which govern year assemblies; the others do not represent the precise convergence. In adverse situations, the Great Yin can lead to sudden death, while the year assembly may result in gradual decline, and heavenly talismans can bring swift yet precarious situations.

Diagram of Same Heavenly Talismans and Same Year Assemblies.[638p]
Here is the translated text:

"Seeing the diagram, the Celestial Talisman of Taiyi and the Celestial Talisman Year: The meeting of the Celestial Talisman together with the year’s branches, the three positions mutually referring to the Taiyi Talisman. When the luck combines with the year branch, it is called the Year Meeting, and the four pillars of Earth must follow the same path. When in the spring coinciding with luck, the Yin is the same as the year, while the Yang corresponds to the Celestial Talisman calling out. Only regarding the Celestial Talisman, what does it signify? The management of Heaven in conjunction with luck is its distinction.

The Talisman of Dry Virtue: Regardless of whether there are diagrams, reading its song will make its meaning clear; thus, it is recorded here.

When neither the year nor the month matches with the Talisman of Dry Virtue, it won’t encounter the vigorous energy and will also be moderate. After surpassing the vigor, the original energy will then appropriately obtain the position of virtue. The year before, during the major cold at the beginning of energy transition, the day’s Talisman combines with the year’s Talisman position. During the transition of energy, if they combine, both will be peaceful energy.

[Note: For example, in the Year of Ding You, if the Wood energy does not prevail, the Metal energy is strong. In the first month, when Ren combines with Ding, this Wood encounters a dominance. In the Year of Ji Mao, if the Earth energy is weak, it falls under Wood dominance; with Metal returning, in the ninth month, when Jia combines with Ji, the Earth returns to its position. After surpassing the previous vigor, it also means finishing after surpassing the original energy. The year, day, and time exclude the beginning of energy transition; the rest may encounter but do not assist each other. Combining means when Jia and Ji join together is an example.]"

On the Channels of the Hands and Feet

The classics state that the five organs and twelve meridians are all connected to the influences of the heavens. This discusses the three Yin and three Yang channels of the hands and feet. The twelve channels run externally along the body's form and internally connect to the organs, corresponding to the twelve months and thus the twelve sections. The five organs are Yin, and the six bowels are Yang. One Yin and one Yang together form a unity, thus the concept of the Six Harmonies.

The Lesser Yin channel, governing the heart and kidney organs, is associated with the heart's element of fire, while its pathway lies mainly in the kidney. Furthermore, the Heart fire presides at noon, and its transformation occurs at midnight, which is why the kidney, as a Lesser Yin organ, is also ruled by it. The five organs are Yin, and it is inappropriate to speak of them as Yang. Water flows from the kidney, so the Taiyang corresponds to the bowels; hence the Hand Taiyang is the small intestine, and the Foot Taiyang is the bladder.

The Great Yin channel governs the spleen and lung organs. The spleen, associated with the Yin earth element, correlates with the Great Yin pathway found in the lungs. Earth generates metal, and thus the fetus resides with the mother, which is why the lung, as a Great Yin organ, commands this relationship. Metal follows the lung; therefore, the Yangming corresponds to the bowels; thus, the Hand Yangming is the large intestine, and the Foot Yangming is the stomach.[640p]
The channel of Jueyin governs the liver and the pericardium. The liver belongs to wood and generates fire. Since the child follows the mother, the pericardium, which is governed by Jueyin, takes precedence. The fire follows the pericardium, hence Shaoyang corresponds to the organs; thus, the hand Shaoyang (San Jiao) and the foot Shaoyang (Gallbladder) are established. The channels of the hands and feet originate from both hands and feet respectively. In terms of the twelve earthly branches, yin is born in noon, which leads to the creation of the hand channels; yang is born in the rat, thus giving rise to the foot channels, serving as a record of upper and lower. Furthermore, the heart and lungs, together with the pericardium, are located above and belong to the hand channels; the liver, spleen, and kidneys are below and belong to the foot channels, which also conveys the same meaning. The organs and viscera share the hand and foot channels, forming a unity. The pericardium is not an organ, nor is the San Jiao an organ. The scripture states: "The zhongwan area is the deputy official, where happiness and joy emerge." Located in the chest, between the two breasts, it is the sea of qi, but it serves as the ruler. The San Jiao functions as the bureaucratic official for the drainage, the pathway for water emerges from here. The San Jiao is named but formless, connecting the heart above and the right kidney below, governing the pathways of various qi, which are referred to as messengers.[641p]
Visions of the Diagram
(Song of the Channels and Organs)
The Sun’s meridian corresponds to the small intestine,
The Yangming corresponds to the large intestine and stomach.
The Shaoyang corresponds to the sanjiao and gallbladder,
The Taiyin corresponds to the lungs and spleen.
The Shaoyin corresponds to the heart and kidneys,
The Jueyin corresponds to the pericardium and liver.

(Affinities of Organs and the Twelve Earthly Branches)
The Rat corresponds to the kidneys and the Horse to the heart,
The Ox corresponds to the spleen and the Rooster to the intestines,
The Goat corresponds to the lungs and the Snake to the liver,
The Rabbit corresponds to the stomach and the Monkey to the sanjiao and gallbladder.

(Complete Collection of Ancient and Modern Books in Medicine, Volume 121)

Discussion of the Six Qi as Illness
The condition brought on by Jueyin leads to urgency in the interior, muscle relaxation, tightness, pain in the sides, softness, side pain, vomiting, and diarrhea;
The condition influenced by Shaoyin results in ulcers and rashes, body heat, aversion to cold, shivering, confusion, mixed emotions, delirium, epistaxis, and blood contamination;
The condition caused by Taiyin presents as fluid accumulation, fullness, disturbance of the middle, cholera, vomiting and diarrhea, heaviness, swelling, and inability to press down on muscle;
The condition from Shaoyang results in sneezing and vomiting, sores, tinnitus, forceful vomiting, inability to retain food, agitation, confusion, unclear vision, sudden pourings, seizures, severe illness, and sudden death;
The condition stemming from Yangming manifests as sneezing, floating and emptiness, skin eruptions, pain in the buttocks, inner thighs, knees, and feet;
The condition derived from Taiyang leads to limited flexion and extension, back pain, sweating during sleep, spasms, and diarrhea that should not be released. These are the illnesses caused by the six qi.[642p]
According to the classic teachings, lust and resentment can overpower one if there are too few principal and guest influences present, revealing varying depths of evil within individuals. Moreover, susceptibility to external forces is simply a matter of one's constitution. Human beings, imbued with the energies of the five elements, are similarly bound by their limits. If one regulates their daily life, fosters health, and avoids malevolence while maintaining righteousness, untimely calamities can be avoided.

However, the seven emotions can internally disturb us, and the six external influences can affect us, leading to numerous ailments and the emergence of various diseases. Additionally, pursuing fame and fortune, indulging in desires, exhausting oneself through labor, and experiencing hunger or satiation, along with exposure to temperature extremes, braving the elements, violating taboos, and undermining one’s true spirit—these factors can surely lead to early death. It is thus to take responsibility for oneself.

The classics state: "If one does not know how to maintain balance, is not timely in appeasing the spirit, and relentlessly seeks to satisfy their own desires, this is what will occur."

Indeed, the malevolent energies of heaven can harm one's internal organs, while the heat and cold of food can affect the six bowels. The extremes of dryness and moisture can damage the skin, flesh, and sinews. Joy and anger can injure one's vital energy, while the extremes of heat and cold can harm one's physical form. Hence, it is understood that the fluctuations of illness stem from within us.

Furthermore, if one is in a year of depletion, loses harmony with the times, or encounters a month of emptiness, then one is more susceptible to malevolent forces. If one is heavily affected by these evils, the risk of severe illness increases. Nevertheless, when the energies of the cosmos interact harmoniously, beneficial influences lead to health; discord leads to sickness. When epidemics arise, impacting one region or another without regard to size, this is indeed a matter of celestial influences. However, if one’s true vital energy is robust, daily activities are timely, and actions do not clash with external influences, even an epidemic will have minimal effect. This is why sages have cultivated methods for promoting life and refining the spirit.[643p]
The text discusses the relationship between the five movements and six atmospheric conditions of heaven and earth and their effects on human health. It explains that a person’s five internal organs correspond to the five elements and the yin-yang energies of the universe, thus being influenced by their fluctuations. Wang Bing believed that the energies distributed by the heavens do not exceed the five elements, suggesting that humans, being within these energies, must be aligned with the way of heaven. Therefore, it is only natural for health to vary with the changing conditions of yin and yang.

The text further explains how the seasonal energies can lead to various ailments, noting specific illnesses associated with each season: cold injuries in winter, heat-related illnesses in spring, summer discomfort, and autumn illnesses. These seasonal energies differ by region, resulting in different diseases. Hence, the text advocates for diverse therapeutic approaches tailored to the specifics of each illness.

Moreover, it acknowledges that certain diseases may occur independent of the annual climatic patterns, suggesting that practitioners should investigate the symptoms carefully without becoming overly fixated on climatic influences.

The "Song of Diseases from the Six Qi" describes various ailments associated with the six qi:

  • Jueyin (Liver) conditions present with soft contractions and urgent pain, nausea, and diarrhea.
  • Shaoyin (Kidney) conditions exhibit cold and heat-related skin lesions, anxiety, sorrow, laughter, delusions, and neglect.
  • Taiyin (Spleen) presents as fluid retention and fullness, heavy limbs, swelling, and cholera.
  • Shaoyang (Gallbladder) issues include throat obstructions, sneezing, nausea, tinnitus, overflow, anxiety, and pain.
  • A sudden attack leads to confusion, blurred vision, dizziness, severe illness, and sudden death.
  • Yangming (Large Intestine) conditions may involve sneezing, rashes, and severe pain in the buttocks and thighs.
  • Taiyang (Bladder) conditions involve sweating, which is influenced by bending or stretching, leading to back pain.

This translation highlights the intricate connection between human health, environmental influences, and seasonal changes as described in the original text.[644p]
On Governance by Law

The energies of the host and guest can both lead to illness. The lower energy is that of the host, and the upper energy is that of the guest. The classic states: The host of wood is addressed with sourness for purging and with spiciness for replenishing; the guest of Jueyin is replenished with spiciness, purged by sourness, and eased by sweetness. The host of fire is addressed with sweetness for purging and with saltiness for replenishing; the guest of Shaoyin is purged by sweetness and collected by sourness; the guest of Shaoyang is replenished by saltiness, purged by sweetness, and softened by saltiness. The host of earth is purged by bitterness and replenished by sweetness; the guest of Taiyin is replenished by sweetness, purged by bitterness, and eased by sweetness. The host of metal is purged by spiciness and replenished by sourness; the guest of Yangming is replenished by sourness, purged by spiciness, and eased by bitterness. The host of water is purged by saltiness and replenished by bitterness; the guest of Taiyang is replenished by bitterness, purged by saltiness, made firm by bitterness, and moistened by spiciness. These are the supplementary and purging actions of the six energies between host and guest. If the guest is victorious, then the guest should be purged and the host replenished; if the host is victorious, then the host should be purged and the guest replenished, responding according to what is urgent and what is gentle in treatment. Furthermore, the classic contains six energies that manage the heavenly influences in treatment for excess or deficiency, as well as methods for medicinal foods appropriate to seasonal changes; thus, each situation is different, and remedies are tailored to the symptoms, following the natural order and regulating with the five flavors.[645p]
For medical practitioners, it is essential to understand the seasonal cycles, observe the physical signs, diagnose the pulse and breath, differentiate between yin and yang, and follow the principles of the classics to provide healing. Thus, there should be no concern about the accuracy of diagnosing ailments. Within the five elements, it is also necessary to address the stagnated energy by using methods to tap into the source of transformation. The "Origins of the Pearl" states that the Sun governs the heavens and should draw from the source of water in September; Yangming governs the heavens and should draw from the source of metal in June; Shaoyin and Shaoyang govern the heavens and should draw from the source of fire in March; Taiyin governs the heavens and should draw from the source of earth in May; Jueyin governs the heavens and should draw from the source of wood in the previous December. This method employs acupuncture to welcome and gather these energies. Therefore, it is said: Do not lose trust in the heavens, do not oppose the energies appropriately, do not hinder their strengths, and do not hinder their recovery. This is what it means to be a master in treatment.[646p]
There are indeed methods for treatment that exist, yet diseases vary in duration and severity, with some being toxic and others not, all of which relate to the principles of treatment. Some might consider that in times of certain celestial influences, when wood is strong and earth weak, one should drain the liver and nourish the spleen and stomach, but this is not a universal principle. Why is that? Can everyone’s organs be the same? For example, if the liver Qi is deficient and the spleen Qi is excessive, under such celestial influences, the liver wood may become somewhat solid, bringing the spleen Qi into balance, thus achieving harmony. However, if one insists on draining the liver and supplementing the spleen, they would confuse what is deficient and what is excessive, depleting what is lacking while reinforcing what is abundant, leading to death; it is the physician who brings this about, failing to recognize their error and inadvertently worsening the patient’s condition. Why is this so? The principles of all things in the world are such that to increase them takes time, while to diminish them happens quickly. If one takes a medicine to achieve an effect, the results will be gradual and mild; but if one consumes something that triggers illness, the response is immediate. Thus, it is evident that while establishing is difficult, destroying is easy; should we not be cautious?[647p]
The Song of Six Qi: Master and Guest, Supplement and Drain

Wood governs sour, drains with pungent;
Fire governs sweet, drains with salty.
Earth governs bitter, drains with sweet taste;
Metal governs pungent, drains with sour.
Water governs salty, drains with bitter,
The six qi's supplement and drain follow the guest.
Pungent supplements sour, drains sweet leads to syncope;
Sweet drains sour, collects the lesser yin's knowledge.
Salty supplements sweet, drains salty, both are soft;
Sweet supplements bitter, drains sweet, gently supports the spleen.
Sour supplements bitter, drains through the lung channel.
Bitter supplements salty, drains according to water's push.
Moreover, bitter's firmness with pungent's moisture,
This is especially suitable for the greater yang.
Though the qi of fire is diverse, its uses remain one.
Wood uses pungent to supplement, sour to drain,
For pungent flavor disperses, thus it supplements,
Sour flavor collects, thus it drains.
The new rectification states this holds a single meaning—
This has not been elaborated upon.
The method again governs qi; it can be infringed or not.
For example, in summer, if it is extremely cold, one can use heat against heat;
If not extreme, it is not permissible to use.[648p]

Song of the Flavors Related to the Five Organs

Sour belongs to the liver, helping to gather;
Bitter, firm, enters the heart, sweet soothes the spleen;
Spicy flavor scatters, can regulate the lungs;
Salty softens, appropriate for the kidneys.

Song of the Flavors Appropriate for the Six Qi

Salty and cold, fire, wood, and spicy cool;
Sweet is warm, regulating the solar season.
For the Great Yin, bitter and hot is suitable;
For Yangming, the flavor is often bitter and warm.

Discussion on Six Illnesses

Understanding the operation of Yin and Yang and the six Qi,
Distinguishing the high and low of the southern and northern seasons,
Observing the victories and defeats of host and guest,
Examining the excess of indulgence and the recovery from depression,
One must first assess the pulse, then proceed to the practice.
If the five movements are insufficient, the victor comes to conquer;
If the five movements are excessive, then the defeated suffer from pathogens.
Heaven and earth’s six Qi interact; when they align, all is smooth; otherwise, it is adverse.
When the Qi harmonizes, there is health; when it does not harmonize, there is illness.
Only the victorious and recovering Qi of heaven and earth,
Is not manifested in evidence; it is the initial Qi and the three Qi of heaven’s victory,
And the completion of the four Qi leading to the recovery of earth.
This is based on Qi, not position; hence, it is not evident through observation of form.
Therefore, one must understand the six pulses.
Thus the classics state:
When the Jueyin reaches, its pulse is string-like;
When the Shaoyin reaches, its pulse is deep;
When the Shaoyang reaches, its pulse is large and floating;
When the Yangming reaches, its pulse is short and thin;
When the Taiyang reaches, its pulse is large and long.
When they reach and harmonize, it is balanced;
When they reach and are excessive, it causes illness.
Reversal upon reaching indicates illness;
Failure to reach indicates illness;
The case of being not reached yet arriving indicates illness;
A change of Yin and Yang indicates danger.[649p]
Those unfit for their positions are ill; those who interchange their positions are ill; those who lose their positions are in danger. This is the principle. However, in human life, although the five elements are complete within one body, vital energy is rooted internally and also ebbs and flows with the energy of heaven and earth. How can this be clarified? It can be likened to the pulse of spring as being gentle, summer as exuberant, autumn as light, and winter as heavy. People experience fortune and energy in life, and it is said they also experience illness through fortune and energy. The classics state: "To go against this will cause transformation; transformation causes illness." Things respond according to their nature, and energy responds according to its nature; thus, one must observe the seasonal energy to distinguish them.

In the theory of common people's energies, it is said: when the sun's pulse arrives, it is robust and long; when the lesser yang's pulse arrives, it is sometimes sparse, sometimes dense, sometimes short, sometimes long; when the yangming pulse arrives, it is superficial, robust, but short. The "Nanjing" cites this and also discusses the three yin and three yang pulses, referring to their superficial and deep aspects as they emerge. The six pulses refer to the interactions of movement and energy, which properly align and respond at the time of their transformation. Therefore, the movement of the pulse does not remain the same; when energies and movements converge at the right time, without exceeding the balance, it is termed as normal. If there is any deviation, one must recognize the illness.[650p]
On Southern and Northern Politics

When utilizing the ten heavenly stems, the sovereign fire does not align with its cycle. Among the six energies, sovereign fire is regarded as the most honorable, while the five movements revere moist earth. Thus, the years of Jia and Ji are aligned with Southern politics, as earth establishes the numbers and connects metal, wood, water, and fire, occupying the center position. The sovereign reveres the south and issues commands, while the four other positions serve as ministers and face north to receive the orders. This creates a distinction, reflected in human meridians corresponding to this arrangement. In the years of Jia and Ji, the two movements face south; thus, in terms of the meridian, the inch is in the south while the foot is in the north. The minor yin governs the heavens, with no correspondence in the two inches, establishing south as the superior and north as the inferior.

This is analogous to a man facing south receiving energy, as the foot pulse is often weak; whereas a woman facing north receives energy and thus has a robust foot pulse, as the yin energy descends, leading to no correspondence. In regards to the positions of the six energies, minor yin is central, with jueyin to the right and taiyin to the left—this cannot be altered. The minor yin governs the two inches of the foot, with jueyin governing the heavens at the right, thus the right side does not correspond, while taiyin governs the heavens at the left, consequently, the left side does not correspond either, based on Southern politics when discussing the measurements.

If one further examines through hand diagnosis, the yin sinks below, reversing becomes floating, and fine becomes extensive. Furthermore, the text states: the opposing inch signifies death, the intersection of yin and yang signifies death. One must first establish the year to understand its energy and observe the responses on both sides before discussing the reversals and alignments of death and life. Further examination is needed to distinguish its reversals, detailing its intersections, and only then is it possible to delve into the subtleties of life and death.

【The song says: Earth, positioned in the south, is called the ruler; fire, metal, wood, and water in the north are the ministers. One must respect the moist earth in its noble position, while the six energies still prioritize the ruler of fire.】

Discussing the physiological influences according to measurements shall not contradict the stated principles.

The text states: When yin and yang intersect, it leads to death. If the year is supposed to be yang, a pulse on the left will oddly present on the right; if the year is supposed to be yin, a pulse on the right will oddly present on the left. When both sides meet, this is called intersection. If the left is solely present, or the right is solely present, it is not responsive and does not qualify as intersection. Only in the years of Yin (Tiger), Shen (Monkey), Si (Snake), Hai (Pig), Chen (Dragon), Xu (Dog), Chou (Ox), and Wei (Goat) occurs this phenomenon. The text states: When measurements are reversed, it indicates death. If the year is supposed to be yin, the measurement should show a pulse at the wrist but appears at the finger; if the year is supposed to be yang, the measurement should show at the finger but appears at the wrist. When both measurements are reversed, it is termed as reversal. If only the wrist appears, or only the finger appears, it is not responsive and does not qualify as reversal. This phenomenon only occurs in the years of Zi (Rat), Wu (Horse), Mao (Rabbit), and You (Rooster). The essence of creation transforms accordingly; thus, qi and blood become chaotic and lead to illness. The text states: Firstly, establish the year to understand the qi; when both sides react, one can discuss the oppositions and harmonies of life and death. This serves as an example, with the same methods applying to other years. Inadequate practitioners confuse cold with heat, treating cold as heat, yet the pulse remains unchanged and heat sickness arises, then they treat heat as cold, yet the pulse reflects this and cold sickness again appears. How can one seek balance under such conditions? The reasons for premature death largely stem from this.

All three yin and three yang energies in charge of the heavens reside in the spring, governing the north-south dynamics, whether on the left or right. The pulse in both the wrist and finger should be downward; if they do not correspond closely, reversing the hand will show a sinking pulse as floating, turning fine into coarse.[652p]
The interplay of the pulse at the wrist reveals death.

When the Taiyin governs the heavens, the yin pulse should ordinarily appear at the left wrist, but if it instead shows at the right, this means the yang pulse has shifted to the left wrist, indicating the intersection of yin and yang, which signifies death. If the left shows only the yin pulse and the right one is absent, or if the right shows only the yang pulse and the left is absent, this does not correspond to the yin energy and simply indicates illness. The same applies to both wrists. This phenomenon occurs during specific years: the years of Yin, Shen, Si, Hai, Chen, Xu, Chou, and Wei.

When the Shaoyin governs the heavens, the yin pulse should appear at both wrists, but if it instead shows at both hands, this indicates that the yang pulse has shifted to both wrists, signaling a reversal, which signifies death. The same applies to both wrists. The interpretation of the pulses remains consistent as mentioned above. This occurs only in the years of Zi, Wu, Mao, and You.[653p]
Song of the Measures and Reversed Pulse

Left inch meets right, right meets left; right chi meets left, left meets right. Two inches alternate with two chi's region, two chi's alternate with two inches' guardianship.

The southern and northern political measures of pulses are unresponsive in their diagrams.

[The pulse being unresponsive refers to where Yin resides, causing the pulse to be deep and thin, as it does not correspond to the original pulse. If one examines with their hands, then what was deep becomes superficial and what was thin becomes large. The measures of the inches and chi's have no upper or lower distinction; the use of 'upper' and 'lower' here serves to differentiate the southern and northern political authorities, where 'Tian' reigns over 'Quan'.]

[The song says: In the southern polity, the inch is above and the chi is below; in the northern polity, the inch is above and the chi below is hindered. The three Yin authorities of heaven do not respond above; at 'Quan' below there is no response. The Tai Yin must examine the left inch and chi; the Jue Yin holds the right hand's measures. The Shao Yin pulse is associated with both inches and chi; this principle is subtle and truly difficult to understand.]

[Note: The unresponsive pulse specifically refers to the three Yin. However, since Shao Yin is the ruler, it governs both the two inches and two chi's. Thus, the Shao Yin presides over heaven, where the two inches do not respond, and at 'Quan', the two chi's do not respond.][654p]
The left hand's chi (pulse) corresponds to the Taiyin, thus Taiyin governs the heavens. If the left cun (inch) does not respond, the Taiyin is at the spring; if the left zhi (inch) does not respond, it is the same. The right hand's chi corresponds to the Jueyin, thus Jueyin governs the heavens. If the right cun does not respond, Jueyin is at the spring; if the right zhi does not respond, it is the same. One should observe the locations of the three Yin, with the governing aspects of heaven at cun and the governing aspects of the spring at zhi, regardless of southern or northern governance; this is the essential principle.

A patient was diagnosed with a non-responsive left zhi and was thought to have exhausted Kidney Qi, facing imminent death. Another doctor examined and found the face to bear Yang, with the qi at the mouth being string-like and elongated, indicating a collective illness from the three Yang of cold damage. The patient also experienced fright from a wind while crossing the sea, leading to blood stagnation and spiritual distress. Under heat aggression, they vomited blood and experienced side pain, thirst, and delirium. A prescription of Xiao Chai Hu Tang was given, with the addition of Sheng Di; after waiting for the stomach to become firm, a purgative was administered, resulting in recovery. At that time, the annual movement of the left zhi should not respond, indicating this is a heavenly harmony pulse rather than an absolute exhaustion of the kidneys.[655p]
Discussion on the Major and Minor Cyclicities

There are major and minor cycles; the major cycle is established by the annual stem and governs the year, which is considered the major cycle. It may begin at the Great Cold or the Lesser Cold, each deriving from the Great Cold day, subsequently generating one another until concluding at the Feathers. Each cycle controls seventy-three days and five quarters, totaling five cycles, which equals three hundred sixty-five days and twenty-five quarters, constituting a year, regarded as the minor cycle.

The minor cycles are governed by the major cycles. In Yang years, it belongs to the Great, while in Yin years, it belongs to the Lesser. The upper elements generate until the Point and cease; the lower elements generate until the Feathers and cease. The mutual generation of upper and lower must rely upon the Great and the Lesser, and must not lose their order.

If the cycle of Jia pertains to the Great Earth, then the upper generates the Great Earth, which leads to the Lesser Fire; the generation of the Lesser leading to the Great is identified with the upper generating until the Point. Furthermore, the Great Earth below generates the Lesser Metal, which in turn produces the Great Water at the Feathers; this is termed the lower generating until the Feathers.

When Jia and Ji combine, Ji derives from the Lesser cycle, promoting mutual generation among the upper and lower.[656p]
In the case of the Yi cycle, the Lesser Metal of Shang gives birth to the Great Earth of Tai Gong; the Great Earth of Tai Gong gives rise to the Lesser Fire of Zheng; the Lesser Fire of Zheng leads to the Great Wood of Jiao. This is also referred to as the upper giving rise to the Jiao. Furthermore, the Lesser Metal of Shang beneath arises from the Great Water of Tai Yu, which is also described as the lower giving rise to the Yu.

When Yi combines with Geng, Geng is influenced by the birth from the upper and lower of Tai Shang. Similarly, in the Bing cycle, the Great Water of Tai Yu above gives rise to the Lesser Metal of Shang; the Lesser Metal of Shang generates the Great Earth of Tai Gong; the Great Earth of Tai Gong produces the Lesser Fire of Zheng; the Lesser Fire of Zheng leads to the Great Wood of Jiao. This is called the upper giving rise to the Jiao. When Bing combines with Xin, Xin is influenced by the birth from the upper of Shao Yu.

In the case of the Ding cycle, the Lesser Wood of Jiao below generates the Lesser Fire of Zheng; the Fire gives rise to the Lesser Earth of Gong; the Earth produces the Lesser Metal of Shang; the Metal leads to the Lesser Water of Yu. This is referred to as the lower giving rise to the Yu. When Ding combines with Ren, Ren is influenced by the birth from the lower of Tai Jiao.

In the Wu cycle, the Great Fire of Zheng above gives rise to the Lesser Wood of Jiao; the Greater Fire below generates the Lesser Earth of Gong; the Earth produces the Greater Metal of Shang; the Metal gives birth to the Lesser Water of Yu. This is described as the upper giving rise to the Jiao and the lower giving rise to the Yu. When Wu combines with Gui, Gui is influenced by the birth from the upper and lower of Tai Zheng.[657p]
Thus, year by year, the principal operations are based on the major cycles. Either the Great Horn serves as the beginning, with the Great Tail as the end; or the Lesser Horn as the beginning, with the Lesser Tail as the end. In total, at each of the major cycle's Horn points, the character for "beginning" is inscribed, and at the Tail points, the character for "end" is inscribed, further indicating to others the nature of the principal operations distinguished by the Great and Lesser Horns and Tails, and their beginnings and ends.

In the years of Jia, Yi, Bing, Ren, and Gui, there is the Great Horn. Wood serves as the initial operation, spanning seventy-three days, starting from the Winter Solstice and concluding thirteen days after the Spring Equinox. The Lesser Zheng Fire represents the second operation, also spanning seventy-three days, commencing thirteen days after the Spring Equinox and ending twenty-five days after the Grain Buds. The Great Palace Earth serves as the third operation, lasting seventy-three days, beginning twenty-five days after the Grain Buds and ending thirty-seven days after the Major Heat. The Lesser Merchant Metal represents the fourth operation, lasting seventy-three days, beginning thirty-seven days after the Major Heat and concluding forty-nine days after the Autumnal Equinox. The Great Tail Water denotes the final operation, lasting seventy-three days, commencing forty-nine days after the Autumnal Equinox and concluding with the Winter Solstice.[658p]
In the fifth year of the Wu, Ji, Geng, Xin, and Ding cycles, the initial operation involves the Lesser Wood, the second operation involves the Great Fire, the third operation involves the Lesser Earth, the fourth operation involves the Great Metal, and the final operation involves the Lesser Water. According to the "Heavenly Origin Jade Book," there is also the guest operation of the year, which functions atop the main operations and is aligned with the methods of the six qi of main and guest. Therefore, it is said that the guest operation among the years typically corresponds to the initial operation of the first twenty days.

On the day of the Great Cold in the years of Shen, Zi, and Chen, the initial exchange occurs at Yin. On the day of the Great Cold in the years of Hai, Mao, and Wei, the initial exchange occurs at Hai. On the day of the Great Cold in the years of Yin, Wu, and Xu, the initial exchange occurs at Shen. On the day of the Great Cold in the years of Si, You, and Chou, the initial exchange occurs at Si.

[These five operations mutually generate and measure the year. Yet, their application is not seen in the texts. From the perspective of the six qi, the operations correspond to their main qi to execute the heavenly mandate. Indeed, the operations of the five elements have one main qi; they should dominate the fourth without fail in the process of transformation. However, the major operation of the year aligns with the main operation of the one year, similar to how the deity of heaven connects with the main operation of the first half of the year. The "Heavenly Origin Jade Book" speaks of the guest of the five operations, mutually governing one year, thus it is clear that the content of the scriptures pertains to the main operation of each year. Hence, one should follow the "Jade Book" as a standard.]

If we take the year of Jia and Ji as an example, we use the earth of that year as the starting point. The five movements follow in succession to the main position, adding year by year as indicated. The five tones are projected upward based on the own cases, with the major and minor being interconnected under certain angles. At the beginning of the angle, it takes flight at the year of the movement, where major and minor succeed in the descending layout. In the year of wood, the angle initially aligns with the major cycle, and the minor next is also linked in descent.
