The excessive movement of the five is purely one transformation; the positive is indeed yang and should not be overlooked. Self-restraint leads to the same transformation degree, while if the movement is insufficient, it becomes negative.

Note: "Degree" refers to the sun. "One transformation" signifies the yang year of the major cycle.[661p]

Discussion on Proper and Erroneous Transformations

If the year of Jiazi belongs to fire, it is associated with heat transformation and is governed by heaven; Jia, associated with earth, corresponds to rain transformation and is governed by movement; and Yin, associated with metal, corresponds to clear transformation and is governed by the earth. Heat transformation, rain transformation, and clear transformation are all essential energies governed by heaven, movement, and earth, hence they are called proper transformations. Moreover, Jia is associated with the positive (yang) and signifies excess; when there is excess, there is neither triumph nor return, hence there is no erroneous transformation. Generally, when encountering a yang year representing excess, the five elements often indicate numerical values; thus, it is said heat transformation is seven, rain transformation is five, and clear transformation is nine.

Furthermore, in the year of Xinyin, associated with metal, it represents clear transformation governed by heaven; Xinyin water represents cold transformation and is governed by movement; and the Zi fire, representing heat transformation, is governed by the earth. Clear transformation, cold transformation, and heat transformation are all essential energies governed by heaven, movement, and earth, hence they are also called proper transformations. However, Xinyin water belongs to the negative (yin) and signifies insufficiency; when there is insufficiency, the transformation of earth into rain will inevitably oppose it. Weak water cannot withstand, and the water's offspring—the wooden wind transformation—will inevitably return to oppose and overpower the earth. Nevertheless, what is opposed by rain and transformed by wind are not the essential energies of heaven, movement, and earth, hence they are called erroneous transformations. Although rain transformation and wind transformation are not essential energies, one prevails and the other is defeated, making it an inevitable principle. Thus, in any year of insufficiency (yin year), where the five elements often indicate birthing values, it is said clear transformation is four, cold transformation is one, and heat transformation is two.[662p]
On the Principal Movement of the Upper and Lower Elements Being Predominantly Lesser

If in a given year, the element of Yang Earth governs as the Supreme Palace, then the Earth of the Supreme Palace is the main focus. Therefore, what is produced by the Supreme Palace and what comes from it both stem from the Lesser aspect, not the Supreme. Thus, what the Supreme Palace Earth produces is the Lesser Metal of Shàng, and what the Lesser Metal of Shàng produces is the Supreme Water of Yǔ; when it encounters Yǔ, it comes to an end. Additionally, what is produced by the Supreme Palace Earth is the Lesser Fire of Zhēng, and what the Lesser Fire of Zhēng produces is the Supreme Wood of Jiǎo; when it encounters Jiǎo, it also reaches a halt. In summary, in the case of a Yang year, the movements of the upper and lower elements are all derived from the Lesser, hence it is said that the Supreme and Lesser mutually generate each other.

Conversely, if in a given year the element of Yin Earth governs as the Lesser Palace, then the Earth of the Lesser Palace is the primary focus. In this scenario, what is produced by the Lesser Palace and what comes from it are both rooted in the Supreme, not the Lesser. Thus, what the Lesser Palace Earth produces is the Supreme Metal of Shàng, and what the Supreme Metal of Shàng produces is the Lesser Water of Yǔ; encountering Yǔ, it ends once more. Furthermore, what is produced by the Lesser Palace Earth is the Supreme Fire of Zhēng, and what the Supreme Fire of Zhēng produces is the Lesser Wood of Jiǎo; meeting Jiǎo, it likewise ceases. Therefore, in Yin years, the movements of the upper and lower elements are all drawn from the Supreme, thus it is again said that the Supreme and Lesser mutually generate each other.

Additionally, regardless of whether it is a Yang or Yin year, one writes an initial character under Jiǎo and a terminal character under Yǔ; for each year, the Wood of Jiǎo represents the initial movement, and the Water of Yǔ represents the terminal movement. This pattern remains consistent year after year, thus forming the principal movement. Just like the principal Qi, year after year, Wood signifies the initial movement and Water the terminal Qi, and this uniformity leads to it being termed the principal Qi.[663p]
Disaster Palace Song:

In years without sufficient fortune, there are positions of disaster palace. The yin and yang align with three, while five associates with the same. The seven numbers are few, mixed with the乙 (Yi) and 癸 (Gui) corresponding with nine, still using earth to support the second position of the Kun. The second is indeed the position of earth, not the number of disaster officials.

Discussion on the Nine Palaces’ Domains:

It is said: In years when the five movements are insufficient, there are positions the disaster palace points to, thus one cannot make a blanket statement about disasters. The classics say: The nine stars hang brightly, the seven luminaries rotate, under heaven's dominion. The nine stars divide the domains, thus in less auspicious years it is said there are disasters in the three palaces; the eastern palace, representing the shock position, is under the jurisdiction of Tian Chong. In less favorable years, it is said there are disasters in the nine palaces; the southern chamber, where the departure position is overseen by Tian Ying. In less fortunate years, it is said there are disasters in the five palaces; the central chamber is under the authority of Tian Qin. The second palace, Kun position, is affiliated. In less advantageous years, it is said there are disasters in the seven palaces; the western chamber, where the joy position is governed by Tian Zhu. In less propitious years, it is said there are disasters in the one palace; the northern chamber, where the pit position is ruled by Tian Peng.

First, it discusses the aspect of fortune's insufficiency. According to the "Heavenly Origin Jade Volume," it states: Tian Peng is associated with water, being the central palace; Tian Rui, associated with earth, is the responding palace. Tian Chong, associated with wood, is the central palace. Tian Fu, also associated with wood, is the responding palace. Tian Qin, associated with earth, is the central palace. Tian Xin, associated with metal, is the responding palace. Tian Zhu, associated with metal, is the central palace. Tian Ren, associated with fire, is the responding palace. Tian Ying, associated with fire, is the central palace. Then align this with the divisions in the nine provinces, namely Yan, Ji, Yan, Qing, Yang, Jing, Yu, Liang, Yong.[664p]
The Twelve Heavenly Stems and Earthly Branches

The first of the Heavenly Stems and Earthly Branches is Jiazi. Yang precedes Yin, following the cycle. If Jiazi is Yang, then Yichou is Yin; Yang marries a Yang partner and Yin marries a Yin partner, as when Jiazi marries Yichou. Offspring are produced, meaning Jiazi gives rise to Renzi at an interval of eight, and Renzi produces Gengchen, all three being of the Metal element, which corresponds to the Zi. The other children have similar meanings. Next, Wuzi Fire produces three generations leading to Wood, Wood produces three generations leading to Water, Water produces three generations leading to Earth, and Earth culminates at three, then returning to Jiawu Metal which produces three generations leading to Wuwu Fire, completing the cycle of the twelve branches, each containing the five tones. For example, in the Zi branch, there are Jiazi Metal, Bingzi Water, Wuzi Fire, Gengzi Earth, and Renzi Wood. The Six Jias encompass sixty tones. The interval of eight does not refer to the eighth directly; for instance, Jiazi to Guichou encompasses ten positions concerning earlier ranks. This is known as the Law of Jia, and in the cycles, it does not reach full application for use.

Explaining the Disorders and Treatments of Qi and Essence[666p]
In the "Suwen" chapter on the Subtle Principles, the Emperor said: "I wish to know the six seasonal patterns of the heavenly way, and how do they reflect prosperity and decline?" Qi Bo replied: "There are ranks above and below, and there are records left and right. Thus, to the right of Shaoyang, the Yangming governs; to the right of Yangming, the Taiyang governs; to the right of Taiyang, the Jueyin governs; to the right of Jueyin, the Shaoyin governs; to the right of Shaoyin, the Taiyin governs; to the right of Taiyin, the Shaoyang governs. This is known as the standard of Qi, which faces south and awaits it. Therefore, it is said to follow the order of heaven; during periods of prosperity and decline, we move and properly position ourselves, waiting correctly—this is what is meant. Above Shaoyang, the fire Qi governs, revealing Shaoyin in the center; above Yangming, the dry Qi governs, revealing Taiyin in the center; above Taiyang, the cold Qi governs, revealing Shaoyin in the center; above Jueyin, the wind Qi governs, revealing Shaoyang in the center; above Shaoyin, the heat Qi governs, revealing Taiyang in the center; above Taiyin, the damp Qi governs, revealing Yangming in the center. This is what is called the root. Below the root, the center reveals; below the revealed, the standard of Qi. The standard and the root are different, leading to various manifestations of Qi. In the "Great Discussion of Essential Truth," the Emperor asked: "How do the six Qi derive from different standards and roots?" Qi Bo said: "Qi comes from the root, from the standard root, and sometimes does not come from the standard root. Shaoyang and Taiyin come from the root; Shaoyin and Taiyang come from both the root and the standard; Yangming and Jueyin do not come from the standard root, but rather from the center. Hence, those that come from the root transform according to the root; those that come from the standard root have transformations based on the standard root; those that come from the center rely on the central Qi for transformation."[667p]
Wang noted: The origin of Shaoyang is fire, and the origin of Taiyin is dampness; since they share the same root, we follow the root. The origin of Shaoyin is heat, which is categorized as yin, while the origin of Taiyang is cold, categorized as yang. Since their roots are different, we categorize according to the sign and then the root. In Yangming, Taiyin is in the middle, and in Jueyin, Shaoyang is in the middle; since the root and the middle are different, we do not follow the signs or the roots, but rather focus on the middle. Hua noted: Yangming is fundamentally dry, with dampness in the middle categorized as yang; Jueyin is fundamentally windy, with fire in the middle categorized as yin. Only these two channels have different roots and middles, thus the treatment follows the root. The officials refer to the six qi as those that move between heaven and earth, implementing virtues and governing policies. As for the years of balanced qi (like Dingyin, Wumao, Jiachen, Jiaxu, Jichou, Jimai, Bingzi, and similar), these are referred to as years of balanced qi.[668p]
Things are born and respond to the meridians; the qi transforms and each attains its normal state. However, if the seasonal qi is excessive or insufficient, there will be changes of victory and defeat, leading to the emergence of illnesses as people interact with the shifting energies around them. In treatment, there are distinctions among the fundamental, the symptomatic, and the intermediary. Although this discussion can be seen in the various writings on the dynamics of qi, it is essentially reflective of the relationships between the classics and the treatment of organ syndromes.

Examining the classics, one finds that the six transformations of heaven, characterized by cold, heat, dryness, moisture, wind, and fire, serve as the foundation, while the three yin and three yang positions serve as the markers. What is referred to as 'the middle seen' reflects the interconnection of yin and yang, mutually influencing each other. Following the celestial order and the timing of flourishing and decline, one adjusts oneself to the correct position and awaits.

In this transformation of qi, reverence is shown; facing south is fundamental, responding to heaven above; beneath this foundation, the qi that is perceived to the north corresponds to humanity in the middle; and below this, the indicators of the lower three yin and three yang are placed, corresponding to the earth below.[669p]
The essence of the sign has not yet become clear. I foolishly speculate on this. The position of the sign corresponds to the six energies of the earth. For instance, the initial phase corresponds to the wind and wood, the second to fire of the two lords, the third to fiery heat, the fourth to moist earth, the fifth to dry metal, and ultimately to cold water. Since the responses below the earth’s energies differ, the influences of the three yin and three yang will also change accordingly. This illustrates the difference between the sign and the essence, leading to differing phenomena in their responses. Furthermore, in the principles of cosmic creation, yang represents advancement, hence nine signifies maturity; yin represents retreat, hence six signifies maturity. Therefore, wherever the essential energy resides, one must closely examine the yin and yang of its original position regarding advancement and retreat, always moving counterclockwise from wood and wind. When it manifests from the energy of the lower sign, it becomes the domain of the sign; thus, we can observe the essence and order of the three talents’ energies.[670p]
When the representative and the original are the same, they mutually represent one another; conversely, those that differ originate from the interstice. For example, above the Shaoyang, the fire is the original essence, and within it, the Jueyin wood winds are observed; the wind serves as the middle essence while the Shaoyang stands as the representative. Thus, from the position of Shaoyang to Yangming, it is regarded as the initial earth essence of the wind and wood, proceeding left in sequence until reaching the lower representative position. At the convergence of the three energies, the fire responds to this, hence both the representative and the original are fire, and thus it follows the original fire. Similarly, above the Taiyin, the humid essence is the original, and within it, the dryness of Yangming gold is observed; dryness serves as the middle essence while the Taiyin stands as the representative. Thus, from the position of Taiyin to Shaoyin, it is regarded as the initial earth essence of the wind and wood, proceeding left in sequence until reaching the lower representative position. At the convergence of the four energies, the humid earth responds to this, hence both the representative and the original are humid, and thus it follows the original humidity. Therefore, the Shaoyang and Taiyin both represent the same essence, which is why it is discussed as originating from the transformation within the original.[671p]
In the case of the Lesser Yin, heat is the origin; when one observes the cold water of the Greater Yang, the cold is considered the central energy, with the Lesser Yin as the standard. The Lesser Yin should retreat to the right, and counting to the left, the final energy of the cold water occupies the position of the standard, and the standard of the Lesser Yin also transforms from cold. This is rooted in heat while the standard is cold, thus wherever the Lesser Yin reaches, it brings forth heat, and the center is treated with cold—sometimes following heat and sometimes cold.

Similarly, in the case of the Greater Yang, cold is the origin; when one observes the warm energy of the Lesser Yin, the warmth is deemed the central energy, with the Greater Yang as the standard. The Greater Yang should advance to the left, and counting forward, the two energies of the sovereign fire occupy the position of the standard, and the standard of the Greater Yang also transforms to warmth. This is rooted in cold while the standard is warm, hence wherever the Greater Yang reaches, it fosters cold, and the center is treated with moisture—sometimes following cold and sometimes warmth.[672p]
The Shaoyin and Taiyang are mutually the principal and secondary, hence they are discussed in terms of their transformation as primary and secondary. Similarly, above the Yangming, the dryness is the essence, while the Taiyin’s moist earth is seen as the central energy, with moisture as the central quality and Yangming as the secondary. Starting from the Taiyang on the left position of Yangming, one moves left in order, until reaching the lower mark position. When aligned with the four energies, the moist earth corresponds. Thus, the Yangming marked also transforms from moisture. This is originally dry, but marked by moisture; hence, the essence and mark are different, and do not follow the essence but are based on the central moisture.

Moreover, above the Jueyin, the wind is the essence; within this, the Shaoyang fire energy is present. Fire is the central energy, while Jueyin serves as the mark. Starting from the Taiyang on the right position of Jueyin, one moves left in order until reaching the lower mark position. When aligned with the five energies, the dry metal corresponds. Thus, the Jueyin marked also transforms from dryness. This is originally wind, but marked by dryness; hence, the essence and mark are different, and do not follow the essence but are based on the central fire.[673p]
The differentiation between Yangming and Jueyin lies in their fundamental nature, considering the transformation through the central energy. All of this adheres to natural laws, which cannot be altered by human intention. In summary: Taiyin and Yangming are connected to dampness; Shaoyin and Taiyang pertain to heat and cold; Jueyin and Shaoyang relate to fire.

Now, discussing the treatment related to Taiyin and Yangming, when the hand Taiyin lung is affected by dampness, symptoms may include wheezing and a voice that sounds as if emerging from a jar; treatments involve the use of herbs like 腾苈 and 木通. Additionally, the foot Taiyin spleen can be affected by dampness leading to fullness, treated with pills like 大消痞丸. Symptoms such as limbs swelling and feeling like clay can be managed with formulas like 胃苓汤. For cases presenting with heaviness in the body and a desire to lie down, treatments may include herbs like 苍术 and 羌活.

Moreover, the foot Yangming stomach may also suffer from stagnation due to water intake, causing chest and abdominal fullness, or difficulties in swallowing water, treated with 五苓散 plus 半夏; in severe cases, herbs like 牵牛 and 甘遂 are employed. The Yangming stomach channel affected by dampness may lead to facial swelling, again treated with 苍术 and 羌活. In the case of hand Yangming experiencing dominance of dampness manifesting as diarrhea, the course of treatment would follow with formulas like 五苓散.

Furthermore, when treating Shaoyin and Taiyang through heat and cold, if the hand Shaoyin heart shows signs of heat and a lack of tranquility in the spirit, treatments may include朱砂安神丸. In cases involving sores or mid-day fevers where heat is present in the blood vessels, 黄连泻心汤 is often utilized.[674p]
If there is excessive heat in the stomach channel affecting the heart, resulting in delirium, it is treated with a formula similar to Da Chengqi Decoction. If there is early heart convulsion due to cold damage leading to fullness and distension, it is treated with Huanglian and Zhi Shi. The classics say: "For abdominal fullness, this is treated by purging internally." If there is stagnation beneath the heart, Da Chengqi Decoction is the primary treatment.

If there is extreme heart fire in the Lesser Yin leading to chills and shivering, this is fundamentally heat presenting as cold, and it is treated with formulas to dispel fire. If there is heart deficiency with cold in the Lesser Yin leading to aversion to cold, it is treated with Ginseng, Aconite, and Red Stone Fat. This is what Wang Taifu proposed to increase fire to dispel yin turbidity.

If there is kidney heat in the Lesser Yin causing seminal emission, it is treated with Pearl Pill combined with Sophora Root Bark. If there is agitation of the heart, it is treated with ingredients like Zhimu.[675p]
If there is pathogenic cold affecting the少阴 kidney channel, leading to symptoms such as dry mouth and dry tongue, the treatment should involve formulas similar to Guizhi Decoction. If there is cold in the少阴 kidney causing body and joint pain, cold hands and feet, and a deep pulse, the treatment should employ formulas similar to Fuzi Decoction. The text states: for a deep pulse with accompanying illness, what is the diagnosis? Qibo replies: when the pulse is present but weak, and upon pressing it does not rebound, with all yang aspects similar, this is the case. If there are cold and heat symptoms in the hands and feet related to the taiyang small intestine and bladder, resulting in frequent, unobstructed, and cold urination with chills and subsequent resolution, the treatment should involve formulas similar to Shengfu Decoction. There may be symptoms such as clear urine, incontinence, or prolonged discharge with turbidity; the treatment should use formulas related to Jiangfu. There are also cases of virtual cold in the taiyang bladder channel with a floating pulse, slight sweating with a dislike of cold, frequent urination, and feelings of agitation; the treatment should involve formulas similar to Guizhi Decoction with Fuzi. Lastly, for heat in the taiyang small intestine and bladder channels resulting in difficulties urinating, the treatment should include Huangbai and Zhimu formulas.[676p]
The scripture states: When the small intestine transfers heat to the bladder, leading to difficulty with the diaphragm and intestines, this is the cause. It may present with symptoms such as painful urination, hematuria, or turbid urine due to heat. For treatment, use Huangbai (Phellodendron), Zhimu (Anemarrhena), and Zhizi (Gardenia). The scripture also mentions: When heat from the uterus shifts to the bladder causing hematuria, this is another manifestation. Additionally, there may be a fire evil in the bladder at the Taiyang region, resulting in redness and swelling in the feet and knees; for this, the treatment includes Danggui (Angelica), Sheng Dihuang (Raw Rehmannia), Huangbai, Longdancao (Gentian), Fangji (Stephania), Cangzhu (Atractylodes), and Honghua (Safflower). Furthermore, in cases of typhoid fever accompanied by chills, fever, and severe headache radiating to the bladder, with symptoms of red and painful urination, this is fundamentally a cold condition presenting a hot symptom. First, use Mahuang Decoction to resolve it, then apply Wuling Powder to promote urination. The scripture states: When a disease arises with excess, treat the root first and then the branch; this is the principle to follow.[677p]
There are also cases where external evil from the excess heat of the Yang channels enters the interior, leading to diarrhea and a clear, watery discharge. This may cause abdominal bloating, chills, fever, headaches, and body aches, with surface symptoms still present. This is fundamentally heat but manifests as cold; therefore, one should first use ginger-tinged soup to warm the body, followed by cinnamon twig decoction to resolve it. The classics say: when illness arises and there is deficiency, addressing both the surface and the root, one should first treat the surface and then the root. This treatment pertains to conditions resulting from the interplay of the lesser Yin and greater Yang due to heat and cold.

Furthermore, regarding treatments from the lesser Yin and lesser Yang relating to fire, if there is heat in the hand’s lesser Yin meridian causing palm heat, the treatment should include substances such as bupleurum, scutellaria, coptis, and forsythia. For conditions such as heat in the lesser Yang's sanjiao organ, the treatment includes three replenishing pills or similar remedies. If heat arises from the left flank causing pain, the treatment should involve substances like Dong quai and dragon gall pills or similar.[678p]
There are also cases where children experience convulsions due to the liver being affected by wind-heat, which can be treated with tranquilizing pills or similar remedies. There are cases of heat in the foot Shaoyang gallbladder leading to a bitter mouth, treatable with Chaihu and Huangqin or similar herbs. When liver heat causes bitterness and gallbladder heat resulting in excessive sleepiness, it can be treated with raw sour jujube seeds and bitter tea or similar solutions. For conditions related to the hand and foot Shaoyang meridians where residual heat causes deafness and pain in the chest and sides, Xiao Chaihu Decoction or similar remedies are effective. In instances of tinnitus, clear air and phlegm-reducing pills can be used. In cases of scrofula, breaking knots and dispersing remedies are appropriate. For rashes, Lianqiao and Fangfeng Decoction or similar formulas are recommended. Patients with chills and fever due to malaria can be treated with Clear Spleen Decoction or similar options. For conditions involving throat obstructions, a decoction of sweet mandarin peel is effective, combined with Fangfeng, Jingjie, Gardenia, Perilla, and Tianhuafen or similar herbs. All these treatments pertain to conditions caused by the interaction of Jueyin and Shaoyang with fire.[679p]
Thus, the "Elementary Learning" states: the liver and gallbladder are governed by fire, and the three burners and heart are no different. The spleen and stomach usually seek moisture, while the lungs and large intestine share this moisture. The heart, kidneys, small intestine, and bladder all follow the balance of cold and heat. This is the essence of the matter.

As for the explanations by the two disciples, they merely interpret the text. For instance, if a position belongs to Yang, it is called Yang; if it belongs to Yin, it is called Yin. They do not understand that the signs involve the distinctions of wind, fire, heat, moisture, dryness, and cold, and can these be simply categorized under the terms Yin and Yang? Furthermore, the texts state that to clarify the relationship between the superficial and the fundamental is to be fully aware of matters; failing to understand this relationship is called reckless action.

The discussion of superficial and fundamental spans from examining celestial phenomena above to investigating terrestrial geography below, and observing human affairs in between. The truth of this path is profound, while its principles are subtle; its applications are boundless, and its implementations must adhere to certain standards. Understanding this enables one to grasp the three principles of heaven, earth, and humankind.[680p]
Medical Laws: Sayings on Qi and Fate

Generally, the physical world has constants and variations. What governs fate are the constants; deviations from what governs are all changes. The constant is like the original Qi, while the changes can be everywhere, thus each has its domain. Therefore, there are variations in responses such as following, opposing, excessive, insufficient, and so forth, each governed by different laws. For example, when the Yin energy is in effect, there is much wind and the plants flourish; this is called following. When the weather is clear and dry without wind, this is called opposing. When the sky is cloudy and the water does not freeze, this is called excessive. When strong winds break trees and there is chaos among clouds, this is called stagnant. When mountains and marshes are scorched and plants wither, this is called excessive. When extreme heat causes pests and locusts to become a plague, this is called recovery. When landslide or earthquakes occur during a time of dust and fog, this is called excessive. And when it is ominously dark with heavy clouds during the day, this is called insufficient.

One must respond quickly to changes as they occur, observing the conditions of the time and place. Even a difference of a few miles can lead to different climates and thus different responses; how could one cling to a fixed rule?

In the yearly cycle, there are dominant Qi and guest Qi. The constant is the dominant, while the external arrivals are the guests.[681p]
The initial energy of the Jueyin and the final energy of the Taiyang represent the regular order of the four seasons, hence they are called master energies. However, the guest energies are not marked, which is why there are many interpretations. Some interpret the year of the Jiazi as starting at the first moment of water, the year of the Yichou as starting at the twenty-sixth moment, the year of the Bingyin at the fifty-first moment, and the year of the Dingmao at the seventy-sixth moment; these are referred to as guest energies. This is related to the four-part calendar system. How does the energy of great cold relate to the yearly cycle? Additionally, there is the fire from the south, supported by water, and the earth from below, supported by wind, which are also considered guest energies. These are still master energies and interact with the six terms, thus they cannot be purely guests.

Generally, what is referred to as guest occurs before the midpoint of the year, when heavenly governance is the master; after the midpoint, earthly governance is the master. The constant energies of the seasons act as the master, while the governance of heaven and earth acts as the guest. Disruption of the master energy leads to sudden harm, while disruption of the guest energy leads to gradual harm. Adjust the master and guest energies to avoid injury and disturbance; this is the method of managing energies.

In the operation of the lesser horn, when the wood of the year is insufficient, and it is insulted and overridden by metal, the metal does not seek virtue, thus it dominates by dryness over wind. At this time, there may be early white dew, the gathering of energies becomes prominent, transformation leads to a chilling disposition, and disasters manifest as sudden drops, named the lesser horn but practically similar to the year of Taishang. In the operation of the lesser tribute, when the fire of the year is insufficient, and it is insulted and overridden by water.[682p]
Water does not cultivate virtue, hence cold overcomes heat; there are times when cold mists gather ominously, and the ground is thick with ice. Its transformation brings sharpness, and its calamity is frost and hail, named the Lesser Proclamation, but in truth it shares the same fate as the Year of Great Feather.

In the operation of the Lesser Palace, the earth fails to keep up, and the one that dishonors and exploits it is wood. Wood does not cultivate virtue, thus wind overcomes moisture; there are times when great winds sweep forcefully, grasses bow and sand flies. Its transformation brings forth expansion, and its calamity is scattering, named the Lesser Palace, but in truth it aligns with the Year of Great Horn.

In the operation of the Lesser Commerce, the year of metal falls short, and the one that dishonors and exploits it is fire. Fire does not cultivate virtue, hence heat overcomes dryness; there are times when fire spreads, scorching and boiling. Its transformation is melting and its calamity is burning, named the Lesser Commerce, but in truth it is like the Year of Great Constellation.

In the operation of the Lesser Feather, the year of water is insufficient, and the one that dishonors and exploits it is earth. Earth does not cultivate virtue, therefore moisture overcomes cold; there are times when springs surge and rivers overflow, and fish inhabit drained marshes. Its transformation leads to sudden downpours, and its calamity is a deluge, named the Lesser Feather, but in truth it coincides with the Year of Great Palace.

Through understanding this, one can discern that the year is marked by drought and great floods, and thus it can be generalized. Between heaven and earth, if the vital energies are uneven and there is no means to rescue them, then the survival of all things becomes quite scarce.[683p]
Therefore, the five elements of wind, heat, dryness, dampness, and cold each govern a specific essence; the five processes of growth, transformation, collection, and storage each govern a specific season. By following the natural order, they can cyclically support one another; by opposing one another, they can cyclically rescue each other. Thus, it is said that the movement of the five essences is like a balance. The higher is suppressed, and the lower is uplifted. The transformative responds, and the conqueror is restored. The transformative responds, evenness of essences occurs; mutual benefit among the five essences arises. The conqueror's restoration indicates an imbalance of essences, leading to mutual harm among the five essences. When the essences are balanced and mutually beneficial, this is the way to maintain the norm; when the essences are unbalanced and harming one another, this is the way to observe change. Those of ancient times who understood this well and were adept at nurturing life, how could they not adjust to the fluctuations of fullness and emptiness according to the path to govern the spirit?

In the year ruled by the Sun, it is advisable to use bitterness and dryness, warming them. In the year ruled by Yangming, it is advisable to employ bitterness, spiciness to induce sweating, cleansing, dispersing, and also using salinity. In the year ruled by Shaoyang, it is advisable to use salinity; it is also suitable to use spiciness and sourness, to permeate, drain, soak, and stimulate, observing the cold and warmth in order to adjust its essence. In the year ruled by Taiyin, it is advisable to use bitterness and dryness, warming them; if severe, it is to stimulate and drain. If neither stimulating nor draining, the dampness overflows, leading to flesh decay and skin cracking, resulting in water and blood intermingling. In the year ruled by Shaoyin, it is advisable to use salinity to soften and adjust the upper body; if severe, use bitterness to stimulate and sourness to consolidate, thus calming the lower body; if extremely severe, use bitterness to purge. In the year ruled by Jueyin, it is advisable to use spiciness to adjust and sourness to moisten.[684p]
The year begins with Yang. In the first month (Yin), it signifies the initiation. The energy of Lesser Yang starts beneath the spring, pulling Yang upward into the realm above Heaven, Earth, and humanity. At this time, all grains and plants have begun to sprout. By the time of the Lesser Yin of summer, the fire blazes in the vast emptiness, leading to flourishing vegetation, hanging branches, and spreading leaves, which exemplifies the use of Yang and the essence of Yin. This illustrates how Heaven produces Yang to nourish Yin.

The text states that before the midpoint of the year, the weather is governed by the ascending and floating energy. When autumn arrives, the operation of Great Yin begins from Heaven and descends, bringing forth阴 (Yin) that penetrates the earth. Consequently, metal stirs into dryness, winds become fierce, and frost descends, leading to the demise of various entities, leaving only barren branches, similar to the fur of a beast. In winter, the energy of Lesser Yin again lies dormant beneath the springs, with ice splitting the ground, and all things densely packed—this shows the application of Yin and the essence of Yang. This illustrates how the earth uses Yang to subdue and hide Yin.

The text mentions that after the midpoint of the year, the earth’s energy governs the descent and consolidation. In the great discussions of the celestial origins, it is stated that the branches and stems of the year manage the six energies, which clearly deviate from the teachings of the ancient sages. The branches and stems of the year are uniform across the world and invariant across the four seasons. The warmth, heat, cold, and coolness of the weather, the illnesses of the populace, the variations in the four directions, and the differences in the hypotheses of spring, summer, autumn, and winter—how could they all be the same? Such fallacies are evident.[685p]
In recent times, the treatment for typhus is primarily based on the celestial stems and branches corresponding to the day of illness, which also derives from this principle. It must not be used indiscriminately. The energies of metal, wood, water, fire, and earth each govern a specific season—during their season, they are the dominant energy, presiding over the heavens; if their energy is present out of season, it is considered foreign energy; and if it is directly opposed to the season, it is termed as lying in the spring, meaning its energy is hidden beneath the yellow spring and thus not visible.

The treatment method involves using warmth for warmth and using cold for cold, as it is essential to acknowledge the seasonal energies and not disturb the harmony of the heavens. In spring, the wood energy presides, making all directions warm; in summer, the fire energy presides, making all directions hot; during the transition from summer to autumn, the earth energy presides, making all directions humid; in autumn, everything becomes cool; and in winter, everything becomes cold. The illnesses of the people often arise from this, which is an easily observable principle. Energies that oppose the season are termed foreign energies. Therefore, the treatment has concepts of using the opposing nature of energies. Observing this, the theory of circulating energies is indeed considerable.

For instance, the transformation of Taiyin rain is applied to the Yangming; the cold transformation of the Yangming is applied to the Shaoyin; the heat transformation of the Shaoyin is applied to the Yangming; the dryness transformation of the Yangming is applied to the Jueyin; and the windy transformation of the Jueyin is applied to the Taiyin. All excesses that prevail in us are our reality. Reality is true evil. Conversely, successes that prevail in others indicate our deficiency. Deficiency is false evil.[686p]
The distinction between the six vital energies refers to the concepts of existence and non-existence. However, although the movement of celestial bodies and vital energies can be categorized into five or six, the application of yin and yang boils down to water and fire alone. Therefore, when yang prevails, yin suffers, and when yin is dominant, yang suffers. One should drain the excess energy, addressing its presence, and nurture the depleted energy, addressing its absence. By seeking the fundamental source and probing its deeper meanings, resolving difficulties becomes as easy as picking up a stray hair.

If one does not understand the principles of order and disorder, fullness and emptiness, and instead firmly holds onto fixed ideas, it is like facing east yet not seeing the west wall, or facing south yet not perceiving the north. Observing a single curve does not allow for discussions on transformation, and focusing on one moment does not permit conversations about the larger picture, which inevitably leads to confusion and harm.

Among the six vital energies, three belong to yin: dampness, dryness, and cold. Two belong to yang: wind and heat. If fire lacks the transformative nature of the monarch, then yin overshadows yang, leading to death over life; thus, these two types of fire are essential. If one merely acknowledges the existence of two fires and concludes that yang is always excessive while focusing solely on its suppression, it disrupts the harmony of the heavens and undermines the foundation of life—nothing is worse than this. Such profound principles merit careful examination by scholars.

Wherever the three yang energies reside, there is an abundance of energy within those channels. Conversely, wherever the three yin energies are found, some channels may be unresponsive due to the deficiency in yang energy, indicating a lack of vitality.[687p]
In the arrangement of the three Yin, only the Lesser Yin stands alone in the center; this is the Yin among Yin. Therefore, the position of the Lesser Yin is one of non-response. In essence, it corresponds to the emptiness of heaven and earth; is it not said that the ruler oversees affairs? The principle of the five actions of overcoming and replenishing arises spontaneously. All things in heaven and earth inevitably reflect the five actions. If excess harms the regulation, how can it not take form? Thus, seeking within humanity, the five viscera balance each other, the five desires overcome each other, the five energies shift among themselves, and the five diseases transform into one another. Therefore, when fire is at its peak, cold arises; when cold is at its peak, dampness arises; when dampness is at its peak, wind arises; when wind is at its peak, dryness arises; and when dryness is at its peak, heat arises. This is all part of their transformation. The regulation in heaven and earth arises from the natural flow of energies, and it exists in humanity as well, where it pertains to the gains and losses of guidance and application. If one can understand its subtleties and grasp its principles, then control lies within oneself—what harm could there be? If the distinctions of prosperity and decline in regulation are unclear, and one cannot discern the true from the false, then chaos may indeed be anticipated.

Thus, when those of the Sun encounter flowing cycles, and those of the Moon meet with radiant epochs, the strong have regulation while the weak find support; the energies achieve their balance—what illness could there be? If the strong Yang encounters fire, then fierce heat arises; if cold Yin meets water, then frost and ice ensue. Heaven has its heavenly signs, the year has its yearly meetings; how can humanity obtain harmony without others?[688p]
Explanation of the Laws in the "Inner Canon"

The emergence of various diseases often stems from their root causes. The effects of the six qi can manifest either in the exterior or the interior. For instance, when there is cold water in the Taiyang, it is inherently cold while the exterior is hot; in the case of Shaoyin, the governing fire is intrinsically hot while the exterior is cold. Treatment may focus either on the root or the exterior, depending on the differentiation of cold and heat.

For the Shaoyang, the fire transforms into the root; for the Taiyin, the damp earth transforms into the root. Treatment should target the essence of the fire and dampness rather than the exterior signs of Shaoyang and Taiyin. In the Yangming, the dry metal transforms from dryness as the root; the Yangming represents the exterior. In the Jueyin, the wind wood transforms from wind as the root; the Jueyin represents the exterior. Treatment should not focus on the exterior signs but rather on the interior, which reflects the central qi.

Indeed, Yangming and Taiyin are interrelated, with their energies communicating internally; thus, treatment for dry metal is derived from the internal energy of damp earth. Likewise, Jueyin and Shaoyang are interrelated, actively interacting internally; therefore, treatment for wind wood is derived from the internal energy of corresponding fire. Furthermore, due to the incongruence between the exterior and the root energies in these two channels, treatment should be confirmed by the internal energies.[689p]
If we consider the interaction of the sun and the lesser yin as interdependent forces perceived in the environment, there are clearly distinct states of cold and heat that can be understood without seeking them internally. As for diseases, they all require treatment at their root. However, when it comes to issues of fullness and the difficulties of urine and feces, these are treated at the surface level. Fullness indicates a distended stomach; if the stomach is full, the energies of food and medicine cannot circulate, leading to a disruption in the organs and their functions. Thus, when unable to address the root, one must first treat the surface, as addressing the surface becomes fundamentally important.

When it comes to difficulties with urination and defecation, this signals an urgent condition. Among various diseases, there is none more pressing than this, so it must be treated first. Without addressing this, one cannot effectively manage other symptoms.

Additionally, the indicators of disease and their underlying causes differ. When a disease arises in excess, it inevitably affects other organs and energies; thus, one should treat the root first to prevent it from impacting other aspects. Conversely, when a disease arises from deficiency, it is likely to be burdened by other organs and energies, necessitating surface treatment first to avoid further complications to the primary organ or energy affected.

Just as in the case of diseases being the root and treatment methods being the surface, if practitioners do not assess the severity of the illness, and if the illness does not discriminate based on the efficacy of the treatment, then the relationship between root and surface becomes muddled. Hence, this summary aims to clarify these concepts.[690p]
The Principle of Treating Illness Without Considering the Annual Qi

In treating illness, if one does not understand the waxing and waning of annual qi, or the true and false vitality of the person's qi, then the responsibility lies with the physician for mismanaging the balance of the pathology and the healthy state. Not knowing how the year influences qi's intensity or decline, nor understanding the origins of true or false vitality, renders one unskilled in the art. Indeed, without awareness of the annual cycles, one cannot grasp the fluctuations of human vitality.

If one neglects the timing and reverses the conditions, without distinguishing between the five phases, internal pathologies arise, and the physician cannot guard against them. Treating illness without recognizing the presence or absence of qi, and failing to recognize the proper timing, leads to a muddling of the seasonal influences, with no clarity in understanding their fluctuations. If harmful pathogens arise internally and afflict the individual, despite the physician's efforts, they will be unable to prevent it due to ignorance of the timing and qi.

Not understanding the relationship between the four seasons and the five elements, nor how they interact and counteract one another, leads to misconceived treatments that attack the wrong conditions and undermine a person’s true vitality, ultimately risking their life unknowingly. Therefore, it is crucial to prioritize the annual qi; one should not disrupt the heavenly harmony.[691p]
There is no excess or deficiency; neglecting this can lead to calamity for people. Do not cause harm or lose what is proper, as this leads to the end of longevity for individuals. This is what the "Inner Canon" warns about in earnest; can learners not seek teachers to clarify? Indeed, the year has six seasonal energies that govern, with the southern and northern influences. Knowing these six energies, one can correspond to the pulse in dimension. In the case of the Taiyin, the pulse is deep; for Shaoyin, it is hooked; for Jueyin, it is taut; for Taiyang, it is large and long; for Yangming, it is short and slippery; for Shaoyang, it is large and superficial. This reveals that the six pulses reflect the harmony of heaven. Those who do not understand call them disease pulses, attacking cold to incite heat, but the pulse remains unchanged while heat sickness arises. Controlling heat to induce cold keeps the pulse the same, yet cold sickness occurs again. How can one seek harmony under such circumstances? The origins of untimely deaths often stem from this. Ignoring true conditions and merely attacking, whether in cases of excess or deficiency, invites harm and loses the proper balance, resulting in calamity and the cessation of longevity for individuals.[692p]
Recipe

Aconite and Cornelian Cherry Decoction. In the Year of the Six Jias, during the prosperous season, this formula is suitable for the illness. Aconite and Cornelian cherry, each one and a half qian; Pinellia and nutmeg, each one and two and a half fen; Chinese quince and dark plum, each one qian; clove and patchouli, each seven and a half fen. Grind and prepare into a pill. Add seven slices of ginger and two jujubes, then boil in water and take.

Coptis and Poria Decoction. In the Year of the Six Bings, during the expansive season, this formula is suitable for the illness. Coptis and red poria, each one and two and a half fen; Ophiopogon and plantago seeds, each five and a half fen. Grind and prepare into a pill. Add seven slices of ginger and two jujubes, then boil in water and take.

Ophiopogon Decoction. In the Year of the Six Wus, during the bright season, this formula is suitable for the illness. Ophiopogon, white peony, Pinellia, bamboo leaves, milk vetch powder, mulberry bark, aster root, and ginseng, each one qian; licorice five and a half fen. Grind and prepare into a pill. Add three slices of ginger and two jujubes, then boil in water and take.

Achyranthes and Chinese Quince Decoction. In the Year of the Six Gengs, during the solidifying season, this formula is suitable for the illness. Achyranthes and Chinese quince, each one qian; white peony, eucommia, goji berries, dodder, Huang Songjie, and Gastrodia, each seven and a half fen; licorice five and a half fen. Grind and prepare into a pill. Add three slices of ginger and two jujubes, then boil in water and take.

Poria and Atractylodes Decoction. In the Year of the Six Rens, during the time of emergence, this formula is suitable for the illness.[693p]
White Poria, White Atractylodes, Magnolia Bark, Green Peel, Dried Ginger, Half Summer, Grass Fruit, and Licorice, each one qian. Grind them together to make a paste, add three slices of ginger and two dates, and decoct in water to take.

Ziwantang: In the Year of the Six Yis, during the period of change, this formula is suitable for treating illnesses of this type.
Purple Aster, White Peony, Ginseng, Astragalus, Rehmannia, Apricot Kernels, White Mulberry Bark, and Licorice, each one qian. Grind them together to make a paste, add three slices of ginger and one date, and decoct in water to take.

Cistanche and Achyranthes Decoction: In the Year of the Six Dings, during the period of harmony, this formula is suitable for treating illnesses of this type.
Meat Cistanche, Achyranthes, Papaya, White Peony, Cooked Rehmannia, Dong Quai, and Licorice, each one qian. Grind them together to make a paste, add three slices of ginger and one black plum, and decoct in water to take.[694p]
White Atractylodes and Magnolia Bark Decoction: In the year of Six Ji, during the reign of the Venerable Supervisor, this is suitable for the illness. Ingredients: White Atractylodes, roasted Magnolia Bark, processed Pinellia, cinnamon heart, and Pogostemon, each one qian; roasted Dried Ginger and honey-fried Licorice, each five fen. Grind these together into a paste, add three slices of ginger and two jujubes, then boil in water and take.

Schisandra Decoction: In the year of Six Xin, during the period of drought, this is suitable for the illness. Ingredients: Schisandra, prepared Aconite, Morinda Officinalis, deer antler, Wild Chinese Wolfberry, cooked Rehmannia, and roasted Eucommia, each one qian. Grind these together into a paste, add seven slices of ginger and a small amount of salt, then boil in water and take.

Astragalus and Poria Decoction: In the year of Six Gui, during the time of Hidden Illumination, this is suitable for the illness. Ingredients: Astragalus, Poria, Polygala, purple river worm, and fried jujube seed, each one qian. Grind these together into a paste, add three slices of ginger and two jujubes, then boil in water and take.

Upright Yang Decoction: In the year of the Rat and Horse, this is suitable for the illness.[695p]
Bai Wei, Yuan Shen, Chuan Xiong, Sang Bai Pi, Dang Gui, Bai Shao Yao, Xuan Fu Hua, and Gan Cao (processed) each one qian. Grind together to make a paste, add five slices of ginger, and decoct in water for consumption. Bei Hua Decoction is suitable for the Year of the Earth Pig and Goat; for illnesses, this should be used as the primary remedy.

Mu Guo and Fu Shen each one and a half qian, Niu Xi and Fu Zi (processed) each one and two-fifths qian, Shu Di Huang and Fu Pen Zi each one qian, and Gan Cao seven-fifths qian. Grind together to make a paste, add five slices of ginger, and decoct in water for consumption. Sheng Ming Decoction is suitable for the Year of the Tiger and Monkey; for illnesses, this should be used as the primary remedy.

Zi Tan Xiang, Che Qian Zi (stir-fried), Qing Pi, Ban Xia (processed), Suan Zao Ren, Qiang Wei, and Gan Cao each one qian. Grind together to make a paste, add five slices of ginger, and decoct in water for consumption. Shen Ping Decoction is suitable for the Year of the Rabbit and Rooster; for illnesses, this should be used as the primary remedy.[696p]
Yuan Zhi and Zi Tan Xiang, each one and a half taels; Tian Men Dong and Shan Zhu Yu, each one qian and two and a half fen; Bai Zhu, Bai Shao Yao, and Gan Cao, each one qian. Grind together to make a plaster, add five slices of ginger, and decoct in water for consumption. Jing Shun Tang: In the years of Chen and Xu, this is suitable for this condition.

Bai Fu Ling and Mu Guo, each one qian and two and a half fen; Fu Zi (prepared) and Niu Xi, each one qian; Fang Feng, He Zi, Gan Jiang (prepared), and Gan Cao (roasted), each seven and a half fen. Grind together to make a plaster, decoct in water for consumption. Fu He Tang: In the years of Si and Hai, this is suitable for this condition.

Ban Xia, Wu Wei Zi, Zhi Shi, Bai Fu Ling, He Zi, Chen Pi, Gan Jiang (prepared), and Gan Cao (roasted), each one qian. Grind together to make a plaster, add two dates, and decoct in water for consumption. Huo Bing Tang: This treats excessive wind and dryness.

Tian Nan Xing, two and a half taels; Jie Geng, seven and a half qian; Zhi Zi Ren, one tael; these three enter the Tai Yin Lung channel, helping to clear dryness and control wind. Huang Lian, eight and a half qian; this one enters the Shao Yin Heart channel, draining fire and suppressing the mother greatly; the mother refers to wood, and this indeed drains its child. Qing Pi, two and a half qian, draws various herbs to the place of excessive wind. Fang Feng, three qian; Bo He, one qian, disperse the wind’s force. Grind to a coarse powder, take seven and a half qian, mix with one large cup of water, three slices of ginger, decoct for seven minutes, strain and take warm.

Feng Bing Tang: This treats excessive water and humidity.[697p]
Cangzhu (Atractylodes) - 2 taels, soaked in rice water overnight, stir-fried; Baizhu (White Atractylodes) - 2.5 taels, stir-fried; Fen (Fried Licorice) - 5 qian, baked; these three ingredients enter the Taiyin spleen meridian, assisting Earth to control excessive Water.

Wuzhuyu (Evodia) - 5 qian, Ganjiang (Dried Ginger) - 5.7 qian; these two ingredients enter the Jueyin liver meridian, draining Wood to restrain excessive Mother, and the Mother here refers to Water; this approach drains its offspring.

Fuzi (Aconite) - 1 qian, processed to guide all herbs to the domain of Water. The above is prepared as a coarse powder, taken at 7 qian, with 1 large date, 1 cup of water, decocted to 7 parts, strained, and taken warm. This is the Wenbing decoction, used to treat when Fire overcomes Cold.

Huangbo (Huangbai) - 2.5 taels, stir-fried in salt water; Zhimu (Anemarrhena) - 1 tael; these two herbs enter the Shaoyin kidney meridian, assisting Cold transformation to control excessive Fire.

Huangqin (Scutellaria) - 5 qian, stir-fried in alcohol; Zhizi (Gardenia fruit) - 4 qian; these two herbs enter the Taiyin spleen meridian, aiding Damp transformation to restrain excessive Mother.

Huanglian (Coptis) - 1 qian, treated with ginger juice, guiding all herbs to the domain of overwhelming Fire. The above is prepared as a coarse powder, taken at 7 qian, with 7 lantern hearts, 5 lotus seeds, and 1 cup of water, decocted to 7 parts, taken warm. This is the Zaobing decoction, used to treat when Earth overcomes Wind.[698p]
For the first recipe:

One tael of Ligusticum wallichii, stir-fried in rice vinegar. One and a half taels of Angelica sinensis, washed in wine; these two ingredients enter the Liver channel of Jueyin, assisting in transforming wind to eliminate dampness. One tael of 南星 (Nanzheng), steamed seven times. Seven qian of mulberry root fried with honey; these two ingredients drain dryness to counteract the mother. Five pieces of jujube to guide the other herbs to the humid region. Eight qian of River herb to disperse dampness.

The above is to be ground into a coarse powder. Each dose consists of seven qian, five slices of ginger, one cup of water, boiled down to seven parts, and taken warm. This is known as the Cold-Syndrome Decoction.

For the second recipe:

Two taels of cinnamon, entering the Heart channel of Shaoyin, assist in transforming heat to control excessive metal. One and a half taels of Angelica sinensis, washed in wine, support wood to generate fire to address excessive dryness. One tael of Alisma, entering the Kidney channel of Shaoyin, dispels cold to suppress the mother element. Six qian of Angelica pubescens; used together with Alisma. Three and a half qian of Platycodon to guide the other herbs to the area dominated by dryness.

The above is also to be ground into a coarse powder. Each dose consists of six qian, one cup of water, boiled down to seven parts, and taken warm. Discontinue if dryness eases.

For the third recipe:

Three taels of Asparagus, heart removed, immersed in pure honey water. Two and a half taels of Rehmannia glutinosa, washed in wine, entering the Yin essence, assisting water to transform excessive heat. Five qian of Bupleurum, two qian each of Forsythia and Scutellaria; these two ingredients enter the fog area, suppressing excess. Two qian each of Lycium bark and Coptis, these two guide the other herbs to the area dominated by heat.

The above is to be ground into a coarse powder. Each dose consists of seven qian, a pinch of duckweed, one cup of water, boiled down to seven parts, and taken warm.[699p]

Original

古今图书集成医部全录卷一百十一

运气门

　　　　黄帝素问

　　　　　五运行大论

　　黄帝坐明堂，始正天纲，临观八极，考建五常。　　【注　天纲，天之度数也。八极，地之八方也。五常，五行政令之常也。】　　请天师而问之曰：论言天地之动静，神明为之纪。阴阳之升降，寒暑彰其兆。　　 【注　神明者，日月斗星也。纪者，以日月纪度星斗定位也。寒暑者，阴阳之征兆也。】　　余闻五运之数于夫子，夫子之所言，正五气之各主岁尔。首甲定运，余因论之。鬼臾区曰：土主甲己，金主乙庚，水主丙辛，木主丁壬，火主戊癸。[1p]
子午之上，少阴主之；丑未之上，太阴主之；寅申之上，少阳主之；卯酉之上，阳明主之；辰戌之上，太阳主之；巳亥之上，厥阴主之。不合阴阳，其故何也？　　 【注　余闻五运之数于夫子者，言五运之气，已论于六节脏象论中矣，余因论之。鬼臾区复以五运六气相合主岁而论者，即天元纪大论也。不合阴阳者，五运六气之阴阳不相合也。】　　岐伯曰：是明道也。此天地之阴阳也。夫数之可数者，人中之阴阳也。然所合数之可得者也。夫阴阳者，数之可十，推之可百，数之可千，推之可万。[2p]
天地阴阳者，不可以数推，以象之谓也。　　 【注　伯言臾区所论五运六气相合而主治者，是明天地阴阳之道也。夫数之可数者，人中之阴阳也。所谓人中之阴阳者，其生五，其气三。三而成天，三而成地，三而成人。三而三之，合则为九。九分为九野，九野为九脏，以应天六六之节，此人中之阴阳与天地相合，其所合之数，可得而数者也。若夫天地之阴阳者，数之可十、可百，推之可千、可万，难以数推，止可以象。[3p]
推之象者，即下文之丹、黅、苍、素、元之天象，南面、北面之图象是也。】　　帝曰：愿闻其所始也。岐伯曰：昭乎哉问也！臣览《太始天元册》文：丹天之气，经于牛、女、戊分；黅天之气，经于心、尾、己分；苍天之气，经于危、室、柳、鬼；素天之气，经于亢、氐、昴、毕；元天之气，经于张、冀、娄、胃。所谓戊己分者，奎、璧、角、轸，则天地之门户也。夫候之所始，道之所生，不可不通也。　　【注　此言五行之化，运始于五方之天象也。丹，赤色，火之气也。牛、女在癸度，经于牛、女戊分，戊癸合而化火也。黅，黄色，土之气也。[4p]
心、尾在甲度，经于心、尾，己分，甲己合而化土也。苍，青色，木之气也。危、室在壬度，柳、鬼在丁度，丁壬合而化木也。素，白色，金之气也。亢、氐在乙度，昴、毕在庚度，乙庚合而化金也。元，黑色，水之气也。张、冀在丙度，娄、胃在辛度，丙辛合而化水也。戊己居中宫，为天地之门户。《遁甲经》曰：六戊为天门，六己为地户，在奎、璧、角、轸之分。奎、璧在干方，角、轸在巽方，此五气化为五行之始，乃天地阴阳道之所生，不可不通也。】　　帝曰：善。[5p]
论言天地者，万物之上下，左右者，阴阳之道路。未知其所谓也。　　 【注　此复论六气之上下左右也。司天在上、在泉、在下，万物化生于其间，故天地为万物之上下。左右者间气也，间气者纪步，故为阴阳之道路。】　　岐伯曰：所谓上下者，岁上下见，阴阳之所在也。　　 【注　此言司天在泉之上下也。如子午岁，少阴在上，则阳明在下；丑未岁，太阴在上，则太阳在下；寅申岁，少阳在上，则厥阴在下；卯酉岁，阳明在上，则少阴在下；辰戌岁，太阳在上，则太阴在下；巳亥岁，厥阴在上，则少阳在下矣。[6p]
】　　左右者：诸上见厥阴，左少阴，右太阳；见少阴，左太阴，右厥阴；见太阴，左少阳，右少阴；见少阳，左阳明，右太阴；见阳明，左太阳，右少阳；见太阳，左厥阴，右阳明。所谓面北而定其位，言其见也。　　 【注　此言在上之左右也。在东为左，在西为右。凡见厥阴在上，则少阴在左，太阳在右；见少阴在上，则太阴在左，厥阴在右；见太阴在上，则少阳在左，少阴在右；见少阳在上，则阳明在左，太阴在右；见阳明在上，则太阳在左，少阳在右；见太阳在上，则厥阴在左，阳明在右。[7p]
盖以图象向南，人面北以观之，言其所见之图象，而命其上下左右之定位也。】　　帝曰：何谓下？岐伯曰：厥阴在上，则少阳在下，左阳明，右太阴；少阴在上，则阳明在下，左太阳，右少阳；太阴在上，则太阳在下，左厥阴，右阳明；少阳在上，则厥阴在下，左少阴，右太阳；阳明在上，则少阴在下，左太阴，右厥阴；太阳在上，则太阴在下，左少阳，右少阴。所谓面南而命其位，言其见也。　　【注　此言在下之左右也。如巳亥岁，厥阴在上，则少阳在下矣，而阳明在少阳之左，太阴在少阳之右。[8p]
如子午岁，少阴在上，则阳明在下矣，而太阳在阳明之左，少阳在阳明之右。如丑未岁，太阴在上，则太阳在下矣，而厥阴在太阳之左，阳明在太阳之右。如寅申岁，少阳在上，则厥阴在下矣，而少阴在厥阴之左，太阳在厥阴之右。如卯酉岁，阳明在上，则少阴在下矣，而太阴在少阴之左，厥阴在少阴之右。如辰戌岁，太阳在上，则太阴在下矣，而少阳在太阴之左，少阴在太阴之右。盖以图象向北，人面南以观之。[9p]
以所见之上下左右，而命其位，故曰言其见也。】　　上下相遘，寒暑相临。气相得则和，不相得则病。　　 【注　相临者，谓加临之六气也。言司天在泉之气，则上下相遇，左右间气之气，则四时加临。如太阳寒水之气，加临于上半岁，则少阴少阳暑热之气，加临于下半岁矣。如暑热之气，加临于上半岁，则寒水之气，加临于下半岁矣。举寒暑而六气自序，盖以上下主岁，上下左右六气纪时。如与时相得则和，与时相逆则病矣。】　　帝曰：气相得而病者何也？岐伯曰：以下临上，不当位也。[10p]
　　 【注　此言加临之六气，与主时之六气，有相得而不相得也。气相得者，如少阴君火之气，与少阳相火之气相合，君臣之相得也。君位在上，臣位在下，如君火加临于相火之上为顺，相火加临于君火之上是为下临上，不当其位也。六微旨论曰：君位臣则顺，臣位君则逆。逆则其病近，其害速；顺则其病远，其害微。所谓二火也。】　　帝曰：动静何如？岐伯曰：上者右行，下者左行。左右周天，余而复会也。　　 【注　动静者，天地之道也。在上者司天，在下者纪地。[11p]
如子年少阴在上，则阳明在下矣。周天之三百六十五日，则在上者，右行于太阴；在下者，左行于太阳也。上下左右周司天之六岁，尚余午、未、申、酉、戌、亥之六岁，又还转而复会也。】　　帝曰：余闻鬼臾区曰：应地者静。今夫子乃言下者左行，不知其所谓也。愿闻何以生之乎？　　 【注　静者，地之体也。生谓动之所生。】　　岐伯曰：天地动静，五行迁复，虽鬼臾区其上候而已，犹不能遍明。　　 【注　天地动静，谓司天在泉之气，繞地而环转也。五行迁复，谓五运相袭，周而复始也。[12p]
其上谓臾区其上至于十世，止能占候其天之动象，地之静形，犹不能遍明天地阴阳之运行也。】　　夫变化之用，天垂象，地成形，七曜纬虚，五行丽地。地者，所以载生成之形类也。虚者，所以列应天之精气也。形精之动，犹根本之与枝叶也。仰观其象，虽远可知也。　　【注　变化之用者，谓天地阴阳之运动也。在天无形而垂象，在地有形而成形。七曜，日月五星也。纬虚者，经纬于太虚之间，亦繞地而环转也。五行，五方五气之所生而成形者。地者，所以载生成之物类也。[13p]
精者，天一所生之精水也。应天之精气者，在天为气，在下为水。水应天而天连水也。形谓地之体，静而不动者也。形精之动者，谓地下在泉之气旋转，犹根本不动而枝叶动摇，然根气又与枝叶之相通也。仰观其天象，见日月五星之繞地右旋，道虽深远，可得而知矣。】　　帝曰：地之为下否乎？岐伯曰：地为人之下，太虚之中者也。帝曰：冯乎？岐伯曰：大气举之也。　　 【注　地之为下者，谓天居上而地居下也。太虚者，虚无之气也，言地居太虚之中，大气举之，无所冯依者也。[14p]
按《浑天说》曰：天之形状似鸟卵，地居其中，天包地外，犹卵之裹黄，圆如弹丸，故曰浑天。言其形体浑浑然也，其术以为天半覆地上，半在地下。其天居地上见者，一百八十二度半强，地下亦然。北极出地上三十六度，南极入地下亦三十六度，而嵩高正当天之中极也。】　　燥以干之，暑以蒸之，风以动之，湿以润之，寒以坚之，火以温之。故风寒在下，燥热在上，湿气在中，火游行其间，寒暑六入，故令虚而生化也。　　 【注　风、寒、暑、湿、燥、火，在天无形之气也。干、蒸、动、润、坚、温，在地有形之征也。[15p]
天包乎地，是以在天之上，在泉之下，在地之中，八极之外，六合之内，无所不至。盖言太虚之气，不惟包乎地之外，而通贯乎地之中也。寒水在下，而风从地水中生，故风寒在下。燥乃干金之气，热乃太阳之火，故燥热在上。土位中央，故湿气在中。火乃太极中之元阳，即天之阳气，故游行于上下之间。《易》曰：日月运行，一寒一暑。寒暑往来，而六者之气，皆入于地中，故令有形之地，受无形之虚气，而生化万物也。】　　故燥胜则地干，暑胜则地热，风胜则地动，湿胜则地泥，寒胜则地裂，火胜则地固矣。　　 【注　此复结上文六入之义。】[16p]
　　帝曰：天地之气，何以候之？岐伯曰：天地之气，胜复之作，不形于诊也。脉法曰：天地之变，无以脉诊。此之谓也。　　【注　天地之气者，五运六气也。胜复之作者，淫胜郁复也。言气运之变，而为民病者，非诊候之可知也。盖每岁有司天之六气，有主岁之五运，有间气之加临，有四时之主气。人在天地气交之中，一气不和，即为民病。是天地四时之气，而为民病，其不能以脉诊，而别某气之不和也。[17p]
再按平脉篇曰：伏气之病，以意候之。今月之内，欲有伏气，假令旧有伏气，当须脉之。盖天地之气，淫胜则所不胜之气郁伏矣，民感之而为病者，亦郁伏于内，而不形于诊也。故欲知伏气之病，当以意候之，候今月之内，有何气之不和，则知民有伏气之病矣。郁伏之气复发，而民病始作，然后发见于脉。故曰：假令旧有伏气，当须脉之。此与暴感风寒暑湿之邪，而卒病伤寒，中风即见于脉诊者之不同。故曰：天地之气，无以脉诊。此之谓也。】　　帝曰：间气如何？[18p]
　　 【注　间气者，加临之六气也。以上之左右，下之左右，兼于其间共为六气，故曰间气。每一气加临于四时之中，各主六十日，故曰间气者纪步。盖以六十日零八十七刻半为一步也。】　　岐伯曰：随气所在，期于左右。
　　【注　六微旨论曰：天枢之上，天气主之。天枢之下，地气主之。又曰：加者地气也。中者天气也。盖以在下之气左转，在上之气右旋，各主六十日以终一岁。故曰，随气所在，期于左右。谓随在上在下之气之所在，而期于左右之旋转也。如子年少阴在上，则阳明在下矣。少阴在上，则厥阴在左，太阴在右。阳明在下，则太阳在左，少阳在右。[19p]
盖以地之左转而主初气，故以太阳主正月朔日之，寅初一刻为始，次厥阴，次少阴以司天之气，终三气，而主岁半以上。次太阴，次少阳，次阳明以在泉之气，终六气，而主岁半以下。各加临六十日，以终一岁也。六气环转相同。】　　帝曰：期之奈何？岐伯曰：从其气则和，违其气则病。　　 【注　间气者，加临之客气也。而一岁之中，又有主时之六气。如主从其客则和，违其客则病矣。如子午岁，初之气，系太阳寒水加临，主气系厥阴风木。如寒胜其风为从，风胜其寒为逆。故下经曰：主胜逆，客胜从。六气皆然。】　　不当其位者病。[20p]
　　 【注　不当其位者，即上文之所谓以下临上也。】　　迭移其位者病。
　　 【注　如初之气，太阳寒水加临而反热。三之气，少阴君火加临而反寒。本位之气互相更迭，气之反也，故为民病。六气皆然。】　　失守其位者危。
　　 【注　失守其位，谓失守其所主之本位。如丑未岁，太阴司天，则初之客气、主气并主厥阴风木，而清肃之气乘所不胜而侮之，是金失守其位矣。至五之气，阳明燥金主气，而本位反虚。风木之子气复雠，火热烁金，则为病甚危，所谓侮反受邪也。】　　尺寸反者死。[21p]
　　 【注　南政北政之岁，有寸不应、尺不应之分。如应不应，而反应之，是为尺寸相反。】　　阴阳交者死。
　　 【注　南政北政之岁，有左右尺寸之不应。盖左为阳，右为阴；寸为阳，尺为阴。如阴阳交相应者死。】　　先立其年，以知其气，左右应见，然后乃可以言死生之逆顺。　　 【注　此总结六气之加临。先立其主气之年，以知其司天在泉之气，则间气之应见于左右，或从或违，然后乃可以言死生之逆顺。】　　帝曰：寒暑燥湿风火，在人合之奈何？其于万物何以化生？　　 【注　此论天地之气，而合于人民万物。】　　岐伯曰：东方生风，风生木，木生酸，酸生肝，肝生筋，筋生心。　　【注　五方生天之五气，五气生地之五行，五行生五味而生五脏，五脏生外合之五体。[22p]
盖人秉天地五方之气味而生成者也。】　　其在天为元，在人为道，在地为化，化生五味。道生智，元生神，化生气。神在天为风，在地为木，在体为筋，在气为柔，在脏为肝。　　 【注　此言阴阳不测之变化，运行于天、地、人之间。为元，为道，为化，为有形之五行、五体、五脏，皆神用无方之妙用也。柔者风木之气柔软也。】　　其性为暄，其德为和，其用为动，其色为苍，其化为荣。其虫毛。其政为散，其令宣发，其变摧拉，其眚为陨，其味为酸，其志为怒。怒伤肝，悲胜怒。风伤肝，燥胜风。酸伤筋，辛胜酸。　　【注　性者，五行之性也。德化者，气之祥也。政令者，气之章也。变眚者，气之易也。[23p]
用者，体之动也。毛虫，木森森之气也。天有五行，御五位以生寒、暑、燥、湿、风。人有五脏，化五气以生喜、怒、忧、思、恐。是人秉五气五味所生，而复伤于五气五志。犹水之所以载舟，而亦所以覆舟也。是以上古之人，饮食有节，起居有常，顺天地之变易，以和调其阴阳，故能苛疾不起，而常保其天命。今时之人，能知岁运之变迁，避胜复之灾眚，不惟可以治人，而亦可以养生。推而广之，可以救斯民于万世也。】　　南方生热，热生火，火生苦，苦生心，心生血，血生脾。其在天为热，在地为火，在体为脉，在气为息，在脏为心。其性为暑，其德为显，其用为躁，其色为赤，其化为茂。[24p]
其虫羽，其政为明，其令郁蒸，其变炎烁，其眚燔焫，其味为苦，其志为喜。喜伤心，恐胜喜。热伤气，寒胜热。苦伤气，咸胜苦。　　【注　息者火气之蕃盛也，躁火之动象也。其虫羽者，火化游行于虚空上下也。炎烁燔焫，热之极也。极则变，变则为灾眚矣。】　　中央生湿，湿生土，土生甘，甘生脾，脾生肉，肉生肺。其在天为湿，在地为土，在体为肉，在气为充，在脏为脾。其性静兼，其德为濡，其用为化，其色为黄，其化为盈。其虫倮，其政为谧，其令云雨，其变动注，其眚淫溃，其味为甘，其志为思。思伤脾，怒胜思。湿伤肉，风胜湿。甘伤脾，酸胜甘。　　【注　充者，土气充贯于四旁也。[25p]
静者土之性，兼者土王四季，兼有寒热温凉之四气也。化生万物，土之用也。倮虫，肉体之虫，土所生也。云雨者，湿气上升也。动注淫溃，湿之极也。】　　西方生燥，燥生金，金生辛，辛生肺，肺生皮毛，皮毛生肾。其在天为燥，在地为金，在体为皮毛，在气为成，在脏为肺。其性为凉，其德为清，其用为固，其色为白，其化为敛。其虫介，其政为劲，其令雾露，其变肃杀，其眚苍落，其味为辛，其志为忧。忧伤肺，喜胜忧。热伤皮毛，寒胜热。辛伤皮毛，苦胜辛。　　【注　成者，万物感秋气而成也。固者，坚金之用也。介虫，外被介甲金之象也。[26p]
肃杀者，物过盛而当杀，于时为金又兵象也。落者，肃杀盛而陨落也。】　　北方生寒，寒生水，水生咸，咸生肾，肾生骨髓，髓生肝。其在天为寒，在地为水，在体为骨，在气为坚，在脏为肾。其性为凛，其德为寒。其用为【缺】 。其色为黑，其化为肃，其虫鳞。其政为静，其令 【缺】 。其变凝冽，其眚冰雹，其味为咸，其志为恐。恐伤肾，思胜恐。寒伤血，燥胜寒。咸伤血，甘胜咸。　　【注　坚者，寒气之化也。静者，水之政令也。鳞虫，水所生也。凝冽，寒之极也。冰雹，水之变也。】　　五气更立，各有所先。非其位则邪，当其位则正。　　 【注　五气五方之气也。更立四时更换也。[27p]
各有所先者，如春之风，夏之热，秋之凉，冬之寒，各先应期而至也，各当其所主之位，四时之正气也。如冬时应寒而反热，夏时应热而反寒，非其所主之位则邪。邪者为万物之贼害也。】　　帝曰：病生之变何如？岐伯曰：气相得则微，不相得则甚。　　 【注　此论四时之气，而变生民病也。如五气各得其位，其病则微。不相得而非其本位，则其病甚矣。】　　帝曰：主岁如何？岐伯曰：气有余则制己所胜，而侮所不胜。其不及，则己所不胜，侮而乘之；己所胜，轻而侮之。　　 【注　此复论五运主岁之有太过不及也。如岁木太过，则制己所胜之土气，而侮所不胜之金气。[28p]
如不及，则己所不胜之金气，侮我而乘之；己所胜之土气，来轻我而侮之。五运皆同，周而复始。】　　侮反受邪。侮而受邪，寡于畏也。帝曰：善。　　 【注　此言乘侮而反受其复也。如岁木不及，则所不胜之金气，侮而乘之，而金反自虚其位矣。室秋令之时，金气虚而反受木之子气来复，则火热铄金所谓侮反受邪也。侮而受邪因木气不及，而金气又能制木，寡于畏之故也。此篇论五运之气，主岁、主时，而兼论六气之上下左右，盖五六相合而后成岁也。】　　五运六气主岁主时太过不及及间气加临之图。　　 【按岁运七篇总以此图推之，其五运、六气、司天在泉，间气、加临、主时、主岁，总括于中矣。再以天时民病合而推之，已了然在目，不必多赘也。】[29p]
　　　　　六微旨大论

　　黄帝问曰：呜呼！远哉。天之道也，如迎浮云，若视深渊。视深渊尚可测，迎浮云莫知其极。　　 【注　天之道者，阴阳之道也。言阴阳之道，高远而渊深也。夫有形者，尚可测。在天之为气者，莫知其极也。】　　夫子数言，谨奉天道。余闻而藏之，心私异之，不知其所谓也。愿夫子溢志，尽言其事，令终不灭，久而不绝。天之道可得闻乎？岐伯稽首再拜对曰：明乎哉问，天之道也。此因天之序，盛衰之时也。　　 【注　天之道者，天之阴阳也。因天之序者，天以六为节，因六气而环序也。盛衰者，六气之有太过不及也。】　　帝曰：愿闻天道，六六之节，盛衰何也？岐伯曰：上下有位，左右有纪。故少阳之右，阳明治之：阳明之右，太阳治之；太阳之右，厥阴治之；厥阴之右，少阴治之；少阴之右，太阴治之；太阴之右，少阳治之。此所谓气之标，盖南面而待之也。[30p]
故曰：因天之序，盛衰之时，移光定位，正立而待之。此之谓也。　　【注　六六者，谓司天之三阴三阳，上合天之六气也。上下有位者，言少阴在上，则阳明在下，太阴在上，则太阳在下；少阳在上，则厥阴在下；厥阴在上，则少阴在下；太阳在上，则太阴在下；厥阴在上，则少阳在下。六期环转，而各有上下之定位也。左右有纪者，如少阴在上，则厥阴在左，太阴在右；太阴在上，则少阴在左，少阳在右；少阳在上，则太阳在左，阳明在右；阳明在上，则少阳在左，太阳在右；太阳在上，则阳明在左，厥阴在右；厥阴在上，则太阳在左，少阴在右。各随气之在上，而有左右之定纪也。故少阳之右，阳明治之；阳明之右，太阳治之。盖以右位之阴阳，转迁于上而主岁也。气之标者，标见于上也。夫天气右旋，故南面观之，而待其循序环转也。移光者，日月运行也，以日行一周天以定一气之位。正立，正南面而立也。】　　六气主岁太过不及之图[31p]
　　见图
