In the year of northern governance, when the Yin is at the spring, then the Shao Yin is on the left, hence the right does not correspond; when the Tai Yin is at the spring, then the Shao Yin is on the right, hence the left does not correspond. In the year of southern governance, when the Yin governs the heavens, then the Shao Yin is on the left, hence the right does not correspond; when the Tai Yin governs the heavens, then the Shao Yin is on the right, hence the left does not correspond. This discusses the correspondence of the pulse at the wrist on the left and right sides. The non-correspondence refers to the left and right not corresponding. To reverse the diagnosis, one positions themselves facing south to diagnose the north. It is based on positioning the diagram flat on a table, with the heavens in the south and the spring in the north. In the year of northern governance, one faces north to diagnose; in the year of southern governance, one faces south to diagnose, thus the non-correspondence of left and right can be seen. Heaven above and earth below, the southern heavens and northern earth, this is the positioning of heaven and earth. When one faces south and north, they dwell in the midst of the exchange of the qi of heaven and earth, revolving in accordance with the qi of heaven and earth.[324p]

】　　帝曰：尺候何如？岐伯曰：北政之岁，三阴在下则寸不应，三阴在上则尺不应。南政之岁，三阴在天则寸不应，三阴在泉则尺不应。左右同。故曰知其要者一言而终，不知其要流散无穷。此之谓也。　　【注　此总结上文之义，故问尺而兼论寸焉。所谓三阴者，以少阴居二阴之中。上下者，以天在上而泉在下也。左右同者，谓尺之左右不应，与寸之左右不应同也。故知其要者，知少阴之不司气化，随阴阳而居上居下也。不知其要，流散无穷者，如疏注之议论纷纭而茫无归着也。】　　帝曰：善。[325p]

The Emperor said: "What about the measurements?" Qi Bo replied: "In a year of northern governance, when the three yin are below, the cun does not respond; when the three yin are above, the chi does not respond. In a year of southern governance, when the three yin are in the heavens, the cun does not respond; when the three yin are in the springs, the chi does not respond. The same applies to both sides. Therefore, it is said that those who understand the essence can conclude it in one sentence, while those who do not understand the essence will endlessly flow and scatter. This is what is meant."

[Note: This summarizes the meaning of the previous text, hence the inquiry about measurements also encompasses the cun. The so-called "three yin" refers to Shao Yin, which occupies the middle position of the two yin. The terms "above and below" refer to heaven being above and springs being below. "The same applies to both sides" means that the chi’s responses on both sides are the same as those of the cun. Therefore, knowing the essence means understanding that Shao Yin does not control the transformation of qi, and resides based on the positions of yin and yang. Not understanding the essence leads to endless scattering, similar to the diverse and unfocused discussions in commentaries.]

The Emperor said: "Well said."[325p]

天地之气内淫：而病何如？岐伯曰：岁厥阴在泉，风淫所胜则地气不明，平野昧，草乃早秀。民病洒洒振寒，善伸数欠，心痛支满，两胁里急，饮食不下，膈咽不通，食则呕，腹胀善噫，得后与气则快然如衰，身体皆重。　　【注　此论六气在泉，而为民病，当以所胜之气味治之。厥阴在泉，寅申岁也。风淫于下，则尘土飞扬，故地气不明，平野昏昧，草得生气，故早秀也。按经脉篇云：脾是动则病洒洒振寒，善伸数欠。脾气病则饮食不下，食则呕，腹胀善噫，得后与气则快然如衰。身体皆重。盖水淫而土病也。又厥阴肝脉，上贯膈布胁肋，故为心痛支满等证。[326p]

The Qi of heaven and earth is unrestrained, causing illness. How is this? Qi Bo said: In the year of the Jueyin, when the wind is dominant, the earth's Qi becomes unclear, the flat lands are dim, and the grasses sprout early. The people suffer from chills and shivering, they often stretch and yawn, experience heart pain and fullness in the chest, feelings of urgency in the sides, inability to eat or drink, obstruction in the throat, vomiting after eating, abdominal bloating, and frequent belching. When gas is released, they feel as if they are revitalized, yet their bodies feel heavy.

[Note: This discusses the influence of the six Qi on the people’s illnesses and how to treat them according to the prevailing Qi. Jueyin appears in the year of Yin and Shen. When the wind prevails below, dust and dirt rise, leading to unclear earth Qi, dim flatlands, and early sprouting of grasses. According to the channel text, spleen issues result in chills and shivering, frequent yawning, and stomach problems such as inability to eat or drink, nausea, bloating, and belching. When gas is released, it offers momentary relief, yet the body remains heavy, indicating water as a cause and soil as the afflicted area. Additionally, Jueyin liver channels reach the diaphragm and sides, causing symptoms like heart pain and fullness.][326p]

】　　岁少阴在泉，热淫所胜则焰浮川泽，阴处反明。民病腹中常鸣，气上冲胸，喘不能久立，寒热，皮肤痛，目瞑，齿痛，(出页)肿，恶寒，发热如疟，少腹中痛，腹大，蛰虫不藏。　　【注　少阴在泉，卯酉岁也。少阴君火生于水中，故焰浮山泽。少阴标阴而本火，故阴处反明。腹中常鸣者，火气奔动也。气上冲胸者，火气炎上也。喘不能久立，寒热皮肤痛者，火淫肺金也。目瞑者，热甚阴虚，畏阳光也。齿痛(出页)肿，热乘阳明也。[327p]

In the Year of the Lesser Yin, when the heat overcomes, flames rise above the rivers and marshes, causing the hidden yin to appear bright. People suffer from constant rumbling in the abdomen, qi rushing up to the chest, and are unable to stand for long due to shortness of breath, alternating chills and fevers, skin pain, closed eyes, toothaches, swelling, aversion to cold, and fevers like malaria. There is pain in the lower abdomen, an enlarged belly, and insects do not hide.

(Note: The Lesser Yin refers to periods related to the year of the hare and rooster. The Lesser Yin fire is generated in the water, hence the flames rise above the mountains and marshes. The nature of the Lesser Yin symbolizes yin but is fundamentally fire, so the hidden yin appears bright. The constant rumbling in the abdomen is due to the agitation of fire qi. Qi rushing to the chest is the upward heat of fire qi. The inability to stand long due to shortness of breath, along with alternating chills and skin pain, is because fire overcomes the metal of the lungs. Closed eyes indicate severe heat and yin deficiency, leading to a fear of sunlight. Toothaches with swelling are caused by heat overwhelming the yang brightness.)[327p]

发热如疟者，少阴标本之气病也。热在下焦则少腹中痛，热在中焦则腹大也。】　　岁太阴在泉，草乃早荣，湿淫所胜则埃昏岩谷，黄反见黑。至阴之交，民病饮积，心痛，耳聋浑浑焞焞，嗌肿喉痹，阴病见血，少腹痛肿，不得小便，病冲头痛，目似脱，项似拔，腰似折，髀不可以曲，腘如结，腨如别。　　【注　太阴在泉，辰戌岁也。土为草木所资，故草乃早荣。黄乃土色，黑乃水色，土胜湿淫，故黄反见黑。五常政论曰：太阴司天，湿气下临，肾气上从，黑起水变，皆土胜水应之义。[328p]

Fever resembling malaria is a disease of the qi of the Shaoyin. If the heat is in the lower jiao, there will be pain in the lower abdomen; if the heat is in the middle jiao, the abdomen will be distended. In the year of the Taiyin at the spring, grasses thrive early; when wetness overcomes, dust clouds the valleys and black is seen instead of yellow. At the transition of the extreme yin, the people suffer from accumulations of drink, heart pain, deafness that is muddled and unclear, swelling of the throat and throat obstruction, bleeding from yin disorders, pain and swelling in the lower abdomen, inability to urinate, headaches that push against the head, eyes that seem to dislocate, neck that feels pulled, waist that feels broken, thighs that cannot bend, hamstrings that feel knotted, and shins that feel distinct.

(Note: In the year of the Taiyin, it's the year of Chen and Xu. Earth nourishes grasses and trees, which is why they thrive early. Yellow is the color of earth, black is the color of water; earth overcomes dampness, hence yellow appears as black. The Five Constants Discussion states: Taiyin governs the heavens, and dampness descends; the kidney qi rises; black signifies the transformation of water, all representing the principle of earth overcoming water.)[328p]

至阴之交，乃三气四气之交，土司令也。饮积心痛，寒湿上乘也。按经脉篇自耳聋至喉痹，乃三焦经病；自阴病至不得小便，以邪湿下流，为肾脏受病；自冲头痛至腨如别，乃膀胱经病。盖三焦为决渎之官，膀胱乃水津之腑，土气淫胜，而水脏水腑皆为病也。】　　岁少阳在泉，火淫所胜则焰明郊野，寒热更至。民病注泄赤白，少腹痛，溺赤，甚则血便。少阴同候。　　 【注　少阳在泉，巳亥岁也。少阳之火，地二所生，故焰明郊野，寒热更至。热伤血分则注赤，热伤气分则注白。[329p]

The intersection of the ultimate yin is the convergence of the three energies and four energies; it is led by the earth element. Drinking and accumulating leads to heart pain, with cold and dampness prevailing. According to the meridian chapters, from deafness to throat obstruction, these are ailments of the Triple Burner meridian; from yin diseases to inability to urinate, this is due to pathogenic dampness flowing downward, causing illness in the kidneys; from head pain to feeling like a knot, these are ailments of the bladder meridian. The Triple Burner governs the flow of vital substances, while the bladder is the organ of water and fluids, and when the earth energy is excessive, both the water organ and the water's pathways become ill.

In the year when the lesser yang is at the spring, if the fire energy prevails, flames become prominent in the fields, and changes of cold and heat occur. The people suffer from dysentery with red and white discharges, lower abdominal pain, and red urination, which may even lead to blood in the stools. The lesser yin corresponds with this.

Note: The lesser yang at the spring occurs in the year of the snake and the pig. The fire of the lesser yang is generated from the earth, hence the flames are bright in the fields, and changes of cold and heat occur. Heat damages the blood level, leading to red discharges, while heat damages the energy level, leading to white discharges.[329p]

热在下焦，故少腹痛而溺赤。血便者，甚则血出于小便也。少阴之火出自水，少阳之火生于地，皆有阴阳寒热之分，故与少阴同候。】　　岁阳明在泉，燥淫所胜则霿雾清暝。民病喜呕，呕有苦，善太息，心胁痛，不能反侧，甚则嗌干面尘，身无膏泽，足外反热。　　 【注　阳明在泉，子午岁也。金气淫于下，则霿雾清暝于上矣。按经脉篇呕苦，善太息，心胁痛，不能转侧，甚则面有微尘，体无膏泽，足外反热，乃足少阳病；嗌干面尘，乃足厥阴病。盖金胜而肝胆病也。】　　岁太阳在泉，寒淫所胜则凝肃惨栗。[330p]

The heat resides in the lower region, hence the pain in the lower abdomen and red urine. In cases of blood in the stool, it can be severe enough for blood to emerge in the urine. The fire of the Shaoyin emerges from water, while the fire of the Shaoyang arises from the earth. Each has its own distinctions of yin and yang, cold and heat, thus correlating with the Shaoyin.

In the year when the Yangming is in the spring, if dryness and humidity dominate, then mist and fog will be clear and dark. The people suffer from nausea, with bitter vomiting, deep sighing, pain in the heart and sides, unable to turn over; in severe cases, the throat may feel dry and the face dusty, the body devoid of moisture, and the feet may feel hot externally.

(Note: The Yangming being in spring refers to the time of the year. When the metal energy is excessive below, there will be clear mist and fog above. According to the classic on meridians, symptoms include bitter vomiting, deep sighing, pain in the heart and sides, inability to turn, and in severe cases, a dusty face and a body lacking in moisture, with hot feet indicating Shaoyang disease; a dry throat and dusty face point to a condition of the Jueyin. This implies that metal excess causes liver and gallbladder issues.)

In the year when the Taiyang is in the spring, if cold and humidity dominate, there will be a feeling of heaviness and shivering.[330p]

民病少腹控睪，引腰脊，上冲心痛，血见，嗌痛颔肿。　　 【注　太阳在泉，丑未岁也。寒水淫胜，故凝肃惨栗。寒淫于下，则膀胱与肾受之。膀胱居于少腹，故小腹痛。肾主阴器，故控引睪丸。太阳之脉挟脊抵腰中，故引腰脊。肾脉络心，故上冲心痛。心主血，而寒气逼之，故血见。按经脉篇嗌痛颔肿，乃小肠经病。小肠者，心之腑也。亦水邪上侮火脏火腑而然。】　　帝曰：善。治之奈何？岐伯曰：诸气在泉，风淫于内，治以辛凉，佐以苦甘，以甘缓之，以辛散之。[331p]

The common people suffer from pain in the lower abdomen and pulling of the testicles, which leads to back pain and heartache. Blood is seen, the throat hurts, and the jaw is swollen.

[Note: The sun is in the spring, during the year of the Ox and the Goat. The cold water is excessive, causing tightness, somberness, and trembling. When cold invades from below, it affects the bladder and kidneys. The bladder is located in the lower abdomen, hence the abdominal pain. The kidneys govern the genitalia, thus the pulling sensation affects the testicles. The sun's meridian intersects the spine at the waist, which accounts for the back pain. The kidney meridian connects to the heart, hence the heartache. The heart governs blood, and with cold forces pressing in, blood is seen. According to the meridian passages, throat pain and jaw swelling indicate an illness of the small intestine. The small intestine is a viscera of the heart. This is also a result of water pathogens assaulting the fire organs and the heart.

The Emperor said: "Good. How should this be treated?" Qi Bo replied: "The qi is in disarray, and wind lingers within. Treat it with acrid cooling agents, supplemented with bitter and sweet, using sweetness to ease it and acridity to disperse it."[331p]

　　【注　风乃木气，金能胜之，故治以辛凉。过辛恐反伤其气，故佐以苦甘，苦胜辛而甘益气也。本性急，故以甘缓之。风邪胜，故以辛散之。脏气法时论曰：肝苦急，急食甘以缓之；肝欲散，急食辛以散之。】　　热淫于内，治以咸寒，佐以甘苦，以酸收之，以苦发之。　　 【注　热乃火气，水能胜之，故宜治以咸寒，佐以甘苦。甘胜咸，所以防咸之过；苦能泄，所以去热之实也。酸乃木味，火生于木，以酸收之者，收火归原也。热郁于内而不解者，以苦发之。】　　湿淫于内，治以苦热，佐以酸淡，以苦燥之，以淡泄之。[332p]

Wind is the energy of wood; metal can overcome it, hence it is treated with acrid and cooling remedies. However, excessive acrid can harm the energy, so it is accompanied by bitter and sweet remedies, as bitterness overcomes acrid and sweetness benefits the energy. The intrinsic nature is urgent, thus sweet remedies help to soothe it. When wind excesses, acrid is used to disperse it.

When heat is excessive internally, it is treated with salty and cold remedies, accompanied by sweet and bitter, with sour to restrain it and bitter to release it. Heat is associated with fire energy, and water can conquer it, thus it is appropriate to treat it with salty and cold, complemented by sweet and bitter remedies. Sweet overcomes salty, to prevent excess of salt; bitterness can drain, thus reducing the substance of heat. Sour represents wood flavor; fire arises from wood, and to restrain fire with sour brings it back to its origin. When heat is trapped inside and does not resolve, bitterness releases it.

When dampness is excessive internally, it is treated with bitter heat, accompanied by sour and light, using bitterness to dry it and light to drain it.[332p]

　　 【注　湿乃阴土之气，故宜治以苦热。苦能胜湿，热以和阴也。酸从木化，故佐以酸淡。以苦燥之者，苦从火化也。卦传曰：燥万物者，莫熯乎火。以淡泄之者，淡味渗泄为阳也。】　　火淫于内，治以咸冷，佐以苦辛，以酸收之。以苦发之。　　 【注　火淫于内，故宜治以咸冷。苦能泄辛能散，故当佐以苦辛。以酸收之，以苦发之，与上文同义。】　　燥淫于内，治以苦温，佐以甘辛，以苦下之。　　 【注　燥乃清凉之金气。故当治以苦温。燥则气结以内，故当佐以辛甘发散，以苦下之。[333p]

Note: Humidity is the energy of damp earth; therefore, it is suitable to treat it with bitter heat. Bitterness can overcome dampness, and heat harmonizes with the yin. Acidity comes from wood transformation; thus, it is complemented with a mild sourness. The bitter and dry elements are transformed by fire. The hexagram texts say: nothing can dry up all things like fire. The mild flavor is used to drain; it represents yang through its penetrating qualities.

When fire is excessive internally, it is treated with salty and cold elements, complemented with bitterness and pungency to disperse it, and then sourness is used to contain it. Bitter elements are used to provoke it.

Note: Since fire is excessive internally, it should be treated with salty and cold elements. Bitterness can disperse, and pungency can scatter, thus it should be complemented with both bitterness and pungency. Sourness is used to contain it, and bitterness is used to provoke it, which corresponds to the previous text.

When dryness is excessive internally, it is treated with warm bitterness and complemented with sweet pungency, allowing bitterness to descend.

Note: Dryness is the clear and cool energy of metal; therefore, it should be treated with warm bitterness. Dryness leads to Qi being constrained internally, so it should be complemented with pungency and sweetness to disperse, allowing bitterness to descend.[333p]

】　　寒淫于内，治以甘热，佐以苦辛，以咸泻之，以辛润之，以苦坚之。　　 【注　寒乃水气，土能胜水，热能胜寒，故宜治以甘热。脏气法时论曰：肾苦燥，急食辛以润之。肾欲坚，急食苦以坚之，以苦补之，以咸泻之。】　　帝曰：善。天气之变何如？岐伯曰：厥阴司天，风淫所胜则太虚埃昏，云物以扰，寒生春气，流水不冰。民病胃脘当心而痛，上支两胁，膈咽不通，饮食不下，舌本强，食则呕，冷泄，腹胀，溏瘕泄，水闭。蛰虫不去，病本于脾。冲阳绝，死不治。　　【注　厥阴司天，巳亥岁也。
风淫于上，故太虚埃昏，云物扰乱，寒生于春气，是以流水不冰。按经脉篇舌本强、食则呕、胃脘痛、腹胀、饮食不下、溏瘕泄、水闭，皆脾经之病，盖风木淫胜，故病本于脾。蛰虫藏于土中，因风气外淫，故不去也。冲阳，足阳明胃脉，在足跗上，动脉应手。胃气已绝，故死不治。】　　少阴司天，热淫所胜，怫热至，火行其政。[334p]

Cold is pervasive within; it should be treated with sweet warmth, assisted by bitter and pungent flavors, to expel it through salty means, moisten it with pungent properties, and strengthen it with bitterness.

The Emperor said: Good. What of the changes in the weather? Qi Bo replied: The Jue Yin regulates the heavens; when wind and dampness prevail, the great void becomes obscure, causing disturbances in the clouds. Cold arises from the spring qi, making the flowing water not freeze. The people suffer from pain in the stomach and heart, with pain in both flanks, obstruction in the diaphragm and throat, inability to eat or drink, a strong tongue with vomiting when eating, diarrhea, abdominal distension, watery loose stools, and water retention. Hibernating insects do not leave, and the illness originates in the spleen. If the Chong Yang is depleted, one cannot recover from death.

The note indicates that Jue Yin governs the heavens, as in the years of Zi and Hai. The wind and dampness above cause the great void to become obscure; disturbances in the clouds and cold arising from spring qi prevent the flowing water from freezing. According to the meridian sections, a strong tongue, vomiting when eating, stomach pain, abdominal distension, inability to drink, loose stools, and water retention are all ailments of the spleen meridian, as the overpowering wind and wood cause illness in the spleen. Hibernating insects hide in the earth; due to the external invasion of the wind qi, they do not leave. The Chong Yang, residing on the foot where the Yangming stomach meridian is located, corresponds to the arteries of the hands. With the stomach's qi extinguished, one cannot recover from death.

The Shao Yin governs the heavens; when hot and dampness prevails, the heat rises, and fire governs its affairs.[334p]

民病胸中烦热，嗌干，右胠满，皮肤痛，寒热咳喘，大雨且至，唾血血泄，鼽衄嚏呕，溺色变，甚则疮疡胕肿，肩背臂臑及缺盆中痛，心痛，肺(月真)，腹大满，膨膨而喘咳。病本于肺。尺泽绝，死不治。　　【注　少阴司天，子午岁也。少阴之火，发于阴中，故为怫热。少阴太阳，阴中有阳，阳中有阴。阴阳相从，标本互换。是以火热甚而大雨至，水寒极而运火炎。民病胸中烦热，嗌干，右胠满，皮肤痛，肺受火热而津液不生也。唾血血泄，热淫而迫，血妄行也。按经脉篇溺色变，肩背臂腨痛，烦心，胸满，肺胀膨膨而喘咳，皆肺经之病。盖火淫则金气受伤，故病本于肺。尺泽，在肘内廉大文中，动脉应手，肺之合穴脉也。肺气已绝，故死不治。[335p]

The people suffer from vexation and heat in the chest, dry throat, fullness on the right side, painful skin, chills and fever with cough and wheezing. A heavy rain is about to come; there is blood in the sputum and bloody discharge, along with nasal bleeding, sneezing, and vomiting. The color of the urine changes, and in severe cases, there are sores and swellings. Pain is felt in the shoulders, back, arms, and around the shoulder blades, with heart pain, lung issues, and a swollen abdomen causing wheezing and coughing. The illness originates in the lungs. If the pulse at the Chize point is absent, death is imminent.

[Note: The lesser yin governs the heavens; it corresponds to the time of the rat and the horse hours. The fire of the lesser yin arises from within, hence it causes vexatious heat. The lesser yin and the greater yang suggest that within yin there is yang and within yang there is yin. The interaction of yin and yang causes the fire to be intense, bringing forth heavy rain, leading to extreme cold that stirs up fiery heat. The people suffer from vexation and heat in the chest, dry throat, fullness on the right side, painful skin, due to the lung being affected by this heat, which inhibits the production of bodily fluids. Blood in the sputum and bloody discharge indicate heat driving the blood to erratically flow. Changes in urine color, shoulder and back pain, vexation, fullness in the chest, and lung distension causing wheezing and coughing are all indicative of lung-related illness. Excessive heat damages the metal element, hence the illness originates in the lungs. The Chize point is located within the inner elbow crease, where the pulse can be felt. It is the communicating vessel of the lungs. With the lung qi already exhausted, death is inevitable.][335p]

】　　太阴司天，湿淫所胜则沉阴且布，雨变枯槁。胕肿，骨痛，阴痹。阴痹者，按之不得。腰脊头项痛，时眩，大便难。阴气不用，饥不欲食，咳唾则有血，心如悬。病本于肾。太溪绝，死不治。　　【注　太阴司天，丑未岁也。湿淫于上，故沉阴且布，草木枯槁，得化气之雨，而变生胕肿阴痹，皆感寒湿之气病。在阴者，名曰痹，故按之不得也。肾主骨而膀胱为之腑，故腰脊头项骨痛。肾开窍于二阴，故大便难也。阴气不用者，不能上交于心也。上下不交，则上焦之火热留于胃，胃热则消谷，故善饥。[336p]

The Great Yin governs the heavens; when dampness and indulgence prevail, it becomes heavy and spreads, causing rain to transform and vegetation to wither. There arise swellings, bone pains, and yin obstruction. Yin obstruction is characterized by an inability to be pressed upon. There are pains in the lower back, spine, and neck, frequent dizziness, and difficulty with bowel movements. When yin energy is unutilized, there is a lack of appetite even in hunger; coughing produces blood, and the heart feels suspended. The illness originates in the kidneys. If the Great Stream is exhausted, there is no cure.

(Note: The Great Yin governs the heavens during the year of the Dog or Sheep. Excessive dampness above causes heaviness and spreading, leading plants to wither. When the transforming energy of rain interacts, swellings and yin obstruction arise, resulting from the influence of cold damp energy. The obstruction is termed "bi," thereby it cannot be pressed. The kidneys govern the bones, and the bladder is their organ, hence the pains in the lower back, spine, and neck. The kidneys open to the two yin, which also contributes to difficulty in bowel movements. When yin energy is unused, it cannot engage with the heart. If the upper and lower do not interact, the upper fire becomes retained in the stomach, leading to gastric heat, which causes loss of appetite.)[336p]

胃气上逆，故不欲食也。咳唾有血者心火在上，而不得上下之相济也。经脉篇曰：肾是动病目(目巟)(目巟)无所见，心如悬若饥。盖心肾不交，故虚悬于上而若饥也。此土湿胜水，故病本于肾。太溪，肾之动脉，在足内踝外踝骨上。太溪脉不至，则肾气已绝，故死不治。】　　少阳司天，火淫所胜则温气流行，金政不平。民病头痛发热，恶寒而疟，热上，皮肤痛，色变黄赤，传而为水，身面胕肿，腹满仰息，泄注赤白，疮疡，咳唾血，烦心胸中热，甚则鼽衄。病本于肺。天府绝，死不治。　　【注　少阳司天，寅申岁也。[337p]

The stomach's qi is rebellious, hence the lack of desire to eat. Coughing up blood indicates that heart fire is rising, failing to connect the upper and lower parts. The Scripture on Meridians states: the kidneys govern movement; when the eyes fail to see, the heart hangs as if in hunger. This is due to the heart and kidneys not communicating, rendering the heart suspended above and feeling like hunger. The earth's dampness overpowers water, hence the illness originates from the kidneys. Tai Xi, the kidney's artery, is located above the outer ankle bone. If the Tai Xi pulse does not reach, then the kidney qi has already been depleted, leading to an untreatable death.

In the Lesser Yang, when fire has excess, warm qi flows improperly, and gold regulation is unbalanced. The people suffer from headaches, fever, chills, and malaria. Heat rises, causing skin pain, discoloration to yellow or red, progressing to water retention, swelling of the body and face, abdominal fullness with difficulty in breathing, red and white diarrhea, sores, coughing up blood, and a hot, restless heart. Ultimately, the illness stems from the lungs. If the Tian Fu is cut off, then death is inevitable.

(Note: Lesser Yang refers to the years of Yin and Shen.)[337p]

火淫所胜，故金政不平。少阳之火，在天为暑，故民病头痛寒热而疟，热上，皮肤痛，色变黄赤，火上淫于肺也。传为水者，逼其金水外溢，故为肿满之水病也。仰息，肺气逆而不得偃息也。泄注赤白，疮疡唾血烦心，火热盛也。鼽衄，甚而及于肺也。此火淫胜金，故病本于肺。天府，肺脉，在腋下三寸，动脉应手。肺气已绝，故死不治。】　　阳明司天，燥淫所胜则木乃晚荣，草乃晚生。筋骨内变，民病左胠胁痛，寒清于中感而疟，大凉革候，咳，腹中鸣，注泄鹜溏。名木敛生菀于下，草焦上首。[338p]

The fire's indulgence prevails, hence the metal's governance is not balanced. The fire of Shaoyang, in the heavens, brings the heat of summer; therefore, the people suffer from headaches and chills, and from malaria, as the heat rises causing skin pain, with color changing to yellow and red, indicating the fire's excess affecting the lungs. When transformed into water, it forces the metal and water outward, resulting in the illness of swollen water accumulation. When one breathes upward, the lung qi rebels and cannot settle. The discharge is red and white, with sores, cough, and blood in the sputum causing distress, indicating an excess of fire heat. Sneezing and nosebleeds can even affect the lungs. Since this fire's indulgence conquers the metal, the illness originates in the lungs.

The Yangming governs the heavens; when the dryness's excess prevails, the wood flourishes late, and grass grows late. The muscles and bones internally change, causing the people to suffer from pain in the left side of the abdomen, chills felt within leading to malaria, dry conditions altering seasons, coughing, gurgling in the abdomen, and clear watery diarrhea. The wood holds back life in the lower parts, while the grass wilts at the top.[338p]

心胁暴痛，不可反侧，嗌干面尘腰痛，丈夫(疒颓)疝，妇人少腹痛，目昧眦疡，疮座痈。蛰虫来见，病本于肝。太冲绝，死不治。　　【注　阳明司天，卯酉岁也。燥金淫胜于上，则木受其制，故草木生荣俱晚。肝血伤而不能荣养筋骨，故生内变。左胠胁痛，肝经病也。感寒清而成疟者，秋成痎疟也。大凉革候者，夏秋之交，变炎暑而为清凉也。腹中鸣，注泄鹜溏，寒清于中也。名木敛于上，而生菀于下，草焦上首，肃杀之气淫于上也。心胁暴痛，不可反侧，嗌干面尘，(疒颓)疝眦疡，皆肝经之病。[339p]

The heart and sides pain violently, making it impossible to turn or move. There is dryness in the throat, dirt on the face, and pain in the waist. Men experience testicular pain, while women have pain in the lower abdomen. There are symptoms of blurred vision and sores. When stinging insects appear, the illness originates from the liver. If the liver channel is blocked (Tai Chong), it may lead to death without treatment.

(Note: Yangming governs the heavens during the years of Yin and Yang. When the dry metal triumphs above, wood is constrained, causing grass and trees to thrive later. Injury to the liver's blood weakens its ability to nourish the muscles and bones, resulting in internal changes. Pain in the left side indicates a liver channel issue. Catching a chill and developing intermittent fevers signifies autumn's fevers (Xie). Great cooling and transformation occurs at the transition between summer and autumn, from intense heat to coolness. Rumbling in the abdomen indicates coldness within. The name "wood" gathers above while decaying below, with grass withering upwards, as the chilling and killing energy dominates above. The violent pain in the heart and sides, difficulty in movement, throat dryness, and various symptoms all point to liver channel disorders.)[339p]

盖金浮于上，故病本于肝。太冲，在足大指本节后二寸，动脉应手，肝经之俞穴脉也。肝气已绝，故死不治。】　　太阳司天，寒淫所胜，则寒气反至，水且冰。血变于中，发为痈疡，民病厥心痛，呕血，血泄，鼽衄，善悲，时眩仆。运火炎烈，雨暴乃雹。胸腹满，手热肘挛掖肿肿　《素问》至真要大论原作「冲」。王冰注作肿。，心淡淡大动，胸胁胃脘不安，面赤目黄，善噫嗌干，甚则色炱，渴而欲饮。病本于心。神门绝，死不治。所谓动气知其脏也。[340p]

Gold floats above, thus the disease originates in the liver. Tai Chong is located two inches behind the base of the big toe; it corresponds to the liver channel's acupoint. When the liver qi is completely depleted, it results in death, untreatable.

When the sun governs heaven and cold prevails, then cold air returns, causing water to freeze. Blood undergoes changes within, leading to boils. The populace suffers from sudden heart pain, vomiting blood, blood leakage, nasal hemorrhage, excessive sorrow, and intermittent dizziness. When fire burns fiercely, storms arise, bringing hail.

The chest and abdomen feel full, hands are hot, and the elbows are swollen. The heart is faint and beating excessively, discomforting the chest, ribs, and stomach, with flushed face and yellowish eyes. There are tendencies to sigh and dry throat, and in severe cases, there’s a dark complexion and thirst with a desire to drink. The disease originates in the heart. When the Shen Men is depleted, it leads to death, untreatable. This is the understanding of how moving qi relates to its organs.[340p]

　　【注　曰寒气反至者，谓太阳为诸阳之首，即君火之阳也。然本于在下之寒水，今寒气反从上而至，是上下皆寒，而太阳运居于中，故曰运火炎烈。夫寒临于上，如阳能胜之，即所谓凡伤于寒则为病热，乃病反其本，得标之病矣。故治反其本，得标之方，此太阳从本从标，寒热更胜之气也。是以痈疡呕血、鼽衄腹满，乃阳热中盛之证。如心痛眩仆，面赤目黄，色炲善噫，乃寒凌心火，逼其火热上炎。水火寒热交争，而神门脉绝，心气灭矣。神门，心之俞穴，在手掌后锐骨端，动脉应手。故所谓候脉之动气，则知其五脏之存亡矣。】　　帝曰：善。治之奈何？[341p]

The note states that the arrival of cold air is referred to as the sun being the chief of all yang, representing the fire of the ruler. However, originating from the cold water below, the cold air now comes from above, resulting in cold both above and below, while the sun's movement resides in the middle, thus it is said to operate with intense fire. When cold comes from above, if the yang can overcome it, this is the so-called occurrence where injury from cold manifests as heat illness, which reflects a reversal of its essence, resulting in identifiable sickness. Therefore, treating the reversal of its essence leads to effective methods; this is akin to the sun acting based on its essence and the recognition of the overpowering forces of cold and heat. As a result, conditions like abscesses, vomiting blood, nasal bleeding, and abdominal fullness are signs of excessive yang heat. Similarly, symptoms like heart pain, dizziness, face redness, and yellowing of the eyes indicate that cold is attacking the fire of the heart, forcing its heat upwards. The conflict between water and fire, cold and heat, leads to the closing off of the Shenmen pulse, extinguishing the heart's energy. Shenmen, the heart's acupoint, is located at the tip of the bony edge of the palm, where the artery can be felt. Thus, monitoring the movement of the pulse indicates the existence or demise of the five organs. The emperor said: "Good. How shall it be treated?"[341p]

　　 【注　此论司天之六气淫胜，而以所胜之气味平之。】　　岐伯曰：司天之气，风淫所胜，平以辛凉，佐以苦甘，以甘缓之，以酸泻之。　　 【注　按在泉之气曰淫于内而曰治，司天之气曰所胜而曰平，盖天气在外，而地气在内也。故曰治者，治其内而使之外也；曰平者，平其上而使之下也。是以在在泉曰以辛散之，在司天曰以酸泻之。】　　热淫所胜，平以咸寒，佐以苦甘，以酸收之。　　 【注　此与在泉之治法相同，但少以苦发之。盖自下而上，淫于内者，宜从之而发散于外也。[342p]

[Note: This discussion concerns the six atmospheric energies, where the excessive elements are balanced by those they overpower.] Qibo said: The energy of the heavens is overpowered by wind; balance it with acrid coolness, assist with bitterness and sweetness, use sweetness to mellow it, and use sourness to drain it. [Note: The energy from the spring is called excessive when internal and called treatment; the energy of the heavens is called overpowered when external and called balance. The atmosphere is external, while the earth's energy is internal. Therefore, to treat means to manage the inner and allow it to manifest outward; to balance means to level what is above and allow it to descend. Thus, in the case of the spring, it is said to disperse with acridity, while in the case of the heavens, it is said to drain with sourness.] The excess of heat is overpowered; balance it with salty coldness, assist with bitterness and sweetness, and use sourness to collect it. [Note: This treatment method is similar to that in the spring, but with slightly less emphasis on bitterness as a release. Since it arises from below and moves upward, the internal excess should be dispersed outward accordingly.][342p]

】　　湿淫所胜，平以苦热，佐以酸辛，以苦燥之，以淡泄之。湿上甚而热，治以苦温，佐以甘辛，以汗为故而止。　　 【注　湿乃土之气，故上甚而热，亦宜用辛温发散，以汗为故而止。《金匮要略》曰：腰以下肿，当利小便；腰以上肿，当发汗乃愈。此皆治水湿之要法。】　　火淫所胜，平以酸冷，佐以苦甘，以酸收之，以苦发之，以酸复之。热淫同。　　 【注　少阳之火，乃地火也。平之而未平者，淫于内也。故当以苦发之。此即三焦之元气，宜复以酸收之。勿使其过于发散也。夫少阴之热，君主之火也，淫甚则外内相合，亦当以苦发之。】　　燥淫所胜，平以苦温，佐以酸辛，以苦下之。[343p]

The victory of dampness is countered with bitterness and heat, assisted by sourness and pungency, and managed with bitter drying and mild diuretics. When dampness is severe and accompanied by heat, it is treated with warming bitterness, complemented by sweetness and pungency, stopping with sweat as a remedy.

(Note: Dampness is the element of earth, thus when it is severe along with heat, pungent warmth should also be used, stopping with sweat as a remedy. "Jinkui Yaolüe" states: When there is swelling below the waist, promote urination; when there is swelling above the waist, sweating is required for recovery. These are essential methods for treating water and dampness.)

The victory of fire is countered with sourness and cooling, assisted by bitterness and sweetness, where sourness should contain it, bitterness should promote it, and sourness should restore it. The same applies to heat.

(Note: The fire of Shaoyang is the fire of the earth. When not balanced, it is due to internal excess. Therefore, it must be promoted with bitterness. This is the original energy of the Sanjiao, and it should be restored with sourness. Care should be taken not to let it excessively dissipate. The heat of Shaoyin represents the fire of the sovereign; when excessive, it combines internally and externally, and should also be resolved with bitterness.)

The victory of dryness is countered with warming bitterness, assisted by sourness and pungency, and managed with bitter diuretics.[343p]

　　 【注　苦温能胜清金，辛能润燥。燥必内结，故以酸苦泄之。】　　寒淫所胜，平以辛热，佐以甘苦，以咸泻之。　　 【注　夫淫于内，则干涉于脏气。故上文曰：以辛润之，以苦坚之。此胜于外，故宜平之泻之而已。】　　帝曰：善。邪气反胜，治之奈何？岐伯曰：风司于地，清反胜之，治以酸温，佐以苦甘，以辛平之。热司于地，寒反胜之，治以甘热，佐以苦辛，以咸平之。湿司于地，热反胜之，治以苦冷，佐以咸甘，以苦平之。火司于地，寒反胜之，治以甘热，佐以苦辛，以咸平之。[344p]

[Note: Bitter and warm can overcome clear and cold; pungent can moisten dryness. Dryness must be internally bound, thus it is released with sour and bitter. ] Cold and damp can be overcome by pungent heat, combined with sweet and bitter for expulsion. [Note: When dampness is internal, it interferes with the organs' energy. Thus, as previously stated, use pungent to moisten and bitter to firm up. This overcomes external elements, so it is suitable to balance and drain them.]

The Emperor said: Good. If pathogenic qi prevails, how should it be treated? Qi Bo replied: Wind dominates the earth, and clear can overcome it. Treat it with sour warmth, assisted by bitter and sweet, and neutralized with pungent. Heat dominates the earth, and cold can overcome it. Treat with sweet warmth, assisted by bitter and pungent, and neutralized with salty. Dampness dominates the earth, and heat can overcome it. Treat with bitter cold, assisted by salty and sweet, and neutralized with bitter. Fire dominates the earth, and cold can overcome it. Treat with sweet warmth, assisted by bitter and pungent, and neutralized with salty.[344p]

燥司于地，热反胜之，治以平寒，佐以苦甘，以辛平之，以和为利。寒司于地，热反胜之，治以咸冷，佐以甘辛，以苦平之。　　【注　邪气反胜者，不正之气反胜在泉主岁之气，又当用胜邪之气味以平治之。】　　帝曰：其司天邪胜何如？岐伯曰：风化于天，清反胜之，治以酸温，佐以甘苦。热化于天，寒反胜之，治以甘温，佐以苦酸辛。湿化于天，热反胜之，治以苦寒，佐以苦酸。火化于天，寒反胜之，治以甘热，佐以苦辛。燥化于天，热反胜之，治以辛寒，佐以苦甘。寒化于天，热反胜之，治以咸冷，佐以苦辛。　　【注　此论六气司天，邪气反胜，宜以所胜之气味平之也。】古今图书集成医部全录卷一百十六[345p]

When dryness governs the earth, heat overcomes it; treat it with balanced cold, supplement it with bitter and sweet flavors, temper it with pungent flavors, and harmony will yield benefits. When cold governs the earth, heat overcomes it; treat it with salty and cold properties, supplement it with sweet and pungent flavors, and temper it with bitterness.

[Note: When evil Qi overcomes, it refers to the improper Qi that overcomes in accordance with the yearly Qi of the water master, thus one should use the flavor of the overpowering evil Qi to balance it.]

The Emperor asked: How should the evil victories in heaven be addressed? Qi Bo replied: When wind transforms in heaven, clarity overcomes it; treat it with sour warmth, and supplement it with sweet and bitter. When heat transforms in heaven, cold overcomes it; treat it with sweet warmth, and supplement it with bitter, sour, and pungent. When moisture transforms in heaven, heat overcomes it; treat it with bitter cold, and supplement it with bitter and sour. When fire transforms in heaven, cold overcomes it; treat it with sweet heat, and supplement it with bitter and pungent. When dryness transforms in heaven, heat overcomes it; treat it with pungent cold, and supplement it with bitter and sweet. When cold transforms in heaven, heat overcomes it; treat it with salty cold, and supplement it with bitter and pungent.

[Note: This discusses the six Qi governing heaven, and when evil Qi overcomes, appropriate flavors should be used to counter it.][345p]

运气门

　　　　黄帝素问

　　　　　至真要大论 【下】

　　帝曰：六气相胜奈何？岐伯曰：厥阴之胜，耳鸣头眩，愦愦欲吐，胃膈如寒。大风数举，倮虫不滋。胠胁气并，化而为热，小便黄赤。胃脘当心而痛，上支两胁，肠鸣飧泄，少腹痛，注下赤白，甚则呕吐，膈咽不通。　　【注　此论三阴三阳主岁之气淫胜而为民病者，宜以所胜之气味平之。耳鸣头眩，木淫于上也。大风数举，淫于下而上也。愦愦欲吐，胃鬲如寒，胃土病也。倮虫不滋，木制之也。胠胁气并，肝气聚也。化而为热，小便黄赤，木淫而生火也。风木气胜则脾胃受伤，故风气淫于上，则胃脘当心而痛，上支两胁。甚则呕吐，膈咽不通，淫于下则肠鸣飧泄，少腹痛，注下赤白，所谓风之伤人也，善行而数变。[346p]

The Door of Luck

Huangdi’s Simple Questions

Discussion on the Ultimate Truth [Volume Two]

The Emperor said: How do the six Qi overcome one another? Qibo replied: The victory of Jueyin causes ear ringing and dizziness, a feeling of wanting to vomit, and a feeling of cold in the stomach. Frequent occurrences of strong wind prevent the growth of parasites. The Qi of the liver and diaphragm gathers and transforms into heat, leading to yellow and red urine. The pain is at the heart of the stomach; there’s pain under the ribs, and sounds in the intestines with diarrhea. There is pain in the lower abdomen, and the discharge is red and white; in severe cases, there may be vomiting, and the throat is obstructed.

[Note: This discussion is about the three Yin and three Yang that dominate the Qi of the seasons, causing illnesses among the people. It is appropriate to balance the prevailing Qi and its flavors. Ear ringing and dizziness signify excessive Wood effects upwards. Frequent strong winds indicate overreach from below upwards. The feeling of wanting to vomit and a cold in the stomach signify a stomach illness. The non-thriving of parasites signifies that Wood tones it down. Gathering of liver Qi indicates a buildup. Transforming into heat with yellow-red urine reflects the excess of Wood creating fire. When wind and Wood prevail, the spleen and stomach are affected; hence, when wind Qi overwhelms upward, it leads to pain in the stomach and heart, and discomfort below the ribs. In severe cases, there may be vomiting and obstructed throat; when it overwhelms below, there are sounds in the intestines with diarrhea, pain in the lower abdomen, and the discharge being red and white—which refers to the harm done by wind, good at acting and changing frequently.][346p]

】　　少阴之胜，心下热善饥，脐下反动，气游三焦。炎暑至，木乃津，草乃萎。呕逆躁烦，腹满痛，溏泄，传为赤沃。　　 【注　心下热善饥，外淫之火交于内也。脐下反动，少阴之标，阴发于下也。气游三焦，谓本标之气游于上下而交于中也。炎暑至者，与少阳气交之时。木乃津者，得少阴阴水之所资养也。草乃萎者，受君相二火之暑热也。呕逆，阴气上逆也。躁烦，阴阳寒热之征也。腹满溏泄，阴寒在下也。传为赤沃，君火下淫也。】　　太阴之胜，火气内郁，疮疡于中，流散于外，病在胠胁，甚则心痛热格，头痛喉痹，项强。独胜则湿气内郁，寒迫下焦，痛留顶互引眉间，胃满。雨数至，燥化乃见。少腹满，腰脽重强，内不便，善注泄，足下温，头重，足胫胕肿。[347p]

The victory of the Lesser Yin is characterized by heat beneath the heart, leading to a good appetite, along with a reaction below the navel and the qi circulating through the three burners. When summer heat arrives, the wood becomes moist, while the grass withers. Symptoms include nausea, vomiting, irritability, abdominal fullness and pain, diarrhea, and the manifestation of red dysentery.

(Note: Heat below the heart leads to a good appetite; the external fire interacts with the internal. The reaction below the navel indicates the mark of the Lesser Yin, with the yin venting from below. The qi circulating through the three burners refers to the primary qi moving up and down, meeting in the center. The arrival of summer heat coincides with the interaction of the Lesser Yang qi. Wood becoming moist indicates nourishment from the Lesser Yin's yin fluids. Grass withering is a result of the heat from the two fiery elements above. Nausea and vomiting indicate the upward rebellion of yin qi. Irritability is a sign of the interaction between yin and yang's cold and heat. Abdominal fullness and diarrhea indicate the presence of cold yin below. The manifestation of red dysentery reflects the downward indulgence of the ruling fire.)

The victory of the Greater Yin is characterized by internal accumulation of fire qi, leading to sores and ulcers within, and spreading outward. The illness affects the sides of the body; severe cases involve hot pain in the heart, headaches, throat obstruction, and stiffness of the neck. Alone, it triumphs when dampness accumulates internally, with cold pressing down on the lower jiao, causing pain that radiates from the crown and pulls between the eyebrows, along with fullness in the stomach. When rain comes frequently, dryness transforms into visibility. Symptoms include fullness in the lower abdomen, heaviness in the waist and lower back, discomfort internally, leading to ease of urination or diarrhea, warm feet, heavy head, and swelling in the legs and shins.[347p]

饮发于中，胕肿于上。　　【注　阴湿之气淫于外，则火气内郁，而疮疡于中矣。湿热之气流散于外，则及于风木而病胠胁。甚则心痛者，木甚而传于火也。热格头痛喉痹项强者，风火之气与湿气相杂，从颈项而上于巅顶也。此言太阴之气，火土相合而淫于岁半以前。独胜者，阴湿之气，复胜于岁半以后也。湿气在中，故内郁而迫于下焦。痛留顶而互引眉间者，风火之气留于巅顶，传于阳明之经，而下及于胃满也。雨数至，燥化乃见者，至四气五气之交而后见此证也。少腹满，腰脽重者，湿气下淫而及于肾也。足下温头重者，风火之气复流于下也。足胫胕肿者，土淫而水泛也。饮发于中，胕肿于上者，水邪之从下而中、中而上也。[348p]

Drinking rises from within, causing swelling above.

[Note: The moist and damp energy emanates externally, thus the heat energy is constrained internally, resulting in sores and ulcers within. When the damp heat energy spreads outward, it affects the wind and wood, leading to ailments in the ribs and flanks. In severe cases, it may cause heart pain, as the wood energy intensifies and transmits to the fire. Heat causing headaches, throat constriction, and stiff neck results from the mingling of wind-fire energy and dampness, rising from the neck to the top of the head. This speaks to the yin energy, which combines with fire and earth to manifest before mid-year. The dominant force afterwards is the damp and moist energy, which prevails post mid-year. The dampness in the middle causes internal stagnation that presses upon the lower organs. Pain centered at the top and drawing between the eyebrows indicates the wind-fire energy lingers at the crown, flowing through the yangming meridian and downward to congest the stomach. If rain frequently occurs and dryness is suddenly displayed, this condition appears at the exchanges of the four and five energies. Fullness in the lower abdomen and heaviness in the waist indicate the dampness rising and affecting the kidneys. Warm feet with heavy heads show the flow of wind-fire energy downward. Swollen shins and ankles are caused by earth and water intermingling. Drinking rises from within and swelling appears above, indicating the presence of water pathogens moving from the lower body, through the middle, to the upper.[348p]

】　　少阳之胜，热客于胃，烦心心痛，目赤欲呕，呕酸善饥，耳痛溺赤，善惊，谵妄。暴热消铄。草萎水涸，介虫乃屈。少腹痛，下沃赤白。　　 【注　少阳之气合三焦，故热客于胃。盖三焦之原，皆出于胃间也。三焦与心包络相合，故烦心心痛。三焦之脉，上入耳中，络目锐眦，故淫于上则为耳痛目赤，淫于中则为呕饥，淫于下则为溺赤、少腹痛、下沃赤白也。善惊谵妄暴热者，阳明胃经热也。三焦之气，蒸津液，化营血。消铄者，热甚而血液伤也。草萎者，暑热在上也。水涸者，火气在下也。介虫乃屈者，暑热在于气交之中，人与天地参也。】　　阳明之胜，清发于中，左胠胁痛，溏泄。内为嗌塞，外为(疒颓)疝。大凉肃杀，华英改容，毛虫乃殃。胷中不便，嗌塞而欬。[349p]

In the case of Lesser Yang's dominance, a hot pathogen invades the stomach, causing heart distress and pain, red eyes with a desire to vomit, sour vomiting accompanied by hunger, ear pain with red urine, easily frightened, and delirium. Violent heat causes consumption. Grass withers and water dries up, insects are forced to bend. Pain in the lower abdomen leads to red and white diarrhea.

(Note: The energy of Lesser Yang combines with the three burners, hence the heat residing in the stomach. The origin of the three burners emanates from the area of the stomach. The three burners connect with the pericardium, leading to heart distress and pain. The pulse of the three burners ascends to the ears, interlacing with the sharp corners of the eyes, therefore, indulgence above causes ear pain and red eyes, indulgence in the middle leads to sour vomiting and hunger, indulgence below results in red urine, lower abdominal pain, and red and white diarrhea. Easily frightened and delirious due to intense heat relates to the Yangming stomach channel's heat. The energy of the three burners steams fluids and transforms nutrients and blood. Consumption results from excessive heat harming the blood and fluids. Grass withering indicates heat above. Water drying indicates burning heat below. Insects bending represents heat present in the intersection of energies, where humans interact with heaven and earth.)

In the case of Yangming's dominance, clarity emerges from within. Left-sided rib pain and diarrhea occur. Internally there is a throat blockage, externally there is litigation-like hernia. Myriad coolness and coldness bring about transformation, while moths bring disaster. Discomfort in the chest leads to a blocked throat and coughing.[349p]

　　 【注　金气寒肃，故清发于中。金胜则木气受亏，故为胁痛(疒颓)疝。清气在下则为溏泄，在上则为嗌塞。大凉肃杀，淫胜极也，故华英改容，毛虫乃殃。胸中不便，嗌塞而咳者，阳明燥金及于肺，同气相感也。】　　太阳之胜，凝凓且至，非时水冰，羽乃后化。痔疟发，寒厥入胃，则内生心痛，阴中乃疡，隐曲不利，互引阴股，筋肉拘苛，血脉凝泣，络满色变，或为血泄，皮肤否肿，腹满食减，热反上行，头项囟顶脑户中痛，目如脱。寒入下焦，传为濡泻。　　【注　太阳寒水气胜，故凝凓且至。非时水冰者，胜气在于岁半以前，故羽虫后化也。《灵枢经》曰：足太阳是主筋所生病者为痔疟者，太阳寒热之邪也。厥逆而入于胃者，水侮土也。[350p]

The cold and austere energy of Metal leads to clear qi emerging from within. When Metal prevails, the energy of Wood becomes deficient, resulting in side pain (inguinal hernia). When clear qi is abundant below, it causes diarrhea; when abundant above, it causes throat obstruction. The great chill is violent and extreme; thus, flowers and elegance change, and caterpillars bring disaster. When there are difficulties in the chest, with throat blockage and coughing, it is due to the dryness of Metal affecting the Lung, responding to corresponding energies.

When the Sun's energy prevails, it solidifies and arrives, leading to icy conditions out of season, thus transforming later. When hemorrhoids and intermittent fever arise, cold and restraint invade the stomach, creating internal heart pain; within, ulcers develop, and hidden pathways are obstructed. Yin regions pull at one another, causing muscular and tendon constriction, blood vessels become clotted and weep, affecting color change; it may cause blood to leak, the skin to swell, the abdomen to bloat with diminished appetite, with heat reversing upward, causing pain in the head, neck, crown, and brain orbs seeming to detach. When cold enters the lower jiao, it leads to profuse diarrhea.

The cold water energy of the Sun prevails, thus it solidifies and arrives. The out-of-season icy water implies that the prevailing energy was strong a year and a half prior, thus causing the insects' later transformation. The "Spiritual Pivot" states that those suffering from hemorrhoids and intermittent fever are affected by the cold and hot evil of the Sun. When restraint enters the stomach, it indicates water insult to the earth.[350p]

胃络上通于心，故心痛也。阴中乃疡，是以隐曲不利而互引阴股。足太阳主筋，故筋肉拘苛也。血脉凝泣，络满色变，或为血泄，邪入于经也。皮肤否肿者，太阳之气主表也。腹满食减者，水气乘脾也。热反上行者，太阳之气随经上入脑，还出别下项。太阳经脉起于目内眦，故目如脱也。寒入下焦者，太阳标阳而本寒，是以阳热上行而阴寒下行也。】　　帝曰：治之奈何？岐伯曰：厥阴之胜，治以甘清，佐以苦辛，以酸泻之。少阴之胜，治以辛寒，佐以苦咸，以甘泻之。太阴之胜，治以咸热，佐以辛甘，以苦泻之。少阳之胜，治以辛寒，佐以甘咸，以甘泻之。阳明之胜，治以酸温，佐以辛甘，以苦泻之。太阳之胜，治以甘热，佐以辛酸，以咸泻之。[351p]

The stomach channels connect upwards to the heart, which is why heart pain occurs. In the realm of yin, there are ulcers, thus causing hidden curves to be obstructed and pulling at the yin groin. The foot's sun channel governs the tendons, which is why the muscles are tense and rigid. Blood vessels swell and change color, possibly leading to a blood discharge due to evil entering the meridians. If the skin is swollen and puffy, it is the sun’s qi that governs the surface. If the abdomen is distended with reduced appetite, it is due to water qi overwhelming the spleen. When heat rises instead of descending, the sun’s qi follows the meridians up into the brain and then emerges at the nape. The sun meridians originate at the inner canthus of the eyes, which is why the eyes may appear dislocated. When cold enters the lower burn, the sun signifies warmth while fundamentally being cold, resulting in yang heat rising and yin cold descending.

The Emperor asked, "How should it be treated?" Qi Bo replied: "For the victory of Jueyin, treat with sweet and clear remedies, assisted by bitter and pungent herbs, and sour to purge. For the victory of Shaoyin, treat with spicy and cold remedies, assisted by bitter and salty herbs, and sweet to purge. For the victory of Taiyin, treat with salty and hot remedies, assisted by spicy and sweet herbs, and bitter to purge. For the victory of Shaoyang, treat with spicy and cold remedies, assisted by sweet and salty herbs, and sweet to purge. For the victory of Yangming, treat with sour and warm remedies, assisted by spicy and sweet herbs, and bitter to purge. For the victory of Taiyang, treat with sweet and hot remedies, assisted by spicy and sour herbs, and salty to purge."[351p]

　　【注　治诸胜气，寒者热之，热者寒之，温者清之，清者温之，散者收之，抑者散之，燥者润之，急者缓之，坚者软之，脆者坚之，衰者补之，强者泻之。各安其气，则病气衰去。此治之大体也。】　　帝曰：六气之复何如？岐伯曰：悉乎哉问也！厥阴之复，少腹坚满，里急暴痛。偃木飞沙，倮虫不荣。厥心痛，汗发，呕吐饮食不入，入而复出，筋骨掉眩，清厥，甚则入脾，食痹而吐。冲阳绝，死不治。　　【注　复者，谓三阴三阳之气，受所胜之气胜制，郁极而复发也。少腹坚满，里急暴痛，厥阴之气，郁而欲发也。偃木飞沙，郁怒之气大复也。倮虫不荣，风气发而土气衰也。厥心痛者，色苍苍如死状，终日不得太息，此厥阴之气干于心也。[352p]

[Note: To treat various excessive conditions, warm the cold, cool the hot, clarify the warm, warm the clear, gather the dispersed, disperse the restrained, moisten the dry, soothe the urgent, soften the hard, harden the brittle, reinforce the weak, and drain the strong. When each condition is stabilized, pathogenic qi diminishes. This is the basic principle of treatment.]

The Emperor asked: "What about the resurgence of the six qi?" Qi Bo replied: "What a comprehensive question! The resurgence of Jueyin manifests as a hard and distended lower abdomen, with sudden and intense pain. Like trees swaying and sand flying, the warmth of life is absent. There is pain in the heart, sweating, vomiting, and inability to retain food, which goes in and then comes out again; there is dizziness in the muscles and bones, and if there is severe cold, it may affect the spleen, leading to food stagnation and vomiting. When Chongyang is exhausted, it results in death without treatment."

[Note: The resurgence refers to the qi of the three yin and three yang being defeated by excessive conditions, leading to a buildup that then breaks out. A hard and distended lower abdomen, coupled with sudden and intense pain, indicates that Jueyin's qi is pent up and ready to erupt. Like trees swaying and sand flying reflects a strong resurgence of pent-up anger. When the warmth of life is absent, it shows the wind qi has emerged while the earth qi has weakened. Heart pain is characterized by a pallid complexion like that of a corpse, with an inability to take deep breaths, indicating that Jueyin's qi is affecting the heart.][352p]

汗发者，风热之阳加于阴也。呕吐饮食不入，木淫而土败也。筋骨掉眩，风气盛也。清厥者。风淫于上，阴气下逆也。痹，闭痛也。冲阳，胃之动脉，此风气盛而土气绝也。】　　少阴之复，燠热内作，烦躁，鼽嚏，少腹绞痛，火见燔焫，嗌燥，分注时止，气动于左，上行于右，咳，皮肤痛，暴喑，心痛，郁冒不知人，乃洒淅恶寒振栗，谵妄，塞已而热，渴而欲饮，少气骨痿，隔肠不便，外为浮肿，哕噫。赤气后化，流水不冰，热气大行，介虫不复，病痱疹疮疡痈疽痤痔，甚则入肺，咳而鼻渊。天府绝，死不治。　　【注　燠热，郁热也。烦躁，火烦而阴躁也。鼽嚏，郁热上乘于肺也。少腹绞痛，少阴之阴气发于下也。火见燔焫，君火之气发于上也。嗌燥，火热铄金也。[353p]

Sweating indicates that the warmth of wind and heat is added to the Yin. Vomiting and inability to intake food suggest that excessive wood has caused the earth to fail. Muscle and bone pain indicates a surging of wind energy. Clear emptiness occurs when wind prevails above and Yin energy reverses downward. Pain due to obstruction is called Bi. The Chongyang is the artery of the stomach, and this indicates a surplus of wind energy while the energy of the earth is depleted.

The return of the lesser Yin brings internal heat, resulting in restlessness, sneezing, and cramping pain in the lower abdomen. Fire is seen raging; the throat is dry. Symptoms occur at intermittent times: energy moves on the left and rises on the right, leading to cough, skin pain, sudden mute episodes, heart pain, and mental confusion. There may also be chills and shivers, along with delirium, heat without relief, thirst leading to a desire for drink, shortness of breath, and muscular weakness. There is difficulty with bowel movements, external swelling, and belching. The red energy transforms behind, with flowing water unable to freeze. Heat energy spreads widely, insects do not reappear, and ailments like rashes, sores, pus-filled lesions, and carbuncles worsen, possibly entering the lungs, causing cough and nasal congestion. If the Tianfu point is blocked, it indicates a condition beyond cure.

(Note: Internal heat refers to oppressive heat. Restlessness suggests fiery irritability combined with an anxious state. Sneezing results from heat overwhelming the lungs. Cramps in the lower abdomen suggest the Yin energy of the lesser Yin is activated from below. The visible fire indicates the Yang energy rising from above. A dry throat implies the fire is excessively consuming fluids.)[353p]

夫阴寒在腹则注泄，得火热之气则注止，少阴标本并发，故注泄分而时注时止也。气动于左者，君火之气发于左肾之水中。上行于右者，肺肾上下相交，肾为本而肺为末也。火淫肺金，则咳而皮痛。金主声，故暴喑也。心痛者，火气自伤也。郁冒不知人者，寒热之气乱于上也。洒淅振栗者，阴阳相搏也。塞已而热者，少阴之阴寒从火化而为热也，故渴而欲饮。少气骨痿，盖火盛则少气，热盛则骨痿也。隔肠，小肠也。哕者，小肠之气不通，逆气上走心而为噫也。赤气后化者，复在五气终气，故流水不冰。痱疹疮疡，乃热伤气血。火热铄金，故天府绝也。】　　太阴之复，湿变乃举，体重中满，食饮不化，阴气上厥，胸中不便，饮发于中，咳喘有声。[354p]

If cold and damp are in the abdomen, it leads to diarrhea; when it gains the warmth of fire, the diarrhea stops. The minor yin manifests in both the root and the branch, thus diarrhea occurs intermittently. If the qi moves to the left, it indicates the yang fire rising from the water of the left kidney. If it ascends to the right, it shows the connection between the lungs and kidneys; the kidneys are the root while the lungs are the end. When fire affects the metal of the lungs, it leads to coughing and pain in the skin. Metal governs sound, hence the sudden loss of voice. Pain in the heart is due to self-inflicted fire damage. If one becomes depressed and fails to recognize others, it indicates chaotic cold and heat disturbances above. The sensation of trembling and chills represents the clash of yin and yang. If one feels blocked yet hot, it indicates that the cold of minor yin transforms into heat because of fire, resulting in thirst and a desire to drink. Weakness in the bones suggests that excessive fire leads to diminished energy, while extreme heat results in bone weakness. The small intestine, which is isolated, creates belching when its qi is obstructed, causing the reverse qi to ascend and produce a sound in the heart. The manifestation of red qi indicates a recovery in the five phases, hence water does not freeze. Rash and sores are due to heat harming qi and blood. The intense heat can melt metal, thus the heavenly repository is rendered ineffective. The return of the greater yin sees a transformation of moisture; the body feels heavy and full, food and drink do not digest, the yin qi ascends leading to chest discomfort, and fluid builds up within, resulting in coughing and wheezing sounds.[354p]

大雨时行，鳞见于陆。头项痛重而掉瘈尤甚，呕而密默，唾吐清液，甚则入肾，窍泻无度。太溪绝，死不治。　　【注　气极则变，阴湿之气盛，故体重中满，食饮不化。胸中，膻中也，宗气之所居，阴气上逆，是以胸中不便。咳喘有声者，饮乘于肺也。太阴所至为湿生，终为注雨。鳞见于陆者，土崩溃也。头项痛重而掉瘛尤甚者，所谓因于湿，首如裹，湿热不攘，大筋软短，小筋弛长，软短为拘，弛长为痿也。呕者。湿乘阳明也。密默者，欲闭户牖而独居也。脉解篇曰：所谓欲独闭户牖而虚者，阴阳相薄也。阳尽而阴盛，故欲闭户牖而居。盖阳明者，表阳也；太阴者，三阴也。阴变而乘于阳，则阳欲尽而阴盛，是以唾吐清液也。甚则入肾，下乘冬令之寒水也。[355p]

When it rains heavily, scales appear on land. The head and neck feel heavy and particularly painful, with vomiting and quietness; saliva is clear, and in severe cases, it enters the kidneys, leading to unrestricted leakage. If the Taiwei pulse is absent, there is no hope for recovery.

[Note: Extreme Qi leads to transformation; with excessive dampness, the body feels heavy and full, and food and drink do not digest. In the chest, the area known as "Xuan" is where the ancestral Qi resides; with Yin Qi rising in rebellion, discomfort occurs in the chest. Coughing and wheezing indicate fluid in the lungs. The appearance of scales on land signifies the earth's collapse. The severe heaviness and pain in the head and neck is attributed to dampness; the head feels wrapped, and since damp heat is not dispelled, the large tendons are short and soft, while the small tendons are elongated and relaxed; short and soft signify stiffness, and relaxed and elongated signify debility. Vomiting occurs due to dampness invading Yangming. Quietness indicates a desire to close the doors and windows and be alone. The chapter on pulses states that wanting to close doors and windows in emptiness indicates an imbalance between Yin and Yang. When Yang is exhausted and Yin is predominant, there is a desire to close off spaces. Yangming refers to the exterior Yang, while Taiyin refers to the three Yin channels. When Yin transforms and invades Yang, Yang tends to diminish while Yin thrives, resulting in the expulsion of clear saliva. In severe cases, it enters the kidneys, leading to the influence of the cold water of winter.][355p]

肾开窍于二阴，故曰窍泻。夫太阴居中土而旺于四季，是以胜气胜于四时，复气在于岁半以后，故止乘肺胃之秋金，冬令之肾水也。】　　少阳之复，大热将至，枯燥燔爇，介虫乃耗。惊瘛咳衄，心热烦躁，便数憎风，厥气上行，面如浮埃，目乃瞤瘛。火气内发，上为口糜呕逆，血溢血泄。发而为疟，恶寒鼓栗，寒极反热，嗌络焦槁，渴饮水浆，色变黄赤，少气脉萎，化而为水，传为胕肿，甚则入肺，咳而血泄。尺泽绝，死不治。　　【注　少阳之火，复发于秋冬之时，故枯燥燔爇。介虫乃耗，谓木枯草焦而甲虫耗散也。惊瘈咳衄，热乘心肺也。便数憎风，表里皆热也。面如浮埃，面微有尘也。手足少阳之脉，皆上系于目，故目乃瞤瘛。[356p]

The kidneys open to the two yin, hence it is called the "orifice draining." The greater yin resides in the central earth and thrives in the four seasons, thus it conquers qi and overcomes in the four times of the year. The restorative qi is found after the midpoint of the year, so it only interacts with the autumn metal of the lungs and the winter water of the kidneys.

The recovery of the lesser yang brings extreme heat. Dryness and burning consume, and insects begin to deplete. Startled spells, coughs, and bleeding from the heart create heat and irritability, resulting in aversion to wind. The qi rises, making the face look as if covered with dust, and the eyes twitch. Internal fire erupts, leading to oral sores and vomiting, blood spilling forth. This can lead to intermittents, coupled with chills and trembling; extreme cold can turn to heat, causing dryness in the throat and insatiable thirst for water. The complexion turns yellow-red, and there is diminished strength and a sinking pulse, transforming into water retention, leading to swelling that can progress to the lungs, resulting in coughing and blood loss. The pulse at the wrist is absent, and there is no hope of recovery.

Note: The fire of the lesser yang reemerges in the autumn and winter, hence the dryness and burning. "Insects begin to deplete" refers to withered wood and scorched grass leading to the depletion of insects. Startled spells and bleeding from the heart indicate heat invading the heart and lungs. Aversion to wind signifies heat within both the exterior and interior. A face that looks as if covered with dust indicates slight dulness. The lesser yang pulses in the hands and feet connect to the eyes, hence the twitching of the eyes.[356p]

火气内发者，阴火发于内也。发于上焦则为口糜，发于中焦则呕逆，发于下焦则血溢血泄也。发而为疟者，少阳主枢，是以寒热阴阳，外内出入。寒极反热，从火化也。嗌络焦槁，肺金伤也。渴饮水浆，阳明胃金燥也。太阴湿土，主四之气。色变黄赤者，火土相合也。少气脉萎者，气血皆伤也。化而为水，传为胕肿者，从四气五气而至于终之气也。】　　阳明之复，清气大举，森木苍干，毛虫乃厉。病生胠胁，气归于左，善太息，甚则心痛否满，腹胀而泄，呕苦，咳哕烦心，病在膈中，头痛，甚则入肝，惊骇筋挛。太冲绝，死不治。　　【注　阳明之复，发于本位主令之时，故清气大举，森木苍干，毛虫乃厉，病生胠胁。气归于左者，金乘木也。心痛痞满，腹胀而泄，乘火土也。[357p]

When the fire energy arises from within, it is the yin fire manifesting internally. If it arises in the upper burner, it results in mouth sores; if in the middle burner, it leads to vomiting and nausea; if in the lower burner, it causes bleeding and diarrhea. When it manifests as malaria, it is governed by the shaoyang, which regulates the dynamics of cold and heat, yin and yang, and the external and internal exchanges. Extreme cold can turn into heat, leading to the transformation of fire. Constriction in the throat indicates injury to the lung's metal element. Thirst during water intake indicates dryness in the stomach's metal element governed by yangming. The damp earth of taiyin governs the four bodily energies. When the color turns yellow or red, it signifies the conjunction of fire and earth. If the qi and pulse are weak, both qi and blood are damaged. When it transforms into water, and leads to swelling and lesions, it comes from the interactions of the four energies and five gases culminating in the final qi.

The recovery of yangming involves a significant expulsion of clear qi, as the lush trees grow tall and strong, causing pests to become harmful. Illness arises with abdominal distension and pain; qi returns to the left side, leading to deep sighing, and in severe cases, heart pain along with fullness, abdominal swelling with diarrhea, bitter vomiting, cough, irritability, and headaches. In severe cases, it may affect the liver, causing fright and muscle spasms. If tai chong is blocked, it leads to certain death.

(Note: The commentary explains that the recovery of yangming occurs during its governing period, hence the expulsion of clear qi and the growth of sturdy trees, which leads to abdominal illnesses. The return of qi to the left indicates the interaction of metal and wood. Heart pain and fullness with abdominal swelling signify the interplay of fire and earth.)[357p]

胆病者，善太息，呕苦，木受金刑，腑亦病也。咳哕，肺气逆也。咳哕烦心者，病在鬲中，阳明之气上逆也。头痛，厥阴病也。夫病生胠胁，头痛病在肝之经气，如入肝则干脏矣。干脏者半死半生，盖邪虽薄脏而脏真不伤者生，如太冲脉绝，真元伤矣。夫厥阴少阳少阴太阴之复，发于五气六气之时。阳明太阳之发，报复岁半以前之气，是以木火土之皆病也。】　　太阳之复，厥气上行，水凝雨冰，羽虫乃死。心胃生寒，胸膈不利，心痛痞满，头痛善悲，时眩仆，食减，腰脽反痛，屈伸不便。地裂冰坚，阳光不治。少腹控睪，引腰脊上冲心。唾出清水，及为哕噫，甚则入心，善忘善悲。神门绝，死不治。　　【注　厥气上行者，郁冒之气上行，而欲复岁半以前之气也。[358p]

Patients with gallbladder issues tend to sigh heavily, suffer from bitter vomiting, and are affected by wood suffering from the punishment of metal, which also causes sickness in the organs. Coughing up phlegm indicates lung Qi is rebelling. If coughing is accompanied by a feeling of heaviness in the heart, the illness is located in the diaphragm, where the Yangming Qi is reversing. Headaches are associated with the Jueyin disorder. When the ailment causes pain in the ribs, the headache is related to the liver’s meridian Qi; entering the liver can dry out the organ. A dried organ is half alive and half dead; although the pathogen may lightly disturb the organ, if the genuine essence is not harmed, one can still live. However, if the Taichong vessel is severed, the true essence is hurt. The recovery of Jueyin, Shaoyang, Shaoyin, and Taiyin occurs with the changes of the five and six Qi. The resurgence of Yangming and Taiyang corresponds to the Qi from half a year prior, which is why ailments of wood, fire, and earth occur.

The resurgence of Taiyang causes Jue Qi to rise, leading to condensation of water, rain, and ice, resulting in the death of insects. Coldness is generated in the heart and stomach, causing obstruction in the chest and diaphragm; there is pain and fullness in the heart, headaches that induce sadness, occasional dizziness and fainting, reduced appetite, and pain in the lower back that may refer to the heart. The earth cracks and ice forms, while sunlight fails to heal. There may be pain in the lower abdomen and a pulling sensation around the testicles that radiates to the waist and spine, pushing towards the heart. Saliva may turn clear, and there may be belching; in severe cases, it can enter the heart, causing forgetfulness and sadness. If the spirit gate is obstructed, it leads to a condition that is incurable.

(Note: The phrase "Jue Qi rising" refers to the upward movement of stagnant Qi, as it seeks to revert to the conditions of half a year prior.)[358p]

水凝，水气在下也。雨冰，寒气在上也。上下皆寒，故羽虫乃死，盖寒淫而火灭也。心胃生寒，胸膈不利，心痛痞满，头痛善悲，时眩仆者，厥气上行，从下而中，中而上也。食减，水乘土也。腰脽反痛，屈伸不利，水淫而反自伤也。阳光不治，木火之气衰也。少腹控睪引腰脊，上冲心者，厥阴病也。唾出清水，及为哕噫，从胃而上及于心也。盖亦报复岁半以前之木火土也。】　　帝曰：善。治之奈何？岐伯曰：厥阴之复，治以酸寒，佐以甘辛，以酸泻之，以甘缓之。少阴之复，治以咸寒，佐以苦辛，以甘泻之，以酸收之，辛苦发之，以咸软之。太阴之复，治以苦热，佐以酸辛，以苦泻之燥之泄之。少阳之复，治以咸冷，佐以苦辛，以咸软之，以酸收之，辛苦发之。[359p]

Water condenses, with moisture descending. Rain and ice signify coldness above. With cold present above and below, winged insects perish, as cold penetrates and extinguishes warmth. The heart and stomach become cold, causing obstruction in the chest and diaphragm, pain in the heart with fullness, headaches and feelings of sadness, and dizziness leading to fainting, where qi rises from below to the center and then upwards. Eating less leads to fluid overwhelming the earth element. Pain in the lower back and ribs, with difficulty in bending and stretching, arises from cold’s excessive influence causing self-harm. If yang fails to treat, the wood and fire elements weaken. Pain in the lower abdomen affecting the waist and spine that rises to the heart indicates a condition of the jueyin. Spitting clear water and experiencing belching arise from the stomach rising to the heart, reflecting a counteraction from earlier wood, fire, and earth elements of half a year prior.

The Emperor said: Good. How should it be treated? Qi Bo replied: For the revival of jueyin, treat with sour and cold, assisted by sweet and spicy, using sour to drain it and sweet to ease it. For the revival of shaoyin, treat with salty and cold, assisted by bitter and spicy, using sweet to drain and sour to gather, with spicy and bitter to disperse, and salty to soften. For the revival of taiyin, treat with bitter and warm, assisted by sour and spicy, to drain, dry, and expel. For the revival of shaoyang, treat with salty and cool, assisted by bitter and spicy, using salty to soften, sour to gather, and spicy and bitter to disperse.[359p]

发不远热，无犯温凉，少阴同法。阳明之复，治以辛温，佐以苦甘，以苦泄之，以苦下之，以酸补之。太阳之复，治以咸热，佐以甘辛，以苦坚之。　　【注　上篇曰，发表不远热，攻里不远寒，如少阳少阴之火郁而不解，是宜不远热而发散之，然无犯其温凉。盖四之气宜凉，五之气宜温，至终之气而后可用热，时气之不可不从也。阳明之复，以苦泄之，以苦下之者，谓渗泄其小便下其大便也。】　　治诸胜复：寒者热之，热者寒之，温者清之，清者温之，散者收之，抑者散之，燥者润之，急者缓之，坚者软之，脆者坚之，衰者补之，强者泻之。各安其气，必清必静，则病气衰去，归其所宗。此治之大体也。[360p]

Heat that does not extend far should not disturb the coolness; treat the lesser yin accordingly. For the recovery of the yangming, use warming methods with acrid herbs and assist with bitter and sweet elements, applying bitterness to promote urination and defecation, while using sourness to replenish. For the recovery of the taiyang, use salty and warming treatments, complemented by sweet and acrid herbs, and bitterness to strengthen.

In reference to the previous section, it is stated that when expressing heat that does not extend far, it attacks the interior without venturing into coldness. This is similar to the fires of the lesser yang and lesser yin being stagnant and unresolved, which makes it appropriate to release the heat while avoiding a disturbance of coolness. The four types of qi should be cool, while the five should be warm; only when reaching the final qi may heat be applied. One must not disregard the seasonal influences.

In treating various manifestations of recovery: heat should be countered with cold, cold with heat, warm with clarity, and clear with warmth; what disperses should be consolidated, what is restrained should be released, dryness should be moistened, urgency should be soothed, hardness softened, fragility solidified, deficiencies supplemented, and strengths drained. Each should maintain their essence, ensuring clarity and tranquility, so that the pathogenic qi diminishes and returns to its origin. This is the overarching principle of treatment.[360p]

　　 【注　五味六气之中，辛甘发散为阳，酸苦涌泄为阴，咸味涌泄为阴，淡味渗泄为阳。六者，或收或散，或缓或急，或燥或润，或软或坚；有补有泻，有逆有从。各随五行六气之所宜，安其胜复之气，使之必清必静，则病气衰而各居其所主之本位，此治之大体也。】　　帝曰：善。气之上下何谓也？岐伯曰：身半以上，其气三矣，天之分也，天气主之。身半以下，其气三矣，地之分也，地气主之。以名命气，以气命处，而言其病。半所谓天枢也。　　【注　此论人身之上下，以应天地之上下也。岁半以上，天气主之。乃厥阴风木，少阴君火，少阳相火。岁半以下，地气主之，乃太阴湿土，阳明燥金，太阳寒水。在人身厥阴风木之气与督脉会于巅顶，是木气在于火气之上矣。君火之下，包络相火主气，是木火火之三气，在身半以上也。[361p]

【Note: Among the five tastes and six qi, pungent and sweet are yang, sour and bitter are yin, salty taste is a release of yin, and bland taste seeps as yang. The six can either gather or disperse, be slow or rapid, dry or moist, soft or firm; there are both tonifying and purging effects, oppositional and conforming. Each corresponds to what is appropriate within the five elements and six qi, ensuring that the victorious and restorative qi is tranquil and pure, leading to a decline in disease qi and allowing each to reside in its natural position. This is the essence of healing.】 The Emperor said: "Good. What is meant by the qi above and below?" Qi Bo replied: "Above half of the body, there are three types of qi; this is the division of the heavens, with heavenly qi being the master. Below half of the body, there are also three types of qi; this is the division of the earth, with earthly qi being the master. By naming and commanding qi, and directing qi to places, we discuss illness. The halfway point is known as Tianshu." 【Note: This discussion refers to the upper and lower parts of the human body corresponding to those of heaven and earth. Above the halfway point, heavenly qi is dominant, consisting of Jueyin Wind Wood, Shaoyin Fire, and Shaoyang Fire. Below the halfway point, earthly qi is dominant, consisting of Taiyin Wet Earth, Yangming Dry Metal, and Taiyang Cold Water. In the human body, the qi of Jueyin Wind Wood meets with the Du meridian at the top, where the wood qi is above the fire qi. Below the Lord Fire, the enveloping ministerial fire commands qi, indicating that the three types of qi of wood and fire are situated above half of the body.】[361p]

脾土居阳明胃金之上，阳明居太阳膀胱之上，是土金水之三气，在身半以下也。以木火土金水之名，以命其上之三气，下之三气，以上下之三气，而命其在天在地之处，以天地之处，而言其三阴三阳之病，则胜复之气可知矣。半者，所谓天枢之分，在脐旁二寸，乃阳明之穴，以此分形身之上下也。夫所谓枢者，上下交互而旋转者也。故在天地，乃上下气交之中名天枢；在人身，以身半之中名天枢也。】　　故上胜而下俱病者，以地名之；下胜而上俱病者，以天名之。　　 【注　此言上下之胜气也。如身半以上之木火气胜，而身半以下之土金水三气俱病者，以地名之，谓病之在地也。[362p]

The Spleen, representing Earth, is positioned above the Stomach, which is associated with Metal, while the Yangming is located above the Taiyang Bladder. These represent the three energies of Earth, Metal, and Water, which reside below the midpoint of the body. By naming the upper and lower three energies as Wood, Fire, Earth, Metal, and Water, and identifying their existence in the heavens and the earth, we can understand the conditions of the three Yin and three Yang. The midpoint, referred to as the Heavenly Pivot, is located two inches beside the navel, marking the area of the Yangming. This serves to differentiate the upper and lower parts of the body. The term "pivot" signifies the interchanging and rotating nature of the upper and lower energies. Thus, in the realm of heaven and earth, the Heavenly Pivot is named within the interplay of these energies; in the human body, it is named as the midpoint. Therefore, when the upper energies prevail and the lower energies are both afflicted, it is named after the earth; when the lower energies prevail and the upper energies are both afflicted, it is named after the heavens.

(Note: This discusses the supremacy of energies above and below. For instance, if the Wood and Fire energies above the midpoint prevail while the three energies of Earth, Metal, and Water below are afflicted, it is referred to as a disease based on its earthly nature.)[362p]

如身半以下之土金水胜，而身半以上之木火气病者，以天名之，谓病之在天也。盖以人身之上下，以应天地之上下，故以天地名之。】　　所谓胜至，报气屈伏而未发也。复至，则不以天地异名。皆如复气为法也。　　 【注　此言上下之复气也。如胜至，则报复之气屈伏于本位而未发也；复至，则如复气而为法，不必以天地而名之。如厥阴少阴少阳之复，其气发于四气五气之时，阳明太阳之复，其气归于初气二气之木火。故不必以木火居岁半以上，而以天名之；金水主岁半以下，而以地名之。皆如复气之所在而为成法也。】　　帝曰：胜复之动，时有常乎？气有必乎？岐伯曰：时有常位，而气无必也。帝曰：愿闻其道也。岐伯曰：初气终三气，天气主之，胜之常也。四气尽终气，地气主之，复之常也。有胜则复，无胜则否。[363p]

If the earth, metal, and water of the lower half of the body prevail, while the wood, fire, and qi of the upper half are in a state of illness, this is named after heaven, signifying the illness’s presence in heaven. This is based on the correspondence between the upper and lower parts of the human body and the upper and lower realms of heaven and earth, hence the terminology related to heaven and earth.

Regarding what is referred to as "arrival of victory," this means that the retaliatory qi is subdued and has yet to manifest. When it returns, it is not named differently than heaven and earth; it operates according to the principle of returning qi.

This refers to the returning qi of the upper and lower aspects. When victory arrives, the retaliatory qi is subdued in its original state and not yet released; when it returns, it acts like returning qi and does not require different names based on heaven and earth. For instance, in the case of the lesser yin, lesser yang, and so on, when their qi manifests in relation to the four and five phases, the yangming and taiyang cycles cause their qi to return to initial energies of wood and fire. Thus, it is unnecessary to designate wood and fire to the upper half of the year and name it after heaven; rather, metal and water, governing the lower half of the year, are named after earth. Everything is based on the location of the returning qi and the established principle.

The Emperor asked: "Is the movement of victory and return constant with time? Is it necessary for qi to be so?" Qi Bo replied: "There is a constant position in time, but qi is not necessarily fixed." The Emperor expressed his desire to understand the way. Qi Bo explained: "Initial qi culminates in the three qi, governed by heavenly qi, which is the constancy of victory. When the four qi terminate in the completing qi, it is governed by earthly qi, which is the constancy of return. Where there is victory, there is return; where there is no victory, there is none."[363p]

　　【注　帝问胜复之气，随四时之有常位乎？其气动随四时之可必乎？伯言木火土金水四时有定位，而胜复之气，不随所主之本位而发，故气不可必也。盖谓六气各主一岁，主岁之气胜，则春将至而即发，是太阴阳明太阳之气，皆发于春夏矣。如六气之复，乃郁极而后发，故发于岁半之后，是厥阴少阴少阳之复皆发于秋冬矣。故曰初气终三气，天气主之，胜之常也。四气尽终气，地气主之，复之常也。有胜则复，无胜则否。是以胜复之气，不随四时之常位而不可必也。】　　帝曰：善。复已而胜何如？岐伯曰：胜至则复，无常数也，衰乃止耳。复已而胜，不复则害，此伤生也。　　 【注　此明有胜则复，展转不已，必待其胜气衰而后乃止耳。[364p]

The Emperor asked, "Is the qi of victory and recovery in accordance with the fixed positions of the four seasons? Can this qi move according to the inevitability of the four seasons?" Bo said, "The wood, fire, earth, metal, and water of the four seasons have their predetermined locations, but the qi of victory and recovery does not emerge from its principal position; therefore, it cannot be certain. It is said that each of the six qi governs a year, and if the qi of that year is victorious, it will emerge as spring approaches, guided by the qi of Taiyin, Yangming, and Taiyang, all of which arise in spring and summer. As for the return of the six qi, they manifest only after they have reached their peak, hence they emerge after the middle of the year, where the recovery of Jueyin, Shaoyin, and Shaoyang occurs in autumn and winter. Thus, it is said that the initial qi lasts for three periods, governed by the heavenly qi, and this is the norm of victory. The four qi reach their conclusion with the ending qi, which is governed by the earthly qi, and this is the norm of recovery. Where there is victory, there is recovery; where there is no victory, there is none. Therefore, the qi of victory and recovery does not adhere strictly to the fixed positions of the four seasons and cannot be deemed certain."

The Emperor said, "Good. What happens after recovery and victory?" Qibo replied, "When victory arrives, recovery follows, but there are no fixed numbers; only when decline occurs does it cease. If recovery occurs and then victory does not return, it is harmful. This injures life."

This clarifies that where there is victory, recovery continues indefinitely, but it must await the decline of the victorious qi before it can stop.[364p]

复已而胜者，如火气复而乘其金已，则金气又复胜之，金气复而侮其火已，则火气又复胜之，所谓胜至则复，无常数也，如胜气衰而后乃止耳。故复气已，而受复之气又复胜之。如火气复而胜其金，则金气又当复胜，如不复胜，此金为火气所害，而金之生气伤矣。故必待其胜衰而后平，如有胜则有复也。】　　帝曰，复而反病何也？岐伯曰：居非其位，不相得也。大复其胜，则主胜之，故反病也。所谓火燥热也。　　 【注　复而反病，复气之反病也。如火气复而乘于金位，金气复而乘于火位，皆居非其位不相得也。是以大复其胜，则主胜之，故反病也。如火气大复而乘于阳明，则五位之主气胜之，如金气大复而乘于少阴，则二位之主气胜之，故复气之反病，所谓火热燥也。[365p]

The restoration of balance leads to victory; just as the fire element, having regained its strength, overcomes metal, metal then regains its strength and overcomes fire in turn. This cycle of overcoming and restoring is variable, without fixed patterns, only ceasing when the overpowering energy diminishes. Hence, when the restorative energy manifests, it can also gain the upper hand. If fire, re-establishing itself, overcomes metal, then metal must also regain its strength. If it fails to regain strength, metal will suffer harm from fire, thus injuring its vitality. Therefore, one must wait for the decline of power before balance is achieved; wherever there is overcoming, there is also restoration.

The Emperor asked, "What is the illness of restoration and reversal?" Qi Bo replied, "It is due to occupying an improper position, leading to disharmony. When restoration achieves dominance, then its master prevails, hence the reversal of illness, which is characterized by heat and dryness associated with fire."

The reversal of restoration refers specifically to the illness stemming from the restorative energy. For example, when fire regains strength and dominates the metal position, the metal energy likewise regains its strength and dominates fire's position; both are out of place and thus fail to harmonize. Therefore, when restoration achieves dominance, its master prevails, resulting in the reversal of illness. When fire's energy strongly dominates in Yangming, the main energies of the five positions overpower it; similarly, when metal's energy strongly dominates in Shaoyin, the main energies of the two positions overpower it. This illustrates the illness of the restorative energy, characterized by the heat and dryness of fire.[365p]

余气皆然。即胜至则复，胜衰则止之意。盖胜复之气，宜于渐衰，而不宜于复大也。】　　帝曰，治之何如？岐伯曰：夫气之胜也，微者随之，甚者制之。气之复也，和者平之，暴者夺之。皆随胜气，安其屈服。无问其数，以平为期。此其道也。　　 【注　微者随之，顺其气以调之。甚者制之，制以所畏。和者平之，平调其微。邪暴者夺之，泻其强盛。但随胜气以冶，则屈伏之气自安矣。然不必问其胜复之展转，惟以气平为期。此治胜复之道也。】　　帝曰：善。客主之胜复奈何？岐伯曰：客主之气胜，而无复也。　　【注　此论四时主气客气之胜复也。】　　帝曰：其逆从何如？岐伯曰：主胜逆，客胜从，天之道也。[366p]

The remaining Qi behaves in this manner. When the victorious Qi returns, it revives; when the victorious Qi wanes, it ceases. The Qi of victory and revival is suitable for gradual decline, but not for a great resurgence.

The Emperor asked, "How should it be governed?" Qi Bo replied: "When the Qi is victorious, the subtle ones follow it, and the extreme ones are restrained. When the Qi revives, the harmonious ones are balanced, and the violent ones are subdued. All conform to the victorious Qi, ensuring their submission. Without concern for their numbers, the goal is to achieve balance. This is the way."

The commentary states: "The subtle ones follow it, adapting to its Qi for adjustment. The extreme ones are restrained, controlled by what they fear. The harmonious ones are balanced, moderating the subtle. The wayward and violent are subdued, their strength diminished. But by merely following the victorious Qi, the Qi of submission will be naturally at peace. There is no need to inquire about the fluctuations of victory and revival; only establishing balance in Qi is the goal. This is the method of governing victory and revival."

The Emperor said, "Good. How about the victory and revival of host and guest?" Qi Bo replied: "The Qi of the host is victorious and without revival."

The commentary adds: "This discusses the victory and revival of the main Qi and the guest Qi across the four seasons."

The Emperor asked, "What of the contraries?" Qi Bo replied: "When the host is victorious, it is contrary; when the guest is victorious, it is in accordance with the way of heaven."[366p]

　　 【注　客气者，乃司天在泉及左右之间气，在天之六气也。天包乎地之外，从泉下而六气环转，天之道也。主气者，五方四时之定位，地之道也。坤顺承天，是以主胜为逆，客胜为从，顺天之道也。】　　帝曰：其生病何如？岐伯曰：厥阴司天，客胜则耳鸣掉眩，甚则咳；主胜则胸胁痛，舌难以言。　　 【注　风木之客气胜于上，是以耳鸣掉眩。厥阴肝木，贯膈上注肺。甚则咳者，上淫之气，内入于经也。主胜则胸胁痛，肝经之脉布胸胁也。厥阴少阳主筋，二经之筋病则舌卷，故难以言。盖客气之从上而下，主气之从内而上也。】　　少阴司天，客胜则鼽嚏，颈项强，肩背瞀热，头痛，少气发热，耳聋目瞑，甚则胕肿血溢，疮疡咳喘；主胜则心热烦躁，甚则胁痛支满。[367p]

Note: The guest qi refers to the energies governed by the heavens, located between the springs and their surroundings, one of the six energies of heaven. Heaven encompasses the earth, and from beneath the springs, the six energies circulate, reflecting the way of heaven. The main qi pertains to the positioning of the five directions and four seasons, embodying the way of the earth. Kun (the earth) follows heaven, thus the main qi overcomes the guest qi in opposition, while the guest qi follows in compliance, aligning with the way of heaven.

The Emperor asked: "What are the symptoms of life-threatening illnesses?" Qi Bo replied: "When the Jueyin (Liver) governs the heavens, if the guest qi prevails, there will be ringing in the ears and dizziness, and in severe cases, coughing; if the main qi prevails, there will be pain in the chest and flanks, and difficulty in speaking."

Note: When the guest qi of wind and wood prevails from above, it causes ringing in the ears and dizziness. The Jueyin liver is linked to the lungs through the diaphragm. In severe cases, coughing indicates the excess qi entering the meridians. When the main qi prevails, it results in pain in the chest and flanks, as the liver meridian spreads through these areas. The Jueyin and Shaoyang govern tendons; when the two meridians are afflicted, the tongue curls, leading to difficulty in speaking. Guest qi descends from above, while main qi ascends from within.
