When the Shaoyin (Heart) governs the heavens, if the guest qi prevails, there will be sneezing, stiff neck, heat in the shoulders and back, headaches, shortness of breath with fever, deafness and closed eyes, and in severe cases, swelling, blood leakage, sores, and cough-induced wheezing; if the main qi prevails, there will be heart heat and irritability, and in severe cases, pain and fullness in the flanks.[367p]

　　 【注　少阴司天，初之气乃太阳寒水，二之气乃厥阴风木，三之气乃少阴君火。鼽嚏耳聋目瞑，厥阴之气胜也。头项强、肩背瞀热、头痛，甚则胕肿，太阳寒水之气胜也。少气发热，血溢疮疡咳喘，君火之气胜也。初之主气乃厥阴风木，二之气君火，三之气相火，主胜则心热烦躁者，君相二火之气胜也。甚则胁痛支满者，厥阴之初气胜也。盖君火司岁，故先火胜，而甚则及于厥阴。】　　太阴司天，客胜则首面胕肿，呼吸气喘。主胜则胸腹满，食已而瞀。　　 【注　客胜则首面胕肿，湿淫于上也。呼吸气喘，淫及于内也。主胜则胸腹满者，初气之木胜伤土也。经云，肺是动病甚则交两手而瞀，乃二气三气之火，上炎而为肺病也。[368p]

Notes:
In the Lesser Yin phase of heaven, the initial energy is the cold water of the Greater Yang, the second energy is the wind and wood of the Jue Yin, and the third energy is the fire of the Lesser Yin. Symptoms such as sneezing, deafness, and closed eyes indicate an excess of Jue Yin energy. Symptoms like stiff neck, shoulder and back heat, and headaches, especially severe cases leading to swelling, indicate an excess of the cold water energy of the Greater Yang. Mild energy surges with fever, blood overflow in sores or coughing and wheezing indicate an excess of the fire energy of the monarch. The initial controlling energy is the wind and wood of Jue Yin, the second energy is the monarch fire, and the third energy is the mutual fire. When the controlling energy prevails, it results in heart heat and restlessness, indicating the dominance of both monarch and mutual fire energies. In severe cases, pain in the ribs and fullness indicates an excess of Jue Yin's initial energy. This is attributed to the monarch fire governing the year, hence the supremacy of fire, which can lead to Jue Yin symptoms.

In the Greater Yin phase of heaven, when the external energy prevails, symptoms include swelling in the head and face, along with respiratory distress. When the internal energy prevails, it results in fullness in the chest and abdomen, leading to restlessness post meals.

Notes:
When the external energy prevails, swelling in the head and face indicates dampness affecting the upper body. Respiratory distress indicates dampness affecting the internal organs. When the internal energy prevails, fullness in the chest and abdomen indicates that the initial energy of wood overwhelms and injures the earth element. According to the classics, the lungs are affected by severe external illnesses, leading to a condition where both hands are crossed, signaling the interrelation of the second and third energies’ fire, resulting in lung diseases.[368p]

】　　少阳司天，客胜则丹胗外发，及为丹熛疮疡，呕逆喉痹，头痛嗌肿，耳聋血溢，内为瘛瘲，主胜则胸满咳仰息，甚而有血，手热。　　【注　少阳司天，初气三气乃君相二火，二之气乃太阴湿土。丹胗即斑疹，因火热而发于外也。丹熛，即赤游发于外而欲游于内也。呕逆瘛瘲，湿土之气合于内也。疮疡嗌肿诸证，亦皆感湿热而生，盖亦自上而下，从外而内也。肺乃心之盖，主胜则胸满，咳仰息者，主气之二火，欲上炎而外出也。仰息者，肺病而不得偃息也。甚而有血手热者，火发于外也。君相二经之脉，皆循于手，故为手热。】　　阳明司天，清复内余，则咳衄嗌塞，心鬲中热。欬不止而白血出者死。　　 【注　清复内余者，清肃之客气入于内而复有余也。咳衄嗌塞，心膈中热，皆肺病也。[369p]

When the Lesser Yang governs the heavens, if the external influence of guests prevails, it leads to the emergence of rash-like conditions, resulting in red eruptions from within. This includes symptoms such as vomiting, throat obstruction, headaches, throat swelling, deafness, blood discharge, and internal disturbances. When these conditions prevail, symptoms manifest as chest fullness, cough, difficulty in breathing, and in severe cases, there may be blood and hot hands.

Note: The Lesser Yang governs the heavens, and its initial energy involves the interaction of two types of fire. The dual energies correspond to the dampness of the Greater Yin. "Dan Zhen" refers to rashes that appear externally due to heat. "Dan Chao" signifies eruptions that emerge outwardly but wish to penetrate inwardly. Vomiting and internal disturbances arise from the convergence of damp and earthy energies. Symptoms such as sores and throat swelling develop due to damp-heat; these conditions originate from above and descend from the outside to the inside. The lungs, which cover the heart, exhibit symptoms related to chest fullness and cough, wherein the dual fires of vital energy rise and seek external release. Difficulty in breathing indicates lung illness preventing rest. Severe symptoms include blood and hot hands, indicating fire emerging externally. The channels of the two governing energies traverse through the hands, hence the observation of warm hands.

When the Greater Yang governs the heavens, if the internal remnants of clarity are restored, it leads to persistent cough and nosebleeds with throat blockage and heat in the heart. If the cough does not cease and white blood emerges, it indicates death.

Note: Restoring the internal remnants of clarity means that the clear and serene guest energy enters within but remains excessive. Coughing, nosebleeds, and throat blockage indicate lung disease and heat within the heart cavity.[369p]

肺属金而主天，是以阳明司天之气余于内，而病在肺也。白血出者，血出于肺也，阳明司天，天之气也。脏属阴而血为阴，血出于肺，则阳甚而阴绝矣。】　　太阳司天，客胜则胸中不利，出清涕，感寒则咳；主胜则喉嗌中鸣。　　 【注　太阳之气在表，而肺主皮毛，是以受司天之客气，即为胸中不利，出清涕而咳。感寒则咳者，谓太阳与寒水有别也。主胜则喉嗌中鸣，乃在下寒水之气而上出于肺也。】　　厥阴在泉，客胜则大关节不利，内为痉强拘瘛，外为不便；主胜则筋骨繇并，腰腹时痛。　　【注　大关节，手足之十二节也。厥阴在泉，始之客气，乃阳明燥金，厥阴主筋，筋燥是以关节不利。[370p]

The lung is associated with metal and governs the sky. Therefore, the yangming controls the qi of the sky, which remains within, resulting in disease in the lung. When blood comes out, it is from the lung, as yangming oversees the sky, which is its qi. The organs are associated with yin, and blood is yin. When blood flows from the lung, it indicates excessive yang and a depletion of yin.

When the taiyang is governing the sky, if the guest is victorious, there will be discomfort in the chest, leading to clear nasal discharge and cough when subjected to cold; if the host is victorious, there will be a sound in the throat.

(Note: The taiyang qi is on the surface, while the lung governs the skin and hair. Hence, when it receives the guest qi of the sky, there will be discomfort in the chest, resulting in clear nasal discharge and cough. The statement regarding coughing due to cold indicates the distinction between taiyang and cold water. The host being victorious results in sound in the throat, which arises from the cold water’s qi below coming forth from the lung.)

In the jueyin, when the guest is victorious, the major joints will be uncomfortable, leading to internal spasms and rigidity, and externally causing inconvenience; when the host is victorious, the muscles and bones will be tense, with occasional pain in the waist and abdomen.

(Note: The major joints refer to the twelve joints of the hands and feet. The jueyin is associated with the springs; the guest qi obtained from the yangming causes dryness due to metal, which leads to the tension in the joints.)[370p]

次之客气，乃太阳寒水，太阳为诸阳主气，阳气者，柔则养筋，寒气淫于内，则太阳受之，故内为痉强拘瘛之痓证。终之客气，乃在泉之风木，故外为不便。不便者，亦筋骨之不利也。《灵枢》根结篇曰：骨繇者，节缓而不收也。所谓骨繇者，摇故也。在泉之主气，乃太阴湿土，阳明燥金，太阳寒水。筋骨繇并腰腹时痛者，三气之为病也。】　　少阴在泉，客胜则腰痛，尻股膝脾腨胻足病，瞀热以酸，胕肿不能久立，溲便变；主胜则厥气上行，心痛发热，膈中众痹皆作，发于胠胁，魄汗不藏，四逆而起。　　【注　四之客气，乃太阳寒水，故为腰尻股胻足病，此太阳经证同气相感也。次之客气，乃厥阴风木，瞀热以酸，胕肿不能久立，乃脾土之证，盖木淫而土病也。终之客气，乃少阴君火，主气乃太阳寒水。[371p]

Next, the guest Qi is that of the cold water of the sun. The sun governs the vital energy of all Yang; the Yang energy, when gentle, nourishes the tendons. If the cold energy lingers within, the sun experiences it, leading to internal conditions of spasm and rigidity, known as the stubbornness of sinew and muscle. The guest Qi at the end pertains to the wind and wood of the spring, thus the external manifestation is one of inconvenience. Inconvenience also implies a disadvantage to the sinews and bones. The "Lingshu" states: "The bones are loose, the joints are slack and do not gather." What is referred to as bone looseness is actually excessive movement.

In the vital energy of spring, the Taiyin governs the moist earth, the Yangming governs the dry metal, and the sun governs the cold water. If the sinews and bones become loose alongside waist and abdominal pain, this indicates illness arising from the interaction of the three energies.

When the Shaoyin Qi rules at the spring, a guest victory leads to waist pain, affecting the buttocks, knees, spleen, and legs, accompanied by dizziness, heat, and sourness, with swelling that prevents prolonged standing, affecting urination and bowel movements. When the host prevails, the Qi of counterflow ascends, causing heart pain and heat, with multiple obstructions in the diaphragm manifesting in the ribs, with the spirit's sweat unable to be retained, leading to four reversals.

The guest Qi of the four is that of the cold water of the sun, hence the waist, buttocks, thighs, and legs are affected; this is a manifestation of the sun channel's condition in relation to similar energies. The next guest Qi is that of the Jueyin wind and wood, leading to dizziness, heat, sourness, and swelling impeding standing, indicating the condition of the spleen’s earth, as wood excess causes the earth to suffer. The final guest Qi is that of the Shaoyin fire, with the governing Qi being the cold water of the sun.[371p]

溲便变者，水火相交，火淫于下也。主胜则厥气上行，心痛发热者，乃寒水之主气，上乘于在泉之君火也。五之主气，乃阳明燥金，客气乃厥阴风木。众痹者，各在其处，更发更止，更居更起，以右应左，以左应右。膈中众痹皆作，发于胠胁，乃阳明之气乘于厥阴之经也。四之主气，乃太阴湿土，客气乃太阳寒水。魄汗，表汗也。汗乃阴液。膀胱者，津液之所藏。四逆而起者，土气上逆也。以土胜水，是以津液不藏而汗出于表也。】　　太阴在泉，客胜则足痿下重，便溲不时，湿客下焦，发而濡泻，及为肿隐曲之疾；主胜则寒气逆满，食饮不下，甚则为疝。　　【注　足痿下重，便溲不时者，在泉之湿气，客于太阴之经，而下及于内也。[372p]

The transformation of urine and stool is caused by the interplay of water and fire, with fire manifesting below. When the primary force is strong, the qi rises; when there is heart pain and heat, it is due to the governing qi of cold water rising above, overpowering the monarch fire at the spring. The primary force of the fifth is the dry metal of Yangming, while the guest qi is the wind wood of Jueyin. Various obstructions exist in their respective places, some worsen and then cease, some reside and then rise, with right responding to left and left to right. Various obstructions in the diaphragm arise from the sides, as the qi of Yangming conquers the meridian of Jueyin. The primary force of the fourth is the damp earth of Taiyin, while the guest qi is the cold water of Taiyang. The po sweat is the exterior sweat. Sweat is the yin fluid. The bladder is where fluids are stored. If there is reverse movement, it is the earth qi rising. By earth overcoming water, fluids are not stored, and sweat emerges on the surface.

When Taiyin prevails at the spring, if the guest qi is strong, there will be weakness in the legs and heaviness below, with urination and defecation occurring at odd times. The dampness of the guest affects the lower focus, causing moist diarrhea and contributing to diseases like edema and hidden curvature. If the primary force is strong, there will be a reversal of cold qi, a fullness that restricts food and drink intake, potentially leading to hernias.

(Note: "Weakness in the legs and heaviness below, urination and defecation at odd times" refers to dampness at the spring affecting the meridian of Taiyin, reaching inward.)[372p]

湿客下焦，发而濡泻及为肿者，因客淫于下，而太阴之主气自病也。隐曲，乃男女之前阴处。终之主气，乃太阳寒水，客气乃司天之湿土，是以主胜则寒气逆满，盖水淫而上乘于土，故逆满也。四之主气乃太阴湿土，客气乃厥阴风木。食饮不下，甚则为疝者，湿气上逆，而病及于厥阴之经也。五之主气乃阳明秋金，客气乃少阴君火，火能制金，故不上胜也。】　　少阳在泉，客胜则腰腹痛而反恶寒，甚则下白溺白；主胜则热反上行而客于心，心痛发热，格中而呕。少阴同候。　　【注　少阳在泉，始之客气乃少阴君火，主气乃太阴湿土；次之客气乃太阴湿土，主气乃阳明燥金；终之客气乃少阳相火，主气乃太阳寒水。腰腹痛而反恶寒者，客胜而太阳之主气病也。太阳之气伤，故恶寒也。[373p]

When the dampness in the lower abdomen manifests as fluid discharge or swelling, it is due to indulgence in sexual activities below, causing illness to the governing qi of the Taiyin. "Yinqu" refers to the areas of the genitals between men and women. The governing qi of the end is the cold water of the Yangming, while the guest qi is the damp earth of the Tian (Heaven); therefore, when the governing qi is strong, the cold qi reverses upward. This occurs because the water overabundance ascends and overpowers the earth, leading to a reversal.

The governing qi of the Four Directions is the damp earth of the Taiyin, while the guest qi represents the wind wood of the Jueyin. When food and drink are not taken, it may lead to hernias when the damp qi rises upward and affects the channels of the Jueyin. The governing qi of the Five Elements is the autumn metal of the Yangming, while the guest qi is the fire of the Shaoyin. Fire can control metal, which is why it does not ascend and dominate.

When the Shaoyang is in the spring, if the guest strong is present, it causes pain in the waist and abdomen with adverse cold symptoms, and in severe cases, it results in white urine; conversely, if the governing qi is strong, heat ascends and affects the heart, causing heart pain and fever with nausea. The situation of the Shaoyin is similar.

(Note: The notes clarify that when the Shaoyang is in the spring, the initial guest qi is the fire of the Shaoyin, with the governing qi as the damp earth of the Taiyin. Subsequently, the guest qi becomes the damp earth of the Taiyin, with the governing qi as the dry metal of the Yangming. Finally, the guest qi becomes the fire of the Shaoyang, while the governing qi is the cold water of the Taiyang. Pain in the waist and abdomen with adverse cold indicates that the guest is strong and the governing qi of the Taiyang is ill. The injury to the qi of the Taiyang causes the adverse cold.)[373p]

甚则溺白下白者，病及于阳明太阴之主气也。盖金主气，气化则溺出。溺白者，气不化而溺不清也。下白者，土气伤而大便色白也。因客胜而主气反病，故曰反。主胜则热反上行而客于心，心痛发热者，君相二火之客气，反上行而自病也。格中而呕者，太阴之客气自病也。因主胜而客反自病，故曰反、曰客，曰少阴同候，谓火性炎上，故二火皆有反逆之自病也。】　　阳明在泉，客胜则清气动下，少腹坚满而数便泻；主胜则腰重腹痛，少腹生寒，下为鹜溏，则寒厥于肠，上冲胸中，甚则喘不能久立。　　 【注　清气动下者，清肃之天气而动于下也。少腹坚满而数便泻者，太阳寒水之病也。主胜则腰重腹痛，少腹生寒者，太阳水寒之气发于下也。[374p]

In severe cases, the presence of white in urine indicates an issue with the Yangming and Taiyin vital energies. The vital energy of Metal, when transformed, results in urination. White urine signifies that the energy is not transforming properly, causing unclear urine. The presence of white stools indicates that the Earth energy is damaged, resulting in pale feces. When the guest energy overcomes the host energy, it causes the latter to rebel, hence the term "rebel." When the host energy prevails, the heat reverses and ascends, affecting the heart. Heart pain accompanied by fever indicates that the guest energy of the two types of fire also ascends and causes disease. If one experiences nausea and vomiting, it signals that the guest energy of the Taiyin is ill. When the host prevails and the guest energy rebels, this is referred to as "rebel" or "guest," and the lesser Yin corresponds. The nature of fire is to rise, which is why both types of fire can cause a rebellious state leading to disease.

When Yangming is in the source, if the guest energy prevails, the clear energy moves downward, leading to a hard and full lower abdomen with frequent diarrhea. If the host energy prevails, there is a sensation of heaviness in the waist and abdominal pain, and the lower abdomen feels cold. If this leads to watery diarrhea, there is a cold sensation in the intestines that ascends to the chest, and in severe cases, it results in difficulty breathing and an inability to stand for long periods.

Notes: The movement of clear energy downward signifies the impact of the crisp and cool Qi in the lower region. Hard and full lower abdomen with frequent diarrhea indicates an illness related to the cold water of the Sun. Host energy prevailing results in a heavy waist and abdominal pain, and the cold sensation in the lower abdomen arises from the cold water energy of the Sun manifesting downward.[374p]

下为鹜溏者，水下泄也。寒厥于肠，上冲胸中，甚则喘者，寒气逆乘阳明之大肠，而上及于胸中之肺脏也。《灵枢经》曰：气上冲胸，喘不能久立，邪在大肠，大肠与肺胃相合，而并主金气。】　　太阳在泉，寒复内余，则腰尻痛，屈伸不利，股胫足膝中痛。　　 【注　寒复内余者，太阳寒水之客气，入于内而复内有余也。腰尻股胫足痛者，太阳之经证也。屈伸不利者，太阳之主筋也。】　　帝曰：善。治之奈何？岐伯曰；高者抑之，下者举之，有余折之，不足补之。佐以所利，和以所宜。必安其主客，适其寒温。同者逆之，异者从之。　　【注　高者抑之，主气之逆于上也。下者举之，客气之乘于下也。有余者，胜气也。不足者，所不胜之气而为病也。佐以所利者，利其所欲也。[375p]

The lower part is where the water leaks. Cold stagnation in the intestines can surge upwards into the chest, leading to severe cases of shortness of breath. The cold energy reverses and invades the Yangming large intestine, rising up to the lungs in the chest. The "Lingshu" states: when the energy surges upward to the chest, it causes breathlessness that cannot be sustained, indicating that the evil is in the large intestine, which is connected to the lungs and stomach, and governs the metal energy.

When the solar energy is at the spring and the cold lingers internally, it results in pain in the lower back and buttocks, making bending and stretching difficult, with pain in the thighs, shins, feet, and knees.

The Emperor asked: How should it be treated? Qibo replied: For what is high, suppress it; for what is low, raise it; for excess, reduce it; and for deficiency, supplement it. Support it with what is beneficial and harmonize it with what is appropriate. Ensure the balance between the host and the guest, adapting to hot and cold. Counteract the similar and follow the different.

To suppress the high refers to reversing the energy that is in excess above. Raising the low refers to the invading energy below. Excess indicates stronger energy. Deficiency refers to the energy that is insufficient, leading to illness. Supporting what is beneficial means enhancing what is desired.[375p]

如肝欲散，急食辛以散之，是以厥阴之胜，佐以苦辛；心欲软，急食咸以软之，是以少阴之胜，佐以苦咸；脾欲缓，急食甘以缓之，是以太阴之胜，佐以辛甘；肺欲收，急食酸以收之，是以燥淫所胜，佐以辛酸；肾欲坚，急食苦以坚之，是以寒淫所胜，佐以甘苦。和以所宜者，和其五味之所宜也。如厥阴色青，宜食甘；少阴少阳色赤，宜食酸；太阴色黄，宜食咸；阳明色白，宜食苦；太阳色黑，宜食辛。安其主客者，使各守其本位也。适其寒温者，治寒以热，治热以寒，治温以凉，治凉以温也。同者逆之，谓气之相得者宜逆治之。如主客之同司火热，则当治以咸寒；如同司寒水，则当治以辛热。温凉亦然。此逆治之法也。异者从之，谓不相得者当从治之。[376p]

If the liver desires to spread, urgently consume pungent foods to disperse it; thus, the victory of Jueyin is assisted by bitter and pungent. If the heart desires to soften, urgently consume salty foods to soften it; hence, the victory of Shaoyin is assisted by bitter and salty. If the spleen desires to relax, urgently consume sweet foods to relax it; thus, the victory of Taiyin is assisted by sweet and pungent. If the lungs desire to contract, urgently consume sour foods to contract them; therefore, the victory of dryness is assisted by pungent and sour. If the kidneys desire to strengthen, urgently consume bitter foods to strengthen them; thus, the victory of cold is assisted by sweet and bitter.

Understanding the suitable harmonization is to align with the appropriate five tastes. For example, Jueyin is associated with the color green and is best complemented by sweet foods; Shaoyin and Shaoyang are associated with red and are best complemented by sour foods; Taiyin is associated with yellow and is best complemented by salty foods; Yangming is associated with white and is best complemented by bitter foods; and Taiyang is associated with black and is best complemented by pungent foods.

Stabilizing the roles of host and guest allows each to maintain its proper position. Adjusting for cold and warmth means treating cold with heat, treating heat with cold, treating warmth with coolness, and treating coolness with warmth. When conditions are similar, they should be treated in an opposing manner, meaning that energies that are compatible should be treated contrary to their nature. For instance, when both host and guest share a fiery heat, they should be treated with salty and cold; likewise, when sharing cold water, they should be treated with pungent and hot. The same applies to warm and cool. This is the method of opposing treatment. When conditions differ, they should be treated accordingly, meaning that those incompatible should be treated in alignment with their condition.[376p]

如寒水司天，如临于二火主气之上，客胜当从二火之热以治寒，主胜当从司天之寒以治热。余气皆然。此平治异者之法也。】　　帝曰：治寒以热，治热以寒。气相得者逆之，不相得者从之。余已知之矣。其于正味何如？　　 【注　此承上而言四时主客之气，各有本位之正味也。上篇论主客之胜，已论治于前，故曰，余已知之。然本气自有盛衰，其于补泻之正味为何如？】　　岐伯曰：木位之主，其泻以酸，其补以辛。　　 【注　木位之主，厥阴所主之位也。此乃四时不易之定位，故曰位。如未至所主之时，而阳春之气先至，此气之盛也，宜泻之以酸。如至而未至，此气之衰也，宜补之以辛。盖木性升，酸则反其性而收之，故为泻。辛则助其发生之气，故为补。】　　火位之主，其泻以甘，其补以咸。[377p]

Like the cold water managing the heavens, like being positioned above the two fiery spirits, the guest must overcome the cold with the heat of the two fires, and the host must overcome the heat with the coldness that manages the heavens. The same applies to all other qi. This is the principle of balancing opposites.

The Emperor said: To treat cold with heat and heat with cold. When energies are compatible, one should counteract them; when they are not compatible, one should follow their lead. I already understand this. But what about the proper flavors?

Qibo replied: The host of the wood position drains with sourness and supplements with spiciness.

This refers to the wood position governed by the jueyin. This is an unchanging position of the four seasons. If the season has not yet reached its peak, but the energy of early spring arrives first, this abundant energy should be drained with sourness. If it has arrived but is not yet at its peak, this waning energy should be supplemented with spiciness. The nature of wood is to rise; sourness counteracts its nature and constrains it, hence it is draining. Spiciness supports and promotes its rising energy, thus it is supplementary.

The host of the fire position drains with sweetness and supplements with saltiness.[377p]

　　 【注　二之气乃君火所主之位，三之气乃相火所主之位。如未至三月而暄热之气先至，未至五月而炎暑之气先至，此来气有余也，宜泻之以甘，盖从子而泄其母气也。如至而不至，此气之不及也，宜补之以咸，盖以水济火也。】　　土位之主，其泻以苦，其补以甘。
　　 【注　土主于四之气，如主气之时，埃蒸注雨，气之盛也，宜苦以泻之，泻其敦阜之气。如化气不令，风寒并兴，主气之不足也，宜补之以甘，盖气不足者，补之以味也。】　　金位之主，其泻以辛，其补以酸。[378p]

The "two energies" refer to the fire governed by the ruler, while the "three energies" pertain to the fire governed by the minister. If warm and hot energies arrive before the third month or before the fifth month, it indicates an excess of incoming energy and should be alleviated with sweetness, as it drains the maternal energy from the child. If energy arrives and yet does not fully manifest, this suggests a deficiency, thus it should be replenished with salinity, as water supports fire.

The earthly authority should be alleviated with bitterness and replenished with sweetness.

The earth governs the four energies; during the time of the governing energy, dust rises and rain falls, indicating an abundance of energy, which should be alleviated with bitterness to drain the stagnation. If the transformative energy is not regulated, wind and cold arise simultaneously, indicating a deficiency of the governing energy. In such cases, it should be supplemented with sweetness, as those lacking energy are nourished by flavor.

The metal authority should be alleviated with pungency and replenished with sourness.[378p]

　　 【注　五之气也，如未及时而清肃之气早至，此气之盛也。其泻宜辛，以辛散之也。如至秋深而暑热尚在，气之不及也。其补宜酸。以酸收之也。】　　水位之主，其泻以咸，其补以苦。
　　 【注　终之气也，如未及时而天气严寒，冰雪霜雹，气之盛也。宜泻之以咸，盖咸能泄下，从其类也。如已至而天气尚温，此气之不及也。宜补之以苦，盖苦味阴寒而炎上作苦，助太阳标本之味也。所谓调之正味，以平为期，勿使四时不平之气而为民病也。】　　厥阴之客，以辛补之，以酸泻之，以甘缓之。　　 【注　此加临之六气，有太过不及之正味也。六气运行，无有定位，如宾客外至，故曰客，常以正月朔日平旦视之。如气来不及，宜补以辛，气来有余，宜泻以酸，以甘缓之。脏气法时论曰：肝苦急，急食甘以缓之。盖主气有余，则气行于外，客气太过，则气乘于内，故当兼用五脏所欲之味以调之。】　　少阴之客，以咸补之，以甘泻之，以咸收之。[379p]

The five phases of qi: when a refreshing air arrives late, this is an indication of the intensity of the qi. For relief, it is appropriate to use pungent flavors, as they disperse it. If the heat persists well into autumn, this indicates an insufficiency of qi. In this case, sour flavors should be used for nourishment, as they help to contain it.

The master of water corresponds to salty flavors for relief and bitter flavors for nourishment.

The terminal phase of qi: when the weather is bitterly cold with ice, snow, and hail, this signifies a heightened state of qi. Salty flavors should be used for relief because they can help to drain it, aligning with its nature. If the weather remains warm despite this phase, it indicates an insufficiency of qi. Therefore, it is beneficial to nourish with bitter flavors since bitterness is cold and helps elevate the dampness associated with heat, supporting the foundational essence of yang. This is referred to as balancing with the proper flavors to achieve harmony, preventing seasonal imbalances from becoming ailments for the populace.

In the case of the guest of jueyin, one should nourish with pungent flavors, relieve with sour flavors, and moderate with sweet flavors.

This also applies to the six phases influenced by external factors, where there are appropriate flavors for both excess and deficiency. The six phases operate without fixed locations, resembling guests arriving from outside, hence the term "guest." It is customary to observe this during the early dawn of the first day of the lunar month. If qi arrives insufficiently, pungent flavors should be used for nourishment; if qi is overly abundant, sour flavors should be used for relief, moderated by sweet flavors. According to the doctrine concerning the internal organs: when the liver is imbalanced and bitter, consuming sweet flavors can help alleviate it. Hence, when qi is abundant, it flows outward; if excess guest qi exists, it remains within, necessitating the combination of flavors desired by the five internal organs to bring balance.

For the guest of shaoyin, one should nourish with salty flavors, relieve with sweet flavors, and contain with salty flavors.[379p]

　　 【注　咸当作酸。脏气法时论曰：心苦缓，急食酸以收之。按论主气，先言泻而后言补，论客气，先曰补而后曰泻。盖补泻之道，有宜补而不宜泻者，有宜泻而不宜补者，有宜先补而后泻者，有宜先泻而后补者，有宜补泻之兼用者。】　　大阴之客，以甘补之，以苦泻之，以甘缓之。　　 【注　脏气法时论曰：脾欲缓，急食甘以缓之。】　　少阳之客，以咸补之，以甘泻之，以咸软之。　　 【注　脏气法时论曰：心欲软，急食咸以软之。盖少阳乃心之包络也。】　　阳明之客，以酸补之，以辛泻之，以苦泄之。　　 【注　脏气法时论曰：肺苦气上逆，急食辛以泻之。】　　太阳之客，以苦补之，以咸泻之，以苦坚之，以辛润之，开发腠理，致津液通气也。[380p]

The theory of organ Qi states: When the heart is weak, quickly consume sour foods to remedy it. In discussing the principle of Qi, draining is mentioned first before supplementing, while in discussing the guest Qi, supplementing is mentioned first before draining. There is a path for supplementing and draining: some cases require supplementation without draining, others require draining without supplementation, some should be supplemented first then drained, some should be drained first then supplemented, and others require a combination of both.

For the guest of great yin, use sweet to supplement, bitter to drain, and sweet to relax. The theory of organ Qi states: When the spleen desires relaxation, quickly consume sweet foods to achieve this.

For the guest of lesser yang, use salty to supplement, sweet to drain, and salty to soften. The theory of organ Qi states: When the heart desires to soften, quickly consume salty foods to achieve this. Lesser yang is the envelope of the heart.

For the guest of yangming, use sour to supplement, pungent to drain, and bitter to discharge. The theory of organ Qi states: When the lung is suffering from upward counterflow of Qi, quickly consume pungent foods to drain it.

For the guest of taiyang, use bitter to supplement, salty to drain, bitter to strengthen, and pungent to moisten, thereby opening the pores and promoting the circulation of fluids and Qi.[380p]

　　【注　脏气法时论曰：肾欲坚，急食苦以坚之。肾苦燥，急食辛以润之。开腠理，致津液通气也。腠者，三焦通会元真之处。理者，皮肤脏腑之文理也。夫水谷入口，津液各走其道，故三焦出气，以温肌肉充皮肤为其津。盖气充肌腠，津随气行，辛味入胃，能开腠理，致津液而通气，故主润。】　　帝曰：善。愿闻阴阳之三也何谓？岐伯曰：气有多少异用也。　　 【注　此言阴阳之有太少，则气有盛衰，而治有轻重矣。阴阳之中，有太阳少阳，有太阴少阴，则气有多少异用也。】　　帝曰：阳明何谓也？岐伯曰：两阳合明也。　　 【注　阴阳系日月论曰：寅者正月之生阳，主左足之少阳。未者六月，主右足之少阳。卯者二月，主左足之太阳。午者五月，主右足之太阳。[381p]

Note: The method of dealing with internal sickness states: The kidney desires firmness, urgently eat bitter foods to strengthen it. The kidney is dry and lacking, urgently eat pungent foods to moisten it. Open the pores to allow fluids to circulate. The pores are where the three burners connect with the true essence. The channels refer to the patterns of skin and internal organs. When food and water enter, fluids follow their respective paths, thus the three burners emit qi to warm the muscles and nourish the skin, forming its fluids. When qi fills the muscles and pores, fluids follow the movement of qi. The pungent flavor enters the stomach, can open the pores, cause fluids to flow, and circulate qi, hence it is the primary moistening agent.

The emperor said: Good. I wish to hear what the three aspects of yin and yang are. Qi Bo replied: Qi has varying amounts and different uses.

Note: This indicates that with the extremes of yin and yang, qi has ups and downs, affecting treatments in terms of lightness and heaviness. Within yin and yang, there are greater yang and lesser yang, as well as greater yin and lesser yin, thus qi has varying amounts and different uses.

The emperor asked: What is meant by yangming? Qi Bo replied: The two yangs combine to become bright.

Note: The discussion about yin and yang states that the tiger signifies the birth of yang in the first month, governing the lesser yang of the left foot. The rabbit signifies the second month, governing the greater yang of the left foot. The horse signifies the fifth month, governing the greater yang of the right foot. The goat signifies the sixth month, governing the lesser yang of the right foot.[381p]

辰者三月，主左足之阳明。巳者四月，主右足之阳明。此两阳合于前，故曰阳明多气而少血。】　　帝曰：厥阴何也？岐伯曰：两阴交尽也。　　 【注论曰：申者，七月之生阴也，主右足之少阴。丑者十二月，主左足之少阴。酉者八月，主右足之太阴。子者十一月，主左足之太阴。戌者九月，主右足之厥阴。亥者十月，主左足之厥阴。此两阴交尽，故曰厥阴。夫厥阴主于阴尽而一阳始蒙，气之微者也，故为阴中之少阳而少气。】　　帝曰：气有多少，病有盛衰，治有缓急，方有大小。愿闻其约奈何？岐伯曰：气有高下，病有远近，证有中外，治有轻重，适其至所为故也。　　 【注　气有高下者，有天地人之九候也。远近者，浅深上下也。中外者，表里也。轻重者，大小其服也。[382p]

In the third month, it is the sign of the Yangming of the left foot. In the fourth month, it is the sign of the Yangming of the right foot. These two Yang enhance each other in the front, thus it is said that Yangming is abundant in Qi but lacks blood. The Emperor asked, "What is Jueyin?" Qi Bo replied, "It is the intersection of the two Yin."

Notes: In the seventh month, the Yin is born, representing the Shaoyin of the right foot. In the twelfth month, it represents the Shaoyin of the left foot. In the eighth month, it represents the Taiyin of the right foot. In the eleventh month, it represents the Taiyin of the left foot. In the ninth month, it represents the Jueyin of the right foot. In the tenth month, it represents the Jueyin of the left foot. Since these two Yin intersect completely, it is called Jueyin. Jueyin governs when Yin is exhausted and a single Yang begins to emerge, being the subtle aspect of Qi, hence it is considered as the Shaoyang among Yin and having lesser Qi.

The Emperor asked, "Qi has abundance and scarcity, diseases have severity and mildness, treatments have urgency and delay, and prescriptions have strengths and weaknesses. I wish to hear how they are measured." Qi Bo replied, "Qi has heights and depths, diseases have distances, symptoms have internal and external aspects, and treatments have lightness and heaviness, all depending on the appropriate action taken."

Notes: The heights and depths of Qi refer to the nine phases of heaven, earth, and humanity. Distances refer to the shallow, deep, up, and down. Internal and external refer to the surface and the interior. Lightness and heaviness refer to the size of the treatment given.[382p]

盖适其至病之所在为故也。】　　大要曰：君一臣二，奇之制也。君二臣四，偶之制也。君二臣三，奇之制也。君二臣六，偶之制也。　　 【注　大要，数之大要也。夫数始于一而成于三，圆之象也。以二偶而成六，方之象也。地数二，木数三，甲己合而土气化也。君二臣六，乾坤位而八卦成。少则二之，阴数之始也。多则九之，阳数之终也。】　　故曰：近者奇之，远者偶之。汗者不以奇，下者不以偶。补上治上制以缓，补下治下制以急。急则气味厚，缓则气味薄。适其至所，此之谓也。　　【注　奇偶者，天地之数也。近谓病之在上而近，故用奇方以治之，天气之在上也。远谓病之在下而远，故用偶方以治之，地气之在下也。[383p]

The root cause lies in addressing the location of the illness. The main principle states: one ruler and two subjects constitute an odd system; two rulers and four subjects form an even system; two rulers and three subjects create an odd system; two rulers and six subjects define an even system.

In notes, the main principle refers to the essence of numbers. Numbers begin with one and achieve completeness with three, representing the circle. By pairing two, they form six, symbolizing the square. Earth is represented by the number two, and wood by three; when甲 (jia) and己 (ji) combine, soil is transformed. Two rulers and six subjects align with the positions of heaven and earth, forming the eight trigrams. When it is less than two, it begins with the yin number; when it is more than nine, it concludes with the yang number.

Thus, it is said: treat those close with odd methods, and those far with even methods. Addressing sweating does not use odd methods, and treating the lower does not employ even methods. To treat those above with a calming approach, and those below with urgency, is the way to proceed. Urgency leads to denser energy, while calmness results in lighter energy. Properly addressing the specific location of the ailment is the key here.

Notes: Odd and even refer to the numbers of heaven and earth. "Close" means the illness is at the top and near, hence odd methods are used to treat it, as weather exists above. "Far" indicates the illness is below and distant, so even methods are employed, reflecting the earth's energy below.[383p]

汗乃阴液，故用偶而不以奇，盖直从下而使之上，犹地气升而后能为云为雨也。下者用奇而不以偶，盖从上而使之下，从天气之下降也。补者，补正气之不足。治者，治邪气之有余。在上者宜缓方，在下者宜急方，急则用气味之厚者，缓则用气味之薄者，盖厚则沉重而易下，薄则轻清而上浮，奇偶缓急，各适其上下远近，至其病之所在而已矣。】　　病所远而中道气味之者，食而过之，无越其制度也。是故平气之道，近而奇偶，制小其服也。远而奇偶，制大其服也。大则数少，小则数多。多则九之，少则二之。　　【注　此复明气味之由中而上下也。病所远者，谓病之在上在下，而远于中胃者也。中道气味之者，谓气味之从中道而行于上下也，故当以药食并用而制度之。[384p]

Sweat is the yin fluid, thus it is used in pairs rather than in singles; this is because it rises directly from below to allow it to ascend, similar to how the earth's qi rises before forming clouds and rain. When there is a need to descend, the single is used rather than the pair, as this comes from above to descend in response to the downward movement of heavenly qi.

The補 (bu) refers to replenishing the deficiency of vital qi, while 治 (zhi) refers to addressing the excess of pathogenic qi. Those above should be treated with slow methods, while those below require urgent approaches. For urgent cases, use heavier flavors, while for slower cases, use lighter flavors, as the heavy flavors are dense and easily descend, while lighter flavors are light and clear, allowing them to rise. The pair and single, slow and urgent, should be adapted to their respective positions above or below, down to the specific location of the illness.

For illnesses that are distant, measured flavors should be consumed in moderation without exceeding their prescribed limits. Therefore, the method of balancing qi is near and with pairs and singles, which requires smaller quantities of food. For distant cases, it is near and uses larger quantities of food. Larger quantities imply fewer items, while smaller quantities imply more items. More items total nine, while fewer items total two.

(Note: This explains the movement of flavors from the center to the top and bottom. When the illness is distant, it refers to an illness located above or below but distant from the central stomach. The measured flavors from the center signify that flavors move accordingly up and down, thus they should be used in conjunction with both medicine and food in prescribed amounts.)[384p]

如病之在上而远于中者，当先食而后药，病在下而远于中者。当先药而后食，以食之先后，而使药味之过于上下也。是故上下之病近于中道，而用奇方偶方者，制小其服；病远于中而用奇方偶方者，宜制大其服。大服小服者，谓分两之轻重也。大则宜于数少而分两多，盖气味专而能远也。小则宜于数多而分两少，盖气味分则力薄而不能远达矣。此平上中下三气之道也。】　　奇之不去则偶之，是谓重方。偶之不去则反佐以取之。所谓寒热温凉，反从其病也。　　 【注　重方，谓奇偶之并用也。反佐以取之，谓春病用温，夏病用热，秋病用凉，冬病用寒。顺四时寒热温凉之气，而反从治其病也。】　　帝曰：善。病生于本，余知之矣。生于标者，治之奈何？岐伯曰：病反其本，得标之病。[385p]

If the illness is located above and distant from the center, one should first consume food and then take medicine. If the illness is below and distant from the center, one should first take medicine and then eat. This is based on the principle of the sequence of food and medicine, ensuring that the flavors of the medicine do not interfere with food in terms of their positioning. Therefore, when the illnesses are located above or below and are close to the central pathway, using unique and general methods requires smaller dosages. When the illness is far from the center and involves unique and general treatments, it is appropriate to use larger dosages. The terms "large" and "small" in dosages refer to their relative lightness and heaviness. Larger doses should be given in fewer numbers with more extensive applications, as they are potent and effective over greater distances. Smaller doses should be given in larger numbers with more limited applications, as their potency is diluted and cannot reach far. This reflects the pathway of the three energies: upper, middle, and lower.

When the unique does not dissipate, then it is accompanied by the general, which is called a heavier prescription. When the general does not dissipate, it is countered and supplemented to be effective. The concepts of cold, heat, warmth, and coolness should align with the nature of the illness viewed in the context of the seasons. The emperor said: "Good. I understand that an illness arises from its origin.” he continued, "But what about illnesses that arise from superficial causes?" Qi Bo replied: "Illness reflects its origin and results in symptoms that are superficial."[385p]

治反其本，得标之方。　　【注　此论三阴三阳之有本标也。病生于本者，生于风寒热湿燥火也。生于标者，生于三阴三阳之气也。如太阳为诸阳之首而本于寒水，少阴为阴中之太阴而本于君火，阳明乃阳盛之气而本于清肃，厥阴主阴极而本于风木之阳，此阴阳之中，又有标本之不同也。病反其本者，如病寒而反得太阳之热化，病热而反见少阴之阴寒，病在阳而反见清肃之虚寒，病在阴而反得中见之火热，所谓病反其本，得标之病也。治反其本者，如病本寒而化热，则反用凉药以治热；如病本热而化寒，则反用热药以治寒；如病在阳明而化虚冷，则当温补其中气；如病在厥阴而见火热，又当逆治其少阳。所谓治反其本，得标之方。少阳少阴，标本相同，皆从阳热阴湿而治。】　　帝曰：善。六气之胜，何以候之？[386p]

To treat the root, one must address the symptoms.

(Note: This discussion pertains to the relationship between the three yin and three yang, distinguishing between the root and the symptoms. Illness arising from the root comes from wind, cold, heat, dampness, dryness, or fire. Illness arising from the symptoms comes from the qi of the three yin and three yang. For example, the sun is the chief of all yang, rooted in cold water; the lesser yin is the greatest of the yin in the midst of yin and is rooted in the fire of the lord; yangming represents the flourishing qi of yang, rooted in clarity and coolness; and jueyin governs extreme yin, which is rooted in the yang of wind and wood. Within the categories of yin and yang, there exists a distinction between root and symptom. When illness reflects the root, for instance, a cold condition might ironically lead to the warmth of the sun; a hot condition might reflect the coolness of the lesser yin; a yang condition could reveal a deficiency in clarity and coolness; and a yin condition could unexpectedly manifest in fire and heat. This notion of illness reflecting the root deals with symptoms arising from that illness. Treating in opposition to the root means that if the actual condition is cold yet manifests warmth, one should counteract heat with cooling medicines; conversely, if the root condition is hot yet shows coldness, one should apply warming medicines to address cold; if the condition lies in yangming and presents with virtual cold, then one should invigorate the inner qi; if the condition is in jueyin and exhibits fire and heat, treatment must reverse to address the lesser yang. Therefore, treatment that opposes the root follows the symptom. Both lesser yang and lesser yin are similar in terms of root and symptom, both deriving treatment from yang heat and yin dampness.)

The Emperor said: Good. How do we assess the triumph of the six qi?[386p]

　　 【注　此论四时五行之气，内合五脏，外应六脉也。】　　岐伯曰：乘其至也。清气大来，燥之胜也，风木受邪，肝病生焉。热气大来，火之胜也，金燥受邪，肺病生焉。寒气大来，水之胜也，火热受邪，心病生焉。湿气大来，土之胜也，寒水受邪，肾病生焉。风气大来，木之胜也，土湿受邪，脾病生焉。所谓感邪而生病也。　　【注　风寒热湿燥，在天四时之五气；木火土金水，在地四时之五行。五气之胜五行，五行而病五脏，是五脏之外合五行，而五行之上呈五气也。】　　乘年之虚，则邪甚也。失时之和，亦邪甚也。[387p]

[Note: This discussion concerns the energies of the four seasons and five elements, which correspond to the five organs internally and the six meridians externally.] Qibo said: When the pure qi arrives abundantly, dryness prevails, and when the wind and wood are affected by evil influences, diseases of the liver arise. When hot qi arrives abundantly, fire prevails, and when metal and dryness are affected by evil influences, diseases of the lung arise. When cold qi arrives abundantly, water prevails, and when fire and heat are affected by evil influences, diseases of the heart arise. When damp qi arrives abundantly, earth prevails, and when cold water is affected by evil influences, diseases of the kidney arise. When wind qi arrives abundantly, wood prevails, and when earth and dampness are affected by evil influences, diseases of the spleen arise. This is what is meant by being affected by evil influences and resulting in illness. [Note: Wind, cold, heat, dampness, and dryness are the five energies of the four seasons in the heavens; wood, fire, earth, metal, and water are the five elements in the four seasons of the earth. The predominance of five energies affects the five elements, and through the five elements leads to diseases of the five organs, reflecting the external connection of the five organs with the five elements, and the manifestation of the five energies above the five elements.] When the yearly cycle is void, the evil influences are severe. When the harmony of the seasons is lost, the evil influences are also severe.[387p]

遇月之空，亦邪甚也。重感于邪，则病危矣。有胜之气，其必来复也。　　【注　乘年之虚者，主岁之气不及也。如木运不及，则清气胜之；火运不及，则寒气胜之；土运不及，则风气胜之；金运不及，则热气胜之；水运不及，则湿气胜之。此岁运不及，而四时之胜气，又乘而悔之。失时之和者，四时之气衰也。如春气不足，则秋气胜之；夏气不足，则冬气胜之；长夏之气不足，则春气胜之，秋气不足，则夏气胜之；冬气不足，则长夏之气胜之。遇月之空者，月廓空之时也。重感于邪者，乘年之虚，失时之和，遇月之空，是谓三虚，而感于邪则病危矣。[388p]

In the presence of the empty moon, there is also great evil. When heavily affected by malevolent influences, illness becomes critical. If there is a victorious energy, it is certain to return.

The emptiness of the year indicates that the annual energies are insufficient. For example, if the wood element is inadequate, the pure energy prevails; if the fire element is insufficient, the cold energy prevails; if the earth element is lacking, the wind energy prevails; if the metal element is insufficient, the heat energy prevails; if the water element is lacking, the moist energy prevails. When the annual energies are lacking, and the prevailing energies of the seasons are also burdened, then the harmony of the right timing is lost, resulting in a decline of seasonal energies. If the energy of spring is insufficient, then the autumn energy prevails; if summer energy is lacking, winter energy prevails; if the extended summer lacks energy, then spring energies prevail, and if autumn energy is insufficient, summer energy prevails; if winter energy is lacking, the extended summer energy prevails.

The empty moon signifies a time of emptiness. Being heavily influenced by malevolent forces due to the emptiness of the year, the loss of seasonal harmony, and the occurrence of the empty moon, is called the three emptinesses. Thus, being influenced by evil brings about critical illness.[388p]

有胜之气，其必来复者，春有惨凄残贼之胜，则夏有炎暑燔铄之复；夏有惨凄凝冽之胜，则四维有埃昏大雨之复；四维发振拉飘腾之变，则秋有肃杀霖霪之复，秋有炎烁燔燎之变，则冬有冰雹霜雪之复；冬有埃昏骤注之变，则春有飘荡振拉之复。此四时之胜而必有复也。】　　帝曰：其脉至何如？岐伯曰：厥阴之至，其脉弦；少阴之至，其脉钩；太阴之至，其脉沉；少阳之至，大而浮，阳明之至，短而濇；太阳之至，大而长。　　 【注　此论六气之应六脉也。厥阴主木，故其脉弦。少阴主火，故其脉钩。太阴主土，故其脉沉。少阳主火，故大而浮。阳明主金，故短而濇。太阳主水而为诸阳主气，故大而长。】　　至而和则平，至而甚则病。至而反者病，至而不至者病，未至而至者病。阴阳易者危。　　【注　此言弦钩长短之脉，当应六气而至也。[389p]

When there is a prevailing force, it will surely return. In spring, when there is the victory of sorrowful and lingering devastation, summer will have the return of scorching heat. Similarly, when summer experiences the victory of sorrowful and chilling cold, the four directions will respond with dark clouds and heavy rain. When the four directions experience the upheaval and swirling changes, autumn will then have the return of chill and relentless rain; autumn’s change from burning heat will lead to winter's return of hail, frost, and snow. When winter experiences dark and sudden downpours, spring will then have the return of drift and upheaval. These are the victories of the four seasons, and there will always be a corresponding return.

The Emperor asked: What is the pulse like when these conditions manifest? Qi Bo replied: The pulse of Jueyin is string-like; the pulse of Shaoyin is hook-like; the pulse of Taiyin is deep; the pulse of Shaoyang is large and floating; the pulse of Yangming is short and wiry; the pulse of Taiyang is large and long.

[Note: This discusses how the six climatic influences correspond to the six pulses. Jueyin governs wood, thus its pulse is string-like. Shaoyin governs fire, hence its pulse is hook-like. Taiyin governs earth, resulting in a deep pulse. Shaoyang also governs fire, producing a large and floating pulse. Yangming governs metal, leading to a short and wiry pulse. Taiyang governs water and represents the master energy of yang, hence it is large and long.]

When these conditions arrive harmoniously, they bring balance; when they become excessive, they lead to illness. If they arrive and then reverse, that indicates illness; if they arrive but do not fully manifest, that, too, indicates illness; if they have not yet arrived but are anticipated to arrive, that is also a sign of illness. The interchange of yin and yang is perilous.

[Note: This indicates how the string-like, hook-like, and long or short pulses should correspond with the six climatic influences.][389p]

如脉至而和，则为平人；脉至而甚，则为病脉。所至之脉与时相反者病，及时而脉不至者病，未及时而脉先至者病。如三阴主时而得阳脉，三阳主时而得阴脉者危。】　　帝曰：六气标本，所从不同奈何？岐伯曰：气有从本者，有从标本者，有不从标本者也。帝曰：愿卒闻之。岐伯曰：少阳太阴从本；少阴太阳从本从标；阳明厥阴不从标本，从乎中也。故从本者，化生于本；从标本者，有标本之化；从中者，以中气为化也。　　【注　风寒暑湿燥火六气为本，三阴三阳为标。阴湿之士而标见太阴之阴，初阳之火而标见少阳之阳，是标之阴阳，从本化生，故太阴少阳从本。少阴之本热而标见少阴之阴，太阳之本寒而标见太阳之阳，阴中有阳，阳中有阴，然有水火寒热之化，故少阴太阳从本从标。阳明之上，燥气治之，中见太阴，厥阴之上，风气治之，中见少阳。[390p]

If the pulse arrives harmoniously, it is that of a healthy person; if it is excessive, it indicates a pathological pulse. The pulse that arrives contrary to the time indicates illness, while the pulse that does not arrive in due time is also a sign of illness. If the pulse arrives prematurely before the time, it is also a symptom of illness. When the three Yin correspond to the time yet detect the Yang pulse, or when the three Yang correspond to the time yet detect the Yin pulse, it is a sign of danger.

The Emperor said: "The six atmospheric influences (qi) differ in their sources and manifestations; how then do they relate?" Qi Bo replied: "There are those that arise from the fundamental source, those that arise from manifest signs and sources, and those that do not arise from manifest sources." The Emperor requested to hear more. Qi Bo explained: "The Shao Yang and Tai Yin arise from the fundamental source; the Shao Yin and Tai Yang arise both from the fundamental source and from signs; the Yang Ming and Jue Yin do not arise from the manifestations but from the center. Therefore, those that arise from the fundamental source are generated from the root; those from signs have transformations associated with those signs; and those that come from the center are transformed by the central qi."

(Note: The six atmospheric influences are wind, cold, heat, dampness, dryness, and fire as the fundamental source, whereas the three Yin and three Yang are considered manifestations. Those with Yin dampness but observe the Tai Yin's Yin, and those with the initial Yang's fire yet observe the Shao Yang's Yang, represent the transformation from the fundamental source, thus Tai Yin and Shao Yang stem from the root. The Shao Yin's fundamental heat shows as the Shao Yin's Yin, the Tai Yang's fundamental cold shows as the Tai Yang's Yang; within Yin is Yang, and within Yang is Yin, thus existing are the transformations of water, fire, cold, and heat, hence the Shao Yin and Tai Yang stem from the fundamental source as well as from signs. Above the Yang Ming, the drying influences govern, revealing the Tai Yin; above the Jue Yin, the windy influences govern, revealing the Shao Yang.)[390p]

盖阳明司四时之秋令，而太阴主四气之清秋，厥阴为两阴交尽，阴尽而一阳始生，是以阳明厥阴从中见之化也。】　　帝曰：脉从而病反者，其诊何如？岐伯曰：脉至而从，按之不鼓，诸阳皆然。帝曰：诸阴之反，其脉如何？岐伯曰：脉至而从，按之鼓甚而盛也。　　【注　此论脉病有标本也。脉从者，阳病而得阳脉，阴病而得阴脉也。如太阳阳明之病，其脉至而浮，是脉之从也。其病反阴寒者，太阳之病从本化，阳明之病从中见之阴化也，故脉虽浮而按之不鼓也。如少阴厥阴之病。其脉至而沉，是脉之从也。其病反阳热者，少阴之病从标化，厥阴之病从中见之火化也，故脉虽沉而按之鼓甚也。是脉有阴阳之化，而病有标本之从也。[391p]

The Yang Ming governs the autumn of the four seasons, while the Tai Yin presides over the clear autumn of the four qi. The Jue Yin corresponds to the intersection of two yin, where yin is exhausted and one yang begins to emerge; thus, Yang Ming and Jue Yin manifest transformations from within. The Emperor asked: If the pulse indicates a reverse condition, what is the diagnosis? Qi Bo replied: When the pulse is present, following it, and pressing does not produce a response, this is true for all yang diseases. The Emperor continued: How is the pulse for all yin reversals? Qi Bo said: When the pulse is present, following it, pressing causes a strong response and is vigorous.

(Note: This discusses pulse diagnosis, which has both superficial and underlying aspects. When the pulse follows, it indicates a yang condition with a yang pulse or a yin condition with a yin pulse. For example, in the case of Tai Yang or Yang Ming illness, if the pulse is present and floating, that is a sign of a superficial condition. If the illness reverses into yin cold, the Tai Yang condition transforms from the surface, and the Yang Ming condition reveals a transformation into yin, hence though the pulse is floating, it does not respond strongly upon pressing. In cases of Shao Yin or Jue Yin illness, if the pulse is present and sinking, that indicates a deeper condition. If the illness reverses into yang heat, the Shao Yin condition transforms from the surface, and the Jue Yin condition reveals a transformation into fire, thus although the pulse is sinking, it responds strongly upon pressing. This highlights the transformation of yin and yang in the pulse and the distinction between the superficial and underlying aspects of illness.)[391p]

按太阳病头痛发热，烦渴不解，此太阳之病本也。如手足挛急，或汗漏脉沉，此太阳之病标也。如少阴病脉沉者急温之，宜四逆汤，此少阴之病标也。如少阴病得之二三日，口燥咽干者，急下之，宜大承气汤，此少阴之病本也。如阳明病发热而渴，大便燥结，此阳明之病阳也。如胃中虚冷，水谷不别，食谷欲呕，脉迟恶寒，此阳明感中见阴湿之化也。如厥阴病脉微，手足厥冷，此厥阴之病阴也。如消渴气上冲心，心中疼热，此厥阴感中见少阳之火化也。如太阴标阴而本湿，故当治之以四逆辈。少阳标阳而本火，则宜散之以清凉。治伤寒六经之病，能于标本中求之，思过半矣。】　　是故百病之起，有生于本者，有生于标者，有生于中气者。有取本而得者，有取标而得者，有取中气而得者，有取标本而得者。[392p]

In cases of illness caused by the Taiyang (greater yang), symptoms include headache, fever, and unquenchable thirst; these are the root manifestations of Taiyang disease. If there are symptoms such as cramping in the hands and feet or deep pulse with sweating, these represent the superficial manifestations of Taiyang disease. For Shaoyin (lesser yin) illness, if the pulse is deep, one should warm it urgently with Sijunzi Decoction; this represents the superficial manifestation of Shaoyin disease. If, after two to three days of Shaoyin disease, one experiences dry mouth and throat, urgent purgation is needed, and Dachengqi Decoction should be used; this is the root manifestation of Shaoyin disease. In cases of Yangming (yang brightness) disease, there are fever and thirst along with dry and constipated stools; these symptoms are the outward signs of Yangming disease. If there is a cold and empty sensation in the stomach, food does not digest, there is a desire to vomit, and the pulse is slow with aversion to cold, this indicates Yangming disease influenced by internal dampness. In cases of Jueyin (reverting yin) disease, if the pulse is weak and the hands and feet are cold, this reflects the inward manifestations of Jueyin disease. If there is diabetes with upward-rebounding qi impacting the heart, causing heat and pain in the heart, this indicates Jueyin influenced by the fire of Shaoyang. For Taiyin (greater yin), with its superficial manifestations being cold and its root being dampness, it should be treated with Sijunzi and similar remedies. Shaoyang, with its superficial manifestations being hot and its root being fire, should be dispersed with cool remedies. In treating cold damage and the diseases of the six channels, one must consider the superficial and deep aspects; in doing so, one is already halfway to understanding.

Therefore, the origins of all diseases can arise from the root, the superficial level, or from the middle qi. Some illnesses derive from the root, others from the superficial level, or from the middle qi; some are obtained from the superficial level, others from the root, or from the combination of both.[392p]

有逆取而得者，有从取而得者。逆正，顺也；若顺，逆也。故曰：知标与本，用之不殆。明知逆顺，正行无问。此之谓也。不知是者，不足以言诊，足以乱经。故大要曰：粗工嘻嘻，以为可知。言热未已，寒病复始。同气异形，迷诊乱经。此之谓也。　　【注　百病之生，总不出于六气之化，如感风寒暑湿燥火而为病者，病天之六气也。天之六气，病在吾身，而吾身中，又有六气之化。如中风，天之阳邪也，病吾身之肌表则为发热咳嚏，在筋骨则为痛痹拘挛，在肠胃则为下痢飧泄，或为燥结闭癃；或直中于内，则为霍乱呕逆，或为厥冷阴寒，此表里阴阳之气化也。如感吾身之阳热，则为病热；感吾身之阴寒，则为病寒；感吾身之水湿，则为痰喘；感吾身之燥气，则为便难。[393p]

There are those who obtain through opposition and those who obtain through compliance. Opposition is correct, compliance is also correct; if one is compliant, it is opposition. Therefore, it is said: understanding the marker and the root, using them without danger. To clearly know the oppositional and the compliant, and to act correctly without question. This is what is meant. Those who do not understand this are not qualified to speak of diagnosis, but only to confuse the principles. Hence, the key point states: crude practitioners laugh as if it were knowledge. They say that heat has not yet ceased, and ailments of cold have begun anew. Similar conditions with different forms lead to confusion in diagnosis and principles. This is what is meant.

[Note: The emergence of all diseases ultimately stems from the transformation of the six atmospheric influences, such as the effects of wind, cold, heat, dampness, dryness, and fire causing illnesses that relate to the six atmospheric influences. The six atmospheric influences from heaven manifest as diseases in our bodies, and within our bodies, there are also transformations of the six influences. For instance, wind as an external yang pathogenic factor affects the skin, resulting in fever and sneezing; it affects the tendons and bones, causing pain, numbness, and cramps; it affects the intestines and stomach, resulting in diarrhea and fluid loss, or causing dryness and retention. If it penetrates internally, it may lead to sudden illness or vomiting, or result in cold limbs and internal cold, as it deals with the transformation of the energies of yin and yang. If one is affected by the yang heat of one's own body, it results in heat illness; if affected by the yin cold, it results in cold illness; impacted by moisture results in sputum and wheezing; affected by dry air leads to constipation.][393p]

如中于腑，则暴仆而卒不知人；中于脏，舌即难言而口唾涎沫。又如伤寒，天之阴邪也，或中于阴，或中于阳。有中于阳而反病寒者，有中于阴而反病热者，是吾身之阴中有阳，阳中有阴，标本阴阳之气化也。如感吾身中之水湿，则为青龙、五苓之证；如感吾身之燥热，又宜于白虎、承气诸汤。此止受天之一邪，而吾身中有表里阴阳变化之不同也。又如夏月之病，有手足厥冷，而成姜桂参附之证者，盖夏月之阳气尽发越于外，而里气本虚，受天之风暑而反变为阴寒，皆吾身之气化，非暑月之有伤寒也。是以神巧之士，知标本之病生，则知有标本之气化，知标本之气化，则能用标本之治法矣。故知标与本，用之不殆，明知顺逆，正行无问，此之谓也。逆者以寒治热，以热治寒。[394p]

If one is struck in the viscera, one may collapse suddenly and not recognize others; if struck in the organs, one’s tongue will become difficult to speak and the mouth will drool saliva. Similarly, in the case of cold damage, it is the evil of the heavens; one may be affected by yin or by yang. There are those who are struck by yang and exhibit symptoms of cold, and those who are struck by yin and exhibit symptoms of heat. This reflects the intermingling of yin and yang within our bodies and the transformation of their energies at the fundamental level. If one is affected by the dampness within the body, it results in symptoms related to Qinglong or Wuling; if one is affected by dryness and heat, then prescriptions like Baitou and Chengqi should be applied. This merely reflects the external evil of heaven, while the inner dynamics with their varying transformations of yin and yang also come into play.

Moreover, during summer illnesses, if there are cold extremities, symptoms resembling those treated by ginger, cinnamon, ginseng, and licorice will arise, because the yang energy of summer has fully emerged outward while the inner energy is originally weak. When subjected to wind and heat from the heavens, it may transform into yin and cold, demonstrating the dynamic changes within our bodies, not a direct result of summer heat causing a cold illness. Thus, adept practitioners understand how fundamental and symptomatic diseases arise, recognizing the transformation of energies. By understanding these transformations, they can effectively apply treatment methods that address both symptoms and root causes. Hence, knowing how to distinguish between symptoms and root causes allows for effective treatment without peril, clearly discerning the nature of things, and proceeding correctly regardless of the situation. This is the principle: treat cold with heat and heat with cold.[394p]

故曰，逆正，顺也。从者以热治热，以寒治寒，故曰若顺，逆也。如阴阳寒热之中，又有病热而反寒者，如厥深热亦深之类。又有病寒而反热者，如揭去衣被，欲入水中，此孤阳外脱，急救以参附之证。粗工嘻嘻，以为可知，言热未已，寒病复始，同气异形，迷诊乱经。此之谓也。】　　夫标本之道，要而博，小而大，可以言一而知百病之害。言标与本，易而勿损。察本与标，气可令调。明知胜复，为万民式。天之道毕矣。　　 【注　此极言标本之用也。标本之道虽为要约，而其用则广博；虽为微小，而其用则宏大。可以言一而知百病之害者，惟知标本故也。[395p]

Therefore it is said, reversing is the same as following. Those who follow treat heat with heat and cold with cold, hence it is said to follow; reversing is the opposite. Within the dynamics of yin and yang, cold and heat, there are also conditions where heat manifests as cold, such as in cases of deep heat presenting as deep cold. Similarly, there are conditions where cold manifests as heat, such as when one removes clothing to enter the water, signifying the solitary yang escaping from the body, needing urgent nourishment from the yin. Amateur practitioners, in their folly, believe they understand; they claim the heat has not yet subsided, while the cold illness resumes, mistaking similar manifestations as identical, thus confusing diagnoses and disrupting the patterns. This is what is meant.

The essence of understanding the relationship between the surface and the root is that it is fundamental yet extensive, small yet significant; knowing one can lead to the understanding of a hundred ailments. Speaking of the surface and the root, they should be approached with ease and without loss. Observing the root and the surface allows for the harmonization of qi. Clear knowledge leads to victory and renewal, serving as a model for all people. This is the complete way of heaven.

[Note: This emphasizes the application of the relationship between surface and root. The principle of their relationship may be succinct, but its application is profound; though it may seem minor, its significance is vast. Knowing the relationship between surface and root allows for the understanding of the harms of a hundred ailments.][395p]

言标与本则施治平易而无伤损，察本与标则六气虽变，可使均调，明知标本胜复则足以为民式，六气在天之道毕矣。】　　帝曰：胜复之变，早晏何如？岐伯曰：夫所胜者，胜至已病，病已愠愠而复已萌也。夫所复者胜尽而起，得位而甚。胜有微甚，复有少多。胜和而和，胜虚而虚。天之常也。帝曰：胜复之作，动不当位，或后时而至，其故何也？岐伯曰：夫气之生与其化，盛衰异也。寒暑温凉，盛衰之用，其在四维。故阳之动始于温，盛于暑；阴之动始于清，盛于寒。春夏秋冬，各差其分。故大要曰：彼春之暖，为夏之暑；彼秋之忿，为冬之怒。谨按四维，斥候皆归。其终可见，其始可知。此之谓也。帝曰：差有数乎？岐伯曰：又凡三十度也。　　【注　此言日月运行，一寒一暑。四时之气，由微而盛，由盛而微。[396p]

The principles of treatment should be straightforward and cause no harm, observing both the root and branches, even if the six energies change, can still be balanced. To understand the interaction between root and branches is sufficient to set a standard for the people, for the six energies follow the way of heaven. The Emperor asked: How does the change between dominance and recovery manifest in early versus late stages? Qibo replied: The one that is dominant indicates that illness has reached a critical point, with distress already present while recovery is just beginning. The one that is recovering shows that dominance has ended and has risen, taking on a significant position. Dominance can vary in intensity, and recovery can vary in quantity. When dominance is harmonized it achieves balance, and when dominance is vacuous, it becomes void. This is the constancy of heaven. The Emperor asked: What occurs when the process of dominance and recovery is misaligned or delayed? Qibo replied: The generation and transformation of qi exhibit different patterns of flourishing and declining. The uses of heat and cold vary across the four seasons. Thus, the movement of yang begins with warmth and flourishes in summer; the movement of yin begins with clarity and flourishes in winter. Each of spring, summer, autumn, and winter has its distinct allocations. Hence, it is said: The warmth of spring prepares for the heat of summer; the anger of autumn prepares for the fury of winter. By carefully observing the four dimensions, all scouts return. The end can be seen, and the beginning can be known. This is what is meant. The Emperor asked: Are there specific differences? Qibo replied: In total, there are thirty degrees.

(Note: This text discusses the principles of treatment and the dynamics of seasonal changes and their effects on health.)[396p]

从维而正，从正而维，寒温互换，凉暑气交，胜复之气，有盛有衰，随时先后，是以有早有晏也。阳之动，始于温，盛于暑，阴之动，始于清，盛于寒，是由微而甚也。如春之沉，夏之弦，秋之数，冬之濇，是冬之余气尚交于春，春之余气尚交于夏，夏之余气尚交于秋，秋之余气尚交于冬，是由盛而微也。所谓正者，春夏秋冬之正方也。维者，春夏之交、夏秋之交、秋冬之交、冬春之交，四隅之四维也。四时之气，从维而正，复从正而维，寒温气交，凉暑更互，环转之不息也。是以胜至已病，病已愠愠而复已萌者，谓复气已发萌于胜气之时也。如春有惨凄残贼之胜，是金气之胜木也。夏有炎暑燔铄之复，是火气之复金也。[397p]

From the supportive to the righteous, and from the righteous to the supportive, cold and warmth interchange, cool and hot energies intersect. The dynamics of success and decline are both abundant and minimal, following the seasons in their order, resulting in early and late appearances. The movement of yang begins with warmth and peaks in heat; the movement of yin starts with clarity and peaks in cold. This transitions from subtlety to intensity. Just as spring is subdued, summer is harmonious, autumn is numerical, and winter is waning. The residual energies of winter still interact with spring, those of spring with summer, summer with autumn, and autumn with winter, resulting in a transition from abundance to subtlety. The so-called 'just' refers to the proper alignment of spring, summer, autumn, and winter. The 'support' refers to the transitions between spring and summer, summer and autumn, autumn and winter, winter and spring—a dimensional framework in four corners. The energies of the four seasons arise from the supportive to the righteous, and then return from the righteous to the supportive, with cold and warmth intersecting and cool and hot alternating, continuously cycling without end. Thus, when prosperity arrives, it may bring illness; when illness recedes, it may rekindle, indicating the resurgence of energy at a time of prosperity. For instance, in spring, there may be the harsh defeat of the sapling by metal energy. In summer, there may be the overpowering heat of fire overcoming metal.[397p]

火气已萌于胜病愠愠之时，是复气之早发于本位之三十度也。所复之气，俟胜尽而起，至炎夏所主之本位而甚，是胜气早而复气将来亦早也。是以胜气甚则复气多。胜气微则复气少，胜气和平而复亦和平，胜气虚衰而复亦虚衰，此天道之常也。如胜复之作，动不当位，后时而至者，此胜复之晏也。夫气之生，生于前之气交，如夏气之生于季春也。气之化，化于后之气交，如春气之流于孟夏也。胜复之气有盛衰，故有早晏之异。盖气之盛者，胜于本位以前所生之三十度，气之衰者，流于本位以后所化之三十度，故不当其位。如金气衰而胜于春夏之交，则复气亦衰，而复于夏秋之交是胜虚而虚，后时而至也。此四时之气，前后互交，故胜复之盛衰，随四时之气交，而或前或后也。故曰，盛衰之用，其在四维。[398p]

The fiery energy has already begun to stir during the time of excessive illness; this is the restoration of energy emerging early at the primary position of thirty degrees. The restorative energy waits until the excessive energy has dissipated, then it rises in the sweltering heat of summer at its primary position, hence both the excessive energy arises earlier and the restorative energy follows suit. Therefore, when the excessive energy is strong, the restorative energy is abundant; when the excessive energy is mild, the restorative energy is scarce; when the excessive energy is balanced, the restorative energy is also balanced; when the excessive energy is weak and declining, the restorative energy is likewise weak and declining. This is the constant of the way of nature. If the emergence of excessive and restorative energies is out of proper order and arrives late, it is due to the tardiness of the excessive and restorative energies. The birth of energy occurs at the interaction of the preceding energies, just as summer energy arises during late spring. The transformation of energy occurs at the interaction of the subsequent energies, like spring energy flowing into early summer. The energies of excess and restoration vary in strength and decline; thus, there are distinctions of early and late. Indeed, vigorous energy arises from the thirty degrees born prior to the primary position, while weak energy flows post the primary position's transformation of thirty degrees; hence, it does not align with its position. If the metal energy weakens and is excessive at the turn of spring and summer, then the restorative energy will also weaken, and its restoration during the turn of summer and autumn indicates a void in excess, arriving late. The energies of the four seasons interact; therefore, the fluctuations of excessive and restorative energies follow the exchanges of the seasonal energies, appearing either early or late. Thus, it is said that the application of prosperity and decline is within the four dimensions.[398p]

又曰，谨按四维，斥候皆归，其终可见，其始可知。谓胜复之早晏，皆归于四维之斥候，或早而在于始之前三十度，或晏而在于终之后三十度也。】　　帝曰：其脉应皆何如？岐伯曰：差同正法，待时而去也。　　 【注　此复以脉候而证明气化之交通，故曰是谓四塞。谓春夏秋冬之气不相交通，则天地四时之气皆闭塞矣。正者，四时之正位也。言脉同四时之正法，而前后相交。待时而去者，待终三十度而去也。如春之沉，尚属冬之气交，终正月之三十日，而春气始独司其令也。】　　脉要曰，春不况，夏不弦，冬不濇，秋不数，是谓四塞。[399p]

It is also said, attentively observing the four seasons, that all responses return; their end can be seen, and their beginning can be known. This means that the early and late victories both pertain to the responses of the four seasons, either early by thirty degrees before the beginning, or late by thirty degrees after the end. The emperor asked: How should the pulse respond? Qibo replied: It differs slightly from the proper method, waiting for the right moment to depart.

(Note: This further uses the pulse state to prove the interaction of qi transformation, therefore it is called "Four Seals." If the qi of spring, summer, autumn, and winter do not interact, then the qi of heaven and earth across the four seasons is all blocked. The "proper" refers to the correct positions of the four seasons. It indicates that the pulse aligns with the proper methods of the four seasons, intersecting before and after. Waiting for the right moment to depart means departing after thirty degrees of the end. For instance, in spring, if it remains dormant, it still belongs to the qi of winter interacting, until the thirtieth day of the last month, at which point spring qi begins to take command alone.)

The essentials of the pulse state are: spring does not allow for unfurling, summer does not sustain, winter does not stagnate, autumn does not enumerate, which is called "Four Seals."[399p]

　　 【注　春不沉则冬气不交于春，夏不弦则春气不交于夏，秋不数则夏气不交于秋，冬不濇则秋气不交于冬，是四时之气不相交通而闭塞也。】　　沉甚曰病，弦甚曰病，濇甚曰病，数甚曰病。参见曰病，复见曰病。未去而去曰病，去而不去曰病。反者死。故曰，气之相守司也，如权衡之不得相失也。夫阴阳之气，清静则生化治，动则苛疾起。此之谓也。　　【注　四时之气，盛于主位之时，而微于始生，衰于交化，故甚则病也。参见者，谓春初之沉弦并见，夏初之弦数并见也。复见者，已去而复见也。未去而去者，未及三十日而去也。去而不去者，已至三十日应去而不去也。反者，谓四时反见贼害之脉也。故曰，气之相守司也。如权衡之不得相失也。言四时之气，守于本位，同于气交，犹权衡之不得相离也。四时阴阳之气，清静则生化治。生化者，生于前而化于后也。动者，气之乱也。[400p]

If spring does not anchor, then winter's energy does not interact with spring; if summer does not resonate, then spring's energy does not interact with summer; if autumn does not count, then summer's energy does not interact with autumn; if winter does not flow, then autumn's energy does not interact with winter. This indicates that the energies of the four seasons do not connect and are obstructed.

Excessive anchoring is called illness, excessive resonance is called illness, excessive flowing is called illness, excessive counting is called illness. Seeing in pairs is called illness; seeing again is called illness. Departing without truly departing is called illness; departing yet remaining is called illness. Reversal indicates death. Thus, it is said, the energies must uphold their roles, just as scales must not lose balance.

The energies of yin and yang require clarity and tranquility for transformation and governance; movement leads to harsh diseases. This is what is meant. The energies of the four seasons are strongest when they are at their primary positions, weak at the beginning of emergence, and faded during conversion; thus, excessive amounts lead to illness. Seeing in pairs refers to the anchoring and resonance occurring together at the beginning of spring, or the resonance and counting together at the beginning of summer. Seeing again means that which has departed returns. Departing without departing means leaving before the thirty-day mark. Departing yet not departing means that one has reached thirty days and should depart but does not. Reversal refers to the problematic pulses visible in the changing seasons.

Thus, it is said, the energies must uphold their roles, just as scales must not become unbalanced. The energies of the four seasons, when maintained in their proper positions and interacting as they should, are like weights not being able to separate. The energies of yin and yang in the four seasons require clarity and tranquility for generation and transformation. Generation occurs first, followed by transformation. Movement indicates chaos in the energies.[400p]

】　　帝曰：幽明何如？岐伯曰：两阴交尽，故曰幽。两阳合明，故曰明。幽明之配，寒暑之异也。　　 【注　幽明者，阴阳也。两阴交尽，阴之极也，故曰幽。两阳合明，阳之极也，故曰明。阴极则阳生，阳极则阴生，寒往则暑来，暑往则寒来。故幽明之配，寒暑之异也。】　　帝曰：分至如何？岐伯曰：气至之谓至，气分之谓分。至则气同，分则气异。所谓天地之正纪也。　　 【注　气至谓冬夏之二至，气分谓春秋之二分。此承上文以申明彼春之暖，为夏之暑，彼秋之忿，为冬之怒。言二至之时总属寒暑阴阳之二气。气分之时，则有温凉之不同也。】　　帝曰：夫子言春秋气始于前，冬夏气始于后，余已知之矣。然六气往复，主岁不常也。[401p]

The Emperor said: How are the realms of darkness and brightness? Qibo replied: The two yangs come together to create brightness, and the two yins converge to represent darkness. The pairing of darkness and brightness corresponds to the differences between cold and heat.

[Note: Darkness and brightness refer to yin and yang. The convergence of the two yins denotes the extreme of yin, hence it is called darkness. The coming together of the two yangs signifies the extreme of yang, hence it is called brightness. When yin reaches its peak, yang is born; when yang reaches its peak, yin is born. Cold departs and heat arrives, and conversely. Therefore, the pairing of darkness and brightness corresponds to the differences in cold and heat.]

The Emperor asked: What about the division of the seasons? Qibo replied: The arrival of qi is referred to as "arrival," while the division of qi is called "division." When it arrives, the qi is the same; when it is divided, the qi differs. This signifies the correct order of heaven and earth.

[Note: "Qi arrival" refers to the two solstices of winter and summer, while "qi division" pertains to the two equinoxes of spring and autumn. This follows from the previous text, clarifying that the warmth of spring leads to the heat of summer, and the coolness of autumn leads to the cold of winter. The times of the two solstices are associated with the dual qi of cold and heat, while the times of the divisions differ in terms of temperature.]

The Emperor said: You say that the qi of spring and autumn begins early, while that of winter and summer begins later; I already understand this. However, the six qi alternate, causing the years to be inconsistent.[401p]

其补泻奈何？岐伯曰：上下所主，随其攸利，正其味，则其要也。左右同法。大要曰：少阳之主，先甘后咸；阳明之主，先辛后酸；太阳之主，先咸后苦；厥阴之主，先酸后辛；少阴之主，先甘后咸；太阴之主，先苦后甘。佐以所利，资以所生，是谓得气。　　【注　春秋之气始于前者，春在岁半以上之前，秋在岁半以下之前。夏冬之气，在二气之后，谓四时之主气也。六气往复主岁不常者，谓加临之客气，六期环转，无有常位也。此篇论四时之主气前后交通，得气之清静者也。若受客胜以动之，又不能循序而苛疾起矣。是以上下所主及左右之间气，当随其攸利，正其味以调之，乃其要也。大要宜先泻而后补之。盖以佐主气之所利，资主气之所生，见谓得四时之气，生化而交通也。】古今图书集成医部全录卷一百十七
[402p]

How should we address supplementation and purging? Qi Bo said: The governing principles above and below should align with what is beneficial, and correctness in flavor is essential. The methods on the left and right follow the same principles. The main points are: the governing principle of the Shao Yang first tastes sweet then salty; the governing principle of the Yang Ming first tastes pungent then sour; the governing principle of the Tai Yang first tastes salty then bitter; the governing principle of the Jue Yin first tastes sour then pungent; the governing principle of the Shao Yin first tastes sweet then salty; the governing principle of the Tai Yin first tastes bitter then sweet. Augment with what is beneficial and support with what is generated; this is called obtaining Qi.

[Note: The Qi of spring and autumn begins with those preceding; spring occurs before the halfway point of the year, and autumn occurs after it. The Qi of summer and winter comes after these two, referred to as the governing Qi of the four seasons. The six Qi that arise and recede lead to irregularities in the years, referred to as visitor Qi. The six phases rotate without a fixed position. This section discusses the interactions between the governing Qi of the four seasons, focusing on acquiring pure and tranquil Qi. If one does not follow the sequence and takes excessive actions in response to visitor Qi, complications may arise. Therefore, the governing principles above and below, and the Qi between left and right, should align with what is beneficial and correct in flavor for regulation, as this is essential. The main principle should be to purge before supplementing, as it relates to supporting the benefits of the governing Qi and nurturing what the governing Qi produces, thus embodying the seasonal Qi and facilitating transformation and interaction.][402p]

运气门

　　　　三因方 【宋　陈无择】

　　　　　六十年运气病方

　　六甲年敦阜之纪，岁土太过，雨湿流行。肾水受邪，民病腹痛清厥，意不乐，肌肉痿足痿，脚下痛，中满食减，四肢不举。宜附子山茱萸汤。　　六丙年流衍之纪，岁水太过，寒水流行。心火受邪，民病身热心烦，阴厥，上下中寒，谵妄心痛，喘咳寝汗。宜黄连茯苓汤。　　六戊年赫曦之纪。岁火太过，大暑流行。肺金受邪，民病疟，少气咳喘，血溢血泄，身热骨病，为浸淫。宜麦门冬汤。　　六庚年坚成之纪，岁金太过，燥气流行。肝木受邪，民病胁与小腹痛，耳聋目赤，胸胁痛引小腹，尻阴股膝脾腨胻足皆痛。宜牛膝木瓜汤。　　六壬年发生之纪，岁木太过，风气流行。脾土受邪，民病飧泄食减，体重烦冤，肠鸣胁痛支满。宜苓朮汤。　　六乙年从革之纪，岁金不及，炎火盛行。民病肩背瞀重，鼽嚏咳喘，血便注下。宜紫菀汤。　　六丁年委和之纪，岁木不及，燥乃盛行。[403p]

Gate of Luck

Three Causes Recipe
Song Dynasty, Chen Wuze

Sixty Years of Luck Illness Recipes

In the year of the Sixth Jia, a period of prosperity, the Earth is excessive; rains are damp and flow widely. The Kidney water is afflicted, causing the people to suffer from abdominal pain and cold conditions. They feel unhappy, suffer from muscle atrophy and weakness in their feet, experience pain beneath the feet, fullness in the stomach with reduced appetite, and limbs that cannot be lifted. Suitable remedy: Aconite and Cornelian Cherry Decoction.

In the year of the Sixth Bing, a year of flowing expansions, the Water is excessive; cold water is prevalent. The Heart fire is afflicted, leading to the people suffering from body heat and irritability, cold in the upper and lower body, delirium, heart pain, coughing, and night sweats. Suitable remedy: Coptis and Poria Decoction.

In the year of the Sixth Wu, the year of brilliance. The Fire is excessive; great heat is prevalent. The Lung metal is afflicted, leading to the people suffering from fevers, shortness of breath, coughing, and blood disturbances, feeling hot in the body and bone diseases, causing immersion. Suitable remedy: Ophiopogon Decoction.

In the year of the Sixth Geng, the year of solidity and completion. The Metal is excessive; dryness is prevalent. The Liver wood is afflicted, causing the people to suffer from pain in the sides and lower abdomen, deafness, redness in the eyes, pain in the chest and sides radiating to the lower abdomen, and pain in the buttocks and knees. Suitable remedy: Achyranthes and Papaya Decoction.

In the year of the Sixth Ren, the year of emergence. The Wood is excessive; windy conditions are prevalent. The Spleen earth is afflicted, leading to the people suffering from diarrhea, reduced food intake, heaviness, pain in the sides, and fullness in the abdomen. Suitable remedy: Poria and Atractylodes Decoction.

In the year of the Sixth Yi, the year of following changes. The Metal is deficient; fiery conditions are prevalent. The people suffer from heaviness in the shoulders and back, sneezing, coughing, and blood in the stool. Suitable remedy: Purple Aster Decoction.

In the year of the Sixth Ding, the year of harmony. The Wood is deficient; dryness is prevailing.[403p]

民病中清，胠胁小腹痛，肠鸣溏泄。宜苁蓉牛膝汤。　　六己年卑监之纪，岁土不及，风气盛行。民病飧泄、霍乱，体重腹痛，筋骨繇并肌肉瞤瘛，善怒。宜白朮厚朴汤。　　六辛年涸流之纪，岁水不及，湿乃盛行。民病肿满身重，濡泄，足痿，清厥，脚下痛。宜五味子汤。　　六癸年伏明之纪，岁火不及，寒乃盛行。民病胸痛，胁满，膺背肩脾两臂内痛，郁冒心痛，暴喑。宜黄芪茯神汤。　　子午之岁，少阴司天，阳明在泉，气化运行先天，宜正阳汤。　　丑未之岁，太阴司天，大阳在泉，气化运行后天，宜备化汤。　　寅申之岁，少阳司天，厥阴在泉，气化运行先天，宜升明汤。　　卯酉之岁，阳明司天，少阴在泉，气化运行后天，宜审平汤。　　辰戌之岁，太阳司天，太阴在泉，气化运行先天，宜静顺汤。　　巳亥之岁，厥阴司天，少阳在泉，气化运行后天，宜敷和汤。
　　　　　运气之变成疫[404p]

The people suffer from internal stagnation, experiencing pain in the lower abdomen, bowel sounds, and diarrhea. The appropriate remedy is Corgong and Niu Xis soup.

In the year of the Six Geng, during the period of record, the soil fails to nourish; the influence of wind prevails. The people suffer from food poisoning and cholera, with heavy bodies, abdominal pain, convulsions in muscles and bones, and irritability. The appropriate remedy is Atractylodes and Magnolia soup.

In the year of the Six Xin, during the period of drought, the water fails to nourish; humidity prevails. The people suffer from swelling, heaviness, diarrhea, leg weakness, cold limbs, and foot pain. The appropriate remedy is Schisandra soup.

In the year of the Six Gui, during the period of hiding brightness, the fire fails to nourish; coldness prevails. The people suffer from chest pain, fullness in the sides, pain in the two arms, heart pain due to stagnation, and sudden silence. The appropriate remedy is Astragalus and Poria soup.

In the year of Zi and Wu, the Shaoyin rules the heavens, and Yangming is in the spring; the qi transforms and operates in a natural and primary manner. The appropriate remedy is Zhengyang soup.

In the year of Chou and Wei, the Taiyin rules the heavens, and Yangming is in the spring; the qi transforms and operates in a postnatal manner. The appropriate remedy is Beihua soup.

In the year of Yin and Shen, the Shaoyang rules the heavens, and Jueyin is in the spring; the qi transforms and operates in a natural and primary manner. The appropriate remedy is Shengming soup.

In the year of Mao and You, the Yangming rules the heavens, and Shaoyin is in the spring; the qi transforms and operates in a postnatal manner. The appropriate remedy is Shenping soup.

In the year of Chen and Xu, the Taiyang rules the heavens, and Taiyin is in the spring; the qi transforms and operates in a natural and primary manner. The appropriate remedy is Jingshun soup.

In the year of Si and Hai, the Jueyin rules the heavens, and Shaoyang is in the spring; the qi transforms and operates in a postnatal manner. The appropriate remedy is Fuhuo soup.

Changes in the movement of qi lead to epidemics.[404p]

　　夫五运六气，乃天地阴阳运行升降之常道也。五运流行，有太过不及之异；六气升降，则有逆从胜复之差。凡不合于德化政令者，则为变眚，皆能病人。故谓之时气也。
　　　　河间六书 【金　刘完素】

　　　　　十干夫妇配合成五运

　　甲己合为土运，甲刚木克己柔土。
　　乙庚合为金运，乙柔木嫁庚刚金。
　　丁壬合为木运，丁阴火配壬阳水。
　　丙辛合为水运，丙阳火娶辛柔金。
　　戊癸合为火运，戊阳士娶癸阴水。

　　　　　五运太过不及

　　阳刚夫为太过，阴柔妻为不及，此其略也。凡六十年而周甲子，有岁运同司天曰天符，同岁支曰岁会。孟年同曰支德符。岁运同司地，刚为同天符，柔为同岁会。凡此二十九岁。太过司天克之曰天刑。及年前大寒交气之日，反时程与运程为夫妇者，曰程德符。皆非太过不及，乃年运之气也。申子辰年寅初交，巳酉丑年巳初交，寅午戌年申初交，亥卯未年亥初交气也。[405p]

The Five Movements and Six Qis are the regular principles of the rise and fall of Yin and Yang in heaven and earth. The flow of the Five Movements has disparities of excess and deficiency; the rise and fall of the Six Qis has differences between opposition and compliance. Anything not aligned with the virtue and governance of the state leads to calamities that can afflict people. Therefore, these are called the seasonal energies.

The Ten Heavenly Stems paired together form the Five Movements:

Jia and Ji combine to create the Earth Movement; Jia, the firm Wood, overcomes Ji, the yielding Earth.
Yi and Geng combine to create the Metal Movement; Yi, the yielding Wood, unites with Geng, the firm Metal.
Ding and Ren combine to create the Wood Movement; Ding, the Yin Fire, pairs with Ren, the Yang Water.
Bing and Xin combine to create the Water Movement; Bing, the Yang Fire, marries Xin, the yielding Metal.
Wu and Gui combine to create the Fire Movement; Wu, the Yang Soil, marries Gui, the Yin Water.

The excess and deficiency of the Five Movements:

The Yang firm husband represents excess, while the Yin yielding wife represents deficiency; this is a brief explanation.
