The text explains: When excess occurs, harm follows; when there is acceptance, control follows, and from control comes transformation. Externally, the order of flourishing and decline reflects harm leading to chaos, and transformation leads to significant illness. This few sentences are often elaborated by earlier scholars, but few truly understand the essence of the text.

To delve into its meaning, it states that excess causes harm, harm leads to chaos, and transformation results in significant illness. Acceptance then brings about control, and control leads to transformation, with external flourishing and decline organized thus. Between heaven and earth, the five types of transformation interact, each overcoming and regulating the others. The terrestrial energy controls its own excess, while celestial energy regulates its own victory, which refers to the control of terrestrial energy over its excess.

The application of the six energies returns to what they cannot overcome to effect transformation: thus, the Greater Yin transforms through rain on the Greater Yang, the Greater Yang transforms coldness into the Lesser Yin, the Lesser Yin transforms heat into the Yang Ming, the Yang Ming transforms dryness into the Lesser Yin, and the Lesser Yin transforms wind into the Greater Yin.

In this realm of the four directions, divided into six phases, it corresponds with the seasonal regulations of the heavens. The energies of heaven and earth alternate in fullness and emptiness; that which cannot be overcome is harmonized, the harmonious flourish, while the discordant decline. When in their rightful places, they flourish; when not, they decline. The terrestrial energy moves inward, while celestial energy moves outward; internally and externally they influence each other, flourishing and declining in reliance, hence the external arrangement of flourishing and decline.[535p]

若夫亢则伤害己胜，不受胜己者之施化，于是有胜则有复，胜复更作，败乱生化之常。故上胜则天气降而下，下胜则地气迁而上，甚则易位，气交易则大变生而病作矣。所谓害则败乱，生化大病者是也。此一胜一制一正一变之异化也。河间云：亢则害承者之母气，于是承者乃起而制之。是知有非位之胜复而不知制则生化，外列盛衰，为当位之正化也。楼氏云：火亢则害，水承乃制之。制则生化，至冬着盛。是以夏之暑生冬之寒化，以冬之寒制夏之暑。亢恐不相及之甚，是知有当位之正化，而不知害则败乱，生化大病为非位之胜复也。安可即以今日既亢之乖气，复为后日得制之平气耶？殊不知亢制字义甚明，言亢则非平，言制则非亢矣。生化盛衰，乃当位之常；败乱生化，乃非位之变也。二家全不分别，何也？[536p]

If one is overly assertive, it harms oneself; they do not receive the transformations of victory, thus when one has victory, there is also retaliation. Victory and retaliation give rise to further conflict, leading to chaos as a normal cycle. Therefore, when the upper wins, the heavenly energy descends; when the lower wins, the earthly energy ascends. In extreme cases, they may change places, and the exchange of energies results in significant transformations and illnesses. This is what is meant by harm causing defeat and chaos, resulting in significant illness from the processes of transformation. This illustrates the differences between victory and restraint, correctness and change. Hejian observes: Excessiveness harms the nurturing energy, which then leads to control. Thus, one understands that there is non-positioned victory and retaliation that are not restrained, resulting in transformations, while the external listing of flourishing and declining represents the proper transformations of the correct position. The Lou family notes: Fire in excess is harmful, while water nurtures and restrains it. Restraint leads to transformations, peaking in winter. Therefore, the heat of summer brings about the cold transformations of winter, and the cold of winter restrains the heat of summer. Excessiveness may severely disrupt harmony; thus, it is understood that there are proper transformations in the correct position, yet it is unknown that harm leads to defeat and chaos, resulting in significant illness from non-positioned victory and retaliation. How can we then regard the currently excessive discord as the balanced energy that will be controlled in the next days? Little do they realize that the meaning of "excess" and "restraint" is very clear: excess implies a lack of balance, while restraint implies a departure from excess. The flourishing and declining of transformations are the constants of the proper position; the defeat and chaos of transformation are the changes of the non-position. Why then do these two schools fail to distinguish between them?[536p]

　　　　　释病机十九条

　　天有五行御五位，以生寒暑燥湿风；人有五脏化五气，以生喜怒忧思恐。故五运之气，内应人之五脏。诸风掉眩，皆属于肝；诸寒收引，皆属于肾；诸湿肿满，皆属于脾；诸气膹郁，皆属于肺；诸痛痒疮疡，皆属于心是也。诸厥固泄，皆属于下，谓下焦肾肝之疾也；诸痿喘满，皆属于上，谓上焦心肺之疾也。此皆五脏之疾病，机由于内动者也。天之三阴三阳，化六气以生寒暑燥湿风火，内应人之六腑，外应十二经络。[537p]

The Mechanisms of Disease in Nineteen Points

Heaven has the five elements corresponding to the five positions, which generate cold, heat, dryness, dampness, and wind; humans have the five internal organs that transform the five qi, producing joy, anger, worry, thought, and fear. Thus, the qi of the five movements internally corresponds to the five internal organs of a person. All forms of dizziness and disturbances belong to the liver; all cold sensations that draw in belong to the kidneys; all dampness leading to swelling belongs to the spleen; all qi stagnation belongs to the lungs; and all pain, itching, sores, and lesions belong to the heart. All forms of collapse and leakage belong to the lower, referred to as diseases of the lower burner involving the kidneys and liver; all forms of weakness and fullness belong to the upper, referred to as diseases of the upper burner involving the heart and lungs. These are all diseases of the five organs, stemming from internal movements. Heaven’s three yin and three yang transform into six qi, generating cold, heat, dryness, dampness, wind, and fire, which internally correspond to the six bowels and externally correspond to the twelve meridians.[537p]

诸热瞀瘛，皆属于火，手少阳三焦经也；诸禁鼓栗，如丧神守，皆属于火，手少阴心经也；诸逆冲上，皆属于火，手厥阴心包经也；诸痉项强，皆属于湿，足太阳膀胱经也；诸腹胀大，皆属于热，足太阴脾经也；诸躁狂越，皆属于火，足阳明胃经也；诸暴强直，皆属于风，足厥阴肝经也；诸病有声，鼓之如鼓，皆属于热，手太阴肺经也；诸病胕肿，疼酸惊骇，皆属于火，手阳明大肠经也；诸转反戾，水液浑浊，皆属于热，手太阳小肠经也；诸病水液，澄澈清冷，皆属于寒，足少阴肾经也；诸呕吐酸，暴注下迫，皆属于热，足少阳胆经也。此皆十二经络之邪病，机由于外入者也。刘河间以此著书，漫然不分所属，殊不深考，何也？楼氏但纠其治法之偏，而未及乎此。故并为正之云尔。[538p]

All hot, dizzy, convulsive conditions belong to fire, related to the hand Shaoyang Sanjiao channel; all restrained anxiety and palpitations, resembling a lost spirit, also belong to fire, related to the hand Shaoyin Heart channel; all rebellious counterflows belong to fire, related to the hand Jueyin Pericardium channel; all muscle spasms and stiffness belong to dampness, related to the foot Taiyang Bladder channel; all abdominal bloating belongs to heat, related to the foot Taiyin Spleen channel; all manic and frantic behavior belongs to fire, related to the foot Yangming Stomach channel; all violent rigidity belongs to wind, related to the foot Jueyin Liver channel; all diseases that have sound, like beating a drum, belong to heat, related to the hand Taiyin Lung channel; all swelling and pain in the abdomen, causing fright, belong to fire, related to the hand Yangming Large Intestine channel; all reversals and muddy water liquid belong to heat, related to the hand Taiyang Small Intestine channel; all diseases where water liquid is clear and cold belong to cold, related to the foot Shaoyin Kidney channel; all sour vomiting and sudden downward pressure belong to heat, related to the foot Shaoyang Gallbladder channel. These are all pathogenic conditions of the twelve meridians, arising from external influences. Liu Hejian wrote about this but did not clearly categorize them, lacking in deep analysis. Why? The Lou family only corrected the biases in treatment methods, without addressing this aspect. Thus, I aim to clarify it.[538p]

　　　　医学入门 【明　李梴】

　　　　　运气总论

　　太极肇分而有阴阳。夫阴阳者，天地之道也，万物之纲纪，变化之父母，生杀之本始，神明之府也。　　【纲纪，谓生长化成收藏之纲纪也。父母，谓万物未形之先也。本始，谓生杀皆因而有也。夫有形禀气，而不为五运阴阳之所摄者，未之有也。所以造化不极，能为万物生化之元始者，何也？以其是神明之府故也。合散不测，生化无穷，非神明无能也。】　　故物生谓之化，物极谓之变，阴阳不测谓之神。[539p]

Medicine Introduction
(Ming - Li Zhan)

General Discussion on Qi Movement

The Supreme Ultimate differentiates into Yin and Yang. Yin and Yang are the principles of Heaven and Earth, the framework of all things, the parents of transformation, the origin of life and death, and the abode of the spiritual and divine.

The framework refers to the principles of growth, transformation, formation, and collection. The parents refer to the formless state of all things before they take shape. The origin signifies that life and death arise from this. There has never been a thing that has form and essence yet is not governed by the Five Movements, Yin, and Yang. Therefore, the process of creation is boundless and able to be the source of all transformations—why is this so? It is because it is the abode of the spiritual and divine. The convergence and dispersion are unpredictable, and transformations are limitless; this does not imply the omnipotence of the divine is lacking. Hence, the emergence of things is called transformation, the culmination of things is called change, and the unpredictable nature of Yin and Yang is called the divine.[539p]

然天地者，万物之上下也；左右者，阴阳之道路也；水火者，阴阳之征兆也；金木者，生成之始终也。阴阳五行，流为十干五化之运，寒暑燥湿风火之气，同流于天地之间，而为万物之原，人则禀其精而囿于两间，所以具五脏六腑，以应五运六气之数也。五运者，金木水火土也。　　【水寒火热，故为阴阳之征兆。金杀木生，故为生成之始终。木言阳气触地而生，火言毁然盛而变化万物，金言阴气禁止万物而揪敛，水言润养万物，土言含吐万物。将生者出，将死者归。】　　六气者，风火暑湿燥寒也。
　　 【六气皆有一化也。木化风，主于春，阳气鼓舞，为天号令。君火化热，主于春末夏初，行暄淑之令，而不行炎暑，君德也。相火化暑，主于夏，炎暑大行。金化清燥，清凉乃行，金为丙妇，带火之气，故燥也。水化寒，严凛乃行。土化湿与土，润溽暑湿化行也。盖湿则土生，干则土死；泉出于地中，湿化信矣。】　　圣人仰观五天云色。[540p]

Heaven and earth are the foundations of all things; the left and right are the pathways of yin and yang; water and fire are the signs of yin and yang; metal and wood are the beginnings and ends of generation. The interplay of yin, yang, and the five elements flows into the ten stems and five transformations, with the energies of cold, heat, dryness, moisture, wind, and fire circulating between heaven and earth, serving as the origin of all things. Humans draw in this essence yet are confined between the two, hence possessing the five viscera and six bowels to correspond to the cycles of the five movements and six energies. The five movements are metal, wood, water, fire, and earth.

[Water is cold and fire is hot, thus serving as signs of yin and yang. Metal cuts down wood, hence marking the beginning and end of generation. Wood indicates that yang energy reaches the ground and brings forth life; fire signifies a destructive force that transforms all things abundantly; metal denotes the constraining of all things and their condensation; water represents the nourishment of all things; earth embodies the containment and release of all things. It brings forth the living and returns the dying.] The six energies are wind, fire, heat, moisture, dryness, and cold.

[Each of the six energies has one transformation. Wood transforms into wind, ruling in spring, energizing with yang and serving as heaven’s decree. Fire transforms into heat, ruling in late spring and early summer, following the decree of warmth but not of intense heat, embodying virtue. Corresponding fire transforms into heat, ruling in summer, where intense heat prevails. Metal transforms into dryness, promoting cooling; metal is the wife of fire and therefore dry. Water transforms into cold, bringing severity; earth transforms into moisture, fostering the humid warmth. Moisture causes earth to thrive, while dryness brings death to earth; springs arise from within the earth, affirming the transformation of moisture.] The sage observes the colors of the clouds in the heavens.[540p]

　　【黅天之气，经于中央，临甲己之位，立为土运。素天之气，经于西方，临乙庚之位，立为金运。元天之气，经于北方，临丙辛之位，立为水运。苍天之气，经于东方，临丁壬之位，立为木运。丹天之气，经于南方，临戊癸之位，立为火运。此五气之色，上经二十八宿，下应十二分位。所以古人占天望气，则何何　原作「和」，据文义改。气之灾疫，应在于何方，了然预知之矣。凡占当于正月初一日，若太过之纪寅初看，不及之纪寅末看，平治之纪寅正看。如苍气为风，丹为热，黅为湿，素为燥，黑为寒。其气之色有兼见者，又当分其微甚而推之。】　　天干取运，地支取气。天干有十，配合则为五运；地支十二，对冲则为六气。所以然者，天有阴阳，地亦有阴阳。　　 【天有阴，故能降。地有阳，故能升。】　　天以阳生阴长，地以阳杀阴藏。[541p]

The air of the black heaven travels through the center, positioned at the place of the Jia and Ji, establishing the earth aspect. The air of the white heaven travels through the west, positioned at the place of Yi and Geng, establishing the metal aspect. The air of the primordial heaven travels through the north, positioned at the place of Bing and Xin, establishing the water aspect. The air of the azure heaven travels through the east, positioned at the place of Ding and Ren, establishing the wood aspect. The air of the red heaven travels through the south, positioned at the place of Wu and Gui, establishing the fire aspect. The colors of these five airs correspond to the twenty-eight lunar mansions above and the twelve divisions below. Thus, when the ancients observed the heavens and sought the airs, they understood precisely the disasters and plagues that should arise in various directions. When divining on the first day of the first lunar month, one should observe in the beginning of the period of Yin if there is excess, in the end of the period of Yin if there is deficiency, and directly during the period of Yin in a balanced state. The azure air represents wind, the red represents heat, the black represents humidity, the white represents dryness, and the black represents cold. If there are overlapping colors of the airs, one must distinguish their subtlety and deduce accordingly.

Heaven takes the movement from the heavenly stems, and the earth takes the khí from the earthly branches. There are ten heavenly stems, which combine to form five aspects; there are twelve earthly branches, which face each other to form six airs. This is because heaven has yin and yang, and the earth also has yin and yang.

Heaven has yin, thus it can descend. The earth has yang, thus it can ascend.

Heaven generates yin through yang, and the earth kills yin and hides it through yang.[541p]

　　【生长者，天之道；藏杀者，地之道。天阳主生，故以阳生阴长；地阴主藏，故以阳杀阴藏。】　　阳中有阴，阴中有阳。人在气交之中，身半以上，天之分也，天气主之；身半以下，地之分也，地气主之。其生五，其气三。三而成天，三而成地，三而成人。三而三之则为九，九九制会，故生九窍九脏而应之也。天有三百六十五日，人有三百六十五骨节。天有五行御五位，以生寒暑燥湿风；人有五脏化五气，以生喜怒思忧恐。在天为元，元生神；在人为道，道生智；在地为化，化生五味。神在天为风，在地为木，在人为怒。神在天为热，在地为火，在人为喜。神在天为湿，在地为土，在人为思。神在天为燥，在地为金，在人为忧。神在天为寒，在地为水，在人为恐。寒暑五气更立，各有所先。非其位则邪，当其位则正。[542p]

Those who grow are governed by the Way of Heaven; those who conceal and kill are governed by the Way of Earth. Heaven, being yang, governs growth, thus, yang gives rise to yin; Earth, being yin, governs concealment, thus, yang kills and conceals yin.

There is yang within yin, and yin within yang. In the interchange of qi, for a person, the upper part of the body corresponds to heaven and is governed by heavenly qi; the lower part corresponds to the earth and is governed by earthly qi. The vital essence manifests in five forms, and qi manifests in three. Three manifest in heaven, three manifest in earth, and three manifest in humanity. If three times three, it amounts to nine; hence, there are nine orifices and nine organs corresponding to this.

Heaven has three hundred sixty-five days, and humans have three hundred sixty-five joints. Heaven encompasses the five elements that govern the five positions, giving rise to cold, heat, dryness, humidity, and wind; humans possess five organs that transform into five types of qi, giving rise to joy, anger, thought, worry, and fear.

In heaven, the primordial is present, and the primordial gives rise to the spirit; within humans, the Way exists, and the Way gives rise to wisdom; upon the earth, transformation exists, and transformation gives rise to the five tastes.

The spirit manifests as wind in heaven, as wood on earth, and as anger in humanity. The spirit manifests as heat in heaven, as fire on earth, and as joy in humanity. The spirit manifests as humidity in heaven, as earth on earth, and as thought in humanity. The spirit manifests as dryness in heaven, as metal on earth, and as worry in humanity. The spirit manifests as cold in heaven, as water on earth, and as fear in humanity.

The five qi of cold and heat alternate, each with its precedence. When not in its rightful position, it becomes evil; when in its rightful position, it is proper.[542p]

阴阳之神，不可得而见也；干支之迹，可得而求之也。　　 【天地阴阳以象，不以数推，惟凭干支则可测焉。】　　天气始于甲，地气始于子，天地相合则为甲子。故甲子者，干支之始也。天气终于癸，地气终于亥，天地相合则为癸亥，故癸亥者，干支之末也。阴阳相间，刚柔相须，是以甲子之后，乙丑继之；壬戌之后，癸亥继之。三十年为一纪，六十年为一周。有主运焉，有客运焉，有主气焉，有客气焉。主运主气，万载而不易；客运客气，每岁而迭迁。自天干兄弟次序言之，甲乙，东方木也；丙丁，南方火也；戊己，中央土也；庚辛，西方金也；壬癸，北方水也。　　【甲者，草木始甲而出；乙者，阳尚屈也。丙乃万物炳然着见而强，丁适阳强与阴气相争也。戊阳土也，万物生而出之，万物伐而入之。己阴土也，无所为而自得也。庚乃阳更而续也，辛乃阳极而更新也。[543p]

The divine entities of Yin and Yang cannot be seen; the traces of the Heavenly Stems and Earthly Branches can be sought. The transformation of heaven and earth is represented not by numbers, but can be measured solely by the Stems and Branches.

The heavenly energy begins with Jia, while the earthly energy begins with Zi; when heaven and earth combine, it forms the Jia Zi. Therefore, Jia Zi is the beginning of the Stems and Branches. The celestial energy concludes with Gui, and the earthly energy concludes with Hai; when heaven and earth combine, it forms Gui Hai, thus Gui Hai is the end of the Stems and Branches. The interplay of Yin and Yang and the mutual dependence of hardness and softness lead to the succession of Yi Chou after Jia Zi, and Gui Hai after Ren Xu.

Thirty years constitute a cycle, while sixty years constitute a complete turn. There are principal motions and guest motions, as well as principal and guest energies. The principal motions and energies remain unchanged for thousands of years; the guest motions and energies, however, shift and change every year.

From the perspective of the order of the celestial stems, Jia and Yi represent the Eastern Wood; Bing and Ding represent the Southern Fire; Wu and Ji represent the Central Earth; Geng and Xin represent the Western Metal; Ren and Gui represent the Northern Water.

Jia is the beginning of the growth of grasses and trees; Yi is when the Yang is still bending. Bing makes all things bright and visible, becoming strong; Ding represents the conflict between strong Yang and Yin energy. Wu is the Yang Earth, from which all things are born; Ji is the Yin Earth, which achieves by doing nothing. Geng represents a renewal of Yang, while Xin represents the peak of Yang followed by transformation.[543p]

壬乃阳气生之妊而为胎，与子同意；癸乃万物闭藏，怀孕于其下，揆然萌芽，天之道也。】　　故木为初之运，火为第二运，土为第三运，金为第四运，水为第五运。此主运也。　　 【诗曰：大寒木运始行初，清明前三火运居，芒种后三土运是，立秋后六金运推，立冬后九水运伏，周而复始万年如。或问曰：木火土金水，天道左旋，自然之序也。然君火生土，土复能生相火，火复生金，其义何在？曰：相火非土不成，未见虚空能聚火。金在矿，非火不能煅出。所以《河图》火七居西，金九居南，互显其成能也。认真五行六气总一气也。故木焚则为火，绞则为水；石击则为火，镕则为水。洲渚之内，江河竞注，大海之中，火光常起，皆情之本有也。又何疑土中火，火中金乎？】　　自其夫妇配合言之：甲与己台而化土，乙与庚合而化金，丙与辛合而化水，丁与壬合而化木，戊与癸合而化火。[544p]

In the ninth month, the Yang energy gives rise to conception, resulting in a fetus, in harmony with the child; the Yin energy is the essence of all things, encapsulating and nurturing life underneath it, sprouting naturally according to the way of Heaven. Therefore, Wood represents the first movement, Fire the second, Earth the third, Metal the fourth, and Water the fifth. This is the principle of movement.

The poem states: In the great cold, the Wood movement begins, before the clear brightness, the Fire movement resides, after the grain harvesting, the Earth movement takes place, after the beginning of autumn, the Metal movement advances, after the beginning of winter, the Water movement lies dormant, cycling endlessly as the years proceed. Someone may ask: Wood, Fire, Earth, Metal, and Water, rotating leftward in the way of Heaven, are the natural order. However, how can Fire generate Earth, and Earth in turn can generate Fire, and Fire generate Metal? What is the reasoning behind this? It is said: The Furnace Fire cannot exist without Earth; the void does not gather fire. Metal exists in ores, and it cannot be smelted without Fire. Thus, in the "River Diagram," Fire is located in the West, and Metal in the South, each revealing its potential.

Indeed, the five elements and six energies are ultimately one energy. Therefore, burning Wood turns into Fire; squeezing it turns into Water; striking stone creates Fire, and melting it turns into Water. Within the islets, rivers compete to flow, and in the vast sea, flames continually arise; these are the inherent aspects of nature. Moreover, why doubt the Fire within Earth, and the Metal within Fire?

From the perspective of the couple's union: Jia merges with Yi to transform into Earth; Yi merges with Geng to transform into Metal; Bing merges with Xin to transform into Water; Ding merges with Ren to transform into Wood; Wu merges with Gui to transform into Fire.[544p]

故甲己之岁，士运统之；乙庚之岁，金运统之；丙辛之岁，水运统之；丁壬之岁，木运统之；戊癸之岁，火运统之。此客运也。　　【诗曰：甲己化土乙庚金，丁壬木位尽成林，丙辛便是长流水，戊癸离宫号曰心。盖甲己之岁正月建丙寅，丙火生土，故为土运。乙庚之岁，正月建戊寅，戊土生金，故为金运。丙辛之岁，正月建庚寅，庚金坐水，故为水运。丁壬之岁，正月建壬寅，壬水生木，故为木运。戊癸之岁，正月建甲寅，甲木生火，故为火运。】　　假如甲己，年甲为土运，初之运即土也。土生金，二之运即金也。金生水，三之运即水也。水生木，四之运即木也。木生火，五之运即火也。每一运各主七十二日零五刻。此天干在上为阳，所以主乎运也。又以地支循环次序言之：寅卯，属春，木也。　　 【寅者，演也。正月阳上阴下，律管飞灰以候之，为演事之始也。卯者，茂也，二月阳气盛而孳茂也。】　　巳午，属夏，火也。[545p]

In the years of Jia and Ji, the Earth element governs; in the years of Yi and Geng, the Metal element governs; in the years of Bing and Xin, the Water element governs; in the years of Ding and Ren, the Wood element governs; in the years of Wu and Gui, the Fire element governs. This is the flow of fortune.

The poem states: "In the years of Jia and Ji, Earth transforms; in the years of Yi and Geng, Metal is secured; in the years of Bing and Xin, flowing Water abounds; in the years of Ding and Ren, Wood flourishes. The years of Wu and Gui, known as the Heart, signify departure."

The year of Jia and Ji begins in the first month with Bing Yin, where Bing Fire generates Earth, thus it is the Earth element. The year of Yi and Geng begins in the first month with Wu Yin, where Wu Earth generates Metal, thus it is the Metal element. The year of Bing and Xin begins in the first month with Geng Yin, where Geng Metal is paired with Water, thus it is the Water element. The year of Ding and Ren begins in the first month with Ren Yin, where Ren Water generates Wood, thus it is the Wood element. The year of Wu and Gui begins in the first month with Jia Yin, where Jia Wood generates Fire, thus it is the Fire element.

Assuming Jia and Ji denote that the year of Jia implies the fortune of Earth, hence the initial fortune is Earth. Earth generates Metal, therefore the second fortune is Metal. Metal generates Water, thus the third fortune is Water. Water generates Wood, leading to the fourth fortune as Wood. Wood generates Fire, marking the fifth fortune as Fire. Each fortune governs for seventy-two days and five periods. This heavenly stem, being above, influences fortunes.

Additionally, considered by the cycle of earthly branches: Yin and Mao belong to Spring, representing Wood.

Yin signifies expansion. In the first month, Yang ascends and Yin descends, controlling the flying ash to signal the beginning of expansion. Mao signifies flourishing; in the second month, the Yang energy is strong and thrives.

Si and Wu belong to Summer, representing Fire.[545p]

　　 【巳者，起也，四月正阳无阴，物毕尽而起。午者，长也，五月阳尚未屈，阴始生而为主，物皆长大矣。】　　辰戌丑未，四季，土也。
　　 【辰者，震也，三明阳已过半，万物尽震而长。戌者，灭也，九月万物皆衰灭矣。丑者，纽也，阴尚执而纽之，十二月始终之际也。未者，味也，六月物成而有味也。】　　申酉，属秋，金也。
　　 【申者，身也，七月物体皆成也。酉者，緧也，八月万物皆緧缩收敛。】　　亥子，属冬，水也。
　　【亥者，劾也，十月阴气劾杀万物，此地之道也。子者，北方寒水阴位，一阳肇生之始，故阴极则阳生，妊而为胎，十一月辰也。】　　故风为初之气，火为二之气，暑为三之气，湿为四之气，燥为五之气，寒为终之气，此主气也。　　 【诗曰：大寒厥阴气之初，春分君火二之隅。小满少阳分三气，大暑太阴四相呼。秋分阳明五位是，小雪太阳六之余。[546p]

The "Yes" signifies rise; in April, the正阳 (pure yang) is without yin, and all things complete and rise. The "Wu" symbolizes growth; in May, the yang is not yet waning, yin begins to manifest as the principal force, and all things grow large.

The "Chen" symbolizes震 (shaking), as the three yangs have surpassed their midpoint; all things tremble and grow. The "Xu" signifies demise; in September, all things decline and perish. The "Chou" symbolizes binding; yin still binds things together, marking the end of December. The "Wei" symbolizes flavor; in June, the things mature, gaining flavor.

The "Shen" symbolizes the body; in July, all things are fully formed. The "You" signifies convergence; in August, all things retract and consolidate.

The "Hai" symbolizes harm; in October, the yin energy harms all things, which is the principle of this place. The "Zi" represents cold water in the north, the position of yin; the beginning of the emergence of yang, thus when yin reaches its peak, yang is born, becoming a fetus, marking November.

Therefore, wind corresponds to the initiating energy, fire to the second energy, heat to the third energy, dampness to the fourth energy, dryness to the fifth energy, and cold to the concluding energy; these are the governing energies.

The poem states: "In the Great Cold, the initial energy of厥阴; at Spring Equinox, the君火 at the second corner. In Lesser Fullness, the 少阳 divides the third energy; in Major Heat, the 太阴 calls the four aspects. At Autumn Equinox, the 阳明 corresponds to the fifth position; in Light Snow, the 太阳 is the sixth remainder."[546p]

】　　自其对冲定位言之：子对午而为少阴君火，丑对未而为太阴湿土，寅对申而为少阳相火，如对酉而为阳明燥金，辰对戌而为太阳寒水，巳对亥而为厥阴风木。　　 【君火司午，火本热，而其气当午位阴生之初，故标寒而属少阴也。水居北方，子位水，本寒，而其气当阳生之初，故标热而属太阳也。土应长夏，未之位，未乃午之次，故曰，太阴相火司于寅，寅乃丑之次。故曰，少阳木，居东方震，在人主肝处膈下，阴位木，必待阴而后生，故属厥阴。金居西方兑，在人主肺，居膈上。阳位金，必待阳而后发，故属阳明也。[547p]

From the perspective of their oppositional positions: the Child (Zi) is countered by the Noon (Wu) and is thus the Minor Yin Lord Fire; the Ox (Chou) counters the Shepherd's Dog (Wei) and is the Major Yin Moist Earth; the Tiger (Yin) counters the Monkey (Shen) and represents the Minor Yang Corresponding Fire, while the Rooster (You) corresponds with the Bright Yang Dry Metal; the Dragon (Chen) counters the Dog (Xu) and symbolizes the Major Yang Cold Water; the Snake (Si) counters the Pig (Hai) and represents the Reckless Yin Wind Wood.

The Lord Fire governs at Noon, and Fire is inherently hot, yet its energy is at the position of Noon, the initial stage of Yin's birth, hence it marks coldness and belongs to the Minor Yin. Water resides in the North, with the Child position being Water, inherently cold, yet its energy is at the initial stage of Yang's birth, thus it marks warmth and belongs to the Major Yang. Earth corresponds to Late Summer, with the position of Wei, which is next to Wu, hence it is said that Major Yin Corresponding Fire governs in the Tiger position, which is next to the Ox. Therefore, it is said to be Minor Yang Wood, which resides in the Eastern Thunder area, under the diaphragm of the human master’s liver. Yin Wood must wait for Yin before it can grow, thus it belongs to the Reckless Yin. Metal resides in the Western Marsh, in the lungs of the human master, and sits above the diaphragm. Yang Metal must wait for Yang before it can emerge, thus it belongs to the Bright Yang.[547p]

】　　故子午之岁，君火主之；丑未之岁，湿土主之；寅申之岁，相火主之；卯酉之岁，燥金主之；辰戌之岁，寒水主之；巳亥之岁，风木主之。此客气也。　　 【诗曰：子午少阴君火天，阳明燥金应在泉。丑未太阴湿土上，太阳寒水雨连绵。寅申少阳相火旺，厥阴风木地中联。卯酉却与子午反，辰戌巳亥到皆然。如卯酉年司天，即子午年在泉；卯酉年在泉，即子午年司天。辰戌年与丑未年同例，巳亥年与寅申年同例。[548p]

Therefore, in the years of Zi and Wu, the ruling element is fire; in the years of Chou and Wei, it is moist earth; in the years of Yin and Shen, it is the fire of the phase; in the years of Mao and You, it is dry metal; in the years of Chen and Xu, it is cold water; in the years of Si and Hai, it is wind wood. This is the energy of guests.

The poem states: "In the years of Zi and Wu, the lesser yin rules the fire of heaven; the greater yang, the dry metal, corresponds to the spring. In the years of Chou and Wei, the greater yin rests on the moist earth; the sun's cold water brings continuous rain. In the years of Yin and Shen, the lesser yang flourishes in its fiery strength; the phase of wind wood is connected in the earth below. The years of Mao and You are contrary to those of Zi and Wu; the years of Chen and Xu and the years of Si and Hai follow the same pattern. If the years of Mao and You preside over heaven, then the years of Zi and Wu are found in the spring; if the years of Mao and You are at the spring, then the years of Zi and Wu preside over heaven. The years of Chen and Xu follow the example of Chou and Wei; the years of Si and Hai follow the example of Yin and Shen."[548p]

】　　假令子午少阴君火司天 【午位，】 阳明燥金司地 【子位。】 上者右行，太阴湿土为天之左间，厥阴风木为天之右间，所以面南而命其位也。下者左行，太阳寒水为地之左间，少阳相火为地之右间，所以面北而命其位也。一气在上【司一岁之天，又主上半年，】 一气在下 【司一岁之地，又主下半年。】 二气在左，二气在右 【司人与万物。】 地之左间为初之气，　　【要诀：每年退二，便是客乡。如子司天，后二支戌太阳寨水为初之气，亥为二气，子为三气，丑为四气，寅为五气，卯为六气。又逐年年辰，逐日日辰，皆名司天。[549p]

If the Celestial Fire of Shaoyin is in the position of Ziwu, and the Dry Metal of Yangming is in the position of Wu; the former moves right, with the Wet Earth of Taiyin on the left side of heaven, and the Wind Wood of Jueyin on the right side of heaven, thus facing south and designating its position. The latter moves left, with the Cold Water of Taiyang on the left side of the earth, and the Rising Fire of Shaoyang on the right side of the earth, thus facing north and designating its position. The upper qi governs the sky of one year and presides over the first half of the year, while the lower qi governs the earth of one year and presides over the second half of the year. There are two qi on the left and two qi on the right, governing humanity and all things. The left side of the earth corresponds to the initial qi. Key insight: Each year retreating by two signifies the guest's dwelling. For instance, if Zi governs the sky, the two subsequent branches, Xu and Yin, signify the initial qi; Hai represents the second qi, Zi represents the third qi, Chou represents the fourth qi, Yin represents the fifth qi, and Yin represents the sixth qi. Furthermore, the yearly and daily positions are all designated as governing the sky.[549p]

】　　天之右间为二之气，司天为三之气，天之左间为四之气，地之右间为五之气，司地为终之气。每一气主旺六十日八十七刻半有奇。　　 【卯酉年，阳明司天，太阴在泉，初气太阴，二气少阳，三气阳明，四气太阳，五气厥阴，六气少阴。辰戌年，太阳司天，太阴在泉，初气少阳，二气阳明，三气太阳，四气厥阴，五气少阴，六气太阴。丑未年，太阴司天，太阳在泉，初气厥阴，二气少阴，三气太阴，四气少阳，五气阳明，六气太阳。[550p]

In the right sector of heaven is the energy of two; in the control of heaven is the energy of three; in the left sector of heaven is the energy of four; in the right sector of earth is the energy of five; and in the control of earth is the energy of ending. Each energy governs for sixty days and eighty-seven and a half moments, with a peculiar occurrence.

In the year of the Rabbit and Rooster, the Yangming governs heaven, while the Taiyin is at the spring. The initial energy is the Taiyin, the second energy is the Shaoyang, the third energy is the Yangming, the fourth energy is the Taiyang, the fifth energy is the Jueyin, and the sixth energy is the Shaoyin.

In the year of the Dragon and Dog, the Taiyang governs heaven, while the Taiyin is at the spring. The initial energy is the Shaoyang, the second energy is the Yangming, the third energy is the Taiyang, the fourth energy is the Jueyin, the fifth energy is the Shaoyin, and the sixth energy is the Taiyin.

In the year of the Ox and Goat, the Taiyin governs heaven, while the Taiyang is at the spring. The initial energy is the Jueyin, the second energy is the Shaoyin, the third energy is the Taiyin, the fourth energy is the Shaoyang, the fifth energy is the Yangming, and the sixth energy is the Taiyang.[550p]

寅申年，少阳司天，厥阴在泉，初气少阴，二气太阴，三气少阳，四气阳明，五气太阳，六气厥阴。巳亥年，厥阴司天，少阳在泉，初气阳明，二气太阳，三气厥阴，四气少阴，五气太阴，六气少阳。】　　此地支在下为阴，所以主乎气也。然客运之流行也，有太过焉，有不及焉。太过之年，甲丙戊庚壬，五阳干也。不及之年，乙丁己辛癸，五阴干也。太过其至先，大寒前十三日交，名曰先天。不及其至后，大寒后十三日交，名曰后天。平气之年，正大寒日交，不先不后，名曰齐天。[551p]

In the Year of the Tiger and Monkey, the Lesser Yang governs Heaven, and the Absolute Yin dwells in the springs. The initial qi is the Lesser Yin, the second qi is the Greater Yin, the third qi is the Lesser Yang, the fourth qi is the Yang Ming, the fifth qi is the Greater Yang, and the sixth qi is the Absolute Yin. In the Year of the Snake and Pig, the Absolute Yin governs Heaven, and the Lesser Yang dwells in the springs. The initial qi is the Yang Ming, the second qi is the Greater Yang, the third qi is the Absolute Yin, the fourth qi is the Lesser Yin, the fifth qi is the Greater Yin, and the sixth qi is the Lesser Yang.

Here, the Earthly Branches are below and thus represent Yin, which governs the qi. However, the flow of guest currents may be excessive or insufficient. In years of excess, the heavenly stems are Jia, Bing, Wu, Geng, and Ren, all five are Yang. In years of insufficiency, the heavenly stems are Yi, Ding, Ji, Xin, and Gui, all five are Yin. The peak of excess arrives first, thirteen days before the Great Cold, known as the Former Heaven. The peak of insufficiency arrives later, thirteen days after the Great Cold, known as the Latter Heaven. In years of balanced qi, it coincides precisely with the day of the Great Cold, neither early nor late, known as the Equal Heaven.[551p]

　　【申子辰年，大寒日寅初一刻，交初之气；春分日子时末，交二之气；小满日亥时末，交三之气；大暑日戌时末，交四之气；秋分日酉时末，交五之气；小雪日申时末，交终之气。所谓一六天也。巳酉丑年，大寒日巳初一刻，交初之气；春分日卯时末，交二之气；小满日寅时末，交三之气；大暑日丑时末，交四之气；秋分日子时末，交五之气；小雪日亥时末，交终之气。所谓二六天也。[552p]

In the year of Shenzi and the hour of Hares, on the day of Great Cold, at the first moment of the tiger, is the onset of the initial qi; on the day of Spring Equinox, at the end of the hour of the rat, is the transition to the second qi; on the day of Minor Fullness, at the end of the hour of the pig, is the transition to the third qi; on the day of Major Heat, at the end of the hour of the dog, is the transition to the fourth qi; on the day of Autumn Equinox, at the end of the hour of the rooster, is the transition to the fifth qi; on the day of Minor Snow, at the end of the hour of the monkey, is the transition to the final qi. This is referred to as the first six heavens.

In the year of Siyouchou, on the day of Great Cold, at the first moment of the snake, is the onset of the initial qi; on the day of Spring Equinox, at the end of the hour of the rabbit, is the transition to the second qi; on the day of Minor Fullness, at the end of the hour of the tiger, is the transition to the third qi; on the day of Major Heat, at the end of the hour of the ox, is the transition to the fourth qi; on the day of Autumn Equinox, at the end of the hour of the rat, is the transition to the fifth qi; on the day of Minor Snow, at the end of the hour of the pig, is the transition to the final qi. This is referred to as the second six heavens.[552p]

寅午戌年，大寒日申初一刻，交初之气；春分日午时末，交二之气；小满日巳时末，交三之气；大暑日辰时末，交四之气；秋分日卯时末，交五之气；小雪日寅时末，交终之气。所谓三六天也。亥卯未年，大寒日亥初一刻，交初之气；春分日酉时末，交二之气；小满日申时末，交三之气；大暑日未时末，交四之气；秋分日午时末，交五之气；小雪日巳时末，交终之气。所谓四六天也。】　　客气之升降也，有正化焉，有对化焉。正化之岁，谓午未寅酉辰亥之年也。对化之岁，谓子丑申卯戌巳之年也。正化者，令之实，从本，其数生；对化者，令之虚，从标，其数成。　　【水一，火二，木三，金四，土五，皆以阴阳而配。[553p]

In the years of Yin, Wu, and Xu, at the beginning of the great cold on the first moment of the third watch, the initial qi transitions; at the end of midday on the spring equinox, the second qi transitions; at the end of the seventh watch on the minor fullness, the third qi transitions; at the end of the fifth watch on the great heat, the fourth qi transitions; at the end of the fourth watch on the autumn equinox, the fifth qi transitions; at the end of the third watch on minor snow, the final qi transitions. This is referred to as the "Three-Six Days."

In the years of Hai, Mao, and Wei, at the beginning of the great cold on the first moment of the twelfth watch, the initial qi transitions; at the end of the tenth watch on the spring equinox, the second qi transitions; at the end of the ninth watch on the minor fullness, the third qi transitions; at the end of the eighth watch on the great heat, the fourth qi transitions; at the end of the seventh watch on the autumn equinox, the fifth qi transitions; at the end of the sixth watch on minor snow, the final qi transitions. This is referred to as the "Four-Six Days."

As for the rise and fall of guest qi, there exists both Zheng transformation and Dui transformation. The years of Zheng transformation are those of Wu, Wei, Yin, You, Chen, and Hai. The years of Dui transformation are those of Zi, Chou, Shen, Mao, Xu, and Si. The Zheng transformation signifies substantiality, based on the essence, manifesting in numbers; the Dui transformation signifies insubstantiality, based on the symbol, completing in numbers.

Water is one, fire is two, wood is three, metal is four, earth is five, all matched according to yin and yang.[553p]

若考其深义，则水生于一，天地未分，万物未成之初，莫不先见于水，故草木子实人虫胎卵未就，皆水也。及水聚而形质皆备阴阳，而后成物，故物之小而味苦者，火之兆也。物熟则甘，土之味也，甘极则淡反本也。人禀阴阳，先生二肾，草木子实，大小虽异，其中皆有两以相合，与人肾同，是以万物非阴阳合体，则不能化生，故次二曰火。既阴阳合体，然后有春生而秋成，故次三曰木，次四曰金。木火金水，莫不因土而成，故次五曰土。[554p]

If we examine its profound significance, water originates from the One, when heaven and earth were not yet separated and all things had not yet come into being. Everything is seen first in water; thus, the seeds of plants and the embryos of creatures, although not yet formed, are all associated with water. When water gathers, it takes on forms and qualities, embodying both yin and yang, and only then do things come into existence. Therefore, those things that are small and bitter signify fire. When things are ripe, they are sweet, which is the flavor of earth. When sweetness reaches its extreme, it turns bland, returning to the original state. Humans, endowed with yin and yang, are first formed with two kidneys. Although the seeds and fruits of plants vary in size, they all contain a duality that unites, resembling the kidneys in humans. Thus, without the union of yin and yang, all things cannot transform and arise; hence, fire is mentioned second. Once yin and yang unite, there is spring birth and autumn maturity; therefore, wood is mentioned third, and metal fourth. Wood, fire, metal, and water all come into being due to earth; thus, earth is mentioned fifth.[554p]

三阴三阳，正化者从本生数，对化者从标成数。】　　假令甲子年，甲为土运，统主一年，子为君火，专司一岁，一期三百六十五日零二十五刻，正合乎周天三百六十五度四分度之一也。　　【周天者，天周地位，非周天之六气也。天体至圆，周围三百六十五度四分度之一，天行健，一日一夜，周三百六十五度四分度之一，又进过一度，日行速健，次于天一日一夜，周三百六十五度四分度之一恰好。然天多进一度，则日为退一度；二日天进二度，则日为退二度。[555p]

Three Yin and Three Yang, the true transformations proceed from the original life numbers, while the transformed ones follow the derived life numbers. For example, in the Year of the Wood Rat, Wood represents the Earth element and governs the year, while Rat signifies the Fire element, presiding over one year. A complete cycle lasts three hundred sixty-five days and twenty-five moments, which corresponds precisely to one three hundred sixty-five degrees and one-fourth of a degree of the celestial sphere. The celestial sphere refers to the heavens surrounding the position of the Earth, distinct from the sixqi of the celestial sphere. The celestial body is perfectly round, with a circumference of three hundred sixty-five degrees and one-fourth of a degree. The heavens operate robustly, completing one rotation in one day and night, which exactly matches three hundred sixty-five degrees and one-fourth of a degree. If the heavens advance by an additional degree, then the sun retreats by one degree; if in two days the heavens advance by two degrees, then the sun retreats by two degrees.[555p]

积至三百六十五日四分日之一，则天所进过之度，又恰周得本数，而日所退之度，亦恰退尽本数，遂与天会而成一年，是谓一年一周天。月行迟，一日一夜行三百六十五度四分度之一行不尽，比天为退了十三度有奇，至二十九日半强，恰与天相值在恰好处，是谓一月一周天。五日为一候，三候成一气，即十五日也。三气成一节，节谓立春、春分、立夏、夏至、立秋、秋分、立冬、冬至，此八节也。三八二十四气而分四时，一岁成矣。春秋言分者，阴阳中分，其气异也。冬夏言至者，阴阳至此而极，其气同也。[556p]

When the accumulation reaches three hundred sixty-five days and one-fourth of a day, the progression of the heavens corresponds to its original measure, and the regression of the sun also corresponds precisely to its original measure. Thus, they converge to complete a year, which is called one year and one revolution of the heavens.

The moon moves slowly, traveling one day and one night through three hundred sixty-five degrees and one-fourth of a degree, not completing its course. Compared to the heavens, it falls behind by thirteen degrees, reaching about twenty-nine and a half days, coinciding perfectly with the heavens at the right moment, which is called one month and one revolution of the heavens.

Five days constitute one phase, and three phases make up one "qi," equating to fifteen days. Three "qi" form one season, with the eight seasons being the Beginning of Spring, Spring Equinox, Beginning of Summer, Summer Solstice, Beginning of Autumn, Autumn Equinox, Beginning of Winter, and Winter Solstice.

There are twenty-four "qi" in total, divided into four seasons, completing a year. The terms used in Spring and Autumn concerning division signify the balance of yin and yang, as their qualities differ. The terms used in Winter and Summer concerning arrival indicate the culmination of yin and yang, as their qualities are similar.[556p]

天亦无候，以风雨霜露草木之类，应期可验而测之，故曰候。言一候之日，以五运之气相生而值之，即五日也。《书》曰：期三百六旬有六日，以闰月定四时成岁，即其义也。】　　一期之中，主运以位，而相次于下，客运以气，而周流于上。客气加于主运之上，主气临于客气之下。天时所以不齐，民病所由生也。　　【辰戌年，初之客气少阳相火，加主气厥阴风木；二之客气阳明燥金，加主气少阴君火；三之客气太阳寒水，加主气少阳相火；四之客气厥阴风木，加主气太阴湿土；五之客气少阴君火，加主气肠明燥金；终之客气太阴湿土，加主气太阳寒水。[557p]

The heavens do not have seasons by themselves; rather, the phenomena of wind, rain, frost, and dew in trees and grass follow a timetable that can be verified and measured, hence they are called seasonal markers. Referring to a seasonal marker day, it corresponds to the five phases interacting with one another, equating to five days. The text states: the period consists of three hundred and sixty ten-day cycles, with six extra days, determined by leap months to establish the four seasons within a year, which embodies this meaning.

Within a single cycle, the principal energy resides in its position, while the secondary energy follows below; the guest energy operates above, and cycles through. The guest energy, when added to the principal energy, combines with the primary energy that acts over the guest energy. This discrepancy in celestial timing leads to the ailments among the people.

In the year of Chen and Xu, the initial guest energy of lesser yang fire adds to the primary energy of the supreme yin wood; the second guest energy of yang brightness metal adds to the primary energy of lesser yin fire; the third guest energy of greater yin water adds to the primary energy of lesser yang fire; the fourth guest energy of supreme yin wood adds to the primary energy of greater yin earth; the fifth guest energy of lesser yin fire adds to the primary energy of bright metal; the concluding guest energy of greater yin earth adds to the primary energy of greater yang water.[557p]

以上皆客气加于主运之上，举此二年为例也。抑论主气，春温夏暑，秋凉冬寒，风以动之，火以温之，暑以蒸之，湿以润之，燥以干之，寒以坚之，皆天地正气之运行。惟客加于主，乃有逆从淫胜，然后春有凄风，夏有伏阴，秋有苦雨，冬有愆阳。风胜则地动，火胜则地固，暑胜则地热，湿胜则地泥，燥胜则地干，寒胜则地裂，气候不齐，疠疾时降。】　　六甲年，土运太过，则雨湿流行，湿病乃生，肾水受邪，治当除湿以补肾。[558p]

The above concerns the influence of external factors on the primary conditions, using these past two years as examples. Discussing the primary elements: in spring, there is warmth; in summer, heat; in autumn, coolness; and in winter, coldness. Wind causes movement, fire provides warmth, heat brings humidity, moisture offers nourishment, dryness causes aridity, and coldness creates solidity—all are manifestations of the proper flow of the universe's vital forces. However, when external influences overpower the primary elements, adverse conditions arise: spring brings chilling winds, summer experiences oppressive gloom, autumn suffers from persistent rain, and winter faces unwelcome sunshine. When wind prevails, the land shakes; when fire dominates, the earth becomes solid; when heat overpowers, the ground becomes scorching; when moisture prevails, the soil turns muddy; when dryness wins, the land dries up; and when cold prevails, the earth fractures. Uneven climates lead to the emergence of diseases at certain times. In the sixth year of the cycle, when the earth’s energy is excessive, humidity increases, resulting in illnesses linked to dampness. Thus, treatment should focus on eliminating moisture to strengthen the kidneys.[558p]

六己年，土运不及，则木气乘旺，反见风化，风病乃行，治当治脾以平木。六丙年，水运太过，则寒气大行，寒病乃生，心火受邪，治当逐寒以补心。六辛年，水运不及，则土气乘旺，反见湿化，湿病乃行，治当补肾以除湿。六戊年，火运太过，则热气大行，热病乃生，肺金受邪，治当降火以补肺。六癸年，火运不及，则水气乘旺，反见寒化，寒病乃行，治当补心以逐寒。六庚年，金运太过，则燥气流行，燥病乃生，肝木受邪，治当清燥以补肝。六乙年，金运不及，则火气乘旺，反见热化，热病乃行，治当清肺以降火。[559p]

In the year of the Six Ji, if the earth's influence is insufficient, then the wood energy flourishes, leading to the appearance of wind and subsequent wind diseases. Treatment should focus on the spleen to balance the wood.

In the year of the Six Bing, if the water's influence is excessive, then the cold energy prevails, resulting in cold diseases. The heart fire is affected by pathogens, and treatment should involve expelling the cold to nourish the heart.

In the year of the Six Xin, if the water's influence is insufficient, then the earth energy thrives, leading to dampness, which causes damp-related diseases. Treatment should focus on nourishing the kidneys to eliminate dampness.

In the year of the Six Wu, if the fire's influence is excessive, then the hot energy prevails, resulting in heat-related diseases. The lung metal is afflicted by pathogens, and treatment should involve reducing heat to nourish the lungs.

In the year of the Six Gui, if the fire's influence is insufficient, then the water energy flourishes, leading to coldness, which causes cold diseases. Treatment should focus on nourishing the heart to expel the cold.

In the year of the Six Geng, if the metal's influence is excessive, then dryness spreads, leading to dry-related diseases. The liver wood is affected by pathogens, and treatment should involve clearing dryness to nourish the liver.

In the year of the Six Yi, if the metal's influence is insufficient, then the fire energy flourishes, leading to heat conversion, which causes heat-related diseases. Treatment should focus on clearing the lungs to reduce heat.[559p]

六壬年，木运太过，则风气大行，风病乃生，脾土受邪，治当平木以补脾。六丁年，木运不及，则金气乘旺，反见燥化，燥病乃行，治当补肝以清燥。此客运之治法也。太阳寒水，治宜辛热；阳明燥金，治宜苦温；少阳相火，治宜咸寒；太阴湿土，治宜苦热；少阴君火，治宜咸寒；厥阴风木，治宜辛凉。此六气之治法也。然运气之所以有变者，气相得则和，不相得则病。又有相得而病者，以下临上不当位也。五行相生者为相得，相克者为不相得。上临下为顺，下临上为逆。[560p]

In the year of Liu Ren, when the Wood element is overly strong, the winds become prevalent, leading to the emergence of wind diseases. The Spleen is then afflicted by evil influences, and treatment should focus on balancing the Wood to supplement the Spleen. In the year of Liu Ding, when Wood is insufficient, the Metal element becomes dominant, resulting in dryness manifesting as dry diseases. Treatment should aim to nourish the Liver to clear the dryness. This is the method of treating guest elements.

For the Yang Sun's cold Water, treatment should favor warm spicy herbs; for the Yang Ming's dry Metal, treatment should favor bitter warm herbs; for the Shao Yang's Fire, treatment should be cool and salty; for the Tai Yin's moist Earth, treatment should be hot and bitter; for the Shao Yin's ruling Fire, treatment should be cool and salty; for the Jue Yin's Wind Wood, treatment should be cool and spicy. This outlines the methods of treating the six qi.

However, the reason for the changes in the elemental cycles is that qi harmonizes when compatible and leads to disease when incompatible. Moreover, there can be cases of compatibility still resulting in sickness due to the misplacement of influences from above to below. The mutual generation of the five elements signifies compatibility, while their mutual overcoming indicates incompatibility. When an influence from above descends to below, it is considered harmonious; when below influences above, it is considered adverse.[560p]

　　【假令土临火，火临木，木临水，水临金，金临土，皆为以下临上，不当位也。父子之义，子为下，父为上，以子临父，不亦逆乎？】　　司天克运则顺，运克司天则逆。气克运则顺，运克气则逆。运气相同曰天符。　　 【戊子、戊午、戊寅、戊申年，运气皆火，丙辰、丙戌年运气皆水，己丑、己未年，运气皆土，乙卯、乙酉年，运气皆金，丁巳、丁亥年，运气皆木。六十年中，有此十二年天符也。又戊子日戊为火运，子为少阴君火司天，运与司天同火，是为天符，此日得病速而危困也。更遇当年太岁，亦是天符，或是岁会，其病尤困。】　　天气生运曰顺化。[561p]

If earth is on top of fire, fire on top of wood, wood on top of water, water on top of metal, and metal on top of earth, all are instances of what is beneath improperly dominating what is above. In the relationship between father and son, the son is below and the father is above; to have the son dominate the father is indeed contrary to this principle.

When the celestial authority harmonizes with the current, it is considered to be in accordance with nature; when the current overcomes the celestial authority, it is contrary. When the vital energy overcomes the current, it is in accordance; when the current overcomes the vital energy, it is contrary. When the current and the vital energy are the same, it is called a heavenly symbol.

In the years of Wu Zi, Wu Wu, Wu Yin, and Wu Shen, the current and vital energy are all fire. In the years of Bing Chen and Bing Xu, they are all water. In the years of Ji Chou and Ji Wei, they are all earth. In the years of Yi Mao and Yi You, they are all metal. In the years of Ding Si and Ding Hai, they are all wood. Among the sixty years, there are these twelve years that are heavenly symbols. Additionally, on the day of Wu Zi, Wu represents the fire current, and Zi represents the subordinate Yin lord fire overseeing the heavens. Since the current and the celestial authority are both fire, this is a heavenly symbol; on this day, illnesses arise quickly and are grave and concerning. Moreover, encountering the Tai Sui of that year is also a heavenly symbol; if it coincides with the year's assembly, the illness is especially burdensome.

Heavenly energy giving birth to the current is called harmonious transformation.[561p]

　　 【甲子、甲午、甲寅、甲申年，火下生土也。壬辰、壬戌年，水下生木也。乙丑、乙未年，土下生金也。辛卯、辛酉年，金下生水也。癸巳、癸亥年，木下生火也。六十年中，有此十二年顺化也。】　　天气克运曰天刑。
　　 【庚子、庚午、庚寅、庚申年，火下克金也。戊辰、戊戌年，水下克火也。辛丑、辛未年，土下克水也。丁卯、丁酉年，金下克木也。己巳、己亥年，木下克土也。六十年中，有此十二年天刑也。】　　运生天气曰小逆。
　　 【壬子、壬午、壬寅、壬申年，木上生火也。庚辰、庚戌年，金上生水也。癸丑、癸未年，火上生土也。己卯、己酉年，土上生金也。辛巳、辛亥年，水上生木也。子临父位，于理未当，六十年中，有此十二年小逆也。】　　运克天气曰不和。[562p]

In the years of Jiazi, Jiayin, Jiayin, and Jiashen, fire generates earth. In the years of Renchen and Renxu, water generates wood. In the years of Yichou and Yimai, earth generates gold. In the years of Xinyou and Xinyu, gold generates water. In the years of Guisi and Guihai, wood generates fire. Within sixty years, there are these twelve years of harmonious transformation. The concept of “Heavenly Punishment” refers to weather overcoming fate.

In the years of Gengzi, Gengwu, Gengyin, and Gengshen, fire overcomes metal. In the years of Wuchen and Wuxu, water overcomes fire. In the years of Xinchou and Ximai, earth overcomes water. In the years of Dingyin and Dingyou, metal overcomes wood. In the years of Jisi and Jihai, wood overcomes earth. Within sixty years, there are these twelve years of heavenly punishment. The concept of “Small Reversal” refers to fate overcoming weather.

In the years of Renzi, Renwu, Renyin, and Renshen, wood generates fire. In the years of Gengchen and Gengxu, metal generates water. In the years of Guichou and Guiwei, fire generates earth. In the years of Jiyin and Jiyou, earth generates gold. In the years of Xinsi and Xinwei, water generates wood. When the child assumes the father's position, it is not in accordance with reason; within sixty years, there are these twelve years of small reversal. The concept of “Dis harmony” refers to fate overcoming weather.[562p]

　　 【丙子、丙午、丙寅、丙申年，水上克火也。甲辰、甲戌年，土上克水也。辛丑、辛未年，水上克土也。癸卯、癸酉年，火上克金也。己巳、己亥年，金上克木也。六十年中，有此十二年不和也。】　　运临木气之位曰岁会。
　　 【子，水位也，丙子年水运临之。午，火位也，戊午年火运临之。卯，木位也，丁卯年木运临之。酉，金位也，乙酉年金运临之。辰戌、丑未土位也，甲辰、甲戌、己丑、己未年土运临之。六十年中，有此八年岁会也。又丙子日丙为水运，子为水支，是运与支同水，乃名岁会，年月日时同，如遇此日得病不死，但执持而徐缓，更会年月时，合天符岁会，其病尤甚。】　　天符岁会相合曰太乙天符。[563p]

In the years of Bingzi, Bingwu, Bingyin, and Bingshen, water overcomes fire. In the years of Jiachen and Jiaxu, earth overcomes water. In the years of Xinchou and Xinwei, water overcomes earth. In the years of Guimao and Guiyou, fire overcomes metal. In the years of Jisi and Jihai, metal overcomes wood. Within the sixty years, there are these twelve years of discord.

When the wood element is in position, it is called the annual meeting.

Zi corresponds to water, and in the year of Bingzi, the water element is dominant. Wu corresponds to fire, and in the year of Wuwu, the fire element is dominant. Mao corresponds to wood, and in the year of Dingmao, the wood element is dominant. You corresponds to metal, and in the year of Yiyou, the metal element is dominant. The positions of Chen and Xu, and Chou and Wei correspond to earth, with Jiachen, Jiaxu, Jichou, and Jiwei being years when the earth element is dominant. Within the sixty years, there are these eight years of annual meetings. Furthermore, on the day of Bingzi, Bing represents the water element, and Zi is the water branch; thus, the element and the branch align in water, leading to the term 'annual meeting.' If one falls ill on this day, they do not die but must manage their condition carefully. Moreover, if the year, month, day, and time coincide with this meeting and align with the heavenly symbol, the illness becomes significantly worse. The convergence of the heavenly symbol and the annual meeting is called the Great One Heavenly Symbol.[563p]

　　 【戊午、乙酉、己未、己丑，六十年中有此四年太乙天符也。又戊午日戊为火运，午是少阴君火司天，又是火支，乃名太乙天符，此日得病主死。】　　运与四孟月相同曰支德符。
　　 【寅属木，孟春月也，壬寅年木运临之。巳属火，孟夏月也，癸巳年火运临之。申属金，孟秋月也，庚申年金运临之。亥属水，孟冬月也，辛亥年水运临之。六十年中，有此四年支德符也。】　　运与交同日相合曰干德符。
　　 【甲与己合，乙与庚合，丙与辛合，丁与壬合，戊与癸合，一年遇些二干，天地德合，亦为平气之岁也。】　　太过之运加地气曰同天符。
　　 【庚子、庚午年，运同司地燥金；壬寅、壬申年，运同司地风木；甲辰、甲戌年，运同司地湿土。六十年中有此六年同天符。】　　不及之运加地气曰同岁会。[564p]

In the years Wu Wu, Yi You, Ji Wei, and Ji Chou, there are these four years of the Taiyi Heavenly Talismans in a sixty-year cycle. Furthermore, on the day of Wu Wu, Wu represents the fire element, and Wu is the lord of the fire aspect of the Shaoyin, while Wu also belongs to the fire branch. Hence, it is called the Taiyi Heavenly Talisman. A disease occurring on this day indicates death. The fortune matches with the four Meng months, referred to as the Zhide Talisman.

The Yin branch belongs to wood and corresponds to the Mengchun month; the Ren Yin year sees the arrival of the wood fortune. The Si branch belongs to fire and corresponds to the Mengxia month; the Gui Si year sees the arrival of the fire fortune. The Shen branch belongs to metal and corresponds to the Mengqiu month; the Geng Shen year sees the arrival of the metal fortune. The Hai branch belongs to water and corresponds to the Mengdong month; the Xin Hai year sees the arrival of the water fortune. In the sixty-year cycle, there are these four years of the Zhide Talisman. The fortune pairing with the intersecting days is referred to as the Gande Talisman.

Jia and Ji combine, Yi and Geng combine, Bing and Xin combine, Ding and Ren combine, Wu and Gui combine; encountering these pairs in one year, where Heaven and Earth join in harmony, represents a year of good fortune. Excessive fortunes combined with earthly energy are referred to as the Tongtian Talisman.

In the years Geng Zi and Geng Wu, the fortunes unite under dry metal; in the years Ren Yin and Ren Shen, the fortunes unite under wind wood; in the years Jia Chen and Jia Xu, the fortunes unite under wet earth. Within the sixty years, there are these six years of the Tongtian Talisman. Insufficient fortunes combined with earthly energy are referred to as the Tongsui Meeting.[564p]

　　 【辛丑、辛未年，运临司地寒水；癸卯、癸酉年，运临司地君火；癸巳、癸亥年，运临司地相火。六十年中有此六年同岁会也。】　　大要：阳年先天时化，则己强而以气胜实，主胜客也，故不胜者受邪。阴年后天时化，则己弱而以气休衰，客胜主也，故胜己者来克，被克之后必待时而复也。行复于所胜，则己不可前，故待得时则子当旺，然后子为母复雠也。　　【又云，阳年太过则传所不胜而乘所胜，阴年不及，则所胜妄行而所生受病。假令肝木有余，则时已气盛，反薄肺金而乘其脾土，肝木不及，则土无所畏，遂自妄行，乃凌其肾水，此五行生克之理。盖胜至则复，复已而胜，故无常气而不息，若复而不胜则是生意已伤而有穷尽矣。】　　经曰：亢则害，承乃制，制则生化。外列盛衰，害则败乱，生化大病。　　【亢者，过极而不退也。当退不退，始则灾害及物，终则灾害及己。承，犹随也，以下奉上有防之之义。[565p]

In the years of Xin Chou and Xin Wei, the运 (Yun) of cold water affects the position of the Earth; in the years of Gui Mao and Gui You, the运 (Yun) of ruling fire affects the position of the Earth; in the years of Gui Si and Gui Hai, the运 (Yun) of mutual fire affects the position of the Earth. Among sixty years, these six years have the same significance.

Main Idea: In yang years, the pre-heaven transformation occurs first, resulting in a strong self that overcomes the substantial, which signifies victory over the other, thus the defeated will suffer from evils. In yin years, the post-heaven transformation occurs, leading to a weak self that experiences declining energy, leading to the other overcoming the self, thus the one that prevails over the self arrives to conquer, and after being conquered, must wait for the right time to recover. When recovering from that which has been conquered, the self cannot advance; thus, one must wait until the right time arrives, then the child will flourish, and then the child will restore the cycle.

Furthermore, it states that in excessively yang years, one transgresses that which cannot be defeated and takes control over that which is overcome; in insufficient yin years, the one that prevails acts recklessly and thus suffers the consequences. For example, if liver wood is excessive, it signifies strong qi at that time, which weakens lung metal while dominating spleen earth; if liver wood is insufficient, earth has nothing to fear, thus acting recklessly and dominating kidney water, illustrating the principle of generation and overcoming in the five elements. Therefore, when victory reaches, recovery occurs; after recovery, the victory happens, which leads to irregular qi that does not cease. If one recovers but does not prevail, it means the vital essence has been harmed and there is an end to it.

The classic states: Excess leads to harm; reception leads to control; control leads to transformation. Externally, the rise and fall is listed; harm leads to disorder, and transformation leads to major diseases.

Excess is to go beyond the limit and not retreat. Failing to retreat when one should, initially brings disaster to others, and ultimately brings disaster upon oneself. Reception implies following; serving below while protecting above carries the meaning of defense.[565p]

制，克胜之也，制则生化者，言有所制，则六气不至于亢而为平，平则万物生而变化无穷矣。生者自无而有，化者自有而无。外列盛衰者，六气分布主治，迭为盛衰，害而无所制，则败坏乖乱之政行，为灾为变，生化几乎息而为万物之大病。大病，即灾变也。万物皆病，天地其能位乎？此亢害承制，皆莫或使然，而自不能不然者也。以天时言之，春时冬令不退，即水亢极而害所承之木，然火为木之子，由是乘土而制水，则木得化生之令，而敷荣列秀于外。[566p]

Control masters victory; through control, transformation occurs. When there is governance, the six energies do not become excessive, leading to balance. In balance, all things arise and undergo endless changes. The act of being originates from non-being, while transformation arises from being but can lead to non-being. The external display of prosperity and decline is governed by the distribution of the six energies, which alternate between abundance and scarcity. If there is harm without governance, it will result in the collapse and disorder of governance, causing disaster and transformation, leading to the great calamity of all things. This great calamity refers to disasters and changes. When all things are afflicted, can heaven and earth still maintain their positions? This excessive harm stems from control, which is unavoidable and inevitable. Taking the timing of heaven into account, if spring does not yield to the winter's decree, then water becomes excessively dominant, harming the wood it supports. However, fire, being the child of wood, then utilizes earth to control water, allowing wood to receive the mandate of transformation and display its beauty and splendor outwardly.[566p]

但草木虫育，自有各年盛衰不同，苟无制而木被其害，则冬入于春，生化几息，而为天地间之灾变，岂非政令败乱之极乎？以人身言之，心火亢甚，口干发燥，身热，则脾土失养，肺金受害，由是水乘而起，以复金母之雠而制心火，汗出发润口津身凉而平矣。苟肾水愈微而不能上制，心火愈胜而不能下退，则神去气孤而灾害至也。】　　又曰：有余而往，不足随之；不足而住，有余从之。知迎知随，气可与期。　　 【言六甲有余已则不足，不足已则有余。若余已复余，少已复少，则天地之道变矣。】　　又曰：出入废则神机灭，升降息则气立孤危。[567p]

However, plants and insects have their own cycles of growth and decline each year. If there is no regulation and the trees suffer harm, then winter will enter spring prematurely, causing life to wither and resulting in disasters between heaven and earth. Could this not be the utmost chaos of governance? Speaking in terms of the human body, when the heart fire is excessive, the mouth becomes dry and parched, and the body overheats. Consequently, the spleen loses nourishment, the lung suffers damage from the metal element, and from this, water rises to counter the fire of the heart. Sweating releases moisture, cooling the mouth and body, bringing balance. If the kidney water is too weak to ascend and regulate, and the heart fire is too strong to descend, then spirit departs, qi becomes solitary, and disasters ensue.

Furthermore, it is said: When there is surplus, it should not be squandered; when there is deficiency, one should remain steady. Knowing when to welcome and when to follow, qi can be anticipated.

This expresses that when there is surplus, there will subsequently be deficiency; when there is deficiency, there will subsequently be surplus. If surplus follows surplus and scarcity follows scarcity, then the principles of heaven and earth are altered.

Again, it is said: When the entering and exiting are neglected, the spirit’s mechanisms are extinguished; when ascension and descent cease, the qi becomes isolated and precarious.[567p]

故非出入则无以生长壮老已，非升降则无以生长化收藏。是以升降出入，无器不有。四者常守，反之则灾害至。　　【出入者，天地之呼吸也。升降者，天地之化气也。毛羽倮鳞介及飞走蚑行者，皆生气根于身中，以神为动静之主，故曰神机。金玉土石草木，皆生气根于外，假气以成立，故曰气立。根于中者，生源系天，其所动浮，皆神气为机发之主，故其所为也，物莫之知，是以神舍去则机息。[568p]

Therefore, without entrance and exit, there would be no growth, aging, and death; without rising and falling, there would be no development, transformation, and storage. Thus, rising and falling, entrance and exit, are present in all things. If these four are not maintained, disaster will come.

Entrance and exit are the breathing of heaven and earth. Rising and falling are the transformative energies of heaven and earth. Beasts with fur and feathers, and creatures that fly or crawl, all derive their life force from within, with the spirit acting as the master of movement and stillness—hence it is called the spirit mechanism. Gold, jade, earth, stones, plants, and trees all derive their life force from the external, depending on atmosphere to establish themselves—thus it is called the establishment of atmosphere. Those that originate within are rooted in the heavens, and all their movements are driven by the spirit energy as the master of mechanism. What they do is unknown to all beings; therefore, when the spirit departs, the mechanism rests.[568p]

根于外者，生源系地，故其生长化成收藏皆造化之气所成立，故其所出也，物亦莫知，是以气止息则造化之道绝矣。九窍横者，皆有出入去来之气。窍竖者，皆有阴阳升降之气。往复于中，壁窗户牖，皆承来气冲击于人，阳升则井寒，阴升则井暖，以物投井，及叶坠空中，翻翻不疾，皆阴气所凝也。虚管溉满，捻土悬之，水固不出，为无升气而不能降也。空瓶小口，顿溉不入，为气不出，故不能入也。由是观之，升无所不降，降无所不升，无出则不入，无入则不出，群品之生，升降出入，生气之常也。[569p]

Those that are rooted in the external world are dependent on the earth for their birth and growth. Thus, their processes of growth, transformation, and storage all arise from the vital essence of nature. Therefore, what emerges from them is unknown to all beings. When the vital essence ceases, the path of creation is cut off. The nine orifices that are horizontal all possess the air of entry and exit. The vertical orifices have the air of yin and yang, rising and falling. The interactions within, along with walls, windows, and openings, all receive the incoming air that strikes us. When yang rises, the well is cold; when yin rises, the well is warm. When objects are thrown into the well and leaves fall from above, tumbling without haste, this is all due to the condensation of yin energy.

The hollow tube holds water completely; if earth is suspended, the water cannot flow out because there is no rising air to facilitate descent. A small-mouthed empty bottle, when poured into suddenly, does not allow liquid in, because the air cannot escape—so it cannot enter. From this, we observe that rise contains no limit to descent, and descent contains no limit to rise. Without exiting, there is no entering; without entering, there is no exiting. The birth of all things involves the cycles of rising, falling, entering, and exiting—this is the constant principle of vital energy.[569p]

若有出无入，有入无出，有升无降，有降无升，则反生化之常道，而神去气孤，非灾害而何？】　　虽然，逆顺灾眚，尽皆天之气运所为也。地在人之下，大气举之也。天六动而不息，地五静而有守。　　 【天以六气临地，地以五位承天，然天气不加君火，以六加五，则五岁而余一气，乃君火不宜岁气，但以名奉天耳。故曰君火以名，相火以位，言相火代君火而用事，故五岁而右迁。若地以五承六，则当六岁乃备尽天元之气，故六期而循环，周而复始。[570p]

If there is exit without entry, entry without exit, ascent without descent, and descent without ascent, then it contradicts the constant way of transformation, and the spirit departs while the energy is solitary—what could this be but disaster? However, both reversals and smoothness, all are manifestations of celestial energy. The earth is below man, upheld by the great atmosphere. Heaven moves six times and does not rest, while the earth is stable in its five positions.

Heaven uses six energies to influence the earth, and the earth, with its five positions, receives heaven. Yet, if the heavenly fire does not augment the lord’s fire, adding six to five results in one excess energy after five years; hence the lord’s fire is not suitable for seasonal energy but is merely a designation following heaven. Therefore, it is said that the lord's fire is based on name, while the fiery energy is based on position; this means that the fiery energy replaces the lord's fire in function, leading to its migration after five years. If the earth supports six with five, then after six years the celestial source energy is fully prepared, thus completing six cycles, repeating and renewing continuously.[570p]

五岁一周，则五行之气遍，六期一备，则六气之位周，五六相合，故三十年一纪之则六十年矣。】　　推之历日，依节交气，常为每岁之主气，又曰地气。若司天在泉左右两间，轮行而居主气之上者，曰天气，客气也。客气乃行岁中天命，主气祗奉客气之天而已。客胜主则从，主胜客则逆，二者有胜而无复矣。　　 【主胜则泻主补客，客胜则泻客补主也。】　　经曰：先立其年，以明其气。每年先立运气，审其太过不及，然后以地之主气为本，天之客气加临于上为标，以求六化之变。如气之胜也，微者随之，甚者制之。[571p]

At five years, the energies of the five elements circulate; at six years, the positions of the six energies complete their cycle. The combination of five and six means that at thirty years, a cycle begins, resulting in sixty years. By examining the calendar days and the transformation of seasons, each year is governed by a dominant energy, referred to as the earth energy. If the heavenly officer is positioned between the springs on either side, moving and residing above the dominant energy, it is called the heavenly energy, which is secondary. The secondary energy follows the heavenly decree throughout the year, while the dominant energy merely serves the secondary energy. If the secondary energy prevails, one follows; if the dominant energy prevails, one resists. There can be a victory of one over the other, but no return.

When the dominant prevails, it diminishes the dominant energy and replenishes the secondary; when the secondary prevails, it diminishes the secondary and replenishes the dominant. The classics state: First, establish the year to clarify its energy. Each year, establish the movement of energies, examine their excesses and deficiencies, then use the dominant energy of the earth as the foundation, while the incoming heavenly energy serves as the marker, in pursuit of the six transformations. As the energies fluctuate, the subtle follows, and the intense is constrained.[571p]

气之复也，和者平之，暴者夺之。皆随胜气安其屈伏，以平为期。抑考褚氏有曰：大挠作甲子，隶首作数，志岁月日时远近。故以当年为甲子岁，冬至为甲子月，朔为甲子日，夜半为甲子时，积一十百千万，亦有条而不紊，皆人所为也。人婴异气，疾难预拟，吾未见其是也。吁！此一偏之见也。不知天时非凡夫可度，人身资大化有生。明堂诗曰：甲胆乙肝丙小肠，丁心戊胃己脾乡。庚属大肠辛属肺，壬属膀胱癸肾藏。三焦亦向壬宫寄，胞络同归入癸方。　　【诗言人秉天地壬之气而生膀胱命门，秉癸之气而生肾，秉甲之气而生胆，秉乙之气而生肝，秉丙之气而生小肠，秉丁之气而生心，秉戊之气而生胃，秉己之气而生脾，秉庚之气而生大肠，秉辛之气而生肺。此天干也，地支亦然。】　　又云：肺寅大卯胃辰经，脾巳心午小未中。申膀酉肾心胞戌，亥三子胆丑肝通。观此二诗，则天地人身，无时不相流通。[572p]

The restoration of qi involves harmonizing what is passive and grasping what is aggressive. Each follows the victorious qi to find its balance, aiming for equilibrium. Moreover, examining the teachings of the Zhu family, it is said that the Great Disturbance generates the Jiazi, and the initiated heads operate by numerical principles, marking the distance of time and seasons. Therefore, the current year is identified as the Jiazi year, the Winter Solstice is the Jiazi month, the New Moon is the Jiazi day, and midnight marks the Jiazi hour. Accumulating ten, a hundred, a thousand, and so forth, all is orderly and coherent, representing human effort. Humans are born into different qi, and their ailments are difficult to predict; I have yet to witness it as true. Alas! This is a biased viewpoint. One does not understand that the timing of heaven is not something an ordinary person can measure; the human body is endowed with tremendous transformation and life.

The Ming Tang poem states: "Jia generates the gallbladder, Yi generates the liver, Bing generates the small intestine, Ding generates the heart, Wu generates the stomach, Ji generates the spleen, Geng belongs to the large intestine, Xin belongs to the lungs, Ren belongs to the bladder, and Gui belongs to the kidneys." The San Jiao also returns to the palace of Ren, and the channels converge in the area of Gui. [The poem indicates that humans embody the heavenly qi of Ren to give birth to the bladder at the gateway of life, embody the qi of Gui to produce the kidneys, embody the qi of Jia to produce the gallbladder, embody the qi of Yi to produce the liver, embody the qi of Bing to generate the small intestine, embody the qi of Ding to produce the heart, embody the qi of Wu to generate the stomach, embody the qi of Ji to produce the spleen, embody the qi of Geng to produce the large intestine, and embody the qi of Xin to produce the lungs. This applies to the heavenly stems as well as the earthly branches.]

Furthermore: "Lungs correspond to Yin, Stomach to Chen, Spleen to Si, Heart to Wu, Small Intestine to Wei. Shen corresponds to the bladder, You to the kidneys, and Xun to the heart and channels of Xu, while Hai corresponds to the three Zi, Gallbladder to Chou, Liver to Tong." Observing these two poems, it becomes evident that the interaction among heaven, earth, and the human body is ceaseless.[572p]

　　【经曰：天气通于肺，地气通于嗌，风气通于肝，雷气通于心，谷气通于脾，雨气通于肾，六经为川，肠胃为海，九窍为水，注之气也。】　　故一气不合，不能生化。天有六气，人以三阴阳而上奉之。　　 【以六经言之，则三阴三阳，以十二支分之，则有六阴六阳，阴从上降，生于午而极于亥，谓之六阴。阳从下起，生于子而极于巳，谓之六阳。】　　地有五行，人以五脏腑而下应之。脏为阴，而其数奇，以应五运，盖五行质具于地，而气则行于天也。[573p]

The scripture states: "Heavenly energy connects with the lungs, earthly energy connects with the throat, windy energy connects with the liver, thunderous energy connects with the heart, grain energy connects with the spleen, and rainy energy connects with the kidneys. The six channels form rivers, and the intestines and stomach form the sea; the nine orifices are water, infusing energy." Therefore, if even one energy is not in harmony, creation and transformation cannot occur. Heaven has six energies, and humans respond to them with three yin and three yang.

Speaking in terms of the six channels, there are three yin and three yang. When divided into twelve branches, there are six yin and six yang. Yin descends from above, is born in the afternoon, and reaches its peak at the midnight, termed as six yin. Yang arises from below, is born at the rat hour, and peaks at the snake hour, termed as six yang.

The earth has five elements, and humans respond to them with the five viscera and bowels. The viscera are yin, while their numbers are odd, corresponding to the five movements. The qualities of the five elements exist in the earth, while their energies move in the heavens.[573p]

腑为阳，而其数偶，以应六气，盖六淫虽降于天，而势必充于地也。子午为天地之中正，君火位焉，手少阴心午居之，足少阴肾子居之。辰戌为七政之魁罡，寒水位焉，　　 【太阳寒水有子位而居于辰戌者，水伏于土，而水由地中行，故戌为六戊天门，辰为六己地户。】　　手太阳小肠戌居之，足太阳膀胱辰居之。然火从水化，水随肾至，故少阴为脏位，与太阳隔而气相合为腑也。丑未为归藏之标本，湿土位焉，足太阴脾未居之，手太阴肺丑居之。卯酉为日月之道路，燥金位焉，足阳明胃酉居之，手阳明大肠卯居之。然子随母居，土旺金盛，故太阴为脏位，与阳明隔而气相合为腑也。[574p]

The organs are yang, and their numbers are even, corresponding to the six energies. Though the six climatic pathogens descend from the heavens, they must inevitably fill the earth. Zi and Wu represent the center and uprightness of heaven and earth, with fire occupying its position. The Hand Shaoyin Heart resides at Wu, and the Foot Shaoyin Kidney is at Zi. Chen and Xu lead the seven governing powers, with cold water in their place.

【The cold water of Taiyang, having Zi's position at Chen and Xu, signifies that water lies hidden beneath the earth, thus Xu serves as the Six Wu heavenly gate, while Chen is the Six Ji earthly door.】 The Hand Taiyang Small Intestine is positioned at Xu, and the Foot Taiyang Bladder is at Chen. Hence, fire is transformed from water, and water follows the kidney; thus, Shaoyin occupies the organ position, integrating with Taiyang through the interaction of qi to form the fu (hollow organs).

Chou and Wei represent the prototype of storage, with damp earth in their place. The Foot Taiyin Spleen is at Wei, and the Hand Taiyin Lung is at Chou. Mao and You are the pathways of the sun and moon, with dry metal in their place. The Foot Yangming Stomach is at You, and the Hand Yangming Large Intestine is at Mao. Therefore, Zi follows its mother; with strong earth and flourishing metal, Taiyin occupies the organ position, integrating with Yangming through the interaction of qi to form the fu.[574p]

巳亥为天地之门户，风木位焉，　　 【卯虽木之正分，为阳明燥金所居，然木生在亥，故居于亥而对化于巳也。】　　足厥阴肝亥居之，手厥阴心胞络巳居之。寅申握生化之始终，相火位焉，　　 【少阳相火佐脾，虽有午位，君火居之，故居寅，火生于寅也。】　　足少阳胆寅居之，手少阳三焦申居之。然相火寄于肝肾，胆者肝之腑，心胞络者肾之配，故厥阴为脏位，与少阳隔而气相合为腑也。　　 【三阴三阳，名异而体则一也。[575p]

The Si-Wei (Snake-Pig) is the gateway of Heaven and Earth, where the Wood of the Wind is positioned. Although the Yin-Mao (Rabbit) is the proper division of Wood and is inhabited by the Yangming Dry Metal, Wood is generated in the Pig, hence it resides in the Pig and transforms in correspondence with the Si.

The Foot Jueyin (Liver) is located in the Pig, while the Hand Jueyin (Heart) resides in the Si. The Yin-Yang (Tiger-Monkey) holds the beginning and end of transformation, where the Fire of the Yin-Yang is situated. Although there is a position in the Wu (Horse) for the Yang Fire, this Fire ultimately resides in the Yin, for Fire is generated in the Yin.

The Foot Shaoyang (Gallbladder) is located in the Yin, and the Hand Shaoyang (San Jiao) resides in the Monkey. However, the Fire of transformation is hosted in the Liver and Kidney. The Gallbladder is the organ of the Liver, while the Heart's network corresponds with the Kidney, thus the Jueyin denotes the position of the organs, and the Shaoyang is separate but harmonizes with the Qi to form the bodily cavities.

The three Yin and three Yang, while named differently, are fundamentally one in essence.[575p]

阴阳气微，则谓之少；阴阳气盛，则谓之太。寅为少阳，卯为阳明，辰为太阳，午为少阴，未为太　阴，亥为厥阴。】　　南政三阴司天，则皆寸不应；三阴在泉，则皆尺不应。北政三阴司天，则皆尺不应；三阴在泉，则皆寸不应。不应者，皆为沉脉也。　　 【此言六气以君火为尊，五运以湿土为重，故甲己土运为南政，盖土以成数，贯金木水火之运位，土居中央，君尊南面而行令，余四运以臣事之，北面而受令所以有别也。然此论其常也。若天行时病，则有不必拘者。[576p]

When the yin and yang energies are weak, it is called "less"; when they are strong, it is called "greater." Yin represents less yang, while the different phases are: Yin (寅) for less yang, Mao (卯) for pure yang, Chen (辰) for great yang, Wu (午) for less yin, Wei (未) for great yin, and Hai (亥) for extreme yin.

In the Southern governance, when the three yin dominate the sky, nothing responds at the inch level; when the three yin are in the spring, nothing responds at the foot level. In the Northern governance, when the three yin dominate the sky, nothing responds at the foot level; when the three yin are in the spring, nothing responds at the inch level. The lack of response is identified as a sinking pulse.

This indicates that among the six energies, the ruler is represented by fire, and among the five movements, damp earth is considered significant. Thus, the Earth movement of Jia and Ji is associated with the Southern governance, as earth constitutes the foundation, integrating the movements of metal, wood, water, and fire. Earth occupies the center, ruling from the south and issuing commands, while the other four movements serve as ministers from the north in a manner that delineates their difference. However, this pertains to the regular case. If there are seasonal illnesses from celestial movements, then not everything must strictly conform.[576p]

经曰：天地之气，胜复之作，不形于诊也。天地以气不以位，故不当以脉诊，但以形证察之。】　　由此观之，经络脏腑，脉病药治，无非运气之所为也。非只一岁也，虽一时一刻之短，而五行之气莫不存。非特一物也，虽一毫一芒之细，而五行之化莫不载。上达于天，则有五星倍减之应；下推于地，则有草木虫育之验。奈何俗医不知医之源者，全然不识运气为何物；不知医之变者，又泥时日，执钤方以害人。要之：有在天之运气，有在人之运气。[577p]

The classics say: "The vital energy of heaven and earth is the source of all transformations, but it does not manifest in diagnosis. Heaven and earth operate through energy, not through positions; thus, one should not diagnose according to meridians, but rather observe through physical symptoms." From this perspective, the channels and organs, pulse diseases, and medicinal treatments all stem from the movement of vital energy. It is not confined to just one year; even in a fleeting moment, the energies of the Five Elements are ever-present. It is not limited to a single object; even in the tiniest detail, the transformations of the Five Elements are contained. When observed in the heavens, there are responses corresponding to the five stars’ patterns; when observed on the earth, there are evidences in the growth of plants and insects. How unfortunate it is that common physicians, unaware of the source of medicine, do not recognize what vital energy truly is; they lack understanding of the changes in medicine and cling to rigid prescriptions that harm people. In summary: There is the celestial vital energy, and there is the vital energy within humanity.[577p]

天时胜则舍人之病而从天之时，人病胜则舍天之时而从人之病。张子曰：病如不是当年气，看与何年运气同，只向某年求活法，方知都在至真中。扁鹊曰：阴淫寒疾，即太阳寒水之令太过；阳淫热疾，相火之令太过；风淫未疾，木令太过；雨淫腹疾，湿令太过；晦淫惑疾，燥令太过，久晴不雨，当为疫厉风痹；明淫心疾，君火初令太过。经曰：必先岁气，勿伐天和。又曰：不知年之所加，气之盛衰，不可以为工。学者合而观之，更精于脉证，乃自得之。噫！儒之道博约而已矣，医之道运气而已矣。学者可不由此入门，而求其蕴奥耶？[578p]

When the heavenly timing prevails, one abandons the afflictions of humanity and follows the way of heaven; when human ailments dominate, one relinquishes the heavenly timing to attend to human sickness. Zhang Zi said: If an illness does not align with the seasonal influences of that year, why consider it in relation to any other year's influences? Only by seeking the method of survival in a certain year can one truly understand the essence of truth. Bian Que said: Cold ailments arise from the excess of yin energies; warm ailments result from the excess of yang fire; ailments from wind are due to excess of wood influences; damp ailments stem from excess moisture; ailments from obscurity and confusion arise from excess dryness; prolonged clear weather without rain may lead to epidemics; heart ailments are caused by an excessive initial activation of the ruling fire. The classics state: One must first consider the yearly influences; do not disturb the harmony of heaven. It also says: Not understanding the impact of the year and the fluctuations of seasonal energies, one cannot pursue mastery. Scholars should combine their observations, refine their understanding of pulse diagnoses, and thus attain their own insights. Ah! The path of Confucianism is broad and succinct, while the path of medicine is rooted in the dynamics of energy. Can scholars not enter through this door and seek its profound essence?[578p]

古今图书集成医部全录卷一百二十

运气门

　　　　运气易览 【明　汪机】

　　　　　学五运六气纲领

　　或问：五运六气，《内经》讲论，诸方所略，其理奥妙，未易造入，愿发明焉。丹溪曰：学医之初，宜须先识病机之变化，论人形而处治。若便攻于运气，恐流于马宗素之徒，而云某年生人，某日病于某经，用某药治之之类也。　　或问：人之五脏六腑，外应天地，司气司运，八风动静之变，人气应焉，岂不切当？苟不知此为医，未造其理，何以调之？曰：杨太受亦如此说。[579p]

The Complete Collection of Books from Ancient and Modern Times, Volume 120: On the Mechanisms of Qi

On the Mechanisms of Qi for Easy Reference [Ming Dynasty, Wang Ji]

The Outline of the Five Movements and Six Qis

Someone asked: The Five Movements and Six Qis are discussed in the "Neijing," but various schools gloss over them. The principles are profound and not easily comprehensible; I wish for them to be elucidated. Danxi said: When beginning to study medicine, one must first understand the variations in disease mechanisms, discuss the human body, and assess treatments. If one hastily focuses on Qi movements, they might end up like the followers of Ma Zongsu, speaking of people born in certain years, becoming ill on certain days, and treating them with specific medicines. Someone further inquired: The five organs and six viscera in humans correspond to the heavens and the earth, governing Qi and movements, reacting to the changes of the eight winds. Isn't this quite relevant? If one does not understand this, how can they practice medicine without grasping the principles of regulation? The answer is that Yang Taishou also mentioned this.[579p]
